ams.description: Course Description: Intensive reading, writing, and special projects. Interdisciplinary group study of special topics in American Culture Studies, designed for non-majors as well as majors.

ams.name: — Special Topics: American Lives Through Autobiography
ams.description: Course Description: Intensive reading, writing, and special projects. Interdisciplinary group study of special topics in American Culture Studies, designed for non-majors as well as majors.

ams.name: — Special Topics: Interrelationship Between Arts & Ideas
ams.description: Course Description: Intensive reading, writing, and special projects. Interdisciplinary group study of special topics in American Culture Studies, designed for non-majors as well as majors.

ams.name: — Special Topics: New Directions in American Culture Studies
ams.description: Course Description: Intensive reading, writing, and special projects. Interdisciplinary group study of special topics in American Culture Studies, designed for non-majors as well as majors.

ams.name: — Special Topics: Problems in Cross-Cultural American Studies
ams.description: Course Description: Intensive reading, writing, and special projects. Interdisciplinary group study of special topics in American Culture Studies, designed for non-majors as well as majors.

ams.name: — A Decade in American Civilization
ams.description: Course Description: Close examination of a single decade in American civilization; the connections between the history, literature, arts, customs, and ideas of Americans living in the decade. Issues and representations of race, class, gender, age, and sexuality in the decade.

ams.name: — Corporate Cultures
ams.description: Course Description: Exploration of the small group cultures of American corporate workplaces, including the role of environment, stories, jokes, rituals, ceremonies, personal style, and play. The effects of cultural diversity upon corporate cultures, both from within and in contact with foreign corporations.

ams.name: — American Popular Culture
ams.description: Course Description: American popular expression and experience as a cultural system, and the relationship between this system and elite and folk cultures. Exploration of theories and methods for discovering and interpreting patterns of meaning in American popular culture.

ams.name: — Feminist Cultural Studies
ams.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Histories, theories, and practices of feminist traditions within cultural studies.

ams.name: — Interdisciplinary Approaches to Environmental Justice/Injustice
ams.description: Course Description: Environmental justice through interdisciplinary lenses. Frameworks that analyze environmental issues through the lens of social justice and human inequality, specifically categories of race, class, gender, nature and nation. Particular focus on California and the Central Valley.

ams.name: — American Landscapes & Places
ams.description: Course Description: Comparative study of several American cultural populations inhabiting a region, including their relationship to a shared biological, physical, and social environment, their intercultural relations, and their relationships to the dominant American popular and elite culture and folk traditions.

ams.name: — The Lives of Children in America
ams.description: Course Description: Experience of childhood and adolescence in American culture, as understood through historical, literary, artistic, and social scientific approaches.

ams.name: — The Individual & Community in America
ams.description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary examination of past and present tensions between the individual and the community in American experience, as those tensions are expressed in such cultural systems as folklore, public ritual, popular entertainment, literature, fine arts, architecture, and social thought.

ams.name: — The Lives of Men in America
ams.description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary examination of the lives of boys and men in America, toward understanding cultural definitions of masculinity, the ways individuals have accepted or resisted these definitions, and the broader consequences of the struggle over the social construction of gender.

ams.name: — Eating in America
ams.description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary examination of the culture of food in America. Exploration of eating as a richly symbolic event integral to how Americans express and negotiate values, politics and identity.

ams.name: — Race, Culture & Society in the United States
ams.description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary examination of the significance of race in the making of America; how race shapes culture, identities and social processes in the United States; the interweaving of race with gender, class and nationhood in self and community.

ams.name: — Animals in American Culture
ams.description: Course Description: Animals as symbols in American thought, as found in folklore, popular culture, literature, and art; customs and stories around human-animal interactions, including hunting, religion, foodways, pets, zoos, circuses, rodeos, theme parks, and scientific research on animals.

ams.name: — Technology & the Modern American Body
ams.description: Course Description: History and analysis of relationships between human bodies and technologies in modern society. Dominant and eccentric examples of how human bodies and technologies influence one another and reveal underlying cultural assumptions.

ams.name: — Undergraduate Seminar in American Studies
ams.description: Course Description: Intensive reading, discussion, research, and writing by small groups in selected topics of American Studies scholarship; emphasis on theory and its application to American material.

ams.name: — Senior Thesis Research Seminar
ams.description: Course Description: Research and prospectus writing for senior thesis.

ams.name: — Senior Thesis
ams.description: Course Description: In consultation with advisor, student writes an extended research paper on a topic proposed in AMS 190A.

ams.name: — Internship in American Studies
ams.description: Course Description: Supervised internship and study in social & community organizations, schools, cultural institutions (e.g., libraries, museums, and archives), or other work sites. Final written report and other assignments as per contract with supervisor.
ams.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; enrollment dependent on availability of intern positions, with priority to American Studies majors.

ams.name: — Tutoring in American Studies
ams.description: Course Description: Tutoring in lower division American Studies courses, usually in small discussion groups. Periodic meetings with the instructor in charge; reports and readings.
ams.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of Chairperson of American Studies Program.

ams.name: — Directed Group Study
ams.description: Course Description: Directed group study.

ams.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
ams.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
ams.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor and chairperson of American Studies Program.

ams.name: — American Folklore & Folklife
ams.description: Course Description: Theory and methods for the study of the folklore and the folk customary behavior of Americans; contributions of folklore studies to scholarship in humanities and social science disciplines.
ams.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

ams.name: — Cultural Study of Masculinities
ams.description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary approaches to understanding the social and cultural construction of masculinities; attention to the effects of biology, gender, race, class, sexual and national identities; criticism of oral, printed, visual, and mass mediated texts, and of sicial relations and structure.
ams.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

ams.name: — Food in American Culture
ams.description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary theories and methods for the study of food in American culture; food studies in relation to issues of identity (age, gender, ethnicity, religion, region, etc.), social relations, systems of production, and cultures of consumption.
ams.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

ams.name: — Group Study
ams.description: Course Description: Group study.

ams.name: — Individual Study
ams.description: Course Description: Individual study.

ams.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
ams.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.

apc.name: — Internship
apc.description: Course Description: Internship experience off and on campus in all subject areas offered in the Department of Anatomy, Physiology & Cell Biology. Internships are supervised by a member of the faculty.
apc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

apc.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
apc.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.

apc.name: — Comparative Vertebrate Organology
apc.description: Course Description: Functional anatomy of major organ systems in vertebrates. Each system examined from cellular to gross level in fish, birds, and mammals. Emphasis on how differentiated cell types are integrated into tissues and organs to perform diverse physiological functions.

apc.name: — Internship
apc.description: Course Description: Internship experience off and on campus in all subject areas offered in the Department of Anatomy, Physiology & Cell Biology. Internships are supervised by a member of the faculty.
apc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; approval of internship.

apc.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
apc.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

apc.name: — Basics of Microscopy & Cellular Imaging
apc.description: Course Description: Practical applications of basic microscope techniques used to image cells and tissues with the goal of using these techniques to generate publication quality images. Principles of light, epifluorescent, confocal and electron microscopy, their applications and limitations.
apc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

apc.name: — Seminar
apc.description: Course Description: Discussion and critical evaluation of advanced topics and current trends in research.

apc.name: — Topics in Biology of Respiratory System
apc.description: Course Description: Topics concerning structure and function of respiratory system. Possible topics include: lung growth, pulmonary reaction to toxicants, pulmonary inflammation, lung metabolism, biology of lung cells, tracheobronchial epithelium, nasal cavity structure and function.
apc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

ane.name: — Internship in Anesthesiology
ane.description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in anesthesia and related fields.
ane.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; approval of project prior to period of internship by preceptor.

ane.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
ane.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

ane.name: — Intro to Anesthesiology & Perioperative Medicine
ane.description: Course Description: Introduction to anesthesiology during the MS3 year, with emphasis on introduction to the field of anesthesiology and the day-to-day practice of an anesthesiologist in the perioperative setting.

ane.name: — Primary Care Multidisciplinary Pain Management
ane.description: Course Description: Rotation will give 3rd year primary-care bound students an overview of the scope of Pain Medicine.

ane.name: — Externship in Anesthesiology
ane.description: Course Description: Away clinical rotation in Anesthesiology or Pain Medicine.

ane.name: — Anesthesiology Clinical Clerkship
ane.description: Course Description: In-depth exposure to anesthesia through informal lectures and mentoring by anesthesiologists. Emphasis on understanding and applying anesthetic principles in managing administration of general, regional, and specialized areas.
ane.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; medical student.

ane.name: — Perioperative Medicine
ane.description: Course Description: Two week rotation provides a broad exposure to various patient care services within the Department of Anesthesiology and Pain Medicine to apply medical knowledge to safely care for patients.
ane.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Successful completion of third-year clerkships; consent of instructor of record.

ane.name: — Perioperative Management of the Obstetric Patient
ane.description: Course Description: Perioperative Management of Obstetric Patient advanced clinical clerkship will offer the medical student the chance to understand and be able to apply the principles of basic science into major improvements in obstetric anesthesia patient care.

ane.name: — Multidisciplinary Pain Management
ane.description: Course Description: Senior clerkship to expose students to all facets of treating pain in all aspects of clinical care: outpatient and inpatient settings, acute and chronic pain, end of life issues, pediatrics, rehabilitation, etc. Daily clinics, rounds, and lectures.
ane.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Senior medical student in good standing.

ane.name: — Multidisciplinary Approach to the Neurosurgical Patient
ane.description: Course Description: Participate in the perioperative care of patients undergoing neurosurgical procedures while under the supervision of anesthesia, neurology and neurosurgical ICU residents and attending physicians.

ane.name: — Away Acting Internship in Anesthesiology
ane.description: Course Description: Work at the level of a sub intern in Inpatient and/or Outpatient settings. Expectation is to provide direct patient management.
ane.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; satisfactory completion of Anesthesiology Clerkship.

ane.name: — Brief Introduction to Clinical Anesthesiology & Chronic Pain Management
ane.description: Course Description: Daily experience in clinical anesthesiology at the preoperative screening unit, operating room, post anesthesia care unit, chronic pain management clinic with daily clinical correlation case discussions, and one-on-one interaction with faculty anesthesiologists.

ane.name: — A Pain in the Neck: Assessment & Management of Spinal Pain
ane.description: Course Description: Designed to assess and treat spinal pain. Reviews the pathophysiology, clinical assessment, and management of: lumbar spinal pain, cervical spinal pain, differential diagnosis & differentiation between sacroiliac/hip/shoulder joint pain, medication management with risk assessment, and non-pharmacological treatments including interventional pain procedures, acupuncture, and psychological support.

ane.name: — Applied Physiology & Pharmacology
ane.description: Course Description: Review and demonstrate the application of basic physiology and pharmacology to patient care. There will be an in-depth analysis of the physiology and pharmacology of the cardiovascular, pulmonary, nervous, renal and endocrine systems.

ane.name: — Interdisciplinary Medicine in Pain Care
ane.description: Course Description: Integrate applied and practical neuroanatomy, physiology, pharmacology, psychology/psychiatry and social medicine in the care of patients who are receiving care for pain caused by acute or chronic medical disease or trauma.

ane.name: — Applied Physiology & Pharmacology
ane.description: Course Description: Review and demonstrate the application of basic physiology and pharmacology to patient care. In-depth analysis of the physiology and pharmacology of the cardiovascular, pulmonary, nervous, renal and endocrine systems.

ane.name: — Individual or Group Study
ane.description: Course Description: Directed reading and discussion and/or laboratory investigation on selected topics.
ane.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Interns and residents with consent of instructor.

ane.name: — Anesthesiology Research
ane.description: Course Description: Problems in clinical and/or laboratory research.
ane.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Third- or fourth-year medical students, advanced standing undergraduate and veterinary medicine students; or consent of instructor.

anb.name: — Scientific Approaches to Animal Behavior Research
anb.description: Course Description: Philosophical issues, goals, strategies and tools in field and laboratory research.

anb.name: — History of Animal Behavior
anb.description: Course Description: Classic, seminal papers in animal behavior. Discussion of readings and broader historical context in which papers were written.

anb.name: — Fundamentals of Animal Behavior
anb.description: Course Description: Survey of the phenomena and theory of animal behavior from the perspectives of multiple biological disciplines, including evolution, ecology, psychology, genetics, neurobiology, endocrinology, and animal science.
anb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division undergraduate introduction to the biology of behavior, such as PSC 101, PSC 122, PSC 123, NPB 102, NPB 150, NPB 152, WFC 141, ENT 104, or ANS 105.

anb.name: — Fundamentals of Animal Behavior
anb.description: Course Description: Survey of the phenomena and theory of animal behavior from the perspectives of multiple biological disciplines, including evolution, ecology, psychology, genetics, neurobiology, endocrinology, and animal science.
anb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ANB 218A or PSC 218A; or ECL 218A; consent of instructor.

anb.name: — Animal Behavior, Ecology & Evolution
anb.description: Course Description: Interface between animal behavior, ecology and evolution. New developments in behavioral ecology development and testing of hypotheses in this discipline.
anb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 102; EVE 100; EVE 101; and consent of instructor, or the equivalent; graduate standing.

anb.name: — Interdisciplinary Approaches to Animal Behavior
anb.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Analysis of literature in behavior and an allied discipline or disciplines that offer the potential, in combination, to advance the understanding of a topic in animal behavior conceptually and empirically. Topics vary from year to year.

anb.name: — Interdisciplinary Approaches to Animal Behavior
anb.description: Course Description: Development of an empirical or theoretical interdisciplinary approach to research on a current topic in animal behavior.
anb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ANB 230A; taken the previous quarter.

anb.name: — Research Conference in Behavioral Ecology
anb.description: Course Description: Critical presentation and evaluation of current literature and ongoing research in behavioral ecology.
anb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

anb.name: — Advanced Animal Behavior
anb.description: Course Description: Reading, reports and discussion on current topics in animal behavior, with a focus on topics that lie at the interface between animal behavior, ecology and evolution.
anb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 102; (EVE 100 or EVE 101); and consent of instructor, or the equivalents; graduate standing.

anb.name: — Seminar in Animal Behavior
anb.description: Course Description: Selected topics in animal behavior.

anb.name: — Seminar in Behavioral Ecology of Predators & Prey
anb.description: Course Description: Presentation and analysis of research papers on social and foraging behavior of predatory animals, antipredator strategies of prey species, co-evolution of predators and prey, and ecology of predator prey interactions.

anb.name: — Group Study
anb.description: Course Description: Lectures and/or discussion of current issues, problems, or techniques in animal behavior.
anb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

anb.name: — Research
anb.description: Course Description: Advanced research in one of the specialty areas in animal behavior.

anb.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
anb.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.

abi.name: — Animal Biology Laboratory
abi.description: Course Description: Scientific methods for answering questions in animal biology by doing exercises to demonstrate hypothesis testing and reporting, short laboratory, population and field experiments. Maintain notebooks, analyze data, interpret results and write reports.

abi.name: — Animal Biology
abi.description: Course Description: Basic biological disciplines important to an understanding of practical animal biology issues including the evolution of animal groups, genetic mechanisms, animal physiology as it relates to maintenance and production, and aspects of comparative anatomy, behavior and ecology.

abi.name: — Animal Biology
abi.description: Course Description: Animal management and conservation. Societal concerns arising from management and conservation issues, including economics, aesthetics, regulations, safety, public perspectives and advocacy.

abi.name: — Intership in Animal Biology
abi.description: Course Description: Office, laboratory or fieldwork off or on campus in research, governmental regulation, policy making, and private enterprise dealing with animal related issues of production, welfare, pest management, biodiversity and the environment. All requirements of Internship Approval Request form must be met.

abi.name: — Special Study for Undergraduate
abi.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduate.

abi.name: — Animal Biochemistry & Metabolism
abi.description: Course Description: Water and biological buffers; thermodynamics of metabolism; structure and function of biomolecules; enzyme kinetics and function; membrane biology; digestion and absorption; carbohydrate metabolism.
abi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (CHE 002A,  CHE 002B,  CHE 008A,  CHE 008B) or (CHE 118A,  CHE 118B).

abi.name: — Animal Biochemistry & Metabolism
abi.description: Course Description: Physiological function and metabolism of lipids and amino acids; integrative metabolism; biochemical basis for nutrient requirements; structure and function of vitamins; mineral metabolism and requirements.

abi.name: — Animal Biology Seminar
abi.description: Course Description: Seminar leading to development of the Major Proposal for the Animal Biology major.

abi.name: — Senior Practicum
abi.description: Course Description: Practicum may be an experimental research project, a library research project or some other creative activity that will serve as a capstone experience for the Animal Biology major.
abi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ABI 050A; ABI 050B; ABI 050C; ABI 187; Junior standing.

abi.name: — Senior Practicum Discussion
abi.description: Course Description: Helps prevent or solve problems during the students' senior practicum activity.
abi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ABI 050A; ABI 050B; ABI 050C; ABI 187; ABI 189 (can be concurrent); junior standing.

abi.name: — Internship in Animal Biology
abi.description: Course Description: Office, laboratory or fieldwork off or on campus in research, governmental regulations, policy making, and private enterprise dealing with animal related issues of production, welfare, pest management, biodiversity and the environment. All requirements of Intership Approval Request form must be met.
abi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of 84 units.

abi.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduate
abi.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduate.

abg.name: — Integrated Animal Biology I
abg.description: Course Description: Natural history, management, historical and current uses, and specialized disciplinary features of model and novel animal systems used in research. Development of conceptual approaches in organismal biology to improve experimental design and interpretation of interdisciplinary research studies.
abg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101;  or consent of instructor, or equivalent course; graduate standing.

abg.name: — Integrated Animal Biology II
abg.description: Course Description: Natural history, management, historical and current uses, and specialized disciplinary features of model and novel animal systems used in research. Development of conceptual approaches in organismal biology to improve experimental design and interpretation of interdisciplinary research studies.

abg.name: — Grant Procurement & Administration
abg.description: Course Description: Topics include: structure of grants, attention to specifications, concise persuasive writing, and grant budgeting. Identify grant opportunities, write a persuasive research grant proposal, and administer grants.

abg.name: — Advanced Animal Welfare
abg.description: Course Description: Advanced animal welfare. Key concepts used when evaluating and understanding the welfare of animals kept by humans. Topics include animal pain, stress, cognition, motivation and emotions. Critical discussion of primary literature.

abg.name: — Advanced Nutritional Energetics
abg.description: Course Description: History of nutritional energetics. Evaluation of energy transformations associated with food utilization. Energy expenditures at cellular, tissue, and animal levels as affected by diet and physiological state. Current and future feeding systems.
abg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ABI 102,  ABI 103,  NPB 101); or the equivalent courses.

abg.name: — Advances in Animal Biotechnology & Genetics
abg.description: Course Description: Introduction to advanced techniques used for assisted reproductive technologies in mammals and birds, genetic engineering, gene editing, stem cell biology. Offered in alternate years.
abg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 121; BIS 101; or consent of instructor.

abg.name: — Mathematical Modeling in Biological Systems
abg.description: Course Description: Model development and evaluation including sensitivity analyses using R. Four principle modeling methodologies included: algebraic functions of biological processes, physiological-based compartmental models, linear programming and meta-analysis. Fundamental background and understanding of mathematical modeling principles in biological systems.
abg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 016A; MAT 016B; STA 100; or equivalents required; graduate standing; MAT 016C or equivalent recommended; more than one course in statistics recommended; ABI 102 or BIS 102 recommended or equivalent course in biochemistry.

abg.name: — Gastrointestinal Microbiology of Livestock
abg.description: Course Description: Microbiology of the gastrointestinal tract of ruminants and other livestock species; its relation to improving livestock production.

abg.name: — Physiology of the Stress Response
abg.description: Course Description: Definition of Stress; Physiological mechanisms of adaptation to stress; Hormonal control of the systemic stress response; Mechanisms of the cellular stress response; Discussion of current trends in stress physiology and current methods for studying the stress response.

abg.name: — Seminar in Animal Biology
abg.description: Course Description: Seminar on advanced topics in animal biology. Presentations by members of the Animal Biology Graduate Group and guest speakers.

abg.name: — Research Conference
abg.description: Course Description: Student presentations of research in Animal Biology and discussions among participating students and Animal Biology faculty.
abg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

abg.name: — Group Study in Animal Biology
abg.description: Course Description: Group study in Animal Biology.
abg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

abg.name: — Research
abg.description: Course Description: Research with a faculty member in Animal Biology Graduate Group.
abg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

abg.name: — Methods in Teaching Animal Biology
abg.description: Course Description: Practical experience in the methods and problems of teaching animal biology. Includes analysis of laboratory exercises, discussion of teaching techniques, grading scientific essays, preparing for and conducting discussion or laboratory sections, formulating quiz and exam questions under instructor supervision.
abg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

abg.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
abg.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.
abg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

abg.name: — Ethics & Professionalism in Animal Biology
abg.description: Course Description: Case studies and discussion of ethical and professional issues for animal biologists, including the use of animals in research and teaching, patenting and intellectual property, consulting and conflict of interest, scientific integrity, dealing with the media, and mentoring relationships.

ang.name: — Animal Cytogenetics
ang.description: Course Description: Principles and techniques of cytogenetics applied to animal systems; chromosome harvest techniques, analysis of mitosis and meiosis, karyotyping, chromosome banding, cytogenetic mapping, chromosome structure and function, comparative cytogenetics.
ang.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; BIS 102; or equivalent of BIS 102.

ang.name: — Horse Genetics
ang.description: Course Description: Coat color, parentage testing, medical genetics, pedigrees, breeds, the gene map and genus Equus. Emphasis on understanding horse genetics based on the unity of mammalian genetics and making breeding decisions based on fundamental genetic concepts.

ang.name: — Genetics & Animal Breeding
ang.description: Course Description: Principles of quantitative genetics applied to improvement of livestock and poultry. Effects of mating systems and selection methods are emphasized with illustration from current breeding practices.

ang.name: — Molecular Biology Laboratory Techniques
ang.description: Course Description: Introduction to the concepts and techniques used in molecular biology; the role of this technology in both basic and applied animal research, and participation in laboratories using some of the most common techniques in molecular biology.
ang.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002C; BIS 101; (BIS 102 or ABI 102); (BIS 103 or ABI 103).

ang.name: — Science of Captive Breeding & Reintroduction
ang.description: Course Description: Explore peer-reviewed literature surrounding the latest advances in captive breeding and reintroduction biology.

ang.name: — Directed Group Study
ang.description: Course Description: Selected topics relating to animal genetics.

ang.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
ang.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

ang.name: — Theory of Quantitative Genetics
ang.description: Course Description: Theoretical basis of quantitative genetics and the consequences of Mendelian inheritance. Concepts used to estimate quantitative genetic differences and basis for partitioning the phenotypic variance.

ang.name: — Advanced Domestic Animal Breeding
ang.description: Course Description: Procedures for the genetic evaluation of individuals to include selection indices and mixed model evaluation for single and multiple traits. Methods of estimating genetic trends.

ang.name: — Estimation of Genetic Parameters
ang.description: Course Description: General methods for the estimation of components of variance and covariance and their application to the estimation of heritability, repeatability and genetic correlations are considered. Specific emphasis is given to procedures applicable to livestock populations under selection.
ang.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ANG 107; ANS 205; ANG 204 and ANG 108 recommended.

ang.name: — Genetic Engineering of Animals
ang.description: Course Description: Review of techniques for the genetic engineering of animals and their limitations and applications. Student-led discussions of recent papers in the field and possible future applications of genetically engineered animals in basic research and applied agricultural and medical research.

ang.name: — Sequence Analysis in Molecular Genetics
ang.description: Course Description: Use of computer algorithms and on-line databases to analyze nucleic acid and protein sequences in molecular genetics research.
ang.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; or the equivalent; graduate standing or consent of instructor.

ang.name: — Group Study
ang.description: Course Description: Lectures and discussions of advanced topics in animal genetics.

ang.name: — Research in Animal Genetics
ang.description: Course Description: Research in Animal Genetics.

ans.name: — Domestic Animals & People
ans.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Animal domestication and factors affecting their characteristics and distribution. Animal use for food, fiber, work, drugs, research and recreation; present and future roles in society. Laboratory exercises with beef and dairy cattle, poultry, sheep, swine, laboratory animals, fish, horses, meat and dairy products.

ans.name: — Introductory Animal Science
ans.description: Course Description: Growth, reproduction, lactation, inheritance, nutrition, and disease control in domesticated animals and species used in aquaculture; the application of sciences to animal production.

ans.name: — Animal Science: Basic Principles & Application
ans.description: Course Description: Overview of domestic and global animal industries. Exploration of production systems, animal biology, genetics, anatomy, physiology, reproduction, health, behavior, research, biotechnology and welfare.

ans.name: — Introductory Horse Husbandry
ans.description: Course Description: Introduction to care and use of light horses emphasizing the basic principles for selection of horses, responsibilities of ownership, recreational use and raising of foals.

ans.name: — Canine Behavior: Learning & Cognition
ans.description: Course Description: Domestic dog behavior from basic principles of learning to complex cognitive behaviors; interaction between learning and cognition including how these processes contribute to interactions with humans; basic genetic correlates of learning and cognition.

ans.name: — Introductory Aquaculture
ans.description: Course Description: Historical and contemporary aquacultural practices. Interaction between the aqueous culture environment and the biology of aquatic animals. Impact of economics and governmental policies on the development of aquaculture. Interaction of aquacultural practices with larger societal goals.

ans.name: — Livestock & Dairy Cattle Judging
ans.description: Course Description: Evaluation of type as presently applied to light horses, meat animals and dairy cattle. Relationship between form and function, form and carcass quality, and form and milk production.

ans.name: — Animal Evaluation
ans.description: Course Description: Attendance at 3 one-day weekend field trips required. Domestic livestock species with emphasis on visual appraisal, carcass evaluation, and application of performance information. Emphasis on accurate written and oral descriptions of evaluations. Prerequisite to intercollegiate judging competition.

ans.name: — Animal Evaluation
ans.description: Course Description: Attendance at three one-day weekend field trips required. Continuation of ANS 022A with emphasis on specific species: swine, beef cattle and sheep. Application of animal science principles to selection and management problem-solving scenarios. Prerequisite to intercollegiate judging competition.

ans.name: — Domestic Animal Production
ans.description: Course Description: Principles of farm animal management, including dairy and beef cattle, sheep, and swine. Industry trends, care and management, nutrition, and reproduction.

ans.name: — Domestic Animal Production Laboratory
ans.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Animal production principles and practices, including five field trips to dairy cattle, beef cattle, sheep, and swine operations and campus labs.

ans.name: — Introductory Companion Animal Biology
ans.description: Course Description: Companion animal domestication. Historical, contemporary perspectives. Legislation concerning companion animals. Selected topics in anatomy, physiology, genetics, nutrition, behavior and management. Scientific methods in studying the human-animal bond. Discussions: application of biological concepts to problems related to companion animals.

ans.name: — Animal Management Practices: Aquaculture
ans.description: Course Description: Application of the principles of elementary biology to the management of a specific animal species. Up to four different topics may be taken.

ans.name: — Animal Management Practices: Beef
ans.description: Course Description: Application of the principles of elementary biology to the management of a specific animal species. Up to four different topics may be taken.

ans.name: — Animal Management Practices: Dairy
ans.description: Course Description: Application of the principles of elementary biology to the management of a specific animal species. Up to four different topics may be taken.

ans.name: — Animal Management Practices: Goats
ans.description: Course Description: Application of the principles of elementary biology to the management of a specific animal species. Up to four different topics may be taken.

ans.name: — Animal Management Practices: Horses
ans.description: Course Description: Application of the principles of elementary biology to the management of a specific animal species. Up to four different topics may be taken.

ans.name: — Animal Management Practices: Laboratory Animals
ans.description: Course Description: Application of the principles of elementary biology to the management of a specific animal species. Up to four different topics may be taken.

ans.name: — Animal Management Practices: Meats
ans.description: Course Description: Application of the principles of elementary biology to the management of a specific animal species. Up to four different topics may be taken.

ans.name: — Animal Management Practices: Poultry
ans.description: Course Description: Application of the principles of elementary biology to the management of a specific animal species. Up to four different topics may be taken.

ans.name: — Animal Management Practices: Sheep
ans.description: Course Description: Application of the principles of elementary biology to the management of a specific animal species. Up to four different topics may be taken.

ans.name: — Animal Management Practices: Swine
ans.description: Course Description: Application of the principles of elementary biology to the management of a specific animal species. Up to four different topics may be taken.

ans.name: — Animal Management Practices: Captive & Companion Avian
ans.description: Course Description: Application of the principles of elementary biology to the management of a specific animal species. Up to four different topics may be taken.

ans.name: — Research Group Conference
ans.description: Course Description: Weekly conference on research problems, progress and techniques in the animal sciences.

ans.name: — Internship in Animal Science
ans.description: Course Description: Internship off and on campus in dairy, livestock, and aquaculture production, research and management; or in a business, industry, or agency associated with these or other animal enterprises. All requirements of Internship Approval form must be met.

ans.name: — Internship in Animal Science Discussion
ans.description: Course Description: Provides opportunities to meet and discuss with staff and/or faculty the biological concepts that are the basis for the care and management programs used with animals during their lower division internship.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ANS 092 (can be concurrent); consent of instructor.

ans.name: — Directed Group Study
ans.description: Course Description: Directed group study.

ans.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
ans.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.

ans.name: — Animal Physiology
ans.description: Course Description: Basic principles of animal physiology in domesticated and captive animals with a comparative approach. Molecular, biochemical, chemical and physical aspects and their influences on function of physiological systems in animals.

ans.name: — Animal Welfare
ans.description: Course Description: Application of principles of animal behavior and physiology to assessment and improvement of the welfare of wild, captive, and domestic animals. Topics include animal pain, stress, cognition, motivation, emotions, and preferences, as well as environmental enrichment methods.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ANS 104 or NPB 102 or WFC 141; or consent of instructor.

ans.name: — Principles & Applications of Domestic Animal Behavior
ans.description: Course Description: Basic principles of animal behavior as applied to domesticated species. Emphasis placed on application of the principles of animal behavior.

ans.name: — Domestic Animal Behavior Laboratory
ans.description: Course Description: Research experience with the behavior of large domestic animals. Experimental design, methods of data collection & analysis, and reporting of experimental results.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ANS 104 or NPB 102; or consent of instructor.

ans.name: — Zoo Biology & Research
ans.description: Course Description: Introduction to the modern zoo, including history, staffing structure, aspects of animal care such as housing, social management, and enrichment, research in genetics, health, nutrition, behavior, cognition, and guest perceptions. Requires a visit to the Sacramento Zoo and development of a project research proposal based on a specific exhibit at the zoo.

ans.name: — Equine Behavior & Welfare
ans.description: Course Description: Improve the understanding and application of good welfare practices when managing, training, transporting, treating, or breeding equine. Recognize changes in behavior or causes related to comprised health or welfare.

ans.name: — Sustainable Animal Agriculture
ans.description: Course Description: Current applications of sustainable animal agriculture including the challenges of animal production, animal needs, animal well-being, and protection of the environment and resources for future food supply systems. Various scenarios for meeting sustainability objectives are evaluated using computing modeling.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002B or ANS 001; STA 100 or PLS 120 recommended.

ans.name: — Meat Safety & Hazard Analysis & Critical Control Points
ans.description: Course Description: Fundamentals of meat safety and Hazard Analysis Critical Control Points (HACCP). Principles, development, implementation of HACCP. Control of physical, chemical, biological hazards assuring meat/food safety via programs (Good Manufacturing Practices, Sanitation Standard Operating Procedures), hazard analysis critical control points. Regulations, focusing on HACCP implementation in meat & seafood products. Value, shortcomings of sampling, and microbial testing in meat safety assurance programs.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ANS 002 or consent of instructor.

ans.name: — Advanced Horse Production
ans.description: Course Description: Feeding, breeding, and management of horses; application of the basic principles of animal science to problems of production of all types of horses. Designed for students who wish to become professionally involved in the horse industry.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ANS 015; BIS 101; NUT 115; (ANS 100 or NPB 101); or consent of instructor.

ans.name: — Fish Production
ans.description: Course Description: Current practices in fish production; relationship between the biological aspects of a species and the production systems, husbandry, management, and marketing practices utilized. Emphasis on species currently reared in California.

ans.name: — Invertebrate Aquaculture
ans.description: Course Description: Management, breeding and feeding of aquatic invertebrates; application of basic principles of physiology, reproduction, and nutrition to production of mollusks and crustaceans for human food; emphasis on interaction of species biology and managerial techniques on production efficiencies.

ans.name: — Principles of Meat Science
ans.description: Course Description: Anatomical, physiological, developmental, and biochemical aspects of muscle underlying the conversion of muscle to meat. Includes meat processing, preservation, microbiology, and public health issues associated with meat products.

ans.name: — Meat Science Laboratory
ans.description: Course Description: Laboratory exercises and student participation in transformation of live animal to carcass and meat, structural and biochemical changes related to meat quality, chemical and sensory evaluation of meat, and field trips to packing plant and processing plant.

ans.name: — Animal Growth & Development
ans.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Growth and development of animals from conception to maturity, viewed from practical and biological perspectives; includes genetic, metabolic, nutritional control of cell and organism function.

ans.name: — Lactation
ans.description: Course Description: Biochemical, genetic, physiological, nutritional, and structural factors relating to mammary gland development, the initiation of lactation, the composition of milk and lactational performance.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (NPB 101 or ANS 100); (ABI 103 (can be concurrent) or BIS 103 (can be concurrent)).

ans.name: — Equine Exercise Physiology
ans.description: Course Description: Basic and applied physiology of the exercising horse. Includes physiological systems, gait analysis, lameness, pharmacology, sports medicine; sport horse performance evaluation and conditioning.

ans.name: — Equine Nutrition
ans.description: Course Description: Equine digestion, digestive physiology, diet development and evaluation, and the relationship of the topics to recommended feeding practices and nutritional portfolios.

ans.name: — Advanced Equine Reproduction
ans.description: Course Description: Reproductive physiology, anatomy and endocrinology of the mare and stallion. Emphasis on structure/function relationships as they are applied to improving equine reproductive management and efficiency.

ans.name: — Agricultural Applications of Linear Programming
ans.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Applications of linear programming in agriculture, emphasizing resource allocation problems and decision making. Problems include crop production, ration formulation, and farm management. Hands-on experience in developing linear programs and interpreting the results.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 021 or ECS 015; or consent of instructor.

ans.name: — Environmental Stewardship in Animal Production Systems
ans.description: Course Description: Management principles of environmental stewardship for grazing lands, animal feeding, operations and aquaculture operations; existing regulations, sample analyses, interpretation and utilization of data, evaluation of alternative practices, and policy development.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 010 or (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B)),  CHE 002A,  CHE 002B,  (CHE 008A,  CHE 008B) or (CHE 118A,  CHE 118B); and consent of instructor.

ans.name: — Endocrinology Laboratory
ans.description: Course Description: Experimental approaches used in animal endocrinology research. Introductions to a variety of topics to help assimilate many ideas from physiology courses, experimental approaches, and skills reading and interpreting scientific papers.

ans.name: — Reproduction & Early Development in Aquatic Animals
ans.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Physiological and developmental functions related to reproduction, breeding efficiency and fertility of animals commonly used in aquaculture.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MCB 150; WFC 120; or consent of instructor.

ans.name: — Microbiology of Animal Systems Laboratory
ans.description: Course Description: Basic microbiology techniques and the ability to produce recombinant proteins from genomic information. Importance of carbohydrate degrading enzymes in animal systems. Animal systems of interest range from the digestive tract of animals (e.g. rumen) to animal waste (e.g. manure).

ans.name: — Animal Cell Culture Laboratory
ans.description: Course Description: Design, conduct, analyze, and present a research project involving cell culture.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ABI 102; ABI 103; (ANS 100 or NPB 101); or consent of instructor.

ans.name: — Animal Nutrition Laboratory
ans.description: Course Description: Animal nutrition research experience for senior-level students. Forming a valid hypothesis, designing treatments, preparing for experiments, recording measurements in the field, summarizing results. Emphasis on developing essential research skills & proper techniques for collecting, summarizing, and presenting data.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ABI 103 (can be concurrent); (ANS 100 (can be concurrent) or NPB 101 (can be concurrent)); (STA 100 or PLS 120).

ans.name: — Production Animal Laboratory
ans.description: Course Description: Biochemical methods for developing and conducting research with production animals, and interpreting and presenting data. Laboratory focus course which uses sheep as model. There may be one or two mandatory all day Saturday field trips.

ans.name: — Techniques & Practices of Fish Culture
ans.description: Course Description: Daily care and maintenance of fish in residential aquariums, research and commercial facilities. Biological and environmental factors important to sound management of fish. Laboratories focus on fish culture including growth trials and biochemical assays.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ANS 002; BIS 002A; BIS 002B; BIS 002C; ((CHE 008A,  CHE 008B) or (CHE 118A,  CHE 118B)).

ans.name: — Techniques & Practices of Avian Culture
ans.description: Course Description: Daily care and maintenance of birds for research, commercial production and companion or hobby uses. Biological and environmental factors important to sound management of birds. Laboratories focus on bird husbandry, management and care and include growth trials and biochemical assays.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ANS 002; BIS 002A; BIS 002B; BIS 002C; ((CHE 008A,  CHE 008B) or (CHE 118A,  CHE 118B)).

ans.name: — Meat Quality & Safety Laboratory
ans.description: Course Description: Advanced hands-on experience with meat and food related research. Development of laboratory skills in chemistry, biochemistry, microbiology, and meat science.

ans.name: — Experimental Animal Physiology
ans.description: Course Description: Combination of theory and hands-on experiences in animal physiology using various experimental techniques. Practical laboratory skill development from cellular level to whole animal, in areas such as genetics, endocrinology, histology and physiological function.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ABI 102; BIS 101; or consent of instructor.

ans.name: — Management of Laboratory Animals
ans.description: Course Description: Laboratory animal management procedures in view of animal physiology, health and welfare, government regulations, and experimental needs. Clinical techniques using rodents and rabbits as models.

ans.name: — Equine Enterprise Management
ans.description: Course Description: Examination of the concepts and principles involved in the operation of an equine enterprise. Essential aspects of equine enterprise management, including equine law, marketing, cash flow analysis, and impact of state and federal regulations.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ANS 115; ECN 001A and ECN 001B recommended.

ans.name: — Companion Animal Care & Management
ans.description: Course Description: Management and production of companion animals. Integration of the disciplinary principles of behavior, genetics, nutrition, and physiology as related to the care of companion animals.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ANS 042; BIS 101; (NPB 101 or ANS 100); ((ABI 102 or BIS 102) and (ABI 103 or BIS 103)) recommended.

ans.name: — Pig & Poultry Care & Management
ans.description: Course Description: Care and management of swine, broilers and turkeys as related to environmental physiology, nutrition and metabolism, disease management and reproduction. Saturday field trips.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 115; (NPB 101 or ANS 100); ANS 041; or consent of instructor.

ans.name: — Beef Cattle & Sheep Production
ans.description: Course Description: Genetics, physiology, nutrition, economics and business in beef cattle and sheep production. Resources used, species differences, range and feedlot operations. Emphasis on integration and information needed in methods for management of livestock enterprises. One or two Saturday field trips.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ANS 041; NUT 115; or consent of instructor; ANG 107 recommended.

ans.name: — Meat Processing & Marketing
ans.description: Course Description: Distribution, processing and marketing of meat and meat products. Meat and meat animal grading and pricing. Government regulations and social/consumer concerns. Future trends and impact on production management practices. Includes poultry.

ans.name: — Dairy Cattle Production
ans.description: Course Description: Scientific principles from genetics, nutrition, physiology, and related fields applied to conversion of animal feed to human food through dairy animals. Management and economic decisions are related to animal biology considering the environment and animal well-being. Mandatory Saturday field-trip.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 115; or consent of instructor; ANG 107 recommended.

ans.name: — Dairy Processing & Marketing
ans.description: Course Description: Examination of distribution systems, processing practices, product quality, impact of government policy (domestic and foreign), marketing alternatives, and product development.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ANS 002; or consent of instructor.

ans.name: — Enterprise Analysis in Animal Industries
ans.description: Course Description: Examination and application of decision making and problem solving in the production enterprise. Areas of production analysis, problem solving, risk analysis and cost-benefit analysis will be examined in terms of the total enterprise.

ans.name: — Farrier Science
ans.description: Course Description: In-depth examination of the structure-function relationship of the equine hoof and how it relates to conformation, injury and performance.

ans.name: — Farrier Science Laboratory
ans.description: Course Description: Art and science of horseshoeing in equine related fields. Proper use of the tools, materials and techniques in the fabrication of shoes and safe preparation of the hoof for application of shoes.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ANS 149 (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

ans.name: — Animal Health & Disease
ans.description: Course Description: Basic concepts of animal immunology, microbiology, parasitology, epidemiology, vaccination, and how the knowledge can be used to improve animal health and prevent animal infection & disease. Includes relevant health and disease issues.

ans.name: — Stress & Reproduction I
ans.description: Course Description: Evaluation of the impact of chronic stress on male reproductive development. Isolation stress tests on young animals. Data collection of treatment and control groups. Biological laboratory techniques and analysis. Two-quarter course.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 121 (can be concurrent); (ANS 104 (can be concurrent) or NPB 102 (can be concurrent)).

ans.name: — Stress & Reproduction II
ans.description: Course Description: Evaluation of the impact of chronic stress on male reproductive development. Isolation stress tests on young animals. Data collection of treatment and control groups. Biological laboratory techniques and analysis. Two-quarter course.

ans.name: — Ethics of Animal Use
ans.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Ethical issues relating to animal use in contemporary society. Integration of philosophical theories with scientific evidence relating to animal behavior, mentality, and welfare. Uses of animals in agriculture, research, and as companions. Ethical responsibilities regarding wildlife and the environment.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Any basic course in composition or speech, or completion of college English requirement.

ans.name: — Research Group Conference
ans.description: Course Description: Weekly conference on research problems, progress and techniques in the animal sciences.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; advanced standing.

ans.name: — Internship in Animal Science
ans.description: Course Description: Internship off and on campus in dairy, livestock and aquaculture production, research and management; or in a business, industry, or agency associated with these or other animal enterprises. All requirements of Internship Approval Form must be met.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of 84 units.

ans.name: — Internship in Animal Science Discussion
ans.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Weekly meeting with staff and/or faculty to discuss the biological concepts that are the basis for the care and management programs used with animals during their internship.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ANS 192 (can be concurrent); consent of instructor.

ans.name: — Research in Animal Science
ans.description: Course Description: Research with a faculty mentor. Weekly discussion and laboratory on specific research topic. May include a seminar to research group. Choose from sections: (1) Animal Behavior; (2) Animal Genetics; (3) Animal Nutrition; (4) Animal Physiology.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ANS 106 or ANS 135 or ANS 136 or ANS 137 or ANS 139 or ANG 111; or ANS 133; and consent of instructor.

ans.name: — Undergraduate Honors Thesis in Animal Science
ans.description: Course Description: Carry out a research project (chosen from faculty-suggested or approved proposals) during the academic year under the guidance of a faculty member. Upon completion, write a thesis and present a public seminar describing his/her research.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (NPB 101 or ANS 100); (ABI 103 or BIS 103); and consent of instructor; minimum cumulative GPA of 3.200 and selection by the Honors Selection Committee.

ans.name: — Undergraduate Honors Thesis in Animal Science
ans.description: Course Description: Carry out a research project (chosen from faculty-suggested or approved proposals) during the academic year under the guidance of a faculty member. Upon completion, write a thesis and present a public seminar describing his/her research.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (NPB 101 or ANS 100); (ABI 103 or BIS 103); and consent of instructor; minimum cumulative GPA of 3.200 and selection by the Honors Selection Committee.

ans.name: — Undergraduate Honors Thesis in Animal Science
ans.description: Course Description: Carry out a research project (chosen from faculty-suggested or approved proposals) during the academic year under the guidance of a faculty member. Upon completion, write a thesis and present a public seminar describing his/her research.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (NPB 101 or ANS 100); (ABI 103 or BIS 103); and consent of instructor; minimum cumulative GPA of 3.200 and selection by the Honors Selection Committee.

ans.name: — Tutoring in Animal Science
ans.description: Course Description: Tutoring of students in courses taught by instructors in the Department of Animal Science; weekly conference with instructor(s) in charge of the course; written critiques of teaching procedures; assist in preparation and development of instructional materials.
ans.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; animal Science or related major; upper division standing.

ans.name: — Directed Group Study
ans.description: Course Description: Selected topics relating to the animal sciences. May be taught abroad.

ans.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
ans.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

ans.name: — Strategies in Animal Production
ans.description: Course Description: Examines the forces and issues in animal agriculture through the strategic management process.

ans.name: — Models in Agriculture & Nutrition
ans.description: Course Description: Basic model building principles and techniques for statistical and systems simulation models. Optimization techniques for non-linear experimental designs and management models are presented. Quantitative analysis and evaluation of linear and non-linear equations used in agriculture and nutrition.

ans.name: — Literature in Animal Science
ans.description: Course Description: Critical presentation and analysis of recent journal articles in animal science.

ans.name: — Seminar
ans.description: Course Description: Reports and discussions of topics of interest in genetics, nutrition, and physiology as they apply to animal science.

ans.name: — Research Group Conference
ans.description: Course Description: Weekly conference on research problems, progress and techniques in the animal sciences.

ans.name: — Current Research in Animal Science
ans.description: Course Description: Current research in animal science explored at weekly seminars presented by guest lecturers. Discussion of research presented.

ans.name: — Supervised Teaching in Animal Science
ans.description: Course Description: Practical experience in teaching Animal Science at University level; curriculum design and evaluation; preparation and presentation of material. Assistance in laboratories, discussion sections, and evaluation of student work. Evaluation letter sent to the graduate advisor with copy to the student.

ans.name: — Group Study
ans.description: Course Description: Lectures and discussions of advanced topics in the animal sciences. (Sect. 1, 2, 3-letter grading; from Sect. 4 on-S/U grading only.)

ans.name: — Research
ans.description: Course Description: Research.

ant.name: — Human Evolutionary Biology
ant.description: Course Description: Processes and course of human evolution; primatology; biological and social diversity within Homo sapiens; human paleontology.

ant.name: — Human Evolutionary Biology (Hybrid Version)
ant.description: Course Description: Evolutionary theory and mechanisms of evolution; basic population and quantitative genetics; primatology; biological and cultural diversity within Homo sapiens; paleoanthropology.

ant.name: — Cultural Anthropology
ant.description: Course Description: Introduction to cultural diversity in its many forms and methods used by anthropologists to account for it. Relational dynamic of culture, history, and power in constituting "social facts" and "realities." Critical thinking of contemporary concerns.

ant.name: — Introduction to Archaeology
ant.description: Course Description: Development of archaeology as an anthropological study; objectives and methods of modern archaeology.

ant.name: — Introduction to Anthropological Linguistics
ant.description: Course Description: Exploration of the role of language in social interaction and world view, minority languages and dialects, bilingualism, literacy, the social motivation of language change. Introduction of analytical techniques of linguistics and demonstration of their relevance to language in sociocultural issues.

ant.name: — Scientific Method in Physical Anthropology
ant.description: Course Description: Skills for scientific thinking; designing, implementing, analyzing, interpreting, presenting, and criticizing research. Collection and analysis of original data. Basic statistical methods.

ant.name: — From Birth to Death: The Evolution of the Human Life Cycle
ant.description: Course Description: Introduction to the biology of birth, childhood, marriage, the family, old age, and death. Examines comparative characteristics of nonhuman primates and other animals as well as cross-cultural variation in humans by study of selected cases.

ant.name: — Comparative Cultures
ant.description: Course Description: Introduction to the anthropological study of cultural diversity. Case studies of eight societies will be presented to illustrate and compare the distinctive features of major cultural regions of the world. Concludes with a discussion of modernization.

ant.name: — Zombies
ant.description: Course Description: Figure of the zombie as window into ideas about race, economic exploitation, and what it means to be human. Zombie lore in the Afro-Atlantic world and its re-imagining in contemporary pop culture.

ant.name: — Myths About Human Evolution
ant.description: Course Description: Myths about human evolution. Use of evidence from evolutionary biology, geology, paleontology, archaeology, and genetics to dispel misconceptions about human evolution.

ant.name: — Introduction to World Prehistory
ant.description: Course Description: Broadly surveys patterns and changes in the human species' physical and cultural evolution from earliest evidence for "humanness" to recent development of large-scale complex societies or "civilizations." Lectures emphasize use of archaeology in reconstructing the past.

ant.name: — Ancient Crops & People
ant.description: Course Description: The archaeological evidence for domestication of plants and the origins of agricultural societies. Anthropological context of agriculture and the effects on sexual division of labor, social inequality, wealth accumulation, warfare, human health, and sedentism.

ant.name: — Ancient Animals & People
ant.description: Course Description: History of human and animal relationships and how animals have influenced social and economic structures of past societies. Why, when and how humans used animals in the context of hunting, domestication, secondary products, ritual, companionship, and conservation.

ant.name: — Mummies of the Ancient World
ant.description: Course Description: Archaeological approaches for studying mummies and the process of mummification in the ancient world. Analytical techniques used, environmental factors promoting mummification, and archaeological conservation of mummified bodies.

ant.name: — Great Adaptations: Genetic & Cultural Evolution in the Spread of Humanity
ant.description: Course Description: How humans adapted to diverse ecologies through cultural and genetic changes. Illustrations include evolution in response to disease, dietary, social, and communication challenges.

ant.name: — Prehistoric Origins of Art
ant.description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary look at the earliest evidence for art and symbolic behavior. Method and techniques to investigate Prehistoric art. Interpretative framework and relevance for understanding the role of symbolic activities in traditional societies.

ant.name: — Vikings
ant.description: Course Description: History of the Vikings through the Slavic and Mediterranean regions in the East and across the vast North Atlantic region to the west. Emphasis on archaeology and sagas to understand Viking culture from the 8th to 11th centuries.

ant.name: — Sexualities
ant.description: Course Description: Introduction to the study of sexuality, particularly to the meanings and social organization of same-sex sexual behavior across cultures and through time. Biological and cultural approaches will be compared, and current North American issues placed in a wider comparative context.

ant.name: — Drugs, Science & Culture
ant.description: Course Description: Drugs, politics, science, society in a cultural perspective: emphasis on roles of science, government and the media in shifting attitudes toward alcohol, marijuana, Prozac and other pharmaceuticals; drug laws, war on drugs and global trade in sugar, opium, cocaine.

ant.name: — Cultures of Consumerism
ant.description: Course Description: Aspects of modern consumer cultures in capitalist and socialist countries. Transformations of material cultures over the past century. Case studies on the intersections of gender, class, and culture in everyday consumption practices.

ant.name: — Star Trek as Social Theory
ant.description: Course Description: Introduction to core concepts in anthropological and social theory using Star Trek as a teaching vehicle. Emphasis on thinking anthropologically about everyday life and popular culture.

ant.name: — Introduction to Primatology
ant.description: Course Description: Basic survey of the primates as a separate order of mammals; natural history and evolution of primates; consideration of hypotheses for their origin.

ant.name: — Introduction to Forensic Anthropology
ant.description: Course Description: Survey of anthropological techniques as applied within the legal system, including scene documentation and recovery, human identification, and trauma analysis. Examination of error and uncertainty, ethics, and human rights in forensic anthropology.

ant.name: — Internship in Anthropology
ant.description: Course Description: Work experience off and on campus in all subject areas offered in the Department of Anthropology under the supervision of a member of the faculty.

ant.name: — Directed Group Study
ant.description: Course Description: Primarily intended for lower division students.

ant.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
ant.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.

ant.name: — Theory in Social-Cultural Anthropology
ant.description: Course Description: Discussion of the theoretical and philosophical developments in cultural anthropology from the 19th century to the present.

ant.name: — Ecology, Nature, & Society
ant.description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary study of diversity and change in human societies, using frameworks from anthropology, evolutionary ecology, history, archaeology, psychology, and other fields. Topics include population dynamics, subsistence transitions, family organization, disease, economics, warfare, politics, and resource conservation.
ant.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ANT 001 or ANT 002 or ESP 030 or EVE 100 or BIS 101 recommended.

ant.name: — Indigenous Peoples & Natural Resource Conservation
ant.description: Course Description: Integration of the interests of resident and indigenous peoples with the conservation of natural resources and ecosystems, using case study examples from both the developing and developed world.
ant.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ANT 002 or GEL 001 or ESP 030 recommended.

ant.name: — Cultural Politics of the Environment
ant.description: Course Description: Political economy of environmental struggles. Relationship between social inequality (based on race, class and/or gender) and ecological degradation. Articulation of local peoples, national policy, and the international global economy in the contestation over the use of environmental resources.

ant.name: — Law, Power, Violence
ant.description: Course Description: Cultural dimensions of law and political power. Colonial and postcolonial legal regimes, bureaucratic reason, legalized violence, sovereign power, and human rights.

ant.name: — Visualization in Science: A Critical Introduction
ant.description: Course Description: Anthropological approaches to scientific visualization techniques, informatics, simulations. Examination of different visualization techniques toward understanding the work involved in producing them, critical assessment of their power and limits, especially when visualizations are used socially to make claims.
ant.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ANT 002 or STS 001 or STS 020 recommended.

ant.name: — The Ethnographic & Literary Imagination
ant.description: Course Description: The ethnographic and literary imagination. Relationship between fiction & anthropology, narrative form, modalities of ethnographic encounter, social & historical phenomena, aesthetics, poetics, language, and the question of representation.

ant.name: — Language & Culture
ant.description: Course Description: Culture, cognition, meaning, and interpretation; language and the classification of experience; communication and learning in crosscultural perspective.
ant.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ANT 004 or LIN 001 recommended; ANT 002 recommended.

ant.name: — Special Topics in Medical Anthropology
ant.description: Course Description: Introduction to critical medical anthropology. Topics include anthropological analysis of bio-medicine, psychiatry, systems of knowledge and healing, the body, emotions, and clinical encounters in a cross-cultural perspective.

ant.name: — Economic Anthropology
ant.description: Course Description: The varieties of production, exchange, and consumption behavior in precapitalist economies, their interaction with culture and social-political organization, and the theories that account for these phenomena. The effects of capitalism on precapitalist sectors.

ant.name: — Capitalism & Power
ant.description: Course Description: Theorizations of economy and society. The rise of modern capitalism and new social and political formations. Relationships between value and violence, subjectivity, the unconscious, money, imperialism and different understandings of exchange and the political.

ant.name: — Resistance, Rebellion, & Popular Movements
ant.description: Course Description: Analysis of popular protest in Third World and indigenous societies ranging from covert resistance to national revolts. Comparative case studies and theories of peasant rebellions, millenarian movements, social bandits, Indian "wars", ethnic and regional conflicts, gender and class conflicts.

ant.name: — Religion in Society & Culture
ant.description: Course Description: Discussion of anthropological theories of religion with emphasis on non-literate societies. Survey of shamanism, magic and witchcraft, ritual and symbols, and religious movements. Extensive discussion of ethnographic examples and analysis of social functions of religious institutions.

ant.name: — Structuralism & Symbolism
ant.description: Course Description: Survey of anthropological approaches to understanding the logic of structuralism and symbolism in cultural analysis. Focus on how structural and symbolic interpretations relate to cultural and linguistic universals and to the philosophical basis of relativism in the social sciences. (Former ANT 125.)

ant.name: — Postmodernism(s) & Culture
ant.description: Course Description: Crucial theories of modernity and post-modernity. How postmodernism is distinct from modernism, why it is related to the collapse of certainty about our collective reality and what it reveals about the status of reason, the self, and collective experience. Readings draw from various philosophical-theoretical, artistic and political literatures.

ant.name: — Anthropology of Development
ant.description: Course Description: Theories of development and current critiques. Colonial legacies and post-colonial realities. Roles of the state and NGOs, population migrations, changing gender identities, cash-earning strategies, and sustainability issues. Stresses importance of cultural understandings in development initiatives. Case studies emphasizing non-industrial societies.

ant.name: — Women & Development
ant.description: Course Description: Current Third World and Western development issues concerning women in agriculture, industry, international division of labor, political movements, revolutions, politics of health, education, family and reproduction. Impact of colonialism, capitalism, the world system, and international feminism on women and development.

ant.name: — Urban Anthropology
ant.description: Course Description: Survey of approaches to urban living: political structures, organization of labor, class relations, world views. The evolution of urban life and its contemporary dilemmas. Cross-cultural comparisons discussed through case studies.

ant.name: — Kinship & Social Organization: From Clans to Countries
ant.description: Course Description: Family, marriage, household and social organization from a cross-cultural and evolutionary perspective. Emphasis on case studies that illustrate human variation, theories that account for this variation, and recent advances in the treatment of this data.

ant.name: — Self, Identity, & Family
ant.description: Course Description: Exploration of self, identity, and family systems cross-culturally. Impact of class, gender, race, ethnicity, ruralization, urbanization, and globalization on notions of selfhood in different social/cultural systems.

ant.name: — Health & Medicine in a Global Context
ant.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Recent works in medical anthropology and the science studies of medicine dealing with social and cultural aspects of global health issues such as AIDS, pandemics, clinical trials, cultural differences in illnesses, diabetes, organ trafficking, medical technologies, illness narratives, and others.

ant.name: — Cultural Dimensions of Globalization
ant.description: Course Description: Cultural dimensions of recent economic and political developments frequently termed "globalization."

ant.name: — Migration & the Politics of Place & Identity
ant.description: Course Description: Internal and international migration from an anthropological perspective, including causes, processes, and political, economic, and cultural effects of spatial mobility and displacement. Emphasizes the interplay of identity, place, and power in diverse cultural and historical contexts.

ant.name: — Ecology & Politics
ant.description: Course Description: Analysis of the complex interactions between ecological dynamics and political processes employing the emerging approach of political ecology. Case studies of environmental degradation (e.g., desertification, logging, mineral extraction, petroleum, water) from various cultural and geographic regions.

ant.name: — Psychological Anthropology
ant.description: Course Description: History of the relationship between anthropology and psychoanalysis. Exploration of anthropology of emotions, colonial psychology, contemporary ethno-psychiatry, studies on personhood, possession, magic, altered states, subjectivity, and definitions of the normal and the pathological in different contexts and cultures.

ant.name: — Anthropology of Ocean Worlds
ant.description: Course Description: Exploration of various oceanic cultures and their engagement with the sea. Piracy, smuggling, exchange, maritime legal regimes, offshore policing, media infrastructures, and ocean ecologies.

ant.name: — Buddhism in Global Culture
