bph.description: Course Description: Introduction to the origin, maintenance, and regulation of the dynamic architecture of the cell, including cellular modes of organization, dynamics and energy dissipation, molecular transport, motility, regulation, and adaptability.

bph.name: — Biophysics Seminar
bph.description: Course Description: Presentation of current research by experts in biophysics.
bph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

bph.name: — Research Conference in Biophysics
bph.description: Course Description: Presentation and discussion of faculty and graduate-student research in biophysics.
bph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BPH 299 (can be concurrent); graduate standing in Biophysics and/or consent of instructor.

bph.name: — Introduction to Research Topics
bph.description: Course Description: Presentation of current research activities of the Biophysics Graduate Group faculty. Facilitation of students in developing their research interest, and promoting collegial interactions.

bst.name: — Biostatistics: Survival Analysis
bst.description: Course Description: Incomplete data; life tables; nonparametric methods; parametric methods; accelerated failure time models; proportional hazards models; partial likelihood; advanced topics.

bst.name: — Biostatistics: Generalized Linear Models
bst.description: Course Description: Likelihood and linear regression; generalized linear model; Binomial regression; case-control studies; dose-response and bioassay; Poisson regression; Gamma regression; quasi-likelihood models; estimating equations; multivariate GLMs.

bst.name: — Analysis of Longitudinal Data
bst.description: Course Description: Standard and advanced methodology, theory, algorithms, and applications relevant for analysis of repeated measurements and longitudinal data in biostatistical and statistical settings.
bst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BST 222 or STA 222); (BST 223 or STA 223); STA 232B; or consent of instructor.

bst.name: — Clinical Trials
bst.description: Course Description: Basic statistical principles of clinical designs, including bias, randomization, blocking, and masking. Practical applications of widely-used designs, including dose-finding, comparative and cluster randomization designs. Advanced statistical procedures for analysis of data collected in clinical trials.
bst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BST 223 or STA 223; or consent of instructor.

bst.name: — Statistical Methods for Bioinformatics
bst.description: Course Description: Standard and advanced statistical methodology, theory, algorithms, and applications relevant to the analysis of -omics data.
bst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BST 131C or consent of instructor; data analysis experience recommended.

bst.name: — Machine Learning in Genomics
bst.description: Course Description: Emerging problems in molecular biology and current machine learning-based solutions to those problem. How deep learning, kernel methods, graphical models, feature selection, non-parametric models and other techniques can be applied to application areas such as gene editing, gene network inference and analysis, chromatin state inference, cancer genomics and single cell genomics.
bst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 208 or ECS 171; or consent of instructor.

bst.name: — Advanced Topics in Biostatistics
bst.description: Course Description: Biostatistical methods and models selected from the following:  genetics, bioinformatics and genomics;longitudinal or functional data; clinical trials and experimental design; analysis of environmental data; dose-response, nutrition and toxicology; survival analysis; observational studies and epidemiology; computer-intensive or Bayesian methods in biostatistics.

bst.name: — Seminar in Biostatistics
bst.description: Course Description: Seminar on advanced topics in the field of biostatistics. Presented by members of the Biostatistics Graduate Group and other guest speakers.

bst.name: — Directed Group Study
bst.description: Course Description: Special topics in Biostatistics appropriate for group study at the graduate level.

bst.name: — Special Study for Biostat Graduate Students
bst.description: Course Description: Special topics in Biostatistics appropriate for directed individual study on advanced topics not otherwise covered in the Biostatistics curriculum.

bst.name: — Dissertation Research
bst.description: Course Description: Research in Biostatistics under the supervision of major professor.
bst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; advancement to Candidacy for Ph.D.

bit.name: — Introduction to Biotechnology
bit.description: Course Description: Principles and technologies of biotechnology as applied to agriculture, the environment, and medicine. Business plans and presentation pitches for new biotechnology products. Bioinformatics approaches exploring genomic databases and DNA manipulations in silica.

bit.name: — Undergraduate Seminars in Biotechnology
bit.description: Course Description: Undergraduate oriented seminar series focused on biotechnology research and product development. Speakers from campus and the private sectors discuss ongoing research, product development and biotechnology careers.

bit.name: — Internship in Biotechnology
bit.description: Course Description: Work experience on or off campus in subject area pertaining to biotechnology or in a business, industry or agency associated with biotechnology. Internship supervised by faculty member in the animal or plant sciences.

bit.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
bit.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.

bit.name: — Applied Bioinformatics
bit.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Concepts and programs needed to apply bioinformatics in biotechnology research. Sequence analysis and annotation and use of plant and animal databases for students in biological and agricultural sciences.
bit.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; (ECS 010 or ECS 015 or PLS 021); (PLS 120 or STA 013 or STA 013Y or STA 100); or consent of instructor.

bit.name: — Principles of Plant Biotechnology
bit.description: Course Description: Principles and concepts of plant biotechnology including recombinant DNA technology, molecular biology, genomics, cell and tissue culture, gene transfer and crop improvement strategies using transgenic crops.

bit.name: — Genetics & Biotechnology Laboratory
bit.description: Course Description: Techniques of genetic analysis at the molecular level including recombinant DNA, gene mapping and basic computational biology.
bit.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 152 or BIS 101; and consent of instructor.

bit.name: — Plant Genetics & Biotechnology Laboratory
bit.description: Course Description: Advanced techniques of genetic analysis at the molecular and cellular levels, including transformation, gene expression and analysis of transgenic plants.
bit.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 152 or BIS 101; and consent of instructor.

bit.name: — Professionalism & Ethics in Genomics & Biotechnology
bit.description: Course Description: Real and hypothetical case studies to illustrate ethical issues in genomics and biotechnology. Training and practice in difficult ethical situations and evaluating personal and social consequences.
bit.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing in a natural science major.

bit.name: — Undergraduate Research Proposal
bit.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Preparation and review of a scientific proposal. Problem definition, identification of objectives, literature survey, hypothesis generation, design of experiments, data analysis planning, proposal outline and preparation.

bit.name: — Laboratory Research in Genomics & Biotechnology
bit.description: Course Description: Formulating experimental approaches to current questions in biotechnology; performance of proposed experiments.
bit.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIT 188; and consent of instructor.

bit.name: — Internship in Biotechnology
bit.description: Course Description: Work experience on or off campus in a subject area pertaining to biotechnology or in a business, industry or agency associated with biotechnology. Internship supervised by faculty member in the animal or plant sciences.

bit.name: — Honors Thesis in Biotechnology
bit.description: Course Description: Independent study of selected topics under the direction of a member or members of the staff. Completion will involve the writing of a senior thesis.
bit.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIT 188; BIT 189L; consent of instructor; senior standing in Biotechnology with 3.250 GPA or higher.

bit.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
bit.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

bax.name: — Foundations of Analytics
bax.description: Course Description: Focuses on teaching the fundamentals of R and SQL. Introduces the topic of numerical optimization, and review the concepts of linear algebra and calculus.

bax.name: — Information, Insight & Impact
bax.description: Course Description: Introduction to the process of analyzing raw data to gain profitable business insight. Applications selected across organizational functions include prediction, process improvement, and general operational decision-making.

bax.name: — Organizational Issues in Implementing Analytics
bax.description: Course Description: Review the evolution of analytics in business, how to assemble and manage analytics teams, and the decision life-cycle. Emphasis on structuring communications to improve buy-in from peers and non-quantitatively-inclined colleagues.

bax.name: — Organizational Effectiveness Workshop
bax.description: Course Description: Examine leadership, communication, and project management within the business, legal and societal contexts in which analytics is applied. Emphasis on privacy, data security, responsibility, and ethics.

bax.name: — Problem Structuring
bax.description: Course Description: Synthesize data-rich business challenges using analytic frameworks and techniques for modeling business problems. Emphasis on modeling uncertainty, optimizing multiple criteria, and building consensus.

bax.name: — Data Management
bax.description: Course Description: Introduction to the extraction, assembly, storage and organization of data in IT systems.

bax.name: — Data Design & Representation
bax.description: Course Description: Introduction to business applications involving standard, streaming, and network data. Emphasis on scalable technologies for processing and analyzing big data for diverse applications.

bax.name: — Big Data
bax.description: Course Description: Learn computational reasoning about data representations by mapping conceptual data models to relational structures and analyzing database architectures and design trade-offs.

bax.name: — Analytics for Logistics & Supply Chain Management
bax.description: Course Description: Introduction to various optimization methods in the domain of logistics and supply chains.

bax.name: — Data Visualization
bax.description: Course Description: Extract insights using visualization tools in R, Python, ManyEyes, HTML/CSS, etc. Standard (histograms, boxplots, and dashboards) and specialized (3D, animation, word clouds) formats are covered.

bax.name: — Statistical Exploration & Reasoning
bax.description: Course Description: Introduction to statistical reasoning and inference extraction from large data-sets. Learn to obtain preliminary insights and form initial hypotheses through exploratory data analysis (EDA).

bax.name: — Advanced Statistics
bax.description: Course Description: Continue exploring statistical reasoning using maximum likelihood estimation, Bayesian models, nonparametric models, Monte Carlo Markov Chain, time series, model specification, model selection, and dimension reduction.

bax.name: — Analytic Decision Making
bax.description: Course Description: Using spreadsheets and specialized modeling tools, explore structured problem solution through meta-heuristics, Monte Carlo simulation, and mathematical optimization.

bax.name: — Machine Learning
bax.description: Course Description: Construct algorithms for learning from data and analyze the process for deriving business intelligence. Coverage of supervised and unsupervised learning, neural networks, etc.

bax.name: — Application Domains
bax.description: Course Description: Students explore contemporary and emerging domains for high-yield applications of analytics. Topics: social network analytics, search analytics, health care analytics, Internet of things, supply chain/operations analytics, and marketing analytics.

bax.name: — Practicum Initiation
bax.description: Course Description: Students form teams, scope their project in light of team capability and business opportunity, create a preliminary structure and solution approach for the core problem, and assess data quality and project risks.

bax.name: — Practicum Elaboration
bax.description: Course Description: Building on problems chosen in BAX 461, teams refine the business opportunity and draw insights from exploratory data analysis.

bax.name: — Practicum Analysis & Implementation
bax.description: Course Description: Focus on completing project deliverables by polishing statistical and non-statistical quantitative analysis, generating insights for technical and business stakeholders, integrating proposed solutions into partner workflows and organizations, and disseminating the findings and outcomes through presentations and publications.

bax.name: — Practicum Implementation
bax.description: Course Description: Project teams complete analysis, plan deployment and obtain client buy-in. Culminates in a project presentation, preferably including representatives from the client organization.

bax.name: — People Analytics
bax.description: Course Description: Students develop an understanding of how to position themselves as strategic partners in a company’s talent management efforts. Explore a range of topics related to people analytics, including hiring and selection, performance evaluation, training/development, promotion, compensation, social networks, diversity, and retention.

bax.name: — Topics in Business Analytics–Cloud Computing
bax.description: Course Description: Covers the foundations of cloud computing models including (Iaas) Infrastructure as a Service, (Paas) Platform as a Service, and Software as a Service (SaaS).

bax.name: — Topics in Business Analytics–Implementing Machine Learning on the Cloud
bax.description: Course Description: Covers the four layers of Machine Learning in the cloud: AI services, ML services, ML Engines & Frameworks, and Infrastructure & Serverless Environments and how to implement solutions on all of the layers by using the best abstraction for the task at hand.

car.name: — Internship in Cardiology
car.description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in cardiology.
car.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; approval of project by preceptor prior to internship.

car.name: — Cardiology Research
car.description: Course Description: Special study by individual arrangement in cardiovascular medicine. Work will include directed readings, laboratory and discussions.

car.name: — Basic Science in Cardiology
car.description: Course Description: Fundamentals underlying cardiovascular medicine. Including hemodynamics, neural control of the circulation, biochemistry and some experimental design and statistics. Experts in each of these fields will give current information in their areas.
car.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate or medical student status.

car.name: — Cardiology Research
car.description: Course Description: Research or special studies.

car.name: — Clinical Cardiology Clerkship: Kaiser
car.description: Course Description: Emphasis placed on history taking and physical examination of pediatric and adult patients with congenital and acquired cardiovascular disease. Hospital rounds in CCU and elsewhere. Roles of ECG, PCG, and cardiac fluoroscopy, etc., in office cardiology will be evaluated.
car.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Third- and fourth-year medical students with advance approval by Division of Cardiology.

car.name: — Cardiology Clinical Clerkship
car.description: Course Description: Participation with members of subspecialty consultation service in initial clinical evaluation, work-up, management, and follow-up of patients with cardiologic disorders. Two outpatient clinics per week.
car.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): IMD 430; third- and fourth-year medical students in good academic standing with consent of instructor.

car.name: — Management of Coronary Artery Disease: Coronary Care Unit
car.description: Course Description: Research in laboratory and exercise testing to be determined by instructor. Current methods of clinical research involving certain aspects of diagnosis and treatment.
car.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of second-year of medical school and advance approval by Division of Cardiology.

car.name: — Management of Coronary Artery Disease (CICU)
car.description: Course Description: Research in laboratory and exercise testing to be determined by instructor. Current methods of clinical research involving certain aspects of diagnosis and treatment.

car.name: — Preventive Cardiology
car.description: Course Description: Clinical experience, weekly seminar and reading on primary and secondary prevention of cardiovascular disease. Will be carried out in Lipid and Hypertension Clinics, Exercise Laboratory, Cardiac Care Unit, Cardiac Catheterization, and Cardiac Surgery services.
car.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of third-year medical school.

car.name: — Insights in Cardiology
car.description: Course Description: Students attend one or more cardiovascular medicine clinics: general, hypertension, arrhythmia. Introduction to the diagnosis/treatment of common cardiovascular problems.
car.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical student in good academic standing and approval by Division of Cardiology.

car.name: — Gender Specific Medicine SSM
car.description: Course Description: Special Studies Module, a four-week course on the topic Basic Science Principles Relating to Gender Specific Medicine.

car.name: — Special Group Study: EKG Unit
car.description: Course Description: Special group study in cardiology for medical students in EKG unit. May include lectures, directed reading, and/or discussion groups.
car.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical student with advance approval by monthly attending faculty.

car.name: — Research
car.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; approval by Division of Cardiology.

cha.name: — Human Gross Anatomy
cha.description: Course Description: Detailed study of the gross anatomical structure of the human body, with emphasis on function and clinical relevance to students entering health care professions.
cha.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; concurrent enrollment in EXB 106L or CHA 101L strongly recommended.

cha.name: — Human Gross Anatomy Laboratory
cha.description: Course Description: Detailed study of prosected human cadavers in small group format with extensive hands-on experience.
cha.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; (EXB 106 (can be concurrent) or CHA 101 (can be concurrent)); if EXB 106 or CHA 101 is not taken concurrently, it must have been already completed.

cha.name: — Human Microscopic Anatomy: Structure & Function of Human Tissues & Organ Systems
cha.description: Course Description: Complements Gross Anatomy by extending the study of structure to the microscopic level. Shows how cells are assembled into tissues, and tissues into organs, with an emphasis on demonstrating how microscopic structure explains function.

cha.name: — Human Clinical Neuroanatomy
cha.description: Course Description: Clinically relevant anatomy of the normal human nervous system, including external and internal anatomy of the brain, spinal cord, and cranial nerves. Blood supply to the brain and spinal cord. Functional neuroanatomy of motor, sensory, and cognitive systems. Application of neuroanatomical principles relevant to clinical problem solving for students entering health care professions.
cha.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHA 101; or consent of instructor.

cha.name: — Internship in Morphology
cha.description: Course Description: Experience of supervised internship in research laboratories of members of the department.
cha.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; laboratory science experience including some chemistry; approval of project by preceptor prior to period of internship.

cha.name: — Tutoring in Cell Biology & Human Anatomy
cha.description: Course Description: Provides laboratory instruction in gross and microscopic human anatomy, with small groups of undergraduates under the supervision of the instructor.
cha.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHA 101 B or better; and consent of instructor.

cha.name: — Directed Group Study
cha.description: Course Description: Directed reading, discussion, and/or laboratory experience on selected topics.

cha.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
cha.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

cha.name: — Graduate Human Gross Anatomy
cha.description: Course Description: Lectures on human gross anatomy and cadaver dissection laboratory. Topics arranged by region; emphasis on osteology, neuromuscular anatomy, cardiovascular anatomy, gastrointestinal anatomy and anatomy of reproductive systems.

cha.name: — Microscopic Anatomy for Researchers
cha.description: Course Description: The growing importance of the use of gene knock-out studies and imaging technology requires significant understanding of basic anatomy. Designed to familiarize students in diverse fields with anatomical, cellular and tissue organization of typical animal models.

cha.name: — Neurobiology
cha.description: Course Description: Physiology and anatomy of the normal human nervous system in an integrated format.
cha.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Two upper division or one graduate course in Neurobiology.

cha.name: — Seminar
cha.description: Course Description: Seminar.

cha.name: — Research Group Conference
cha.description: Course Description: Discussion of problems, progress and literature groups relevant to current research undertaken by laboratory groups Human Anatomy.
cha.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Graduate student with research experience (may be taken concurrently).

cha.name: — Advanced Group Study
cha.description: Course Description: Advanced group study.

cha.name: — Research
cha.description: Course Description: Research.

cha.name: — Developmental, Gross & Radiologic Anatomy
cha.description: Course Description: Integrated presentation of developmental, gross and radiologic anatomy. Embryology and radiology correlated with the dissection of the entire body. Embryology from implantation to birth.

cha.name: — Cell & Tissue Biology
cha.description: Course Description: Microscopic structure of the basic cells, tissues and organs of the body with an emphasis on how structure explains function. Analysis and identification of sectioned material at the light microscopic and ultrastructural levels.

cha.name: — Medical Neuroanatomy
cha.description: Course Description: Anatomy of the normal human nervous system, to include gross external and internal morphology of brain and spinal cord, and function neuroanatomy of motor, sensory and cognitive systems. Incorporates application of neuroanatomy to clinical problem solving.

cha.name: — Anatomy Medical Education Special Study Module
cha.description: Course Description: Attend all of the lectures and laboratory sessions for CHA 400 and CHA 402 during the four-week section; approximately seven anatomy labs and three-four histology labs. Tutor first-year students during the laboratory sessions. Prepare and present a clinical correlate session.
cha.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. UC Davis School of Medicine students only.

cha.name: — Tutoring in Human Anatomy
cha.description: Course Description: Assist instructor by tutoring medical students in preparation for one of the departmental courses that is a component of the required curriculum for the School of Medicine.
cha.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Advanced standing or consent of instructor.

cha.name: — Advanced Group Study
cha.description: Course Description: Directed reading and group discussions and/or laboratory experience on selected topics.
cha.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical students, interns, and residents with consent of instructor.

cha.name: — Research
cha.description: Course Description: Research.

ech.name: — Design of Coffee–An Introduction to Chemical Engineering
ech.description: Course Description: Non-mathematical introduction to how chemical engineers think, illustrated by elucidation of the process of roasting and brewing coffee. Qualitative overview of the basic principles of engineering analysis and design. Corresponding experiments testing design choices on the sensory qualities of coffee.

ech.name: — Design of Coffee–An Introduction to Chemical Engineering
ech.description: Course Description: Non-mathematical introduction to how chemical engineers think, illustrated by elucidation of the process of roasting and brewing coffee. Qualitative overview of the basic principles of engineering analysis and design. Corresponding experiments testing design choices on the sensory qualities of coffee.

ech.name: — Introduction to Analysis & Design in Chemical Engineering
ech.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Quantitative introduction to the engineering principles of analysis and design. Applications of differential and integral calculus. Laboratory experiments using coffee to illustrate chemical engineering concepts and to conduct an engineering design competition.

ech.name: — Material Balances
ech.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Application of the principle of conservation of mass to single and multicomponent systems in chemical process calculations. Studies of batch, semi-batch, and continuous processes involving mass transfer, phase change, and reaction stoichiometry.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 021C C- or better; MAT 021D (can be concurrent).

ech.name: — Numerical Methods in Engineering
ech.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Problem solving in chemical, biochemical and materials engineering using MATLAB. Programming styles, data structures, working with lists, functions and rules. Applications drawn from material balances, statistics, numerical methods, bioinformatics, transport phenomena, kinetics, and computational analysis.

ech.name: — Chemical Engineering Profession
ech.description: Course Description: Professional opportunities and professional responsibilities of chemical engineers. Opportunities and needs for post-baccalaureate education. Relationship of chemical engineering to contemporary issues.

ech.name: — Honors Discussion Section
ech.description: Course Description: Examination of special topics covered in selected lower division courses through additional readings, discussions, collaborative work, or special activities which may include projects, laboratory experience or computer simulations.

ech.name: — Directed Group Study
ech.description: Course Description: Directed Group Study.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Lower division standing.

ech.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
ech.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.

ech.name: — Mathematical Methods in Biochemical & Chemical Engineering
ech.description: Course Description: Mathematical methods for solving problems in chemical and biochemical engineering, with emphasis on transport phenomena. Fourier series and separation of variables. Sturm-Liouville eigenvalue problems. Similarity transformations. Tensor analysis. Finite difference methods for solving time-dependent diffusion problems.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 022B; (ECH 060 or ENG 006); or equivalents of ECH 060 or ENG 006.

ech.name: — Fluid Mechanics for Biochemical & Chemical Engineers
ech.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Principles and applications of fluid mechanics in chemical and biochemical engineering. Hydrostatics. Stress tensor and Newton's law of viscosity.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECH 051 C- or better; ECH 140.

ech.name: — Heat Transfer for Biochemical & Chemical Engineers
ech.description: Course Description: Conduction, convection, and radiation of thermal energy in applications to chemical and biochemical engineering. Derivation of thermal and mechanical energy equations. Thermal boundary layers. Macroscopic balances. Applications: heat transfer in tubes, channels, and integrated circuits, and analysis of heat exchangers.

ech.name: — Mass Transfer for Biochemical & Chemical Engineers
ech.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Derivation of species conservation equations describing convective and diffusive mass transfer. Fick's law and the Stefan-Maxwell constitutive equations. Mass transfer coefficients. Multicomponent mass transfer across gas/liquid interfaces. Applications include drying, heterogeneous chemical reactions, and membrane separations.

ech.name: — Rheology & Polymer Processing
ech.description: Course Description: Deformation in steady shear, unsteady shear, and elongational flows. Linear and non-linear viscoelastic constitutive models. The principle of material indifference and admissibility of constitutive equations. Introduction to the unit operations of polymer processing.

ech.name: — Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics Laboratory
ech.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Laboratory experiments in chemical engineering thermodynamics.

ech.name: — Chemical Engineering Transport Lab
ech.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Laboratory experiments in chemical engineering transport phenomena.

ech.name: — Chemical Kinetics & Reaction Engineering
ech.description: Course Description: Ideal chemical reactors. Rate laws and stoichiometry. Design and analysis of isothermal reactors with multiple reactions.

ech.name: — Chemical Kinetics & Reaction Engineering
ech.description: Course Description: Design and analysis of non-isothermal reactors. Reactions in packed beds with pressure drop. Adsorption and heterogeneous catalysis. Transport limitations.

ech.name: — Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics
ech.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Application of principles of thermodynamics to chemical processes.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECH 060 or ENG 006; or equivalents.

ech.name: — Chemical Engineering Thermodynamics
ech.description: Course Description: Continuation of ECH 152A.

ech.name: — Chemical Engineering Kinetics & Reactor Design Laboratory
ech.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Laboratory experiments in chemical kinetics, reactor design and process control.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECH 145B; ECH 148A; ECH 148B (can be concurrent); ECH 157 (can be concurrent); upper division English composition requirement (can be concurrent).

ech.name: — Process Dynamics & Control
ech.description: Course Description: Fundamentals of dynamics and modeling of chemical processes. Design and analysis of feedback control of chemical processes.

ech.name: — Process Economics & Green Design
ech.description: Course Description: Senior design experience in process and product creation and design with multiple realistic constraints. Cost accounting and capital investment estimation. Profitability analysis techniques. Green chemistry, health risk assessment and life cycle assessment concepts.

ech.name: — Separations & Unit Operations
ech.description: Course Description: Senior design experience with multiple realistic constraints. Heuristic and rigorous design of chemical process equipment. Separation by filtration, distillation and extraction. Synthesis of reactor and separation networks, heat and power integration.

ech.name: — Plant Design Project
ech.description: Course Description: Senior design experience for chemical and biochemical processes. Impact of multiple realistic constraints. Design, costing and profitability analysis of complete plants. Use of computer-aided design techniques.

ech.name: — Fundamentals of Biomanufacturing
ech.description: Course Description: Principles of large scale bioreactor production of metabolites, enzymes, and recombinant proteins including the development of strains/cell lines, fermentor/bioreactor design, monitoring and operation, product recovery and purification, and biomanufacturing economics.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MIC 102 or BIS 102 or ABI 102.

ech.name: — Biochemical Engineering Fundamentals
ech.description: Course Description: Biokinetics; bioreactor design and operation; transport phenomena in bioreactors; microbial, plant, and animal cell cultures.

ech.name: — Bioseparations
ech.description: Course Description: Product recovery and purification of biochemicals. Cell disruption, centrifugation, filtration, membrane separations, extraction, and chromatographic separation.

ech.name: — Biotechnology Facility Design & Regulatory Compliance
ech.description: Course Description: Design of biotechnology manufacturing facilities. Fermentation and purification equipment, and utility systems. Introduction to current good manufacturing practices, regulatory compliance, and documentation.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECH 158A,  ECH 161A (can be concurrent),  ECH 161B (can be concurrent)) or DEB 263 (can be concurrent).

ech.name: — Bioprocess Engineering Laboratory
ech.description: Course Description: Laboratory experiments in the operation and analysis of bioreactors; determination of oxygen mass transfer coefficients in bioreactors and ion exchange chromatography.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECH 145B,  ECH 161A,  ECH 161B) or VEN 186 or (BIS 103,  MCB 120L).

ech.name: — Catalysis
ech.description: Course Description: Principles of catalysis based on an integration of principles of physical, organic, and inorganic chemistry and chemical kinetics and chemical reaction engineering. Catalysis in solution; catalysis by enzymes; catalysis in swellable polymers; catalysis in microscopic cages (zeolites); catalysis on surfaces.

ech.name: — Chemical & Engineering Principles in Whisky & Fuel Alcohol Production
ech.description: Course Description: Chemical & engineering principles underlying the manufacture of whisky & fuel alcohol. Biochemistry of malting. Assessment of grain modification & diastatic power, and of the phenol content of peated malt. Lautering as a problem of fluidized bed compaction. Fermentation and its assessment. Fractional distillation and the Rayleigh equation. The fate of congeners in pot and column distillation. Chemical reactions affecting flavor from kilning to maturation.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 128A; CHE 128B (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

ech.name: — The Design of Cocktails: Applied Thermodynamics & Transport Phenomena in Mixed Drinks
ech.description: Course Description: Scientific and engineering principles underlying the preparation of mixed drinks. Thermodynamics and kinetics of ice crystallization; phase diagram of ethanol-water-ice mixtures; mass transfer of aromatics; solubility of sucrose and carbon dioxide; colloidal behavior of dispersed solids and emulsified oils. Corresponding laboratory experiments testing the effect of design choices on the sensory quality of cocktails.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECH 145B; ECH 152B; consent of instructor.

ech.name: — Introduction to Colloid & Surface Phenomena
ech.description: Course Description: Introduction to the behavior of surfaces and disperse systems. Fundamentals will be applied to the solution of practical problems in colloid science. Should be of value to engineers, chemists, biologists, soil scientists, and related disciplines.

ech.name: — Research Group Conference
ech.description: Course Description: Research group conferences.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing in Chemical Engineering.

ech.name: — Honors Discussion Section
ech.description: Course Description: Examination of special topics covered in selected upper division courses through additional readings, discussions, collaborative work, or special activities which may include projects, laboratory experience or computer simulations.

ech.name: — Internship in Chemical or Biochemical Engineering
ech.description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in Chemical or Biochemical Engineering.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of a minimum of 84 units; project approval before period of internship.

ech.name: — Group Study
ech.description: Course Description: Group study.

ech.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
ech.description: Course Description: Special study.

ech.name: — Preparing for Graduate Student Success
ech.description: Course Description: Introduction to the soft-skills and campus resources needed to succeed in graduate school. Emphasis on the student-mentor relationship and the process of selecting a research mentor.

ech.name: — Biochemical Engineering
ech.description: Course Description: Interaction of chemical engineering, biochemistry, and microbiology. Mathematical representations of microbial systems. Kinetics of growth, death, and metabolism. Continuous fermentation, agitation, mass transfer and scale-up in fermentation systems, product recovery, enzyme technology.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MIC 102; MIC 102L; BIS 101; BIS 102; BIS 103; MCB 120L; MCB 200A; or consent of instructor; FST 205 recommended.

ech.name: — Enzyme Engineering
ech.description: Course Description: Application of basic biochemical and engineering principles of practical enzymatic processes. Lectures cover large scale production and separation of enzymes, immobilized enzyme systems, enzyme related biotechnology, reactor design and optimization, and new application of enzymes in genetic engineering.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MIC 102; MIC 102L; BIS 102; BIS 103; MCB 122; MCB 120L; MCB 200A; or consent of instructor.

ech.name: — Micro- & Nano-Technology in Life Sciences
ech.description: Course Description: Survey of biodevice design from engineering and biological perspectives; micro-/nano-fabrication techniques; surface science and mass transport; essential biological processes and models; proposal development skills on merging aforementioned themes.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

ech.name: — Advanced Biochemical Engineering
ech.description: Course Description: Advances in the field of biotechnology including genetic engineering, enzyme engineering, fermentation science, and renewable resources development. The important results of original research will be evaluated for understanding of the fundamental principles and for potential practical application.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECH 206; or consent of instructor.

ech.name: — Statistical Thermodynamics
ech.description: Course Description: A treatment of the statistical basis of thermodynamics;introduction to statistical mechanics; discussion of the laws of thermodynamics; application of thermodynamic relationships to phase and chemical reaction equilibrium; introduction to molecular simulations and the evaluation of thermodynamic properties from molecular simulations.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECH 152B; ENG 105B or the equivalent.

ech.name: — Advanced Fluid Mechanics
ech.description: Course Description: Kinematics and basic principles of fluid flow. Principles of constitutive equations. Navier-Stokes equations for Newtonian fluids. Survey of rectilinear creeping flow, lubrication flow and boundary layer theory.

ech.name: — Advanced Heat Transport
ech.description: Course Description: Fundamental energy postulates and derivation of microscopic and macroscopic energy equations. Mechanisms of conduction. Isotropic, thermoelastic and anisotropic materials solution problems using Greens functions and perturbation theory.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECH 142; ECH 259; or the equivalent.

ech.name: — Advanced Mass Transfer
ech.description: Course Description: Kinematics and basic conservation principles for multicomponent systems. Constitutive equations for momentum, heat and mass transfer, applications to binary and ternary systems. Details of diffusion with reaction, and the effects of concentration.

ech.name: — Colloid & Surface Phenomena
ech.description: Course Description: Thermodynamics and rate processes at interfaces. These fundamental processes will be applied to determine the collective properties of thin films and membranes, self-assembled systems, liquid crystals and colloidal systems. Experimental techniques in surface analysis.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in science or engineering or consent of instructor.

ech.name: — Chemical Kinetics & Reaction Engineering
ech.description: Course Description: Analysis of the performance of chemical reactors and design of chemical reactors based on the principles of chemical kinetics and transport phenomena. Consideration of noncatalytic/catalytic reactions in single fluid phases and emphasis on reactions in multiphase mixtures, especially gas-solid reactors.

ech.name: — Advanced Engineering Mathematics
ech.description: Course Description: Applications of methods of applied mathematics to the analytical and numerical solution of linear and nonlinear ordinary and partial differential equations arising in the study of transport phenomena.

ech.name: — Molecular Modelling of Soft & Biological Matter
ech.description: Course Description: Modern molecular simulation techniques with a focus on soft matter like polymers, biologically relevant systems, and glasses.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EMS 247 or ECH 252; or equivalent course in advanced thermodynamics/statistical mechanics.

ech.name: — Transport Phenomena in Multiphase Systems
ech.description: Course Description: Heat, mass and momentum transfer in multiphase, multicomponent systems with special emphasis on transport processes in porous media. Derivation of the averaging theorem and application of the method of volume averaging to multicomponent, reacting systems.

ech.name: — Rheology & Mechanics of Non-Newtonian Fluids
ech.description: Course Description: Mechanics of polymer solutions and suspension, especially the development of properly invariant constitutive equations. Topics include: viscometry, linear and nonlinear viscoelasticity, continuum mechanics, kinetic theory.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECH 253A; ECH 259; or consent of instructor.

ech.name: — Emulsions, Microemulsions & Bilayers
ech.description: Course Description: Thermodynamic and mechanical descriptions of surfactant-laden interfaces. Forces between and within interfaces. Physics of micelle and microemulsion formation. Structure and stability of emulsions. Properties of phospholipid bilayers, with emphasis on vesicles.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): An undergraduate course in physical chemistry.

ech.name: — Advanced Process Control
ech.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Advanced course in analysis and synthesis of linear multivariable systems. Emphasis on frequency domain techniques and applications to chemical processes. Topics include singular value analysis, internal model control, robust controller design methods as well as self-tuning control techniques.

ech.name: — Polysaccharides Surface Interactions
ech.description: Course Description: Study of fundamental surface science theories as applied to physical and chemical interactions of carbohydrates and polysaccharides.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate students in science or engineering.

ech.name: — Cell & Molecular Biophysics for Bioengineers
ech.description: Course Description: Introduction to fundamental mechanisms governing the structure, function, and assembly of bio-macromolecules. Emphasis is on a quantitative understanding of the nano-to-microscale interactions between and within individual molecules, as well as of their assemblies, in particular membranes.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIM 284; or equivalent; graduate standing; undergraduate students by consent of instructor.

ech.name: — Organic Electronic Materials, Processing & Devices
ech.description: Course Description: Organic electronic materials synthesis and molecular design, methods for device fabrication, optical and electrical characteristics of the devices, discussion of the technology readiness, and a broad survey of methods used to characterize organic electronic materials and devices.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate major in Chemistry, Physics or Engineering discipline or consent of instructor.

ech.name: — Special Topics in Chemical Engineering: Fluid Mechanics
ech.description: Course Description: Special topics in Fluid Mechanics.

ech.name: — Special Topics in Chemical Engineering: Nonlinear Analysis & Numerical Methods
ech.description: Course Description: Special topics in Nonlinear Analysis and Numerical Methods.

ech.name: — Special Topics in Chemical Engineering: Process Control
ech.description: Course Description: Special topics in Process Control.

ech.name: — Special Topics in Chemical Engineering: Chemistry of Catalytic Processes
ech.description: Course Description: Special topics in Chemistry of Catalytic Processes.

ech.name: — Special Topics in Chemical Engineering: Biotechnology
ech.description: Course Description: Special topics in Biotechnology.

ech.name: — Special Topics in Chemical Engineering: Interfacial Engineering
ech.description: Course Description: Special topics in Interfacial Engineering.

ech.name: — Special Topics in Chemical Engineering: Molecular Thermodynamics
ech.description: Course Description: Special topics in Molecular Thermodynamics.

ech.name: — Special Topics in Chemical Engineering: Membrane Separations
ech.description: Course Description: Special topics in Membrane Separations.

ech.name: — Special Topics in Chemical Engineering: Advanced Materials Processing
ech.description: Course Description: Special topics in Advanced Materials Processing.

ech.name: — Special Topics in Chemical Engineering: Novel Experimental Methods
ech.description: Course Description: Special topics in Novel Experimental Methods.

ech.name: — Special Topics in Chemical Engineering: Advanced Transport Phenomena
ech.description: Course Description: Special topics in Advanced Transport Phenomena.

ech.name: — Special Topics in Chemical Engineering: Biomolecular Engineering
ech.description: Course Description: Special topics in Biomolecular Engineering.

ech.name: — Seminar
ech.description: Course Description: Seminar.

ech.name: — Graduate Research Group Conference
ech.description: Course Description: Research problems, progress and techniques in chemical engineering.

ech.name: — Current Progress in Biotechnology
ech.description: Course Description: Seminars presented by guest lecturers on subjects of their own research activities.

ech.name: — Group Study
ech.description: Course Description: Group study.

ech.name: — Research
ech.description: Course Description: Research.

ech.name: — Teaching of Chemical Engineering
ech.description: Course Description: Participation as a teaching assistant or associate-in in a designated engineering course. Methods of leading discussion groups or laboratory sections, writing and grading quizzes, use of laboratory equipment, and grading laboratory reports.
ech.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; qualifications and acceptance as teaching assistant and/or associate-in in chemical engineering.

che.name: — Preparation for General Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Preparation for the general chemistry series (CHE 002ABC & CHE 004ABC); unit conversion, dimensional analysis, periodic table, chemical equations, stoichiometry, and gases.

che.name: — General Chemistry
che.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Periodic table, stoichiometry, chemical equations, physical properties and kinetic theory of gases, chemical equilibrium, acids and bases. Laboratory experiments in stoichiometric relations, properties and collection of gases, atomic spectroscopy, introductory quantitative analysis and acids and bases.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): High school chemistry and physics, and concurrent enrollment in mathematics at or above the level of MAT 012 strongly recommended; must earn a qualifying score of 24 or better on the Chemistry Placement Exam; ore information about the Chemistry Placement Requirements to ensure enrollment in CHE 002A can be found at https://chemistry.ucdavis.edu/undergraduate/general-chemistry-series/chemistry-placement-requirements.

che.name: — Honors General Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Limited enrollment course with a more rigorous treatment of material covered in CHE 002A. Students completing CHE 002AH can continue with CHE 002BH or CHE 002B.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; high school chemistry and physics, and concurrent enrollment in mathematics at or above the level of MAT 012 strongly recommended; must earn a qualifying score of 33 or better on the Chemistry Placement Exam; more information about the Chemistry Placement Requirements to ensure enrollment in CHE 002A can be found at https://chemistry.ucdavis.edu/undergraduate/general-chemistry-series/chemistry-placement-requirements.

che.name: — General Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Continuation of CHE 002A. Thermodynamics, atomic and molecular structure and chemical bonding, condensed phases and intermolecular forces, solubility. Laboratory experiments in thermochemistry, equilibria, and quantitative analysis using volumetric methods.

che.name: — Honors General Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Limited enrollment course with a more rigorous treatment of material covered in CHE 002B. Students completing CHE 002BH can continue with CHE 002CH or CHE 002C.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 002A or CHE 002AH C or better; MAT 021B (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor; CHE 002A with consent of instructor.

che.name: — General Chemistry
che.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Continuation of CHE 002B. Kinetics, electrochemistry, spectroscopy, structure and bonding in transition metal compounds, application of principles to chemical reactions. Laboratory experiments in selected analytical methods and syntheses.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 002B C- or better or CHE 002BH C- or better.

che.name: — Honors General Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Limited enrollment course with a more rigorous treatment of material covered in CHE 002C.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 002B or CHE 002BH C or better; MAT 021C (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor; CHE 002B with consent of instructor.

che.name: — Chemistry for Life Sciences: Determining Structure & Predicting Properties
che.description: Course Description: Integrated General and Organic Chemistry intended for majors in the life sciences. Core concepts of chemical composition, structure and properties. Includes phase changes, separation methods, composition, spectroscopy, atomic & molecular structure, periodicity, bonding, charge distribution, intermolecular forces, and physical properties.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): High school chemistry and physics strongly recommended; satisfactory score on the Chemistry and Mathematics Placement Examinations or satisfactory completion of the ALEKS Summer Chemistry Prep Course; a satisfactory grade in WKL 041C ('P' or 'C' or better) will suffice in lieu of a satisfactory Chemistry Placement Examination score.

che.name: — Chemistry for Life Sciences: Predicting & Characterizing Chemical Change
che.description: Course Description: Continuation of CHE 003A covering core concepts of characterization of chemical processes and predicting chemical changes. Includes modeling chemical reactions, understanding proportions/stoichiometry, tracking energy, activation energy, reaction kinetics, thermodynamics, and equilibrium.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 003A C- or better; note: C- or better in CHE 002A or 002AH does not satisfy the prerequisite requirement.

che.name: — Chemistry for Life Sciences: Controlling Processes & Synthetic Pathways
che.description: Course Description: Continuation of CHE 003B covering core concepts of harnessing energy, controlling reaction extent, and organic chemistry synthetic pathways. Includes acids and bases, thermodynamics, chemical equilibria, organic chemistry terminology and mechanisms.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 003B C- or better; note: C- or better in CHE 002B or 002BH does not satisfy the prerequisite requirement.

che.name: — General Chemistry for the Physical Sciences & Engineering
che.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: General chemistry course with a more rigorous treatment of material covered in CHE 002A, intended for students majoring in the physical sciences and engineering. Students completing CHE 004A can continue with CHE 004B or CHE 002B.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): High school chemistry and physics, and concurrent enrollment in mathematics at or above the level of MAT 012 strongly recommended; must earn a qualifying score of 28 or better on the Chemistry Placement Exam; more information about the Chemistry Placement Requirements to ensure enrollment in CHE 004A can be found at https://chemistry.ucdavis.edu/undergraduate/general-chemistry-series/chemistry-placement-requirements.

che.name: — General Chemistry for the Physical Sciences & Engineering
che.description: Course Description: General chemistry course with a more rigorous treatment of material covered in CHE 002B, intended for students majoring in the physical sciences and engineering.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 021B (can be concurrent); (CHE 004A C- or better or CHE 002AH C- or better); or consent of instructor.

che.name: — General Chemistry for the Physical Sciences & Engineering
che.description: Course Description: General chemistry course with a more rigorous treatment of material covered in CHE 002C, intended for students majoring in the physical sciences and engineering.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 021C (can be concurrent); (CHE 004B C- or better or CHE 002B B or better or CHE 002BH B or better); or consent of instructor.

che.name: — Organic Chemistry: Brief Course
che.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: With CHE 008B, an introduction to the nomenclature, structure, chemistry, and reaction mechanisms of organic compounds. Intended for students majoring in areas other than organic chemistry.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 002B C- or better or CHE 002BH C- or better.

che.name: — Organic Chemistry: Brief Course
che.description: Course Description: Laboratory concerned primarily with organic laboratory techniques and the chemistry of the common classes of organic compounds. Lecture portion a continuation of CHE 008A.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 008A or CHE 118A or CHE 128A.

che.name: — Concept of Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Survey of basic concepts and contemporary applications of chemistry. Designed for non-science majors and not as preparation for CHE  002A.

che.name: — Directed Group Study
che.description: Course Description: Primarily for lower division students.

che.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
che.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.May be taught abroad.

che.name: — Environmental Water Chemistry
che.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Practical aspects of water chemistry in the environment, including thermodynamic relations, coordination chemistry, solubility calculations, redox reactions and rate laws. Computer modeling of the evolution in water chemistry from contact with minerals and gases.

che.name: — Chemistry for Life Sciences: Determining Organic Structures & Properties
che.description: Course Description: Continuation of PHE 003C. Core concepts of organic structure, nomenclature, functional groups, organic acids and bases, resonance and delocalization, aromaticity, intermolecular forces, three-dimensional structure and conformational analysis, spectroscopy.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 002C C- or better or CHE 002CH C- or better; (CHE 008A or CHE 118A or CHE 128A).

che.name: — Chemistry for Life Sciences: Predicting & Controlling Organic Pathways
che.description: Course Description: Continuation of CHE 103A. Core concepts of functional group transformations, synthesis, mechanisms, sustainable chemistry, structure and function of biomolecules, organic reactions in biological systems, molecular design, detection, separation, and identification of organic molecules.

che.name: — Forensic Applications of Analytical Chemistry
che.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Theory and application of standard methods of chemical analysis to evidentiary samples. Use and evaluation of results from screening tests, FTIR, GC and GCMS to various sample types encountered in forensics.

che.name: — Analytical & Physical Chemical Methods
che.description: Course Description: Fundamental theory and laboratory techniques in; analytical and physical chemistry, errors and data analysis methods, basic electrical circuits in instruments, advanced solution equilibria, potentiometric analysis, chromatographic separations, UV-visible spectroscopy, lasers.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 110A (can be concurrent) or CHE 107B (can be concurrent).

che.name: — Physical Chemistry for the Life Sciences
che.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Physical chemistry intended for majors in the life science area. Introductory development of classical and statistical thermodynamics including equilibrium processes and solutions of both non-electrolytes and electrolytes. The thermodynamic basis of electrochemistry and membrane potentials.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 002C or CHE 002CH; (MAT 016C or MAT 017C or MAT 021C); (PHY 007C or PHY 009C or PHY 009HC).

che.name: — Physical Chemistry for the Life Sciences
che.description: Course Description: Continuation of CHE 107A. Kinetic theory of gases and transport processes in liquids. Chemical kinetics, enzyme kinetics and theories of reaction rates. Introduction to quantum theory, atomic and molecular structure, and spectroscopy. Application to problems in the biological sciences.

che.name: — Molecular Biochemistry
che.description: Course Description: Chemical principles and experimental methods applied to the biological sciences to understand the molecular structure and function of proteins, nucleic acids, carbohydrates, and membrane lipids.

che.name: — Physical Chemistry: Introduction to Quantum Mechanics
che.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduction to the postulates and general principles of quantum mechanics. Approximations based on variational method and time independent perturbation theory. Application to harmonic oscillator, rigid rotor, one-electron and many-electron atoms, and homo-and hetero-nuclear diatomic molecules.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PHY 007C or PHY 009C or PHY 009HC); (CHE 002C or CHE 002CH); (MAT 016C or MAT 017C or MAT 021C); completion of MAT 021D, MAT 022A, MAT 022AL; PHY 009C or PHY 009HC, strongly recommended.

che.name: — Physical Chemistry: Properties of Atoms & Molecules
che.description: Course Description: Group theory. Application of quantum mechanics to polyatomic molecules and molecular spectroscopy. Intermolecular forces and the gas, liquid and solid states. Distributions, ensembles and partition functions. Transport properties.

che.name: — Physical Chemistry: Thermodynamics, Equilibria & Kinetics
che.description: Course Description: Development and application of the general principles of thermodynamics and statistical thermodynamics. Chemical kinetics, rate laws for chemical reactions and reaction mechanisms.

che.name: — Instrumental Analysis
che.description: Course Description: Intermediate theory and laboratory techniques in analytical and physical chemistry. Advanced data analysis methods and goodness-of-fit criteria. Fourier-transform spectroscopic methods and instrumentation. Mass spectrometry. Electrochemistry. Liquid chromatography.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 105; (CHE 110B (can be concurrent) or (CHE 107A,  CHE 107B)).

che.name: — Organic Chemistry for Health & Life Sciences
che.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: The 118A-C series is for students planning professional school studies in health and life sciences. Rigorous, in-depth presentation of basic principles with emphasis on stereochemistry and spectroscopy and preparations and reactions of nonaromatic hydrocarbons, haloalkanes, alcohols and ethers.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 002C C- or better or CHE 002CH C- or better.

che.name: — Organic Chemistry for Health & Life Sciences
che.description: Course Description: Continuation of CHE 118A, with emphasis on spectroscopy and the preparation and reactions of aromatic hydrocarbons, organometallic compounds, aldehydes and ketones.

che.name: — Organic Chemistry for Health & Life Sciences
che.description: Course Description: Continuation of CHE 118B, with emphasis on the preparation, reactions and identification of carboxylic acids and their derivatives, alkyl and acyl amines, ß-dicarbonyl compounds, and various classes of naturally occurring, biologically important compounds.

che.name: — Introduction to Molecular Structure & Spectra
che.description: Course Description: Modern theoretical and experimental methods used to study problems of molecular structure and bonding; emphasis on spectroscopic techniques.

che.name: — Chemistry of Nanoparticles
che.description: Course Description: Chemical and physical aspects of inorganic nanoparticles. Topics include synthesis, structure, colloidal behavior, catalytic activity, size and shape dependency of physical properties, analytical methods and applications.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 110C (can be concurrent) or CHE 107B (can be concurrent).

che.name: — Inorganic Chemistry: Fundamentals
che.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Symmetry, molecular geometry and structure, molecular orbital theory of bonding (polyatomic molecules and transition metals), solid state chemistry, energetics and spectroscopy of inorganic compounds.

che.name: — Inorganic Chemistry: Main Group Elements
che.description: Course Description: Synthesis, structure and reactivity of inorganic and heteroorganic molecules containing the main group elements.

che.name: — Inorganic Chemistry: D & F Block Elements
che.description: Course Description: Synthesis, structure and reactivity of transition metal complexes, organometallic and bioinorganic chemistry, the lanthanides and actinides.

che.name: — Laboratory Methods in Inorganic Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: The preparation, purification and characterization of main group and transition metal inorganic and organometallic compounds.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 124B or CHE 124C (can be concurrent).

che.name: — Advanced Methods in Physical Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Advanced theory and laboratory techniques in analytical and physical chemistry. Advanced spectroscopic methods. Thermodynamics. Kinetics. Chemical literature. Digital electronics and computer interfacing. Laboratory measurements and vacuum techniques.

che.name: — Organic Chemistry
che.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduction to the basic concepts of organic chemistry with emphasis on stereochemistry and the chemistry of hydrocarbons. Designed primarily for majors in chemistry. Chemistry majors should enroll in CHE 129A concurrently. May be taught abroad.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 002C C or better or CHE 002CH C or better.

che.name: — Organic Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Continuation of CHE 128A with emphasis on the chemistry of alcohols, ethers, their sulfur analogs, and carbonyl compounds. Introduction to the application of spectroscopic methods to organic chemistry. Introduction to synthesis of moderately complex organic molecules. May be taught abroad.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 128A; or consent of instructor.

che.name: — Organic Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Continuation of CHE 128B with emphasis on enolate condensations and the chemistry of amines, phenols, and sugars; selected biologically important compounds. May be taught abroad.

che.name: — Organic Chemistry Laboratory
che.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduction to laboratory techniques of organic chemistry. Emphasis on methods used for separation and purification of organic compounds. May be taught abroad.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (CHE 002C C or better or CHE 002CH C or better); CHE 128A (can be concurrent).

che.name: — Organic Chemistry Laboratory
che.description: Course Description: Continuation of CHE 129A. Emphasis on methods used for synthesis and isolation of organic compounds.

che.name: — Organic Chemistry Laboratory
che.description: Course Description: continuation of PHE 129B.

che.name: — Pharmaceutical Chemistry
che.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Examination of the design principles and experimental methods used in pharmaceutical and medicinal chemistry. May be taught abroad.

che.name: — Pharmaceutical Chemistry
che.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Continuation of CHE 130A with emphasis on case studies of various drugs and the use of computational methods in drug design. May be taught abroad.

che.name: — Case Studies in Pharmaceutical Chemistry
che.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Seminar. Exploration of medicinal and pharmaceutical chemistry topics through seminars presented by professional chemists (and allied professionals). Designed to highlight career opportunities for students with a degree in pharmaceutical chemistry.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 130A (can be concurrent); CHE 130B (can be concurrent).

che.name: — Modern Methods of Organic Synthesis
che.description: Course Description: Introduction to modern synthetic methodology in organic chemistry with emphasis on retrosynthetic analysis, reaction mechanisms, and application to multistep syntheses of pharmaceuticals and natural products.

che.name: — Advanced Bio-organic Chemistry Laboratory
che.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Separation, purification, identification and biological evaluation of organic compounds using modern methods of synthesis, computational chemistry and instrumentation. Emphasis on pharmaceutical and medicinal substances.

che.name: — Good Quality Practices
che.description: Course Description: Preparation for work in GQP laboratories in both research and industry. Context within GQP-Good Quality Practices (GMP Good Manufacturing Practice, GCP Good Clinical Practices). Lab practice in GQP skills.

che.name: — Chemistry of Natural Products
che.description: Course Description: Chemistry of terpenes, steroids, acetogenins, and alkaloids: isolation, structure determination, biosynthesis, chemical transformations, and total synthesis. May be taught abroad.

che.name: — Scientific Programming for Chemistry
che.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Chemical applications of computer programming with Python. Numpy, Scipy, Matplotlib libraries. Multidimensional arrays, data visualization, linear algebra routines. Force fields and molecular dynamics simulations. Numerical integration of differential equations with applications to chemical kinetics. Least squares fitting of experimental data.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECS 010 or ECS 032A; or equivalent; or consent of instructor.

che.name: — Chemical & Engineering Principles in Whisky & Fuel Alcohol Production
che.description: Course Description: Chemical & engineering principles underlying the manufacture of whisky & fuel alcohol. Biochemistry of malting. Assessment of grain modification & diastatic power, and of the phenol content of peated malt. Lautering as a problem of fluidized bed compaction. Fermentation and its assessment. Fractional distillation and the Rayleigh equation. The fate of congeners in pot and column distillation. Chemical reactions affecting flavor from kilning to maturation.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 128A; CHE 128B (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

che.name: — Internship in Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Supervised internship in chemistry; requires a final written report.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; project approval by faculty sponsor prior to enrollment.

che.name: — Undergraduate Honors Research
che.description: Course Description: Original research under the guidance of a faculty advisor, culminating in the writing of an extensive report.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open only to chemistry majors who have completed 135 units and who qualify for the honors program.

che.name: — Undergraduate Honors Research
che.description: Course Description: Original research under the guidance of a faculty advisor, culminating in the writing of an extensive report.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open only to chemistry majors who have completed 135 units and who qualify for the honors program.

che.name: — Undergraduate Honors Research
che.description: Course Description: Original research under the guidance of a faculty advisor, culminating in the writing of an extensive report.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open only to chemistry majors who have completed 135 units and who qualify for the honors program.

che.name: — Careers in Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Designed to give Chemistry undergraduate students an in-depth appreciation of career opportunities with a bachelors degree in chemistry. Professional chemists (and allied professionals) describe research and provide career insights.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Junior or senior standing in Chemistry.

che.name: — Projects in Chemical Education
che.description: Course Description: Participation may include development of laboratory experiments, lecture demonstrations, autotutorial modules or assistance with laboratory sessions.

che.name: — Directed Group Study
che.description: Course Description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor based upon adequate preparation in chemistry, mathematics and physics.

che.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
che.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates. May be taught abroad.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor based upon adequate preparation in chemistry, mathematics, and physics.

che.name: — Chemical Uses of Symmetry & Group Theory
che.description: Course Description: Symmetry elements and operations, point groups, representations of groups. Applications to molecular orbital theory, ligand field theory, molecular vibrations, and angular momentum. Crystallographic symmetry.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 124A; CHE 110B; or consent of instructor.

che.name: — Mathematical Methods in Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Introduction to mathematical and numerical methods in chemistry. Real and complex functions. Methods of integration. Differential equations. Linear algebra and matrices. Special functions. Integral transforms. Statistics.

che.name: — Symmetry, Spectroscopy, & Structure
che.description: Course Description: Vibrational and rotational spectra; electronic spectra and photoelectron spectroscopy; magnetism; electron spin and nuclear quadrapole resonance spectroscopy; nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy; other spectroscopic methods.

che.name: — Special Topics in Physical Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Advanced topics in physical chemistry, biophysical chemistry or chemical physics chosen from areas of current research interest.

che.name: — Quantum Chemistry: Introduction & Stationary-State Properties
che.description: Course Description: Stationary-state quantum chemistry: postulates of quantum mechanics, simple solutions, central field problems and angular momenta, hydrogen atom, perturbation theory, variational theory, atoms and molecules.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 110B; CHE 110C; or consent of instructor.

che.name: — Quantum Chemistry: Time-Dependent Systems
che.description: Course Description: Matrix mechanics and time-dependent quantum chemistry: matrix formulation of quantum mechanics, Heisenberg representation, time-dependent perturbation theory, selection rules, density matrices, and miscellaneous molecular properties.

che.name: — Quantum Chemistry: Molecular Spectroscopy
che.description: Course Description: Molecular spectroscopy: Born-Oppenheimer approximation, rotational, vibrational and electronic spectroscopy, spin systems, and molecular photophysics.

che.name: — Advanced Physical Chemistry: Statistical Thermodynamics
che.description: Course Description: Principles and applications of statistical mechanics; ensemble theory; statistical thermodynamics of gases, solids, liquids, electrolyte solutions and polymers; chemical equilibrium.

che.name: — Statistical Mechanics
che.description: Course Description: Statistical mechanics of nonequilibrium systems, including the rigorous kinetic theory of gases, continuum mechanics transport in dense fluids, stochastic processes, brownian motion and linear response theory.

che.name: — Chemical Dynamics
che.description: Course Description: Introduction to modern concepts in chemical reaction dynamics for graduate students in chemistry. Emphasis will be placed on experimental techniques as well as emerging physical models for characterizing chemical reactivity at a microscopic level.

che.name: — Theoretical & Computational Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Mathematics of wide utility in chemistry, computational methods for guidance or alternative to experiment, and modern formulations of chemical theory. Emphasis will vary in successive years.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 211A; CHE 210B; or consent of instructor.

che.name: — Magnetic Resonance Spectroscopy
che.description: Course Description: Quantum mechanics of spin and orbital angular momentum, nuclear magnetic resonance, theory of chemical shift and multiplet structures, electron spin resonance, theory of gtensor in organic and transition ions, spin Hamiltonians, nuclear quadrupolar resonance, spin relaxation processes.

che.name: — X-Ray Structure Determination
che.description: Course Description: Introduction to x-ray structure determination; crystals, symmetry, diffraction geometry, sample preparation and handling, diffraction apparatus and data collection, methods of structure solution and refinement, presentation of results, text, tables and graphics, crystallographic literature.

che.name: — Macromolecules: Physical Principles
che.description: Course Description: Relationship of higher order macromolecular structure to subunit composition; equilibrium properties and macromolecular dynamics; physical chemical determination of macromolecular structure.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 110A; CHE 110B; CHE 110C; or equivalent.

che.name: — Spectroscopy of Organic Compounds
che.description: Course Description: Identification of organic compounds and investigation of stereochemical and reaction mechanism phenomena using spectroscopic methods–principally NMR, IR and MS.

che.name: — Laboratory in Spectroscopy of Organic Compounds
che.description: Course Description: Practical application of NMR, IR and MS techniques for organic molecules.

che.name: — Special Topics in Organic Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Selected topics of current interest in organic chemistry. Topics will vary each time the course is offered, and in general will emphasize the research interests of the staff member giving the course.

che.name: — Special Topics in Organic Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Selected topics of current interest in organic chemistry. Topics will vary each time the course is offered, and in general will emphasize the research interests of the staff member giving the course.

che.name: — Special Topics in Organic Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Selected topics of current interest in organic chemistry. Topics will vary each time the course is offered, and in general will emphasize the research interests of the staff member giving the course.

che.name: — Special Topics in Organic Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Selected topics of current interest in organic chemistry. Topics will vary each time the course is offered, and in general will emphasize the research interests of the staff member giving the course.

che.name: — Special Topics in Organic Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Selected topics of current interest in organic chemistry. Topics will vary each time the course is offered, and in general will emphasize the research interests of the staff member giving the course.

che.name: — Special Topics in Organic Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Selected topics of current interest in organic chemistry. Topics will vary each time the course is offered, and in general will emphasize the research interests of the staff member giving the course.

che.name: — Special Topics in Organic Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Selected topics of current interest in organic chemistry. Topics will vary each time the course is offered, and in general will emphasize the research interests of the staff member giving the course.

che.name: — Special Topics in Organic Chemistry
