che.description: Course Description: Selected topics of current interest in organic chemistry. Topics will vary each time the course is offered, and in general will emphasize the research interests of the staff member giving the course.

che.name: — Chemistry of Nanoparticles
che.description: Course Description: Chemical and physical aspects of inorganic nanoparticles, including synthesis, purification, reactivity, characterization, and applications for technology. Emphasis is on problems from the current literature.

che.name: — Principles of Transition Metal Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Electronic structures, bonding, and reactivity of transition metal compounds.

che.name: — Bio-inorganic Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Defines role of inorganic chemistry in the functioning of biological systems by identifying the functions of metal ions and main group compounds in biological systems and discussing the chemistry of model and isolated biological compounds. Offered every third year.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 226; or consent of instructor.

che.name: — Main Group Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Synthesis, physical properties, reactions and bonding of main group compounds. Discussions of concepts of electron deficiency, hypervalency, and non-classical bonding. Chemistry of the main group elements will be treated systematically. Offered every third year.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 226; or consent of instructor.

che.name: — Solid-State Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Design and synthesis, structure and bonding of solid-state compounds; physical properties and characterization of solids; topics of current interest such as low-dimensional materials, inorganic polymers, materials for catalysis. Offered every third year.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 124A; CHE 110B; CHE 226; or equivalent.

che.name: — Homogeneous Catalysis
che.description: Course Description: Overview of homogeneous catalysis and related methods, with emphasis on kinetics, mechanisms, and applications for organic synthesis. The related methods may include cluster, colloid, phase transfer, enzymatic, heterogeneous and polymer-supported catalysis. Offered every third year.

che.name: — Magnetochemistry
che.description: Course Description: Covers the basic principles and concepts of magnetism, methods used for characterization of magnetic properties, as well as specific state-of-the-art magnetic materials and topics from the recent chemistry literature.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 124A or CHE 201; or an equivalent class from either Physics or Chemical Engineering and Materials Science.

che.name: — Organic Synthesis: Methods & Strategies
che.description: Course Description: Current strategies and methods in synthetic organic chemistry. Focus on construction of carbon frameworks, control of relative and absolute stereochemistry and retrosynthetic strategies. Use of databases and molecular modeling software in multistep strategies.

che.name: — Advanced Organic Synthesis
che.description: Course Description: Current strategies and methods in synthetic organic chemistry. Continuation of CHE 231A. Organic synthesis of complex target molecules. Stereochemical considerations and asymmetric synthesis. Organometallics for selective transformations. Carbocyclic and heterocyclic ring formation.

che.name: — Physical-Organic Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Introduction to elementary concepts in physicalorganic chemistry including the application of simple numerical techniques in characterizing and modeling organic reactions.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 128A; CHE 128B; CHE 128C; CHE 110A; CHE 110B; CHE 110C; or equivalent.

che.name: — Chemical & Molecular Neuroscience
che.description: Course Description: Basic principles in chemistry and molecular biology applied to questions in neuroscience. Chemical and molecular tools driving innovative work in chemical and molecular biology.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 128C; BIS 102; or equivalent courses.

che.name: — Organometallic Chemistry in Organic Synthesis
che.description: Course Description: Current trends in use of organometallics for organic synthesis; preparations, properties, applications, and limitations of organometallic reagents derived from transition and/or main group metals.

che.name: — Chemistry of Natural Products
che.description: Course Description: Advanced treatment of chemistry of naturally occurring compounds isolated from a variety of sources. Topics will include isolation, structure determination, chemical transformations, total synthesis, biological activity, and biosynthesis. Biosynthetic origin will be used as a unifying theme.

che.name: — Bio-Organic Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Structure and function of biomolecules; molecular recognition; enzyme reaction mechanisms; design of suicide substrates for enzymes; enzyme engineering; design of artificial enzymes and application of enzymes in organic synthesis.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Chemistry or consent of instructor.

che.name: — Introduction to Chemical Biology
che.description: Course Description: Synthesis of complex molecules in nature. Use of biosynthetic pathways in synthesis of new chemical entities. Applications of small molecules in chemical genetics and structural biology. Solving biological problems using synthetic biomolecules.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 118C or CHE 128C; or equivalent; CHE 130A, CHE 130B and BIS 102, BIS 103, and BIS 104, or the equivalents recommended.

che.name: — Advanced Analytical Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Numerical treatment of experimental data; thermodynamics of electrolyte and non-electrolyte solutions; complex equilibria in aqueous and non-aqueous solutions; potentiometry and specific ion electrodes; mass transfer in liquid solutions; fundamentals of separation science, including column, gas and liquid chromatography.

che.name: — Surface Analytical Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Concepts of surfaces and interfaces: physical properties, unique chemistry and electronic effects. Focus on gas-solid interfaces, with some discussion of liquid-solid interfaces.

che.name: — Laser & X-ray Spectroscopy
che.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Concepts and mechanisms of light-matter interactions. Chemical applications of modern spectroscopic methods, including multiphoton spectroscopy, time-resolved laser and x-ray photolysis, and phase-contrast x-ray imaging.

che.name: — Mass Spectrometry
che.description: Course Description: Mass spectrometry and related methods with emphasis on ionization methods, mass analyzers, and detectors. Related methods may include ion-molecule reactions, unimolecular dissociation of organic and bio-organic compounds, and applications in biological and environmental analysis.

che.name: — Electroanalytical Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Electroanalytical chemistry with consideration of mass transfer and electrode kinetics for polarizable electrodes. Current-potential curves for a variety of conditions, including both potentiostatic and galvanostatic control, and their application in chemical analysis.

che.name: —  Microscopy & Imaging Techniques
che.description: Course Description: Introduction to modern microscopy and imaging techniques: scanning tunneling, atomic force, far-field optical, fluorescence, scanning near-field optical, and scanning electron microscopy. Application to nanoscience and analytical and bioanalytical chemistry. Some laboratory demonstrations.

che.name: — Mechanistic Enzymology
che.description: Course Description: Advanced topics in chemical kinetics relevant to enzymes, enzyme kinetics, theory of enzyme catalysis, and the analysis of a selection of organic enzyme reaction mechanisms by the tools introduced in the first part of the course.

che.name: — Current Topics in Chemical Research
che.description: Course Description: Designed to help chemistry graduate students develop and maintain familiarity with the current and past literature in their immediate field of research and related areas.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Chemistry or consent of instructor.

che.name: — Introduction to Chemistry Research
che.description: Course Description: Group and individual discussion of research activities in the Department and research topic selection. Designed for incoming graduate students preparing for higher degrees in chemistry.

che.name: — Introduction to Chemical Research Methodology
che.description: Course Description: Introduction to identification, formulation, and solution of meaningful scientific problems including experimental design and/or theoretical analyses of new and prevailing techniques, theories and hypotheses. May be repeated for credit when topic differs.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 293; and consent of instructor; graduate student standing in Chemistry.

che.name: — Advanced Chemical Research Methodology
che.description: Course Description: Applications of the methodology developed in CHE 263 to experimental and theoretical studies. Advanced methods of interpretation of results are developed. Includes the preparation of manuscripts for publication.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 263; or consent of instructor.

che.name: — Seminar
che.description: Course Description: Seminar.

che.name: — Presentation of Chemistry Research
che.description: Course Description: Introduces first- and second-year Chemistry graduate students to the process of giving an effective research presentation. Advanced Ph.D. students give formal seminars describing the design and execution of their research projects.

che.name: — Careers in Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Designed to give Chemistry graduate students an in-depth appreciation of career opportunities with a M.S. or Ph.D. degree in chemistry. Professional chemists (and allied professionals) give seminars describing both research and career insights.

che.name: — Research in Pharmaceutical Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Laboratory provides qualified graduate students with the opportunity to pursue original investigation in Pharmaceutical Chemistry and allied fields in order to fulfill the letter-graded research requirement of the Integrated B.S./M.S. Program in Chemistry (Pharmaceutical Chemistry Emphasis).
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 130A; CHE 130B; CHE 135; CHE 233 (can be concurrent); and consent of instructor.

che.name: — Group Study
che.description: Course Description: Group study.

che.name: — Research
che.description: Course Description: The laboratory is open to qualified graduate students who wish to pursue original investigation. Students wishing to enroll should communicate with the department well in advance of the quarter in which the work is to be undertaken.

che.name: — Methods of Teaching Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Practical experience in methods and problems of teaching chemistry. Includes analyses of texts and supporting material, discussion of teaching techniques, preparing for and conducting of discussion sessions and student laboratories. Participation in the teaching program required for Ph.D. in chemistry.
che.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate student standing in Chemistry.

che.name: — Advanced Methods of Teaching Chemistry
che.description: Course Description: Advanced topics in teaching chemistry. Analysis and discussion of curricular design, curricula materials, teaching methods and evaluation. For students who are planning a career in teaching chemistry.

chi.name: — Introduction to Chicana/o Studies
chi.description: Course Description: Analysis of the situation of the Chicana/o (Mexican-American) people, emphasizing their history, literature, political movements, education and related areas.

chi.name: — Chicana/o & Latina/o Health Care Issues
chi.description: Course Description: Overview of health issues of Chicanas/os and Latinas/os in the State of California; role of poverty/lack of education in limited access to health care.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 010.

chi.name: — Chicana/o & Latina/o Health Care Issues
chi.description: Course Description: Overview of health issues of Chicanas/os and Latinas/os in the State of California; role of poverty/lack of education and limited access to health care. All course instruction in Spanish. May be taught abroad.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 003 or SPA 003V or SPA 003Y; or equivalent.

chi.name: — Qualitative Research Methods
chi.description: Course Description: Dominant models of qualitative inquiry in educational and social science research as well as mestizo approaches to research with latinos. Emphasis given to choosing and designing culturally appropriate strategies to investigate latino health, education, social context, and policy issues.

chi.name: — United States Political Institutions & Chicanas/os
chi.description: Course Description: Overview of the major political institutions and ideologies of the United States and the Chicana/o people's historical and contemporary role in, effects from, and responses to them. Theory, method and critical analysis.

chi.name: — Comparative Health: Top Leading Causes of Death
chi.description: Course Description: Introduction to the epidemiology of the leading causes of death for ethnic/racial minorities. Assessment of disproportionate rates at which ethnic/racial minorities suffer and die from chronic and infectious diseases and injuries and statistical methods used to calculate these rates.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 013 or STA 013Y; or consent of instructor.

chi.name: — Comparative Health: Leading Causes of Death
chi.description: Course Description: Introduction to epidemiology of leading causes of death for ethnic/racial minorities. Assessment of disproportionate rates at which ethnic/racial minorities suffer & die from chronic and infectious diseases & injuries & statistical methods used to calculate these rates. May be taught abroad.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 013 or STA 013Y; or consent of instructor.

chi.name: — Food Justice: Chicana/o & Indigenous Communities
chi.description: Course Description: Issues surrounding food justice in Chicana/o and Indigenous Communities. Emphasis on discourses and practices of growing a food justice movement centered on the ecological care of the earth and decolonized environmental methodologies.

chi.name: — Chicana & Chicano Culture
chi.description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary survey of Chicana/o cultural representation in the 20th century. Examines Chicana/o culture within a national and transnational context. Explores how Chicano cultural forms and practices intersect with social/material forces, intellectual formations and cultural discourses. (Former CHI 020.)

chi.name: — Chicana & Chicano Representation in Cinema
chi.description: Course Description: Introductory-level study of Chicana and Chicano representation in cinema. Depiction of Chicana and Chicano experience by Chicana/o filmmakers, as well as by non-Chicanos, including independent filmmakers and the commercial industry.

chi.name: — New  Latin American Cinema
chi.description: Course Description: Historical, critical, and theoretical survey of the cinemas of Latin America and their relationship to the emergence of U.S. Latino cinema. Emphasis on representation and social identity including gender, sexuality, class, race and ethnicity.

chi.name: — Survey of Chicana/o Art
chi.description: Course Description: Survey of contemporary Chicana/o art in context of the social turmoil from which it springs. Includes political use of the poster and the mural, the influence of the Mexican mural and graphic movement, and social responsibility of the artist.

chi.name: — Chicana/o Art Expression Through Silk Screen
chi.description: Course Description: Introductory level studio course using silk screen and basic printing techniques to explore and develop images of Chicana/o cultural themes and expressions. Students experiment with images and symbols from their immediate environment/culture. Integrated approach to Chicana/o philosophy of art.

chi.name: — Internship
chi.description: Course Description: Academic guidance combined with internship in community agencies serving Mexican/Latina/Latino/Chicana/Chicano clients. Students will use their bilingual skills and knowledge of history, culture, economics, politics and social issues.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 010; or consent of instructor.

chi.name: — Directed Group Study
chi.description: Course Description: Directed group study.

chi.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
chi.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.

chi.name: — Chicana/o Theoretical Perspective
chi.description: Course Description: Critical examination of emerging Chicana/o Studies theoretical perspectives in light of contemporary intellectual frameworks in the social sciences, arts, and humanities. Includes analysis of practices of self-representation, and socio-cultural developments in the Chicana/o community.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 010; CHI 050.

chi.name: — Chicana/o Feminist Theoretical Understandings of K-20 Educational Disparities
chi.description: Course Description: Examination of educational disparities of the K-20 educational system. Chicana/o education theory and analysis with a specific emphasis on feminist frameworks and analytical tools used to guide and inform educational policy-making.

chi.name: — Grassroots Community Activism & Mobilization Efforts Challenging Educational Inequity
chi.description: Course Description: Exploration and research on effective grassroots community activism and mobilization efforts by Chicana/o students, along with their teachers, families, and other allies to protest structured inequality of the U.S. educational system. Mentoring and tutoring in a school under the supervision of a faculty member is required.

chi.name: — Policy & Law Challenging Segregation & Educational Inequity
chi.description: Course Description: Focus on successful lawsuits against school segregation of Mexican-origin children in the United States. Mentoring and tutoring in a school under the supervision of a faculty member is required.

chi.name: — Sociology of the Chicana/o Experience
chi.description: Course Description: The Chicana/o experience in the American society and economy viewed from theoretical perspectives. Immigration, history of integration of Chicana/o labor into American class structure, education inequality, ethnicity, the family and Chicana/o politics. (Former course SOC 110.)
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 010 or SOC 001.

chi.name: — Chicanas/Mexicanas in Contemporary Society
chi.description: Course Description: Analysis of the role and status of Chicanas/Mexicanas in contemporary society. Special emphasis on their historical role, the political, economic and social institutions that have affected their status, and their contributions to society and their community. (Former CHI 102.)
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 010 or CHI 050; (WMS 050 or HIS 169B).

chi.name: — Globalization, Transnational Migration, & Chicana/o & Latina/o Communities
chi.description: Course Description: Chicana/o and Latina/o migration experiences within a global context. Topics include national and/or transnational migration in Mexico, Central America, and the United States.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 010.

chi.name: — Latin American Women’s Engagement in Social Movements
chi.description: Course Description: Examination of how women of different racial/ethnic and class backgrounds in Latin America challenge their marginalization. Exploration of US foreign policy, its effects on Latin American’s institutions and on Latin American citizens. Using Chicana feminist perspective.

chi.name: — Women of Color Reproductive Health & Reproductive Politics in a Global Perspective
chi.description: Course Description: Study contemporary issues in reproductive health and reproductive politics, both globally and in the U.S., for women of color.

chi.name: — Women of Color Reproductive Health & Gender Politics in Cuba & the U.S.
chi.description: Course Description: Study of contemporary issues in reproductive health, reproductive politics, and gender politics both in Cuba and in the U.S., for women of color.

chi.name: — Chicana/o Psychology
chi.description: Course Description: Introduction to the field of Chicana/o psychology. Analysis of socio-cultural context of Chicanas/os and Latinas/os. Special attention to issues of ethnic identity development, bilingualism, and development of self esteem. Impact of minority experience, migration, acculturation are examined.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 021; Introductory psychology course recommended.

chi.name: — Chicana/o Community Mental Health
chi.description: Course Description: Mental health needs, problems, and service utilization patterns of Chicanas/os and Latinas/os will be analyzed. Analysis of social service policy, and the economic context of mental health programs.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 010; or CHI 020.

chi.name: — Psychology Perspectives Chicana/o & Latina/o Family
chi.description: Course Description: Role of migration and acculturation on family structure and functioning. From a psychological and Chicana/o Studies perspective, contemporary gender roles and variations in family structures are examined. Special topics include family violence, addiction, family resilience and coping strategies.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 010; and consent of instructor; introductory psychology course highly recommended.

chi.name: — Psychology Perspectives Chicana/o & Latina/o Family
chi.description: Course Description: Role of migration and acculturation on family structure and functioning. From a psychological and Chicana/o Studies perspective, contemporary gender roles and variations in family structures are examined. Special topics include family violence, addiction, family resilience and coping strategies. May be taught abroad.

chi.name: — Psychological perspectives on Chicana/o & Latina/o Children & Adolescents
chi.description: Course Description: Psychological and educational development of Chicano/Latino children and adolescents, with particular attention to the formation of ethnic, gender, class, race, and sexual identities.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 010 or CHI 021.

chi.name: — Latino Families in the Age of Globalization: Migration & Transculturation
chi.description: Course Description: Impact of globalization on Latino families in the American continent. Relationships of political structure, economics and family. Intimate partner violence, child maltreatment and alcohol/drug abuse in contemporary Latino families. Offered in a Spanish speaking country; may be taught abroad.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 003 or the equivalent highly recommended.

chi.name: — United States-Mexican Border Relations
chi.description: Course Description: Theories of U.S.-Mexican border relations, with an overview of the political, economic, and social relationships and an in-depth analysis of immigration issues, border industrialization, women's organizations, economic crises, and legal issues.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

chi.name: — Chicanas in Politics & Public Policy
chi.description: Course Description: Historical and political analysis of Chicana/Latina political involvement and activities in the general political system, women's movement, Chicano movement, and Chicana movement. Examines the public policy process and the relationship of Chicanas/Latinas to public policy formation.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 030 or POL 001.

chi.name: — Chicanas in Politics & Public Policy
chi.description: Course Description: Historical and political analysis of Chicana/Latina political involvement and activities in the general political system, women's movement, Chicano/a movement. Examines the public policy process and the relationship of Chicanas/Latinas to public policy formation. May be taught abroad.

chi.name: — Political Economy of Chicana/o Communities
chi.description: Course Description: Historical and contemporary study of political and economic forces which define and influence the development of Chicana/o communities. Includes critiques of traditional and Marxian theories and concepts applicable to Chicana/o communities, case studies of Chicana/o communities,especially in California and Texas.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; lower division Chicana/o Studies (CHI) course recommended.

chi.name: — Transnational Latina/o Political Economy
chi.description: Course Description: Intensive reading, discussion and research on selected topics from Latin America and the U.S. with regard to immigrant and native communities. Topics include comparative immigration and macroeconomic policies in the U.S. and Latin America. Offered in a Spanish speaking country; may be taught abroad.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 003 or SPA 003V or SPA 003Y; or consent of instructor, or equivalent; ECN 001A and ECN 001B recommended.

chi.name: — Critical & Abolitionist Pedagogies
chi.description: Course Description: How marginalized groups conceptualize learning and teaching as a practice of freedom. Foundational text and concepts in critical pedagogy. Diverse and intersecting intellectual traditions that inform how oppressed peoples use education as a tool of liberation.

chi.name: — Quantitative Methods: Chicano/Latino Health Research
chi.description: Course Description: Focuses on measuring Latino/Chicano health outcomes using a quantitative approach. Assesses main types of study designs and addresses measurement of disease frequency and health effects.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Two years of high school algebra or the equivalent in college.

chi.name: — Community-Based Participatory Research & Chicana/o & Latina/o Health
chi.description: Course Description: Overview of CBPR, as well as methodological CBPR considerations in building community partnerships, community assessment, issue analysis, research planning, data gathering, and data sharing with Chicana/o and Latina/o communities in particular.

chi.name: — Bi-National Health
chi.description: Course Description: Examination of  health status and intervention strategies presented in public health care settings, private clinics and by indigenous healers in Mexico. Analysis of impact of high risk diseases. Offered in a Spanish speaking country under supervision of UC Davis faculty/lecturer; may be taught abroad.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 001A; BIS 001B; BIS 001C; (SPA 021 or SPA 021V or SPA 021Y or SPA 031); or consent of instructor. Upper division standing only.

chi.name: — Public Health in Latin America
chi.description: Course Description: Critical examination of emerging Public Health issues in Latin America in light of economic, political and social conditions. Contemporary behavioral frameworks used in public health. Includes analysis of clinical medicine and health care systems.

chi.name: — Indigenous Healing & Biodiversity in Latin America
chi.description: Course Description: Contrast between western and traditional healing practices in Latin America and the role of the natural environment in creating sustainable health delivery systems. Questions of health status attributable to public health and environmental risk factors. May be taught abroad.

chi.name: — Decolonizing Spirit
chi.description: Course Description: Legacies of colonization and decolonization; indigenous forms of spirituality and sacredness. Emphasis on remembering traditions, practices, relations, and forms of indigenous knowledge.

chi.name: — The Chicana & Chicano Movement
chi.description: Course Description: Development of the Chicano Movement within the context of the socio-political movements of the 1960’s in a national and global perspective. Ideological/political perspectives and the implications for political strategies.

chi.name: — The Chicana/o Novel
chi.description: Course Description: Introduction to the forms and themes of the Chicana/o novel with special attention to the construction of gender, nationality, sexuality, social class, and the family by contemporary Chicana/o novelists. Bilingual readings, lectures, discussions, and writing in Spanish. (Former course SPA 126A.)
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Intermediate Spanish or consent of instructor.

chi.name: — Chicana/o Theater
chi.description: Course Description: Examination of the formal and thematic dimensions of Chicana/o theater in the contemporary period with special emphasis on El Teatro Campesino and Chicana Feminist Theater. Bilingual readings, lectures, discussions, and writing in Spanish. (Former course SPA 126B.)
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Intermediate Spanish or consent of instructor.

chi.name: — Chicana/o Poetry
chi.description: Course Description: Survey of Chicana/o poetry with special emphasis on its thematic and formal dimensions. Bilingual readings, lectures, discussions, and writing in Spanish. (Former course SPA 126C.)
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Intermediate Spanish or consent of instructor.

chi.name: — Chicana & Chicano Narrative
chi.description: Course Description: Exploration of contemporary forms of the Chicana and Chicano narrative, encompassing visual art, fiction, poetry, film, theater, and creative nonfiction. Exposure to a variety of artists and scholars whose work shapes our evolving understanding of the Chicana/o experience.

chi.name: — Contemporary Issues in Latinx Literature
chi.description: Course Description: Contemporary Chicanx Literature within the broader umbrella of Latinx Literature. Genres, including fiction, nonfiction, and poetry, but also hybrid and mixed genre texts. New trends and topics relating to 21st Century Latinx authors, including intersectionality and multiple identities, AfroLatinx and Indigenous identity, Queer representation, Young Adult literature, and undocumented writers.

chi.name: — Mexican Film & Greater Mexican Identity
chi.description: Course Description: Survey of the role Mexican cinema plays in consolidation and contestation of post-revoluationary Mexican state and in the formation of a Greater Mexican cultural identity including Chicana/o identity. Showcases genres, perios, auteurs, movements and emphasis on gendered and sexualized narratives.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Intermediate Spanish.

chi.name: — Queer Latinidad
chi.description: Course Description: Introduction to queer Latina and Latino studies with a focus on Chicana and Chicano theory and cultural production.

chi.name: — Chicanas, Latinas & Mexicanas in Commercial Media
chi.description: Course Description: The portrayal of Chicanas, Latinas and Mexicanas in commercial media. The relation between the representation of Chicana, Latina, and Mexicana women in commercial television and cinema and the role of women in Mexican and U.S. societies.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 060; or other film or feminist theory course; conversational fluency in Spanish.

chi.name: — Contemporary Issues in Chicano Art
chi.description: Course Description: Issues and conflicts in the dismantling of the Contemporary Chicano Art Movement. Response and challenge to the dominant culture.

chi.name: — Mexican & Chicano Mural Workshop
chi.description: Course Description: The Mural: a collective art process that empowers students and people through design and execution of mural paintings in the tradition of the Mexican Mural Movement; introduces materials and techniques.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 070; and consent of instructor.

chi.name: — Chicana/o Voice/Poster Silk Screen Workshop
chi.description: Course Description: The poster as a voice art form used by Chicanas/os and other people of color to point to the defects of social and political existence and the possibility for change, from the Chicana/o artists' perspective.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 070 or CHI 073; and consent of instructor.

chi.name: — Grant Writing in the Chicana/o/Latina/o Community
chi.description: Course Description: Overview of key elements for grant writing. Topics include community needs assessments, development of human subjects protocols, data collection, methods, evaluation designs and community based methodologies for grant development applications in the Latino community.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 010 or CHI 023; or consent of instructor.

chi.name: — Chicanas & Latinas in the U.S.: Historical Perspectives
chi.description: Course Description: Historical issues in the lives of Chicanas and Latinas in the U.S. and their diverse countries of origin.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 010 or WMS 050.

chi.name: — Race & Juvenile Justice
chi.description: Course Description: Individual and institutinal respnses to "troublesome" youth of color through history and in contemporary siciety. Emphasis on how race, as well as ethnicity, class, and gender have informed the treatment of "delinquent" youth.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHI 010; or equivalent.

chi.name: — Latino Youth Gangs in Global Perspective
chi.description: Course Description: Comparative analysis of Latino youth gangs in Europe, Latin America, and the United States. Social, economic, political, and cultural factors leading to youth gangs as well as the responses are considered within a global perspective.

chi.name: — Latino Youth Gangs in Global Perspective
chi.description: Course Description: Comparative analysis of Latino youth gangs in Europe, Latin America, and the United States. Social, economic, political, and cultural factors leading to youth gangs as well as the responses to the youths are considered within a global perspective. May be taught abroad.

chi.name: — Internship in the Chicana/Chicano/Latina/Latino Community
chi.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Academic guidance combined with internship in community agencies serving Mexican/Latina/Latino/Chicana/Chicano clients. Use of bilingual skills and knowledge of history, culture, economics, politics and social issues. Internship project required.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (CHI 010 or CHI 021 or CHI 050); (SPA 003 or SPA 003V); or equivalent of SPA 003.

chi.name: — Internship
chi.description: Course Description: Internship. May be taught abroad.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (CHI 010 or CHI 021 or CHI 050); (SPA 003 or SPA 003V or SPA 003Y); and consent of instructor, or equivalent of SPA 003, SPA 003V, SPA 003Y.

chi.name: — Senior Honors Research Project
chi.description: Course Description: Student is required to read, research, and write Honors Thesis on Chicana/o Studies topics.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; senior standing in Chicana/o Studies major.

chi.name: — Senior Honors Research Project
chi.description: Course Description: Student is required to read, research, and write Honors Thesis on Chicana/o Studies topics.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; senior standing in Chicana/o Studies major.

chi.name: — Senior Honors Research Project
chi.description: Course Description: Student is required to read, research, and write Honors Thesis on Chicana/o Studies topics.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; senior standing in Chicana/o Studies major.

chi.name: — Directed Group Study
chi.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing and consent of Program Chairperson.

chi.name: — Directed Group Study
chi.description: Course Description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

chi.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
chi.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing and consent of Program Chairperson.

chi.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
chi.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates. May be taught abroad.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

chi.name: — Chicano/Latino Hispanic Politics
chi.description: Course Description: Examination of Chicano/Latino political experiences. Evaluate theories, ideology, and practice of Chicano politics. Brief history of Chicano/Latino/Hispanic political activity, comparisons among political modes, gendered politics, and understanding relationships among Chicano, Mexican, American and world politics.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Two undergraduate courses in Chicana/o Studies (CHI) or consent of instructor.

chi.name: — Community Based Participatory Research
chi.description: Course Description: Provides knowledge & skills to plan and implement participatory & community based projects that highlight community empowerment framework.

chi.name: — Group Study for Graduate Students
chi.description: Course Description: Group study for graduate students.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

chi.name: — Special Study for Graduate Students
chi.description: Course Description: Special study for graduate students.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

chi.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
chi.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.
chi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

chn.name: — Elementary Chinese
chn.description: Course Description: Developing elementary level skills of listening, speaking, reading and writing in Mandarin Chinese in everyday communication settings. Introduction of fundamentals of pronunciation, grammar, and Chinese characters will be introduced.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): No background in Chinese or placement exam or consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Accelerated Intensive Elementary Chinese
chn.description: Course Description: Introduction and practice in contexts of pronunciation, writing system, basic grammar and vocabulary as basis of communicative competency in Mandarin Chinese within a special nine-week intensive course which combines CHN 001, CHN 002 and CHN 003.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): No background in Chinese or placement exam or consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Accelerated Written Chinese I
chn.description: Course Description: Trainings on all the communicative skills of listening, speaking, reading, and writing for students who already have elementary level ability to understand or speak Mandarin Chinese. Emphases on standard Mandarin pronunciation, Chinese characters, and discourse level conversations.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Placement exam or consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Mandarin for Cantonese Speakers I
chn.description: Course Description: Training in spoken Mandarin, particularly in the phonetic transcription system known as pinyin, for students who already read and write Chinese.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Placement exam or consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Elementary Chinese
chn.description: Course Description: Continuation of elementary level skill development in listening, speaking, reading and writing Mandarin Chinese in everyday communication settings. Continued introduction of basic vocabulary and characters as well as core grammar, and further train pronunciation.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 001; or placement exam or consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Accelerated Written Chinese II
chn.description: Course Description: Further trainings on all the communicative skills of listening, speaking, reading, and writing for students that already have elementary level ability to understand or speak Mandarin Chinese. Emphases on standard Mandarin pronunciation, Chinese characters, and discourse level conversations.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 001BL; or placement exam or consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Mandarin for Cantonese Speakers II
chn.description: Course Description: Continuation of CHN 001CN. Training in spoken Mandarin for students who can already read and write Chinese.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 001CN; or placement exam or consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Elementary Chinese
chn.description: Course Description: Continuation of elementary level skill development in listening, speaking, reading and writing Mandarin Chinese in everyday communication settings. Continued introduction of basic vocabulary and characters as well as core grammar, and further train pronunciation.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 002; or placement exam or consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Accelerated Written Chinese III
chn.description: Course Description: Continuation of CHN 002BL with further trainings on all the communicative skills of listening, speaking, reading, and writing with emphases on standard Mandarin pronunciation, Chinese characters, and discourse level conversations in more communication settings.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 002BL; or placement exam or consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Mandarin for Cantonese Speakers III
chn.description: Course Description: Continuation of CHN 002CN. Prepares students for entering upper division courses in Chinese.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 002CN; or placement exam or consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Intermediate Chinese
chn.description: Course Description: Continuation of intermediate-level communication skills in spoken and written Mandarin, based on language skills developed in CHN 003.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 003 or placement exam or consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Accelerated Intensive Intermediate Chinese
chn.description: Course Description: Special nine-week accelerated, intensive summer session course that combines the work of CHN 004, CHN 005, and CHN 006. Intermediate-level training in spoken and written Chinese in cultural and communicative contexts, based on language skills developed in CHN 003 or CHN 001A.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 003 or CHN 001A or placement exam or consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Intermediate Chinese
chn.description: Course Description: Training continues at intermediate-level in spoken and written Chinese in cultural contexts, based on language skills developed in CHN 004.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 004 or placement exam or consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Intermediate Chinese
chn.description: Course Description: Intermediate-level training in spoken and written Chinese in cultural contexts, based on language skills developed in CHN 005.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 005; CHN 005 or placement exam or consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Chinese Business Culture
chn.description: Course Description: Introduction to business culture of China. Basic conversation and Romanization of Chinese words.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Introduction to Chinese Language & Culture
chn.description: Course Description: Chinese culture through the lens of Chinese language. Relationship of language to religion, food, arts, ethnic groups, dialects, writing systems, etc. All readings are in English; no previous background is necessary.

chn.name: — Modern Chinese Literature (In English)
chn.description: Course Description: Introductory course requiring no knowledge of Chinese language or history. Reading and discussion of short stories and novels and viewing of two films. Designed to convey a feeling for what China has experienced in the 20th century.

chn.name: — Great Books of China (in English)
chn.description: Course Description: Readings in English translation of classical and medieval Chinese poetry, Chinese historiography, tales of the supernatural, Tang romances, opera, and late imperial era vernacular literature, with key works by Sima Qian, Gan Bao, Tao Qian, Han Yu, and Feng Menglong. Background information on periods, authors and the interrelationships of culture, literature and social change.

chn.name: — Introduction to the Literature of China & Japan
chn.description: Course Description: Methods of literary analysis and their application to major works from the various genres of Chinese and Japanese literature (in translation), including film. East Asian cultural traditions will also be introduced.

chn.name: — Directed Group Study
chn.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
chn.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Daoist Traditions
chn.description: Course Description: English-language survey of key Daoist texts and scholarship. Topics include Daoist concepts of the cosmos, the natural world, scripture, the body, and immortality; Daoist divinities; Daoism and the state.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): A course in Chinese history recommended.

chn.name: — Confucian Traditions
chn.description: Course Description: Key aspects of the Confucian tradition in dynastic China. Major themes addressed include ritual, classical studies, and Confucian influences on the Chinese family and state.

chn.name: — Chinese Film
chn.description: Course Description: English language survey of Chinese film, from its inception to the end of the 20th century. Chinese films as important texts for understanding national, transnational, racial, gender, and class politics of modern China.

chn.name: — Modern Chinese Drama
chn.description: Course Description: English language survey of modern Chinese spoken drama in the 20th century and its major playwrights, in the context of Chinese history and the interaction of Chinese culture with other cultures.

chn.name: — Modern Chinese Fiction (in English)
chn.description: Course Description: English language survey of Chinese fiction as it evolved amidst the great historical, social and cultural changes of the 20th century. Thorough study of the most influential writers and genres.

chn.name: — Western Influences on 20th-Century Chinese Literature (in English)
chn.description: Course Description: Introduction of Western literary thought into modern China, the experimentation with Western literary forms and techniques, and the development of Marxism in contemporary literary writing.

chn.name: — Chinese Poetry (in English)
chn.description: Course Description: Organized topically and chronologically, the lyric tradition is explored from the dawn of folk songs down to modern expressions of social protest. Topics include friendship, love, oppression, war, parting, death, ecstasy and beauty. All readings are in English.

chn.name: — Traditional Chinese Fiction (in English)
chn.description: Course Description: Dawn of Chinese fiction and its development down to modern times. Survey of literary history with close reading of representative works. Readings, lectures, and discussions in English.

chn.name: — Poetry of China & Japan (in English)
chn.description: Course Description: A comparative approach to Chinese and Japanese poetry, examining poetic practice in the two cultures; includes a general outline of the two traditions, plus study of poetic forms, techniques, and distinct treatments of universal themes: love, nature, war, etc.

chn.name: — Topics in Chinese Literature: Crime & Punishment
chn.description: Course Description: Examines how crime and punishment have been represented in traditional Chinese short stories, novels, operas, and histories.

chn.name: — Topics in Chinese Literature: Women Writers (in English)
chn.description: Course Description: Topics in Chinese literature; women writers.

chn.name: — Topics in Chinese Literature: The Knight-Errant (in English)
chn.description: Course Description: Topics in Chinese literature; the knight-errant.

chn.name: — Topics in Chinese Literature: The City in Fiction (in English)
chn.description: Course Description: Topics in Chinese literature; the city in fiction.

chn.name: — Topics in Chinese Literature: The Literature of 20th-Century Taiwan (in English)
chn.description: Course Description: Topics in Chinese literature; the literature of 20th-century Taiwan.

chn.name: — Topics in Chinese Literature: Popular Literature (in English)
chn.description: Course Description: Topics in Chinese literature; popular literature.

chn.name: — Topics in Chinese Literature: Scholar & The Courtesan (in English)
chn.description: Course Description: Chinese romance stories, focusing on depictions of scholars and courtesans in Tang fables, late imperial operas, Ming short-stories, and 19th-century novels.

chn.name: — Great Writers of China: Texts & Context (in English)
chn.description: Course Description: Examination of major theoretical concepts and interpretive methods in the study of literature by using examples from the Chinese tradition; discussions of classical and modern works with an emphasis on the relations between literature, author, society, and culture.

chn.name: — Modern Chinese: Reading & Discussion
chn.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Building on Chinese 006/003BL, further development of communication skills in Modern Standard Mandarin-speaking environments. Reading of dialogues/articles pertaining to contemporary China.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 006 C- or better or CHN 003BL C- or better or CHN 004A C- or better; or placement exam or consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Intensive Third-Year Chinese
chn.description: Course Description: Nine-week intensive summer course combines CHN 111, CHN 112, and CHN 113. Training at intermediate-high and advanced-low level in spoken and written Chinese in cultural and communicative contexts based on language skills developed in CHN 006.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 006 or CHN 003BL or CHN 004A; or placement exam or consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Modern Chinese: Reading & Discussion
chn.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Further development of communication skills from CHN 111 in Modern Standard Mandarin-speaking environments. Reading dialogues/articles pertaining to contemporary China issues and discussing ethical, moral, aesthetic, social, and cultural concerns.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 111; or placement exam or consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Modern Chinese: Reading & Discussion
chn.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Continuation of CHN 112, further developing communication skills in Modern Standard Mandarin-speaking environments. Read dialogues/articles pertaining to contemporary China issues and discuss ethical, moral, aesthetic, social, and cultural concerns. Study strategies for moving between simplified and traditional Chinese characters.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 112; or placement exam or consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Introduction to Classical Chinese
chn.description: Course Description: Introduction to the language in which, until the 20th century, most official, documentary, scholarly, and belle-lettristic Chinese literature was written.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 112; or equivalent language proficiency. consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Introduction to Classical Chinese II
chn.description: Course Description: Continuation of enhancing classical Chinese reading skills with literature ranging from the prose found in Han dynasty historical works, Six Dynasties anecdotal literature, and Tang occasional texts, as well as the poetic shi and fu genres.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 114; or Consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Introduction to Classical Chinese III
chn.description: Course Description: Translations of extended readings in the original sources and brief analyses of syntax. These sources will include texts written by well-known figures from the 8th through 15th centuries, composing in a wide variety of genres.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 115; or consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Advanced Chinese for Non-Native Speakers
chn.description: Course Description: Analysis of material from various genres (literature, newspapers, blogs, TV, film, etc) with focus on Chinese society and culture. Advanced reading, writing, aural comprehension, and formal speech in Mandarin Chinese. For students who have completed the third-year Chinese series (CHN 111-113), but do not have substantial background as heritage or native speakers of Chinese.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 113; or equivalent language proficiency; consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Advanced Chinese
chn.description: Course Description: Evaluation of readings from various genres (literature, newspapers, TV and movies, etc.) develop advanced reading, writing, aural comprehension, and formal/professional speech skills in Mandarin Chinese. Chinese society/cultural studies, especially those sociocultural issues reflected in the language used in learning materials.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 113; or placement exam or consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Business Chinese
chn.description: Course Description: Mandarin Chinese language for business and professional purposes. Appropriate usages and protocols within the context of Chinese business culture.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 113 or consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Readings in Traditional Chinese Fiction
chn.description: Course Description: Examination of representative works of traditional Chinese fiction popular from the 12th Century until the 17th and 18th centuries. Translations in English of the Chinese texts will be available to students as reference.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 111; or equivalent language proficiency.

chn.name: — Readings in Traditional Chinese Poetry
chn.description: Course Description: Traditional Chinese poetry from its beginnings to the golden ages of Tang and Song, surveying forms and poets that best reveal the Chinese poetic sensibility and the genius of the language of Chinese poetry.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 111; consent of instructor, or equivalent language proficiency.

chn.name: — Readings in Modern Chinese Poetry
chn.description: Course Description: Chinese poetry from the Literary Revolution of 1917 to the present, surveying works that embody exciting innovations and reflect the modernity of 20th-century Chinese society and culture.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 111; consent of instructor, or equivalent language proficiency.

chn.name: — Readings in Modern Chinese Prose & Drama
chn.description: Course Description: Literary works and scholarly essays on selected topics of Chinese prose and drama, development of a deep understanding of Chinese culture and society through sophisticated reading materials of these two important genres of the modern period.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 111; or equivalent language proficiency, or consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Chinese Film in Chinese Language
chn.description: Course Description: Chinese film and scholarly essays on Chinese cinema and film history. Develop a deep understanding of Chinese culture and society through viewing and studying Chinese films in the Chinese language.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 111; or equivalent language proficiency.

chn.name: — Readings in Classical Chinese
chn.description: Course Description: Study and philological analysis of selected texts from the first millennium of Imperial China.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Fifth-Year Chinese: Selected Topics in Chinese Language, Literature, & Culture
chn.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Examination of literary works and scholarly essays on selected topics of Chinese culture and society. Development of a deep understanding of Chinese culture and society through sophisticated Chinese speaking and writing exercises.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 120; or placement exam or consent of instructor.

chn.name: — The Chinese Language
chn.description: Course Description: Introduction to structural features of Chinese (Mandarin) sounds, lexicon, grammar, and writing (characters), as well as relevant dialectal and sociolinguistic issues of the language.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHN 006 (can be concurrent) or CHN 003BL (can be concurrent) or CHN 003CN (can be concurrent) or CHN 004A (can be concurrent); or placement exam or consent of instructor; LIN 001 recommended.

chn.name: — Chinese Internship
chn.description: Course Description: Work experience in the Chinese language, with analytical term paper on a topic approved by instructor.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing and consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Senior Thesis Honors Project
chn.description: Course Description: Guided research, under the direction of a faculty member, leading to a senior honors thesis on a topic in Chinese literature, civilization, or language studies.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; senior standing and qualification for the Chinese honors program.

chn.name: — Tutoring in Chinese
chn.description: Course Description: Leading of small voluntary discussion groups affiliated with one of the Department's regular courses.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of Department.

chn.name: — Directed Group Study
chn.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
chn.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Directed Independent Study
chn.description: Course Description: Directed independent study on a topic culminating in a term paper. Independent studies may only be arranged with consent of the instructor and when graduate seminars are unavailable.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Research
chn.description: Course Description: Research.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

chn.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
chn.description: Course Description: Any course taught by a graduate student under the direction of the Director.
chn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

cdm.name: — Introduction to Film Studies
cdm.description: Course Description: Analysis of film form and narrative, including cinematography, editing, and sound. Issues in film studies including authorship, stardom, race, gender, class, and cultural identity. Introduction to selected cinematic movements and national film traditions.

cdm.name: — Introduction to Technocultural Studies
cdm.description: Course Description: Contemporary developments in the fine and performing arts, media arts, digital arts, and literature as they relate to technological and scientific practices.

cdm.name: — Media Archaeology
cdm.description: Course Description: Evolution of media technologies and practices beginning in the 19th century as they relate to contemporary digital arts practices. Special focus on the reconstruction of the social and artistic possibilities of lost and obsolete media technologies.

cdm.name: — Introduction to Media Computation
cdm.description: Course Description: Introduction to key computational ideas necessary to understand and produce digital media. Fundamentals of programming and analysis of how media are represented and transmitted in digital form. Aimed primarily at non-computer science students.

cdm.name: — Filmmaking Foundations
cdm.description: Course Description: Introduction to filmmaking concepts, principles, and methods. Emphasis on form, content and historical dialectic between classical narrative filmmaking conventions and artists' challenges to these conventions.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 001 and/or CDM 003 recommended.

cdm.name: — Filmmaking Foundations
cdm.description: Course Description: Introduction to filmmaking concepts, principles, and methods. Emphasis on form, content and historical dialectic between classical narrative filmmaking conventions and artists' challenges to these conventions.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 001 and/or CDM 003 recommended.

cdm.name: — History of Cinema from 1895-1945
cdm.description: Course Description: Examination of the cultural context of the emergence of cinema. Discussion of cinema as a product of the age of industrialization and conquest, as well as an element of urban culture, and mass transportation.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 001 recommended.

cdm.name: — History of Cinema from 1945-Present
cdm.description: Course Description: Examines cinema from 1945 through the present, with focus on neo-realist, new wave and third-world movements. Examines social critique in cinema from studio system to New Wave, Cine Novo, postcolonial cinema and contemporary independent cinema.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 001 recommended.

cdm.name: — History of Cinema from 1945-Present
cdm.description: Course Description: Examines cinema from 1945 through the present, with focus on neo-realist, new wave and third-world movements.  Examines social critique in cinema from studio system to New Wave, Cine Novo, postcolonial cinema and contemporary independent cinema.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 001 recommended.

cdm.name: — Introduction to Games
cdm.description: Course Description: Introduction to the history, theory, and practice of play. Survey of both analog and digital games. Overview of gaming cultures, aesthetics, industries, and technologies.

cdm.name: — Internship
cdm.description: Course Description: Supervised internship, on or off campus, in the area of cinema and digital media.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

cdm.name: — Directed Group Study
cdm.description: Course Description: Directed group study in cinema and digital media.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

cdm.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
cdm.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates in cinema and digital media.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

cdm.name: — Experimental Digital Cinema I
cdm.description: Course Description: Experimental approaches to the making of film and video in the age of digital technologies. Builds upon the foundation provided by CDM 020. Instruction in technical, conceptual, creative, and critical skills for taking a project from idea to fruition.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 020 or ART 012; or consent of instructor.

cdm.name: — Experimental Digital Cinema II
cdm.description: Course Description: Continuation of CDM 100 with further exploration of digital cinema creation. Additional topics include new modes of distribution, streaming, installation and exhibition.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 100; consent of instructor.

cdm.name: — Interactivity & Animation
cdm.description: Course Description: Fundamentals of creating interactive screen-based work. Theories of interactivity, linear versus non-linear structures & audience involvement and participation. Use of digital production tools to produce class projects.

cdm.name: — Documentary Production
cdm.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Traditional and new forms of documentary, with focus on technocultural issues. Skills and strategies for producing work in various media. Progression through all stages of production, from conception through post-production to critique.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 020; CDM 155; or consent of instructor.

cdm.name: — Feminist Media Production
cdm.description: Course Description: Media production as a mode of cultural criticism, furthering feminist and social justice goals. Fundamentals of camera, editing and distribution via a social engagement model. Study and hands-on response to key historic and contemporary feminist and social justice media discourses.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (CTS 020 or CDM 020); or two WMS courses.

cdm.name: — Acting for Camera
cdm.description: Course Description: Analysis and practice of acting skills required for camera work and digital media.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

cdm.name: — Community Media Production
cdm.description: Course Description: Use of video and new media tools to address social issues among neighborhood and community groups. Use basic video, sound, and lighting techniques while working with local groups in a group video project.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 020 recommended.

cdm.name: — Community Networks & Social Media
cdm.description: Course Description: Impact and implications of computer-based networks in community, civic, and social life. Subjects may include community-access computer sites, neighborhood wireless networks, the digital divide, open-source software, and citizen action.

cdm.name: — Introduction to Sonic Arts
cdm.description: Course Description: Introduction to the use of sound within the arts. Techniques and aesthetics of experimental contemporary practices. Creation of original sound works.

cdm.name: — Introduction to Sonic Arts
cdm.description: Course Description: Introduction to use of sound within the arts. Techniques and aesthetics of experimental contemporary practices. Creation of original sound works.

cdm.name: — Intermediate Sonic Arts
cdm.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Techniques of recording, editing, mixing, and synthesis to combine voice, field recordings, and electronic signals. Incorporating live, recorded, found sounds to create multidimensional stories. Presentation of live performances, etc.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 121; or consent of instructor.

cdm.name: — Intermediate Sonic Arts
cdm.description: Course Description: Techniques of recording, editing, mixing, and synthesis to combine voice, field recordings, and electronic signals. Incorporating live, recorded, found sounds to create multidimensional stories. Presentation of live performances, etc.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 121 or CDM 121V; or consent of instructor.

cdm.name: — Sight & Soundtrack
cdm.description: Course Description: Use of sound to articulate, lend mood or subconsciously underscore visual, environmental, or performative situations, combining music, voice, sound effects and other noises to create sound designs that enhance, alter or support action and movement.

cdm.name: — Advanced Sound: Performance & Improvisation
cdm.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Culmination of CDM sound courses. Focuses on performance and improvisation, culminating in a final public performance. Expectation of extensive reading and rehearsal outside of class time.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 121; CDM 122; or consent of instructor.

cdm.name: — Fundamentals of Computer Graphics
cdm.description: Course Description: Foundation course teaches the theory of three-dimensional computer graphics, including modeling, rendering and animation. Development of practical skills through the use of professional software to create computer graphics.

cdm.name: — Character Animation
cdm.description: Course Description: The art of character animation in three dimensional computer animation. Movement theory, principles of animation, animation timing. Development of technical and practical skills.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 130 or TCS 130.

cdm.name: — Object-Oriented Programming for Artists
cdm.description: Course Description: Introduction to object-oriented programming for artists. Focus on understanding the metaphors and potential of object-oriented programming for sound, video, performance, and interactive installations.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 002 recommended.

cdm.name: — Electronics for Artists
cdm.description: Course Description: Creative application of electronic technology relevant to media and fine arts involving both electronic principles and hands-on application.

cdm.name: — Topics in Virtuality
cdm.description: Course Description: Social, political, economic, and aesthetic factors in virtual reality. Artificial environments, telepresence, and simulated experience. Focus on contemporary artists' work and writing.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 002 recommended.

cdm.name: — Media Theory
cdm.description: Course Description: Critical and theoretical approaches to the emergence of new technologies since the invention of photography. Examine various approaches to media (formalist, semiotic, structuralist, Frankfurt School, cybernetics, visual and gamer theory).
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 002 or CDM 003 recommended.

cdm.name: — Epic Television: The Golden Age of TV? Sopranos, Wire, Girls, Walking Dead
cdm.description: Course Description: Critically celebrated scripted television since the mid-1990s. Key themes including class, ethnicity, race, violence, and US politics. Major developments in the medium’s history as context for recent wave of epic television.

cdm.name: — Technology & the Modern American Body
cdm.description: Course Description: History and analysis of relationships between human bodies and technologies in modern society. Dominant and eccentric examples of how human bodies and technologies influence one another and reveal underlying cultural assumptions.

cdm.name: — Art & Cinema: Between the White Cube & the Black Box
cdm.description: Course Description: Current debates between cinema studies and contemporary art. Issues covered include, experimental modes of filming, montaging, installing, screening, and displaying images between the White Cube (gallery/museum) and the Black Box (cinema).

cdm.name: — Art & Cinema: Between the White Cube & the Black Box
cdm.description: Course Description: Current debates between cinema studies and contemporary art. Experimental modes of filming, montaging, installing, screening, and displaying images between the White Cube (gallery/museum) and the Black Box (cinema).

cdm.name: — Nazi & Fascist Cinema: Film & other Visual Media
cdm.description: Course Description: Analysis of nefarious and noxious cultural products in history: films made under the Nazis and other fascists, 1933-1945. Questions at heart of humanistic studies: relationship of culture to propaganda, politics, and even unfathomable crime.

cdm.name: — Topics in U.S. Film History
cdm.description: Course Description: Study of an aspect of American film history (such as the silent era; the studio system; U.S. avant-garde cinema), including the influences of technological, economic, regulatory, cultural, and artistic forces.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 001; or consent of instructor.

cdm.name: — Topics in Film Genres
cdm.description: Course Description: Study of one or more of the film genres (such as musicals, film noir, screwball comedy, or westerns), including genre theory and the relationship of the genre(s) to culture, history, and film industry practices. May be taught abroad.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 001; or consent of instructor.

cdm.name: — Video Games & Culture
cdm.description: Course Description: Critical approaches to the study of video games, focusing on formal, historical, and cultural modes of analysis. History of software and hardware in North American and global contexts. Relations of games to society, politics, economics, media, etc.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 072 or ENL 072 recommended.

cdm.name: — Introduction to Analog Game Design
cdm.description: Course Description: Fundamental theories and practices of analog game design. Pen & paper, dice & cards, checkers & chess to riddles & stories, track & field, and other forms of play. Prototype, playtest, and presentation of original analog games.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 072 or CDM 172 or CTS 172; or consent of instructor.

cdm.name: — Special Topics in Analog Game Design
cdm.description: Course Description: Special topics in analog game design for upper division students.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 072 or CDM 172 or CTS 172; or consent of instructor; Recommended: CDM 173, CDM 175 or CDM 177.

cdm.name: — Introduction to Digital Game Development
cdm.description: Course Description: Digital game development. Theories of control, interface, game feel, glitch, mechanics. Design, demo, and distribution of new digital games.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 072 or CDM 172 or CTS 172; consent of instructor.

cdm.name: — Special Topics in Digital Game Development
cdm.description: Course Description: Special topics in digital game development for upper division students.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 072 or CDM 172 or CTS 172; or consent of instructor. Recommended: CDM 173, CDM 175 or CDM 177.

cdm.name: — Introduction to Game Programming
cdm.description: Course Description: Introduction to computer science concepts and programming practices for video games.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 072 or CDM 172 or CTS 172; or consent of instructor.

cdm.name: — Special Topics in Game Programming
cdm.description: Course Description: Special topics in game programming for upper division students.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 072 or CDM 172 or CTS 172; or consent of instructor. Recommended: CDM 173, CDM 175 or CDM 177.

cdm.name: — Special Topics in Cinema & Digital Media
cdm.description: Course Description: Special topics in cinema & digital media.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 001 or CDM 002 recommended.

cdm.name: — Research Methods in Cinema & Digital Media
cdm.description: Course Description: Introduction to basic research methods for Cinema and Digital Media; e.g., electronic & archived images, sounds & data, etc.

cdm.name: — Internship
cdm.description: Course Description: Supervised internship, on or off campus, in the area of cinema and digital media.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

cdm.name: — Honors Project in Cinema & Digital Media
cdm.description: Course Description: Directed reading, research and writing culminating in the completion of a senior honors thesis or significant creative project under direction of faculty sponsor.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; GPA of at least 3.500; senior standing.

cdm.name: — Honors Project in Cinema & Digital Media
cdm.description: Course Description: Directed reading, research and writing culminating in the completion of a senior honors thesis or significant creative project under direction of faculty sponsor.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; GPA of at least 3.500; senior standing.

cdm.name: — Tutoring in Cinema & Digital Media
cdm.description: Course Description: Leading small voluntary discussion groups affiliated with departmental courses under the supervision of the course instructor.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Consent of Department Chair.

cdm.name: — Directed Group Study
cdm.description: Course Description: Directed group study in cinema and digital media. For students with upper division standing. May be taught abroad.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

cdm.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
cdm.description: Course Description: Special study in cinema and digital media. For advanced undergraduates with upper division standing.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

cdm.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
cdm.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.
cdm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

cts.name: — Media History 1, Guttenberg to Oppenheimer
cts.description: Course Description: History of Media to 1945, with particular focus on mechanically reproduced mass media technologies including the printing press, the newspaper, photography, cinema, radio and early computing technology. Analysis of inter-related cultural and political topics.

cts.name: — Media History 2 1945-Present
cts.description: Course Description: History of media from 1945 to present, with particular focus on the development of the computer, digital network and Internet technologies in the context of other media infrastructures like radio, television and satellite networks. Analysis of inter-related cultural/political topics.

cts.name: — Design on Screen
cts.description: Course Description: Analysis of the contribution of outstanding designers for cinema, television and filmed entertainment. Study of diverse aesthetic theories of production design and art direction, costume design, or cinematography. Introductory principles and practice, history.

cts.name: — Costume Design for Film
cts.description: Course Description: Theory and practice of the art and business of film costume design. Script analysis, costume research, developing design concepts, budgeting, and current production practices and methods. Execution of designs for period and contemporary films. Viewing of current films.
cts.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): DRA 024; or consent of instructor.

cts.name: — Modern Iranian Cinema
cts.description: Course Description: Iranian cinema of the 20th century in the context of profound cultural and social changes in Iran especially since the Iranian Revolution. Productions by representative directors such as Kiarostami, Makhmalbaf, Bahram Beizaie are included. Knowledge of Persian not required.
cts.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing, or consent of instructor.

cts.name: — Modern South Asia Cinema
cts.description: Course Description: South Asian cinema of last 100 years in the context of cultural, social, and political changes. South Asian history, Independence, Partition, urban life, class, migration, postcolonial identity, diaspora, gender, sexuality, religion, sport, performance, etc.
cts.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

cts.name: — Japanese Literature on Film
cts.description: Course Description: Survey of films based on works of Japanese literature, emphasis on pre-modern and early modern texts. Introduction to major directors of Japan, with a focus on cinematic adaptation. Lectures and readings in English. Films in Japanese with English subtitles.

cts.name: — Media Theory
cts.description: Course Description: Critical and theoretical approaches to the emergence of new technologies since the invention of photography. Examine various approaches to media (formalist, semiotic, structuralist, Frankfurt School, cybernetics, visual and gamer theory).

cts.name: — Surveillance Technologies & Social Media
