dra.description: Course Description: Modern directing theory as it applies to non-realistic theatre; development of directorial concepts for production of selected non-realistic plays-Greek to the present; emphasis on textual analysis.

dra.name: — Special Problems in Directing
dra.description: Course Description: Projects in directing scenes selected from plays from ancient Greece to the present.

dra.name: — Advanced Problems in Choreography & Performance
dra.description: Course Description: Explores contemporary issues of choreography and performance in depth and how those issues pertain to performance work. Focus will include contemporary thought on representation, legibility, new forms, and cultural attitudes.

dra.name: — Critical Approaches to Traditional Systems of Body Movement
dra.description: Course Description: Introduction to traditional systems for body movement, development of critical approaches to them, and experiments in how they inform training and practice in theatre, dance, and performance.

dra.name: — Modern Theatre
dra.description: Course Description: Theatre of Europe and America, 1860-1940, with emphasis on the relationship of the dramas of the period to the physical circumstances under which they were produced.

dra.name: — Scoring & Scripting in Performance
dra.description: Course Description: Process of weaving together various performance elements brought into play by the artists in their respective disciplines. The "script" is the thread from which the artists' "scores" will layer and transform the "script" into performance for specific time, place, spectators.

dra.name: — Performance: Concepts of Space, Place, & Time
dra.description: Course Description: Innovative theories of creating performance spaces, establishing a sense of place, and communicating the concept of time explored through collaborative interaction. Research includes traditional principles, site-specific spaces and consideration of various tempi from music and movement.

dra.name: — Approaches to Collaboration
dra.description: Course Description: Exploration of different approaches to collaboration among artists in different media and their influence on the creative process.

dra.name: — Performing Identities/Personae
dra.description: Course Description: Historical and contemporary theories of constructing stage identities. Discussion and project collaborations based on theories. Questions of identity related to ethnicity, gender or sexual orientation.

dra.name: — Composition in the Arts
dra.description: Course Description: Examine manner in which specific elements utilized by actors, dancers, directors, choreographers, and designers are combined or related to form a whole in space and time, as well as methods of sequencing used by each discipline to produce artistic products.

dra.name: — Visual Language for Performance
dra.description: Course Description: Exploration of different approaches and methods to the visual elements of performance. Focus on design and style for different media and genres, storytelling through visual elements of performance.

dra.name: — Interdisciplinary Seminar in Theatre, Dance & Performance
dra.description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary seminar for first- and second-year M.F.A. students in Theatre & Dance. Topics range from current practice in dance, theatre, film and performance, to leading edge developments by outstanding practitioners in the field.

dra.name: — Topics in Contemporary Theatre & Performance
dra.description: Course Description: Special topics designed to study in depth aspects of contemporary performance including performance analysis, cultural and historical context, modes of production, theoretical and political entailments, and issues of spectatorship; e.g., "Brecht & After," "British Theater," "Race & Gender in Performance."

dra.name: — Approaches & Methodologies to Studies in Performance & Practice
dra.description: Course Description: Instruction is offered a variety of disciplinary approaches and methodologies in Performance & Practice, with a focus is on cross-disciplinary learning and research. Usually offered each quarter.
dra.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Admission to any graduate program in the University and consent of instructor.

dra.name: — Performance Studies: Modes of Production
dra.description: Course Description: Introduces students to the literature of performance production in a variety of media: theatre, dance, film, video, computer-based, looking at cultural, aesthetic, rhetorical and political theory. Usually offered in alternate years.

dra.name: — Peformance Studies: Signification & the Body
dra.description: Course Description: Introduces students to analysis of the body in performance, drawing on theoretical models from several fields.

dra.name: — Performance Studies: Performance & Society
dra.description: Course Description: Introduces students to the role of performance (broadly defined), in everyday life, sociopolitical negotiation, identity, social movements, the media, and the state.

dra.name: —  Performance studies: Theory, History, Criticism
dra.description: Course Description: Introduction to the theory, history and criticism, informing performance studies.

dra.name: — Theatre Laboratory
dra.description: Course Description: Advanced practice in acting, designing, directing, playwriting, and technical theatre.

dra.name: — Group Study
dra.description: Course Description: Group study.

dra.name: — Individual Study
dra.description: Course Description: Individual study.

dra.name: — Dissertation Research
dra.description: Course Description: Dissertation research.

dra.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
dra.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.

dra.name: — Stage Make-up
dra.description: Course Description: Approved for graduate degree credit. Lectures, demonstrations, and practical work in aspects of theatrical make-up.

eas.name: — Korean Culture & Society: From Ancient Three Kingdoms to the Global K-Pop
eas.description: Course Description: Evolution of Korean society from Three Kingdoms period (B.C.E 57 to C.E. 676) to the contemporary era emphasizing the perseverance and transformations of traditional social and cultural patterns.

eas.name: — Cinema & Society in China
eas.description: Course Description: Knowledge of Chinese not required. Viewing and analysis of one Chinese film with English subtitles each week, followed by discussion and short essays. Cinematic technique, social values and film topics from 1930s to today.
eas.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HIS 190C; HIS 193; or consent of instructor.

eas.name: — East Asian Studies Seminar
eas.description: Course Description: Political, social, cultural, and economic issues in East Asia. Topic varies each year.
eas.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

eas.name: — East Asian Studies Seminar
eas.description: Course Description: Work experience in the East Asian Studies field, with analytical term paper on a topic approved by the instructor.
eas.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

eas.name: — Special Study for Honors Students
eas.description: Course Description: Guided research, under the direction of a faculty member, leading to a senior honors thesis on a topic in East Asian Studies culture, society, or language.
eas.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open only to majors of senior standing who qualify for Honors Program.

eas.name: — Honors Seminar
eas.description: Course Description: A two-quarter research project culminating in an Honors thesis. A grade of B or higher must be earned to qualify the student for honors distinction at graduation.
eas.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; GPA of 3.500 in the major; senior standing.

eas.name: — Honors Seminar
eas.description: Course Description: A two-quarter research project culminating in an Honors thesis. A grade of B or higher must be earned to qualify the student for honors distinction at graduation.
eas.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; GPA of 3.500 in the major, senior standing.

ecl.name: — Principles & Applications of Ecology
ecl.description: Course Description: Covers principles of community structure and functioning, species diversity patterns, ecosystem ecology and biogeochemistry, landscape ecology, biogeography and phylogenetics.
ecl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 102; MAT 016A; MAT 016B; or consent of instructor; first course in Ecology (e.g., ESP 100).

ecl.name: — Principles & Applications of Ecology
ecl.description: Course Description: Provides a broad background in the principles and applications of ecology, and serves as a foundation for advanced ecology courses. Topics include ecophysiology, behavioral ecology, population ecology, genetics and evolution. Emphasis on historical developments, current understanding, and real world applications.
ecl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 102; MAT 016A; MAT 016B; or consent of instructor; first course in Ecology (e.g., ESP 100).

ecl.name: — Community Ecology
ecl.description: Course Description: Introduction to literature and contemporary research into processes structuring ecological communities.
ecl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): An upper division course in Ecology (ECL).

ecl.name: — Concepts & Methods in Plant Community Ecology
ecl.description: Course Description: Principles and techniques of vegetation analysis, including structure, composition, and dynamics. Emphasis given to sampling procedures, association analysis, ordination, processes and mechanisms of succession, and classification. Most techniques are demonstrated or conducted during field trips and laboratories.
ecl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; introductory courses in statistics and plant ecology.

ecl.name: — Plant Population Biology
ecl.description: Course Description: Introduction to theoretical and empirical research in plant population biology. Emphasis placed on linking ecological ecological and genetic approaches to plant population biology.
ecl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Advanced undergraduate ecology course (e.g., ESP 100, EVE 101, ENT 104 or PLB 117), and advanced undergraduate course in genetics and/or evolution (e.g., BIS 101 or EVE 100).

ecl.name: — Issues in Conservation Biology
ecl.description: Course Description: Graduate-level introduction to current research in conservation biology. Emphasizes reading and discussing primary literature. Specific topics will reflect the research interests of UC Davis conservation biology faculty.
ecl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Introductory biology (e.g. BIS 002B) and an upper division organismal biology class.

ecl.name: — Environmental Policy Process
ecl.description: Course Description: Introduction to selected topics of the policy process and applications to the field of environmental policy. Develops critical reading skills, understanding of policy theory, and an ability to apply multiple theories to the same phenomena.

ecl.name: — Environmental Policy Evaluation
ecl.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Method and practice, philosophical basis, and political role of policy analysis. Reviews basic concepts from economic theory; how and why environmental problems emerge in a market economy; and tools necessary for solving environmental problems.

ecl.name: — Marine Ecology: Concepts & Practice
ecl.description: Course Description: Critical review and analysis of concepts and practices in modern marine ecology at the interface of several fields of study including oceanography, evolution, behavior, and physiology. Emphasis on critical thinking, problem solving, and hands-on study. Two field trips required.
ecl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Graduate standing or one course in ecology, one course in evolution or genetics; survey course in marine ecology recommended.

ecl.name: — Social Ecological Systems
ecl.description: Course Description: Overview of social-ecological systems that links environmental policy and decision-making to ecological processes. Delves deeper into different social science topics related to this broader idea. Applying of course readings to case studies chosen by students and a final paper.
ecl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of core courses for specific graduate programs, for example ECL 200A, ECL 200B.

ecl.name: — Ecology & Agriculture
ecl.description: Course Description: Ecological principles as relevant to agriculture. Integration of ecological approaches into agricultural research to increase ecosystem functions and services. Topics include crop autoecology, biotic interactions among crops and pests, ecosystem and landscape ecology.
ecl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EVE 011; or consent of instructor.

ecl.name: — Ecosystem Biogeochemistry
ecl.description: Course Description: Multi-disciplinary analysis of energy and nutrient transfers within terrestrial ecosystems. Examination of processes and inter- and intra-system interactions between the atmosphere, biosphere, lithosphere, and hydrosphere. Laboratory section uses biogeochemical simulation models to examine case studies.
ecl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Introductory courses in ecology/biology and soils are recommended; undergraduates accepted with consent of instructor.

ecl.name: — Terrestrial Field Ecology
ecl.description: Course Description: Field course conducted over spring break and four weekends at Bodega Bay, emphasizing student projects. Ecological hypothesis testing, data gathering, analysis, and written and oral presentation of results are stressed.
ecl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Introductory ecology and introductory statistics or consent of instructor.

ecl.name: — Mathematical Methods in Population Biology
ecl.description: Course Description: Mathematical methods used in population biology. Linear and nonlinear difference equation and differential equation models are studied, using stability analysis and qualitative methods. Partial differential equation models are introduced. Applications to population biology models are stressed.
ecl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 016C or MAT 021C; or the equivalent.

ecl.name: — Theoretical Ecology
ecl.description: Course Description: Examination of major conceptual and methodological issues in theoretical ecology. Model formulation and development will be emphasized. Topics differ from year to year.

ecl.name: — Computational Methods in Population Biology
ecl.description: Course Description: Numerical methods for simulating population dynamics using the computational software package R. Emphasis placed on model formulation and development, theoretical concepts and philosophical principles to guide simulation efforts, model parameterization, and implementing simulations with R.
ecl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): A course in theoretical ecology (e.g., ECL 231 or an equivalent to ESP 121 from your undergraduate institution) or consent of instructor; no programming experience required.

ecl.name: — Ecological Genomics
ecl.description: Course Description: Genomics concepts, technologies, and analyses for ecology research. Mixture of lecture, discussion of recent literature, hands-on training in data analysis and experimental design, and research proposal preparation and evaluation. One all-day field trip is required.
ecl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECL 242; or equivalent training in ecology and genetics according to the discretion of the instructors.

ecl.name: — Climate Change, Water & Society
ecl.description: Course Description: Integration of climate science and hydrology with policy to understand hydroclimatology and its impact upon natural and human systems. Assignments: readings, take-home examination on climate and hydrologic science, paper that integrates course concepts into a research prospectus or review article.

ecl.name: — Advanced Population Dynamics
ecl.description: Course Description: Logical basis for population models, evaluation of simple ecological models, current population models with age, size, and stage structure, theoretical basis for management and exemplary case histories. Emphasis on development and use of realistic population models in ecological research.
ecl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing; advanced course in ecology (e.g., EVE 101), population dynamics (e.g., WFC 122), and one year of calculus; familiarity with matrix algebra and partial differential equations recommended.

ecl.name: — Research Conference in Ecology
ecl.description: Course Description: Critical presentation and evaluation of current literature and ongoing research in ecology. Requirements include active participation in weekly discussions and the presentation of a paper or chapter once per quarter.
ecl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ecl.name: — Current Anthropology Journal Editorial Workshop
ecl.description: Course Description: Reading and offering workshop critiques of manuscripts submitted for publication, and reading and discussion of other relevant work in anthropology and human ecology. Track and edit published comments and authors’ replies that accompany major features. Participation in the development of new sections for the electronic edition of the journal, including a "news and views" section and a debate section.
ecl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ecl.name: — Seminar in Ecology
ecl.description: Course Description: Topics in ecology. Students are expected to present an oral seminar on a particular aspect of the general topic under consideration.
ecl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ecl.name: — Topics in Ecology & Evolution
ecl.description: Course Description: Seminars presented by visiting lecturers, UC Davis faculty, and graduate students.
ecl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

ecl.name: — Tutoring in Ecology
ecl.description: Course Description: Teaching ecology including conducting discussion groups for regular departmental courses under direct guidance of staff.
ecl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing in ecology.

ecl.name: — Group Study
ecl.description: Course Description: Group study.

ecl.name: — Research
ecl.description: Course Description: Research.
ecl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

ecn.name: — Principles of Microeconomics
ecn.description: Course Description: ECN 001A & ECN 001B may be taken in either order. Analysis of the allocation of resources and the distribution of income through a price system; competition and monopoly; the role of public policy; comparative economic systems.

ecn.name: — Principles of Microeconomics
ecn.description: Course Description: Analysis of the allocation of resources and the distribution of income through a price system; competition and monopoly; the role of public policy; comparative economic systems.

ecn.name: — Principles of Microeconomics
ecn.description: Course Description: Analysis of the allocation of resources and the distribution of income through a price system; competition and monopoly; the role of public policy; comparative economic systems.

ecn.name: — Principles of Macroeconomics
ecn.description: Course Description: ECN 001A & ECN 001B may be taken in either order. Analysis of the economy as a whole; determinants of the level of income, employment and prices; money and banking, economic fluctuations, international trade, economic development; the role of public policy.

ecn.name: — Principles of Macroeconomics
ecn.description: Course Description: Analysis of the economy as a whole; determinants of the level of income, employment and prices; money and banking, economic fluctuations, international trade, economic development; the role of public policy.

ecn.name: — Lower Division Seminar
ecn.description: Course Description: Examination of a special topic in Economics through shared readings, discussions, and written assignments.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Lower division standing.

ecn.name: — Internship & Field Work
ecn.description: Course Description: Intensive study of practical application of concepts in economics, stressing research methods and empirical analysis.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Group Study for Undergraduates
ecn.description: Course Description: Primarily for lower division students.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Individual Study for Undergraduates
ecn.description: Course Description: Individual study for undergraduates.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Intermediate Micro Theory: Consumer & Producer Theory
ecn.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Consumer and producer theory. Equilibrium and welfare analysis. Topics include competitive markets, consumer and producer surplus at an intermediate level.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 001A C- or better or ECN 001AV C- or better); ECN 001B C- or better; (MAT 016A C- or better or MAT 017A C- or better or MAT 021A C- or better); (MAT 016B C- or better or MAT 017B C- or better or MAT 021B C- or better).

ecn.name: — Intermediate Micro Theory: Imperfect Competition & Market Failure
ecn.description: Course Description: Imperfect competition and market failure. Topics include exchange, monopoly, game theory, uncertainty, asymmetric information, and public goods.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 100A.

ecn.name: — Intermediate Macro Theory
ecn.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Theory of income, employment and prices under static and dynamic conditions, and long term growth.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 001A C- or better or ECN 001AV C- or better); ECN 001B C- or better; ((MAT 016A C- or better,  MAT 016B C- or better) or (MAT 021A C- or better,  MAT 021B C- or better) or (MAT 017A C- or better,  MAT 017B C- or better)).

ecn.name: — Analysis of Economic Data
ecn.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Analysis of economic data to investigate key relationships emphasized in introductory micro and macro economics. Obtaining, transforming, displaying data; statistical analysis of economic data; basic univariate and multivariate regression analysis.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 001A or ECN 001AV); ECN 001B; (STA 013 or STA 013Y or STA 032); (MAT 016A or MAT 017A or MAT 021A); (MAT 016B or MAT 017B or MAT 021B); or consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Economics of Uncertainty & Information
ecn.description: Course Description: Optimal decisions under uncertainty, expected utility theory, economics of insurance, asymmetric information, signalling in the job market, incentives and Principal-Agent theory, optimal search strategies and the reservation price principle.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 100 or ECN 100A or (ARE 100A,  ARE 100B)),  ECN 100B,  (MAT 016A or MAT 017A or MAT 021A),  (MAT 016B or MAT 017B or MAT 021B).

ecn.name: — Decision Making
ecn.description: Course Description: Descriptive and normative analysis of individual decision making, with applications to personal, professional, financial, and public policy decisions. Emphasis on decision making under uncertainty and over time. Heuristics and biases in the psychology of decisions; overcoming decision traps.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ((MAT 016A C- or better,  MAT 016B C- or better) or (MAT 017A C- or better,  MAT 017B C- or better) or (MAT 021A C- or better,  MAT 021B C- or better)); (STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better or STA 032 C- or better); or consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Neuroeconomics/Reinforcement Learning & Decision Making
ecn.description: Course Description: Theoretical and empirical approaches to neuroeconomics (neuroscience of decision making) from psychology, neuroscience, economics, and computer science. Neuroscience of judgment and decision making, behavioral economics, and reinforcement learning.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 100 or PSC 100Y or PSC 135 or ARE 100A or ECN 100A or NPB 162 or NPB 163); (STA 013 or STA 013Y or STA 100 or PSC 103A); or consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — World Economic History Before the Industrial Revolution
ecn.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Development and application of analytical models to explain the nature and functioning of economies before the Industrial Revolution. Examples will be drawn from a variety of societies, including England, China, Polynesia, and Pre-Columbian America.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 001A or ECN 001AV); ECN 001B.

ecn.name: — World Economic History Since the Industrial Revolution
ecn.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Development and application of analytical models to explain the nature and functioning of economies since the Industrial Revolution. Examples will be drawn from a variety of societies, including England, China, Germany, and India.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 001A or ECN 001AV); ECN 001B.

ecn.name: — Economic History
ecn.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Survey of economic change in the United States from Colonial times to 1865; reference to other regions in the Western Hemisphere.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 001A or ECN 001AV); ECN 001B; or consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Economics History
ecn.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Survey of economic change in the United States from 1865 to the post World War II era.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 001A or ECN 001AV) or ECN 001B; or consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Economic Development
ecn.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Major issues encountered in emerging from international poverty, including problems of growth and structural change, human welfare, population growth and health, labor markets and internal migration. Important issues of policy concerning international trade and industrialization.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 001A or ECN 001AV); ECN 001B.

ecn.name: — Economic Development
ecn.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Major macroeconomic issues of developing countries. Issues include problems in generating capital, conduct of monetary and fiscal policies, foreign aid and investment. Important issues of policy concerning international borrowing and external debt of developing countries.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 001A or ECN 001AV); ECN 001B.

ecn.name: — Economic Development
ecn.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Macroeconomic issues of developing countries. Problems in generating capital, conduct of monetary and fiscal policies, foreign aid and investment. Issues of policy concerning international borrowing and external debt of developing countries.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 001A or ECN 001AV); ECN 001B.

ecn.name: — Comparative Economic Systems
ecn.description: Course Description: Economics analysis of the relative virtues of capitalism and socialism, including welfare economics. Marxian exploitation theory, the socialist  calculation debate (Hayek and Lange), alternative capitalist systems (Japan, Germany, U.S.) and contemporary models of market socialism.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 100 or ECN 100A or ARE 100A); (ECN 100B or ARE 100B).

ecn.name: — Economics of International Immigration
ecn.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduction to research on the economics of immigration. Immigrant demographics and reasons for migrating. Immigrant success and effects on native populations. Influence of immigrants on those left behind. Discussion of migration policy in the US and other countries.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 001A or ECN 001AV); ECN 001B.

ecn.name: — Industrial Organization
ecn.description: Course Description: Appraisal of the role of competition and monopoly in the American economy; market structure, conduct, and economic performance of a variety of industries.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 100 or ECN 100A or ARE 100A); (ECN 100B or ARE 100B).

ecn.name: — Industrial Organization
ecn.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Study of antitrust and economic regulation. Emphasis on applying theoretical models to U.S. industries and case studies, including telecommunications, software, and electricity markets. Topics include natural monopoly, optimal and actual regulatory mechanisms, deregulation, mergers, predatory pricing, and monopolization.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 100 or ECN 100A or ARE 100A); (ECN 100B or ARE 100B).

ecn.name: — Theory of Games & Strategic Behavior
ecn.description: Course Description: Introduction to game theory. Explanation of the behavior of rational individuals with interacting and often conflicting interests. Non-cooperative and cooperative theory. Applications to economics, political science and other fields.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MAT 016A,  MAT 016B) or (MAT 021A,  MAT 021B) or (MAT 017A,  MAT 017B); or consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Energy Economics
ecn.description: Course Description: Application of theoretical and empirical models to examine efficiency in energy production and use. Energy and environmental policy, market structure and power, global climate change, optimal regulation, and real-world applications; e.g., California electricity crisis.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 100 or ECN 100A or ARE 100A; consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Public Microeconomics
ecn.description: Course Description: Public expenditures; theory and applications. Efficiency and equity of competitive markets; externalities, public goods, and market failures; positive and normative aspects of public policy for expenditure, including benefit-cost analysis. Topics include consumer protection, pollution, education, poverty and crime.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 100 or ECN 100A or ARE 100A); (ECN 100B or ARE 100B).

ecn.name: — Public Finance
ecn.description: Course Description: Economic burden of taxation; equity and efficiency considerations in tax design; structure and economic effects of the U.S. tax system (including personal income tax, corporation income tax, and property tax); tax loopholes; recent developments; tax reform proposals.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 100 or ECN 100A or ARE 100A); (ECN 100B or ARE 100B).

ecn.name: — Health Economics
ecn.description: Course Description: The health care market, emphasizing the role and use of economics. Individual demand, provision of services by doctors and hospitals, health insurance, managed care and competition, the role of government access to health care.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 100 or ECN 100A or ARE 100A); (ECN 102 or ECN 140 or ARE 106 or STA 108); ECN 100B; or consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Poverty, Inequality & Public Policy
ecn.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Examination of the economics of poverty and inequality in the United States, including measurement, trends, and related policies.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 001A or ECN 001AV); ECN 001B.

ecn.name: — Financial Economics
ecn.description: Course Description: General background and rationale of corporation; finance as resource allocation over time; decision making under uncertainty and the role of information; capital market and interest rate structure; financial decisions.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 100 or ECN 100A or ARE 100A); (STA 013 or STA 013Y); (ECN 100B or ARE 100B).

ecn.name: — Money, Banks, & Financial Institutions
ecn.description: Course Description: Banks and the banking system. Uncertainty and asymmetric information in the lending process; efficiency of competitive equilibrium in lending markets. Regulation and the conduct of monetary policy.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 101; (STA 013 or STA 013Y).

ecn.name: — Topics in Macroeconomic Theory
ecn.description: Course Description: Advanced Topics in macroeconomics theory. Develops the theoretical and empirical analysis of a specific field of macroeconomics. Possible topics include, business cycle theories, growth theory, monetary economics, political economics and theories of unemployment and inflation.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 101.

ecn.name: — Macroeconomic Policy
ecn.description: Course Description: Theory and practice of macroeconomic policy, both monetary and fiscal.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 100 or ECN 100A or ARE 100A); (ECN 100B or ARE 100B); ECN 101; (STA 013 or STA 013Y).

ecn.name: — Public Economics in International Perspective
ecn.description: Course Description: Social problems and government responses in developed and developing countries; health, unemployment, informal insurance, poverty, corruption, and public service delivery; emphasis on quantitative and data analysis skills; applications to real world policy problems.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 100A or ECN 100 or ARE 100A); ECN 102.

ecn.name: — Econometrics
ecn.description: Course Description: Problems of observation, estimation and hypotheses testing in economics through the study of the theory and application of linear regression models. Critical evaluation of selected examples of empirical research and exercises in applied economics.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 100 or ECN 100A or ARE 100A); (ECN 102 or STA 108); or consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Economic & Financial Forecasting
ecn.description: Course Description: Introduction to economics and financial forecasting tools. Econometrics modeling methods and real-world data applications using the computing language R. Time-series techniques including auto-regression, random walk, and volatility forecasting. Financial econometrics topics including yield curve modeling and asset pricing.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 100 or ECN 100A); ECN 101; (ECN 102 or STA 108); or consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Economics & Business Data Analytics
ecn.description: Course Description: Introduction to economics and business data analytics. Statistical learning methods to analyze big data in economics and business data analysis. Statistical learning, linear regression, classification, resampling methods, and linear model selection and regularization.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 100 or ECN 100A); (ECN 102 B or better or ECN 140 B or better).

ecn.name: — Transportation Economics
ecn.description: Course Description: Examination of fundamental problems of planning and financing transportation "infrastructure" (roads, ports, airports). Economics of the automobile industry, as well as the impact of government regulation and deregulation in the airlines and trucking industries. Intended for advanced Economics undergraduates.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 100 or ECN 100A or ARE 100A); (ECN 102 or STA 108); or consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Economics of the Labor Market
ecn.description: Course Description: Theory of labor supply and demand; determination of wages and employment in the labor market. Policy issues:  labor force participation by married women; minimum wages and youth unemployment; effect of unions on wages.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 100 or ECN 100A or ARE 100A.

ecn.name: — Economics of Human Resources
ecn.description: Course Description: Human resource analysis; introduction to human capital theory and economics of education; the basic theory of wage differentials, including theories of labor market discrimination; income distribution; poverty. Policy issues; negative income tax; manpower training programs; incomes policy.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 100 or ECN 100A or ARE 100A.

ecn.name: — Economics of Education
ecn.description: Course Description: Application of theoretical and empirical tools of economics to the education sector. Demand for Education; Education Production and Market Structures in Education. Policy applications: class size reduction, school finance equalization, accountability, and school choice.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 100 C- or better or ECN 100A or ARE 100A C- or better); (ECN 100B or ARE 100B C- or better); ECN 102 C- or better; (STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better or STA 032 C- or better); or consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — International Microeconomics
ecn.description: Course Description: International grade theory: impact of trade on the domestic and world economies; public policy toward external trade.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 100 or ECN 100A or ARE 100A.

ecn.name: — International Macroeconomics
ecn.description: Course Description: Macroeconomic theory of an open economy. Balance of payments adjustment mechanism, international monetary economics issues; international financial institutions and their policies.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 101.

ecn.name: — International Economic Relations
ecn.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: International trade & monetary relations, trade policy, exchange rate policy, policies toward international capital migration and investment. Emphasis on current policy issues. Intended especially for non-majors.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 001A or ECN 001AV); ECN 001B; or consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — International Finance
ecn.description: Course Description: Advanced international finance. Decision-making processes of large firms, institutional investors and sovereign governments, and their interactions in global financial markets. Pricing of currencies, equities and bonds as well as intermediation and regulation of asset markets. Solving theoretical models, analyzing financial data, and presenting real-life case studies.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 100A or ECN 100 or ARE 100A); ECN 101.

ecn.name: — Economic Development in Weak States
ecn.description: Course Description: Barriers to economic development in developing countries. Economic and policy tools to address barriers within a functioning, well-intentioned government and non-functioning or ill-intentioned governments. Conflict between the state and other subnational actors for legitimate political control. Field experiments and other methodology to understand the success of economic and policy tools in weak states.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 100A; ECN 100B.

ecn.name: — Economy of East Asia
ecn.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Intensive reading, discussion and research on selected topics from the economies of the countries of East Asia. Consult department for course scheduling.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 001A or ECN 001AV); ECN 001B; or consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Topics in Economics
ecn.description: Course Description: Selected topics in economic analysis and public policy. Variable content.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Upper Division Seminar
ecn.description: Course Description: In-depth examination at an upper division level of a special topic in Economics. Emphasis on focused analytical work. May not be repeated for credit.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 100 or ECN 100A); ECN 100B; ECN 101; and consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Internship
ecn.description: Course Description: Internship experience off and on campus in all subject areas offered in the Department of Economics. Supervised by a member of the staff.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

ecn.name: — Special Study for Honors Students
ecn.description: Course Description: A program of research culminating in the writing of a senior honors thesis under the direction of a faculty advisor.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Major in Economics with senior standing; consent of instructor and completion of 135 units with a minimum GPA of 3.500 in courses counted toward the major.

ecn.name: — Special Study for Honors Students
ecn.description: Course Description: A program of research culminating in the writing of a senior honors thesis under the direction of a faculty advisor.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Major in Economics with senior standing; consent of instructor and completion of 135 units with a minimum GPA of 3.500 in courses counted toward the major.

ecn.name: — Tutoring in Economics
ecn.description: Course Description: Undergraduates assist the instructor by tutoring students in one of the department's regularly scheduled courses.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor and chairperson.

ecn.name: — Directed Group Study
ecn.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
ecn.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Microeconomic Theory
ecn.description: Course Description: Linear and non-linear optimization theory applied to develop the theory of the profit-maximizing firm and the utility-maximizing consumer.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

ecn.name: — Microeconomic Theory
ecn.description: Course Description: Characteristics of market equilibrium under perfect competition, simple monopoly and monopsony. Emphasis on general equilibrium and welfare economics; the sources of market success and market failure.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 200A.

ecn.name: — Microeconomic Theory
ecn.description: Course Description: Uncertainty and information economics. Individual decision making under uncertainty. Introduction to game theory, with emphasis on applications to markets with firms that are imperfect competitors or consumers that are imperfectly informed.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 200B.

ecn.name: — Macroeconomic Theory
ecn.description: Course Description: Macro static theory of income, employment, and prices.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 101; MAT 021A; MAT 021B; MAT 021C; or equivalent courses.

ecn.name: — Macroeconomic Theory
ecn.description: Course Description: Macrodynamic theory of income, employment, and prices.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 200B (can be concurrent); ECN 200D.

ecn.name: — Macroeconomic Theory
ecn.description: Course Description: Interaction between financial markets’ frictions and macroeconomic fluctuations. Leverage and the financial accelerator, fire sales, credit booms and busts, liquidity, the role of intermediaries and the risk of bank runs, speculative bubbles, and incomplete markets and precautionary savings.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 200A; ECN 200B; ECN 200C { can be concurrent }; ECN 200D; ECN 200E.

ecn.name: — History of Economic Thought
ecn.description: Course Description: Economic thought from the classical Greece era to modern times.

ecn.name: — History of Economic Thought II
ecn.description: Course Description: Origins and emergence of modern economic analysis.

ecn.name: — Advanced Economic Theory
ecn.description: Course Description: Advanced topics in general equilibrium theory and welfare economics: existence, determinateness and efficiency; intertemporal economies; uncertainty.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 200A; ECN 200B.

ecn.name: — Advanced Economic Theory: Game Theory
ecn.description: Course Description: Covers the most recent developments in game theory, with the focus changing from year to year. Main topics are: refinements Nash equilibrium, repeated games, evolution, social situations, bounded rationality, and bargaining theory.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 200A; ECN 200B; ECN 200C.

ecn.name: — Topics in Economic Theory
ecn.description: Course Description: Selected topics in contemporary microeconomic theory.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 200A; ECN 200B; ECN 200C.

ecn.name: — Economic History
ecn.description: Course Description: Economic history of the eastern hemisphere in the modern period. Medieval Europe or other regions may be studied, depending on student interest.

ecn.name: — Economic History
ecn.description: Course Description: The United States from Colonial times to the present. Other areas of the western hemisphere may be studied, according to student interest.

ecn.name: — Economic History
ecn.description: Course Description: Selected topics and issues, emphasis on current research. (Quarter offered to be flexible.)
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): A graduate course in economic history.

ecn.name: — Development Economics
ecn.description: Course Description: Review of the principal theoretical and empirical issues whose analysis has formed development economics. Analysis of economic development theories and development strategies and their application to specific policy issues in developing country contexts.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 100A; ARE 100B; ECN 101; ARE 204/ECN 204 and ECN 160A-ECN 160B recommended.

ecn.name: — Microdevelopment Theory & Methods I
ecn.description: Course Description: Agricultural development theory, with a focus on microeconomics. Agricultural household behavior with and without market imperfections and uncertainty. Analysis of rural land, labor, credit and insurance markets, institutions, and contracts.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 200A or ECN 204; ECN 240A recommended.

ecn.name: — Open Macroeconomics of Development
ecn.description: Course Description: Models and policy approaches regarding trade, monetary and fiscal issues, capital flows and debt are discussed in the macroeconomic framework of an open developing country. Basic analytical focus is real exchange rate and its impact on sectoral allocation of resources.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ARE 200A or ECN 200A); (ARE 204 or ECN 204); (ECN 214 or ECN 215A); ECN 200D or ECN 205.

ecn.name: — Microdevelopment Theory & Methods II
ecn.description: Course Description: Extension of development theory and microeconomic methods. Agricultural growth and technological change; poverty and income inequality; multisectoral, including village and regional models. Computable general equilibrium methods and applications.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 215A.

ecn.name: — Environmental & Economic Development
ecn.description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary course drawing on theoretical and empirical research on interactions between environmental resource use and economic development processes. Analysis of issues emerging at the interface of environmental and development economics.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 200A; (ECN 204 or ARE 275).

ecn.name: — Energy & Climate Policy
ecn.description: Course Description: Fundamentals of energy technology, economics, and policy. Survey and analysis of current and prospective climate policies at the local and global level, including but not limited to cap-and-trade, emissions offsets, intensity standards, technology standards, mandates and subsidies.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 100A or ARE 100A; or consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — The Theory of Industrial Organization
ecn.description: Course Description: Game theory is used to analyze strategic interaction of firms in industries. Topics include models of competition, product differentiation, entry-deterring strategies, contractual arrangements, vertical control and antitrust issues.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 200A; ECN 200B; ECN 200C.

ecn.name: — Empirical Analysis in Industrial Organization
ecn.description: Course Description: Recent empirical work in industrial organization. Topics include empirical analysis of cartels, product differentiation, innovation and technological change, and imperfect competition in international markets.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 221A; ECN 240B.

ecn.name: — Industrial Organization & Regulation
ecn.description: Course Description: Optimal regulation of natural monopoly. Topics include regulatory mechanisms for single and multiple output firms under symmetric and asymmetric information, optimality without regulation, the economic theory of regulation, and empirical studies of regulation and deregulation.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 221A; ECN 240B.

ecn.name: — Public Economics
ecn.description: Course Description: Measures of deadweight loss and consumer surplus; optimal commodity and income taxation; tax incidence; policy issues in personal taxation, corporate taxation, and social insurance; the evaluation of effective tax rates.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 200C.

ecn.name: — Public Economics
ecn.description: Course Description: Effects of government policies on economic behavior; labor supply, program participation, investment, consumption and savings.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 240A; ECN 240B.

ecn.name: — Public Economics
ecn.description: Course Description: Advanced topics in economics of the public sector, with emphasis on current research. Topics differ from year to year.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 200C; ECN 240B.

ecn.name: — Poverty & Public Policy
ecn.description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary course covering qualitative and quantitative U.S. based poverty research. Topics include measurement, statistics, theories and evidence on the causes and consequences of poverty, and the history and efficacy of major anti-poverty programs.

ecn.name: — Macroeconomics
ecn.description: Course Description: Frontiers of applied/empirical macroeconomics. Evidence and lessons from macroeconomic history for The Great Depression, financial crises, efficient markets, parity conditions, capital flows, default, financial crises, exchange rates, growth, and other current empirical research topics.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 200D; or consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Macroeconomics
ecn.description: Course Description: Search theory, theory of real-world markets characterized by search frictions, with applications: Labor economics: models of unemployment and wages differentials; Financial economics: determination of asset prices in OTC financial markets; Monetary Economics: foundations for money as a medium of exchange.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 200D; or consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Macroeconomics
ecn.description: Course Description: Basic numerical methods for analytically intractable problems in economics. Techniques presented applicable in a wide range of fields including macroeconomics, econometrics, resource economics, labor economics, economic theory, international trade, finance, game theory, public finance, contract theory, and others.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 200D; or consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Macroeconomics
ecn.description: Course Description: Selected topics in Macroeconomics.

ecn.name: — Econometric Foundations
ecn.description: Course Description: Prepares students for econometric theory and empirical work by examining the statistical foundation of econometrics. Special attention is paid to problems specific to non-experimental data common to social sciences. Topics from matrix algebra are also covered.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Econometric Methods
ecn.description: Course Description: Least squares, instrumental variables, and maximum likelihood estimation and inference for single equation linear regression model; linear restrictions; heteroskedasticity; autocorrelation; lagged dependent variables.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 239; or consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Econometric Methods
ecn.description: Course Description: Topics include asymptotic theory and instrumental variables, pooled time-series cross-section estimation, seemingly unrelated regression, classical hypothesis tests, identification and estimation of simultaneous equation models, cointegration, errorcorrection models, and qualitative and limited dependent variable models.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 240A.

ecn.name: — Time Series Econometrics
ecn.description: Course Description: Probability theory; estimation, inference and forecasting of time series models; trends and non-standard asymptotic theory; vector time series methods and cointegration; time series models for higher order moments and transition data; state-space modeling and the Kalman filter.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 240B; or consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Cross Section Econometrics
ecn.description: Course Description: Estimation and inference for nonlinear regression models for cross-section data; models for discrete data and for limited dependent variables; models for panel data; additional topics such as bootstrap and semiparametric regression.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 240B; or consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Topics in Time Series Econometrics
ecn.description: Course Description: Modern econometric techniques for time series data. Expand on topics covered in ECN 240A, ECN 240B, ECN 240C. Content may differ year to year.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 240C; or consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Topics in Cross Section Econometrics
ecn.description: Course Description: Modern econometrics techniques for cross-section data. Expand on topics covered in ECN 240A, ECN 240B, ECN 240D. Content may differ year to year.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 240D; or consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Labor Economics
ecn.description: Course Description: Philosophy, theory and history of American and foreign labor movements; union structure, organization and collective bargaining under changing labor market conditions; current labor market issues.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 150A and ECN 150B) or the equivalent.

ecn.name: — Labor Economics
ecn.description: Course Description: Microeconomic theory of labor supply and labor demand, estimation of labor supply and demand functions; human capital theory; labor market analysis.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 151A; or consent of instructor; ECN 204 or ECN 200A recommended.

ecn.name: — International Economics
ecn.description: Course Description: Theory of trade determinants; gains from trade; tariffs and effective protection; economic unions.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 200A or ECN 204.

ecn.name: — International Economics
ecn.description: Course Description: Balance of payments adjustment mechanisms; foreign exchange markets theories of balance of payments policy and international monetary mechanisms.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 200D; ECN 200E.

ecn.name: — International Investment & Trade
ecn.description: Course Description: Analysis of foreign investment and its links to trade; theories of the firm as they relate to firm's export and investment decisions; and an introduction to the political economy of trade policies.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 260A.

ecn.name: — Topics in International Macroeconomics
ecn.description: Course Description: Survey of current literature in international macroeconomic theory.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 260B; or consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Topics in International Trade
ecn.description: Course Description: Current literature in international trade theory.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 260A; ECN 260B.

ecn.name: — International Macroeconomic Policy
ecn.description: Course Description: Theory and practice of international macroeconomic policy. Topics include exchange rate regimes, international financial institutions, crises and current topics.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 260B.

ecn.name: — Economics of Growth
ecn.description: Course Description: Modern theories and empirics of economic growth beginning with the neoclassical theories up to current endogenous growth models. Emphasis on the analysis of human capital and growth, technological innovation, its diffusion and  empirical evidence on growth.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 200D; ECN 200E.

ecn.name: — Economics of Growth
ecn.description: Course Description: Empirical analysis of growth patterns and growth models. Emphasis on the relationship between macroeconomic management and long-term growth; the use of foreign capital in accelerating growth and its occasional mishaps; the comparison of growth performance in East Asia and Latin America since WW2; the experiences of centrally-planned economies and transitions to market-based growth; and the transformation from an industrial economy to a knowledge economy.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 200D; ECN 200E.

ecn.name: — Economics of Growth
ecn.description: Course Description: Institutional bases; politics; contracts and commitment; money and finance; malthusian dynamics; modern economic growth; transition of industrialization; dual economies, core and periphery; sources of convergence and divergence; openness and growth; resources, demography, and geography; institutions, imperialism, and class conflicts.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 200D; ECN 200E.

ecn.name: — Orientation to Economic Research
ecn.description: Course Description: Bridge the gap between students' classwork and their subsequent research. Topics such as the origination of a research project, some mechanics of empirical research and hints on the submission of research papers.

ecn.name: — Topics in Economics
ecn.description: Course Description: Selected topics in economic analysis and public policy, focusing on current research.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ecn.name: — Contemporary Economics Seminar
ecn.description: Course Description: Seminar series on topics of current interest.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Economics.

ecn.name: — Group Study
ecn.description: Course Description: Group study.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Graduate standing.

ecn.name: — Individual Study
ecn.description: Course Description: Individual study.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Graduate standing.

ecn.name: — Dissertation Research
ecn.description: Course Description: Dissertation research.

ecn.name: — Teaching of Economics
ecn.description: Course Description: Teaching of economics: methods of instruction, organization of courses, examination and evaluation procedures.
ecn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in economics.

edu.name: — Foundations for University Success: Introduction to the University System
edu.description: Course Description: Introduction to resources supporting first year student academic success and transition to a tier one research university.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; student must be a part of an approved Foundations for University Success program.

edu.name: — Foundations for University Success: Introduction to Research at a Tier 1 University
edu.description: Course Description: Development of important skills necessary for research including critical thinking, study skills, writing skills, and presentation skills.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; student must be a part of an approved Foundations for University Success program.

edu.name: — Foundations for University Success: Internships, Graduate School & Careers
edu.description: Course Description: Resources to explore academic and career connections and opportunities including internships, volunteer opportunities, graduate schools and careers.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; student must be a part of an approved Foundations for University Success program.

edu.name: — Learning in Science & Mathematics
edu.description: Course Description: Exploration of how students learn and develop understanding in science and mathematics classrooms. Introduction to case studies and interview techniques and their use in K-6 classrooms to illuminate factors that affect student learning.

edu.name: — Internship
edu.description: Course Description: Internship as a teacher’s aide or tutor in K-12 classrooms under the supervision of a faculty member.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

edu.name: — Directed Group Study
edu.description: Course Description: Primarily for lower division students.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

edu.name: — Introduction to Schools
edu.description: Course Description: Study of occupational concerns of teachers; skills for observing classroom activities; school organization and finance; school reform movement; observing, aiding, and tutoring in schools.

edu.name: — Educational Psychology: General
edu.description: Course Description: Learning processes, cognitive development, individual differences, testing and evaluation.

edu.name: — Quantitative Methods in Educational Research
edu.description: Course Description: Problems and methods in data analysis. Design of research projects. Some consideration of procedures suited to digital computers.

edu.name: — Educating Children with Disabilities
edu.description: Course Description: Educational issues and processes involved in teaching children with disabilities. Focuses on the structure of special education, with an emphasis on meeting the educational needs of children who are mainstreamed in regular classes.

edu.name: — Use & Misuse of Standardized Tests
edu.description: Course Description: Principles underlying educational and psychological testing. Purposes of testing for individual achievement and evaluation of school programs. Interpretation and misinterpretations of outcomes. Analysis of SAT, GRE and other common tests. Experience in test administration and outcome interpretation.

edu.name: — Philosophical & Social Foundations of Education
edu.description: Course Description: Philosophical, historical, and sociological study of education and the school in our society.

edu.name: — Introduction to Education Policy Analysis: Tools, Methods & Frameworks
edu.description: Course Description: Introduces students to the field of education policy analysis with a specific emphasis on the quantitative frameworks and analytical tools, drawn primarily from economics and statistics, that are used to guide and inform educational policymaking.

edu.name: — Children, Learning & Material Culture
edu.description: Course Description: How material artifacts shape what and how children learn in school, at home, and in the community. Artifacts examined include books, computers, household appliances, toys and games, entertainment media, collectibles, sports equipment, clothing, folk arts and crafts, and neighborhood space.

edu.name: — Issues in Higher Education
edu.description: Course Description: Analysis of current issues in higher education and of some practical implications of varying philosophical approaches to the role of the university.

edu.name: — Introduction to Environmental Education
edu.description: Course Description: Study of history, philosophy, principles and approaches to environmental education (EE) and outreach; learning theories, teaching strategies and techniques in EE and outreach; evaluation of EE curricula in non-formal and in-school contexts; observing, aiding and facilitating local environmental education programs.

edu.name: — Anglos, Latinos, & Spanish Black Legend: Anti-Hispanic Prejudice Origins & Educational Implications
edu.description: Course Description: Examination of anti-Hispanic prejudice in the United States focusing on the "Black Legend," a 16th-century, anti-Spanish myth underpinning the doctrine of "Manifest Destiny." Exploration of the Legend's presence in contemporary American society through interviews and analysis of school textbooks.

edu.name: — Cultural Diversity & Education in a Sociopolitical Context
edu.description: Course Description: Introduction to cultural diversity and education in a sociopolitical context. Interactive course. Small and large-group discussions explore, extend, and apply readings; range of writing genres for responses to assignments and course themes; lectures, slide shows, speakers, brief fieldwork, and presentations.

edu.name: — Language Development in the Chicano Child
edu.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Bilingualism, first and second language acquisition, bilingual education, language assessment, Chicano Spanish and the role of dialect varieties in the classroom.

edu.name: — Language Development in the Chicano Child
edu.description: Course Description: Bilingualism, first and second language acquisition, bilingual education, language assessment, Chicano Spanish and the role of dialect varieties in the classroom.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Acceptance in Teaching Credential Program.

edu.name: — Academic Spanish for Bilingual Teachers
edu.description: Course Description: Communicative class taught in Spanish focused on the development of Spanish communication skills for current and/or future bilingual teachers. Main topics are related to school content areas in bilingual settings, with an emphasis on standard and Southwest Spanish dialects.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Acceptance in Teaching Credential Program or consent of instructor.

edu.name: — Diversity in the K-12 Classroom
edu.description: Course Description: Analysis of research on learning styles among culturally diverse students with review and evaluation of responsive curricula and classroom teaching techniques. The ethnographic interview as a research tool.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Acceptance in Teaching Credential Program.

edu.name: — Languaging in Chicanx & Latinx Communities & Schools
edu.description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary research on the diverse communicative practices of individuals from Chicanx/Latinx communities in the U.S. Critiques deficit orientation of early social science research and introduces scholarship providing contextualized and nuanced findings about the linguistic practices that Chicanxs and Latinxs use to communicate across a range of learning settings in and out of schools.

edu.name: — Ethnic Studies in K-12 Schools
edu.description: Course Description: Brief historical genealogy of Ethnic Studies as an interdisciplinary field, content and pedagogical knowledge of Ethnic Studies approaches in K-12 school settings and grassroots communities, and reviews the existing research of Ethnic Studies literacies in US public schools.

edu.name: — Introduction to Peer Counseling
edu.description: Course Description: Introduction to peer counseling techniques and development of peer counseling skills.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

edu.name: — Issues in Peer Counseling
edu.description: Course Description: In-depth review and development of skills for specific counseling topics.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

edu.name: — Guidance & Counseling
edu.description: Course Description: Nature and scope of pupil personnel services; basic tools and techniques of guidance; theory and practice of counseling psychology, with emphasis on educational and vocational adjustment.

edu.name: — Language Development
edu.description: Course Description: Theory and research on children's acquisition of their native language, including the sound system, grammatical systems, and basic semantic categories.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): LIN 001 or LIN 001Y; or consent of instructor. LIN 103A, LIN 103B recommended.

edu.name: — Computers in Education
edu.description: Course Description: Applications of computers in education as instructional, intellectual, and communication tools.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Acceptance in Teacher Credential Program.

edu.name: — Computers in Education
edu.description: Course Description: Applications of computers in education as instructional, intellectual, and communication tools.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EDU 180A; acceptance in Teacher Credential Program.

edu.name: — Computers in Education
edu.description: Course Description: Applications of computers in education as instructional, intellectual, and communication tools.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EDU 180B; acceptance in Teacher Credential Program.

edu.name: — Teaching in Science & Mathematics
edu.description: Course Description: Exploration of effective teaching practices based on examination of how middle school students learn math and science. Selected readings, discussion and field experience in middle school classrooms.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; major in mathematics, science, or engineering; or completion of a one-year sequence of science or calculus.

edu.name: — Computer Project for Curricular Integration
edu.description: Course Description: Design and implementation of a curricular unit to integrate computer technology into a K-12 classroom setting. A project-based seminar intended for students with substantial prior experience with instructional use of computers and related technologies.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

edu.name: — Teaching High School Mathematics & Science
edu.description: Course Description: Exploration and creation of effective teaching practices based on examination of how high school students learn mathematics and science. Field experience in high school classrooms.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Major in mathematics, science, or engineering; or completion of a one-year sequence of science or calculus and consent of the instructor.

edu.name: — Learning in a Digital Age: Information, Schooling, & Society
edu.description: Course Description: Focus on the changing nature of learning in a digital age: social media, ubiquitous connectivity, online education, electronic communication, writing, gaming, and youth culture. Readings drawn from major recent works detailing fundamental shifts in information, schooling, and society.

edu.name: — Internship
edu.description: Course Description: Internship as a tutor, teacher's aide, or peer counselor in a school or educational counseling setting under the supervision of a faculty member. May be taught abroad.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

edu.name: — Tutoring in Education
edu.description: Course Description: Leading of small voluntary discussion groups affiliated with the School's upper division courses under the supervision of, and at the option of, the course instructor, who will submit a written evaluation of the student's work.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

edu.name: — Directed Group Study
edu.description: Course Description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

edu.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
edu.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

edu.name: — Educational Research
edu.description: Course Description: Defining educational research questions, reviewing relevant literature, developing research designs, developing research instruments, selecting appropriate data analysis procedures, and writing research projects. A case problem will provide practice in designing and reporting research.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Introductory statistics or consent of instructor.

edu.name: — Qualitative Research in Education
edu.description: Course Description: Examines the design and conduct of educational research using non-numerical data (e.g., text, discourse, imagery and artifacts). Focuses on issues (e.g., validity, reliability, generalizability, ethics) and reporting genres (e.g., narrative accounts, case studies, and arguments).
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

edu.name: — Computer Analysis of Qualitative Data
edu.description: Course Description: Critical and practical understanding of how to use computer software programs to analyze qualitative data (text, images, and videotape) in conducting social research.

edu.name: — Educational Testing & Evaluation
edu.description: Course Description: Introduces the theoretical assumptions underlying traditional test construction, as well as the basic statistical principles involved in the design, evaluation, and interpretation of standardized tests. Introduces the debates surrounding the uses of different kinds of tests and evaluation tools.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

edu.name: — Quantitative Methods in Educational Research:  Analysis of Correlational Designs
edu.description: Course Description: Methods for analysis of correlational data in educational research. Topics include multiple correlation and regression, discriminant analysis, logistic regression, and canonical correlation. Emphasis on conceptual understanding of the techniques and use of statistical software.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Introductory statistics or consent of instructor.

edu.name: — Quantitative Methods in Educational Research:  Experimental Designs
edu.description: Course Description: Methods for analysis of experimental data in educational research. Topics include ANOVA, fixed v. random effects models, repeated measures ANOVA, analysis of co-variance, MANOVA, chi square tests, small sample solutions to t and ANOVA.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Introductory statistics or consent of instructor.

edu.name: — Ethnographic Research in Schools I: Current Theory & Practice
edu.description: Course Description: Current literature from anthropology and society related to schools.Emphasis on the organizational structure of institutions,and the analysis of face-to-face interaction. Explore the relationship between field-based research and theory development on the acquisition of knowledge in specific social and cultural contexts.

edu.name: — Ethnographic Research in Schools II: Field-Based Research Projects
edu.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Student research projects in specific schools with cooperative critical analysis of the design, data collection, and inferencing by researchers. Students will continue to meet with instructor as a group throughout the quarter to discuss specific projects.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EDU 205A.

edu.name: — Inquiry into Classroom Practice: Traditions & Approaches
edu.description: Course Description: Introduction to traditions and approaches of teachers conducting research in their own classrooms: purposes, focal areas, methods of data collection and analysis, and written genre conventions.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Acceptance in Teacher Credential Program.

edu.name: — Inquiry into Classroom Practice: Application of Teacher Research Approaches
edu.description: Course Description: Analysis and application of teacher research through the development, implementation and evaluation of a short-term classroom research-based intervention. Particular attention to research that enhances learning of English language learners and under-performing students.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EDU 206A; or consent of instructor.

edu.name: — Inquiry into Classroom Practice: Study Design
edu.description: Course Description: Proposal development for classroom-based inquiry designed to address student learning needs. Mixed methods research design and preliminary data collection approaches. Design and application of baseline student assessment for proposal development. Literature review. Data collection in K-12 classrooms required.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EDU 206B; or consent of instructor.

edu.name: — Inquiry into Classroom Practice: Data Analysis & Research Reporting
edu.description: Course Description: Support of the inquiry in EDU 206C through continuous collaborative critique and feedback resulting in the writing and presentation of a research study.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EDU 206C; or consent of instructor.

edu.name: — Concepts of the Curriculum
edu.description: Course Description: Development of the skills of philosophical analysis and argument for the establishment of a point of view, in the consideration of curriculum theory and practice. Classical and contemporary approaches to subject matter and activity emphases, hidden curriculum, and moral education.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

edu.name: — Presenting Educational Research in Written Reports
edu.description: Course Description: Rhetorical and substantive challenges of presenting educational research through written reports; research rhetoric and genres; competing discourse conventions of educational research, policy, and practice; the social organization of publishing educational research.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

edu.name: — Image-Based Field Research
edu.description: Course Description: Critical and practical understanding of video tape and still photography as resources for enhancing field research in schools and other social setting.

edu.name: — Psychological Perspectives on School Learning
edu.description: Course Description: Study of human learning theory and research related to learning of academic content. Review of contemporary issues of constructivism, problem solving, expertise, conceptual change, transfer, and metacognition.

edu.name: — Sociocultural & Situative Perspectives on Learning & Cognition
edu.description: Course Description: Sociocultural and situative theories of cognition and learning. Major ideas of L.S. Vygotsky, followed by modern perspectives: situated cognition, cognitive apprenticeship, situated learning, communities of practice, cultural-historical activity theory, and distributed cognition. Implications of each theoretical perspective for educational practice.

edu.name: — Individual Assessment
edu.description: Course Description: Theories of intellectual functioning and the measurement of cognitive abilities in school-aged children. Supervised practice in administration and scoring of contemporary tests for children including the WISC-R, the WAIS-R, the Stanford Binet, the McCarthy Scales of Children's Ability.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Introductory statistics or consent of instructor.

edu.name: — Research on Achievement Motivation in Education
edu.description: Course Description: Analysis and critique of recent research on cognitive processes related to achievement motivation in school settings. Topics include self-determination theory, attribution theory, goal theory, intrinsic and extrinsic motivation, learned helplessness. psychological reactance, gender and culture, and research design.
edu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

edu.name: — Concepts & Methods of Policy Analysis
