Solution of the state equations and an analysis of stability, controllability, observability, realizations, state feedback and state estimation. Discrete-time signals and systems, and the Z-transform.

eec.name: — Nonlinear Systems
eec.description: Course Description: Nonlinear differential equations, second-order systems, approximation methods, bifurcations, Lyapunov stability, absolute stability, Popov criterion, circle criterion, sliding-mode control, feedback linearization techniques.

eec.name: — Multivariable Control System Design
eec.description: Course Description: Review of single-loop feedback design. Stability, performance and robustness of multi-input multi-output control systems. H-infinity design. Frequency response methods. Optimization-based design. Algebraic design methods for uncertain systems.

eec.name: — Optimization
eec.description: Course Description: Modeling optimization problems in engineering design and other applications; optimality conditions; unconstrained optimization (gradient, Newton, conjugate gradient and quasi-Newton methods); duality and Lagrangian relaxation constrained optimization. (Primal method and an introduction to penalty and augmented Lagrangian methods.)
eec.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 022A; Knowledge of FORTRAN or C.

eec.name: — Robotic Systems
eec.description: Course Description: Introduction to robotic systems. Mechanical manipulators, kinematics, manipulator positioning and path planning. Dynamics of manipulators. Robot motion programming and control algorithm design.

eec.name: — Reinforcement Learning
eec.description: Course Description: Reinforcement Learning (RL) is the subset of machine learning, the core of artificial intelligence. Topics include fundamentals of RL, bandit problems, Markov decision processes, and dynamic programming.

eec.name: — Random Signals & Noise
eec.description: Course Description: Random processes as probabilistic models for signals and noise. Probability and random variables, Convergence and limit theorems, Specification of random processes, Markov Chains, Wiener process and white Gaussian noise, Poisson process and shot noise, Processing and frequency analysis of random signals.

eec.name: — Signal Processing for Communications
eec.description: Course Description: Signal processing in wireless and wireline communication systems. Characterization and distortion of wireless and wireline channels. Channel equalization and maximum likelihood sequence estimation. Channel precoding and pre-equalization. OFDM and transmit diversity. Array processing.
eec.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 165; EEC 260; or consent of instructor.

eec.name: — Multi-access Communications Theory
eec.description: Course Description: Maximum stable throughput of Poisson collision channels. Classic collision resolution algorithms. Carrier sensing multiple access and its performance analysis. System stability analysis. Joint design of the physical/medium access control layers. Capacity region of multi-access channels. Multi-access with correlated sources.
eec.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (EEC 173A or ECS 152A); STA 120; or equivalent of STA 120.

eec.name: — Optimal & Adaptive Filtering
eec.description: Course Description: Geometric formulation of least-squares estimation problems. Theory and applications of optimum Wiener and Kalman filtering. MAP and maximum likelihood estimation of hidden Markov models, Viterbi algorithm. Adaptive filtering algorithms, properties and applications.

eec.name: — Estimation & Detection of Signals in Noise
eec.description: Course Description: Introduction to parameter estimation and detections of signals in noise. Bayes and Neyman-Pearson likelihood-ratio tests for signal detection. Maximum-likelihood parameter estimation. Detection of known and Gaussian signals in white or colored noise. Applications to communications, radar, signal processing.

eec.name: — Principles of Digital Communications
eec.description: Course Description: Introduction to digital communications. Coding for analog sources. Characterization of signals and systems. Modulation and demodulation for the additive Gaussian channel. Digital signaling over bandwidth-constrained linear filter channels and over fading multipath channels. Spread spectrum signals.
eec.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 165; EEC 260; or consent of instructor.

eec.name: — Information Theory & Coding
eec.description: Course Description: Topics include Entropy, Relatively Entropy, Mutual Information; Asymptotic Equipartition Property; Entropy Rates of Stochastic Process; Data Compression; Channel Capacity; Differential Entropy; Gaussian Channel; Rate Distortion Theory; Network Information Theory.

eec.name: — Mobile Communications
eec.description: Course Description: Time-varying multi-path fading channel models and receiver performance in fading channels; multiple access techniques and multiple access receivers design and performance; optimum design and the capacity of wireless channels.

eec.name: — Error Correcting Codes I
eec.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduction to the theory and practice of block codes,  linear block codes, cyclic codes, decoding algorithms, coding techniques.

eec.name: — Error Correcting Codes II
eec.description: Course Description: Introduction to convolutional codes, turbo codes, trellis and block coded modulation codes,soft-decision decoding algorithms, the Viterbi algorithm,reliability-based decoding, trellis-based decoding, multistage decoding.

eec.name: — Computer Architecture
eec.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduction to modern techniques for high-performance single and multiple processor systems. Topics include advanced pipeline design, advanced memory hierarchy design, optimizing pipeline and memory use, and memory sharing among multiprocessors. Case studies of recent single and multiple processor systems.

eec.name: — High-Performance Computer Architecture
eec.description: Course Description: Designing and analysis of high performance computer architecture with emphasis on vector processing, on-chip interconnect networks, chip-level multiprocessors, memory and storage subsystem design and impact of technological advances on computer architecture.

eec.name: — Networking Architecture & Resource Management
eec.description: Course Description: Design & implementation principles of networking architecture and protocols. Internet, data center, and telephony case studies. Topics: Internet data & control planes; application & services; resource management; Quality of Service (QoS) provisioning; traffic engineering; performance evaluation, software-defined networks, & future research issues.

eec.name: — Modern Parallel Computing
eec.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Exploration of the architecture of modern parallel computers, their programming models, and their programming systems.
eec.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECS 036B or ECS 034; EEC 170 or ECS 154A recommended.

eec.name: — VLSI Digital Signal Processing
eec.description: Course Description: Digital signal processors, building blocks, and algorithms. Design and implementation of processor algorithms, architectures, control, functional units, and circuit topologies for increased performance and reduced circuit size and power dissipation.
eec.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 150B; EEC 170; (EEC 180 or EEC 180B); or consent of instructor.

eec.name: — Advanced Design Verification of Digital Systems
eec.description: Course Description: Design verification techniques for digital systems; simulation-based design verification techniques; formal verification techniques, including equivalence checking, model checking, and theorem proving; timing analysis and verification; application of design cerification techniques to microprocessors.

eec.name: — Design & Optimization of Embedded Computing Systems
eec.description: Course Description: Introduction to design and optimization of digital computing systems for embedded applications. Topics include combinatorial optimization techniques, performance and energy optimization in embedded systems, compilation and architecture-specific mapping, programmable and reconfigurable platforms; design automation and algorithmic improvements to design process.
eec.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 170; (EEC 180 or EEC 180B); or consent of instructor. ECS 122A recommended.

eec.name: — Introduction to Digital System Testing
eec.description: Course Description: Review of several current techniques used to detect physical faults in both combinational and sequential circuits. Topics include fault modeling, fault simulation, test generation, compression techniques, and testing architectures.

eec.name: — Special Topics in Electrical & Computer Engineering: Computer Science
eec.description: Course Description: Special topics in Computer Science.

eec.name: — Special Topics in Electrical & Computer Engineering: Programming Systems
eec.description: Course Description: Special topics in Programming Systems.

eec.name: — Special Topics in Electrical & Computer Engineering: Digital Systems
eec.description: Course Description: Special topics in Digital Systems.

eec.name: — Special Topics in Electrical & Computer Engineering: Digital Systems
eec.description: Course Description: Special topics in Digital Systems.

eec.name: — Special Topics in Electrical & Computer Engineering: Signal Transmission
eec.description: Course Description: Special topics in Signal Transmission.

eec.name: — Special Topics in Electrical & Computer Engineering: Digital Communication
eec.description: Course Description: Special topics in Digital Communication.

eec.name: — Special Topics in Electrical & Computer Engineering: Control Systems
eec.description: Course Description: Special topics in Control Systems.

eec.name: — Special Topics in Electrical & Computer Engineering: Robotics
eec.description: Course Description: Special topics in Robotics.

eec.name: — Special Topics in Electrical & Computer Engineering: Signal Processing
eec.description: Course Description: Special topics in Signal Processing.

eec.name: — Special Topics in Electrical & Computer Engineering: Image Processing
eec.description: Course Description: Special topics in Image Processing.

eec.name: — Special Topics in Electrical & Computer Engineering: High Frequency Phenomena & Devices
eec.description: Course Description: Special topics in High Frequency Phenomena & Devices.

eec.name: — Special Topics in Electrical & Computer Engineering: Solid-State Devices & Physical Electronics
eec.description: Course Description: Special topics in Solid-State Devices & Physical Electronics.

eec.name: — Special Topics in Electrical & Computer Engineering: Systems Theory
eec.description: Course Description: Special topics in Systems Theory.

eec.name: — Special Topics in Electrical & Computer Engineering: Active & Passive Circuits
eec.description: Course Description: Special topics in Active & Passive Circuits.

eec.name: — Special Topics in Electrical & Computer Engineering: Integrated Circuits
eec.description: Course Description: Special topics in Integrated Circuits.

eec.name: — Special Topics in Electrical & Computer Engineering: Computer Software
eec.description: Course Description: Special topics in Computer Software.

eec.name: — Special Topics in Electrical & Computer Engineering: Computer Engineering
eec.description: Course Description: Special topics in Computer Engineering.

eec.name: — Special Topics in Electrical & Computer Engineering: Microprocessing
eec.description: Course Description: Special topics in Microprocessing.

eec.name: — Special Topics in Electrical & Computer Engineering: Electronics
eec.description: Course Description: Special topics in Electronics.

eec.name: — Special Topics in Electrical & Computer Engineering: Electromagnetics
eec.description: Course Description: Special topics in Electromagnetics.

eec.name: — Special Topics in Electrical & Computer Engineering: Optoelectronics
eec.description: Course Description: Special topics in Optoelectronics.

eec.name: — Special Topics in Electrical Engineering & Computer Science: Computer Networks
eec.description: Course Description: Special topics in Computer Networks.

eec.name: — Seminar in Electrical & Computer Engineering
eec.description: Course Description: Discussion and presentation of current research and development in Electrical & Computer Engineering.

eec.name: — Graduate Research Group Conference in Electrical & Computer Engineering
eec.description: Course Description: Research problems, progress, and techniques in electrical and computer engineering.

eec.name: — Capstone Project For MS Plan II
eec.description: Course Description: Conducting research projects in electrical and computer engineering. Communicating research results in written reports and oral presentations. Systemic project implementation to answer a comprehensive scientific or technical question in the area of electrical and computer engineering.

eec.name: — Solid-State Circuit Research Laboratory Seminar
eec.description: Course Description: Lectures on solid-state circuit and system design by various visiting experts in the field.

eec.name: — Seminar in Solid-State Technology
eec.description: Course Description: Lectures on solid-state technology by various visiting experts in the field.

eec.name: — Computer Engineering Research Seminar
eec.description: Course Description: Lectures, tutorials and seminars on topics in computer engineering.
eec.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

eec.name: — Communications, Signal & Image Processing Seminar
eec.description: Course Description: Communications, signal and image processing, video engineering and computer vision.

eec.name: — Systems, Control & Robotics Seminar
eec.description: Course Description: Seminars on current research in systems and control by faculty and visiting experts. Technical presentations and lectures on current topics in robotics research and robotics technology.

eec.name: — Photonics Research Seminar
eec.description: Course Description: Lectures on photonics and related areas by faculty and visiting experts.

eec.name: — Group Study
eec.description: Course Description: Group study.

eec.name: — Research
eec.description: Course Description: Research.

eec.name: — The Teaching of Electrical Engineering
eec.description: Course Description: Participation as a teaching assistant or associate-in in a designated engineering course. Methods of leading discussion groups or laboratory sections, writing and grading quizzes, use of laboratory equipment, and grading laboratory reports.
eec.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Meet qualifications for teaching assistant and/or associate-in in Electrical Engineering.

eec.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
eec.description: Course Description: Teaching Assistant training.

emr.name: — Emergency Medicine Clinical Research Internship
emr.description: Course Description: Intended to give the undergraduate student an opportunity to conduct "hands-on" clinical research in the Emergency Department. Through the lecture/discussion, students will learn the basics of conducting and developing clinical research studies, using examples from ongoing studies.
emr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; undergraduate student in good academic standing at UC Davis.

emr.name: — Joan Viteri Memorial Clinic Preceptorship
emr.description: Course Description: Directed towards the undergraduate students at UC Davis that volunteer at the Joan Viteri Memorial Clinic (JVMC).

emr.name: — Emergency Medicine Clinical Research Internship
emr.description: Course Description: Intended to give the upper division undergraduate student an opportunity to conduct "hands-on" clinical research in the Emergency Department. Through the lecture/discussion, students learn the basics of conducting and developing clinical research studies.
emr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; undergraduate student in good academic standing at UC Davis.

emr.name: — Joan Viteri Memorial Clinic (JVMC) Student Volunteer
emr.description: Course Description: Field experience in health care delivery, patient histories and physical examinations, health promotions and disease prevention, diagnosis and treatment of episodic, acute and chronic illness, basic laboratory testing and appropriate referral and follow-up. Students must apply and interview.

emr.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
emr.description: Course Description: For students interested in working on specific EM projects in a more extensive way. Must commit at least four hours per week for two quarters.
emr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; experienced RA's who have successfully performed in the EMRAP program for a minimum of three quarters; must have database skills.

emr.name: — Research
emr.description: Course Description: Directed research in the Department of Emergency Medicine.

emr.name: — Preceptorship in Emergency Medicine
emr.description: Course Description: Exposure to the specialty of Emergency Medicine and observation of a wide array of patients in the Emergency Department.

emr.name: — Fundamentals of Point-of-Care Ultrasound
emr.description: Course Description: First in a longitudinal elective course spanning the first two years of medical school. Introduces the fundamental concepts and technique of ultrasonography in preparation for patient assessment during clinical work. Through a series of lectures accompanied by hands-on practice sessions and case challenges, spaced teaching and deliberate practice, students will grasp the fundamentals of diagnostic ultrasound and solidify their knowledge of key medical science concepts.

emr.name: — Fundamentals of Point-of-Care Ultrasound
emr.description: Course Description: Second longitudinal elective course spanning the first two years of medical school. Introduces the fundamental concepts and technique of ultrasonography in preparation for patient assessment during clinical work. Through a series of lectures accompanied by hands-on practice sessions and case challenges, spaced teaching and deliberate practice, students will grasp the fundamentals of diagnostic ultrasound and solidify their knowledge of key medical science concepts.

emr.name: — Introduction to Medical Toxicology
emr.description: Course Description: In-depth review of clinical and medical toxicologic emergencies. Rotation includes contact with toxicology trained emergency faculty, didactic lectures, journal club, simulation training and exposure to a very busy poison control center.
emr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student in good standing.

emr.name: — Diagnostic Medicine for the Undifferentiated Patient
emr.description: Course Description: Distance Learning Didactic Elective. Develop skills for clinical assessment and diagnostic planning for common acute complaints. Develop a process for further expansion of clinical assessment skills that can be utilized for any chief complaint. Develop a broad differential diagnosis based solely on the chief complaint; “scripts” are created. Problem-based learning, self-study, and a diagnostic modality project is utilized.

emr.name: — Wilderness Medicine
emr.description: Course Description: Introductory elective course for students to explore how physicians can interact with the environment in austere conditions through lectures, hands-on/field experience, and case-based learning.

emr.name: — Emergency Medicine Clerkship
emr.description: Course Description: Students complete clinical shifts in the Emergency Department, functioning as Acting Intern. Treat a wide variety of patients and problems under the supervision of the EM Attending. Students are expected to take focused histories and present in clear, concise fashion.
emr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Satisfactory completion of Medicine, Surgery, and Pediatric Clerkship.

emr.name: — Emergency Medicine Ultrasound for Fourth-Year Medical Student
emr.description: Course Description: Intended for students interested in learning both the technical and cognitive skills of bedside ultrasound. Emphasis will be on the use of ultrasound in emergency medicine as a diagnostic tool and in procedural guidance.
emr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Fourth-year Medical Student in good standing; interest in Emergency Medicine or Critical Care is recommended; EMR 440 or equivalent is recommended prior to the rotation.

emr.name: — Ambulatory Elective in Emergency Medicine
emr.description: Course Description: Credit will be given for approved non-AI Emergency Medicine courses at other institutions to which there is not an equal learning experience at UC Davis.

emr.name: — Focus on POCUS A
emr.description: Course Description: Directed towards gaining a greater proficiency of point-of-care ultrasound. Particularly useful for those pursuing careers that use this modality heavily in clinical practice such as primary care, pediatrics, emergency medicine, critical care, physical medicine and rehabilitation, etc.

emr.name: — Focus on POCUS B
emr.description: Course Description: Directed towards gaining a greater proficiency of point-of-care ultrasound. Particularly useful for those pursuing careers that use this modality heavily in clinical practice such as primary care, pediatrics, emergency medicine, critical care, physical medicine and rehabilitation, etc.

emr.name: — Externship in Emergency Medicine
emr.description: Course Description: Students complete clinical shifts in the Emergency Department, functioning as Acting Intern. Treat a wide variety of patients and problems under the supervision of the EM Attending. Students are expected to take focused histories and present in clear, concise fashion.
emr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Satisfactory completion of Medicine, Surgery and Pediatrics.

emr.name: — Pediatric Emergency Medicine Clerkship
emr.description: Course Description: See patients in the Pediatric area of the Emergency Department under the supervision of an Emergency Medicine Attending. Emphasis on recognition and management of the acutely ill pediatric patient and treatment of common pediatric complaints.
emr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Satisfactory completion of Medicine, Surgery, and Pediatrics.

emr.name: — Addiction Medicine; Advanced Clinical Clerkship
emr.description: Course Description: Consists primarily of clinical experiences, with complementary didactics. Clinical experiences will be multidisciplinary, working with drug and alcohol counselors, harm reduction workers, and physicians in family medicine, emergency medicine, internal medicine, and psychiatry. Clinical skills focus on risk factors, diagnosis, comorbidities, and treatment of substance use disorders.

emr.name: — Understanding Health Policy: A Focus on Analysis & Translation
emr.description: Course Description: Paradigm of healthcare delivery in the U.S. is changing rapidly. To prepare the next generation of physician leaders, provide the skills, tools, and knowledge needed to impact decisions made at the policy level.

emr.name: — Emergency Procedures Elective
emr.description: Course Description: Simulator-based skills training for emergency procedures. Topics include airway management, central venous access, chest tube placement, and general critical care resuscitation skills.
emr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Current basic life support (BLS) certification.

emr.name: — Cardiac Arrest, Resuscitation & Repurfusion SSM
emr.description: Course Description: Special Studies Module, a four-week course specific to the topics of Cardiac Arrest, Resusciatation & Repurfusion.

emr.name: — Cardiac Arrest, Resuscitation & Repurfusion SSM
emr.description: Course Description: Special Studies Module, a four-week course specific to the topics of Cardiac Arrest, Resusciatation & Repurfusion.

emr.name: — Research
emr.description: Course Description: Elective where topics may be selected in either basic or clinical research areas of Emergency and/or Critical Care Medicine. The goals will be tailored to each individual student. Enrollment requires prior discussion and consent of instructor.

enm.name: — Internship in Endocrinology
enm.description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in endocrinology.
enm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; approval of project by preceptor prior to internship.

enm.name: — Endocrinology Clinical Clerkship
enm.description: Course Description: Participation with members of subspecialty service in the initial evaluation, work-up, management and follow-up of patients with endocrinologic disorders.
enm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): IMD 430; and/or consent of instructor.

enm.name: — Clinical Nutrition Clerkship
enm.description: Course Description: In-depth experience in assessment and monitoring of nutritional support of patients whose illnesses are complicated by malnutrition and of patients with problems in under-nutrition due to various illnesses.
enm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): IMD 430; consent of instructor of record.

enm.name: — Insights in Endocrinology
enm.description: Course Description: First- or second-year students observe in morning Endocrine and Diabetes clinics; attend bi-weekly noon and afternoon endocrine conferences. Present brief endocrine physiology oral presentation to the endocrine group.
enm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; student in good academic standing.

egg.name: — Introduction to Energy Systems
egg.description: Course Description: Technical, societal and environmental components of energy systems at global, national and regional scales from an interdisciplinary perspective. Energy resources; end-uses and demand; electricity systems; energy efficiency; energy justice; energy emissions; energy policy.

egg.name: — Life Cycle Assessment for Sustainable Engineering
egg.description: Course Description: Life cycle assessment methodology. Emphasis on applications to infrastructure and energy systems. Life cycle design, life cycle cost methods, other tools from industrial ecology, and links to policy.

egg.name: — Energy & Climate Policy
egg.description: Course Description: Fundamentals of energy technology, economics, and policy. Survey and analysis of current and prospective climate policies at the local and global level, including but not limited to cap-and-trade, emissions offsets, intensity standards, technology standards, mandates and subsidies.
egg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 100A or ARE 100A; or consent of instructor.

egg.name: — Energy Seminar
egg.description: Course Description: Selected topics of current interest in energy. Topics vary and will be announced at the beginning of each quarter. Seminar speakers include invited speakers from outside the university as well as faculty.
egg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

egg.name: — Group Study
egg.description: Course Description: Directed reading and discussion on select topics.

egg.name: — Group Study
egg.description: Course Description: Directed reading and discussion on select topics.

eng.name: — Introduction to Engineering
eng.description: Course Description: Introduction to the role of engineers in the acquisition and development of engineering knowledge, the differences and similarities among engineering fields, and the work ethic and skills required for engineering.

eng.name: — Introduction to Engineering Design
eng.description: Course Description: Introduction to the engineering design process that incorporates the development of oral and written communication skills integral to the design process. Conducted in workshop format with hands-on engagement in the design process.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

eng.name: — Introduction to Engineering Design
eng.description: Course Description: Introduction to the engineering design process that incorporates the development of oral and written communication skills  integral to the design process. Conducted in workshop format with hands-on engagement in the design process.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

eng.name: — Engineering Graphics in Design
eng.description: Course Description: Engineering design, descriptive geometry, pictorial sketching, computer-aided graphics, and their application in the solution of engineering problems.

eng.name: — Engineering Problem Solving
eng.description: Course Description: Methodology for solving engineering problems. Engineering computing and visualization based on MATLAB. Engineering examples and applications.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MAT 016A C- or better or MAT 017A C- or better or MAT 021A C- or better); (MAT 016B C- or better (can be concurrent) or MAT 017B C- or better (can be concurrent) or MAT 021B C- or better (can be concurrent)).

eng.name: — Introduction to Entrepreneurship
eng.description: Course Description: Students from all majors will learn the processes involved in modern entrepreneurship and identify an opportunity for innovation. The 3 C's of the entrepreneurial mindset (developed by KEEN) will be covered: Curiosity, Connections, and Creating Values.

eng.name: — The Science Behind the Technology in Our Lives
eng.description: Course Description: Understanding of how the technology in our lives works using only basic concepts and rudimentry mathematics.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): High school algebra.

eng.name: — Issues in Engineering
eng.description: Course Description: Engineering profession and its role in society; engineering design and development process; introduction to the engineering grand challenges; and professional resources for students.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

eng.name: — Issues in Engineering
eng.description: Course Description: Engineering disciplines; the engineering profession’s methods, principles, and career opportunities; professional resources for students.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

eng.name: — Circuits I
eng.description: Course Description: Basic electric circuit analysis techniques, including electrical quantities and elements, resistive circuits, transient and steady-state responses of RLC circuits, sinusoidal excitation and phasors, and complex frequency and network functions.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 021C; C- or better recommended.

eng.name: — Circuits I
eng.description: Course Description: Basic electric circuit analysis techniques, including electrical quantities and elements, resistive circuits, transient and steady-state responses of RLC circuits, sinusoidal excitation and phasors, and complex frequency and network functions.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 021C.

eng.name: — Introduction to Space Exploration: Understanding the Technological & Environmental Challenges
eng.description: Course Description: Introductory overview of the space environment. Discussion of space exploration technology including propulsion, orbital mechanics, and spacecraft engineering.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): High school level Algebra, Geometry, General Science (Physics and Chemistry).

eng.name: — Statics
eng.description: Course Description: Force systems and equilibrium conditions with emphasis on engineering problems.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PHY 009A C- or better or PHY 009HA C- or better); MAT 021D C- or better (can be concurrent).

eng.name: — Properties of Materials
eng.description: Course Description: Introduction to the properties of engineering materials and their relation to the internal structure of materials.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MAT 016C C- or better or MAT 021C C- or better); CHE 002A C- or better; PHY 009A C- or better.

eng.name: — Honors Properties of Materials
eng.description: Course Description: Examination of special materials science and engineering topics through additional readings, discussions, collaborative work, or special activities which may include projects, laboratory experience or computer simulations.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 045 (can be concurrent) or ENG 045Y (can be concurrent); enrollment in the Materials Science and Engineering Honors Program; ENG 045 or ENG 045Y required concurrently.

eng.name: — Properties of Materials
eng.description: Course Description: Introduction to the properties of engineering materials and their relation to the internal structure of materials.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MAT 016C C- or better or MAT 021C C- or better); CHE 002A C- or better; PHY 009A C- or better.

eng.name: — Directed Group Study
eng.description: Course Description: Directed group study.

eng.name: — Electronic Circuits & Systems
eng.description: Course Description: Introduction to analog and digital circuit and system design through hands on laboratory design projects.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 017; C- or better recommended.

eng.name: — Dynamics
eng.description: Course Description: Kinematics and kinetics of particles, systems of particles, and of rigid bodies; application of these topics are applied to engineering problems.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 035 C- or better; (MAT 022B C- or better or MAT 027B C- or better).

eng.name: — Fluid Mechanics
eng.description: Course Description: Fluid properties, fluid statics, continuity and linear momentum equations for control volumes, flow of incompressible fluids in pipes, dimensional analysis and boundary-layer flows.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 035 C- or better; PHY 009B C- or better; (MAT 022B C- or better or MAT 027B C- or better).

eng.name: — Mechanics of Materials
eng.description: Course Description: Uniaxial loading and deformation. General concepts of stress-strain-temperature relations and yield criteria. Torsion of shafts. Bending of beams. Deflections due to bending. Introduction to stability and buckling.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 035 C- or better; (MAT 022B C- or better or MAT 027B C- or better).

eng.name: — Mechanics of Materials Laboratory
eng.description: Course Description: Experiments which illustrate the basic principles and verify the analysis procedures used in the mechanics of materials are performed using the basic tools and techniques of experimental stress analysis.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 104.

eng.name: — Thermodynamics
eng.description: Course Description: Fundamentals of thermodynamics: heat energy and work, properties of pure substances, First and Second Law for closed and open systems, reversibility, entropy, thermodynamic temperature scales. Applications of thermodynamics to engineering systems. May be taught abroad.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 009B C- or better; (MAT 022B C- or better or MAT 027B C- or better).

eng.name: — Engineering Economics
eng.description: Course Description: Analysis of problems in engineering economy; the selection of alternatives; replacement decisions. Compounding, tax, origins and cost of capital, economic life, and risk and uncertainty are applied to methods of selecting most economic alternatives.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing in Engineering.

eng.name: — Launching a Company
eng.description: Course Description: Technological innovation and product development. Working as a team to turn ideas into companies through customer development.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 008 or consent of instructor.

eng.name: — Electric Machinery Fundamentals
eng.description: Course Description: Principles of AC and DC electric motors and generators, their control systems and power sources. Selection of electric power equipment components based on their construction features and performance characteristics.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 017 C- or better.

eng.name: — Fluid Power Actuators & Systems
eng.description: Course Description: Hydraulic and pneumatic systems with emphasis on analysis and control of actuators. Design of hydraulic and pneumatic systems, specification and sizing of components, and selection of electro-hydraulics/electro-pneumatics, servo valves, and closed loop systems to solve basic control problems.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 100 C- or better; ENG 102 C- or better.

eng.name: — Introduction to Mechanical Vibrations
eng.description: Course Description: Free and forced vibrations in lumped-parameter systems with and without damping; vibrations in coupled systems; electromechanical analogs; use of energy conservation principles.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 102 C- or better; (ENG 006 C- or better or ENG 005 C- or better or ECS 030 C- or better); ability to program in MATLAB.

eng.name: — Environmental Physics & Society
eng.description: Course Description: Impact of humankind on the environment are discussed from the point of view of the physical sciences. Calculations based on physical principles will be made, and the resulting policy implications are considered.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PHY 009D or PHY 010 or PHY 001B); MAT 016B; or the equivalent of MAT 016B.

eng.name: — Engineering Analysis
eng.description: Course Description: Solutions of systems of linear and nonlinear algebraic equations; approximation methods; solutions of ordinary differential equations; initial and boundary value problems; solutions of partial differential equations of Elliptic, parabolic, and hyperbolic types; Eigen value problems.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ENG 006 C- or better or EME 005 C- or better or ECS 030 C- or better or ECS 032A C- or better or ECS 036A C- or better); ((MAT 021D C- or better,  (MAT 022B C- or better or MAT 027B C- or better)).

eng.name: — Science & Technology of Sustainable Power Generation
eng.description: Course Description: Focus on scientific understanding and development of power generation that is the basis of modern society. Concentration on power generation methods that are sustainable, in particular, discussion of the most recent innovations.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 007C or PHY 009C; upper division standing.

eng.name: — Professional Responsibilities of Engineers
eng.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Organization of the engineering profession; introduction to contracts, specifications, business law, patents, and liability; discussion of professional, ethical, societal, and political issues related to engineering.

eng.name: — Directed Group Study
eng.description: Course Description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.

eng.name: — Technology Management
eng.description: Course Description: Management of the engineering and technology activity. Functions of design, planning, production, marketing, sales, and maintenance. Technological product life cycle. Research and development activity. Project planning and organization. Manufacturing issues. Case studies.
eng.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

enl.name: — Introduction to Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Introductory study of several genres of English literature, emphasizing both analysis of particular works and the range of forms and styles in English prose and poetry. Frequent writing assignments will be made.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

enl.name: — Writers' Workshop
enl.description: Course Description: Focuses on the development of writing and revision strategies, exploring ways to understand a writing task; to develop appropriate content for a writing task; to revise content to reflect competence as a communicator.

enl.name: — Introduction to Creative Writing: Fiction
enl.description: Course Description: Elementary principles of writing fiction. Write both in prescribed forms and in experimental forms of their own choosing. No final examination.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

enl.name: — Introduction to Creative Writing: Non-Fiction
enl.description: Course Description: Elementary principles of writing creative non-fiction. Work in prescribed literary forms (such as essay, meditation, biography, memoir, book review, documentary, or experimental non-fiction forms) and forms of students' choosing. No final examination.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

enl.name: — Introduction to Creative Writing: Poetry
enl.description: Course Description: Elementary principles of writing poetry. Write both in prescribed forms and in experimental forms of their own choosing. No final examination.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

enl.name: — Literatures in English I: To 1700
enl.description: Course Description: Historical introduction to English language and literature from 800-1700. Linguistic borrowing, innovation, and change. Emergence of key literary genres. Colonial America as a new site of English literary production and consumption.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or equivalent.

enl.name: — Literatures in English II: 1700-1900
enl.description: Course Description: Historical introduction to English language and literature from 1700-1900. Linguistic borrowing, innovation, colonization, and change. Emergence and development of key literary genres. America, Britain, Ireland, Scotland, and India as important sites of English literary production and consumption.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or equivalent.

enl.name: — Literatures in English III: 1900 to Present
enl.description: Course Description: Historical introduction to English language and literature from 1900-present. Linguistic borrowing, innovation, and change. Emergence and development of key literary genres. Formal experimentation. Modernism as transnational phenomenon.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or equivalent.

enl.name: — Introductory Topics in Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Study of a special topic. Literature written in English in any period or place or genre. Thematic, formal, or temporal focus.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or equivalent.

enl.name: — Introductory Topics in Literature & Media
enl.description: Course Description: Study of a topic centered on the relationships between literature and moving-image media.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or (UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y); or equivalent.

enl.name: — Approaches to Reading
enl.description: Course Description: Close reading and interpretation of literature from a variety of traditional and contemporary approaches. Topics include traditional textual and historical approaches; new criticism; formalism; psychological criticism; feminism and gender; reader-response; materialist approaches. Frequent written assignments.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or (UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y); or equivalent.

enl.name: — Introductory Topics in Drama
enl.description: Course Description: Close reading of, and topics relating to selected works of British and American drama from a range of historical periods.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or equivalent.

enl.name: — Introductory Topics in Fiction
enl.description: Course Description: Close reading of, and topics relating to, British and American Fiction: short stories, novellas, novels.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or (UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y); or equivalent.

enl.name: — Introductory Topics in Poetry
enl.description: Course Description: Topical study and close reading of selections from English and American poetry.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or (UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y); or equivalent.

enl.name: — Hot Bars, Supreme Lyrics, & Rhymes for Days: Hip Hop as Poetry
enl.description: Course Description: Literary approaches to hip hop as poetry. Formal examination of rap lyrics in relation to technology, visual expression, dance, and knowledge production. Historical and cultural consideration of race, ethnicity, gender, urban culture, and politics.

enl.name: — Pop Culture Shakespeare
enl.description: Course Description: Critical approaches to the study of Shakespeare’s afterlife in contemporary American media. Focus on visual, audio, and kinesthetic modes of analysis and presentation. Relation of Shakespeare to contemporary society, politics, media, and economics.

enl.name: — Youth in Revolt
enl.description: Course Description: American literary and cultural representations of adolescence as a time of rebellious refusals and wild behaviors in relation to questions of gender and sexuality, psychological states, economic pressures, racial inequality, and methods of discipline and punishment.

enl.name: — Literature, Health, &  Medicine
enl.description: Course Description: Literary and cultural representations of health and medicine in relation to issues of race, gender, sexuality, and disability. Narratives and reading practices that provide complex accounts of the social determinants of health, contested understandings of illness, and critical perspectives on biomedicine.

enl.name: — Literary Animals
enl.description: Course Description: Literary exploration of animals as spectacles, symbols, scientific objects, human companions, and speaking subjects through animal fables and allegories, tales for children, poems, realist narratives, essays, and experimental fictions.

enl.name: — Speculative Fictions
enl.description: Course Description: Historical or thematic exploration of speculative genres such as science fiction, fantasy, utopia/dystopia, and/or horror. May include worldbuilding, intersections with scientific and other disciplinary knowledges, relation to social and political conditions.

enl.name: — Racial Imaginaries
enl.description: Course Description: Critical vocabularies and frameworks for studying the cultural construction of race as a signifier of human difference. Theories of racial formation in poetry, fiction, and other imaginative genres. Rhetorical and media strategies that present and/or obscure the material sources and institutional histories of race and racism.

enl.name: — Introduction to Games
enl.description: Course Description: Introduction to the history, theory, and practice of play. Survey of both analog and digital games. Overview of gaming cultures, aesthetics, industries, and technologies.

enl.name: — Internship in English
enl.description: Course Description: Internships in fields where students can practice their skills. May be taught abroad.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; and consent of instructor.

enl.name: — Directed Group Study
enl.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; and consent of instructor.

enl.name: — Student Facilitated Course
enl.description: Course Description: Student facilitated course intended primarily for lower division students.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or (UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y); consent of instructor.

enl.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
enl.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.

enl.name: — Creative Writing: Fiction
enl.description: Course Description: Writing of fiction. No final examination.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 005F or ENL 005P; ENL 005NF; and consent of instructor.

enl.name: — Creative Writing Advanced Fiction
enl.description: Course Description: Development and evaluation of students' work in prose, primarily in the workshop format. Some reading and discussion of published novels and short stories. Conferences with individual students once per quarter.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 100F.

enl.name: — Creative Writing: Non-Fiction
enl.description: Course Description: Writing of non-fiction. No final examination.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 005F or ENL 005P or ENL 005NF; and consent of instructor.

enl.name: — Creative Writing: Poetry
enl.description: Course Description: Writing of poetry.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 005F or ENL 005P or ENL 005NF; and consent of instructor.

enl.name: — Creative Writing Advanced Poetry
enl.description: Course Description: Development and evaluation of students' work in poetry, primarily in the workshop format. Some reading and discussion of published works of poetry. Conferences with individual students once per quarter.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 100P.

enl.name: — History of the English Language
enl.description: Course Description: History of the English language. Examination of the language as recorded from Old English to present-day English. Relationship of English to other languages; development of vocabulary, phonology, and grammatical patterns.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or (UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y); or the equivalent.

enl.name: — English Grammar
enl.description: Course Description: Survey of present-day English grammar as informed by contemporary linguistic theories. The major syntactic structures of English; their variation across dialects, styles, and registers; their development; and their usefulness in describing the conventions of English.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or LIN 001 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or consent of instructor.

enl.name: — English Grammar Practicum
enl.description: Course Description: Practice in teaching the principles of grammar to the kinds of audiences teachers encounter in California. Discussions with teachers who teach in these areas. Examination of pedagogical research on teaching grammar.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 106; LIN 106 (can be concurrent).

enl.name: — Freedom of Expression
enl.description: Course Description: Historical development of fundamental issues and contemporary controversies about freedom of expression, with emphasis on literary and artistic censorship.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or (UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y); or the equivalent.

enl.name: — Introduction to Literary Theory
enl.description: Course Description: Key theoretical terms, concepts, and thinkers from the Greeks to the modern era.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

enl.name: — Introduction to Modern Literary & Critical Theory
enl.description: Course Description: History of literary criticism in the modern era, with emphasis on the ties with the past and the special problems presented by modern literary theory.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

enl.name: — Topics in Medieval Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused intensive examination of selected topics in Medieval British literature.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

enl.name: — Chaucer: Troilus & the "Minor" Poems
enl.description: Course Description: Development of the poet's artistry and ideas from his first work to his masterpiece, "Troilus and Criseyde"
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

enl.name: — Chaucer: The Canterbury Tales
enl.description: Course Description: Literary analysis of the complete "Canterbury Tales."  Courtly love, literary forms, medieval science and astrology, theology and dogma as they inform the reading of Chaucer's work.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

enl.name: — Topics in 16th- & 17th-Century Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of the Renaissance.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

enl.name: — Shakespeare
enl.description: Course Description: Historically, generically, or thematically focused study of Shakespeare's works.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or equivalent.

enl.name: — Law & Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Historically, thematically, or generically focused study of the relationship between law and literature.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

enl.name: — Milton
enl.description: Course Description: Selected major works, including Paradise Lost.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

enl.name: — 18th-Century British Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused study of 18th-century English literature.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

enl.name: — Topics in Irish Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Intensive study or treatment of special topics relating to the emergence, invention, and re-invention of Irish literature.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or equivalent.

enl.name: — British Romantic Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of Romantic English literature.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

enl.name: — 19th-Century British Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of 19th-century English literature.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

enl.name: — British Literature, 1900-1945
enl.description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of British literature (drama, poetry, prose fiction) from the period between 1900 and the end of World War II.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

enl.name: — British Literature, 1945 to Present
enl.description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of British literature (drama, poetry, prose fiction) from the period between 1945 and the present. May be taught abroad.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

enl.name: — Topics in Global Literatures & Cultures
enl.description: Course Description: Historically or regionally focused study of world literatures in English (other than the national literatures of British Isles and the United States), particularly from post-colonial regions in Africa, the Caribbean, and Asia, and immigrant cultures in the English-speaking world.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

enl.name: — Topics in Postcolonial Literatures & Cultures
enl.description: Course Description: Study of postcolonial literature of Anglophone colonies. Specific emphases may include literature from and about Anglophone India, the Caribbean, the Middle East, South Asia, Africa, and/or South America.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

enl.name: — Topics in Diasporic Literatures & Migration
enl.description: Course Description: Study of literatures, histories, and cultures of one or more diasporic groups.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

enl.name: — Early American Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused study of American literature of the 17th and 18th centuries.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

enl.name: — 19th-Century American Literature to the Civil War
enl.description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of 19th-century American literature.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

enl.name: — Post-Civil War American Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of post-Civil War American literature.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

enl.name: — Reading Race, Class, & Gender
enl.description: Course Description: Readings in literature and culture that present race, class, gender, sexuality, ability, and citizenship as inter-articulated signifiers of difference. Literature is contextualized alongside works of sociology, history, philosophy, and law. Inter-discursive nature of racial thought and policy, and on historical and rhetorical practices through which race acquires meaning.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or COM 001 or COM 002 or COM 003 or COM 004 or NAS 005 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

enl.name: — American Literature 1900-1945
enl.description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused study of American literature (drama, poetry, prose fiction) from the period between 1900 and the end of World War II.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

enl.name: — American Literature, 1945 to the Present
enl.description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused study of American literature (drama, poetry, prose fiction) from the period between 1945 and the present.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or equivalent.

enl.name: — Topics in Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Intensive examination of literature considered in topical terms, not necessarily historically. May be taught abroad.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

enl.name: — British Drama to 1800
enl.description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of English drama prior to 1800.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

enl.name: — Drama from 1800 to the Present
enl.description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused study of works of British drama from 1800 to the present.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

enl.name: — Topics in Drama
enl.description: Course Description: Historical or thematic study of drama.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

enl.name: — The Graphic Novel
enl.description: Course Description: Thematically, historically, and formally focused study of the graphic novel genre. Contents may include any regional, national, or transnational group of graphic novels.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or equivalent courses.

enl.name: — 18th-Century British Novel
enl.description: Course Description: Historically or thematically organized examination of the 18th-century British novel, with particular emphasis on its evolution, including the epistolary novel, the picaresque novel, and the Gothic novel: Richardson, Fielding, Sterne, Austen.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

enl.name: — 19th-Century British Novel
enl.description: Course Description: Historically or thematically organized examination of 19th-century British novelists, with emphasis on the historical novel, the social novel, and novels by women: Scott, Dickens, the Brontes, Eliot, Hardy.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

enl.name: — 20th-Century British Novel
enl.description: Course Description: Historically or thematically organized examination of the 20th-century British novel, with emphasis on impressionism; the revolt against naturalism; the experimental novel; the anti-modernist reaction: Conrad, Joyce, Woolf, Lawrence, Drabble, Rhys.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

enl.name: — The Short Story
enl.description: Course Description: The short story as a genre; its historical development, techniques, and formal character as a literary form. European as well as American writers.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

enl.name: — Detective Fiction
enl.description: Course Description: Historically, formally, and thematically focused study of novels and short stories in the detective fiction genre.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

enl.name: — The American Novel to 1900
enl.description: Course Description: Historically or thematically organized examination of the rise and development of the American novel from its beginnings; Hawthorne, Melville, Twain, James, and others.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

enl.name: — The American Novel from 1900 to the Present
enl.description: Course Description: Historically or thematically organized examination of important American novelists from 1900 to the present: authors may include Willa Cather, Nathanael West, William Faulkner, Ralph Ellison, Zora Neale Hurston, Thomas Pynchon, Ishmael Reed, Maria Helena Viramontes, Rachel Kushner, and others.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

enl.name: — Topics in the Novel
enl.description: Course Description: Examination of major novels arranged thematically. Topics might include Bildungsroman, stream-of-consciousness novel, Gothic novel, historical novel.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

enl.name: — Film as Narrative
enl.description: Course Description: Study of modern film (1930 to present) as a storytelling medium.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

enl.name: — Film Theory & Criticism
enl.description: Course Description: Film theory and criticism, with a study of ten major works of international film art.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

enl.name: — Literary Study in the British Isles
enl.description: Course Description: Literary Study in the British Isles: On-site study of the literature, film, and/or performance of the British Isles. Taught abroad.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

enl.name: — Writing Science
enl.description: Course Description: Texts and writing practices in the production of scientific knowledge. Surveys the literary structure of scientific arguments; history of scientific genres; rhetoric and semiotics in scientific culture; graphical systems in the experimental laboratory; narratives of science, including science fiction.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003; STS 001; or equivalent.

enl.name: — Topics in Poetry
enl.description: Course Description: Intensive examination of various topics expressed in poetry from all periods of English and American literature.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y); ENL 045.

enl.name: — Love & Desire in Contemporary American Poetry
enl.description: Course Description: Close reading of contemporary American poems on the theme of love and desire by poets of diverse ethnicities and of gay, lesbian, and heterosexual orientations.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

enl.name: — 20th-Century African American Poetry
enl.description: Course Description: African American poetry in the 20th-century, including oral and literary traditions. Authors covered may include Gwendolyn Brooks, Countee Cullen, Robert Hayden, and Langston Hughes.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V; UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

enl.name: — 20th-Century American Poetry
enl.description: Course Description: Historical Study of American poetry since 1900, with thematic and formal focus at the instructor's discretion.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

enl.name: — The Bible as Literature: The Old Testament
enl.description: Course Description: Selected readings from the Old Testament illustrating various literary forms. Emphasis on the Pentateuch, the Historical Books, and the Wisdom Books. May be taken independently of ENL 171B.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

enl.name: — The Bible as Literature: Prophets & New Testament
enl.description: Course Description: Selected readings from the Old Testament prophets and the New Testament. May be taken independently of ENL 171A.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

enl.name: — Video Games & Culture
enl.description: Course Description: Critical approaches to the study of video games, focusing on formal, historical, and cultural modes of analysis. History of software and hardware in North American and global contexts. Relations of games to society, politics, economics, media, etc.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CDM 072 or ENL 072 recommended.

enl.name: — Science Fiction
enl.description: Course Description: Literary modes and methods of science fiction. Representative texts, authors, and themes of the genre, e.g., time travel, alternative universes, and utopias. Relations of science fiction to science, philosophy, and culture.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or STS 001; or equivalent.

enl.name: — Study of an Individual Author
enl.description: Course Description: In-depth study of an author's works; historical context; relation to predecessors and contemporaries; critical reception; influence.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 110A or ENL 110B.

enl.name: — Topics in Nations, Regions, & Other Cultural Geographies
enl.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Literary productions of a local, regional, national, transnational, or other geographical formation; e.g., the global South; literature of Hawaii; literature of Australia.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or equivalent.

enl.name: — Topics in Comparative Racial & Ethnic Literary Studies
enl.description: Course Description: Writings by Black, Indigenous, and/or People-of-Color authors responding to specific American contexts of racialization such as slavery, imperial warfare, international and internal migration, naturalization law, religion, mass incarceration, and environmental injustice.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y or COM 001 or COM 002 or COM 003 or COM 004 or NAS 005; Or standing above freshman level.

enl.name: — Children's Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Historical backgrounds and development of types of children's literature, folklore and oral tradition, levels of interest, criticism and evaluation, illustration and bibliography.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

enl.name: — African American Literature to 1900
enl.description: Course Description: African American literature from the colonial period to 1900. Particular attention to the rapid development of the African American literary culture from a primarily oral tradition to various literary genres, including the slave narrative.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

enl.name: — African American Literature 1900-Present
enl.description: Course Description: Major African American writers in the context of cultural history from 1900 to the present. Writers may include Richard Wright, Ann Petry, James Baldwin, Ralph Ellison, Paule Marshall, Toni Morrison, Alice Walker, Clarence Major.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

enl.name: — Literature of California
enl.description: Course Description: Focus is on the diverse contributions to the rise of California literature. Reading of poetry, fiction, and essays. Emphasis on 19th- and 20th-century naturalists, turn of the century novelists, the Beats, and writers of the last two decades.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

enl.name: — Young Adult Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Theoretical, critical, and literary issues informing the study and teaching of American young adult literature.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or equivalent.

enl.name: — Literature & the Environment
enl.description: Course Description: Historical and/or thematic survey of topics in writing about the environment.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

enl.name: — Literature by Women Before 1800
enl.description: Course Description: Women's Writing in English before 1800; organized by period, place, genre, or theme.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y or COM 001 or COM 002 or COM 003 or COM 004 or NAS 005.

enl.name: — Literature by Women from 1800-1900
enl.description: Course Description: Women's Writing in English from 1800 to 1900; organized by period, place, genre, or theme.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y or COM 001 or COM 002 or COM 003 or COM 004 or NAS 005.

enl.name: — Literature by Women after 1900
enl.description: Course Description: Women's Writing in English after 1900; organized by period, place, genre, or theme.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y or COM 001 or COM 002 or COM 003 or COM 004 or NAS 005.

enl.name: — Literature, Sexuality, & Gender
enl.description: Course Description: Historically or thematically focused intensive examinations of gender and sexuality in British and American literature.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

enl.name: — Topics in Literature & Media
enl.description: Course Description: Group study of a topic centered on the relationships between literature and film or other moving-image media.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 110A or ENL 110B; and consent of instructor.

enl.name: — Topics in Literary & Critical Theory
enl.description: Course Description: Intensive examination of theories addressing a particular problem, topic, or question.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 110A or ENL 110B; and consent of instructor.

enl.name: — Seminar in Literary Studies
enl.description: Course Description: Intensive, focused study of literature at an advanced level. May be organized by topic, author, period, movement, or genre. High participation.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 110A or ENL 110B.

enl.name: — Internship in English
enl.description: Course Description: Internships in fields where students can practice their skills. A maximum of 4 units is allowed toward the major in English. May be taught abroad.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

enl.name: — Seminar for Honors Students
enl.description: Course Description: Preparation for writing an honors thesis in ENL 195H. High level of participation expected.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 110A or ENL 110B; One advanced study course; admission to English Department Senior Honors Program in Literature, Criticism, and Theory.

enl.name: — Honors Thesis
enl.description: Course Description: Preparation of a thesis, under the supervision of an instructor. Students satisfying requirements for the general major or the teaching emphasis write on a scholarly or critical subject; creative writing students submit a volume of poems or fiction.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 194H.

enl.name: — Tutoring in English
enl.description: Course Description: Leading of small voluntary discussion groups designed to develop reading and writing skills and affiliated with one of the university's regular courses.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing and consent of Chairperson.

enl.name: — Community Tutoring in English
enl.description: Course Description: Field experience, with individuals or in classroom in instruction of English language, literature, and composition. Does not fulfill requirement for major.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing and a major in English; consent of Chairperson.

enl.name: — Directed Group Study
enl.description: Course Description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or ENL 005F or ENL 005P or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y.

enl.name: — Student Facilitated Course
enl.description: Course Description: Student facilitated course intended primarily for upper division students.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; consent of instructor.

enl.name: — Directed Group Study
enl.description: Course Description: Group study closely tied to the texts and periods studied in ENL 163S. Investigations of historical sites, museums, galleries, and performances. May be taught abroad in London.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 163S (can be concurrent); and consent of instructor; ENL 163S required concurrently.

enl.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
enl.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

enl.name: — Student Facilitated Course Development
enl.description: Course Description: Under the supervision of a faculty member, an undergraduate student plans and develops the course they will offer under 098F/198F.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; consent of instructor.

enl.name: — Student Facilitated Teaching
enl.description: Course Description: STU FAC. Under the supervision of a faculty member, an undergraduate student teaches a course under 098F/198F.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 003 or UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; consent of instructor.

enl.name: — Introduction to Graduate Studies in English
enl.description: Course Description: Introduction to literary scholarship with special attention to the elements of professionalism and to different modes of literary investigation.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

enl.name: — Anglo-Saxon Language & Culture
enl.description: Course Description: The language and culture of Anglo-Saxon England; readings in Old English prose and poetry.

enl.name: — Beowulf
enl.description: Course Description: A study of the poem and the Heroic Age of Germanic literature.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 205; or the equivalent.

enl.name: — Middle English
enl.description: Course Description: Study of the phonology, morphology, syntax, and lexicon between 1100 and 1500 with investigation of the regional dialects; pertinent facts on both the internal and external linguistic history; intensive reading of texts.

enl.name: — Readings in English & American Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Content varies according to specialty of instructor.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division course in area studied.

enl.name: — Topics in Irish Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Varied topics, including the 19th-century novel, contemporary Irish poetry, rise of the drama, or a study of a major author.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

enl.name: — Study of a Major Writer
enl.description: Course Description: Artistic development of one major writer and his intellectual and literary milieu.

enl.name: — Problems in English Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Selected issues in the current study and critical assessment of a limited period or topic in English literature.

enl.name: — Problems in American Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Selected topics for intensive investigation.

enl.name: — Dramatic Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Historical introduction to dramatic theory; the genres of tragedy, comedy, and tragicomedy.

enl.name: — Theory of Fiction
enl.description: Course Description: Theories of fiction as they relate to the professional writer's practice of the craft. For students in the Creative Writing Program.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

enl.name: — Seminar for Writers
enl.description: Course Description: Varied topics in the study of literature and literary culture craft and poetics from the perspective of the writer/practitioner.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

enl.name: — Special Topics in Literary Theory
enl.description: Course Description: Advanced topics in literary theory and criticism. Preparation and evaluation of research paper.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENL 237; or the equivalent.

enl.name: — Medieval Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Studies of Medieval literature. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

enl.name: — 16th-Century Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Studies in 16th-century literature. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

enl.name: — Shakespeare
enl.description: Course Description: Studies in Shakespeare. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

enl.name: — 17th-Century Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Studies in 17th-century literature. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

enl.name: — 18th-Century Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Studies in 18th-century literature. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

enl.name: — Romantic Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Studies in Romantic literature. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

enl.name: — Victorian Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Studies in Victorian literature. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

enl.name: — 20th-Century British Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Studies in 20th-century British literature. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

enl.name: — Early American Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Studies in Early American literature. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

enl.name: — American Literature: 1800 to the Civil War
enl.description: Course Description: Studies in American literature from 1800 to Civil War. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

enl.name: — American Literature: Civil War to 1914
