enl.description: Course Description: Studies in American literature from the Civil War to 1914. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

enl.name: — American Literature after 1914
enl.description: Course Description: Studies in American literature after 1914. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

enl.name: — Studies in Modern British & American Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Studies in modern British and American literature. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

enl.name: — Studies in Contemporary World Literature
enl.description: Course Description: Emerging global, international or transnational techniques, theories, and individual works of contemporary world prose or poetry. Discussion, seminar reports, research papers.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing, consent of instructor, with preference given to those enrolled in the masters program in Creative Writing.

enl.name: — Proseminar in Research Practices
enl.description: Course Description: Study of various practical and technical skills needed to perform research in literary studies. Materials to be selected by the instructor. Evaluation based on student projects that involve hands-on application of skills taught in the proseminar.

enl.name: — Seminar in Research Practices
enl.description: Course Description: Study of various practical and technical skills needed to perform research in literary studies. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Evaluation based on student projects that involve hands-on application of skills taught in the seminar.

enl.name: — Literature by Women
enl.description: Course Description: Studies in literature by women and the theoretical approaches to literature by women. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.

enl.name: — Topics in Literature & Media
enl.description: Course Description: Study of a topic centered on film or other moving-image media. Course materials to be selected by the instructor. Preparation and evaluation of research papers.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

enl.name: — Prospectus Workshop
enl.description: Course Description: Training in writing the dissertation prospectus. Participation in group discussions of preparatory assignments and final proposal.

enl.name: — Article Writing Workshop
enl.description: Course Description: Training in preparing an article for publication. Participation in group discussions of article drafts.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

enl.name: — Creative Writing: Special Topic
enl.description: Course Description: Writing that falls outside the generic confines of traditional genres (fiction, poetry, and nonfiction) or traditional workshop formats. Evaluation of written materials and individual student conferences.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

enl.name: — Creative Writing: Fiction
enl.description: Course Description: Writing of prose fiction. Evaluation of written materials and individual student conferences.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Graduate standing, with preference given to those enrolled in master's program in Creative Writing.

enl.name: — Creative Writing: Non-Fiction
enl.description: Course Description: Writing of literary non-fiction, with emphasis on autobiography, biography, memoir, the occasional or nature essay, or other non-fiction prose narratives.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Graduate standing; with preference given to those enrolled in the master's program in Creative Writing.

enl.name: — Creative Writing: Poetry
enl.description: Course Description: Writing of poetry. Evaluation of written materials and individual student conferences.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Graduate standing, with preference given to those enrolled in master's program in Creative Writing.

enl.name: — Directed Group Study
enl.description: Course Description: Directed group study.

enl.name: — Individual Study
enl.description: Course Description: Individual study.

enl.name: — Special Study for the Doctoral Dissertation
enl.description: Course Description: Special study for the doctoral dissertation.

enl.name: — Teaching Creative Writing
enl.description: Course Description: Designed for new instructors of ENL 005F or ENL 005P; discussion of ways to facilitate creative writing workshops and to respond to student manuscripts.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing; appointment as Teaching Assistant in the English Department.

enl.name: — Teaching Literature & Composition
enl.description: Course Description: Designed for new instructors of  ENL 003 or the equivalent courses; discussion of problems related to teaching literature and composition to lower division students.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing; appointment as Teaching Assistant in the English Department.

enl.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
enl.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training.
enl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

ent.name: — Art, Science & the World of Insects
ent.description: Course Description: Fusion of entomology and art to create an appreciation of insect biology, ecology, interactions with humans and importance in human culture. Multidisciplinary approaches in education and career paths in entomology and art will be highlighted.

ent.name: — Biodiversity
ent.description: Course Description: Introduction to nature, scope and geographical distribution of biodiversity (diversity of life, with emphasis on plants and animals, especially insects). Humans and biodiversity; domestication, aesthetics, ethics and valuation. Species richness and "success." Biodiversity through time; monitoring, evaluation and conservation. Biomes-global, continental and Californian.

ent.name: — Natural History of Insects
ent.description: Course Description: Introduction to the insects detailing their great variety, structures and functions, habits, and their significance in relation to plants and animals including man. Designed for students not specializing in entomology.

ent.name: — Special Topics in Entomology
ent.description: Course Description: Freshman seminar course for indepth examination of a special topic within the subject area.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ent.name: — Internship
ent.description: Course Description: Work-learn experience on and off campus in all subject areas offered by the department, supervised by a member of the faculty.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ent.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
ent.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.

ent.name: — General Entomology
ent.description: Course Description: Biology, anatomy, physiology, development, classification, ecology and relation of insects to human welfare.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002B; or consent of instructor.

ent.name: — General Entomology Laboratory
ent.description: Course Description: Anatomy, development, population ecology, methods of collecting, classification and identification of insects of all orders and of major families.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENT 100 (can be concurrent).

ent.name: — Functional Insect Morphology
ent.description: Course Description: Study of the basic external and internal structures, organs and tissues of insects, with emphasis on functional systems. Functional anatomy, histology and fine structures of important organs and tissues will be discussed.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENT 100.

ent.name: — Insect Physiology
ent.description: Course Description: Processes by which insects maintain themselves, reproduce, and adapt to environment. Insects as models for basic/applied research through detailed analysis of metabolic, physiological, and behavioral processes. Emphasis on analysis of methodology, fact, and theory.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENT 100; or course in physiology or invertebrate zoology.

ent.name: — Insects Systematics
ent.description: Course Description: Principles and methods of systematics, with particular reference to insects. Emphasis on different theories of classification, and analysis of phylogenetic relationships.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Introductory course in zoology or entomology.

ent.name: — Behavioral Ecology of Insects
ent.description: Course Description: Basic principles and mechanisms of insect behavior and ecology. An evolutionary approach to understanding behavioral ecology of insects.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Introductory biology or zoology.

ent.name: — Insect Ecology
ent.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduction to insect ecology combining fundamental concepts and questions in ecology with ideas, hypotheses and insights from insects. Integrates aspects of individual, population, community and ecosystem ecology.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002B (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

ent.name: — California Insect Diversity
ent.description: Course Description: Survey of the diversity of insects from selected ecological zones in California with emphasis on collection, identification, and natural history.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): An introductory course in entomology.

ent.name: — Evolution & Ecology of Arachnids
ent.description: Course Description: Spider external morphology, functional anatomy, metabolism, neurobiology, development, predatory & reproductive behavior, ecology, phylogeny, systematics, zoogeography, and faunistics.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002C or ENT 100

ent.name: — Evolution & Ecology of Arachnids Laboratory
ent.description: Course Description: Laboratory on spider natural history, identification, external morphology, and taxonomy, morphology and identification. Emphasis on the spiders of the California Floristic Province.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 002C or ENT 100 or ENT 100L); ENT 108 (can be concurrent); ENT 108 required concurrently or consent of instructor.

ent.name: — Field Taxonomy & Ecology
ent.description: Course Description: Study of insects in their natural habitats; their identification and ecology.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): An introductory course in entomology or consent of instructor.

ent.name: — Arthropod Pest Management
ent.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Sustainable management & ecology of arthropod pests in agricultural systems. Techniques for effective, management of arthropod pests via in-depth knowledge about pest biology, life strategies, spatial ecology, and food web functions. Lab & field trip exercises in applied research in pest management, ecology, and evolution using digital technologies (apps, remote sensing, cloud-based decision support).
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (STA 013 or STA 100 C- or better); BIS 002B C- or better; or consent of instructor.

ent.name: — Chemical Ecology
ent.description: Course Description: Fundamental concepts in chemical ecology, classic and recent examples of chemical-mediated species interactions; introduction to the methods and techniques used in the field of chemical ecology.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002B C- or better; CHE 002A C- or better; CHE 002B C- or better; or consent of instructor.

ent.name: — Freshwater Macroinvertebrates
ent.description: Course Description: Biology, ecology and taxonomy of freshwater macroinvertebrates, including insects, crustaceans, molluscs, worms, leeches, flatworms and others. Adaptations to life in freshwater. Aquatic food webs. Uses of macroinvertebrates in water quality monitoring. Field trips during regular lab hours.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002B; or equivalent.

ent.name: — Aquatic Insect Collection
ent.description: Course Description: Collection of aquatic insects and identification to the Family level. Collections will require two, one-day weekend field trips (by arrangement). Collection requirement is 40 Families.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENT 100L or ENT 116 (can be concurrent); or prior experience with insect/arthropod identification to Family level.

ent.name: — Longevity
ent.description: Course Description: Nature, origin, determinants, and limits of longevity with particular reference to humans; emphasis on implications of findings from non-human model systems including natural history, ecology and evolution of life span; description of basic demographic techniques including life table methods.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

ent.name: — Apiculture
ent.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Biology and behavior of honeybees; communication, orientation, social organization, foraging activities, honey production, pollination activities.

ent.name: — Pollination Biology
ent.description: Course Description: Natural history, ecology, evolution and applications of pollination. Conceptual underpinnings and basic methodologies of pollination. Primary focus on animal-mediated pollination.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002B C- or better; or consent of instructor. EVE 100 EVE 101 recommended.

ent.name: — Plant-Virus-Vector Interaction
ent.description: Course Description: Analysis of interactions necessary for viruses to infect plants.Interactions among insect vectors and host plants involved in the plant-virus life cycle. Evolutionary aspects of the molecular components in viral infection and modern approaches to the interdiction of viral movement.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; BIS 101; PLB 105, PLP 120, and ENT 100 recommended.

ent.name: — Introduction to Biological Control
ent.description: Course Description: Introduction to biological control.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENT 100 or ENT 110.

ent.name: — Medical Entomology
ent.description: Course Description: Basic biology and classification of medically important arthropods with special emphasis on the ecology of arthropodborne diseases and principles of their control. Relationships of arthropods to human health.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; BIS 002B; or consent of instructor; upper division standing in one of the biological sciences.

ent.name: — Biology of Parasitism
ent.description: Course Description: Lectures on the biological and ecological aspects affecting host-parasite relationships using selected examples from protozoan and metazoan fauna.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; or consent of instructor.

ent.name: — Biology of Parasitism Laboratory
ent.description: Course Description: Laboratory demonstrations using selected examples of protozoan and metazoan organisms along with various techniques used in parasitology to exemplify concepts presented in the lecture course.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENT 156 (can be concurrent); ENT 156 required concurrently or consent of instructor.

ent.name: — Forensic Entomology
ent.description: Course Description: Arthropods, their general biology, succession, developmental cycles and population biology in matters of criminal prosecution and civil litigation. Emphasis on basic arthropod biology, ecological and developmental concepts and methods, development of reasoning abilities, implication, development of opinions and evidence.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENT 100; or consent of instructor; upper division standing.

ent.name: — Experimental Ecology & Evolution in the Field
ent.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Experimental design in field ecology. Examination of primary literature, experimental design, independent and collaborative research, analysis of data, development of original research paper based on field experiments.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EVE 100 (can be concurrent); (ENT 105 (can be concurrent) or ESP 100 (can be concurrent) or EVE 101 (can be concurrent)); due to the unusual nature of this course, all prospective students are strongly encouraged to contact the instructor.

ent.name: — Experimental Ecology & Evolution in the Field
ent.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Experimental design in field ecology. Examination of primary literature, experimental design, independent and collaborative research, analysis of data, development of original research paper based on field experiments.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EVE 180A or ENT 180A.

ent.name: — Internship
ent.description: Course Description: Laboratory experience or fieldwork off and on campus in all subject areas offered in the Department of Entomology. Internships supervised by a member of the faculty.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of 84 units.

ent.name: — Tutoring in Entomology
ent.description: Course Description: Leading small discussion groups. Preview assignments and prepare guidelines for discussion.

ent.name: — Directed Group Study
ent.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ent.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
ent.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

ent.name: — Molecular Biology of Insects & Insect Viruses
ent.description: Course Description: Molecular biological analysis of insect systematics, physiology, and defense mechanisms. Molecular biology of insect viruses. Baculovirus expresion vectors and post-translation modification of expressed polypeptides. Biological control of using neuropeptides and toxin genes in insect viruses.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ent.name: — Vector-borne Infectious Diseases: Changing Patterns
ent.description: Course Description: Vector-borne infectious diseases especially as they relate to changing patterns associated with climatic changes, trade and population movement.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open to graduate students, MPVM and MPH students, DVM and medical students with second- or third-year standing. Open to upper division undergraduate students with consent of instructor(s).

ent.name: — Terrestrial Field Ecology
ent.description: Course Description: Field course conducted over spring break and four weekends at Bodega Bay, emphasizing student projects. Ecological hypothesis testing, data gathering, analysis, and written and oral presentation of results are stressed.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Introductory ecology and introductory statistics or consent of instructor.

ent.name: — Advanced Biological Control
ent.description: Course Description: Principles and current issues in biological control of arthropod pests and weeds; laboratory devoted to identification and life history of the major groups of parasitic and predaceous arthropods.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate or upper division standing in biological science or consent of instructor.

ent.name: — Advanced Medical Entolomogy
ent.description: Course Description: An analysis of several anthropod-borne human diseases with emphasis on the relationships of the biology of the vector to the ecology of the disease. Discussion includes demonstration of vectors and techniques.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One upper division ENT course (other than ENT 153) and one course in Microbiology; ENT 153 strongly recommended.

ent.name: — Exploratory Topics in Entomology
ent.description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary topics in entomology, including innovative applications of entomological concepts to other fields of research and human endeavor (e.g. medicine, technology, art, criminology).

ent.name: — Current Topics in Medical & Veterinary Entomology
ent.description: Course Description: Discussions of parasitology, ecology and epidemiology related to vectors of pathogens causing disease in humans and animals.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENT 153.

ent.name: — Current Topics in Insect Physiology & Behavior
ent.description: Course Description: Analysis of contemporary advances in insect physiology, biochemistry and/or behavior. Interpretation and description of physiological and behavioral mechanisms and functions. Application of general principles to solution of problems in the laboratory and field.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENT 102 if topic is physiology, a course in behavior if topic is behavior, or either if topic bridges both.

ent.name: — Current Topics in Insect Biotechnology & Genomics
ent.description: Course Description: Discussion of advances in insect biotechnology, including genetic engineering and genomics.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENT 212.

ent.name: — Current Topics in Insect Ecology, Evolution, & Systematics
ent.description: Course Description: Discussions of advanced topics in ecology, evolution and systematics with emphasis on analysis of factors influencing the distribution, abundance, adaptations and evolutionary relationships of insects. Includes consideration of applications of basic theory; e.g. biological control.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENT 103; general course in ecology or evolution.

ent.name: — Current Topics in Agricultural Entomology & Bee Biology
ent.description: Course Description: Discussion of advanced topics about the biology, ecology, behavior, and management of pest and beneficial insects.
ent.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENT 110 if topic relates to pests and beneficial predators; ENT 119 if topic is bee biology; either if topic bridges both.

ent.name: — Seminar in Entomology
ent.description: Course Description: Weekly Entomology seminar.

ent.name: — Group Study
ent.description: Course Description: Group study.

ent.name: — Research
ent.description: Course Description: Research.

enh.name: — Introduction to Environmental Horticulture/Urban Forestry
enh.description: Course Description: Introduction to the use of plants to enhance the physical, visual and social environment, the use of ecological principles in developing sustainable, low maintenance landscape systems, and the career opportunities in these areas.

enh.name: — Introduction to Environmental Plants
enh.description: Course Description: Classification, nomenclature and variation of environmental plants. The use of floral and vegetative characteristics and terminology to key unknown plants. Characteristics of plant groups and basics of climate, soils and plant selection. Identification of 150 common landscape plants.

enh.name: — Urban Forestry
enh.description: Course Description: Principles and practices of planning and managing urban vegetation. Basics of tree appraisal, natural resource inventory, and development of long term urban forest management plans.
enh.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENH 001 or PLS 002 or BIS 002B.

enh.name: — Trees of the Urban Forest
enh.description: Course Description: Identification and evaluation of 200 tree species of the urban forest on campus, in the Arboretum, and in the city of Davis; appraised and aesthetic values, condition, and branch structure; contribution of trees to this ecosystem. Bicycle required.
enh.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENH 006; or consent of instructor.

enh.name: — Physiological Principles in Environmental Horticulture
enh.description: Course Description: Physiological principles and processes essential to floriculture, nursery crop production, turfculture and landscape horticulture. Emphasis on the control of vegetative and reproductive development for a broad species range in greenhouse and extensive landscape environments.

enh.name: — Taxonomy & Ecology of Environmental Plant Families
enh.description: Course Description: Classification and identification of introduced and native species used in urban forests, with emphasis on floral and vegetative characteristics of the prominent families of angiosperms and gymnosperms, adaptations to environmental variations in western landscapes, and horticultural classification.
enh.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENH 006; or consent of instructor.

enh.name: — Management of Container Media
enh.description: Course Description: Principles of soil science and practices related to management of container media are taught, emphasizing appropriate use of soils and amendments, irrigation, and fertilizers.Physical and chemical properties are tested and effects of management on crops are evaluated in the laboratory.

enh.name: — Greenhouse & Nursery Crop Production
enh.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Principles and techniques for the production of ornamental greenhouse and nursery crops. Hands-on experience producing greenhouse crops. Optional weekend field trip.

enh.name: — Woody Plants in the Landscape: Growth, Ecology & Management
enh.description: Course Description: Principles and practices of managing trees and shrubs in the urban landscape and other managed environments. Topics include woody plant form; growth response and adaptation; tree management in relation to soil, moisture, climate; plant problems.

enh.name: — Genetics & Plant Conservation: The Biodiversity Crisis
enh.description: Course Description: Conservation of genic diversity, measurement of diversity, threats to diversity and reasons for protection, the process of extinction, distribution of diversity, determination of what to conserve and means of conservation. Examples drawn largely from forest tree species.

enh.name: — Restoration Ecology
enh.description: Course Description: Broad, interdisciplinary approach to effective restoration. Design and implementation of restoration projects based on principles of physiology, population, community, ecosystem and landscape ecology.
enh.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SSC 112 C or better or ESP 100 C or better or ESM 144 C or better or PLS 162 C or better or PLS 163 C or better or PLS 130 C or better or PLS 144 C or better or PLS 147 C or better or PLS 160 C or better or ESP 121 C or better or ESP 127 C or better or ESP 155 C or better or EVE 101 C or better or EVE 104 C or better or EVE 117 C or better or EVE 119 C or better or EVE 181 C or better or PLB 117 C or better or ECL 200AN C or better or ECL 200BN C or better; or consent of instructor; or equivalent course in ecology/plant ecology.

enh.name: — Restoration Ecology Laboratory
enh.description: Course Description: Companion field course to ENH 160. Series of part-day and all day visits to various field sites, involving site evaluations, guest field presentations by local restorationists, and actual restoration activities.
enh.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENH 160 (can be concurrent); consent of instructor.

env.name: — Analysis of Environmental Management & Policy
env.description: Course Description: Introduction to rational decision making for public policy problems. Modeling natural/human system interactions, data gathering and hypothesis testing. Predicting outcomes of policy options.

env.name: — Environmental Policy Evaluation
env.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Method and practice, philosophical basis, and political role of policy analysis. Reviews basic concepts from economic theory; how and why environmental problems emerge in a market economy; and tools necessary for solving environmental problems.

env.name: — Social Ecological Systems
env.description: Course Description: Introduction to the concept of social ecological systems with applications to the field of environmental policy. Develops critical analysis skills, understanding links between social and environmental systems, and an ability to understand resilience of social ecological systems in face of change.

env.name: — Environmental Law
env.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Roles of legislatures, agencies, and courts in creating and interpreting law; legal strategies for addressing environmental problems; major environmental statutes; and the relationship between federal and state/local legal authority.

env.name: — Policy Development & Implementation
env.description: Course Description: Environmental policy development and implementation processes: developing and enacting legislation, regulation development and review, and implementation of new laws. California state processes. Local, federal, and international policy. Business’ role in climate policy. Theory, applied study, discussion with guest experts, and practical skills such as how to write for a policy audience.

env.name: — Environmental Policy Clinic
env.description: Course Description: Teams of students analyze an environmental policy problem from scientific, legal, and economic perspectives. Hands-on learning partnering with rotating clients.

env.name: — Environmental Policy Clinic
env.description: Course Description: Teams of students analyze environmental policy problems and natural resources issues from scientific, legal, and economic perspectives. Hands-on learning partnering with a client organization.

env.name: — Environmental Policy Clinic
env.description: Course Description: Teams of students analyze environmental policy problems and natural resources issues from scientific, legal, and economic perspectives. Hands-on learning partnering with a a client organization. A continuation of ENV 203A.
env.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENV 203A B- or better; or consent of instructor.

env.name: — Seminar
env.description: Course Description: Environmental justice and equity within the environmental field. Climate justice, energy, land use and urban planning, air pollution, politics and theory, and other environmental justice focused issues.

env.name: — Graduate Internship
env.description: Course Description: Individually designed supervised internship, off campus, in community or institutional setting. Developed with advice of faculty mentor.

env.name: — Environmental Policy & Management Practicum
env.description: Course Description: Practicum experience integrating coursework into an applied professional setting.

env.name: — Professional Development Seminar
env.description: Course Description: Weekly seminar inviting policy and management professionals to come and discuss their challenges and achievements.

env.name: — Research
env.description: Course Description: Individual study under the direction of a faculty member.

esm.name: — Water Quality at Risk
esm.description: Course Description: Natural and human threats to water quality. Balance of science and policy in all aspects of attaining, maintaining, and managing water quality, water contamination. Decoding popular media coverage of water quality and water contamination.

esm.name: — Internship
esm.description: Course Description: Work experience off and on campus in resource sciences. Internship supervised by a member of the faculty.
esm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

esm.name: — Directed Group Study
esm.description: Course Description: Primarily for lower division students.

esm.name: — Student Facilitated Course Development
esm.description: Course Description: Student-facilitated (taught) course intended for lower division students.

esm.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
esm.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.

esm.name: — Principles of Hydrologic Science
esm.description: Course Description: Topics include hydrology (surface and ground water), hydraulic flow through porous media, water in the soil-plant-atmosphere continuum, water quality, flow through open channels, and representative water-resource problems.

esm.name: — Environmental Monitoring
esm.description: Course Description: Instrumentation and methods for environmental and ecological monitoring; GPS, sensors, datalogging, and GIS. Wide range of measurement techniques for environmental parameters.
esm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EVE 101; ESP 100; ETX 101; WFC 100; ERS 100; SSC 100; ENH 100; LDA 050; or the equivalent for any of theses courses.

esm.name: — Irrigation Systems & Water Management
esm.description: Course Description: Soil and plant aspects of irrigation and drainage. Soil-water principles including water storage and movement, plant response to irrigation, water use by crops, irrigation systems (i.e., micro-irrigation, sprinkler irrigation and surface irrigation), and related salinity and water quality impacts.

esm.name: — Evapotranspiration Principles, Measurement & Modeling
esm.description: Course Description: Estimation of evapotranspiration (ET) for irrigation management and water resources planning; including the basic principles and key factors controlling evaporation and ET rates, methods of measuring these factors in the field and remotely, and determination of likely water requirements for crops and various landscape conditions as needed for water resources planning.
esm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HYD 124 C or better; consent of instructor.

esm.name: — Global Environmental Interactions
esm.description: Course Description: Relationships among climate, hydrology, biogeochemical cycles, soils and vegetation distribution in diverse landscapes and biomes. Emphasis on physical, chemical, and biological processes affecting ecosystems from the poles to the equator, and human impacts on the environment.
esm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One college level chemistry course; one college level biology course.

esm.name: — Water Science & Management
esm.description: Course Description: Role of water as an essential natural resource in contemporary society. Aspects of the scientific method, including descriptions of natural phenomena and underlying physical causes. Water for cities, agriculture, industry, wildlife and recreation; case studies of water management.

esm.name: — River Conservation
esm.description: Course Description: Law, policy, science, and practice used in managing rivers with the aim of balancing human societal needs and those of riparian and aquatic species.
esm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ESM 100 or ESM 108 or ESM 120 or ESM 121 or GEL 001 or GEL 050 or HYD 010 or HYD 141 or HYD 143 or SSC 100 or EVE 101 or ESP 100 or ESP 001 or ESP 110 or WFC 010 or WFC 051 or ECI 040 or ECI 100.

esm.name: — Air as a Resource
esm.description: Course Description: Degradation of the atmospheric resource, historical aspects and effects of air pollution examined. Evaluation of primary gaseous and particulate pollutants and discussion of their impact.

esm.name: — Role of Fire in Natural Ecosystems
esm.description: Course Description: Fire regimes and roles in major North American vegetation types, especially in the west. Physics of fire, fire effects on organisms and ecosystem functioning, reconstructing fire histories, fire in resource management, and fire use by indigenous people.
esm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 002A or PLS 002); (BIS 002B or BIS 002C); basic biological, ecology/evolution concepts.

esm.name: — Trees & Forests
esm.description: Course Description: Biological structure and function of trees as organisms; understanding of forests as communities and as ecosystems; use of forests by humans; tree phenology, photosynthesis, respiration, soil processes, life histories, dormancy, forest biodiversity, and agroforestry.
esm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 002 or BIS 001C or BIS 002C.

esm.name: — Aerial Photo Interpretation & Remote Sensing
esm.description: Course Description: Basics of remote sensing and photogrammetry, grids and map projections, aerial photo interpretation, sensors and platforms for aerial and space photography and non-photographic imaging systems, aerial thermography, microwave sensing, and introduction to remote sensing applications.

esm.name: — Environmental Remote Sensing
esm.description: Course Description: Overview of satellite, airborne, and ground-based remote sensing, building on properties of electromagnetic radiation. Applications include hydrologic processes, weather and climate, ecology and land use, soils, geology, forestry, and agriculture. Computer based analysis and visualization of images and processing techniques.
esm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 016B; (PHY 007C or PHY 009B); upper division standing; LDA 150 recommended.

esm.name: — Internship
esm.description: Course Description: Work experience off and on campus in resource sciences. Internship supervised by a member of the faculty.
esm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of 84 units.

esm.name: — Senior Honor Thesis
esm.description: Course Description: Independent study, guided research on an environmentally related subject of special interest to the student.
esm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Senior standing, overall GPA of 3.50 or higher and consent of master advisor.

esm.name: — Integrating Environmental Science & Management
esm.description: Course Description: Practical aspects of environmental improvement through integrated analyses of contemporary issues or problems associated with advocacy, regulation, science and resource management from the perspectives of the physical and ecological sciences and current policy/management.
esm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; senior status in Environmental Science  Management major or other environmental science major (e.g. Environmental Resource Science; Environmental Biology  Management; Environmental Toxicology; Environmental Policy Analysis  Planning; Wildlife, Fish,  Conservation Biology; Hydrologic Science).

esm.name: — Directed Group Study
esm.description: Course Description: Directed group study.

esm.name: — Student Facilitated Course
esm.description: Course Description: Student-facilitated (taught) course intended for upper division students.

esm.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
esm.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

esm.name: — Student Teaching Course Development
esm.description: Course Description: Under the supervision of a faculty member, an undergraduate student plans and develops the course they will teach under 098F/198F.

esm.name: — Student Teaching Course Development
esm.description: Course Description: Student facilitated. Under the supervision of a faculty member, an undergraduate student teaches a course under 098F/198F.

esp.name: — Environmental Analysis
esp.description: Course Description: Analysis of the physical, biological, and social interactions which constitute environmental problems. Emphasis on analysis of environmental problems, the consequences of proposed solutions, and the interaction of environmental science and public policy in creating solutions.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 (can be concurrent) or UWP 001Y (can be concurrent) or UWP 001V (can be concurrent) or ENL 003 (can be concurrent); or equivalent; sophomore standing; ECN 001A and BIS 002B recommended.

esp.name: — Current Issues in the Environment
esp.description: Course Description: Science behind environmental issues, and policies affecting our ability to solve domestic and international environmental problems. Resources, environmental quality, regulation, environmental perception and conservation. Integrative case studies.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Elementary biology recommended.

esp.name: — Internship
esp.description: Course Description: Work experience off and on campus in all subject areas offered in the College of Agricultural & Environmental Sciences. Internship supervised by member of the faculty.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

esp.name: — Directed Group Study
esp.description: Course Description: Primarily for lower division students.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

esp.name: — General Ecology
esp.description: Course Description: Theoretical & experimental analysis of the distribution, growth & regulation of species populations; predator-prey & competitive interactions; and the organization of natural communities. Application of evolutionary & ecological principles to selected environmental problems.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C); (MAT 016A or MAT 017A or MAT 021A); (MAT 016B or MAT 017B or MAT 021B); STA 013 recommended.

esp.name: — Ecology, Nature, & Society
esp.description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary study of diversity and change in human societies, using frameworks from anthropology, evolutionary ecology, history, archaeology, psychology, and other fields. Topics include population dynamics, subsistence transitions, family organization, disease, economics, warfare, politics, and resource conservation.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ANT 001 or ANT 002 or ESP 030 or EVE 100 or BIS 101 recommended.

esp.name: — Community Ecology
esp.description: Course Description: Population growth and density dependence; predation; exploitative, interference and apparent competition; mutualism and facilitation; coexistence mechanisms; niches, spatial and temporal variation etc. Emphasis on quantitative understanding through models, concepts, and empirical evidence.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ESP 100 or EVE 101.

esp.name: — Environmental Data Science
esp.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Programming with environmental data using R. Understanding data types, loops, branching and functions. Reproducible workflows and version control to import, organize, explore, analyze and visualize environmental data. Data science terminology and approaches. Common data sources used in environmental science and policy.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 013 (can be concurrent) or STA 032 (can be concurrent) or STA 100 (can be concurrent).

esp.name: — Principles of Environmental Science
esp.description: Course Description: Application of physical and chemical principles, ecological concepts, and systems approach to policy analysis of atmospheric environments, freshwater and marine environments, land use, energy supplies and technology, and other resources.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PHY 001A or PHY 007A); (MAT 016B or MAT 017B or MAT 021B); BIS 002A or BIS 010 recommended; upper division standing.

esp.name: — Marine Environmental Issues
esp.description: Course Description: Examination of critical environmental issues occurring in coastal waters including the effects of climate change, overfishing, and other human impacts. Through readings and group discussions, students will develop an integrative understanding of the oceanographic and ecological processes.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

esp.name: — Oceanography
esp.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Advanced oceanographic topics: Chemical, physical, geological, and biological processes; research methods and data analysis; marine resources, anthropogenic impacts, and climate change; integrated earth/ocean/atmosphere systems; weekly lab and one weekend field trip.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 001 or GEL 002 or GEL 016 or GEL 050.

esp.name: — Population Ecology
esp.description: Course Description: Development of exponential and logistic growth models for plant and animal populations, analysis of age structure, analysis of competition and predator-prey systems, and analysis of disease dynamics. Developing mathematical models and using them to make predictions and solve problems.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002B; (MAT 016B or MAT 017B or MAT 021B or MAT 021BH).

esp.name: — Introduction to Field & Laboratory Methods in Ecology
esp.description: Course Description: Introduction to methods used for collecting ecological data in field and laboratory situations. Methods used by population ecologists and community ecologists; emphasis on experimental design, scientific writing and data analysis.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ESP 100 or EVE 101); (STA 013 or STA 013Y or STA 100); or equivalent.

esp.name: — Marine & Coastal Field Ecology
esp.description: Course Description: Ecology of marine populations and communities living in diverse habitats along the California coast. Hands-on learning using scientific process and tools of the biological trade to address ecological questions arising during field trips. Critical thinking through discussing scientific literature.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor; introductory animal biology (BIS 001B) recommended; residence at or near Bodega Marine Lab required.

esp.name: — Plant Conservation Biology
esp.description: Course Description: Principles governing the conservation of plant species and plant communities, including the roles of fire, exotic species, grazing, pollination, soils, and population genetics; analytic and practical techniques for plant conservation; and introduction to relevant legal, ethical, and policy issues.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ESP 100 or EVE 101; or equivalent upper division general ecology.

esp.name: — Physical & Chemical Oceanography
esp.description: Course Description: Physical and chemical properties of seawater, fluid dynamics, air-sea interaction, currents, waves, tides, mixing, major oceanic geochemical cycles.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ESP 116N or GEL 116N); (PHY 007B or PHY 009B); (MAT 016C or MAT 017C or MAT 021C); (CHE 002C or GEL 055); and consent of instructor.

esp.name: — Geological Oceanography
esp.description: Course Description: Introduction to the origin and geologic evolution of ocean basins. Composition and structure of oceanic crust; marine volcanism; and deposition of marine sediments. Interpretation of geologic history of the ocean floor in terms of sea-floor spreading theory.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 050 or (GEL 116N or ESP 116N).

esp.name: — Biological Oceanography
esp.description: Course Description: Ecology of major marine habitats, including intertidal, shelf benthic, deep-sea and plankton communities. Existing knowledge and contemporary issues in research. Segment devoted to human use. One weekend field trip required.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; consent of instructor; a course in general ecology.

esp.name: — Limnology
esp.description: Course Description: Biology and productivity of inland waters with emphasis on the physical and chemical environment.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; BIS 002B; (BIS 002C and ESP 100 or EVE 101 recommended.)

esp.name: — Limnology Laboratory
esp.description: Course Description: Limnological studies of lakes, streams, and reservoirs with interpretation of aquatic ecology.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ESP 151 (can be concurrent); junior, senior, or graduate standing.

esp.name: — Coastal Oceanography
esp.description: Course Description: Oceanography of coastal waters, including bays, river plumes, nearshore and estuaries; focus on transport patterns, how they are forced and implications for ecological and environmental problems. Pertinent for students in oceanography, ecology, environmental engineering, geology and hydrology.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of the instructor; physics (PHY 009B), calculus (MAT 021B) and exposure to physical and chemical oceanography (GEL 150A and ESP 150A) are recommended; residence at or near Bodega Marine Laboratory required.

esp.name: — Wetland Ecology
esp.description: Course Description: Introduction to wetland ecology. The structure and function of major wetland types and principles that are common to wetlands and that distinguish them from terrestrial and aquatic ecosystems.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; or equivalent of BIS 002A; ESP 100 or EVE 101 recommended.

esp.name: — Wetland Ecology Laboratory
esp.description: Course Description: Modern and classic techniques in wetland field ecology. Emphasis on sampling procedures, vegetation analysis, laboratory analytical procedures, and examples of successful wetland restoration techniques.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ESP 155 (can be concurrent).

esp.name: — The Policy Process
esp.description: Course Description: Alternative models of public policymaking and application to case studies in the U.S. and California.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001; ECN 001A and STA 013 recommended.

esp.name: — Environmental Law
esp.description: Course Description: Introduction for non-Law School students to some of the principal issues in environmental law and the judicial interpretation of some important environmental statutes, e.g., NEPA.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; one course in environmental science or political science recommended.

esp.name: — Environmental Policy
esp.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Compares economic with socio-cultural approaches to understanding the causes of environmental problems and strategies for addressing them. Includes different approaches to the policy process, policy instruments, and environmental behavior. Applies these principles to several problems.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 001A or ECN 001AV.

esp.name: — Energy & Environmental Aspects of Transportation
esp.description: Course Description: Engineering, economic, and systems planning concepts. Analysis and evaluation of energy, air quality and selected environmental attributes of transportation technologies. Strategies for reducing pollution and petroleum consumption in light of institutional and political constraints. Evaluation of vehicle emission models.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing in engineering or economics or environmental studies.

esp.name: — Climate Policy
esp.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Models, data and assumptions behind competing arguments regarding societal response to the prospect of climate change at the state, national and international level from economic, ethical and policy science perspectives.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ESP 001 or ECN 001A or ECN 001AV; or consent of instructor.

esp.name: — Ocean & Coastal Policy
esp.description: Course Description: Overview of U.S. and International ocean and coastal policy, including energy, coastal land-use and water quality, protected areas and species.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ESP 001; or consent of instructor.

esp.name: — Energy Policy
esp.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Survey of primary energy resources (fossil, renewable, nuclear), energy conversion methods, future energy demand scenarios, and environmental impacts of energy. Overview of energy policy in the U.S. Analysis of policy alternatives for addressing energy-related environmental and national security issues.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ECN 001A or ECN 001AV); (MAT 016B or MAT 017B or MAT 021B); or consent of instructor.

esp.name: — Methods of Environmental Policy Analysis
esp.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Evaluation of alternatives for solution of complex environmental problems; impact analysis, benefit cost analysis, distributional analysis, decision making under uncertainty, and multi-objective evaluation.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ESP 001 or ESP 010); (STA 013 or STA 013Y or STA 100); (ECN 001A or ECN 001AV); ECN 100 recommended.

esp.name: — Methods of Environmental Policy Evaluation
esp.description: Course Description: Continuation of ESP 168A. Emphasis on examination of the literature for applications of research & evaluation techniques to problems of transportation, air & water pollution, land use, and energy policy.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ESP 168A.

esp.name: — Water Policy & Politics
esp.description: Course Description: Governance of water, including issues of water pollution/quality and water supply. Politics of water decision-making and effectiveness of water policy. Broad focus on federal water policy, with case examples from nationally significant U.S. watersheds.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECN 001A or POL 001 recommended.

esp.name: — Conservation Biology Policy
esp.description: Course Description: Analysis of policies designed to conserve species and their habitats. Emphasis on how individual incentives affect the success of conservation policies. Valuation of endangered species and biodiversity. Criteria for deciding conservation priorities.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in environmental science (e.g., ESP 001), conservation (e.g., WFC 011 or WFC 154), or government (e.g., POL 001) recommended.

esp.name: — Urban & Regional Planning
esp.description: Course Description: How cities plan for growth in ways that minimize environmental harm. Standard city planning tools (general plan, zoning ordinance) and innovative new approaches. Focus on planning requirements and practices in California. Relationships between local, regional, state, and federal policy.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ESP 001 or ESP 161 or ESP 179 recommended.

esp.name: — Public Lands Management
esp.description: Course Description: Investigation of alternative approaches to public lands management by Federal and state agencies. Role each agency's legislation plays in determining the range of resource allocations.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POL 001 and ECN 001A recommended.

esp.name: — Land Use & Growth Controls
esp.description: Course Description: Exposes students to the economic, political, and legal factors affecting land use and growth controls, and helps students critically evaluate written materials in terms of their arguments and supporting data. May be taught abroad.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; one course in environmental policy.

esp.name: — Environmental Justice Policy & Practice
esp.description: Course Description: History and frameworks of environmental justice; environmental justice policy; methods of spatial analysis. Emphasis on California and the United States.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ESP 001 or equivalent recommended.

esp.name: — Natural Resource Economics
esp.description: Course Description: Economic concepts and policy issues associated with natural resources, renewable resources (ground water, forests, fisheries, and wildlife populations) and non-renewable resources (minerals and energy resources, soil).
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 100A C- or better or ECN 100A C- or better or ECN 100 C- or better.

esp.name: — Applied Research Methods
esp.description: Course Description: Research methods for analysis of urban and regional land use, transportation, and environmental problems. Survey research and other data collection techniques; demographic analysis; basic forecasting, air quality, and transportation models. Collection, interpretation, and critical evaluation of data.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 103 or STA 100 or STA 108 or SOC 106 or ARE 106; or the equivalent.

esp.name: — Environmental Impact Assessment
esp.description: Course Description: Introduction to the information resources and methods typically used in environmental impact analysis. Emphasis on how environmental information is applied to planning, environmental regulation, and public policymaking, with case studies from California land use and natural resource policy.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ESP 001; or the equivalent.

esp.name: — Environmental Impact Reporting Using Geographic Information
esp.description: Course Description: Introduction to Geographic Information Systems (GIS) by using ArcView for assessment and environmental planning.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ESP 179 (can be concurrent); ESP 179 required concurrently.

esp.name: — Workshops on Environmental Problems
esp.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Workshops featuring empirical analyses of contemporary environmental problems by multidisciplinary student teams. Guided by faculty and lay professionals, the teams seek to develop an integrated view of a problem and outline a series of alternative solutions.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

esp.name: — Workshop on Food System Sustainability
esp.description: Course Description: First in a two-quarter senior capstone course sequence. Identify projects addressing specific problems and opportunities of sustainable agriculture and food systems, form multidisciplinary teams, and identify and consult with key stakeholders to understand their needs and concerns.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 015; CRD 020; ARE 121; PLS 150; or consent of instructor; upper division standing.

esp.name: — Workshop on Food System Sustainability
esp.description: Course Description: Continuation of ESP 191A. Teams conduct analyses of a specific issue in sustainable agriculture or food systems, prepare a critical assessment of technological, economic, environmental, and social dimensions of options for action and present their results to stakeholders.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ESP 191A.

esp.name: — Internship
esp.description: Course Description: Work experience off and on campus in all subject areas offered in the College of Agricultural and Environmental Sciences. Internships supervised by a member of the faculty.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of 84 units.

esp.name: — Tutoring in Environmental Science & Policy
esp.description: Course Description: Experience in teaching under guidance of faculty member.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

esp.name: — Directed Group Study
esp.description: Course Description: Directed group study.

esp.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
esp.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

esp.name: — Environmental Policy Process
esp.description: Course Description: Introduction to selected theories of the policy process and applications to the field of environmental policy. Develops critical reading skills, understanding of policy theory, and an ability to apply multiple theories to the same phenomena.

esp.name: — Environmental Policy Evaluation
esp.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Method and practice, philosophical basis, and political role of policy analysis. Reviews basic concepts from economic theory; how and why environmental problems emerge in a market economy; and tools necessary for solving environmental problems.

esp.name: — Tropical Ecology
esp.description: Course Description: Overview of present status of knowledge on structure and processes of major tropical ecosystems. Differences and similarities among tropical and temperate systems stressed.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ESP 100; EVE 101; EVE 117; EVE 138 recommended.

esp.name: — Advanced Simulation Modeling
esp.description: Course Description: Advanced techniques in simulation modeling; optimization and simulation, dynamic parameter estimation, linear models, error propagation, and sensitivity testing. Latter half of course introduces model evaluation in ecological and social system models.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (STA 108 or ARE 106); (ESP 128 and ESP 128L).

esp.name: — Economic Analysis of Resource & Environmental Policies
esp.description: Course Description: Development of externality theory, market failure concepts, welfare economics, theory of renewable and non-renewable resource use, and political economic models. Applications to policy issues regarding the agricultural/environment interface and managing resources in the public domain.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 204 or ECN 204.

esp.name: — Research Methods in Environmental Policy
esp.description: Course Description: Introduction to scientific research in environmental policy.Major issues in the philosophy of the social sciences.How to design research that acknowledges theoretical assumptions and that is likely to produce evidence in an intersubjectively reliable fashion with explicit recognition of its uncertainties.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 106; or the equivalent.

esp.name: — Directed Group Study
esp.description: Course Description: Directed group study.

esp.name: — Research
esp.description: Course Description: Research.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

esp.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
esp.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.
esp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

etx.name: — Introduction to Environmental Toxicology
etx.description: Course Description: Hazardous substances, their effects on humans and their actions and movement in the environment. Emphasis on substances of current concern.

etx.name: — Introduction to Forensic Science
etx.description: Course Description: Basic principles of forensic science, types of information on which investigations focus, how information is obtained and used in criminal investigations, types of scientific skills required to practice forensic science, guidance on training. Real cases discussed; demonstrations of methods provided.

etx.name: — Chemical & Drug Use & Abuse
etx.description: Course Description: Overview of chemical use and abuse in our society. Effects of chemicals (therapeutic drugs, pesticides, food additives, herbal remedies, environmental contaminants, and recreational drugs) on humans and other living systems.

etx.name: — Internship
etx.description: Course Description: Work experience off and on campus in all subject areas offered in the College of Agricultural & Environmental Sciences. Internships supervised by a member of the faculty.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

etx.name: — Directed Group Study
etx.description: Course Description: Group study on focused topics in Environmental Toxicology. Topic varies according to instructor.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

etx.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
etx.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

etx.name: — Principles of Environmental Toxicology
etx.description: Course Description: Principles of toxicology with a focus on environmental, industrial, and natural chemicals. Topics include fate and effects of chemicals in organisms and the environment, air pollutants, insecticides, aquatic toxicology, endocrine disruptors, biomarkers and bioassays, and risk assessment.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (CHE 008B or CHE 118B or CHE 128B); BIS 002A.

etx.name: — Environmental Fate of Toxicants
etx.description: Course Description: Properties of toxic chemicals influencing their distribution and transformations; action of environmental forces affecting toxicant breakdown, movement, and accumulation; sources and occurrence of major classes of environmental toxicants.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 008B or CHE 118B or CHE 128B; or consent of instructor.

etx.name: — Quantitative Analysis of Environmental Toxicants
etx.description: Course Description: Sample preparation methods for trace analysis of environmental toxicants. Concept and techniques of advanced analytical instrumentation. Interpretation and use of analytical data.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ETX 102A.

etx.name: — Biological Effects of Toxicants
etx.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Biological effects of toxic substances in living organisms. Metabolism, cellular and tissue targets, mechanisms of action, and pathological effects.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 101; ETX 101 recommended.

etx.name: — Biological Effects of Toxicants: Experimental Approaches
etx.description: Course Description: Experimental approaches for assessing the biological effects of toxicants.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ETX 103A.

etx.name: — Environmental & Nutritional Factors in Cellular Regulation & Nutritional Toxicants
etx.description: Course Description: Cellular regulation from nutritional/toxicological perspective. Emphasis: role of biofactors on modulation of signal transduction pathways, role of specific organelles in organization/regulation of metabolic transformations, major cofactor functions, principles of pharmacology/toxicology important to understanding nutrient/toxicant metabolism.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; (BIS 103 or ABI 103).

etx.name: — Toxic Tragedies & Their Impact on Society
etx.description: Course Description: Examination of toxic tragedies, their origins, consequences, and effects on toxic regulation.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division status or consent of instructor required.

etx.name: — Introduction to Mass Spectrometry
etx.description: Course Description: Introduction to mass spectrometry, including ionization techniques, mass analyzers, interpretation of mass spectra, and applications of mass spectrometry. Emphasis on fundamental concepts of mass spectrometry necessary to identify and quantify organic molecules.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 118C or CHE 128C.

etx.name: — Perspectives in Aquatic Toxicology
etx.description: Course Description: Toxic substances, their fate in marine and freshwater systems, and their effects on aquatic organisms, populations, and ecosystems. Emphasis will be on substances and issues of current concern.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 008B; (CHE 118B or CHE 128B); BIS 002A; or consent of instructor.

etx.name: — Environmental Stress & Development in Marine Organisms
etx.description: Course Description: Taught at Bodega Marine Laboratory. Effects of environmental and nutritional stress, including pollutants, on development and function in embryos and larvae of marine organisms. Emphasis on advanced experimental methods.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ETX 101 or BIS 102 or BIS 104; and consent of instructor, or the equivalent; ETX 114A or NUT 114 recommended.

etx.name: — Food Toxicology
etx.description: Course Description: Chemistry and biochemistry of toxins occurring in foods, including plant and animal toxins, intentional and unintentional food additives. The assessment of food safety and toxic hazards.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 102; BIS 103.

etx.name: — Role & Applications of Toxicology in Modern Industry
etx.description: Course Description: Role of toxicology in industry research and development, human health and environmental protection, hazard and risk evaluations, risk management and communications, product stewardship, and regulatory compliance. Scientific principles and methods of toxicology in chemical, energy, pharmaceutical, pesticide, biotechnology industries.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ETX 101; ETX 103A recommended.

etx.name: — Environmental Toxicology of Air Pollutants
etx.description: Course Description: Field trip required. Toxicology of air pollutants in the ambient, indoor, and occupational environments. Health effects, sources, environmental fates, pulmonary responses, sampling and analyses, and air-quality criteria and standards. Field trip required.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 008B (can be concurrent); or the equivalent; BIS 102 recommended.

etx.name: — Health Risk Assessment of Toxicants
etx.description: Course Description: Current practices of health risk assessment of environmental chemicals using toxicological principles and their application to regulatory control of these chemicals.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ETX 101; ETX 114A recommended.

etx.name: — Legal Aspects of Environmental Toxicology
etx.description: Course Description: Federal and California legislation concerning air and water pollution, pesticide use, food and feed additives, consumer protection, and occupational exposure to toxic substances; roles of federal regulatory agencies; alternatives to government control.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. ETX 010 or ETX 101 recommended.

etx.name: — Genes & the Environment
etx.description: Course Description: Evaluation of evidence that human health and disease susceptibility result from complex interactions between genes and the environment. Critical thinking through problem solving using the scientific method with examples of cancer, metabolic, cardiovascular, and neurological health outcomes related to environmental and genetic risk factors and mechanisms.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A (can be concurrent) or MCB 010 (can be concurrent) or BIS 101 (can be concurrent); college-level coursework in environmental toxicology recommended.

etx.name: — Exposure & Dose Assessment
etx.description: Course Description: Exposure component of risk assessment; specifically, the presence and/or formation of toxic substances in environmental media, their movement within and between contaminated media, and the contacts of human populations with those media.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ETX 112A; ETX 135 recommended.

etx.name: — Evolution in Human-Altered Environments
etx.description: Course Description: Effects of recent human alterations to the natural environment on the evolutionary trajectories of diverse species, including our own.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002B.

etx.name: — Seminar
etx.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Selected topics presented by students, faculty, or outside speakers covering current research and instructional activities within environmental toxicology. Reports and discussion concerning oral and written presentations, literature sources, and career opportunities.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

etx.name: — Research Group Conference
etx.description: Course Description: Weekly conference of advanced research methods and the interpretation of research results.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

etx.name: — Environmental Toxicology Career Seminar
etx.description: Course Description: Careers in environmental toxicology; discussions with graduates from the Department of Environmental Toxicology and other experts in the field.

etx.name: — Internship
etx.description: Course Description: Work experience off and on campus in all subject areas offered in the College of Agricultural and Environmental Sciences. Internships supervised by a member of the faculty.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of 84 units.

etx.name: — Honors Research
etx.description: Course Description: Specific research project conducted under the supervision of a faculty sponsor. Experience to include experimental design, learning new techniques, data analysis and interpretation of findings.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; senior standing; minimum GPA of 3.250.

etx.name: — Honors Research
etx.description: Course Description: Specific research project conducted under the supervision of a faculty sponsor. Experience to include experimental design, learning new techniques, data analysis and interpretation of findings.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; senior standing; minimum GPA of 3.250.

etx.name: — Honors Research
etx.description: Course Description: Continuation of ETX 194HA & ETA 194HB.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; senior standing, minimum GPA of 3.250.

etx.name: — Tutoring in Environmental Toxicology
etx.description: Course Description: Teaching toxicology including conducting discussion groups for regular departmental courses under direct guidance of staff.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; advanced standing in Environmental Toxicology, a related major, or the equivalent experience.

etx.name: — Directed Group Study
etx.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

etx.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
etx.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

etx.name: — Environmental Toxicants
etx.description: Course Description: Toxic chemicals: selected topics illustrating their occurrence, structure, and the reactions underlying detection, toxicity, fate, and ecological importance.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 008B or CHE 128C; and consent of instructor, or the equivalent of CHE 128C.

etx.name: — Mechanisms of Toxic Action
etx.description: Course Description: Chemical, biochemical, and molecular mechanisms underlying the adverse effects of toxic chemicals. Students are required to write a grant proposal and participate in a grant review panel.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 102; BIS 103; and consent of instructor.

etx.name: — Analysis of Toxicants
etx.description: Course Description: Principles of microanalysis of toxicants. Theoretical considerations regarding separation, detection and quantitative determination of toxicants using chemical and instrumental techniques.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Coursework in organic chemistry.

etx.name: — Analysis of Toxicants Laboratory
etx.description: Course Description: Laboratory techniques for microanalysis of toxicants. Separation, detection, and quantitative determination of toxicants using chemical and instrumental methods.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ETX 220 (can be concurrent); consent of instructor.

etx.name: — Current Topics in Neurotoxicology
etx.description: Course Description: General principles of neurotoxicology, the cell and molecular mechanisms and health impacts of specific neurotoxicants and the contribution of neurotoxic compounds to complex eurodevelopmental disorders and neurodegenerative diseases.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Core courses in one of the following graduate programs: Pharmacology  Toxicology (PTX), Agricultural  Environmental Chemistry (AGC), Biochemistry  Molecular Biology (BMB), Cell  Developmental Biology (CDB), Immunology (IMM), Molecular Cellular  Integrative Physiology (MCP) or Neuroscience (NSC).

etx.name: — Ecotoxicology
etx.description: Course Description: Principles of toxicology as applied to chemical action on natural populations, communities, and ecosystems. Physical, chemical, and biological characteristics which influence ecotoxic effects, modeling, and field research. Selected case histories are analyzed and presented in class.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; elementary course in toxicology and ecology or the equivalent.

etx.name: — Reproductive Toxicology
etx.description: Course Description: Application of toxicological principles in reproductive studies. Effects of toxicants on the male, female, and developing embryo/fetus. Critical evaluation of reproductive toxicity studies and development of mechanistic approaches to understanding how chemical exposure can adversely affect reproduction.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PTX 203.

etx.name: — Immunotoxicology
etx.description: Course Description: Provides students with skills and knowledge for evaluating and applying research on the impact of environmental toxicants on immunological function in human and wildlife populations.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Undergraduate or graduate introduction to immunology coursework recommended but not required; graduate standing or consent of instructor.

etx.name: — Toxicology of Pesticides
etx.description: Course Description: Classification and chemical properties of pesticides, their mode of action, metabolism and disposition, pesticide resistance, effects on human health and ecological health and methods of risk benefit analyses.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ETX 101; one course each in (a) Organic Chemistry, (b) Biochemistry, (c) Toxicology (ETX 101 or equivalent), or with consent of instructor; graduate standing.

etx.name: — Molecular Techniques
etx.description: Course Description: Recombinant DNA technology and its applications.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

etx.name: — Forensic DNA Analysis
etx.description: Course Description: Foundation in theory and practice of forensic DNA analysis; past, present, and emerging technologies; legal and quality assurance issues. DNA extraction, DNA quantitation, multiplex amplification of STR loci, capillary electrophoresis of amplified products, and analysis of STR typing data.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Coursework in genetics and molecular biology.

etx.name: — Principles & Practice of Forensic Serology & DNA Analysis
etx.description: Course Description: Comprehensive overview of forensic serology and DNA typing techniques and technologies. Strong emphasis on real-world applications, including preservation and tracking of biological evidence, detection and identification of bodily fluids, and methods to extract, quantify, and type human DNA.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (FOR 278 or ETX 278) or (FOR 280 or ETX 280); or equivalent; consent of instructor.

etx.name: — Non-Human Forensic DNA; Theory & Casework Application
etx.description: Course Description: Provides a comprehensive understanding of plant and animal forensic biology in terms of sample collection, preservation, analytical methods, and of the invaluable lines of inquiry these forensic evidence may permit.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor required for all students not enrolled in the MS Forensics program; upper division Molecular Biology and Genetics or its equivalent.

etx.name: — Seminar
etx.description: Course Description: Current topics in environmental toxicology.

etx.name: — Advanced Research Conference
etx.description: Course Description: Presentation and critical discussion of advanced research methods and interpretation of research results. Designed primarily for graduate students.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

etx.name: — Tutoring in Environmental Toxicology
etx.description: Course Description: Teaching toxicology including conducting discussion groups for regular departmental courses under direct guidance of staff.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing in Environmental Toxicology, a related major, or the equivalent experience.

etx.name: — Group Study
etx.description: Course Description: Group study.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

etx.name: — Research
etx.description: Course Description: Research.
etx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

etx.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
etx.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training.

epi.name: — Quantitative Epidemiology I: Probability
epi.description: Course Description: Foundations in probability for epidemiologists. Emphasis on properties of and relationships between distributions and application of probability concepts to epidemiology. Includes a mathematical skills laboratory to assist in solution of epidemiologic problems.
