epi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ((MAT 016A,  MAT 016B) or (MAT 017A,  MAT 017B) or (MAT 021A,  MAT 021B)); STA 102; STA 108; or PHR 402  PHR 403 or equivalent of any listed course; concurrent or previous enrollment in a basic epidemiology course; e.g., EPI 205.

epi.name: — Quantitative Epidemiology II: Statistical Inference
epi.description: Course Description: Provides the mathematical statistics foundation for statistical models, methods, and data analysis.
epi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (EPI 202 or STA 130A or STA 131A or STA 133); EPI 205; a basic epidemiology course (EPI 205 or equivalent).

epi.name: — Quantitative Epidemiology III: Statistical Models
epi.description: Course Description: Introduces statistical models, methods, and data analysis in the areas of generalized linear model and survival analysis methodology.
epi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (EPI 203 or STA 130B or STA 131B or STA 133); EPI 205; STA 108 recommended; a basic epidemiology course (EPI 205 or equivalent); consent of instructor.

epi.name: — Foundation of Statistical Models, Methods, & Data Analysis for Scientists
epi.description: Course Description: Provides the mathematical statistics foundation for statistical models, methods, and data analysis.
epi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 130A or STA 131A or STA 133; EPI 228 recommended.

epi.name: — Statistical Models, Methods, & Data Analysis for Scientists
epi.description: Course Description: Introduces statistical models, methods, and data analysis in the areas of generalized linear, survival, and correlated data methodology.
epi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EPI 204A; STA 108 recommended.

epi.name: — Principles of Epidemiology
epi.description: Course Description: Basic epidemiologic concepts and approaches to epidemiologic research, with examples from veterinary and human medicine, including outbreak investigation, infectious disease epidemiology, properties of tests, and an introduction to epidemiologic study design and surveillance.
epi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MPM 202; or consent of instructor; an introductory statistics course.

epi.name: — Integration of Epidemiologic Concepts
epi.description: Course Description: In-depth analysis and integration of basic epidemiologic concepts and approaches to epidemiologic research presented in  MPM 405/EPI 205A, with more mathematical and theoretical basis and examples from veterinary and human medicine, including outbreak investigation, infectious disease epidemiology, properties of diagnostic tests, study design, and surveillance.

epi.name: — Epidemiologic Study Design
epi.description: Course Description: Builds on concepts presented in EPI 205. Concepts of epidemiologic study design (clinical trials, observational cohort studies, case control studies) introduced in EPI 205A are covered in more depth, using a problem-based format. Discussion of published epidemiologic studies.
epi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EPI 205; or consent of instructor.

epi.name: — Advanced Epidemiologic Methodology
epi.description: Course Description: In-depth integration of advanced epidemiological concepts. Theory, methods, and applications for observational studies including random and systematic error, confounding, counterfactuals, causal inference, effect modification, internal and external validity, estimability, and interpretation of effect measures, and advanced study designs.
epi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EPI 206.

epi.name: — Analysis & Interpretation of Epidemiologic Data
epi.description: Course Description: Application of theory and concepts of statistics and epidemiology to analysis and interpretation of data typically found in veterinary and human epidemiologic research.
epi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EPI 204 (can be concurrent); EPI 207; (STA 144 or PHR 202); and entry level skill in standard statistical software (eg. SPSS, BMDP, SAS, Stata, MinTab, S-Plus).

epi.name: — History of Epidemiology in Public Health
epi.description: Course Description: Introduction to the history of epidemiology in solving major public health problems. Original historical articles will be read/discussed. Topics may include: infectious disease, accidents/adverse events, nutritional deficiencies, community vaccination trials, occupational exposures, cancer, birth defects, cardiovascular disease, and smoking.

epi.name: — Problems in Epidemiologic Study Design
epi.description: Course Description: Design and development of research protocols and funding applications for peer review. Application of research methods data collection and management and statistical analysis in research proposals. Methods of evaluating research proposals, mechanisms of funding, specifying human subjects considerations.
epi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MPM 405; STA 102; STA 106; or the equivalent; MPM 406 or the equivalent; PHR 207 required concurrently.

epi.name: — Spatial Epidemiology
epi.description: Course Description: Geographic Information Systems (GIS) and spatial statistics. Students are expected to complete a term project based on their graduate research.
epi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EPI 205A or MPM 205.

epi.name: — Health & Ecological Risk Analysis
epi.description: Course Description: Methodological approach to risk analysis for human and animal-related health and ecological issues. Basic principles of risk analysis, including perception, communication, assessment and management. Emphasis on the assessment of risk.

epi.name: — Advanced Topics in Epidemiology Methods
epi.description: Course Description: An in-depth study of topics in epidemiology theory and methods, selected from: causal inference, confounding, study design, or other related areas, with year to year variation. Readings are assigned and students are expected to lead discussions on them.
epi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EPI 205B; EPI 206; EPI 207; or equivalents, with consent of instructor.

epi.name: — Methods for Longitudinal & Repeated Measurement Data
epi.description: Course Description: Mixed models for longitudinal data (LD)/repeated measurements; Mean and covariance models; General linear LD models; Random coefficients models; Linear mixed effects models for continuous outcome; Generalized linear mixed effects model for discrete outcome including binary, ordinal and count data.
epi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EPI 204; or consent of instructor.

epi.name: — Meta Analysis
epi.description: Course Description: Systematic review, standard and advanced statistical methods for meta-analysis and syntheses of knowledge and evidence. Quantitative analysis of published data, primarily in aggregate form. Students demonstrate skills in study design, protocol, analysis, and results reporting through presentation of drafted first author paper.
epi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): A course in basic statistics or consent of instructor.

epi.name: — Geographic Information Systems for Health Professionals
epi.description: Course Description: Emphasis on basic geographic and data management principles. Focus on software proficiency in application to analyzing/solving health-related problems. For graduate and professional students in epidemiology, public health, preventive veterinary medicine, health informatics with interest in spatial techniques in research.

epi.name: — Introduction to Molecular Epidemiology
epi.description: Course Description: Overview of the modern field of molecular epidemiology. Integrates molecular biology into traditional epidemiologic research by identifying pathways, molecules and genes that influence the risk of developing disease.
epi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EPI 205.

epi.name: — Infectious Disease Epidemiology
epi.description: Course Description: Infectious disease epidemiology and prevention, with emphasis on human and veterinary diseases of global health importance. Major global health epidemics and challenges of infectious diseases, by mode of transmission.
epi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Introductory epidemiology course; e.g., EPI 205.

epi.name: — Advanced Data Analysis with SAS
epi.description: Course Description: Provide an overview of common advanced statistical methods as well as a treatment of how to use SAS to implement them. Learn the ideas of reproducible research and reporting of statistical analyses.
epi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EPI 202; EPI 203; EPI 204; or the equivalent, or consent of instructor.

epi.name: — Principles of Injury Epidemiology
epi.description: Course Description: Overview of the epidemiology of human injury, including general principles, surveillance methods, behavioral factors, environmental factors, treatment issues and engineering and legal interventions related to vehicular injuries, drownings, falls, fires and burns, poisonings, firearm injuries, and other intentional injuries.

epi.name: — Critical Thinking in Epidemiology
epi.description: Course Description: Critical thinking in Epidemiology.
epi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EPI 205 B or better; EPI 206 B or better; EPI 207 (can be concurrent).

epi.name: — Environmental Epidemiology
epi.description: Course Description: Examination of the human health effects and the risk of disease from community, occupational, and personal exposure to toxic substances.
epi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MPM 405 (can be concurrent); upper division undergraduates who have completed EST 126; or the equivalent.

epi.name: — Social Epidemiology
epi.description: Course Description: Social determinants of health; psychosocial and physiological pathways; health and social inequality; gender and racial/ethnic disparities in health; social support, social cohesion and health; social gradient in behavioral risk factors; social ecological approaches to health intervention; interventions addressing social determinants.
epi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EPI 205A; and consent of instructor.

epi.name: — Epidemiology of Chronic Diseases & Aging
epi.description: Course Description: Overview of the epidemiology of chronic disease in old age. Topics include biology of aging, epidemiology of cardiovascular disease, neoplasms, osteoporosis and fractures, psychosocial factors and health in old age, dementias, functional status and prevention of disease.

epi.name: — Research Methods in Occupational Epidemiology
epi.description: Course Description: Methods used in epidemiologic research on occupational hazards. Topics include design and analysis of cohort and case-control studies, sample size, measuring dose, choosing a control group, validation of employment and health data, interpreting negative studies, and analysis software.
epi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (EPI 205A or MPM 205); (MPM 202 or STA 102).

epi.name: — Cancer Epidemiology
epi.description: Course Description: We will cover the underlying concepts essential to understanding cancer epidemiology, such as trends in incidence and survival, epidemiologic methods used to assess cancer etiology, prevention and control, and an introduction to the cancer initiation and progression multi-stage model.
epi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EPI 205A; EPI 205B; EPI 206 (can be concurrent); STA 102; must have basic understanding of epidemiologic and statistical concepts covered in the listed courses.

epi.name: — Mathematical Models in Epidemiology
epi.description: Course Description: Theory of epidemics and mathematical modeling concepts for infectious diseases to include discrete and continuous time models, their use to explore disease dynamics and investigate prevention and control strategies for human and veterinary infectious diseases.
epi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MPM 403; MPM 405; consent of instructor; although not required, students encouraged to refresh their knowledge of high school calculus and differential equations.

epi.name: — Introduction to SAS Programming
epi.description: Course Description: Introduction to SAS, an integrated software system for data retrieval and management, data manipulation and programming.
epi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Introductory statistics course; e.g., MPM 402, STA 102.

epi.name: — Seminars in Epidemiology
epi.description: Course Description: Faculty and students will present and lead discussion of ongoing or published epidemiologic research.

epi.name: — Seminars in Human Health Services Research & Clinical Epidemiology
epi.description: Course Description: Critical review, evaluation, and discussion of research in health services and clinical epidemiology. Presentation of statistical, epidemiologic, and econometric methods. Students present their own research and critique the work of others.

epi.name: — Group Study
epi.description: Course Description: Group study in selected areas of epidemiology.

epi.name: — Research
epi.description: Course Description: Research in selected areas of epidemiology.

eve.name: — Biodiversity
eve.description: Course Description: Introduction to nature, scope and geographical distribution of biodiversity (the diversity of life, with emphasis on plants and animals, especially insects). Humans and biodiversity; domestication, aesthetics, ethics and valuation. Species richness and "success."  Biodiversity through time; monitoring, evaluation and conservation. Biomes - global, continental and Californian.

eve.name: — Evolution for Non-Biologists
eve.description: Course Description: Introduction to evolutionary biology for the general population.

eve.name: — Principles of Ecology
eve.description: Course Description: Ecological principles with emphasis on humans and their interactions with the environment; how humans affect and depend on natural ecosystems; the future of the Earth's biosphere.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Elementary biology recommended.

eve.name: — Life in the Sea
eve.description: Course Description: Diversity of life in the sea; adaptations to physical/chemical ocean environment; marine science research methods; utilization of living marine resources by humans; factors and processes that influence diversity of sea life, including humans.

eve.name: — Sex in the Natural World
eve.description: Course Description: Explores the diversity, mechanisms and evolution of sexual behaviors across the kingdoms of life.

eve.name: — Wild Davis: A California Naturalist Certification Course
eve.description: Course Description: Natural history and urban ecology of Davis. Basics of ecological observation, community science and service, and California’s unique natural communities. If fee is paid, completion of the course provides certification in the UC California Naturalist Program.

eve.name: — Dining with Darwin: Evolutionary Insights Into Your Diet
eve.description: Course Description: Crave salty, fatty, sugary foods? Want to know why? Evolution of cravings, metabolism and dentition, and of cooking our food. Relate Paleo, South Beach, and vegan diets to ancestral and global diets and current metabolism. For majors and nonmajors.

eve.name: — Darwinian Medicine
eve.description: Course Description: Introduction for non-biologists to the evolved traits of humans and pathogens that influence human biological variation, health, and disease.

eve.name: — Internship
eve.description: Course Description: Work experience off and on campus in all subject areas offered in the Department of Evolution & Ecology. Internships supervised by a member of the faculty.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

eve.name: — Directed Group Study
eve.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

eve.name: — Special Study for Lower Division Students
eve.description: Course Description: Special study for lower division students.

eve.name: — Introduction to Evolution
eve.description: Course Description: General survey of the origins of biological diversity and evolutionary mechanisms.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C); (MAT 016A or MAT 017A or MAT 021A); (MAT 016B or MAT 017B or MAT 021B); STA 100 recommended.

eve.name: — Introduction to Ecology
eve.description: Course Description: General survey of the principles of ecology.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C); (MAT 016A or MAT 017A or MAT 021A); (MAT 016B or MAT 017B or MAT 021B); or the equivalent.

eve.name: — Introduction to Computer Models in Ecology
eve.description: Course Description: Computational methods and mathematical models used to study ecological phenomena.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EVE 101 (can be concurrent); EVE 101 required concurrently.

eve.name: — Population & Quantitative Genetics
eve.description: Course Description: Evolution as caused by random mating, genetic drift, natural selection, inbreeding, migration,and mutation in theory and actuality. The resemblance between relatives and consequences of selection for quantitative traits. Application of these ideas to topics such as the evolution of sex.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; (STA 100 or STA 102); EVE 100.

eve.name: — Phylogeny, Speciation & Macroevolution
eve.description: Course Description: Statistical inference of evolutionary patterns and processes above the species level. Topics include estimation of phylogenies and divergence times, character evolution, biogeographic history, and rates and patterns of lineage diversification, with an emphasis on the origin of species.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EVE 100.

eve.name: — Community Ecology
eve.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Population growth and density dependence; predation; exploitative, interference and apparent competition; mutualism and facilitation; coexistence mechanisms; niches, spatial and temporal variation etc. Emphasis on quantitative understanding through models, concepts, and empirical evidence.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EVE 101 or ESP 100.

eve.name: — Phylogenetic Analysis of Vertebrate Structure
eve.description: Course Description: The structure of the classes and subclasses of vertebrates is described and interpreted in terms of phylogeny.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 001A,  BIS 001B) or (BIS 002B,  BIS 002C).

eve.name: — Mechanical Design in Organisms
eve.description: Course Description: Explores fundamental principles in the form and function of organisms, examining how basic properties of size, shape, structure, and habitat constrain ways in which plants and animals interact and cope with their physical surroundings.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor; introductory animal biology (BIS 001B or BIS 002B), invertebrate zoology (EVE 112), and/or ecology (EVE 101) are recommended; residence at or near Bodega Marine Lab required.

eve.name: — Animal Communication
eve.description: Course Description: How animals use songs, dances, colors, chemicals, electricity and vibrations to communicate. Mechanisms of signal production and detection (sensory systems), theory of information transfer and signal design, and the role of natural selection in shaping communication.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002B.

eve.name: — Systematics & Evolution of Angiosperms
eve.description: Course Description: Diversity and classification of angiosperms (flowering plants) on a world scale, and current understanding of the origin of angiosperms and evolutionary relationships and trends within them based on morphological and molecular evidence.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 001A,  BIS 001B,  BIS 001C) or (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C).

eve.name: — Molecular Ecology
eve.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Use of molecular tools to answer fundamental questions in ecology and evolution of natural populations. Use of DNA and protein sequences to measure diversity and natural selection within and between populations and species and application to the fields of ecology and conservation. Hands-on manipulation and analysis of data in R.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EVE 100.

eve.name: — Running, Swimming & Flying
eve.description: Course Description: Examines the bases of organism movement in terrestrial, aquatic, and aerial environments, emphasizing both the unifying principles underlying locomotion, as well as a range of strategies employed across diverse groups of organisms.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor; introductory animal biology (BIS 001B or BIS 002B), invertebrate zoology (EVE 112), and/or ecology (EVE 101) are recommended; residence at or near Bodega Marine Lab required.

eve.name: — Marine Environmental Issues
eve.description: Course Description: Examination of critical environmental issues occurring in coastal waters including the effects of climate change, overfishing, and other human impacts. Through readings and group discussions, students will develop an integrative understanding of the oceanographic and ecological processes.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

eve.name: — Biology of Invertebrates
eve.description: Course Description: Survey of the invertebrate phyla, emphasizing aquatic forms, and focusing on morphology, development, natural history, ecology, and phylogenetic relationships.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 001B or (BIS 002B,  BIS 002C); courses in systematics, ecology, and evolution recommended.

eve.name: — Biology of Invertebrates Laboratory
eve.description: Course Description: Field and laboratory experience with representative members of the major invertebrate phyla discussed in EVE 112. Emphasis on comparative morphology, natural history, ecology, and behavior of living invertebrates. Two field trips required.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 001B or (BIS 002B,  BIS 002C)),  EVE 112 (can be concurrent); EVE 112 required concurrently.

eve.name: — Experimental Invertebrate Biology
eve.description: Course Description: Biology, ecology, and evolution of local marine invertebrates with a focus on adaptations to environmental and biological factors encountered on the California coast. Hands-on field and laboratory learning with an emphasis on generating and testing hypotheses.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor; introductory cell, animal and plant biology (BIS 001A and BIS 001B and BIS 001C, or BIS 002B), invertebrate zoology (EVE 112),  ecology (EVE 101), and/or evolution (EVE 100) are recommended; residence at or near Bodega Marine Lab required.

eve.name: — Marine Ecology
eve.description: Course Description: Processes affecting the distribution, abundance, and diversity of plant and animal life in the sea. Introduction to marine habitat diversity and human impacts on marine ecosystems.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EVE 101 or ESP 100 or BIS 002B; or consent of instructor.

eve.name: — Plant Ecology
eve.description: Course Description: The study of the interactions between plants, plant populations or vegetation types and their physical and biological environment. Special emphasis on California. Four full-day field trips and brief write-up of class project required.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 001A,  BIS 001B,  BIS 001C) or (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C); PLB 111 recommended.

eve.name: — Population Biology of Invasive Plants & Weeds
eve.description: Course Description: Origin and evolution of invasive plant species and weeds, reproduction and dispersal, seed ecology, modeling of population dynamics, interactions between invasive species, native species, and crops, biological control. Laboratories emphasize design of competition experiments and identification of weedy species.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 001A,  BIS 001B,  BIS 001C) or (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C); introductory statistics recommended.

eve.name: — Global Change Ecology
eve.description: Course Description: Treatment of historical evolution of the biosphere resulting from physical, chemical, and biological influences. Special focus upon changes caused by humans. Topics pertain to biodiversity, resources, conservation, and ecosystem services.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EVE 100; EVE 101; or equivalents.

eve.name: — Human Genetic Variation & Evolution
eve.description: Course Description: Introduction to genome-wide nucleotide sequence variation in human populations and computational methods for its analysis. Topics to include forensics, disease gene mapping, and studies of human evolutionary history. Misuses, such as eugenics, and ethical/legal issues will be discussed.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 001B or BIS 002B.

eve.name: — Ecology of Tropical Latitudes
eve.description: Course Description: Biological, physical, and human-related aspects of the ecology of low latitudes. Distribution, numbers, and relationships of tropical organisms. Problems of development and conservation in the context of ecological and evolutionary theory.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. One course in Biological Sciences (BIS), Entomology (ENT), Wildlife, Fish,  Conservation Biology (WFC), Geography (GEO), or tropical experience.

eve.name: — Paleobotany
eve.description: Course Description: Introduction to plant fossil record, beginning with invasion of land in the Silurian, emphasizing origin and evolution of major groups and adaptations and changing composition and distribution of floras in relation to plate tectonics and climatic change.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 001A,  BIS 001B,  BIS 001C) or (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C).

eve.name: — Principles of Systematics
eve.description: Course Description: Historical background, philosophical rationale, contemporary approaches, and working rules of biosystematics, including International Code of Zoological Nomenclature.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 001B or BIS 001C or BIS 002B; EVE 100 recommended.

eve.name: — Biogeography
eve.description: Course Description: Movements of terrestrial organisms. The role of geologic, climatic, and biologic changes in the geographic distribution of organisms.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002B or (BIS 001A,  BIS 001B).

eve.name: — Evolution of Ecological Systems
eve.description: Course Description: Evolution as an organizing force in natural communities. Coadaptation in trophic and competitive relationships. Ecology of polymorphisms, clines, and speciation.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (EVE 101 or ESP 100); EVE 100; or equivalent courses.

eve.name: — Evolution of Animal Development
eve.description: Course Description: Comparative analysis of animal development and the genetic basis of morphological diversification.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; EVE 100; EVE 100 (may be waived for graduate students with consent of instructor).

eve.name: — Microbial Phylogenomics; Genomic Perspectives on the Diversity & Diversification of Microbes
eve.description: Course Description: Use of DNA and genomic sequencing in studies of the diversity of microorganisms. Diversity of microbes, phylogenetics, genome sequencing, comparative genomics, phylogenomics, lateral gene transfer, molecular ecology, metagenomics, and studies of the human microbiome.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; BIS 002B; BIS 002C; or equivalent.

eve.name: — Computational Genetics
eve.description: Course Description: The use of computers to solve problems in genetics and evolution. Introduction to a general purpose computer language (Python),  computational statistical methods, and applications such as QTL mapping, linkage detection, estimation of rates of evolution, and gene finding.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; (STA 100 or STA 102).

eve.name: — Experimental Ecology & Evolution in the Field
eve.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Experimental design in field ecology. Examination of primary literature, experimental design, independent and collaborative research, analysis of data, development of original research paper based on field experiments.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EVE 100 (can be concurrent); (EVE 101 (can be concurrent) or ESP 100 (can be concurrent) or ENT 105 (can be concurrent)); due to the unusual nature of this course, all prospective students are strongly encouraged to contact the instructor.

eve.name: — Experimental Ecology & Evolution in the Field
eve.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Experimental design in field ecology. Examination of primary literature, experimental design, independent and collaborative research, analysis of data, development of original research paper based on field experiments.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EVE 180A or ENT 180A.

eve.name: — Ecology & Evolution of Animal-Plant Interactions
eve.description: Course Description: Animal adaptations for eating plants, pollinating flowers, dispersing seeds. Plant adaptations to herbivore defense, attraction of mutualists; role of coevolutionary arms race, mutualists and cheaters in plant/animal speciation. Exploration through lectures, original scientific literature, discussions and term paper.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002B; BIS 002C (can be concurrent).

eve.name: — Introduction to Biological Research
eve.description: Course Description: Introduction to research methods in biology. Presentation and discussion of research by faculty, graduate, and undergraduate students.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing in Evolution  Ecology or related biological science.

eve.name: — Undergraduate Seminar
eve.description: Course Description: Student reports on current topics with emphasis on integration of concepts, synthesis, and state-of-the-art research approaches. Reviews of literature and reports of undergraduate research may be included.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing in the biological sciences or a related discipline.

eve.name: — Internship
eve.description: Course Description: Work experience off and on campus in all subject areas offered in the Department of Evolution & Ecology. Internships supervised by a member of the faculty.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of 84 units.

eve.name: — Research Honors
eve.description: Course Description: Students pursue intensive research under the guidance of a faculty advisor. Students are expected to complete the full three-quarter sequence culminating in the writing of an honors thesis.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Students who have completed 135 units and qualify for the Honors Program (as defined by the current catalog).

eve.name: — Research Honors
eve.description: Course Description: Students pursue intensive research under the guidance of a faculty advisor. Students are expected to complete the full three-quarter sequence culminating in the writing of an honors thesis.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Students who have completed 135 units and qualify for the Honors Program (as defined by the current catalog).

eve.name: — Research Honors
eve.description: Course Description: Students pursue intensive research under the guidance of a faculty advisor. Students are expected to complete the full three-quarter sequence culminating in the writing of an honors thesis.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Students who have completed 135 units and qualify for the Honors Program (as defined by the current catalog).

eve.name: — Tutoring in Biological Sciences 2B
eve.description: Course Description: Assisting the instructor by tutoring students in a Biological Sciences 2B laboratory. Tutoring is voluntary and is supervised by a Laboratory Teaching Assistant and the Laboratory Coordinator.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 001B B or better.

eve.name: — Directed Group Study
eve.description: Course Description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.

eve.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
eve.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

eve.name: — Molecular Phylogenetic Analysis
eve.description: Course Description: Theory and practice of inferring phylogenetic trees using molecular sequence data. Practical techniques for obtaining sequence data, advantages and disadvantages of common approaches for inferring trees, statistical methods for comparing alternative hypotheses.

eve.name: — Applied Phylogenetics
eve.description: Course Description: Applications of phylogenetic methods to fields outside of systematics. Core lectures/labs in remedial phylogenetics, phylogeography, conservation and comparative morphology. Special topics vary yearly.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EVE 103 or EVE 210 or PBG 200C; or equivalent, graduate standing.

eve.name: — Species & Speciation
eve.description: Course Description: Current status of species concepts, models of speciation, current research on speciation, and relevance of species to conservation biology.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EVE 100 or PHI 108; or the equivalent; HPS 130B recommended.

eve.name: — Linear Mixed Modeling in Ecology & Evolution
eve.description: Course Description: Analysis of clustered data requires hierarchical or mixed statistical models. Conceptual basis and practical application of linear (mixed) models. Examples drawn from evolutionary and behavioral ecology. Hands-on manipulation and analysis of data in R.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 205 or equivalent coursework or experience with basic linear modelling is strongly recommended.

eve.name: — Principles of Biological Data Analysis
eve.description: Course Description: Introduction to the principles of data analysis, experimental design, statistical modeling, inference, and hypothesis tests. Statistical methods of particular importance in biological applications will be emphasized. Examples will be presented from the fields of ecology and evolutionary genetics.

eve.name: — Paleobotany & Angiosperm Evolution
eve.description: Course Description: Critical analysis of the plant fossil record as a source of evidence on origin, evolution, and phylogeny of the angio-sperms, Cretaceous and Tertiary climates, geographic history of modern taxa, and origin of modern vegetation types.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLB 108 or PLB 116 or EVE 140.

eve.name: — Research Conference
eve.description: Course Description: Presentation and discussion of faculty and graduate student research in biology.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

eve.name: — Group Study
eve.description: Course Description: Group study.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

eve.name: — Research
eve.description: Course Description: Research.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

eve.name: — Methods of Teaching
eve.description: Course Description: Practical experience in the methods and problems of teaching. Includes analyses of texts and supporting material, discussion of teaching techniques and preparing and conducting of laboratory and discussion sections.
eve.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

exb.name: — Research Conference
exb.description: Course Description: Research findings and methods in exercise biology. Presentation and discussion of research by faculty and students.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EXB 099 (can be concurrent); Lower division standing in Exercise Biology or related biological science and consent of instructor; EXB 099 required concurrently.

exb.name: — Lower Division Seminar
exb.description: Course Description: Gives freshman or sophomore level students the opportunity to study a special topic in the general area of Exercise Biology in a small class setting.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

exb.name: — Exercise Biology Internship
exb.description: Course Description: Work experience in the application of physical activity programs to teaching, recreational, clinical or research situations under department faculty supervision.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; enrollment dependent on availability of intern positions.

exb.name: — Tutoring in Exercise Biology
exb.description: Course Description: Assisting the professor by tutoring students in exercise biology course-related projects.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

exb.name: — Tutoring Exercise Biology in the Community
exb.description: Course Description: Tutoring in the community in exercise biology related projects under the guidance of the faculty.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor and chairperson.

exb.name: — Directed Group Study
exb.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor and chairperson.

exb.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
exb.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

exb.name: — Exercise Physiology
exb.description: Course Description: Physiology of Exercise; acute responses and adaptations to training. Neuromuscular function; bioenergetics; metabolic responses to acute exercise; adaptation to trainings; cardiorespiratory; and, applications to environmental physiology, and human health.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 101 or NPB 110C; or consent of instructor.

exb.name: — Introduction to Motor Learning & the Psychology of Sport & Exercise
exb.description: Course Description: Theoretical and practical issues in motor learning, sport psychology, and exercise psychology are examined. Emphasis is placed on how motor skills are acquired and retained, and on the application of social psychology and human motivation studies to human performance.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 001 recommended.

exb.name: — Exercise Biology Laboratory
exb.description: Course Description: Principles and analytical procedures for assessing fundamental physiological, biomechanical, motor learning and motor control factors which underlie human movement and performance.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EXB 101 (can be concurrent); EXB 102 (can be concurrent); EXB 103 (can be concurrent); courses may be taken concurrently.

exb.name: — Human Gross Anatomy
exb.description: Course Description: Detailed study of the gross anatomical structure of the human body, with emphasis on function and clinical relevance to students entering health care professions.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; concurrent enrollment in EXB 106L or CHA 101L strongly recommended.

exb.name: — Human Gross Anatomy Laboratory
exb.description: Course Description: Detailed study of prosected human cadavers in small group format with extensive hands-on experience.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; EXB 106 (can be concurrent) or CHA 101 (can be concurrent); must have completed EXB 106 or CHA 101 or required concurrently.

exb.name: — Exercise Metabolism
exb.description: Course Description: Exercise metabolism, with emphasis on skeletal muscle and cardiac muscle metabolism during activity and inactivity. Basics of bioenergetics, substrate utilization, and cell signaling; mechanisms that regulate these properties, and differences between skeletal muscle and cardiac muscle metabolism.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EXB 101 or NPB 101 or NPB 110C.

exb.name: — Environmental Effects on Physical Performance
exb.description: Course Description: The effects of thermal, barometric and gravitational conditions on physiological function and physical performance of humans. Acute and chronic effects, emphasizing physiological adaptations and limitations, will be studied.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EXB 101; or consent of instructor.

exb.name: — Clinical Exercise Physiology
exb.description: Course Description: Physical activity as a therapeutic modality in normal and diseased populations (cardiovascular, pulmonary, diabetic). Effects of exercise and inactivity in terms of normal physiology, pathophysiology, and therapeutic benefit. Exercise fitness and disease assessment methods.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 101 or NPB 110C; or consent of instructor.

exb.name: — Biomechanical Bases of Movement
exb.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Biomechanical bases of human movement investigated; topics include musculo-skeletal mechanics, tissue mechanics, electromyography, and measurement and analysis techniques. Application made to sport, clinical, and work environments, including extensive analysis of locomotion.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EXB 103; or consent of instructor.

exb.name: — Nutrition for Physically Active Persons
exb.description: Course Description: The role of nutrition and exercise in modifying metabolism, body composition, performance and health of humans.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EXB 101; NPB 101.

exb.name: — Exercise & Aging in Health & Disease
exb.description: Course Description: Etiology of and standard therapy for various diseases associated with inactivity and aging; e.g., cardiovascular, pulmonary, diabetes, obesity, lipemias, etc. Exercise will then be considered as a protective and/or therapeutic modality.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 101 or NPB 110C; or consent of instructor.

exb.name: — Advanced Sport Psychology
exb.description: Course Description: Advanced study and consideration of major theoretical and practical issues in sport psychology. Emphasis on practical application to sport and human performance.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EXB 102; PSC 001 recommended.

exb.name: — Psychological Effects of Physical Activity
exb.description: Course Description: Physical activity is evaluated in terms of its ability to enhance the quality of life. Topics studied include:  individual factors (self concept, type A); special populations (elderly, cardiovascular); and mental health changes (depression, anxiety).
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 001 or PSC 001Y.

exb.name: — Physiology of Maximal Human Performance
exb.description: Course Description: Molecular mechanisms underlying adaptation to training. Learn how to exercise to maximize their own performance as well as learning how the frequency, intensity and timing of exercise and nutrition affect the molecular signals that underlie performance.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EXB 101; or consent of instructor; BIS 101, BIS 102, and BIS 103 recommended.

exb.name: — Neuromuscular & Behavioral Aspects of Motor Control
exb.description: Course Description: Factors which affect control of movement from neuropsychological, physiological, behavioral, and mechanical viewpoints. Topics include central vs. peripheral control mechanisms, open and closed loop theories, motor programming, cognitive learning strategies, and the effects of biochemical and biomechanical influences.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EXB 101.

exb.name: — Theory & Practice of Exercise Testing
exb.description: Course Description: Theory and practice of exercise testing applied to older adult populations. Physiological responses to and limitations of exercise testing. Application of exercise testing and training to healthy and diseased populations.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EXB 112 (can be concurrent).

exb.name: — Adult Fitness Testing Laboratory
exb.description: Course Description: Testing symptomatic and asymptomatic older adults for functional aerobic capacity, body composition, blood lipids, pulmonary function, and cardiovascular disease risk. Counseling adults in appropriate exercise programs and lifestyle modifications. Two quarters minimum; third quarter permitted. (Former course PHE 148L).
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EXB 148; EXB 148 required concurrently.

exb.name: — Frontiers in Exercise Biology
exb.description: Course Description: Lectures by leading authorities and discussion of the latest research in newly emerging areas in exercise biology. Offered every fourth year.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EXB 101; EXB 102; EXB 103 (can be concurrent); EXB 104L recommended.

exb.name: — International Perspectives in Exercise Biology
exb.description: Course Description: Compare and contrast exercise science issues between the US and an international location. Identify political, economic, cultural, technological and environmental issues that impact human exercise, physical activity, wellness, and sport from a global perspective.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EXB 010; or upper division standing in Exercise Biology; consent of instructor: students will be accepted based upon academic merit, personal experience, and academic discipline in order to provide multidisciplinary perspectives.

exb.name: — Research Conference
exb.description: Course Description: Research findings and methods in exercise biology. Presentation and discussion of research by faculty and students.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EXB 099 (can be concurrent); upper division standing in Exercise Biology or related biological science and consent of instructor; EXB 199 required concurrently.

exb.name: — Exercise Biology Internship
exb.description: Course Description: Work experience in the application of physical activity programs to teaching, recreational, clinical or research situations under program faculty supervision. Written report required.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; enrollment dependent on availability of intern positions.

exb.name: — Research Honors
exb.description: Course Description: Completion of individual honors research project in Exercise Biology, under the guidance of an Exercise Biology faculty advisor, culminating in written honors thesis.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Senior standing; minimum of 6 units of EXB 199; 3.500 GPA or greater in major courses; consent of honors thesis advisor.

exb.name: — Tutoring in Exercise Biology
exb.description: Course Description: Assisting the instructor by tutoring students in exercise biology course-related projects.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

exb.name: — Tutoring Exercise Biology in the Community
exb.description: Course Description: Tutoring in the community in exercise biology related projects under the guidance of the faculty.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor and chairperson.

exb.name: — Directed Group Study
exb.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor and chairperson.

exb.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
exb.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
exb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of chairperson.

exs.name: — Exercise Cardiorespiratory Physiology
exs.description: Course Description: Advanced course on integrated responses of the cardiovascular and respiratory systems to exercise. Includes hemodynamic, neurohormonal, and autonomic aspects of cardiac and vascular function, principles of myocardial metabolism, and mechanisms underlying changes in pulmonary function and gas transport.
exs.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Undergraduate course in systemic physiology, exercise physiology, and biochemistry (intermediary metabolism).

fap.name: — Primary Care Clinic
fap.description: Course Description: Students must apply and interview with the Board of Clinica Tepati or Imani Clinic. Field experience exposes lower division students to health care delivery, patient histories, physical examinations,health promotion, disease prevention, diagnosis; treatment of episodic,acute,chronic illness; appropriate referral and follow-up.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; enrollment at the UC Davis campus, for freshman and sophomore students.

fap.name: — Primary Care Clinics
fap.description: Course Description: Students must apply and interview with the Board of Clinica Tepati or Imani Clinic. Field experience introduces students to health care delivery, patient histories and physical examinations, health promotions and disease prevention, diagnosis and treatment of episodic, acute and chronic illness, basic laboratory testing and appropriate referral and follow-up.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; enrollment at the UC Davis campus; upper division standing.

fap.name: — Health Care to Underserved Populations
fap.description: Course Description: Discusses sociocultural perspectives of underserved populations in California impacting their health; roles of family/interpersonal relationships in making health care decisions; and clinician's perspectives in treating people of cultures which are unfamiliar and/or uncomfortable with Western medicine.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Sociology, political science, or applied behavioral science background recommended, or registration in medical school.

fap.name: — Introductory Preceptorship in Family Practice
fap.description: Course Description: Preceptorship in family practice offered as an introduction to clinical medicine. 20 hours or 40 hours per week in a family physician's office, doing patient interviews, historytaking, and performing physical exams.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of first-year of medical training.

fap.name: — The Healer's Art
fap.description: Course Description: Learning to strengthen your humanity and remain open-hearted can make the difference between burnout and a fulfilling life. Learn tools for selfcare, healing, finding meaning, strengthening commitment and becoming a true physician.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

fap.name: — Selected Studies of Systems for Chronic Illness Care
fap.description: Course Description: Understanding of chronic illness, particularly diabetes, participate in patient care, alternative techniques.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FAP 400A; FAP 400B; FAP 400C; medical students with consent of instructor.

fap.name: — Family Medicine Clerkship
fap.description: Course Description: Family medicine clerkship for third year medical students.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

fap.name: — SJVP Longitudinal Family Medicine Clerkship
fap.description: Course Description: Longitudinal Family Medicine Clerkship runs concurrently with Internal Medicine, Pediatrics and Psychiatry for 32 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

fap.name: — SJVP Longitudinal Family Medicine Clerkship
fap.description: Course Description: Longitudinal Family Medicine Clerkship runs concurrently with Internal Medicine, Pediatrics and Psychiatry for 32 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

fap.description: Course Description: Longitudinal Family Medicine Clerkship runs concurrently with Internal Medicine, Pediatrics and Psychiatry for 32 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty.

fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

fap.description: Course Description: Family Medicine Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.

fap.description: Course Description: Family Medicine Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

fap.description: Course Description: Family Medicine Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

fap.name: — Rural PRIME Family Medicine Longitudinal Clerkship
fap.description: Course Description: Family Medicine Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

fap.name: — TeachMS Longitudinal Primary Care Clerkship (A)
fap.description: Course Description: Longitudinal Clerkship runs concurrently with Internal Medicine and Psychiatry for 24 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty. On-going patient write-ups, rounds, conferences are required.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

fap.description: Course Description: Longitudinal Clerkship runs concurrently with Internal Medicine and Psychiatry for 24 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty. On-going patient write-ups, rounds, conferences are required.

fap.description: Course Description: Longitudinal Clerkship runs concurrently with Internal Medicine and Psychiatry for 24 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty. On-going patient write-ups, rounds, conferences are required.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

fap.name: — Introduction to Primary Care Continuity Clinic
fap.description: Course Description: Longitudinal component of the third-year primary care curriculum. Attend clinic roughly 18 half-days over the course of the year, working one-on-one with a primary care preceptor.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of the Pre-Clinical Curriculum.

fap.description: Course Description: Longitudinal component of the third-year primary care curriculum. Attend clinic roughly 18 half-days over the course of the year, working one-on-one with a primary care preceptor.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of the Pre-Clinical Curriculum.

fap.description: Course Description: Longitudinal component of the third-year primary care curriculum. Attend clinic roughly 18 half-days over the course of the year, working one-on-one with a primary care preceptor.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of the Pre-Clinical Curriculum.

fap.description: Course Description: Longitudinal component of the third-year primary care curriculum. Attend clinic roughly 18 half-days over the course of the year, working one-on-one with a primary care preceptor.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of the Pre-Clinical Curriculum.

fap.name: — ACE-PC Continuity Clinic
fap.description: Course Description: Longitudinal clinic component of the second year of the ACE-PC Program. Start with a four-week immersion experience and then 12 additional half-days over the course of the year, working one-on-one with a primary care preceptor.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

fap.description: Course Description: Longitudinal clinic component of the second year of the ACE-PC Program. Start with a four-week immersion experience and then 12 additional half-days over the course of the year, working one-on-one with a primary care preceptor.

fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

fap.name: — Primary Care Clinics-Clínica Tepati
fap.description: Course Description: Learn counseling, diagnosis and treatment of patients with chronic and acute disease under supervision of physician. Provides exposure to special health care needs of various ethnic and poverty-level populations.

fap.name: — Primary Care Clinics-Imani Clinic
fap.description: Course Description: Learn counseling, diagnosis and treatment of patients with chronic and acute disease under supervision of physician. Provides exposure to special health care needs of various ethnic and poverty-level populations.

fap.name: — Continuity Clinic in Primary Care; Shifa Clinic
fap.description: Course Description: Learn counseling, diagnosis and treatment of patients with chronic and acute disease under supervision of physician. Provides exposure to special health care needs of various ethnic and poverty-level populations.

fap.name: — Primary Care Clinics: Knights Landing
fap.description: Course Description: Learn counseling, diagnosis and treatment of patients with chronic and acute disease under supervision of physician. Provides exposure to special health care needs of various ethnic and poverty-level populations in the community of Knights Landing.

fap.name: — Directed Clinical Studies in Family Medicine
fap.description: Course Description: Individual directed studies in extended preparation for modified curriculum or to complete a clinical rotation following a leave of absence.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

fap.name: — Directed Studies in Family Medicine
fap.description: Course Description: Individual directed studies in extended preparation for remediation of all or part of clinical rotation. Clinical studies to accommodate and satisfy remedial work as directed by the Committee on Student Progress and approved by the course IOR.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

fap.name: — Advanced Preceptorship in Family Medicine
fap.description: Course Description: Preceptorships with primary care physicians in a variety of settings. Acquisition skills to evaluate and devleop a treatment plan for patients with common medical problems seen by primary care physicians in an out patient setting.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of third-year primary care plus clerkship or consent of instructor.

fap.name: — CAM in Family & Community Health
fap.description: Course Description: Complementary and alternative medicine courses at away institutions that cover various aspects of integrative medicine, including but not limited to: botanicals, homeopathy, mind/body, naturopathy, nutrition, traditional Chinese medicine, osteopathy, and energy medicine. Intended to grant units for away rotations; not offered at the UC Davis Medical Center.

fap.name: — Away Advanced Clinical Clerkship in Family Medicine
fap.description: Course Description: Preceptorships with primary care physicians in a variety of settings. Acquisition skills to evaluate and develop a treatment plan for patients with common medical problems seen by primary care physicians in an out patient setting.

fap.name: — Geriatrics in Community Health
fap.description: Course Description: Visits to community agencies including mental health teams, adult day health centers, a diagnostic and research center, and case management specialists. Observation and participation in MMSE's, patient-family conferences, interdisciplinary team meetings, neuropsychiatric testing and home visit evaluations.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FAP 430.

fap.name: — International Preceptorship
fap.description: Course Description: Preceptorship with a family practitioner in a foreign country (Arranged by student contact or with assistance of the Family and Community Medicine Department.) Participate in clinical activities, analyze and report characteristics of the practice.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical students with consent of instructor.

fap.name: — Inpatient Acting Internship in Family Medicine
fap.description: Course Description: Comprehensive primary medical care of inpatients on a family medicine hospital service. Available sites are university-based family medicine residency programs and programs within the UC Davis Network of Affiliated Family Medicine Residency Programs.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of third-year of medical school or consent of instructor.

fap.name: — Inpatient Clinical Elective in Family Medicine
fap.description: Course Description: Comprehensive primary medical care of patients on a family medicine hospital service. Usually includes inpatient and outpatient experience.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of third-year of medical school or consent of instructor.

fap.name: — Combined Inpatient/Outpatient Clinical Elective in Family Medicine
fap.description: Course Description: Combined inpatient and outpatient elective. Consists of comprehensive primary medical care of patients on a family medicine hospital service and in a family medicine outpatient clinic.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of third-year of medical school or consent of instructor.

fap.name: — Away Inpatient Acting Internship in Family Medicine
fap.description: Course Description: Comprehensive primary medical care of inpatients on a family medicine hospital service.

fap.name: — Selected Studies in Family Practice
fap.description: Course Description: Assigned readings in family practice to increase understanding on selected topics relating to family medicine and primary health care delivery; visits to and written analysis of selected health care programs; and/or exposure to family practice with a community physician preceptor.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical students with consent of instructor.

fap.name: — Health Care to Underserved Populations
fap.description: Course Description: Discusses sociocultural perspectives of underserved populations impacting health; roles of family/interpersonal relationships in making health care decisions; the nature of ethnic/racial/socioeconomic health care disparities; and clinicians' perspectives in treating people of cultures which are unfamiliar and/or uncomfortable with Western medicine.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Sociology, Political Science, or Applied Behavioral Science background recommended, or registration in medical school.

fap.name: — Aging & Health
fap.description: Course Description: Is disease and infirmity the inevitable consequence of aging? We will spend four weeks exploring this question by reviewing the biology of aging, physiologic changes seen in aged individuals and disease processes commonly found in elderly persons.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

fap.name: — LGBTIQQA Healthcare Lecture Series
fap.description: Course Description: Increase the awareness of medical issues surrounding the LGBTIQQA community and arm students with knowledge of the health disparities the community faces. Provide better quality care to the LGBTIQQA patients cared for as physicians.

fap.name: — Advanced Transgender & Gender Nonbinary (TGNB) Health
fap.description: Course Description: Focuses on cultural competency in caring for Transgender & Gender Nonbinary (TGNB) patients, including awareness of health disparities.

fap.name: — Directed Group Study
fap.description: Course Description: Explore in-depth various topics in primary care. Extensive contact with and oversight by instructor.

fap.name: — Research
fap.description: Course Description: Research in various aspects of the health care delivery system.
fap.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical students with consent of instructor.

fps.name: — Principles of Polymer Materials Science
fps.description: Course Description: Basic principles of polymer science are presented including polymer structure and synthesis; polymerization mechanisms, polymer classes, properties, and reactions; polymer morphology, rheology, and characterization; polymer processing.
fps.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 002A; CHE 002B; ((CHE 008A,  CHE 008B) or (ENG 045 or ENG 045Y)); Introductory physics.

fps.name: — Plastics in Society & the Environment
fps.description: Course Description: Basic concepts and methodologies in the study of plastics. Formation, classification, structure, properties, processing, and formulation. Their application to societal needs, and their impact on society and the environment.
fps.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 010; or introductory course in physical sciences.

fps.name: — Polymer Syntheses & Reactions
fps.description: Course Description: Organic and physical chemistry aspects of polymer syntheses and reactions including polymerization mechanisms, kinetics and thermodynamics for major types of organic high polymers.

fps.name: — Structure & Properties of Fibers
fps.description: Course Description: Structure, properties and reactions of natural- and man-made fibers; the relations between molecular structure of fibers and their physical properties; interactions of fibers and detergents.

fps.name: — Textile Chemical Analysis Laboratory
fps.description: Course Description: Laboratory methods and procedures employed in qualitative and quantitative analysis of textile fibers and auxiliaries.

fps.name: — Introduction to Research in Fiber & Polymer Science
fps.description: Course Description: Senior thesis on independent problems. Research begun in TXC 180A continued and completed in TXC 180B.
fps.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; senior standing in major related to Fiber and Polymer Science.

fps.name: — Introduction to Research in Fiber & Polymer Science
fps.description: Course Description: Senior thesis on independent problems. Research begun in TXC 180A continued and completed in TXC 180B.
fps.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; senior standing in major related to Fiber and Polymer Science.

fps.name: — Internship in Fiber & Polymer Science
fps.description: Course Description: Work experience off campus in a fiber and polymer science related area. Supervision by a member of the Textiles and Clothing faculty.

fps.name: — Tutoring in Fiber & Polymer Science
fps.description: Course Description: Tutoring of students in Fiber & Polymer Science courses. Assistance with discussion groups and laboratory sections under supervision of instructor.
fps.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division fiber and polymer science related major.

fps.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
fps.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

fps.name: — Special Topics in Polymer & Fiber Science
fps.description: Course Description: Selected topics of current interest in polymer and fiber sciences. Topics vary each time course is offered.
fps.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FPS 100; or consent of instructor.

fps.name: — Special Topics in Polymer & Fiber Science
fps.description: Course Description: Selected topics of current interest in polymer and fiber sciences. Topics vary each time course is offered.
fps.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FPS 100; or consent of instructor.

fps.name: — Special Topics in Polymer & Fiber Science
fps.description: Course Description: Selected topics of current interest in polymer and fiber sciences. Topics vary each time course is offered.
fps.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FPS 100; or consent of instructor.

fps.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
fps.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant, training practicum.

fms.name: — Vampires & Other Horrors in Film & Media
fms.description: Course Description: History of representations of vampires and horror generally from the 19th-21st centuries. Emphasis on transnational history of the horror genre; psychologies of horror effects; issues of race, gender, and class; intersections with prejudice, medicine, modernity.

fms.name: — Lower Division Seminar
fms.description: Course Description: Study of a special topic in Film Studies in a small class setting.
fms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

fms.name: — Italian-American Cinema
fms.description: Course Description: Exploration of representations of Italian-American identity in American (U.S.) cinema. Analysis of both Hollywood and independently produced films, especially as they represent ethnicity, gender, and social class of Italian Americans.

fms.name: — New Italian Cinema
fms.description: Course Description: Italian cinema of the 21st century in the context of profound cultural and social changes in Italy since World War II. Productions by representative directors such as Amelio, Giordana, Moretti, Muccino are included. Knowledge of Italian not required.
fms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FMS 001; and upper division standing, or consent of instructor.

fms.name: — New Italian Cinema
fms.description: Course Description: Italian cinema of the 21st century in the context of profound cultural and social changes in Italy since World War II. Productions by representative directors such as Amelio, Giordana, Moretti, Muccino are included. Knowledge of Italian not required. May be taught abroad.
fms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FMS 001; and upper division standing, or consent of instructor.

fms.name: — Film Theory
fms.description: Course Description: Survey of the conceptual frameworks used to study film (including semiotics, psychoanalysis, spectatorship, auteur, genre and narrative theories). Historical survey of major film theorists.
fms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FMS 001; or consent of instructor.

fms.name: — Russian Film
fms.description: Course Description: History of Russian film; film & social revolution, the cult of Stalin, dissident visions; film & the collapse of the Soviet empire; gender and the nation in Russian film. Taught in English; Russian films with English subtitles.
fms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Subject A requirement.

fms.name: — New German Cinema
fms.description: Course Description: German filmmakers of the 1960s-1980s such as Fassbinder, Herzog, Syberberg, Brückner, Schlöndorf, Kluge, Wenders. Knowledge of German is not required.

fms.name: — Classic Weimar Cinema
fms.description: Course Description: German Weimar (1919-1933) cinema. Fritz Lang, F.W. Murnau, and G.W. Pabst among others. Influence on world-wide (esp. Hollywood) film genres such as film noir, horror, science fiction, and melodrama.

fms.name: — Postwar German Cinema
fms.description: Course Description: Exploration of German cinema from 1945 to 1980, when the Nazi past was a central theme. Includes study of postwar "rubble films," escapist "homeland films," and New German Cinema of the 1970s (including films by Fassbinder, Kluge, Syberberg, and Herzog).

fms.name: — Upper Division Seminar
fms.description: Course Description: Study of a special topic in film studies in a small class setting.
fms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

fst.name: — Principles of Food Science
fst.description: Course Description: Food science fundamentals. Fresh and processed food technologies; world food problems; food composition; food microbiological and toxicological safety; food laws; evaluation of acceptability and nutritional value.

fst.name: — Introduction to Brewing & Beer
fst.description: Course Description: Basic description of brewing and associated processes, from raw materials to final product; history of brewing and brewing science; types of beer worldwide; world beer markets; basics of beer quality, including wholesomeness; role of scientist in brewing.

fst.name: — Introduction to Brewing & Beer
fst.description: Course Description: Basic description of brewing and associated processes, from raw materials to final product; history of brewing and brewing science; types of beer worldwide; world beer markets; basics of beer quality, including wholesomeness; role of scientist in brewing.

fst.name: — Food Science, Folklore & Health
fst.description: Course Description: Ancient and modern food folklore in relation to health and well-being. Food safety, organic food, herbalism, food preservation, and nutritional enhancement.

fst.name: — Introduction to Food Preservation
fst.description: Course Description: Introduction to modes of fresh food preservation including use of chemicals and microbes, heat and energy, control of water and atmosphere, and by indirect approaches such as packaging, hygienic design and sanitation.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 002A; BIS 002A (can be concurrent); (STA 013 (can be concurrent) or STA 013Y (can be concurrent) or STA 100 (can be concurrent)).

fst.name: — Food in American Culture
fst.description: Course Description: Relationship between food and culture; relationship between food and the social order; influences on eating habits and the tensions between them including identity, convenience, and responsibility; multiple disciplines and genres.

fst.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
fst.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

fst.name: — Food Chemistry
fst.description: Course Description: Chemical aspects of food composition. Emphasis on the functional properties and chemical reactions of the major components of foods: carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, and water.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (CHE 008B or CHE 118B or CHE 128B); BIS 002A recommended.

fst.name: — Food Properties
fst.description: Course Description: Sensory quality, chemical and microbial safety, and nutritional properties of foods. Effects of food processing and preparation on these properties. Selected properties of food commodities.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FST 100A; CHE 008B; and consent of instructor.

fst.name: — Food Physical Chemistry
fst.description: Course Description: Fundamentals of thermodynamics and kinetics related to food physical chemistry. Phase behavior, crystallization, water activity and food stability, solubility, aroma volatility, formation of glasses, gels and dispersions, biopolymers and rheology.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FST 100A.

fst.name: — Food Chemistry Laboratory
fst.description: Course Description: Study of basic chemical and physical properties that influence the reactivity and functional properties of components in food systems.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FST 100A (can be concurrent).

fst.name: — Food Properties Laboratory
fst.description: Course Description: Study of properties of food described in FST 100B.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FST 100B (can be concurrent); must be taken concurrently.

fst.name: — Malting & Brewing Science
fst.description: Course Description: Technology of the malting, brewing and fermentation processes is integrated with the chemistry, biochemistry and microbiology that determine industrial practices and product quality.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 102,  BIS 103) or BIS 105; senior standing recommended.

fst.name: — Practical Malting & Brewing
fst.description: Course Description: Provides practical working knowledge of analytical methods used in malting and brewing and experience with brewing materials and processes, by analysis of samples that illustrate the range of values experienced in practice and pilot scale brewing.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FST 102A; CHE 002C.

fst.name: — Physical & Chemical Methods for Food Analysis
fst.description: Course Description: Theory and application of physical and chemical methods for determining the constituents of foods. Modern separation and instrumental analysis techniques are stressed.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 002C; CHE 008B; BIS 103; FST 100B.

fst.name: — Food Microbiology
fst.description: Course Description: Microorganisms in food safety, spoilage, and production. Food-borne disease agents and their control. Growth parameters of food spoilage agents. Destruction of microbes in food. Food fermentations. The development of microbes as a resource for the food industry.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; BIS 103.

fst.name: — Food Microbiology Laboratory
fst.description: Course Description: Cultural and morphological characteristics of microorganisms involved in food spoilage, in foodborne disease, and food fermentation. Analysis of microbiological quality of foods. May be taught abroad.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; BIS 103; FST 104.

fst.name: — Food Chemistry for Clinical Nutrition
fst.description: Course Description: Chemical and physical principles that influence functional properties, nutrient content, safety, and sensory aspects of food. Emphasis on the application of these concepts in clinical nutrition.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 008B C- or better or CHE 118B C- or better or CHE 128B C- or better; concurrent with FST 100A recommended.

fst.name: — Food Sensory Science
fst.description: Course Description: Critical examination of techniques and theories of sensory measurement of food; measures of consumer perception and acceptance. An introduction to the sensory and cognitive systems associated with the perception of food.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FST 117 (can be concurrent); (STA 013 or STA 013Y).

fst.name: — Principles of Quality Assurance in Food Processing
fst.description: Course Description: Quality assurance systems for food industry with essential measurement & analysis techniques and discussion of QA management & control programs. Regulations and audit, as well as the processes for validation and verification of quality of food systems, are emphasized.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 013 or STA 013Y.

fst.name: — Food Processing
fst.description: Course Description: Application of the conservation of mass and energy to food processing. Elements of engineering thermodynamics, fluid mechanics, heat and mass transfer. Quantitative analysis through problem solving and simulation.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 007A; PHY 007B; PHY 007C (can be concurrent); (MAT 016C or MAT 017C or MAT 021C).

fst.name: — Food Processing Laboratory
fst.description: Course Description: Laboratory exercises to gain experience with common food processing operations at the bench and pilot plant scales.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FST 110 (can be concurrent).

fst.name: — Food Law & Regulations
fst.description: Course Description: Food law and regulatory landscape of the food industry. Regulatory aspects of food safety. Major U.S. food laws and regulations including labeling, standards, misbranding, adulteration, food fraud, environmental policies, as well as international law. Laws pertaining to specific food categories including milk, dairy, meat, poultry, eggs, seafood, produce, packaged foods, and alcohol.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

fst.name: — Fermented Foods
fst.description: Course Description: Physiology, biochemistry, and genetics of microorganisms important in food fermentations. How microorganisms are used in fermentations and how raw materials are converted into finished fermented foods and beverages.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 103; MIC 102; or consent of instructor.

fst.name: — Design & Analysis for Sensory Food Science
fst.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Methods of design and analysis for sensory food science. Experimental design strategies. Use of taste panels and consumer testing. Data analysis and computation including the relative merits and limitations of parametric and nonparametic approaches. Modifications for quality assurance.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 013.

fst.name: — Chemistry & Technology of Milk & Dairy Products
fst.description: Course Description: Composition, structure and properties of milk and products derived from milk. Relates chemical, microbiological, and technological principles to commercial practices in processing of milk and its products.
