fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; BIS 102; consent of instructor.

fst.name: — Introduction to Enzymology
fst.description: Course Description: Principles of physical, chemical and catalytic properties of enzymes and their importance. Purification, characterization, and quantitative evaluation of reaction conditions on activity are stressed. Specificity and mechanism of action illustrated by use of selected enzymes. (Former course BCP 123.)
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FST 123L (can be concurrent); BIS 102; BIS 103.

fst.name: — Enzymology Laboratory
fst.description: Course Description: Laboratory procedures involved in detection, purification and characterization of enzymes. (Former course BCP 123L.)
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 103; FST 123 (can be concurrent); FST 123 required concurrently.

fst.name: — Sensory Evaluation of Foods
fst.description: Course Description: Critical examination of methods of sensory measurement applied to food and beverage systems; descriptive analysis and consumer tests and their application to quality assurance, product development and optimization.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FST 117.

fst.name: — Food Toxicology
fst.description: Course Description: Chemistry and biochemistry of toxins occurring in foods, including plant and animal toxins, intentional and unintentional food additives. The assessment of food safety and toxic hazards.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 102; BIS 103.

fst.name: — Food Packaging
fst.description: Course Description: Principles of food packaging. Functions of packaging. Properties of metal, glass, paper and plastic materials and packages. Design, fabrication, and applications of food packaging. Packaging of fresh and processed foods, including fruits and vegetables, dairy foods, beer and wine.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 008B; BIS 001B; PHY 007C.

fst.name: — Food Freezing
fst.description: Course Description: Mechanisms of ice crystallization, interpretation of freezing diagrams, and modes of heat transfer. Food properties at sub-freezing temperatures, refrigeration requirements, and estimation of freezing times. Industrial systems used in freezing foods.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FST 110A; or the equivalent.

fst.name: — New Food Product Ideas
fst.description: Course Description: Create, refine, test and present viable ideas for new food products. Activities include trend monitoring, consumer research, idea generation, concept screening, and new product concept presentations.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FST 050; BIS 002A; PHY 007A; PHY 007B; PHY 007C; CHE 002A; CHE 002B; CHE 002C.

fst.name: — Food Product Development
fst.description: Course Description: Product implementation stage of food product development including preliminary product description, prototype development, product testing, and formal presentation of a new product development.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FST 050; FST 103; FST 104; FST 110.

fst.name: — Senior Seminar
fst.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Selected topics presented by students on recent advances in food science and technology. Reports and discussions concerning oral and written presentations, literature sources and career opportunities.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Senior standing or consent of instructor.

fst.name: — Internship for Advanced Undergraduates
fst.description: Course Description: Work experience on or off campus in the practical application of food science.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

fst.name: — Directed Group Study
fst.description: Course Description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

fst.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
fst.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

fst.name: — Food Chemistry & Biochemistry
fst.description: Course Description: Advanced topics in food chemistry and biochemistry, emphasizing the application of the basic principles of chemistry and biochemistry to food composition, properties, preservation and processing. Chemical structures, interactions, reaction mechanisms and experimental methods are stressed.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Undergraduate courses in organic chemistry and biochemistry; undergraduate course in food chemistry is recommended.

fst.name: — Physical Chemistry of Foods
fst.description: Course Description: Fundamental principles of chemistry and physics are applied to a study of changes in water binding properties and activity, changes in proteins, nutrients, toxic constituents, and other compounds during storage, heating, freezing, dehydrating, and concentrating of food materials.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 107A; CHE 107B; BIS 102 recommended.

fst.name: — Food Processing
fst.description: Course Description: Principles of food engineering applied to food processing. Relationship of Newtonian and non-Newtonian fluid properties to heat and momentum transfer. Application of mass transfer in controlling kinetics and quality changes of foods.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FST 110A; PHY 007C); CHE 107B; or consent of instructor.

fst.name: — Advanced Food Microbiology
fst.description: Course Description: Principles and recent developments in food microbiology. Mechanisms of foodborne disease, pathogen detection, parameters of microbial growth and control in foods, intestinal microbiology including probiotics and prebiotics, and the microbiology of food and beverage fermentations.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Undergraduate level coursework in microbiology, or consent of instructor.

fst.name: — Industrial Microbiology
fst.description: Course Description: Use of microorganisms for producing substances such as amino acids, peptides, enzymes, antibiotics and organic acids. Emphasis on metabolic regulation of pathways leading to fermentation products, on yeast fermentations, and on genetic manipulations (including recombinant DNA techniques) of industrial microorganisms.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 001A; BIS 102; BIS 103; MIC 130A and MIC 130B or BIS 101 recommended.

fst.name: — Advanced Sensory-Instrumental Analyses
fst.description: Course Description: Basic principles of measurement of color, texture, and flavor of foods by sensory and instrumental methods. Advanced statistical analysis of relation of colorimetry, texturometry, and chemistry of volatile compounds to perception of appearance, texture, flavor.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FST 107; and consent of instructor.

fst.name: — Proteins: Functional Activities & Interactions
fst.description: Course Description: Relationships of structure of proteins to their biological functions. Structural proteins, complexing proteins, and catalytic proteins in plant and animal materials and products.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 103.

fst.name: — Lipids: Chemistry & Nutrition
fst.description: Course Description: Chemistry of lipids as it pertains to research in food and nutrition. Relations between lipid structure and their physical properties in tissues and foods. Regulation of absorption, transport, and metabolism of lipids. Implications of dietary fats and health.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 103; CHE 107B; CHE 128B.

fst.name: — Flavor Chemistry of Foods & Beverages
fst.description: Course Description: Become familiar with basic principles of flavor chemistry, analysis, and formation in fresh and processed foods. Required to read and critically evaluate flavor chemistry literature.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 008B; VEN 123; (VEN 123L or FST 103); or consent of instructor.

fst.name: — Advanced Food Sensory Science
fst.description: Course Description: Advanced study of the techniques and theory of the sensory measurement of food as an analytical tool and as a measure of consumer perception and acceptance. Advanced examination of the sensory and cognitive systems associated with the perception of food.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FST 107 (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

fst.name: — Biochemistry, Microbiology & Technology of Cheeses of the World
fst.description: Course Description: Compositional and physico-chemical aspects of milk and their implications on cheesemaking; enzymatic, microbiological and physical aspects of cheesemaking; cheese as a biological composite; designing cheese quality attributes; cheese aging. Cheese from all over the world tasted and discussed.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FST 119; (BIS 103 or FST 100A); FST 123; BIS 103; CHE 107B; CHE 128B; or consent of instructor.

fst.name: — Food Perception & the Chemical Senses
fst.description: Course Description: Examination of the anatomy and physiology of the chemical senses (taste, smell, and the trigeminal senses) and how they are involved in the perception of food and food intake.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FST 107B (can be concurrent); and consent of instructor.

fst.name: — Sustainable Food Systems
fst.description: Course Description: Environmental impacts of food systems. Methods for quantifying resource use and managing waste for food production and processing. Influence of policies, technologies, and consumer demand on advancing sustainable food systems.

fst.name: — Food & Gut Microbiota
fst.description: Course Description: Impact of specific food structures on the structure and function of the animal gut microbiota. How food is transformed by, and modulates, the gut microbiota to provide the host with nutrients and protection.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Microbiology and molecular biology undergraduate coursework or consent of instructor.

fst.name: — Design Thinking of Food
fst.description: Course Description: Tools of design thinking as applied to high-impact, food-related challenges through a multi-disciplinary team based, experiential learning process. Application of the field of food studies to the social and cultural contexts of eating habits, food systems, and the design solutions that respond to these factors. Working with stakeholders to design innovative solutions to food system challenges.

fst.name: — Seminar
fst.description: Course Description: Seminar.

fst.name: — Advanced Research Conference
fst.description: Course Description: Critical presentation and evaluation of original research by graduate students. Planning of research programs and proposals. Discussion led by individual major instructors for their research group.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

fst.name: — Advanced Food Science Seminar
fst.description: Course Description: Oral presentation of student's original research, discussion, and critical evaluation.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FST 290; completion of at least one quarter of FST 290.

fst.name: — Group Study
fst.description: Course Description: Group study.

fst.name: — Research
fst.description: Course Description: Research.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

fst.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
fst.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training.
fst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

fsm.name: — Principles of Quantity Food Production
fsm.description: Course Description: Fundamental principles of food service management, including quantity food preparation, institutional equipment, receiving and storage, service, menu planning, merchandising, and safety. Students earn food safety certification.

fsm.name: — Quantity Food Production Laboratory
fsm.description: Course Description: Laboratory experience in quantity food production and service.

fsm.name: — Food Service Systems Management
fsm.description: Course Description: Principles of quantity food production management: production schedules, portion control, financial management, layout and equipment planning, evaluation of alternative systems, and computer applications.

fsm.name: — Internship
fsm.description: Course Description: Work experience on or off campus in practical aspects of food service management, supervised by a faculty member.
fsm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; one upper division course in Food Service Management (FSM).

fsm.name: — Tutoring in Food Service Management
fsm.description: Course Description: Tutoring of students in food service management, assistance with discussion groups or laboratory sections; weekly conference with instructor in charge of course; written evaluations.
fsm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Dietetics or related major; completion of the Food Service Management (FSM) course in which tutoring is done.

fsm.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
fsm.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

for.name: — Fundamental Concepts in Forensic Science
for.description: Course Description: Overview of Forensic Science. Problem definition, strategies for problem solving, analytical tools, and professional and ethical considerations.

for.name: — Forensic Science Fundamentals-A
for.description: Course Description: Professional responsibilities and ethics, physical evidence concepts, drug chemistry and toxicology, controlled substances and analytical chemistry and instrumentation as practiced in the forensic sciences. First of three courses that, in part, covers the curriculum requirements of the Forensic Education Program Accreditation Committee (FEPAC).
for.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; enrolled in the Forensic Science Graduate Program.

for.name: — Forensic Science Fundamentals-B
for.description: Course Description: Forensic biology and DNA, microscopy and materials analysis and pattern evidence as practiced in the forensic sciences. Second in a series of three courses which covers the curriculum requirements of the Forensic Education Program Accreditation Committee (FEPAC).
for.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; enrolled in the Forensic Science Graduate Program.

for.name: — Forensic Science Fundamentals-C
for.description: Course Description: Arson and explosives, quality assurance and accreditation, the law and science interface and court testimony as practiced in the forensic sciences. Third in a series of three courses that covers the curriculum requirements of the Forensic Education Program Accreditation Committee (FEPAC).
for.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; enrolled in the Forensic Science Graduate Program.

for.name: — Microscopy & Microanalytical Methods in Forensic Science
for.description: Course Description: Introduction to optical and electron microscopy. Transmission, diffraction, reflection and absorption; polarized light and polarizing crystals; phase contrast. Radiography; image recording, SEM analysis of gunshot residues, paints, glass. EDS, XRF analysis, signal-to-noise ratios, minimum detectable levels and homogeneity.

for.name: — Advanced Spectroscopy Methods in Forensic Science
for.description: Course Description: Discuss, evaluate and interpret advanced molecular spectra/structure, Infrared Spectroscopy, such as chemical applications of spectroscopic methods, vibrational, rotational spectra; electronic spectra, photoelectron spectroscopy generated by various analytical instruments used in forensic science community.

for.name: — Forensic Toxicology
for.description: Course Description: Forensic toxicology as related to driving under the influence of drugs (DUID) investigations, detection, and evaluation through the use of standardized field sobriety tests and drug recognition protocols.

for.name: — Forensic Alcohol
for.description: Course Description: Analytical methods used in the determination and quantitation of ethanol in biological matrices commonly encountered in cases involving operating a motor vehicle.
for.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FOR 220 (can be concurrent); consent of instructor.

for.name: — Personal Identification Methods In Forensic Science
for.description: Course Description: Methods for identifying individuals from evidence collected at crime scenes, suspects or victims, crime scene examination and analytical methods used to support such investigations. Topics include forensic anthropology and odontology; latent prints; shoe prints; facial reconstruction/recognition; eyewitness identifications; biometric systems.

for.name: — Scientific Evidence & Courtroom Testimony
for.description: Course Description: Explores the relationship between science and the criminal justice system. Admissibility of scientific testimony and documentary proof during the trial, concepts of relevancy, hearsay and opinion rule, examination of expert witnesses, impact of Kelley-Fry and Daubert decisions & court testimony.

for.name: — Forensic Fire & Arson Investigation
for.description: Course Description: Principles and techniques of scientific investigation of fires and related crimes; offer peer-reviewed protocols for processing fire and explosion scenes; discuss recognition, collection, analysis of physical evidence, and describe the scientific method for decision-making in fire/arson investigation.

for.name: — Technical Writing in Forensic Science
for.description: Course Description: How to write clear, credible forensic science reports and scientific articles, that (a) serve the ends of the justice system, (b) meet their readers’ varying needs and (c) reflect well on the author.
for.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of the instructor required for all students not enrolled in the Forensic Science program.

for.name: — Analysis of Toxicants
for.description: Course Description: Principles of microanalysis of toxicants. Theoretical considerations regarding separation, detection and quantitative determination of toxicants using chemical and instrumental techniques.

for.name: — Forensic Science Analytical Instrumentation
for.description: Course Description: Methodology and instruments used for the analysis of substances of interest in the discipline of Forensic Science. Practical experience with modern instrumental techniques & methodologies used in the advanced forensic science laboratory.

for.name: — Homicide Crime Scene Investigation
for.description: Course Description: Processing and evaluating complex homicide scenes. Functions and activities of police agencies. Recognition, documentation, identification, and collection of evidence. Event sequence reconstruction. Evidence collection, preservation, report writing. Courtroom presentation.

for.name: — Forensic Computer Science Investigations
for.description: Course Description: Discuss the threats to the security of any kind of evidence that is captured, transmitted, or stored digitally and develop critical thinking and basic knowledge of computer forensic science issues in the evaluation of digital evidence.
for.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate student.

for.name: — Statistics in Forensic Science
for.description: Course Description: Statistics that are used by the forensic scientist, their limitations/applications in presenting evidential results in such areas as DNA-STR results, trace evidence correlation, fingerprint statistics, population sampling and the Bayes method.

for.name: — Population Genetics
for.description: Course Description: Principles, theories, and models of population genetics as they apply to forensic science.
for.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FOR 280; FOR 281; or consent of instructor.

for.name: — Forensic Genetics; Next Generation Techniques & Applications
for.description: Course Description: Review organization/function of the human genome, recent developments, next generation sequencing techniques including the preparation of DNA samples, principles of the new generation sequencing assay formats and biochemical reactions. Includes quality control parameter, and bioinformatic approaches.
for.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Undergraduate courses in fundamental and applied principles of: genetics, biochemistry, and molecular biology, or consent of instructor.

for.name: — Molecular Techniques
for.description: Course Description: Recombinant DNA technology and its applications.
for.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

for.name: — Forensic DNA Analysis
for.description: Course Description: Foundation in theory and practice of forensic DNA analysis; past, present, and emerging technologies; legal and quality assurance issues. DNA extraction, DNA quantitation, multiplex amplification of STR loci, capillary electrophoresis of amplified products, and analysis of STR typing data.
for.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Coursework in genetics and molecular biology.

for.name: — Principles & Practice of Forensic Serology & DNA Analysis
for.description: Course Description: Comprehensive overview of forensic serology and DNA typing techniques and technologies. Strong emphasis on real-world applications, including preservation and tracking of biological evidence, detection and identification of bodily fluids, and methods to extract, quantify, and type human DNA.
for.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (FOR 278 or ETX 278) or (FOR 280 or ETX 280); and consent of instructor, or equivalent of FOR 280/ETX 280.

for.name: — Forensic Biology
for.description: Course Description: Overview to the foundational concepts in forensic biology: chemistry and molecular biology of biological evidence, genetic basis of biological uniqueness, evolutionary basis of species differences, patterns and dynamics of evidence deterioration, and the legal/ professional considerations associated with biological evidence.

for.name: — Non-Human Forensic DNA; Theory & Casework Application
for.description: Course Description: Provides a comprehensive understanding of plant and animal forensic biology in terms of sample collection, preservation, analytical methods, and of the invaluable lines of inquiry these forensic evidence may permit.
for.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor required for all students not enrolled in the M.S. Forensics program; upper division Molecular Biology and Genetics or its equivalent.

for.name: — Survey in Forensic Science
for.description: Course Description: Analytical methods in contemporary forensic science. Clandestine laboratories in California, crime scene management, examination and analysis of human hair, forensic ballistics/trajectory reconstruction, shoe/tire print impressions, serial number restoration, forensic aspects of alcohol impairment, bloodstain pattern interpretation, microscopy of building materials, biological aspect of forensic science.

for.name: — Seminar in Forensic Science
for.description: Course Description: Students will be exposed to topical areas in Forensic Science by presentations conducted by expert guest speakers. The seminar will also serve as a medium whereby the exiting students will present the research conducted as part of their thesis requirement.

for.name: — Graduate Research Conference in Forensic Science
for.description: Course Description: Individual and/or group conference on problems, progress and techniques in forensic science and research.

for.name: — Forensic Science Research Methodology
for.description: Course Description: Introduction to identification, formulation, and solution of meaningful scientific problems encountered in the Forensic Science area including experimental design and/or theoretical analysis of new and prevailing techniques, theories and hypotheses. Students will present and defend their thesis research/journal article proposals.

for.name: — Group Study in Forensic Science
for.description: Course Description: Group study in Forensic Science.

for.name: — Research in Forensic Science
for.description: Course Description: Research in Forensic Science.

fre.name: — Elementary French
fre.description: Course Description: Introduction to French grammar and development of all language skills in a cultural context with special emphasis on communication.

fre.name: — Accelerated Intensive Elementary French
fre.description: Course Description: Introduction to French grammar and development of all language skills in a cultural context with special emphasis on communication. Special 12-week, accelerated, intensive summer session course that combines the work of FRE 001, FRE 002, and FRE 003.

fre.name: — Elementary French
fre.description: Course Description: Continuation of FRE 001.

fre.name: — Elementary French
fre.description: Course Description: Continuation of FRE 002.

fre.name: — Intermediate French
fre.description: Course Description: Review of grammar and vocabulary acquired in the elementary sequence, as well as the study of new grammatical structures and a continuing enrichment of vocabulary through oral work in class, written exercises, readings and compositions.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FRE 001A or FRE 003 or FRE 003S.

fre.name: — Intermediate French
fre.description: Course Description: Continuation of FRE 021 or FRE 021S. Review of grammar and vocabulary, as well as the study of new grammatical structures and a continuing enrichment of vocabulary.

fre.name: — Intermediate French
fre.description: Course Description: Continuation of  FRE 022 or FRE 022S. Review of grammar and vocabulary, as well as the study of new grammatical structures and a continuing enrichment of vocabulary.

fre.name: — French Film
fre.description: Course Description: Introduction to the tradition of French cinema from its invention by Méliès and the Lumière brothers through New Wave (especially the works of Truffaut and Godard) and more recent developments in French and Francophone film. Taught in English.

fre.name: — Major Works of French Literature in Translation
fre.description: Course Description: Readings in English translation of key works of French and Francophone literature from the Middle Ages to the Present. Particular attention is given to the long-standing interest of French writers in issues of social, regional, gender, sexual, and ethnic identity.

fre.name: — France & the French-Speaking World
fre.description: Course Description: Taught in English. Survey of the history and culture of France and the French-speaking world, especially Canada, the Caribbean and Africa. Study of social, historical and cultural issues that occupy the French-speaking world, with particular attention to mass media.

fre.name: — French as a World Language
fre.description: Course Description: The linguistic status of French and its function in multilingual societies and international arenas. Linguistico-political landscape of communities in Euroasia, Africa, and the Americas. Sociolinguistic concepts and emergence of French as a world language.

fre.name: — Directed Group Study
fre.description: Course Description: Directed group study.

fre.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
fre.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.

fre.name: — Composition in French
fre.description: Course Description: Instruction and practice in expository writing in French, with emphasis on organization, correct syntax, and vocabulary building.

fre.name: — Introduction to French Poetry
fre.description: Course Description: Analysis and evaluation of works representing the main types of French poetry. Study of French poetic conventions and versification.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FRE 100; or consent of instructor.

fre.name: — Introduction to French Drama
fre.description: Course Description: Analysis and evaluation of plays representing the main types of French drama, with emphasis on dramatic structure and techniques.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FRE 100; or consent of instructor.

fre.name: — Introduction to French Prose
fre.description: Course Description: Analysis and evaluation of works representing main types of French prose, with emphasis on narrative structure and techniques.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FRE 100; or consent of instructor.

fre.name: — Advanced French Grammar
fre.description: Course Description: Understanding of, and extensive practice with, various grammatical structures in French. Lexical-semantic, morphological, and syntactic analysis.

fre.name: — The Making of Modern France
fre.description: Course Description: Introduction to French culture through a historical approach to topics such as the citizen and the state (politics, justice, social security), the nation and centralization, the rise of public education, colonization, class and social relationships.

fre.name: — Pre- & Early-Modern France
fre.description: Course Description: Introduction to pre- and early-modern French culture through a historical approach to topics such as the feudal system, the rise of the monarchy, the Reformation and religious wars.

fre.name: — The Making of Modern France
fre.description: Course Description: Introduction to French culture through a historical approach to topics such as the absolute monarchy, the role of the parlements, the French revolution, and the political regimes of the 19th century.

fre.name: — Modern French Culture
fre.description: Course Description: Survey of modern French culture from the Dreyfus affair to the present day. Topics may include women and French culture, decolonialization and modernization, education, social welfare and immigration.

fre.name: — French Phonetics
fre.description: Course Description: Introduction to the sound-inventory of French and practice in phonetic transcription, with a focus on ways in which phonetic contrasts signal grammatical contrasts; spoken forms and spelling; formal differences between the "Standard" and other varieties across the French-speaking world.

fre.name: — Stylistics & Creative Composition
fre.description: Course Description: Intensive course in creative composition using a variety of techniques and literary styles, patterned on Queneau's Exercices de style. Practice in such stylistic modifications as inversion, antithesis, changes in tense, mood, tonality, etc. The writing of poetry.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FRE 100; or consent of instructor.

fre.name: — Medieval French Literature & Society
fre.description: Course Description: Social and cultural life of medieval France as studied through its representation in such literary works as La Chanson de Roland, courtly love lyric, the Arthurian romances of Chrétien de Troyes, Aucassin et Nicolette, selected fabliaux and farces.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FRE 100; or consent of instructor.

fre.name: — The French Renaissance
fre.description: Course Description: Overview of major works and writers with particular attention to the historical context of the turbulent 16th century. Writers to be read may include Rabelais, Marot, Ronsard, Du Bellay, Labé, Marguerite de Navarre, Montaigne, and D'Aubigné.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FRE 100; or consent of instructor.

fre.name: — Baroque & Preclassicism
fre.description: Course Description: Literature and intellectual culture of the period between the Renaissance and French classicism.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FRE 100; or consent of instructor.

fre.name: — The Classical Moment
fre.description: Course Description: Literature, culture, and politics in the Age of Louis XIV.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FRE 100; or consent of instructor.

fre.name: — Age of Reason & Revolution
fre.description: Course Description: Literature and philosophy of the French Enlightenment. Readings from such authors as Bayle, Fontenelle, Montesquieu, Voltaire, Rousseau and Diderot.

fre.name: — Private Lives & Public Secrets: The Early French Novel
fre.description: Course Description: History of the French roman from the Middle Ages to the Revolution with particular emphasis on the novels of the 18th century.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FRE 100; or consent of instructor.

fre.name: — The Romantic Imaginary
fre.description: Course Description: Major concepts and themes of French Romanticism, such as dream and the supernatural, impossible love, exoticism, revolution, individualism, nature, the mal du siècle, Romantic irony, the creative imagination, the cult of ruin.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FRE 100; or consent of instructor.

fre.name: — Realism, History & the Novel
fre.description: Course Description: Narrative and historical codes of French realist fiction, with emphasis on the representation of history in the realist novel, its depiction of social "realities" such as class and gender, and its relation to the historical situation of post-revolutionary society.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FRE 100; or consent of instructor.

fre.name: — From Baudelaire to Surrealism
fre.description: Course Description: Study of the main poets and poetic movements from the mid-19th to the early 20th century, including Baudelaire, the Symbolists, and the Surrealists.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FRE 100; or consent of instructor.

fre.name: — Modern French Thought
fre.description: Course Description: Overview of post-Second World War French intellectual currents from existentialism to structuralism and deconstructionism. Readings will include Sartre and de Beauvoir, Camus, Lévi-Strauss, Lacan, Barthes, Foucault, Derrida, Kristeva, Sollers, Cixous, and Irigaray.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FRE 100; or consent of instructor.

fre.name: — 20th-Century French Novel
fre.description: Course Description: Novels and theories of the novel, from Proust to the Nouveau Roman and beyond. Readings from among Gide, Sartre, de Beauvoir, Camus, Breton, Beckett, Robbe-Grillet, Sarraute, Simon, Barthes, Duras, Tournier, Perec, Modiano, Guibert, Toussaint.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FRE 100; or consent of instructor.

fre.name: — French & Francophone Film
fre.description: Course Description: French and Francophone film from the Lumière Brothers to the present. Topics may include analysis of film form and narrative, major filmmakers and filmic traditions, and film theory.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FRE 100; or consent of instructor.

fre.name: — Post-Colonial & Francophone Literature
fre.description: Course Description: Post-Independence Black African and/or Caribbean and/or North African literatures written in French. Selected topics include: identity & subjectivity, the role of the intellectual, women's voices, languages & oral literatures, cultural syncretism, theories of post-colonialism.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FRE 100; or consent of instructor.

fre.name: — French Literature & Other Arts
fre.description: Course Description: Relationship between French literature and other arts-painting, music, cinema, architecture, opera-from different periods.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FRE 100; or consent of instructor.

fre.name: — Paris: Modernity & Metropolitan Culture
fre.description: Course Description: Representation of Paris in 19th- and 20th-century texts and its importance in defining the experience and art of modernity.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FRE 100; or consent of instructor.

fre.name: — Topics in French Culture
fre.description: Course Description: In-depth study of a particular topic in French culture. Topics may include the Court of Louis XIV, the French Revolution and Immigration.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FRE 100; or consent of instructor.

fre.name: — From Page to Stage: Theatre & Theatricality
fre.description: Course Description: French theater as literature and performance.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FRE 100; or consent of instructor.

fre.name: — Gender & Politics in French Literature & Culture
fre.description: Course Description: Thematic, theoretical and political tendencies in contemporary French fiction. Barthes, Foucault, Duras, Guibert, considered in terms of their writing on identity and gender.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FRE 100; or consent of instructor.

fre.name: — Study of a Major Writer
fre.description: Course Description: Concentrated study of works of a single author.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FRE 100; or consent of instructor.

fre.name: — Selected Topics in French Literature
fre.description: Course Description: Subjects and themes such as satiric and didactic poetry of the Middle Ages, poetry of the Pléiade, theater in the 18th century, pre-romantic poetry, autobiography, literature and film, etc.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FRE 100; or consent of instructor.

fre.name: — Linguistic Study of French-Language in Context
fre.description: Course Description: Introduction to the linguistic study of modern French, with focus pragmatics - the ways in which language is modified in the context of use. Topics include politeness, formality/informality, personal stance, and intimacy/distance.

fre.name: — Linguistic Study of French: Form & Meaning
fre.description: Course Description: Introduction to the linguistic study of modern French, with focus on sentence construction and constituency, meaning and discourse functions.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FRE 100 or LIN 001 or LIN 001Y.

fre.name: — History of the French Language
fre.description: Course Description: Main periods in development of the French language, from Latin to contemporary popular aspects, with emphasis on relationship between socio-cultural patterns and evolution of the language.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FRE 100 or LIN 001 or LIN 001Y.

fre.name: — Internship
fre.description: Course Description: Practical application of the French language through work experience in government and/or business, culminating in an analytical term paper on a topic approved by the sponsoring instructor.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

fre.name: — Special Study for Honors Students
fre.description: Course Description: Guided research, under the direction of a faculty member, leading to a senior honors thesis on a topic in French literature, civilization, or language studies.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open only to French majors of senior standing who qualify for Honors Program.

fre.name: — Honors Thesis
fre.description: Course Description: Writing of an honors thesis on a topic in French literature, civilization, or language studies under the direction of a faculty member.

fre.name: — Tutoring in French
fre.description: Course Description: Tutoring in undergraduate courses including leadership in small voluntary discussion groups affiliated with departmental courses.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; consent of Chairperson.

fre.name: — Tutoring in the Community
fre.description: Course Description: Tutoring in public schools under the guidance of a regular teacher and supervision by a departmental faculty member.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; consent of Chairperson.

fre.name: — Directed Group Study
fre.description: Course Description: Directed group study.

fre.name: — Directed Group Study
fre.description: Course Description: Group study on focused topics in French literature and culture. Taught abroad.

fre.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
fre.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

fre.name: — Introduction to Graduate Study in French
fre.description: Course Description: Introduction to a range of methodologies and critical practices in the field of French Studies, including literature, culture, and linguistics. Covers basic principles of bibliographic research in the humanities.

fre.name: — History of French
fre.description: Course Description: Presentation of the main changes in the grammatical structures of French, from Latin to contemporary usage, involving textual analysis and sociolinguistic description.

fre.name: — Topics in French Civilization
fre.description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary approach to the study of French and Francophone civilization from the Middle Ages to the present. Content varies by instructor.

fre.name: — Topics in Medieval Literature
fre.description: Course Description: Study of Medieval French literature, focusing on a particular period, milieu, literary movement, genre, or theoretical approach.

fre.name: — 16th-Century Literature: The Humanists
fre.description: Course Description: French humanism in its most varied forms. Although at different times Rabelais and Montaigne will be primarily studied, other leading intellectuals and religious writers will also receive attention.

fre.name: — 17th-Century Literature: Theater
fre.description: Course Description: Works of Corneille, Racine, Molière, and minor dramatists. One or more authors may be covered.

fre.name: — 17th-Century Literature: Prose
fre.description: Course Description: Works of authors such as Pascal, Descartes, Mme de Lafayette. One or more authors may be covered.

fre.name: — 17th-Century Literature: Poetry
fre.description: Course Description: Studies of the works of one or more poets of the period.

fre.name: — 18th-Century Literature: Philosophies
fre.description: Course Description: Not a course in philosophy, but an examination of the role of philosophy in the design and context of literary works. Study of one or more authors.

fre.name: — 18th-Century Literature: Novel
fre.description: Course Description: Rise of the novel. Study of narrative experiments in the context of the philosophical climate and new literary values. May treat one or more novelists of the period.

fre.name: — 19th-Century Literature: Fiction
fre.description: Course Description: Study of the works of one or several novelists and/or short-story writers of the period.

fre.name: — 19th-Century Literature: Poetry
fre.description: Course Description: Study of the works of one or several poets of the period.

fre.name: — 20th-Century: Prose
fre.description: Course Description: Study of the works of one or several writers of the period.

fre.name: — 20th-Century: Theater
fre.description: Course Description: Study of the works of one or several dramatists of the period.

fre.name: — 20th-Century: Poetry
fre.description: Course Description: Study of the works of one or several poets of the period.

fre.name: — Studies in Narrative Fiction
fre.description: Course Description: Studies in narrative fiction.

fre.name: — Studies in Criticism
fre.description: Course Description: Studies in criticism.

fre.name: — Studies in Theater
fre.description: Course Description: Studies in the theater.

fre.name: — Studies in Poetry
fre.description: Course Description: Studies in poetry.

fre.name: — Study of a Literary Movement
fre.description: Course Description: Study of a literary movement.

fre.name: — Topics in French & Francophone Film
fre.description: Course Description: Aspects of French and Francophone film from the Lumière Brothers through the present. Topics may include a specific historical period of filmmaking, film theories and the analysis of film form and narrative, and major filmmakers and filmic traditions.

fre.name: — Francophone Literatures
fre.description: Course Description: Study of cultural productions (literature,  film, visual arts) by  Francophone peoples  such as found in North Africa, West Africa, the Caribbean, South-East Asia, the Americas, and Metropolitan France.

fre.name: — French Linguistics I
fre.description: Course Description: Theoretical approach to the forms and functions of French, with emphasis on phonology and morphology. Overview of current linguistic theories and their application to French. Offered in alternate years.

fre.name: — French Linguistics II
fre.description: Course Description: Theoretical approach to the forms and functions of French, with emphasis on syntax and semantics. Overview of current linguistic theories and their application to French. Offered in alternate years.

fre.name: — Topics in the Linguistic Study of French
fre.description: Course Description: Questions relevant to the linguistic study of French, such as language acquisition, sociolinguistics, or theoretical examination of structure. Intended for students in French Linguistics and those applying linguistic models to literature or teaching.

fre.name: — Foreign Language Learning in the Classroom
fre.description: Course Description: Overview of approaches to university-level foreign language instruction and the theoretical notions underlying current trends in classroom practices across commonly taught foreign languages.

fre.name: — Individual Study
fre.description: Course Description: Description:

fre.name: — Group Study
fre.description: Course Description: Group study.

fre.name: — Research
fre.description: Course Description: Description:

fre.name: — Dissertation Research
fre.description: Course Description: Dissertation research.

fre.name: — Teaching of a Modern Foreign Language
fre.description: Course Description: Teaching of a modern foreign language.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Senior or graduate standing; a major or minor in a modern foreign language.

fre.name: — The Teaching of French in College
fre.description: Course Description: Designed for graduate teaching assistants with emphasis on problems and procedures encountered by teachers of lower division classes at the university.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

fre.name: — The Teaching of French in College
fre.description: Course Description: Designed for graduate teaching assistants with emphasis on problems and procedures encountered by teachers of lower division classes at the university.
fre.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

fre.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
fre.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training.

frs.name: — First-Year Seminar
frs.description: Course Description: Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take more than one in any given quarter.

frs.name: — First-Year Seminar
frs.description: Course Description: Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take more than one in any given quarter.

frs.name: — First-Year Seminar
frs.description: Course Description: Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take more than one in any given quarter.

frs.name: — First-Year Seminar
frs.description: Course Description: Investigation of a special topic through shared readings, discussions, written assignments, term papers, and special activities (such as fieldwork, site visits, laboratory work, etc.). Emphasis placed upon student participation in learning. Students may take more than one First-Year Seminar, but may not take more than one in any given quarter.

fse.name: — Developing Teaching Resources
fse.description: Course Description: Development of curricular materials relevant to undergraduate science courses including complete learning outcomes, lesson plans, learning activities, assessments, data from implementation, and student or peer evaluation of material.

fse.name: — Building a Teaching Portfolio
fse.description: Course Description: Development of a professional and comprehensive teaching portfolio including a teaching philosophy statement, teaching resume/CV, cover letter, reflection on teaching and professional development experiences, sample curricular materials, student evaluations, and peer evaluation. Careers in higher education.

fse.name: — Effective Teaching of College Biology
fse.description: Course Description: Undergraduate science education pedagogy. Evidence-based practices in undergraduate science course design, structure and facilitation of classroom learning, assessment, student engagement, inclusion of diverse learners, and the use of technology in enhancing learning.

fse.name: — Scholarship of Teaching & Learning Seminar
fse.description: Course Description: Research articles on the scholarship of teaching and learning. Current trends in undergraduate level pedagogical research methods and results.

fse.name: — Teaching Practicum in the Sciences
fse.description: Course Description: Teaching practicum in a college-level science course. Planning and facilitation of class sessions in a college-level setting. Assessment of student learning under the guidance of a science faculty mentor. Teaching assignments must be approved by the instructor of record and the students' thesis advisor.

gas.name: — Internship in Gastroenterology
gas.description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in gastroenterology.
gas.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; approval of project by preceptor prior to internship.

gas.name: — Gastroenterology Clinical Clerkship
gas.description: Course Description: Work-up, manage, and follow-up new patients on active inpatient consulting service. Gastroenterology/Hepatology patients. Daily rounds with attending physician.
gas.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Completion of third-year of medical school.

gas.name: — Insights in Gastroenterology
gas.description: Course Description: To gain insight in clinical activities of Gastroenterology Division through attendance at any of the following: endoscopic procedures, ward rounds, outpatient clinic, and G.I. grand rounds.
gas.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; student in good academic standing.

gas.name: — Research
gas.description: Course Description: Part-time participation in active clinical and basic research projects. Some will involve both patient care and relevant laboratory procedures. Basic research includes liver metabolism, cancer markers, porphyrias diet and cancer, folate metabolism.
gas.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; medical student status.

gsw.name: — Introduction to Critical Gender Studies
gsw.description: Course Description: Introduction to interdisciplinary, critical gender studies.The emergence of women’s, gender and feminist studies internationally, its links to women’s movements, and its influence within the various arts, humanities and social science disciplines.

gsw.name: — Theory & History of Sexualities
gsw.description: Course Description: Key issues in the social construction, organization, and reproduction of sexualities such as the intersection of sexual identity with gender, race, ethnicity, and class, and the relation between movements for sexual liberation and the regulation of the body.

gsw.name: — Special Topics in Critical Gender Studies
gsw.description: Course Description: In-depth examination of a women and gender studies topic related to the research interest of the instructor.

gsw.name: — First Year Seminar
gsw.description: Course Description: Examination of a special topic in Gender, Sexuality, and Women's Studies through shared readings, discussions, and written assignments.

gsw.name: — Directed Group Study
gsw.description: Course Description: Directed group study.Learning Activities: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Enrollment Restrictions: Credit Limitation(s): Cross Listing: Repeat Credit: General Education: Grade Mode: Passed/Not Passed only.

gsw.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
gsw.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduate students.

gsw.name: — Colonialism
gsw.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Changing configurations of gender, class, culture and sexuality in colonial pacification and anti-colonial resistance in diverse societies.

gsw.name: — Introduction to Feminist Theory
gsw.description: Course Description: Introduction to the emergence of feminist theory and to key concepts in feminist theorizing. Examination of past and current debates over sexuality, race, identity politics, and the social construction of women's experience.

gsw.name: — Feminist Cultural Studies
gsw.description: Course Description: Histories, theories, and practices of feminist traditions within cultural studies.

gsw.name: — Science, Gender, & Social Justice
gsw.description: Course Description: Critical reading and reflection on the history and practice of Western science, scientific institutions and the changing role of science in relation to inequalities of class, race, gender and sexuality, and global struggles for equality and justice.

gsw.name: — Autobiography, Narrative, Memoir
gsw.description: Course Description: Life narrative writings by women. Transgressive voices exploring issues of race, class, sexuality, women's silence, and marginalization. Theories of autobiography, autoethnography, and memoir.

gsw.name: — Literature as Aesthetics of Resistance
gsw.description: Course Description: Literature by women and other marginal groups which embody dissent and subversion as a means of challenging the status quo to affect social transformation.

gsw.name: — Women & Islamic Discourses
gsw.description: Course Description: Introduction to debates/discourses about women and Islam. Transformations in debates/discourses in colonial and postcolonial periods in the Middle East & South Asia. Comparative study of debates/discourses on family, work, law, sexuality, religion, comportment, human rights, and feminist and religious movements.

gsw.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
gsw.description: Course Description: Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates.

gsw.name: — Feminism & Research Methodology
gsw.description: Course Description: Application of feminist epistemology and ethics in the design of graduate research.
gsw.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor;students are required to have Bachelor's Level Competency in Gender Studies.

gsw.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
gsw.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.

gmd.name: — Internship in General Medicine
gmd.description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in general medicine.
gmd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; approval of project by preceptor prior to internship.

gmd.name: — Seminars in Human Health Services Research & Clinical Epidemiology
gmd.description: Course Description: Critical review, evaluation, and discussion of research in health services and clinical epidemiology. Presentation of statistical, epidemiologic, and econometric methods. Students present their own research and critique the work of others.

gmd.name: — General Medicine Consults
gmd.description: Course Description: Supervised opportunity to see entire spectrum of medical problems encountered by a general internist. Student spends time in General Medicine Clinic and on the General Medicine Consult Service. Consultation Service is particularly concerned with medical evaluation of surgical patients.
gmd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Fourth-year medical students with consent of instructor; a general medicine clerkship.

gmd.name: — Health Care Ethics
gmd.description: Course Description: Guided independent study of issues in biomedical ethics, with discussion of readings that are based on student interests and needs. Participation in ethics rounds.

gmd.name: — Introduction to Health Care Ethics
gmd.description: Course Description: Introduction to concepts and methods of healthcare ethics. Emphasis on problems and methods.
gmd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical student in good standing.

gmd.name: — General Medicine Research
gmd.description: Course Description: Student will be involved in a clinical research problem within the areas, interest and expertise of members of Division of General Internal Medicine. Alternatively,the research effort will be directed toward investigation of a clinical problem of general medical interest.

ggg.name: — Advanced Genetic Analysis
ggg.description: Course Description: Fundamentals of genetic analysis and chromosome structure using model organisms including mutation, transmission, complementation, suppression, and enhancement as well as epigenetic phenomena at the whole organism and molecular levels.
ggg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; STA 100; or the equivalent, graduate standing.

ggg.name: — Genomics
ggg.description: Course Description: Prokaryotic and eukaryotic genomes. Experimental strategies and analytical challenges of modern genomics research and the theory and mechanics of data analysis. Structural, functional, and comparative genomics. Related issues in bioinformatics.
ggg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GGG 201A; GGG 201C; or equivalents that provide a basic understanding of genetics and molecular biology.

ggg.name: — Molecular Genetic Mechanisms in Disease
ggg.description: Course Description: Exploration of how basic mechanisms of molecular biology contribute to health and disease. Diseases related to animals, plants, and microbes will highlight fundamental concepts in the assembly, function and regulation of DNA, RNA, and protein.

ggg.name: — Quantitative & Population Genetics
ggg.description: Course Description: Basic concepts of quantitative and population genetics including gene and genotypic frequencies, multiple factor hypothesis, phenotypic and genotypic values, heritability, selection, genetic variation, the detection of quantitative trait loci and evolution in populations. Experimental and analytical methods.
ggg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GGG 201A; or consent of instructor.

ggg.name: — Molecular Genetics Laboratory
ggg.description: Course Description: Students will conduct experiments in molecular genetics laboratories. Individual research problems will emphasize experimental design, experience with methodologies, and data interpretation.
ggg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101 (can be concurrent); or the equivalent course; enrolled in Genetics Graduate Group.

ggg.name: — Concepts in Human Genetics & Genomics
ggg.description: Course Description: Human genomic organization; genetic structure of populations; positional cloning, application of linkage, association, and haplotypes; quantitative trait loci analyses; integrative genetic studies of gene expression; DNA repair mechanisms in genetic disease; mutation analyses; epigenetics; mitochondrial disease; gene manipulation and therapy.
ggg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GGG 201A; or equivalent course; GGG 201B and GGG 201C or equivalent are recommended.

ggg.name: — Genomics & Biotechnology of Plant Improvement
ggg.description: Course Description: Integration of modern biotechnology and classical plant breeding including the impact of structural, comparative and functional genomics on gene discovery, characterization and exploitation. Covers molecular markers, plant transformation, hybrid production, disease resistance, and novel output traits.

ggg.name: — Gene & Cellular Therapies
ggg.description: Course Description: Gene therapy from basic concepts to clinical applications. Topics include the human genome and genetic variation, genetic diseases, methods to manipulate gene expression, viral and non-viral delivery vectors, history and progress of gene therapy, case studies, and ethical issues.

ggg.name: — Functional Genomics: From Bench to Bedside
ggg.description: Course Description: Functional genomics (how genetic variation and epigenomics affect gene expression), with an emphasis on clinical relevance and applications. Topics include genetic variation and human disease, cancer therapeutics, and biomarker discovery.

ggg.name: — Seminar in Evolutionary, Developmental & Population Genetics
ggg.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Topics of current interest in evolutionary, population, and developmental genetics.

ggg.name: — Graduate Student Conference in Genetics
ggg.description: Course Description: Student-given seminars on topics in genetics, with critiques by instructor and peers.

ggg.name: — Seminar in History of Genetics
ggg.description: Course Description: The development of modern genetic theories beginning with Mendel.

ggg.name: — Seminar in Genomics & Epigenomics
ggg.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Topics of current interest in genomics and epigenomics.

ggg.name: — Seminar in Animal Genetics
ggg.description: Course Description: Emphasis on recent advances in the field of animal genetics, ranging from quantitative genetics to molecular biology as it relates to animals.
ggg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GGG 201A; or consent of instructor.

ggg.name: — Seminar in Human Genetics
ggg.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Topics of current interest in human genetics and genomics.

ggg.name: — Seminar in Molecular Genetics
ggg.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Topics of current interest related to the structure, modification and expression of genes.
ggg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GGG 201A; or consent of instructor.

ggg.name: — Scientific Professionalism & Integrity
ggg.description: Course Description: Review of basic skills required of contemporary scientists. Topics include scientific conduct, manuscript preparation, grant writing, seminar presentations, and time management. Emphasis on responsibilities of scientists to factually and thoughtfully communicate results.
ggg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

ggg.name: — Seminar in Plant Genetics
ggg.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Current topics in plant genetics will be examined in student-conducted seminars and discussion format. The integration of molecular, organismal and population genetics to address questions in plant biology will be emphasized.
ggg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GGG 201A; or consent of instructor.

ggg.name: — Group Study
ggg.description: Course Description: Group study of selected topics in genetics.

ggg.name: — Research
ggg.description: Course Description: Research.

ggg.name: — Methods in Teaching Genetics
ggg.description: Course Description: Practical experience in the methods and problems of teaching genetics. Includes analysis of texts and supporting material, discussion of teaching techniques, preparing for and conducting discussion or laboratory sections, formulating examinations under supervision of instructor.
ggg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

geo.name: — Research Trends in Geography
geo.description: Course Description: Major current research themes and trends in geography.

geo.name: — Geographical Concepts
geo.description: Course Description: Concepts and thematic content of the discipline, including contemporary research questions. A brief review of the history of geographic thought and practice is done at the beginning of the course.
geo.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Geography or consent of instructor.

geo.name: — Theory & Practice of Geography
geo.description: Course Description: Development, application, and philosophical background of theory in discipline of geography and geographical knowledge production. Similarities and differences in theories employed in physical and human geography and cartography. Geographic contributions to interdisciplinary theory bridging biophysical sciences, social sciences, and humanities.
geo.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

geo.name: — Quantitative Geography
geo.description: Course Description: Provides an overview of quantitative approaches in spatial data analysis. Overview of different approaches used for inference, modeling, and prediction. Also learn how to write computer programs to implement these methods.

geo.name: — Socio-Spatial Analysis in Geography
geo.description: Course Description: Introduction to methodologies of socio-spatial analysis in interviews, and ethnographic fieldwork. Students develop a critical understanding of different methodological and theoretical approaches, and their appropriate applications in overall research design.

geo.name: — Advanced Research Design in Geography
geo.description: Course Description: Helps Ph.D. students develop their research question, design their research plan and complete a full dissertation research proposal.
geo.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEO 200AN; GEO 200BN; GEO 200CN; GEO 200DN; graduate standing.

geo.name: — Sources & General Literature of Geography
geo.description: Course Description: Designed for students preparing for higher degrees in geography.
geo.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Graduate standing in geography.

geo.name: — Topics in Biogeography
geo.description: Course Description: Current topics in historical and ecological biogeography, including macroecology and areography, GIS and remote sensing, phylogeography, vegetation, plant and animal community and species geography. Systematics, climate change, and conservation will be addressed.
geo.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EVE 147 or WFC 156 (can be concurrent); or equivalent.

geo.name: — Physical Geography Traditions & Methods
geo.description: Course Description: Discussion of the physical science tradition in geography, including key concepts and current research in climatology, geomorphology, soils geography, biogeography, climate change, watershed science, and coastal studies. Research paradigms,  programs, and methods as used by physical geographers will be discussed.
geo.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Introductory course in physical geography.

geo.name: — Water Resource Management
geo.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Engineering, institutional, economic, and social basis for managing local and regional water resources. Examples in the context of California's water development and management. Uses of computer modeling to improve water management.
geo.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEO 114; GEO 141; GEO; 142; GEO 153 recommended.

geo.name: — Seminar in Geographical Ecology
geo.description: Course Description: Recent developments in theoretical and experimental biogeography, historical biogeography and related themes in systematics, the biology of colonizing species, and related topics.
geo.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EVE 100 or EVE 101; or consent of instructor.

geo.name: — What is Infrastructure; Critical Infrastructure Studies
geo.description: Course Description: Introduction to interdisciplinary scholarship and design on expanding conceptions of infrastructure, that include social, technical, ecological, political and aesthetic dimensions of the medium. Focus on application of theory to case studies and thinking through landscape as infrastructure.

geo.name: — Topics in Human Geography
geo.description: Course Description: Examination of philosophy and theory in human geography with an emphasis on contemporary debates and concepts in social, cultural, humanistic, political, and economic geographies. Specific discussion of space, place, scale and landscape; material and imagined geographies.
geo.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

geo.name: — Citizenship, Democracy, & Public Space
geo.description: Course Description: Introduction to seminal works in political theory, philosophy, and the social sciences that focus on citizenship and the public sphere; development of critical perspective regarding restructuring of public space in a pluralistic and global culture; discussion of contemporary case studies.
geo.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

geo.name: — Urban Planning & Design
geo.description: Course Description: Regulation, design, and development of the built landscape, planning and land development processes, zoning and subdivision regulation, site planning, urban design goals and methods, public participation strategies, creatively designing landscapes to meet community and ecological goals.

geo.name: — Transportation Planning & Policy
geo.description: Course Description: Transportation planning process at the regional level, including the role of federal policy in shaping regional transportation planning, tools and techniques used in regional transportation planning, issues facing regional transportation planning agencies, pros and cons of potential solutions and strategies.

geo.name: — Community Development Theory
geo.description: Course Description: Introduction to theories of community development and different concepts of community, poverty, and development. Emphasis on building theory, linking applied development techniques to theory, evaluating development policy, and examining case studies of community development organizations and projects.

geo.name: — The Economics of Community Development
geo.description: Course Description: Economic theories and methods of planning for communities. Human resources, community services and infrastructure, industrialization and technological change, and regional growth. The community's role in the greater economy.
geo.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

geo.name: — The Political Economy of Urban & Regional Development
geo.description: Course Description: How global, political and economic restructuring and national and state policies are mediated by community politics; social production of urban form; role of the state in uneven development; dynamics of urban growth and decline; regional development in California.
geo.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CRD 157; CRD 244; or the equivalent.

geo.name: — The Political Economy of Transnational Migration
geo.description: Course Description: Theoretical perspectives and empirical research on social, cultural, political, and economic processes of transnational migration to the U.S. Discussion of conventional theories will precede contemporary comparative perspectives on class, race, ethnicity, citizenship, and the ethnic economy.
geo.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

geo.name: — Social Policy, Welfare Theories & Communities
geo.description: Course Description: Theories and comparative histories of modern welfare states and social policy in relation to legal/normative, organizational, and administrative aspects. Analysis of specific social issues within the U.S./California context.
geo.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

geo.name: — Political Ecology of Community Development
geo.description: Course Description: Community development from the perspective of geographical political ecology. Social and environmental outcomes of the dynamic relationship between communities and land-based resources, and between social groups. Cases of community conservation and development in developing and industrialized countries.
geo.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

geo.name: — Global Political Ecology
geo.description: Course Description: Background, genesis, current debates in political ecology. Examination of political-economic and social-cultural causes of environmental change. Introduction to development theory, globalization, history of science and power/knowledge. Cases of social movements, justice, resistance, gender, race and class. Focus outside North America.

geo.name: — Exploring Data from Built Environment Using R
geo.description: Course Description: Introduction to modern data science, specifically data acquisition, exploratory data, visualization, and beginning data analysis using R. Emphasizes computational reasoning and working with tabular and non-standard data. Focus will be on data generated in the built environment.

geo.name: — Field Studies in Geography
geo.description: Course Description: A topic or sub-discipline of geography forms the theme for the course in any given offering, with a focus on current research on this topic, field methodologies, and data analysis in human and physical geography.
geo.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; undergraduate or graduate coursework in geography.

geo.name: — Transportation Survey Methods
geo.description: Course Description: Description of types of surveys commonly used in transportation demand modeling, including travel and activity diaries, attitudinal, panel, computer, and stated-response surveys. Discussion of sampling, experimental design, and survey design issues. Analysis methods, including factor, discriminant and cluster analysis.
geo.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (STA 013 or STA 013Y); ECI 251 recommended.

geo.name: — Selected Topics in Environmental Remote Sensing
geo.description: Course Description: In depth investigation of advanced topics in remote sensing applications, measurements, and theory.
geo.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ERS 186; and consent of instructor, or equivalent required; ERS 186L recommended.

geo.name: — Seminar in Geography
geo.description: Course Description: Seminar focuses on specified topical areas within geography, which will vary quarter to quarter. Students expected to present an oral seminar on an aspect of the general topic under discussion.
geo.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

geo.name: — Seminar in Cultural Geography
geo.description: Course Description: Seminar in cultural geography.

geo.name: — Graduate Internship
geo.description: Course Description: Individually designed, supervised internship, off campus, in community or institutional setting. Developed with advice of faculty mentor.
geo.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

geo.name: — Seminar in Urban Geography
geo.description: Course Description: Seminar in urban geography.

geo.name: — Graduate Group in Geography
geo.description: Course Description: Seminars by UC Davis faculty and prominent national and international scholars; research presentations by Graduate Group in Geography Ph.D. candidates.
geo.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

geo.name: — Group Study
geo.description: Course Description: Group study.
geo.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

geo.name: — Research
geo.description: Course Description: Research.

geo.name: — Individual Study
geo.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Individual study.
geo.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate student status in Geography.

gel.name: — The Earth
gel.description: Course Description: Introduction to the study of the Earth. Earth's physical and chemical structure; internal and surface processes that mold the Earth; geological hazards and resources.

gel.name: — Earth System Science
gel.description: Course Description: Solid and fluid earth and its place in the solar system. How the solid earth interacts with the atmosphere, hydrosphere, biosphere, and extraterrestrial environment.

gel.name: — Earth System Science Discussion
gel.description: Course Description: Small group discussion and preparation of short papers for GEL 002.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 002 (can be concurrent); GEL 002 required concurrently.

gel.name: — History of Life
gel.description: Course Description: The history of life during the three and onehalf billion years from its origin to the present day. Origin of life and processes of evolution; how to visualize and understand living organisms from their fossil remains.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 001 recommended.

gel.name: — History of Life: Discussion
gel.description: Course Description: Small group discussion and preparation of short papers for GEL 003. GE credit with concurrent enrollment in GEL 003: WE.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 003 (can be concurrent); GEL 003 required concurrently.

gel.name: — History of Life Laboratory
gel.description: Course Description: Exercises in understanding fossils as the clues to interpreting ancient life, including their functional morphology, paleoecology, and evolution.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 003 (can be concurrent); GEL 003 required concurrently.

gel.name: — Evolution: Science & World View
gel.description: Course Description: Introduction to biological evolution. Emphasis on historical development, major lines of evidence and causes of evolution; relationships between evolution and Earth history; the impact of evolutionary thought on other disciplines.

gel.name: — Geology Field Experience
gel.description: Course Description: Exposure to geologic features and earth processes in the field. Experiential instruction in earth-science concepts, spatial visualization, landscape evolution, deep time, critical thinking skills, and integrative scientific themes. One 4-5 day field trip.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; at least one previous GEL class, or concurrent enrollment.

gel.name: — Modern & Ancient Global Environmental Change
gel.description: Course Description: Fundamental scientific concepts underlying issues such as global warming, pollution, and the future of nonsustainable resources presented in the context of anthropogenic processes as well as natural forcing of paleoenvironmental change throughout Earth's history.

gel.name: — Evolution & Paleobiology of Dinosaurs
gel.description: Course Description: Introduction to evolutionary biology, paleobiology, ecology and paleoecology, using dinosaurs as case studies.

gel.name: — The Oceans
gel.description: Course Description: Introductory survey of the marine environment. Oceanic physical phenomena, chemical constituents and chemistry of water, geological history, the seas biota and human utilization of marine resources.

gel.name: — The Oceans: Discussion
gel.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Scientific method applied to discovery of the processes, biota and history of the oceans. Group discussion and preparation of term paper.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 016 (can be concurrent).

gel.name: — The Oceans
gel.description: Course Description: Introductory survey of the marine environment. Oceanic physical phenomena, chemical constituents and chemistry of water, geological history, the seas biota and human utilization of marine resources.

gel.name: — Earthquakes & Other Earth Hazards
gel.description: Course Description: Impact of earthquakes, tsunami, volcanoes, landslides, and floods on humans, structures, and the environment. Discussion of the causes and effects of disasters and catastrophes, and on prediction, preparation, and mitigation of natural hazards.

gel.name: — Energy & the Environment
gel.description: Course Description: Conventional and alternative energy resources and their environmental impacts. Basic principles, historical development, current advantages and disadvantages, future prospects. Oil, natural gas, coal, nuclear, wind, geothermal, water, tidal, solar, hydrogen, and other sources of energy for the 21st century.

gel.name: — Energy & the Environment
