gel.description: Course Description: Conventional and alternative energy resources and their environmental impacts. Basic principles, historical development, current advantages and disadvantages, future prospects. Oil, natural gas, coal, nuclear, wind, geothermal, water, tidal, solar, hydrogen, and other sources of energy for the 21st century.

gel.name: — Geology of California
gel.description: Course Description: The geologic history of California, the origin of rocks and the environments in which they were formed, the structure of the rocks and the interpretation of their structural history, mineral resources, and appreciation of the California landscape. Offered in alternate years.

gel.name: — Geology of National Parks
gel.description: Course Description: Appreciation of the geologic framework underlying the inherent beauty of U.S. National Parks. Relationship of individual parks to geologic processes such as mountain building, volcanism, stream erosion, glacial action and landscape evolution.

gel.name: — Geology of National Parks
gel.description: Course Description: Appreciation of the geologic framework underlying the inherent beauty of U.S. National Parks. Relationship of individual parks to geologic processes such as mountain building, volcanism, stream erosion, glacial action and landscape evolution.

gel.name: — Astrobiology
gel.description: Course Description: Origin, evolution and distribution of life in our solar system and the Universe. Detecting habitable worlds, Drake equations, necessities and raw materials for life, philosophical implications of the search for life elsewhere.

gel.name: — Fractals, Chaos & Complexity
gel.description: Course Description: Modern ideas about the unifying ideas of fractal geometry, chaos and complexity. Basic theory and applications with examples from physics, earth sciences, mathematics, population dynamics, ecology, history, economics, biology, computer science, art and architecture. Offered in alternate years.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 016A or MAT 017A or MAT 021A.

gel.name: — Volcanoes
gel.description: Course Description: Role of eruptions, and eruptive products of volcanoes in shaping the planet's surface, influencing its environment, and providing essential human resources.

gel.name: — Rivers
gel.description: Course Description: Introduction to geomorphology, climate and geology of rivers and watersheds, with case examples from California. Assessment of impacts of logging, agriculture, mining, urbanization and water supply on river processes. Optional river field trips.

gel.name: — The Solar System
gel.description: Course Description: Nature of the sun, moon, and planets as determined by recent manned and unmanned exploration of the solar system. Comparison of terrestrial, lunar, and planetary geological processes. Search for life on other planets. Origin and evolution of the solar system. (Former course GEL 113 & GEL 113G.)

gel.name: — Physical Geology
gel.description: Course Description: The Earth, its materials, its internal and external processes, its development through time by sea-floor spreading and global plate tectonics.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): High school physics and chemistry.

gel.name: — Physical Geology Laboratory
gel.description: Course Description: Introduction to classification and recognition of minerals and rocks and to interpretation of topographic and geologic maps and aerial photographs.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 050 (can be concurrent).

gel.name: — Introduction to Geobiology
gel.description: Course Description: Introduction to interactions between Earth and life with an emphasis on how metabolism, cellular processes, evolution and ecology emerged within natural environments and have changed Earth’s surface.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 001 or GEL 002 or GEL 050.

gel.name: — Introduction to Geochemistry
gel.description: Course Description: Introduction to key geochemical principles in Earth & Planetary Sciences; chemical bonding, geochemical affinity of elements, redox & acid base equilibria in geological systems, radioactive decay, isotopic fractionation and paleoclimate records.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (GEL 001 or GEL 002 or GEL 050); (CHE 002A or CHE 002AH); (CHE 002B or CHE 002BH).

gel.name: — Introduction to Geophysics
gel.description: Course Description: Introduction to geophysical topics essential to all aspects of Earth and planetary sciences: theory of plate tectonics, gravitational field of planets, diffusion, rheology, seismology, and earthquakes.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (GEL 001 or GEL 050); (PHY 007A or PHY 009A); (PHY 007B or PHY 009B).

gel.name: — Earth Materials: Introduction
gel.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Physical and chemical properties of Earth materials; structure, chemical composition, and identification of rock-forming minerals; mineral-rock associations, and their origin from silicate liquids, aqueous fluids, and solid state transformations.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (CHE 002A or CHE 002AH); (MAT 016A or MAT 017A or MAT 021A); (GEL 001 or GEL 050); GEL 050L.

gel.name: — Optical Mineralogy
gel.description: Course Description: Optical properties of inorganic crystals; techniques of mineral identification using the polarizing microscope; strategies for studying rocks in thin section.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 060 (can be concurrent).

gel.name: — Learning in Science & Mathematics
gel.description: Course Description: Exploration of how students learn and develop understanding in science and mathematics classrooms. Introduction to case studies and interview techniques and their use in K-6 classrooms to illuminate factors that affect student learning.

gel.name: — Internship
gel.description: Course Description: Work-learn experience on and off campus in all subject areas offered by the department. Internships supervised by a member of the faculty.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

gel.name: — Directed Group Study
gel.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
gel.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

gel.name: — Structural Geology
gel.description: Course Description: Study of processes and products of rock deformation. Introduction to structural geology through a survey of the features and geometries of faults and folds, techniques of strain analysis, and continuum mechanics of rock deformation.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 050; GEL 050L; (PHY 007A or PHY 009A); (MAT 016A or MAT 017A or MAT 021A); consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Structural Geology Lab
gel.description: Course Description: Laboratory study of the processes and products of rock deformation. Introduction to the practice of structural geology through observations and analysis of rock deformation, including field measurement techniques and geologic mapping.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 050; GEL 050L; (PHY 007A or PHY 009A); GEL 101 (can be concurrent); consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Field Geology
gel.description: Course Description: Field mapping projects and writing geological reports. Weekly classroom meetings devoted to preparation of maps, cross sections, stratigraphic sections, rock descriptions, and reports. Seven-eight days for field trips will occur on weekends during the quarter.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 101; GEL 101L.

gel.name: — Earth Materials: Igneous Rocks
gel.description: Course Description: Origin and occurrence of igneous rocks. Laboratory exercises emphasize the study of these rocks in hand specimen and thin section.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 060; (MAT 016A or MAT 017A or MAT 021A); CHE 002B (can be concurrent).

gel.name: — Earth Materials: Metamorphic Rocks
gel.description: Course Description: Physical and chemical properties of metamorphic rocks; interpretation of metamorphic environments. Laboratory exercises emphasize the study of these rocks in hand specimen and thin section.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 105.

gel.name: — Earth History: Paleobiology
gel.description: Course Description: Evolution and ecological structure of the biosphere from the origin of life to the present.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 003 or GEL 053 or BIS 002A or BIS 002B.

gel.name: — Earth History: Paleobiology Laboratory
gel.description: Course Description: Exercises in determining the ecological functions and evolution of individuals, populations, and communities of fossil organisms in field and laboratory.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 107 (can be concurrent).

gel.name: — Earth History: Paleoclimates
gel.description: Course Description: Geological and environmental factors controlling climate change, the greenhouse effect with a detailed analysis of the history of Earth's climate fluctuations over the last 600 million years. Past and present climate records are used to examine potential future climatic scenarios.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (GEL 001 or GEL 050 or GEL 116N or ESP 116N); CHE 002A; consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Earth History: Sediments & Strata
gel.description: Course Description: Sediment formation, transport, and deposition. Interpretations of sedimentary processes across landscapes and through time in the context of environmental and geological problems. Reconstruction of ancient environmental change from sedimentary rocks.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 001 or GEL 050.

gel.name: — Earth History: Sediments & Strata Laboratory
gel.description: Course Description: Methods of stratigraphic and sedimentologic analysis of modern and ancient sediments. Identification of major sediment and sedimentary rock types. Outcrop and subsurface analysis of sedimentary basins. GE credit with concurrent enrollment in GEL 109. Includes four one-day field trips.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 050L; GEL 109 (can be concurrent).

gel.name: — Summer Field Geology: Structures & Neotectonics
gel.description: Course Description: Advanced application of geologic field methods to the study of deformed rocks and their interpretation in terms of tectonic processes. Includes development and interpretation of geologic maps, cross sections and stratigraphic sections. Six days/week for three weeks in an off-campus location.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 060; GEL 103; GEL 109.

gel.name: — Summer Field Geology: Volcanology
gel.description: Course Description: Advanced application of geologic field methods to the study of volcanic and plutonic rocks and their interpretation in terms of igneous processes. Includes development and interpretation of geologic maps, cross sections, stratigraphic sections, and outcrop scale observations. Six days/week for three weeks in an off-campus location.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 105; GEL 109.

gel.name: — Summer Field Geology: Special Projects
gel.description: Course Description: Advanced application of geologic field methods to a special project location and the interpretation of field observations in terms of its geologic processes and geologic history. Variable field location and specific activities. Six days/week for three weeks in an off-campus location.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Earth Science, History, & People
gel.description: Course Description: Study of interplay between the Earth and its human inhabitants through history, including consideration of acute events such as earthquakes and eruptions as well as the geology of resources, topography, and water.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 001 or GEL 050.

gel.name: — Oceanography
gel.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Advanced oceanographic topics: Chemical, physical, geological, and biological processes; research methods and data analysis; marine resources, anthropogenic impacts, and climate change; integrated earth/ocean/atmosphere systems; weekly lab and one weekend field trip.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 001 or GEL 002 or GEL 016 or GEL 050.

gel.name: — Origins: From the Big Bang to Today
gel.description: Course Description: Long-term and large-scale perspectives on the origins of the universe, stars and planets, life, human evolution, the rise of civilization and the modern world. Multi-disciplinary approach to "Big History" involving cosmology, astronomy, geology, climatology, biology, anthropology, archeology and traditional history.

gel.name: — Non-Renewable Natural Resources
gel.description: Course Description: Origin, occurrence, and distribution of non-renewable resources, including metallic, nonmetallic, and energy-producing materials. Problems of discovery, production, and management. Estimations and limitations of reserves, and their sociological, political, and economic effects.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 001 or GEL 050.

gel.name: — Risk: Natural Hazards & Related Phenomena
gel.description: Course Description: Risk, prediction, prevention and response for earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, landslides, floods, storms, fires, impacts, global warming.

gel.name: — Introductory Inorganic Geochemistry
gel.description: Course Description: Nucleosynthesis of chemical elements, physical and chemical properties of elements, ionic substitution, elemental partition, distribution and transport among planetary materials, basic thermodynamics and phase diagrams, isotopic geochronometers, stable isotope fractionation, mixing and dilution, advection and diffusion, geochemical cycles.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 060 (can be concurrent); CHE 002B.

gel.name: — Environmental Geochemistry
gel.description: Course Description: Introduction to Earth surface processes with a focus on topics of current environmental interest such as nuclear power and waste disposal, acid mine drainage, carbon sequestration, history of polar ice sheets and sea level change.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 002A; CHE 002B.

gel.name: — Environmental Geology & Land Use Planning
gel.description: Course Description: Geologic aspects of land use and development planning. Geologic problems concerning volcanic and earthquake hazards, land stability, floods, erosion, coastal hazards, non-renewable resource extraction, waste disposal, water resources.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 001 or GEL 050; consent of instructor.; one course in Geology (GEL).

gel.name: — Ecogeomorphology of Rivers & Streams
gel.description: Course Description: Integrative multidisciplinary field analysis of streams. Class project examines hydrology, geomorphology, water quality and aquatic and riparian ecology of degraded and pristine stream systems. Includes cooperative two-week field survey in remote wilderness settings with students from diverse scientific backgrounds.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Upper division or graduate standing in any physical science, biological science, or engineering.

gel.name: — Introductory Volcanology
gel.description: Course Description: Principles of physical and chemical volcanology. Taught in a volcanically active setting (e.g., Hawaii) with a strong field component.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 060; GEL 109; consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Rivers: Form, Function & Management
gel.description: Course Description: Analysis of river form and processes, emphasis on fluvial geomorphology, and river and stream restoration; case studies to illustrate concepts and applications. Two weekend field trips required. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 050 or GEL 050L; MAT 016B or MAT 017B or MAT 021B recommended.

gel.name: — Introduction to Process Geomorphology
gel.description: Course Description: Quantitative description and interpretation of landscapes with emphasis on the relationships between physical processes, mass conservation, and landform evolution. Topics covered include physical & chemical weathering, hillslopes, debris flows, fluvial systems, alluvial fans, pedogenesis, eolian transport, glaciation and Quaternary geochronology.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (GEL 001 or GEL 050); (MAT 016B or MAT 017B or MAT 021B).

gel.name: — Evolutionary History of Vertebrates
gel.description: Course Description: Evolutionary history of vertebrates; fossil record and phylogeny; timing of major evolutionary events; appearance of major vertebrate groups; physical constraints in vertebrate evolution; paleobiogeography of vertebrates; effect of continental movement on vertebrate evolution; dinosaurs and other strange vertebrates. Offered in alternate years.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 003 or GEL 053 or BIS 002A.

gel.name: — Evolutionary History of Vertebrates Laboratory
gel.description: Course Description: Augments lecture GEL 141 through handling of specimens enabling in-person examination of three dimensional features observed in vertebrate skeletons, both fossil and living. Offered in alternate years.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 141 (can be concurrent).

gel.name: — Basin Analysis
gel.description: Course Description: Analysis of sedimentary basins from initiation to maturity, including controls on sedimentary fill, subsidence analysis, sequence stratigraphy, core logs, and applications to petroleum exploration and hydrology. One two-day field trip. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 050; GEL 050L; GEL 109.

gel.name: — Advanced Igneous Petrology
gel.description: Course Description: Physical and chemical properties of magmatic environments and processes of igneous rock formation. Laboratory study of representative igneous rocks. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 105; (MAT 016C or MAT 017C or MAT 021C); (CHE 002C or GEL 055).

gel.name: — Historical Ecology
gel.description: Course Description: Ancient ecosystems and the factors that caused them to change. Species, expansion, evolution of new modes of life, geologically induced variations in resource supply, and extinction provide historical perspective on the biosphere of future.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division course in environmental science or ecology, or an introductory course in paleobiology.

gel.name: — Advanced Metamorphic Petrology
gel.description: Course Description: Metamorphic processes and the origin of metamorphic rocks. Laboratory study of representative rock suites. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 106; (HYD 134 or CHE 002C or GEL 055); (MAT 016C or MAT 017C or MAT 021C).

gel.name: — Radiogenic Isotope Geochemistry & Cosmochemistry
gel.description: Course Description: Basic principles of nuclear chemistry and physics applied to geology to determine the ages of terrestrial rocks, meteorites, archeological objects, age of the Earth, to trace geological/environmental processes, and explain formation of the chemical elements in the Universe. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (CHE 002C or GEL 055); (PHY 007C or PHY 009C or GEL 056); (MAT 016C or MAT 017C or MAT 021C).

gel.name: — Geology of Ore Deposits
gel.description: Course Description: Tectonic, lithologic and geochemical setting of major metallic ore deposit types emphasizing ore deposit genesis, water/rock interaction and the environmental effects of mining. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (CHE 002C or GEL 055 or HYD 134); GEL 060; GEL 105.

gel.name: — Stable Isotopes & Geochemical Tracers
gel.description: Course Description: Use of oxygen and hydrogen isotopes in defining hydrologic processes; carbon, nitrogen, and sulfur isotopes as indicators of exchange between the lithosphere, hydrosphere, atmosphere and biosphere. Radiogenic, cosmogenic, and noble gas isotope tracers. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (CHE 002C or GEL 055 or HYD 134); GEL 050; GEL 050L; GEL 060.

gel.name: — Geothermal Systems
gel.description: Course Description: Geology, geochemistry, and geophysics of geothermal systems, including electrical power generation and direct use applications. Includes one day field trip on a weekend during the quarter. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 050; GEL 050L; CHE 002B.

gel.name: — Physical & Chemical Oceanography
gel.description: Course Description: Physical and chemical properties of seawater, fluid dynamics, air-sea interaction, currents, waves, tides, mixing, major oceanic geochemical cycles.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ESP 116N or GEL 116N); (PHY 007B or PHY 009B); (MAT 016C or MAT 017C or MAT 021C); (CHE 002C or GEL 055); consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Geological Oceanography
gel.description: Course Description: Introduction to the origin and geologic evolution of ocean basins. Composition and structure of oceanic crust; marine volcanism; and deposition of marine sediments. Interpretation of geologic history of the ocean floor in terms of sea-floor spreading theory.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 050 or (GEL 116N or ESP 116N).

gel.name: — Biological Oceanography
gel.description: Course Description: Ecology of major marine habitats, including intertidal, shelf benthic, deep-sea and plankton communities. Existing knowledge and contemporary issues in research. Segment devoted to human use. One weekend field trip required.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; consent of instructor; a course in general ecology.

gel.name: — Paleobiology of Protista
gel.description: Course Description: Morphology, systematics, evolution, and ecology of single-celled organisms that are preserved in the fossil record. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 107 or BIS 002A; consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Hydrogeology & Contaminant Transport
gel.description: Course Description: Physical and chemical processes affecting groundwater flow and contaminant transport, with emphasis on realistic hydrogeologic systems. Groundwater geology and chemistry. Fundamentals of groundwater flow and transport analysis. Laboratory includes field pumping test and work with physical and computer models.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HYD 144 or ECI 144; or the equivalent.

gel.name: — Geological Data Analysis
gel.description: Course Description: Introduction to quantitative methods in analyzing geological data including basic principles of statistics and probability, error analysis, hypothesis testing, inverse theory, time series analysis and directional data analyses.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MAT 016A (can be concurrent) or MAT 017A (can be concurrent) or MAT 021A (can be concurrent)); GEL 056; or prior introductory level programming in Python, Matlab, or R.

gel.name: — Geophysical Field Methods
gel.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Geophysical methods applied to determining subsurface structure in tectonics, hydrogeology, geotechnical engineering, hydrocarbon and mineral exploration. Theory, survey design & interpretation of gravity, electrical resistivity, electromagnetic, reflection & refraction seismology, and ground-penetrating radar measurements.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (GEL 001 or GEL 050); (MAT 016C or MAT 017C or MAT 021C); (GEL 056 or PHY 007C or PHY 009C).

gel.name: — Geophysics of the Solid Earth
gel.description: Course Description: Theory and use of physics in the study of the solid earth. Gravity, magnetism, paleomagnetism, and heat flow. Application to the interpretation of the regional and large-scale structure of the earth and to plate tectonics. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MAT 016C or MAT 017C or MAT 021C); (GEL 056 or PHY 007C or PHY 009C).

gel.name: — Planetary Geology & Geophysics
gel.description: Course Description: Principles of planetary science. Planetary dynamics, including orbital mechanics, tidal interactions and ring dynamics. Theory of planetary interiors, gravitational fields, rotational dynamics. Physics of planetary atmospheres. Geological processes, landforms and their modification. Methods of analysis from Earth-based observations and spacecraft.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (GEL 001 or GEL 002 or GEL 028 or GEL 036 or GEL 050 or AST 010G or AST 010L or AST 010S or AST 025); (MAT 016A or MAT 017A or MAT 021A); (GEL 056 or PHY 007C or PHY 009C).

gel.name: —  Advanced Field Geology
gel.description: Course Description: Advanced field studies of selected geologic terrains, interpretation and discussion of field observations. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Teaching in Science & Mathematics
gel.description: Course Description: Exploration of effective teaching practices based on examination of how middle school students learn math and science. Selected readings, discussion and field experience in middle school classrooms.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; major in mathematics, science, or engineering; or completion of a one-year sequence of science or calculus.

gel.name: — Field Studies in Marine Geochemistry
gel.description: Course Description: Marine geochemistry with the opportunity of going to sea or into the field on land. Techniques of sea-floor mapping using bottom photography, marine geochemical sampling, and method of data reduction and sample analysis. Analysis of data/samples collected. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Teaching High School Mathematics & Science
gel.description: Course Description: Exploration and creation of effective teaching practices based on examination of how high school students learn mathematics and science. Field experience in high school classrooms.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Major in mathematics, science, or engineering; or completion of a one-year sequence of science or calculus and consent of the instructor.

gel.name: — Conceptual Integrated Science for Non-Science Majors: The Physical World
gel.description: Course Description: Conceptual, inquiry-based integrated science course. Topics in the Next Generation Science Standards. Elementary school level teaching practice. Physics, chemistry, and science inquiry.

gel.name: — Conceptual Integrated Science for Non-Science Majors: Earth System Science
gel.description: Course Description: Conceptual, inquiry-based integrated science course. Topics in the Next Generation Science Standards. Elementary school level teaching practice. Earth, space and environmental science, and science inquiry.

gel.name: — Facilitating Learning in STEM Classrooms
gel.description: Course Description: STEM Learning Assistant Seminar. Theoretical and practical issues of effective teaching in discussion/labs: student-centered, active, cooperative learning environments, responsive teaching, and differentiated classroom instruction.

gel.name: — Seminar in Geology
gel.description: Course Description: Presentation and discussion of current topics in geology by visiting lecturers, staff, and students. Written abstracts.

gel.name: — Internship in Geology
gel.description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in geology.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; project approval prior to internship.

gel.name: — Senior Thesis
gel.description: Course Description: Guided independent study of a selected topic, leading to the writing of a senior thesis.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open to Geology majors who have completed 135 units and who do not qualify for the Honors Program.

gel.name: — Senior Thesis
gel.description: Course Description: Guided independent study of a selected topic, leading to the writing of a senior thesis.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open to Geology majors who have completed 135 units and who do not qualify for the Honors Program.

gel.name: — Senior Honors Project
gel.description: Course Description: Guided independent study of a selected topic, leading to the writing of an honors thesis.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open to Geology majors who have completed 135 units and who qualify for the Honors Program.

gel.name: — Senior Honors Project
gel.description: Course Description: Guided independent study of a selected topic, leading to the writing of an honors thesis.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open to Geology majors who have completed 135 units and who qualify for the Honors Program.

gel.name: — Directed Group Study
gel.description: Course Description: Group study focused on topics in Geology.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Senior standing in Geology or consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
gel.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

gel.name: — Advanced Field Stratigraphy
gel.description: Course Description: Fieldwork over spring break. Application of stratigraphic techniques to research problems. Collection, compilation, and interpretation of field data. Integration of data with models for deposition and interpretations of Earth history. Topics will vary. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 109; GEL 110; or consent of instructor; GEL 206 recommended.

gel.name: — Stratigraphic Analysis
gel.description: Course Description: Topics in advanced methods of stratigraphic analysis, regional stratigraphy and sedimentation, and sedimentary basin analysis. Emphasis on techniques used to interpret stratigraphic record and on current issues in stratigraphy and sedimentation. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 109; GEL 109L; or consent of instructor; GEL 144 recommended.

gel.name: — Active Tectonics
gel.description: Course Description: Active deformation associated with faults, landslides, and volcanoes. Geodetic measurement techniques such as triangulation, trilateration, leveling, Global Positioning System (GPS), and radar interferometry. GPS data acquisition and analysis. Inversion of geodetic data and mechanical models of crustal deformation. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Tectonics
gel.description: Course Description: Nature and evolution of tectonic features of the Earth. Causes, consequences, and evolution of plate motion, with selected examples from the Earth's deformed belts. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 101; or consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Topics in Geophysics
gel.description: Course Description: Discussion and evaluation of current research in a given area of geophysics. Topic will change from year to year. Offered in alternate years.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Analysis of Structures in Deformed Rocks
gel.description: Course Description: Recent advances in the understanding and analysis of structures in brittlely and ductilely deformed rocks. Detailed investigation of the characteristics of the structures, models for their formation, and applications to inferring the kinematics of larger scale tectonics. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 101; GEL 101L; or consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Fracture & Flow of Rocks
gel.description: Course Description: Origins of those structures in rocks associated with brittle and ductile deformation. Theoretical analysis, using continuum mechanics, and experimental evidence for the origin of the structures with emphasis on deformational processes in the earth. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 101; or consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Mechanics of Geologic Structures
gel.description: Course Description: Development in tensor notation of the balance laws of continuum mechanics, and constitutive theories of elasticity, viscosity, and plasticity and their application to understanding development of geologic structures such as fractures, faults, dikes, folds, foliations, and boudinage. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 009A; MAT 021C; or consent of instructor; MAT 021D and (MAT 022A or MAT 027A or BIS 027A recommended.)

gel.name: — Advanced Sedimentary Petrology
gel.description: Course Description: Advanced petrography and geochemistry of sediments and sedimentary rocks. Geochemical, textural and mineralogical evolution of sedimentary rocks reflecting depositional or burial processes. Laboratory work emphasizes thin section study of rocks. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 144; or consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Stable Isotopes Biogeochemistry
gel.description: Course Description: Discussion and application of stable isotope techniques for scientific research problems. Emphasizes carbon, oxygen, nitrogen, hydrogen and sulfur isotopes. Laboratory develops basic skills of cryogenic gas extraction and specific techniques for individual research using stable isotopes. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

gel.name: — Topics in Paleoceanography
gel.description: Course Description: Critical discussion and review of selected topics in paleoceanography and paleoclimatology relating to the history of the processes controlling and affecting climate change and ocean circulation throughout the geologic record. Topics vary. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 108; GEL 150A; or consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Geomorphology & River Management
gel.description: Course Description: Impacts of management and land use activities on the geomorphology of rivers and streams. Evaluation and use of analytical tools for river assessment. Assessment of river and stream restoration strategies and emerging issues in river management.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 139; or equivalent; graduate standing.

gel.name: — Oceans & Climate Change
gel.description: Course Description: Modern climate change and linkages between the ocean-atmosphere-cryosphere-terrestrial climate system. Importance of the ocean in forcing climate change, and the impacts of anthropogenic processes on the ocean. Topics vary. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Surface Processes
gel.description: Course Description: Recent advances in the analysis of landforms and their evolution. Detailed investigation of the tools used to document surface processes. Evaluation of concepts and processes that govern landscape evolution. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 050; GEL 050L; MAT 016B or MAT 017B or MAT 021B recommended.

gel.name: — Inverse Theory in Geology & Geophysics
gel.description: Course Description: Inversion of data for model parameters. Evaluation of parameter uncertainties. Linear and nonlinear problems for discrete and continuous models. Bakus-Gilbert inversion. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Theoretical Seismology
gel.description: Course Description: Elastodynamic wave equation. Greens functions and source representations. Ray theory. Plane and spherical waves and boundary conditions. Elastic wave propagation in stratified media.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Geophysics of the Earth
gel.description: Course Description: Physics of the earth's crust, mantle, and core. Laplace's equation and spherical harmonic expression of gravity and magnetic fields. Elastic wave equation in geologic media. Body and surface seismic waves. Equations of state, thermal structure of the earth. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 009B; (MAT 022B or MAT 027B or BIS 027B).

gel.name: — Geomagnetism
gel.description: Course Description: Nature and origin of the Earth's magnetic field. Present field and recent secular variation. Spherical harmonic analysis. Paleosecular variation. Polarity transitions and geomagnetic excursions. Statistics of polarity intervals. Dynamo theory. Planetary magnetism. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

gel.name: — Paleomagnetism
gel.description: Course Description: Principles and applications of paleomagnetism. Physical basis of rock and mineral magnetism. Field and laboratory techniques. Instrumentation. Analysis of paleomagnetic data. Statistical methods. Rock magnetic properties. Geological and geophysical applications. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

gel.name: — Physical Chemistry of Metamorphic Processes
gel.description: Course Description: Physiochemical principles of metamorphic mineral assemblages and methods of interpreting the paragenesis of metamorphic rocks. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 145; CHE 110A; or consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Metamorphic Petrology Seminar
gel.description: Course Description: Selected topics in metamorphic petrology (e.g., mass transport processes, tectonic settings, geothermometry, thermal structure of metamorphic belts, regional studies). Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 145; or consent of instructor; GEL 246 recommended.

gel.name: — Advanced Geochemistry Seminar
gel.description: Course Description: Critical review of selected topics in geochemistry including: ore genesis, hydrothermal and geothermal fluids, recent and ancient sediments, isotope geology, origin and chemistry of the oceans. Subject varies yearly depending on student interest.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 146; or consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Advanced Topics in Isotope Geochemistry & Cosmochemistry
gel.description: Course Description: Astrophysical context on origin of Solar System, synthesis of chemical elements, condensation sequence, star and planet formation, cosmochronology, building blocks of planets, development on planets' layered structure, atmosphere and hydrosphere and the role of comets/asteroids for volatile delivery. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Current Topics in Igneous Petrology
gel.description: Course Description: Topical seminar designed to help graduate students develop and maintain familiarity with current and past literature related to igneous rock petrogenesis.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 143; or consent of instructor; graduate standing in Geology.

gel.name: — Physical Chemistry of Igneous Processes
gel.description: Course Description: Introduction of modern concepts in chemical thermodynamics and kinetics, and fluid dynamics of magmatic systems for graduate students in petrology. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 110A; GEL 143; and consent of instructor; GEL 143 or consent of instructor; CHE 110B and CHE 110C recommended.

gel.name: — Experimental Petrology
gel.description: Course Description: Introduction to techniques and methods of design and executing experiments on Earth-forming minerals and rocks. Problems and examples from igneous and metamorphic petrology will be utilized. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 143; or consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Paleontology
gel.description: Course Description: Selected problems in paleontology. Subject to be studied will be decided at an organizational meeting. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in geology or a biological science.

gel.name: — Paleobiology Graduate Seminar 1: Evolutionary Aspects
gel.description: Course Description: Treat one or more of several topics in paleobiology from a phylogenetic perspective, including major patterns in evolution, building the tree of life, extinction & phylogeny, phylogeny of major phyla, and the relation between taxonomy & phylogeny.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Geology or a biological science; qualified undergraduates will be accepted on an exception-only basis.

gel.name: — Paleobiology Graduate Seminar: Methodological Aspects
gel.description: Course Description: One or more major methods used in the study of fossils: Morphometrics and three-dimensional reconstruction of fossils, phylogenetic methodology, the application of geochemical techniques, and electron microscopy.

gel.name: — Instrumental Techniques for Earth Scientists
gel.description: Course Description: Laboratory research techniques for new graduate students in Geology. Demonstration of and exposure to appropriate techniques in research.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MAT 016A or MAT 017A or MAT 021A); (MAT 016B or MAT 017B or MAT 021B); (MAT 016C or MAT 017C or MAT 021C); ((PHY 007A or PHY 009A); (PHY 007B or PHY 009B); (PHY 007C or PHY 009C)); or consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Field Studies in Marine Geochemistry
gel.description: Course Description: Marine geochemistry with the opportunity of going to sea or into the field on land. Techniques of seafloor mapping using bottom photography, marine geochemical sampling, and method of data reduction and sample analysis. Analysis of data/samples collected.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Seminar in Geology
gel.description: Course Description: Presentation and discussion of current topics in geology by visiting lecturers, staff, and students.

gel.name: — Geology of the Sierra Nevada
gel.description: Course Description: Short oral presentations by students and faculty concerning results of their past work and plans for future work in the Sierra. A written abstract is required following the format required at professional meetings. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

gel.name: — River Forum
gel.description: Course Description: Review and discussion of latest research and fundamental issues surrounding riverine systems, with emphasis on physical processes. Topics vary. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

gel.name: — Geologic Event of the Week
gel.description: Course Description: Seminar/discussion group to review and discuss recent earthquakes, volcanic eruptions, and other significant geologic events. The focus is on understanding the available observations, the physical processes behind each event, the geological setting, and societal consequences. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

gel.name: — Structure/Tectonics Forum
gel.description: Course Description: Seminar/discussion group to review and discuss latest research in structural geology and tectonics, and on-going research of participants. Topics will vary each quarter depending on the interests of the group. Occasional field trips to areas of current interest.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate student in geology or consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Geophysics Forum
gel.description: Course Description: Seminar/discussion group to review and discuss latest research in geophysics, and on-going research of participants. Topics will change each quarter depending on the interests of the group. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 101; or consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Advanced Problems in Tectonics
gel.description: Course Description: Seminar dealing with current problems in tectonics of selected regions. Topics will change from year to year. Emphasis on study of recent literature. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GEL 101; consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Geophysics Forum
gel.description: Course Description: Seminar/discussion group to review and discuss latest research in geophysics, and on-going research of participants. Topics will change each quarter depending on the interests of the group. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate student status in the Geology Department, or consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Group Study
gel.description: Course Description: Group study.

gel.name: — Research
gel.description: Course Description: Research.

gel.name: — Methods of Teaching Geology
gel.description: Course Description: Introduction to graduate-level writing and undergraduate-level teaching skills in geology. Persuasive (proposal) writing workshop; discussions on campus teaching resources, presenting information, managing classroom dynamics, evaluating student performance. Participation in teaching program required for Ph.D. in Geology.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate student standing in Geology.

gel.name: — Ethical Issues in Earth Science
gel.description: Course Description: Reading and discussion of ethical issues arising in the earth sciences. Topics include scientific misconduct, gender equity in science, authorship of scientific papers, establishing priorities in research, and related issues. Offered irregularly.
gel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Geology or consent of instructor.

gel.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
gel.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training.

ger.name: — Elementary German
ger.description: Course Description: Introduction to German grammar and development of all language skills in a cultural context with special emphasis on communication.

ger.name: — Accelerated Intensive Elementary German
ger.description: Course Description: Special 12-week accelerated, intensive summer session course that combines the work of GER 001, GER 002, and GER 003. Introduction to German grammar and development of all language skills in a cultural context with emphasis on communication.

ger.name: — Elementary German
ger.description: Course Description: Continuation of GER 001 in areas of grammar and basic language skills.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 001.

ger.name: — Elementary German
ger.description: Course Description: Completion of grammar sequence and continuing practice of all language skills through cultural texts.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 002.

ger.name: — German Fairy Tales from the Grimms to Disney
ger.description: Course Description: Introduction to the genre of fairy tale with a focus on the Brothers Grimm and Hans Christian Andersen in their respective political/cultural contexts. Discusses filmic adaptations by Disney, the East German DEFA and Hollywood.

ger.name: — Travel & the Modern World
ger.description: Course Description: Examination of travel as an essential human activity and experience of global modernity and cross-cultural encounters from the 18th to the 21st century with an emphasis on German-speaking culture. Travelogues, literature, art, memoirs, and films in English translation.

ger.name: — Intermediate German
ger.description: Course Description: Review of grammatical principles by means of written exercises; expanding of vocabulary through readings of modern texts.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 003; can be concurrent with GER 006.

ger.name: — Intermediate German
ger.description: Course Description: Review of grammatical principles by means of written exercises; expanding of vocabulary through readings of modern texts; addresses social relations and cultural practices in Germany; discusses history of Germany.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 020.

ger.name: — Intermediate German
ger.description: Course Description: Review of grammatical principles by means of written exercises; expanding of vocabulary through readings of modern texts.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 021.

ger.name: — Great German Short Stories (in English)
ger.description: Course Description: Major German short stories from Goethe at the end of the 18th century to Thomas Mann at the beginning of the 20th century.

ger.name: — Melodrama from Mozart to Lion King
ger.description: Course Description: Melodrama as a major dramatic genre from Mozart’s music dramas in the 18th century to films in the 21st century. Tragic psychological effects of death, war destruction, and the demonic, melodramatic expressions of political oppression, economic exploitation, and revolution, issues of race, gender, and class, capitalism and modernity, transnational and trans-generic adaptations.

ger.name: — Vampires & Other Horrors in Film & Media
ger.description: Course Description: History of representations of vampires and horror generally from the 19th-21st centuries. Emphasis on transnational history of the horror genre; psychologies of horror effects; issues of race, gender, and class; intersections with prejudice, medicine, modernity.

ger.name: — Myth & Saga in the Germanic Cultures
ger.description: Course Description: Knowledge of German not required. English translation from the Norse Eddas, the Volsung and Sigurd-Siegfried cycles, and the Gudrun lays; literary mythology in German Romanticism culminating in Wagner's "total art-work" concept and The Ring of the Nibelung cycle. May not be counted toward major in German.

ger.name: — Freshman Colloquium
ger.description: Course Description: Readings, discussion and written projects treating topics such as communist-capitalist tension in German literary culture; masculine "versus" feminine authorial consciousness; disintegration and reconstitution of language reflecting cultural transformation; exorcising post-Holocaust national guilt and individual frustration-Germany's new European "mission."
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open only to students who have completed 40 or fewer quarter units of transferable college level work.

ger.name: — Field Work in German
ger.description: Course Description: Total immersion program in Germany or a German speaking setting in the U.S. to further develop students' proficiency in the German language.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

ger.name: — Directed Group Study
ger.description: Course Description: Primarily for lower division students.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ger.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
ger.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.

ger.name: — Survey of German Literature, 800-1800
ger.description: Course Description: German literature from the Middle Ages to Classicism (800-1800) with an overview of major movements and authors.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 022; or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — Survey of German Literature, 1800-Present
ger.description: Course Description: German literature from the Age of Romanticism (1800) to the present  with an overview of major movements and authors.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 022.

ger.name: — Writing Skills in German
ger.description: Course Description: Practice in different kinds of writing, such as abstracts, correspondence, lecture summaries, analysis of or response to short literary texts.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 022; or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — Translation
ger.description: Course Description: Exercises in German-to-English, English-to-German translation using texts from the areas of culture and commerce.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 022; or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — The Modern German Language
ger.description: Course Description: Introduction to the linguistic analysis of contemporary German, including its phonology, morphology, syntax and semantics, as well as sociolinguistic considerations.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 022; or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — Business German
ger.description: Course Description: Specialized language course using business-oriented information and publications as the basis for discussions, roleplay, reports, compositions and translations.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 022; or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — Advanced Business German
ger.description: Course Description: Specialized advanced language course providing in-depth study of major business topics with the help of authentic texts and videos.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 022; or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — Topics in German Literature
ger.description: Course Description: Knowledge of German not required. Investigation of significant themes and issues within their European context.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — Goethe's Faust
ger.description: Course Description: Knowledge of German not required. Intensive study of Goethe's Faust in its entirety. Discussions and readings in English; reading the text in the original is encouraged.

ger.name: —  From Marlene Dietrich to Run, Lola Run: German Women & Film
ger.description: Course Description: Knowledge of German not required. Women in German film from the Weimar Republic to present, with special emphasis on conceptualizations of gender, historical and political context, aesthetic and filmic innovations.

ger.name: — German Literature Since 1945
ger.description: Course Description: Knowledge of German not required. Major writers of the post-war generation of Austria, Switzerland and Germany: novelists, such as Böll, Grass, Johnson, Walser, Handke; playwrights such as Frisch, Dürrentmatt and Hochhuth; and poets, such as Celan, Enzensberger, and Aichinger.

ger.name: — Readings in Jewish Writing & Thought in German Culture
ger.description: Course Description: Historical tradition of Jewish thought in the German cultural context; unique contributions of Jewish writers to culture of the German-speaking world; what it means to be "other" in the mainstream culture.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): RST 023; or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — After the Catastrophe: Jews & Jewish Life in Post-1945 Germany
ger.description: Course Description: Jews and Jewish life in post-1945 Germany, with special attention given to literature, historical debates, photography, film, as well as websites and other new media.

ger.name: — Vienna at the Turn of the 20th Century (The End of the Habsburg Empire)
ger.description: Course Description: Knowledge of German not required. Cultural ferment in Vienna, capital of the multinational Habsburg empire, at the turn of the century, with consideration of innovations in literature, music, graphic arts, architecture philosophy and psychology, heralding European modernism.

ger.name: — Weimar Culture: Defeat, the Roaring Twenties, the Rise of Nazism
ger.description: Course Description: Knowledge of German not required. Expressionism in graphic arts, literature, film, New Objectivity, Brecht, and Bauhaus considered in the context of the failure of the German experiment in democracy, the Weimar Republic of 1919-33.

ger.name: — Germany Under the Third Reich
ger.description: Course Description: No knowledge of German required. Interdisciplinary study of German society and culture during the Third Reich (1933-45); readings in aesthetics, history, and philosophy; study of Fascist culture in literature, film, architecture, and the graphic arts; focus on everyday life in Hitler's Germany.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Background in Modern European History; GER 118B recommended.

ger.name: — Contemporary German Culture
ger.description: Course Description: Political, economic, social and cultural scene of Germany today.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 022; or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — From German Fiction to German Film
ger.description: Course Description: Examines a number of film adaptations of major German prose works and plays to ascertain the types of changes involved in the shift in medium and the positive and negative effects achieved by such transferences.

ger.name: — Survey of German Culture
ger.description: Course Description: Major developments in German arts, philosophical thought, social institutions, and political history.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 022; or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — The Medieval Period in German Literature
ger.description: Course Description: Literary-philosophical profile of the Mittelhochdeutsche Blütezeit in terms of the significant epics, romances, and lyric poetry. Readings in German.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 022; or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — Reformation & Baroque
ger.description: Course Description: Exemplary literary works of the 16th and 17th centuries tracing the principal lines of development and showing the reflection in literature of the social, as well as religious, scenes.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 022; or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — Literature of the Classical Age
ger.description: Course Description: Critical assessment of principal works of Goethe and Schiller within the historical and philosophical context of their times.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 022; or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — Major Movements in German Literature
ger.description: Course Description: Significant movements and schools in German literary history (e.g., the medieval troubadours, Storm and Stress, the romanticists, the George Circle, the expressionists), with emphasis on the broader cultural dynamics and ideologies as these apply to individual literary works.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 022; or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — Short Fiction: 1880-1914
ger.description: Course Description: Reading of short German fiction from the fin-de-siècle period and representative of various prose styles and cultural currents.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 022; or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — Modern German Literature
ger.description: Course Description: Selections from significant works of major contemporary writers, such as Hesse, Mann, Kafka, Rilke, Brecht, Grass.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 022; or consent of instructor.

ger.name: —  Major Writers in German
ger.description: Course Description: Examination of representative works by a major writer, set in the broader cultural context of the relevant period or movement.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 022; or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — Postwar Women Writers
ger.description: Course Description: Major writers in both Germanies, Austria, and Switzerland since 1945. Topics include the concept of a feminist aesthetics, East vs. West German writers, and the status of minority women writers in Germany (Jewish, Turkish-German, Afro-German).
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 022; or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — German Lyric Poetry
ger.description: Course Description: Study of the genre of lyric poety from the late Middle Ages through Renaissance, Baroque, Classical, Romantic, and Modern periods in correlation with other literary forms and the social climate of each period.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 022; or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — The German Novelle
ger.description: Course Description: Inquiry into the art of the "Novelle" through analysis of the materials and formal devices of representative authors from Goethe to Kafka.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 022; or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — The German Drama
ger.description: Course Description: Readings in the works of Germany's leading dramatists from the 18th century to the present day, such as Lessing, Goethe, Schiller, Kleist, Büchner, Hauptmann, Brecht.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 022; or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — Topics in German Intellectual History
ger.description: Course Description: Topics in German intellectual history with materials from a number of periods, genres, and disciplines.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 022; or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — The Holocaust & its Literary Representation
ger.description: Course Description: Knowledge of German not required. Aesthetic representation and metaphorical transformation of the Holocaust in its human and historical perspectives.

ger.name: — New German Cinema
ger.description: Course Description: Knowledge of German not required. German filmmakers of the 1960s-1980s such as Fassbinder, Herzog, Syberberg, Brückner, Schlöndorf, Kluge, Wenders.

ger.name: — Language Through Media
ger.description: Course Description: Study of contemporary German-language news media (press, video, film, CD-ROM, Internet) for insight into political and cultural developments in the German-speaking countries.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 022; or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — Marx, Nietzsche, Freud
ger.description: Course Description: Study of major texts of Marx, Nietzsche, and Freud, selected with an eye to their impact on 20th-century economics, ethics, and attitudes toward eros. Particular focus on conceptions of the self and the individual's relation to society.

ger.name: — Love in the Middle Ages
ger.description: Course Description: Analysis of the phenomenon of love in selected medieval lyrical poems and romances of the 12th- and 13th-century Blütezeit. Origins of courtly love, love & individualism, love & the Church, love & adultery.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 022; or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — Nazi & Fascist Cinema: Film & other Visual Media
ger.description: Course Description: Analysis of nefarious and noxious cultural products in history: films made under the Nazis and other fascists, 1933-1945. Questions at heart of humanistic studies: relationship of culture to propaganda, politics, and even unfathomable crime.

ger.name: — Multiculturalism in German Literature
ger.description: Course Description: Examples of German literature from the High Middle Ages to the present that explore the "encounter with the other" (people of color, different beliefs and cultures, and inner-German minorities).
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 022; or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — Classic Weimar Cinema
ger.description: Course Description: German Weimar (1919-1933) cinema; Fritz Lang, F.W. Murnau, and G.W. Pabst among others. Influence on worldwide (especially Hollywood) film genres such as film noir, horror, science fiction, and melodrama.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HUM 001.

ger.name: — The Age of Bismarck
ger.description: Course Description: Notable literary repercussions of the zenith of Germany's international status at the time of Bismarck's Chancellorship. The poetry of Storm, the prose of Fontane, the drama of Hauptmann.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 022; or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — Field Work in German
ger.description: Course Description: Total immersion program in Germany or a German speaking setting in the U.S. to further develop student proficiency in the German language.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GER 109A; or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — Honors Program
ger.description: Course Description: Research of an integrative nature (in either "General" or "Area Studies Emphasis" fields of major), guided by thesis advisor chosen by student.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open only to majors with a 3.500 minimum GPA in at least 135 graduation units.

ger.name: — Honors Program
ger.description: Course Description: Writing of Honors Thesis on topic selected by student in consultation with thesis advisor.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open only to majors with a 3.500 minimum GPA in at least 135 graduation units.

ger.name: — Tutoring in German
ger.description: Course Description: Tutoring in undergraduate courses including leadership in small voluntary discussion groups affiliated with department courses.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of German Program Director.

ger.name: — Directed Group Study
ger.description: Course Description: Directed group study.

ger.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
ger.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

ger.name: — Middle High German
ger.description: Course Description: Outline of grammar; selections from Middle High German epic, romance, and lyric poetry.

ger.name: — Cognitive Grammar for Applied Linguists
ger.description: Course Description: Analysis of grammar and application of cognitive grammar to language instruction. Syntactical problems and analyses relevant to the language which the student will teach.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

ger.name: — Techniques of Literary Scholarship
ger.description: Course Description: Bibliographical, organizational, and methodological tools and resources for advanced, independent research.

ger.name: — Concepts in Literary Theory
ger.description: Course Description: Advanced course in concepts of literary theory and criticism. Discussion of the emergence of theoretical concepts and their impact on the understanding and appreciation of literary works. Discussion in German and English, readings in German.

ger.name: — Contemporary Approaches to Literary Theory
ger.description: Course Description: Study of contemporary theoretical approaches such as structuralism, deconstruction, feminism, Marxism/Frankfurt School, and reception theory in conjunction with the works of major authors.

ger.name: — Narrative & Narrative Theory
ger.description: Course Description: Studies, in a theoretical and literary historical context, major elements of 19th- and 20th-century narrative, such as techniques of framing, refraction, and montage; narrative perspective; mimesis; and self-consciousness. Focuses on paradigmatic prose texts alongside a spectrum of critical approaches.

ger.name: — Forms of German Verse
ger.description: Course Description: Development of German verse from the Middle Ages to the present, with special emphasis on different techniques of text analysis and interpretation.

ger.name: — The German Drama
ger.description: Course Description: Major forms of German drama from its origins to the middle of the 20th century.

ger.name: — The German Novelle
ger.description: Course Description: The major German Novellisten, with particular emphasis on the flowering of this genre in the 19th century.

ger.name: — Fontane & the Rise of the Modern German Novel
ger.description: Course Description: Fontane, the father of the modern German novel and the chief German representative of the European novel at its greatest, in the context of the 19-century European political and social scene.

ger.name: — Gender & Comedy
ger.description: Course Description: Studies of genre and gender in German-language comedy by male and female writers from the 18th century to the present. Authors treated include Lessing, Kleist, Büchner, Ebner-Eschenbach, Hauptmann, Hofmannsthal, Frisch, Langner, and Jelinek.

ger.name: — The Writing of Lessing
ger.description: Course Description: Study of Lessing's theory of literature with particular emphasis upon his critical attacks on French drama.

ger.name: — Goethe
ger.description: Course Description: Study of the origins of Goethe's thought in German Pietism, and his principal artistic, autobiographical, scientific, and philosophical works.

ger.name: — Schiller
ger.description: Course Description: Critical analysis of Schiller's major works and his impact on the intellectual climate in Germany during the late-18th and early-19th centuries.

ger.name: — Aesthetics in the Age of Goethe
ger.description: Course Description: Emergence of aesthetic autonomy from 18th-century normative poetics during the Age of Goethe. The shift from a model based on the imitation of nature (and the Ancients) to a new concept grounded in the individuality of aesthetic experience.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — Heinrich von Kleist
ger.description: Course Description: Kleist's important dramatic and prose works; special attention will be given to the peculiar hermeneutic problems in modern German, French, and Anglo-American Kleist criticism.

ger.name: — The Novels of Thomas Mann
ger.description: Course Description: Reading of selected novels with emphasis on aesthetic techniques, originality, ethical and political views, and influence on the contemporary literary scene in Germany.

ger.name: — Studies in Kafka
ger.description: Course Description: Study of Kafkas narrative techniques with special emphasis in the shorter works on the existential development from its roots in Expressionism.

ger.name: — The Poetry of Rilke
ger.description: Course Description: Study of the principal motifs, myths, images, and problems in the poetry of Rainer Maria Rilke.

ger.name: — Brecht & the Epic Theater
ger.description: Course Description: Reading of Brechts works with emphasis on the ideas which impelled the development of new literary forms and concepts.

ger.name: — Studies in Turn-of-the-Century Culture
ger.description: Course Description: Investigates literary currents in turn-of-the-century Germany and Austria against the background of contemporaneous developments in psychology, the visual arts, philosophy, and music. Authors treated include Hauptmann, Holz and Schlaf, Schnitzler, T. Mann, Wedekind, Musil, Hofmannsthal.

ger.name: — Middle High German Literature
ger.description: Course Description: Extensive reading of Middle High German texts in the original language. Examines linguistic and literary problems.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ger.name: — Renaissance & Reformation in German Literature
ger.description: Course Description: Parabolic and didactic style in Germany's literature during the 16th century.

ger.name: — German Literature of the Baroque
ger.description: Course Description: The "Elegantiaideal" and the varying methods used to portray it in 17th-century German literature.

ger.name: — The Enlightenment in German Literature
ger.description: Course Description: Revolt against the concept of the Elegantiaideal, and evolution of a new literature based on reason and wit.

ger.name: — Foreign Language Learning in the Classroom
ger.description: Course Description: Overview of approaches to university-level foreign language instruction and the theoretical notions underlying current trends in classroom practices across commonly taught foreign languages.

ger.name: — Sentimentality & Sturm und Drang in German Literature
ger.description: Course Description: Reaction to overemphasis on Reason: theories of Hamann and Herder and works of poets such as Lenz, Leisewitz, the early Goethe and Schiller.

ger.name: — The Classical Age of German Literature
ger.description: Course Description: Inquiry into the aesthetic and humanistic qualities of Germany's greatest literary epoch.

ger.name: — The Romantic Period in German Literature
ger.description: Course Description: Survey of the works of early 19th-century authors in reaction against the age of classicism.

ger.name: — Poetic Realism in German Literature
ger.description: Course Description: Outstanding figures in German literature between 1840 and 1890. Important phases in their developments will be treated.

ger.name: — 20th-Century German Literature
ger.description: Course Description: Considers the revolt of the Hauptmann generation, Symbolism, Expressionism, and the chief currents of the contemporary scene.

ger.name: — Special Topics in German Literature
ger.description: Course Description: Various special topics in German literature, which may cut across the more usual period and genre rubrics.

ger.name: — Group Study
ger.description: Course Description: Group study.

ger.name: — Individual Study
ger.description: Course Description: Individual study.

ger.name: — Special Study for the Doctoral Dissertation
ger.description: Course Description: Special study for doctoral dissertation.

ger.name: — The Teaching of German
ger.description: Course Description: Theoretical instruction in modern teaching methods and demonstration of their practical application. Required of new teaching assistants.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — The Teaching of German
ger.description: Course Description: Theoretical instruction in modern teaching methods and demonstration of their practical application. Required of new teaching assistants.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — The Teaching of German
ger.description: Course Description: Theoretical instruction in modern teaching methods and demonstration of their practical application. Required of new teaching assistants.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

ger.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
ger.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

ger.name: — Tutorial & Instructional Internship
ger.description: Course Description: Apprentice training in ongoing undergraduate literature courses taught by regular staff, with supplementary weekly critique sessions; intern leadership of discussion sections under staff supervision.
ger.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

gdb.name: — Introduction to Global Disease Biology
gdb.description: Course Description: Introduction to the Global Disease Biology major, research and internship opportunities, and potential career paths in human, animal, and plant health. Communication, ethics and the nature of science.
gdb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open to GDB majors only, or consent of instructor.

gdb.name: — Epidemiology
gdb.description: Course Description: Principles and practice of epidemiology as applied to human, animal, and plant populations and the environment in which these populations co-exist. Quantitative analysis of both infectious and non-infectious disease. Inter-dependence between epidemiological analysis, decision-making and policy formulation will be highlighted.
gdb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SAS 013; BIS 002A; BIS 002B; BIS 002C; ((STA 013 or STA 013Y) or (STA 100 or PLS 120)).

gdb.name: — Disease Intervention & Policy
gdb.description: Course Description: Examination of the prevention and treatment of diseases affecting humans, animals, and plants. Case studies illustrate the merits of a unified approach to promoting health at local, regional, and global scales.
gdb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GDB 101; SAS 013; BIS 002A; BIS 002B; BIS 002C; PMI 129Y; VME 158.

gdb.name: — Microbiome of People, Animals, & Plants
gdb.description: Course Description: Examination of the structure and function of microbial communities that live inside and on host organisms. Introduction to general concepts of the microbiome and microbiota, and their relationship to host health and disease.

gdb.name: — Geographies of Health
gdb.description: Course Description: Multiple geographies of health, including how both physical environmental systems and human social, economic & political systems impact health and disease. Global, comparative geographical approach emphasizes the benefits of integrated multidisciplinary analyses for planetary health success.

gdb.name: — Global Disease Biology Seminar
gdb.description: Course Description: Seminar leading to development of the research proposal and academic plan for the Global Disease Biology major.

gdb.name: — Global Disease Biology Senior Research
gdb.description: Course Description: Capstone research experience for the Global Disease Biology major. Project may be experimental, library research, or some other creative activity.
gdb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GDB 090; GDB 189D (can be concurrent); SAS 013; GBD 189D required concurrently the first time GBD 189 is taken.

gdb.name: — Global Disease Biology Research Discussion
gdb.description: Course Description: Prevent or solve problems during the students’ research activity. Independent advising and assistance on research proposal.
gdb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GDB 090; GDB 187; SAS 013; GDB 189; or consent of instructor.

glo.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
glo.description: Course Description: Special Study for Undergraduates.

glo.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
glo.description: Course Description: Special Study for Undergraduates.

grd.name: — Directed Group Study
grd.description: Course Description: Preparation of undergraduate students in identified graduate school pipeline programs (e.g. McNair scholars) for graduate education. Emphasis on educating and training undergraduates on key skills and competencies needed for the development of a successful graduate school applicant and future graduate scholar. Topics will vary.

grd.name: — Directed Group Study
grd.description: Course Description: Training and preparation of graduate students for successful scholarship and future careers. Emphasis on development of written and verbal communication, professional development, leadership, and mentoring. Topics will vary.

grd.name: — Research
grd.description: Course Description: Special study or research for graduate students.

grd.name: — Teaching in Higher Education
grd.description: Course Description: Selected topics related to preparation for teaching in higher education, leadership in academic institutions, job opportunities and career pathways for graduate students pursuing careers in teaching and education.

grd.name: — Directed Group Study
grd.description: Course Description: Preparation of graduate students for careers as teachers and educators in higher education. Emphasis on the development of clear written and verbal communication skills as well as leadership practices applicable to teaching in academic institutions.

grk.name: — Elementary Greek
grk.description: Course Description: Introduction to the basic grammar and vocabulary of Classical and New Testament Greek. Development of translation skills with emphasis on Greek-English.

grk.name: — Elementary Greek
grk.description: Course Description: Continuation of GRK 001.
grk.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 001; or the equivalent.

grk.name: — Elementary New Testament Greek
grk.description: Course Description: Supplementary study of New Testament Greek.
grk.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 002 (can be concurrent); concurrent attendance required.

grk.name: — Intermediate Greek
grk.description: Course Description: Continuation of GRK 002. Selected readings from Greek authors.
grk.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 002; or the equivalent.

grk.name: — Elementary New Testament Greek
grk.description: Course Description: Supplementary study of New Testament Greek.
grk.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 003 (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor; concurrent attendance required.

grk.name: — Directed Group Study
grk.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
grk.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

grk.name: — Readings in Greek Prose
grk.description: Course Description: Review of Greek morphology, syntax, and vocabulary. Readings in Greek prose authors, including Xenophon.
grk.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 003; or equivalent.

grk.name: — Plato
grk.description: Course Description: Study of Plato and his works.
grk.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 100; or consent of instructor.

grk.name: — Euripides
grk.description: Course Description: Study of Euripides and his works.
grk.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 100; or consent of instructor.

grk.name: — Homer: Iliad
grk.description: Course Description: Selected readings from Homer's Iliad.
grk.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): GRK 003.

grk.name: — Homer: Odyssey
grk.description: Course Description: Selected readings from Homer's Odyssey.
