his.description: Course Description: Designed primarily for students preparing for higher degrees in history. (X) World History.

his.name: — Major Issues in Historical Interpretation: Ancient
his.description: Course Description: Fundamental issues and debates in the study of history. Ancient. Readings, papers, and class reports.

his.name: — Major Issues in Historical Interpretation: Medieval Europe
his.description: Course Description: Fundamental issues and debates in the study of history. Medieval Europe. Readings, papers, and class reports.

his.description: Course Description: Fundamental issues and debates in the study of history. Modern Europe. Readings, papers, and class reports.

his.description: Course Description: Fundamental issues and debates in the study of history. India. Readings, papers, and class reports.

his.description: Course Description: Fundamental issues and debates in the study of history. Japan. Readings, papers, and class reports.

his.description: Course Description: Fundamental issues and debates in the study of history. Latin America. Readings, papers, and class reports.

his.name: — Research Seminar
his.description: Course Description: Designed for students preparing for higher degrees in history. Individual research and analysis resulting in substantial research paper of publishable quality. Completion required of all Ph.D. candidates. The three courses must be taken in continuous sequence, ordinarily during second year.

his.name: — Research Seminar
his.description: Course Description: Designed for students preparing for higher degrees in history. Individual research and analysis resulting in substantial research paper of publishable quality. Completion required of all Ph.D. candidates. The three courses must be taken in continuous sequence, ordinarily during second year.

his.name: — Research Seminar
his.description: Course Description: Designed for students preparing for higher degrees in History. Individual research and analysis resulting in substantial research paper of publishable quality. Completion required of all Ph.D. candidates. The three courses must be taken in continuous sequence, ordinarily during second year.

his.name: — Historiography
his.description: Course Description: Major issues in the philosophy and methodology of history.

his.name: — Medieval History
his.description: Course Description: Topics in the history of medieval and early Renaissance Europe.

his.name: — Modern European History
his.description: Course Description: Primary sources and research methodologies in the history of modern France and Germany. May be repeated once for credit.

his.name: — Latin American History
his.description: Course Description: Latin American history.
his.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Two courses in Latin American history; reading knowledge of Spanish or Portuguese.

his.name: — United States History
his.description: Course Description: Research in literature, methods, and sources on aspects of United States history, culminating in each student completing a research paper in the field by the end of the second quarter.

his.name: — United States History
his.description: Course Description: Research in literature, methods, and sources on aspects of United States history, culminating in each student completing a research paper in the field by the end of the second quarter.

his.name: — Chinese History
his.description: Course Description: Research on topics to be chosen by the students for the purpose of writing article-length papers.

his.name: — Chinese History
his.description: Course Description: Completion of article-length papers on topics chosen by students.

his.name: — Methods & Issues in Chinese History
his.description: Course Description: Readings in Chinese historical materials. Training in the use of Chinese reference works (including on-line resources).
his.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Reading knowledge of Chinese.

his.name: — College Teaching Internship
his.description: Course Description: Student prepares and teaches one lower division history course in a nearby community college under the supervision of a UC Davis instructor and a community college instructor.

his.name: — Group Study

his.name: — Introductory Seminar for Teaching Assistants
his.description: Course Description: An introduction to the broad comparative and theoretical issues of teaching methods and techniques in history.

his.name: — Teaching History in College
his.description: Course Description: Designed for teaching assistants with emphasis on problems and procedures encountered by teachers of lower division classes at the university.

hnr.name: — Honors Discussion Section
hnr.description: Course Description: Examination of special topics in selected lower division courses through additional readings, discussions, term papers, collaborative work, or special activities, including projects, field and laboratory experiences, computer simulations, creative works.
hnr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open only to students in the Davis Honors Challenge.

hnr.name: — Internship
hnr.description: Course Description: Supervised work experience under the auspices of the Davis Honors Challenge.
hnr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; open only to students in the Davis Honors Challenge.

hnr.name: — Honors Seminar
hnr.description: Course Description: Collaborative, multidisciplinary exploration of complex contemporary problem. Focus on critical thinking and analytical interpretation, on oral and written communication, and on the use of electronic media in gathering information.

hnr.name: — Directed Group Study
hnr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; open to students in the Davis Honors Challenge.

hnr.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
hnr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; student in the Davis Honors Challenge.

hnr.name: — Honors Contract
hnr.description: Course Description: In-depth examination of material in an upper division course as defined in an Honors Contract Proposal submitted by the student. Contract must be approved by the instructor and the Honors Council of the Academic Senate.
hnr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open only to students in the Davis Honors Challenge.

hnr.name: — Internship
hnr.description: Course Description: Supervised work experience under the auspices of the Davis Honors Challenge.
hnr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; open only to students in the Davis Honors Challenge.

hnr.name: — Honors Seminar
hnr.description: Course Description: Team-based work on actual problems drawn from the public or private sector. Focus on critical thinking and analytic interpretation, oral and written communication skills, and developement of practical solutions to real-world problems.

hnr.name: — Honors Thesis/Honors Project
hnr.description: Course Description: Guided independent study of a selected topic leading to the presentation of an honors thesis/honors project.
hnr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open only to students in the Davis Honors Challenge.

hnr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; open only to students in the Davis Honors Challenge.

hnr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open only to students in the Davis Honors Challenge.

hrt.name: — Horticulture & Agronomy: Principles
hrt.description: Course Description: Core course to introduce students to the principles that are of general importance in horticultural and agronomic research, including agroecology, plant developmental physiology, crop improvement, and biotechnology. Generally taken in the first year of the graduate program.

hrt.name: — Horticulture & Agronomy: Practices
hrt.description: Course Description: Introduction to horticultural and agronomic cropping systems. Covers current applied research within agroecology, crop improvement, crop production, postharvest biology.

hrt.name: — Research Perspectives in Horticulture
hrt.description: Course Description: Following lectures/discussions of scientific methodology, students develop research proposals aided by classroom discussions and individual interactions with instructors. Lectures and critiques of classical papers provide a sense of the evolution of the current concepts in perennial plant biology.

hrt.name: — Current Topics in Root Biology
hrt.description: Course Description: How roots grow and interact with their environment, from embryonic roots to large tree roots. Analysis of recent literature related to the impact of internal controls on root growth and root system development (e.g., developmental signaling, carbohydrate availability, water status), and the impacts of the external environment on root physiology, root system development, and individual root growth (e.g., soil structure, soil microbial, water, nutrients).

hrt.name: — Seminar
hrt.description: Course Description: Seminars presented by invited speakers, students, or faculty on selected topics in horticulture.
hrt.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing at UC Davis.

hde.name: — Human Sexuality
hde.description: Course Description: Vocabulary, structure/function of reproductive system; sexual response; pre-natal development; pregnancy and childbirth; development of sexuality; rape and sexual assault; birth control; sexually transmitted diseases; homosexuality; establishing/maintaining intimacy; sexual dysfunctions; communication; enhancing sexual interaction, cultural differences in attitudes towards sexuality. May be taught abroad.

hde.name: — Internship
hde.description: Course Description: Supervised internship, off campus and on campus, in community and institutional setting. Involves progressively greater (supervised) participation in program delivery or assessment.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; field work experience or at least one course related to fieldwork assignment (e.g. HDE 100A, HDE 100B, HDE 140 or HDE 140L).

hde.name: — Directed Group Study for Undergraduates
hde.description: Course Description: Directed group study for undergraduates.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

hde.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
hde.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.

hde.name: — Infancy & Early Childhood
hde.description: Course Description: Biological, social, and cultural influences in the psychological growth and development of children, prenatal through age six. Two observations of preschool children required.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); (BIS 002A or BIS 010 or BIS 001A or BIS 010V) or MCB 010 or NPB 010 or NPB 012 or MIC 010.

hde.name: — Infancy & Early Childhood
hde.description: Course Description: Biological, social, and cultural influences in the psychological growth and development of children, prenatal through age six. Two observations of preschool children required.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); (BIS 002A or BIS 010 or BIS 001A or BIS 010V or MCB 010 or NPB 010 or NPB 012 or MIC 010).

hde.name: — Middle Childhood & Adolescence
hde.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Interplay of biological and social-cultural factors in the emotional, cognitive and social development from middle childhood through adolescence.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (HDE 100A or PSC 140); (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y).

hde.name: — Adulthood & Aging
hde.description: Course Description: Development during early, middle, and late adulthood; biological, cognitive, and psycho-social aspects of adult development. Emphasis on normative patterns of development which characterize "successful aging."
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 001 or PSC 001Y.

hde.name: — Cognitive Development
hde.description: Course Description: Theories, methods, evidence, and debates in the field of cognitive development, such as nature/nurture, constraints on learning, and the role of plasticity. Topics include attention, memory, concepts about the physical and social world, and language.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HDE 100A or HDE 100B or PSC 140 or PSC 140Y.

hde.name: — Social & Personality Development
hde.description: Course Description: Social and personality development of children, infancy through adolescence. Topics include the development of personality, achievement motivation, self-understanding, sex-role identity, and antisocial behavior. Emphasis on the interface between biological and social factors.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HDE 100A or HDE 100B.

hde.name: — Children in Families, Schools, Communities
hde.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Children's social contexts (e.g., family, peers, school, neighborhood, community culture), development, and environmental challenges (e.g., poverty, maltreatment) from birth through adolescence.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HDE 100A or HDE 100B or PSC 140.

hde.name: — Families in Communities
hde.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Family member's roles, interactions, and development, and how families are impacted by the larger community and society in which they live. Relevant topics/issues include: gender, race/ethnicity, parenting, marriage, grandparents, divorce, acculturation, migration, and  policies relevant to family well-being.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 001 or PSC 001Y or CRD 001 or CRD 002 or SOC 001 or SOC 002.

hde.name: — Families in Communities
hde.description: Course Description: Family members' roles, interactions, and development, and how families are impacted by the larger community and society in which they live. Relevant topics/issues include gender, race/ethnicity, parenting, marriage, grandparents, divorce, acculturation, migration, and policies relevant to family well-being.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CRD 001 or CRD 002 or PSC 001 or PSC 001Y or SOC 001 or SOC 002.

hde.name: — Family Stress & Resilience
hde.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Theories and research associated with stressors affecting family functioning throughout the lifespan. Normative transitions and non-normative stressors, family services and family based policies and interventions.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HDE 110.

hde.name: — Social Relationships Across the Lifespan
hde.description: Course Description: Spectrum of relationships across the lifespan; e.g., families, friends, members from the broader social network. Major theories and research among social relationships and development.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HDE 100A or HDE 100B or HDE 100C.

hde.name: — Longevity
hde.description: Course Description: Nature, origin, determinants, and limits of longevity with particular reference to humans; emphasis on implications of findings from non-human model systems including natural history, ecology and evolution of life span; description of basic demographic techniques including life table methods.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

hde.name: — Research Methods in Human Development
hde.description: Course Description: Scientific process, research designs, and experimental controls; APA manuscript style and scientific writing; statistical analysis and interpretation of results. Laboratory exercises to collect data, analyze and interpret results, and write scientific papers.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 013 or STA 013Y or STA 013V or STA 100 or EDU 114 or PSC 041 or (SOC 046A,  SOC 046B).

hde.name: — Psychological Assessment
hde.description: Course Description: Current issues and methodology related to the process of psychological assessment with children.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (HDE 100A or HDE 100B); (STA 013 or STA 013Y or PSC 041 or (SOC 046A,  SOC 046B)).

hde.name: — Developmental Psychopathology
hde.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Foundational principles and current issues in developmental psychopathology, the study of mental health problems and disorders that originate in childhood and adolescence (e.g., disruptive behavior, mood and anxiety disorders).
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (HDE 100A,  HDE 100B) or PSC 140; consent of instructor.

hde.name: — Thriving Across the Lifespan
hde.description: Course Description: Positive developmental trajectories from womb to tomb. Developmental process of thriving (e.g., happiness, life satisfaction, wisdom) and the factors that support thriving.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HDE 100A or HDE 100B or HDE 100C.

hde.name: — Individual Differences in Cognition
hde.description: Course Description: Individual differences in cognition, including learning disabilities and giftedness. Education implications and neurodevelopmental substrates of individual differences in cognition.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); (HDE 100A or HDE 100B).

hde.name: — Stress, Adversity & Resilience
hde.description: Course Description: Short and long term biobehavioral responses to stress and adversity. The biological, psychological, social, and cultural factors of resilience. Interventions promoting resilience. Developmental perspective of stress and resilience across the lifespan.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HDE 100A or HDE 100B or HDE 100C.

hde.name: — Stress, Adversity & Resilience
hde.description: Course Description: Short and long term biobehavioral responses to stress and adversity. The biological, psychological, social, and cultural factors of resilience. Interventions promoting resilience. Developmental perspective of stress and resilience across the lifespan.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HDE 100A or HDE 100B or HDE 100C.

hde.name: — Disparities & Inequalities in Health & Wellbeing
hde.description: Course Description: Biological, psychosocial, environmental, historical, and political factors on disparities and inequalities. Individual differences in risk exposures. Developmental and intergenerational processes. Policy applications of disparities research.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HDE 100A or HDE 100B or HDE 100C.

hde.name: — Health Behaviors Across the Lifespan
hde.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Development of health-related behaviors and physical and mental health outcomes across the lifespan. Coping strategies and behaviors such as nutrition, physical activity, technology, substance use/abuse, and social and cognitive engagement, as related to developmental stage.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 011 or NUT 010 or SAS 013 or HDE 100A or HDE 100B or HDE 100C.

hde.name: — Contextual Determinants of Health
hde.description: Course Description: Community, cultural, political, and physical environment influences on health and well-being. Developmental approach. Unique contextual determinants of health from womb to tomb.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HDE 100A or HDE 100B or HDE 100C.

hde.name: — Laboratory in Early Childhood
hde.description: Course Description: Application of theories of learning and development to interaction with infants, toddlers, and preschoolers at Early Childhood Laboratory. Applied skills in communication, guidance and curriculum.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HDE 100A; consent of instructor; to enroll, students must contact the Internship Coordinator in 1303 Hart Hall.

hde.name: — Field Study With Children & Adolescents
hde.description: Course Description: Study of children's affective, cognitive and social development within the context of family/school environments, hospitals and foster group homes.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HDE 100A or HDE 100B; and consent of instructor.

hde.name: — Field Study with Emotionally Distressed Children & Adolescents
hde.description: Course Description: Field study with children who are identified as emotionally distressed, including those with internalizing and externalizing behavioral problems.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HDE 130 (can be concurrent); and consent of instructor.

hde.name: — Field Studies of the Elderly
hde.description: Course Description: Apply theory and research on adult development and aging, work with older adults in a variety of settings, and develop skills relevant to that application. Develop a small research project.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HDE 100C or HDE 160 (can be concurrent); and consent of instructor.

hde.name: — Social Aspects of Aging
hde.description: Course Description: How the social context affects adult development and aging. Emphasis on demography, social policy, culture, and adaptation. Oral histories as class projects.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HDE 100C.

hde.name: — Technology Use, Health, & Aging
hde.description: Course Description: Principles from gerontology applied to older adults' use of technology to support health and well-being across a variety of domains (e.g., cognitive and physical fitness, social engagement) and contexts (assisted living, aging in place). Cognitive, sensory, and physical changes in later life that impact technology use.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); HDE 100C; or consent of instructor.

hde.name: — Cognitive Neuropsychology in Adulthood & Aging
hde.description: Course Description: Theories, methods, and findings concerning the relationship between cognitive processes and brain functioning. Readings, lectures, and in-class discussions cover research on normal younger and older adults, neuropsychological case studies, and selected patient groups (e.g., amnesia, schizophrenia, Alzheimer's disease).
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); HDE 100C recommended.

hde.name: — Special Topics in Human Development
hde.description: Course Description: In-depth examination into selected topics in the field of human development (e.g., brain development, parenting, nutrition).  Content varies from quarter to quarter.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Four upper division courses in Human Development (HDE).

hde.name: — Introductory Research Conference
hde.description: Course Description: Instructors lead discussions with undergraduate students who involve themselves in a research project. Research papers are reviewed and aspects of project proposals developed out of class are presented and evaluated.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Involvement in ongoing research; consent of instructor.

hde.name: — Internship
hde.description: Course Description: Supervised internship off and on campus, in community, and institutional settings.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

hde.name: — Peer Tutoring in Human Development
hde.description: Course Description: Assist the instructor of a Human Development course by tutoring individual students or small groups of students, leading voluntary discussion groups, or organizing other voluntary activities.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing  completion of course to be tutored.

hde.name: — Directed Group Study
hde.description: Course Description: May be taught abroad.

hde.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
hde.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

hde.name: — Early Development
hde.description: Course Description: Theory and research on the biological, social, cognitive, and cultural aspects of development from conception to the age of five years.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing; basic biology or physiology; one upper division course in psychology or a related field; one upper division or graduate course in developmental psychology (can be concurrent).

hde.name: — Middle Childhood & Adolescence
hde.description: Course Description: Theory and research on biological, cognitive, social, and cultural influences on behavioral development from age five years until late adolescence.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing; basic biology or physiology, and at least two upper division or graduate level courses in psychology or related fields.

hde.name: — Development in Adulthood
hde.description: Course Description: Theory and research focusing on social, personality, cognitive, and biological development from early to late adulthood. Emphasis is on theory development and continuity and change.

hde.name: — Adolescent Behavioral & Emotional Development
hde.description: Course Description: Analysis of recent theories, research methods, and major findings on adolescent behavioral and emotional development, including contextual and genetic influences on adolescence, pubertal transitions, and social/family contexts and processes. Emphasis on multi-level mechanisms underlying adolescent behavioral and emotional development.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HDE 200B.

hde.name: — Developmental Neuroscience & Adolescent Psychopathology
hde.description: Course Description: Introduction to human developmental neuroscience. Understanding of adolescence and its characterization as a time of risky and unhealthy behavior and vulnerability to onset of mental disorder as well as issues around plasticity of the adolescent brain and prevention/intervention.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Human Development, Psychology, Education, Neuroscience or consent of instructor.

hde.name: — Longitudinal Data Analysis
hde.description: Course Description: Introduction to longitudinal data manipulation, organization, description, and modeling in the multilevel modeling and structural equation modeling frameworks.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 204B; or equivalent graduate courses in statistics or consent of instructor; familiarity with multiple regression and the basics of matrix algebra.

hde.name: — Topics in Technology Use, Health & Aging
hde.description: Course Description: Principles from gerontology applied to older adults' use of technology to support health and well-being across a variety of domains (e.g., cognitive and physical fitness, social engagement) and contexts (assisted living, aging in place). Cognitive, sensory, and physical changes in later life that impact technology use.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in one of the following Graduate Groups: Human Development, Psychology, Communication, Education, and Nursing Science and Healthcare Leadership, or consent of instructor.

hde.name: — Theories of Behavioral Development
hde.description: Course Description: Consideration of enduring issues in theories of behavioral development; analysis of adequacy of major theoretical schools (e.g., social learning, Piagetian) as scientific theories.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in behavioral sciences.

hde.name: — Physiological Correlates of Behavioral Development
hde.description: Course Description: An overview of mechanisms of organismic development and the implications of developmental biology for the analysis of behavioral ontogeny; consideration of parallels between processes of organismic development and behavioral development in children and infra-human mammals.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

hde.name: — Research Methods in Human Growth & Development
hde.description: Course Description: Overview of qualitative and quantitative approaches to empirical inquiry in the social sciences, with a focus on theory and research methods in biological growth and cognitive and social/emotional development from prenatal period to death.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 013 or STA 013Y; or the equivalent and at least two upper division courses in Human Biology or Developmental Psychology.

hde.name: — Cognition & Aging
hde.description: Course Description: Manner in which cognitive processes are affected by aging as well as an understanding of the changes in the central nervous system occurring with aging.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HDE 200C.

hde.name: — Children's Learning & Thinking
hde.description: Course Description: Analysis of theories, research methods, and major findings of children's higher-order cognition, including origins of knowledge, development of problem-solving skills, reasoning strategies, and scientific concepts, with an emphasis on the underlying mechanism involved in children's thinking and learning processes.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HDE 200A or PSC 212 recommended.

hde.name: — The Context of Individual Development
hde.description: Course Description: Analysis of human development within the context of daily life. Contextualizing theories and methods of developmental psychology will be distinguished from contextual theories and methods. Developmental psychology models will be distinguished from child psychology models.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Human Development, Child Development, Education, Psychology, Anthropology, Sociology, or consent of instructor.

hde.name: — Developmental Psychopathology
hde.description: Course Description: Theories, current issues, and empirical studies of atypical development from infancy to adulthood that integrate multiple system levels from genes, neurobiology, cognition, emotion, family and peer dynamics to community and cultural contexts.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Human Development, Psychology, Sociology, a related social science, or consent of instructor.

hde.name: — Peer Relationships during Adolescence
hde.description: Course Description: Examines the role of peer relationships in adolescent development including forms and functions at the individual, dyadic and group levels. Ethnicity and cross cultural research will be discussed. Emphasis on methodology, including surveys, peer nominations/sociometrics, experimental, and observational designs.

hde.name: — Current Research on Family Relationships
hde.description: Course Description: Discussion of theories, methods, and current research on the nature and development of sibling, romantic, and parent-child relationships across the lifespan. Emphasis on interpersonal and family processes examined in ethnic/cultural contexts. Implications for individual development will be addressed.

hde.name: — Family Research, Programs & Policy
hde.description: Course Description: Examines the competing interests of research, policy, and service on current issues of family functioning and individual well being. Considers communication barriers between researchers, practitioners, and policy makers.

hde.name: — Seminar
hde.description: Course Description: Discussion and evaluation of theories, research, and issues in human development. Different topics each quarter.

hde.name: — Research Conference
hde.description: Course Description: Supervising instructors lead research discussions with their graduate students. Research papers are reviewed and project proposals are presented and evaluated.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

hde.name: — Research Issues in Human Development
hde.description: Course Description: In-depth presentations of research issues in particular areas of behavioral development.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate Standing in the behavioral sciences.

hde.name: — Graduate Internship
hde.description: Course Description: Individually designed supervised internship, off campus, in community or institutional setting. Developed with advice of faculty mentor.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of faculty (internship sponsor) and satisfactory completion of placement relevant course work, for example: EDU 213, EDU 216; HDE 222, HDE 242; LAW 272, LAW 273.

hde.name: — Group Study
hde.description: Course Description: Group study.

hde.name: — Research
hde.description: Course Description: Research.

hde.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
hde.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training.
hde.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

hph.name: — Student Facilitated Course
hph.description: Course Description: Student facilitated course intended primarily for lower division students.
hph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

hph.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
hph.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
hph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

hph.name: — Cannabis & Cannabinoids in Physiology & Medicine
hph.description: Course Description: In-depth scientific analysis of cannabis and cannabinoids, topics include biochemical, physiological, behavioral, pharmacological, social and therapeutic aspects of cannabinoids, with emphasis on the physiological impacts on major organ systems in humans and animals, and the potential medicinal uses.
hph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 100 or NPB 101 or NPB 110B; or consent of instructor.

hph.name: — Advanced Physiology of Animal/Human Disease
hph.description: Course Description: Centers on fundamental mechanisms and pathophysiological basis for animal and human diseases. Case-based and uses animal and human diseases to help exemplify the physiological consequences of organ dysfunction.
hph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 101 B+ or better or NPB 110C B+ or better; consent of instructor.

hph.name: — Internship in Human Physiology
hph.description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in physiology and related fields.
hph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; approval of project prior to period of internship by preceptor.

hph.name: — Directed Group Study
hph.description: Course Description: Directed reading, discussion and/or laboratory experience on selected topics.
hph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

hph.name: — Student Faciliated Course
hph.description: Course Description: Student facilitated course intended primarily for upper division students.
hph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

hph.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
hph.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
hph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Senior standing in biology, chemistry, physics, psychology, or engineering.

hph.name: — Student Facilitated Course Development
hph.description: Course Description: Under the supervision of a faculty member, an undergraduate student plans and develops the course they will teach under 098F/198F.
hph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

hph.name: — Student Facilitated Teaching
hph.description: Course Description: Under the supervision of a faculty member, an undergraduate student teaches a course under 098F/198F.
hph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

hph.name: — Advanced Physiology
hph.description: Course Description: Advanced course on fundamental principles of cell physiology, transport physiology, signal transduction, physiology of excitable cells, and muscle physiology.
hph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Physiology Ph.D. program or consent of instructor.

hph.name: — Advances in Computational Physiology & Pharmacology
hph.description: Course Description: Multi-scale biomedical modeling methodologies and applications, with emphasis on ion channel structure-function, computer-aided drug design, and membrane excitability. State-of-the-art techniques used for multi-scale modeling of biomedical systems and their applications.
hph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): No formal requirements; basic knowledge of mathematics, physics, chemistry, and biology helpful.

hph.name: — Group Study
hph.description: Course Description: For graduate students desiring to explore particular topics in depth. Lectures and conferences may be involved.
hph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

hph.name: — Research
hph.description: Course Description: Research.
hph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

hph.name: — Human Physiology
hph.description: Course Description: General and cellular physiology of neurons, muscle, and epithelial cells and systemic physiology of cardiovascular, respiratory, gastrointestinal, and renal systems.

hph.name: — Medical Neuroanatomy
hph.description: Course Description: Anatomy of the normal human nervous system, to include gross external and internal morphology of brain and spinal cord, and function neuroanatomy of motor, sensory and cognitive systems. Incorporates application of neuroanatomy to clinical problem solving.
hph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HPH 400; Block 1.

hph.name: — Cannabis & Cannabinoids in Physiology & Medicine
hph.description: Course Description: Provides an in-depth scientific analysis of current knowledge on cannabis and cannabinoids pertaining to human physiology and potential medicinal uses.
hph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

hph.name: — Physiological Principles in SICU SSM
hph.description: Course Description: Special Study Module, a four-week course on the topic: Care of the Critically Ill Surgical Patient: Use of Physiological Principles to Guide Treatment of Patients with Common Surgical Problems.
hph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; restricted to UC Davis School of Medicine students only.

hph.name: — Tutoring in Human Physiology
hph.description: Course Description: Assist instructor by tutoring medical students in preparation for one of the departmental courses that is a component of the required curriculum of the School of Medicine.
hph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Advanced standing or consent of instructor.

hph.name: — Directed Reading & Group Study
hph.description: Course Description: Directed reading and discussion on selected topics in human physiology.
hph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; medical students.

hph.name: — Research
hph.description: Course Description: Laboratory investigation on selected topics.
hph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; medical students.

hmr.name: — Human Wrongs/Human Rights
hmr.description: Course Description: Introduction to Human Rights and the problems they seek to address. Using key episodes of inhumanity like slavery, genocide, and racism. Examines how international movements for social justice led to the emergence of the international Human Rights system.

hmr.name: — Art, Architecture, & Human Rights
hmr.description: Course Description: Study of human rights as they relate to art, architecture, and cultural heritage. Examines museums, art collections, and cultural-heritage management, their relation to the cultural prerogatives of communities and indigenous groups, and protection of cultural heritage during war and conflict.

hmr.name: — Special Topics in Human Rights
hmr.description: Course Description: Thematic study of human rights. Topics may include contemporary or historical issues in the promotion, protection, and violation of human rights; human rights and the arts, religion, literature are possible topical areas.

hmr.name: — Genocide
hmr.description: Course Description: Comparative and critical study of the modern phenomenon of genocide from religious, ethical and historical perspectives.

hmr.name: — Human Rights & the Refugee
hmr.description: Course Description: Comparative, historical, global and theoretical study of the human rights of refugees and the concept of the refugee; analysis of refugee protection, resettlement and integration; study of United Nations, intergovernmental and non-governmental organizations and refugees.

hmr.name: — Human Rights
hmr.description: Course Description: Introduction to the interdisciplinary study of the origins, evolution, denial and protection of Human Rights.

hmr.name: — Human Rights Tools For Advocacy & Practice
hmr.description: Course Description: Practices in the field of human rights leading to improvements in people’s lives; recent political developments in the global application of human rights and strategic tools used to promote the realization of human rights standards. Key international and local NGOs and their work promoting the capacities of rights holder to claim and enjoy their rights and in persuading duty bearers to fulfill their human rights obligations.

hmr.name: — Human Rights in the Middle East
hmr.description: Course Description: Study of the experience of Human Rights in the modern Middle East, with special attention to the Human Rights issues raised by events of Arab Spring; Palestine-Israel conflict; history of genocide, mass killing and totalitarianism in the region.

hmr.name: — Human Rights, Gender, & Sexuality
hmr.description: Course Description: Gender and sexuality in the context of human rights. Topics include women's participation in the public sphere, the right to change gender, the right for family privacy, and the right to marriage.

hmr.name: — Human Rights & the Popular Imagination
hmr.description: Course Description: Arts, music, literature, film and television in the rise of human rights movements and the protection, promotion and violation of human rights. Topics may include: human rights & science fiction; human rights & the graphic novel; human rights & contemporary cinema; human rights & rock and roll.

hmr.name: — Art & Politics of Memory: Truth, Justice, Reconciliation & Human Rights
hmr.description: Course Description: Critical exploration of the role of art and memory in the dictatorships, authoritarian societies, civil conflicts, and genocides of the late 20th and early 21st centuries. Case studies focus on the violation of massive human rights and political and cultural conflict for truth, justice, and reconciliation in the aftermath of those violations. Emphasis on how memory is constructed and contested by states, artitists, writers, historians and different ethnic and political communities.

hmr.name: — Human Rights in Latin America
hmr.description: Course Description: History of the origins, denial and protection of Human Rights in Latin America. Emphasis on dictatorships, political violence, social resistance, democracy, justice, accountability, truth commissions, memory.

hmr.name: — Human Rights & Indigenous Peoples
hmr.description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary, global, and comparative study of human rights and the history, struggles, revitalization, and current status of indigenous peoples. Topics include the UN Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous People, settler colonialism, genocide, indigenous rights movements, and efforts towards justice, recognition, and restitution.
hmr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HMR 001 or HMR 134 or HMR 161 or NAS 001 recommended; or consent of instructor.

hmr.name: — The History of Human Rights in Europe
hmr.description: Course Description: History of the origins, development, and state of international humanitarian law (IHL) and international human rights law (IHRL) in Europe. Emphasis on Enlightenment-era and modern theories of the source, utility, and limits of human rights.

hmr.name: — Seminar
hmr.description: Course Description: Emphasis on current scholarly debate about the methods for analyzing and comparing diverse human rights issues with the intention of integrating disciplined study of the field.

hmr.name: — Human Rights Internship
hmr.description: Course Description: Participation in community service, Human Rights Studies outreach, collaboration with community groups locally, nationally or internationally culminating in an analytical term paper on a topic approved by the sponsoring instructor.  Students will work with faculty to develop, plan and implement an internship with a local non-profit organization, government organization, or similar institution with the purpose of exploring the practical implementation of human rights.
hmr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

hmr.name: — Directed Group Study
hmr.description: Course Description: Group study on focused topics in human rights. May be taught abroad.

hmr.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
hmr.description: Course Description: Opportunity for advanced undergraduate students to work with a faculty member in a focused manner on a topic or topics of human rights.

hmr.name: — History, Theory & Criticism of Human Rights
hmr.description: Course Description: Introduces the advanced study of Human Rights and the theoretical and practical elaboration of the international Human Rights system. Seminar engages with criticism of Human Rights and develops research and teaching within disciplinary and interdisciplinary frameworks.
hmr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

hmr.name: — Memory, Culture, & Human Rights
hmr.description: Course Description: Explores the multiple convergences among memory, culture, and human rights. Discusses diverse approaches to how societal actors in different historical, cultural, and national settings, construct meanings of past political violence, inter-group conflicts, and human rights struggles.
hmr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

hmr.name: — Group Study
hmr.description: Course Description: Group study on focused topics in human rights. Four-unit courses may serve as electives for the Designated Emphasis in Human Rights.

hmr.name: — Individual Study
hmr.description: Course Description: Individual study for the designated emphasis in human rights.

hmr.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
hmr.description: Course Description: Teaching Assistant Training Practicum.
hmr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

hum.name: — Humanities Forum
hum.description: Course Description: Reading and discussion of a single work representative of a particular culture, historical period, or genre and significant for its ongoing cultural impact in the humanities, sciences, social sciences, technology, and popular arenas. Attention to provocative implications for contemporary society.

hum.name: — Issues & Concepts in the Humanities
hum.description: Course Description: Small group discussions and preparation of short papers for HUM 001.
hum.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HUM 001 (can be concurrent); HUM 001 required concurrently.

hum.name: — Global Humanities Forum
hum.description: Course Description: Introduction to humanities topics and methodologies; analysis of major figures, works, and genres in world arts and literatures, with emphasis on relationships between history, society, and culture.

hum.name: — American Humanities Forum
hum.description: Course Description: Introduction to humanities topics and methodologies; analysis of major figures, works, and genres in American arts and literatures, with emphasis on relationships between history, society, and culture.

hum.name: — Medicine & Humanities
hum.description: Course Description: Evolution of the "medical arts" into the "science of medicine." Culture of medicine in the context of society, medical ethics.
hum.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Satisfaction of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

hum.name: — Animals & Human Culture
hum.description: Course Description: Meaning of human relations with animals studied across a variety of historical periods and cultures and from a variety of humanistic perspectives.

hum.name: — Animals & Human Culture: Discussion
hum.description: Course Description: Small group discussions and preparation of short papers for HUM 004.
hum.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HUM 004 (can be concurrent); HUM 004 required concurrently.

hum.name: — Travel & Travel Literature
hum.description: Course Description: History of travel from the age of exploration to the modern era. Contemporary trends in travel, including mas tourism, adventure travel, and ecotravel. Social, economic, and cultural issues related to modern trends in travel. Analysis of literary representations of travel.
hum.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Satisfaction of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

hum.name: — Introduction to Perspectives on Narrative
hum.description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary approach to the use of story across time, culture, and discipline. How the telling and retelling of particular stories reflect the values, concerns, and assumptions of their original audiences and genres.
hum.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Satisfaction of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

hum.name: — Don Quixote & the Modern World
hum.description: Course Description: Reading Don Quixote as emblem of modernity in the West. Issues of reality versus illusion, heroism, freedom and self-fulfillment, racial tolerance and love. Don Quixote in other cultural and popular media: film, dance, art, musical drama, and television. GE credit with concurrent enrollment in HUM 009D: ArtHum, Wrt.

hum.name: — Don Quixote & the Modern World Discussion
hum.description: Course Description: Small group discussions and preparation of short papers for HUM 009.

hum.name: — How to be a Critic: Understanding Cultural Products & Practices
hum.description: Course Description: Introduction to key topics and methodologies of interest to humanists. Series uses a variety of critical approaches to examine the cultural significance of subjects such as: fashion, film, architecture, music, food, dance.

hum.name: — How to be a Critic: Discussion
hum.description: Course Description: Optional discussion section can be taken concurrently with HUM 10. Small group discussions and preparation of short papers.

hum.name: — Witches: Myth & Historical Reality
hum.description: Course Description: Examines the historical construction of the witch. Four areas covered are: European pagan religions and the spread of Christianity; the "Burning' Times" in early modern Europe; 17th-century New England and the Salem witch trials; and fairy tales.

hum.name: — Language & Identity
hum.description: Course Description: Introduction to topics related to the construction of identity through language use, including geographical and social factors affecting language groups. Language ideology affecting linguistic groups, including bilinguals and non-native speakers of English.

hum.name: — Narrative & Argumentative Approaches to Major Current Issues in the Media, Culture, & Society
hum.description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary approach to contemporary issues (abortion, AIDS, civil rights, war and peace, welfare state) around which individuals, communities and institutions define themselves in American society, by applying principles of narrative theory to the narratives where those issues are embedded.
hum.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): English A or the equivalent.

hum.name: — Internship
hum.description: Course Description: Internships in fields where students can practice their skills.

hum.name: — Marx, Nietzsche, Freud
hum.description: Course Description: Study of major texts of Marx, Nietzsche, and Freud, selected with an eye to their impact on 20th-century economics, ethics, and attitudes toward eros. Particular focus on conceptions of the self and the individual's relation to society.

hum.name: — Topics in the Humanities
hum.description: Course Description: Analysis of interdisciplinary issues in the Humanities. Topics vary. May be taught abroad.

hum.name: — Internship
hum.description: Course Description: Internships in fields where students can practice their skills.

hum.name: — Directed Group Study
hum.description: Course Description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.

hum.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
hum.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

hum.name: — Topics in the Humanities
hum.description: Course Description: Topics in the humanities, selected by the instructor.
hum.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

hum.name: — Graduate Internship
hum.description: Course Description: Individually designed supervised internship, off campus, in community or institutional setting. Developed with advice of faculty mentor.

hum.name: — Directed Group Study
hum.description: Course Description: Directed group study.

hum.name: — Individual Research
hum.description: Course Description: Individual research in the humanities resulting in a formal written research report.

hum.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
hum.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training.
hum.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

hyd.name: — Water, Power, Society
hyd.description: Course Description: Water resources issues. How water has been used to gain and wield socio-political power. Water resources development in California as related to current and future sustainability of water quantity and quality. Roles of science and policy in solving water problems.

hyd.name: — Hydrologic Science Internship
hyd.description: Course Description: Work experience off and on campus in Hydrologic Science. Internship supervised by a member of the faculty.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division student.

hyd.name: — Directed Group Study
hyd.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

hyd.name: — Fluid Mechanics Fundamentals
hyd.description: Course Description: Fluid mechanics axioms, fluid statics, kinematics, velocity fields for one-dimensional incompressible flow and boundary layers, turbulent flow time averaging, potential flow, dimensional analysis, and macroscopic balances to solve a range of practical problems.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 009B.

hyd.name: — Irrigation Systems & Water Management
hyd.description: Course Description: Soil and plant aspects of irrigation and drainage. Soil-water principles including water storage and movement, plant response to irrigation, water use by crops, irrigation systems (i.e., micro-irrigation, sprinkler irrigation and surface irrigation), and related salinity and water quality impacts.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 007A; SSC 100 recommended.

hyd.name: — Evapotranspiration Principles, Measurement & Modeling
hyd.description: Course Description: Estimation of evapotranspiration (ET) for irrigation management and water resources planning; including the basic principles and key factors controlling evaporation and ET rates, methods of measuring these factors in the field and remotely, and determination of likely water requirements for crops and various landscape conditions as needed for water resources planning.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HYD 124 C or better; consent of instructor.

hyd.name: — Plant-Water-Soil Relationships
hyd.description: Course Description: Principles of plant interactions with soil and atmospheric water environments and practical applications to crop management (e.g., irrigation) and plant eco-physiology (e.g., drought).
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (SSC 100 (can be concurrent) or SSC 107 (can be concurrent)); (PLS 100A (can be concurrent) or PLB 111 (can be concurrent)); or consent of instructor.

hyd.name: — Aqueous Geochemistry
hyd.description: Course Description: Chemistry of natural waters; dielectric properties of water; thermodynamic and mass-action relations; metal hydrolysis; acid-base equilibria; metal-coordination chemistry; solubility calculations; electron-exchange reactions; sorptive partitioning; ion exchange; and dissolved organic matter.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 002B.

hyd.name: — Physical Hydrology
hyd.description: Course Description: Introduction to the processes that constitute the hydrologic cycle. Special emphasis on a quantitative description of the following processes: precipitation, infiltration, evaporation, transpiration, surface runoff, and groundwater runoff.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 009B; MAT 021B; HYD 100 recommended.

hyd.name: — Systems Hydrology
hyd.description: Course Description: General course considering hydrologic processes from a systems or statistical model perspective. General probability concepts are applied to frequency, time series and spatial data analysis. Linear systems are also considered in conjunction with Kalman filter techniques.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HYD 141 or ECI 142.

hyd.name: — Ecohydrology
hyd.description: Course Description: Movement and storage of water in individual ecosystems and the integrated functioning of water and biota at the watershed scale.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HYD 010 or HYD 141 or ESP 001 or ESM 100 or ESM 108 or ESM 120 or GEL 001 or GEL 050 or SSC 100; or consent of instructor.

hyd.name: — Groundwater Hydrology
hyd.description: Course Description: Global role of groundwater resources in society; groundwater in the hydrologic cycle; geology of groundwater; global, US, and California geography of groundwater; physical measures of groundwater occurrence and flow; water balance; modeling groundwater flow; principles of well construction; aquifer tests; groundwater quality; contaminant transport and monitoring; groundwater law, water quality regulations, and sustainable management.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 012 (can be concurrent) or MAT 016B (can be concurrent) or MAT 021A (can be concurrent).

hyd.name: — Water Science & Design
hyd.description: Course Description: Introduction to watershed engineering, storm water management, design of hydraulic systems. Topics include hydrological risk analysis, flood routing, design storms, open channel flow, pipes, culverts, spillways, and detention basins. Class project and field trips will apply theory to real-life problems.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (HYD 141 or ESM 100); (MAT 016B or MAT 021B); or consent of instructor.

hyd.name: — Hydrogeology & Contaminant Transport
hyd.description: Course Description: Physical and chemical processes affecting groundwater flow and contaminant transport, with emphasis on realistic hydrogeologic systems. Groundwater geology and chemistry. Fundamentals of groundwater flow and transport analysis. Laboratory includes field pumping test and work with physical and computer models.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HYD 144 or ECI 144; or the equivalent.

hyd.name: — Runoff, Erosion & Water Quality Management
hyd.description: Course Description: Practical hydrology and runoff water quality management from disturbed watersheds. Development of hillslope and soils restoration concepts and practice, modeling and application.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PHY 007B or PHY 009B); (MAT 016C or MAT 017C or MAT 021C); (ECI 142 or HYD 141 or ESM 100); or equivalent.

hyd.name: — Water Law
hyd.description: Course Description: Principles and issues of California Water Law.Types of water rights, groundwater rights and management, and protection of instream uses.Water projects, role of federal government and federal/state relations. Basic water quality acts, endangered species act, water transfers and current water issues.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor or upper division standing.

hyd.name: — Field Methods in Hydrology
hyd.description: Course Description: Measurement methods and data analysis for evaluation of water storage, movement and contamination in the field. Equipment such as data loggers, water and sediment samplers, pressure transducers, weather stations, surveying equipment, and flow meters will be used.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ERS 100 or HYD 141.

hyd.name: — Environmental Analysis using GIS
hyd.description: Course Description: Ecosystem and landscape modeling with emphasis on hydrology and solute transport. Spatial analysis of environmental risk analysis including ecological risk assessment, natural resource management. Spatial database structures, scripting, data models, and error analysis in GIS.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ABT 150 or LDA 150; or equivalent GIS experience and skills; general biology and/or ecology courses are recommended.

hyd.name: — Hydrologic Science Internship
hyd.description: Course Description: Work experience off and on campus in water science. Internship supervised by a member of the faculty.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of 84 units.

hyd.name: — Directed Group Study
hyd.description: Course Description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.

hyd.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduate
hyd.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Senior standing.

hyd.name: — Hydrologic Sciences Core Survey
hyd.description: Course Description: Considers the primary sub-disciplines while reviewing the fundamental scientific concepts/processes of the hydrologic sciences research community, and includes a basic writing component.

hyd.name: — Hydrologic Sciences Core Seminar
hyd.description: Course Description: Exposes students to the research underway in the Hydrologic Sciences Graduate Group as well as provide them the opportunity to present and refine their research through interaction with other students in the Graduate Group.

hyd.name: — Vadose Modeling & Characterization
hyd.description: Course Description: Principles and modeling of water flow and chemical transport in the vadose zone, with specific applications to soils. Topics include hydraulic properties, finite difference application to unsaturated water flow, parameter optimization, diffusive and convective transport in gaseous and liquid phases.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SSC 107; or consent of instructor.

hyd.name: — Precision Irrigation Systems & Management
hyd.description: Course Description: Advanced irrigation science and engineering for agricultural, horticultural, engineering, and hydrology graduate students. Precision irrigation techniques for application of water to meet specific requirements of individual plants or management units and maximum economic benefits of crop production.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ABT 110; SSC 100; HYD 110; EBS 145.

hyd.name: — Hydrology & Sustainability of Irrigated Lands
hyd.description: Course Description: Impact of irrigated agricultural on groundwater depletion, surface water and groundwater quality, soil salinization, downstream ecosystems, and seawater intrusion. Exploration of efficient resource use, and policies adopted in California to enhance sustainability of irrigated crop production.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ABT 110 or ESM 110 or HYD 110 or EBS 145.

hyd.name: — Water Resource Planning & Management
hyd.description: Course Description: Applications of deterministic and stochastic mathematical programming techniques to water resource planning, analysis, design and management. Water allocation, capacity expansion, and reservoir operation. Conjunctive use of surface water and groundwater. Water quality management. Irrigation planning and operation models.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HYD 141 or ECI 142.

hyd.name: — Climate Change, Water & Society
hyd.description: Course Description: Integration of climate science and hydrology with policy to understand hydroclimatology and its impact upon natural and human systems. Assignments: readings, take-home examination on climate and hydrologic science, paper that integrates course concepts into a research prospectus or review article.

hyd.name: — Hillslope Geomorphology & Sediment Budgets
hyd.description: Course Description: Exploration of theoretical and empirical foundations of sediment production on hillslopes using computer models and field experiments to promote an understanding of how watersheds evolve naturally and with human impacts.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HYD 141 or GEL 035 or ECI 142; or consent of instructor.

hyd.name: — Ecohydraulics
hyd.description: Course Description: Use of 2D hydrodynamic modeling to perform instream flow assessment by exploring flow-dependent hydraulic patterns at multiple spatial scales and extrapolating results with empirical and analytical functions to evaluate geomorphic resilience and ecological functions.

hyd.name: — Geomorphology of Estuaries & Deltas
hyd.description: Course Description: Survey of the processes and landforms associated with sediment deposition in the coastal zone. Application of geomorphic principles to coastal management issues.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HYD 141 or GEL 035; or ECI 042 or consent of instructor.

hyd.name: — Modeling of Hydrologic Processes
hyd.description: Course Description: Techniques used to model the spatio-temporal structure of rainfall and runoff are introduced. Procedures studied include those based on stochastic point processes, chaos theory, fractal geometry, and fractional noises.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HYD 141; STA 102; or the equivalents.

hyd.name: — Numerical Modeling of Groundwater Systems
hyd.description: Course Description: Finite difference and finite element techniques in modeling groundwater flow and transport. Fundamentals of constructing and calibrating models with hands-on applications. Methods and limitations of numerical solution of transport equations. Model interpretation and ethics.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 022B; (ECI 144; or HYD 145A); HYD 145B.

hyd.name: — Introduction to Geostatistics
hyd.description: Course Description: Statistical treatment of spatial data with hydrologic emphasis. Topics: theory of random functions, variogram analysis, Kriging/co-Kriging, indicator geostatistics, and stochastic simulation of spatial variability. Geostatistical software use.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 130A; STA 130B; or the equivalent.

hyd.name: — Practice of Groundwater Flow & Transport Modeling
hyd.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Selecting and building groundwater flow and transport models. Planning, preparation, execution, presentation, and review of modeling projects. Review of methods, assumptions, and limitations of groundwater models; practicing with MODFLOW, MT3D, associated GUI, and with other groundwater modeling software of choice.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HYD 269; (ECI 272B or ECI 272C).

hyd.name: — Analysis of Spatial Processes
hyd.description: Course Description: Characterization of homogeneous random fields; extremes and spectral parameters; geometry of excursions, local averaging; scale of fluctuation; non-Gaussian and irregular random fields; geostatistical applications.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 102; or the equivalent; HYD 273 or STA 273A recommended.

hyd.name: — Selected Topics in Environmental Remote Sensing
hyd.description: Course Description: In depth investigation of advanced topics in remote sensing applications, measurements, and theory.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ERS 186; consent of instructor, or equivalent; ERS 186L recommended.

hyd.name: — Seminar in Hydrologic Science
hyd.description: Course Description: Seminars and critical review of problems, issues, and research in hydrologic sciences. Oral presentations of research. Topics vary.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Graduate standing and background in Hydrologic Science.

hyd.name: — Group Study
hyd.description: Course Description: Group study.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

hyd.name: — Research
hyd.description: Course Description: Research.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Graduate standing.

hyd.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
hyd.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training.

hyd.name: — Hazardous Waste Operations Training
hyd.description: Course Description: Forty-hour course designed to meet the requirements of Federal OSHA regulation CFR 1910.120. Covers the health, regulatory, processing and safe handling issues/problems associated with working with hazardous materials.
hyd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing in College of Agricultural and Environmental Sciences.

imm.name: — Introductory Immunology
imm.description: Course Description: Comprehensive introduction to the principles of immunology.

imm.name: — Advanced Immunology Laboratory Rotations
imm.description: Course Description: Laboratory assignment in two research laboratories. Individual research problems with emphasis on methodological/procedural experience and experimental design. Student writes a project outline and gives oral presentation.

imm.name: — Advanced Immunology Laboratory Rotations
imm.description: Course Description: One four-week and one six week assignment in immunology research laboratories. Individual research problems with an emphasis on methodological/procedural experience and experimental design.

imm.name: — Cancer Immunology
imm.description: Course Description: Covers concepts in cancer biology, progression and immune evasion. It will also cover topics such as: immune surveillance, immune effector mechanisms and current concepts in immune therapy.

imm.name: — Topics in Innate Immunity
imm.description: Course Description: Covers current topics in the field of innate immunity through student seminar presentations and critical evaluation of the literature. Concepts include: pathogen recognition, intercellular communication, specialized cellular function and effector/signaling molecules.
imm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): IMM 201; or equivalent; IMM 293 preferred.

imm.name: — Topics on Neuroimmunology & Neuroinflammation
imm.description: Course Description: Topics will include a broad range of frontiers in neuroimmunology and neuroinflammation. Research articles in current literature will serve to guide in-depth discussions of experimental approaches, technical aspects of experimental techniques, data interpretation, and other relevant aspects of each topic.

imm.name: — Introduction to Critical Analysis of Immunology Research Literature
imm.description: Course Description: Introduction to critical reading of primary research papers in Immunology. Guided discussions on recent primary research papers provided to students before each class.
imm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): IMM 201 (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

imm.name: — Immunotoxicology Seminar
imm.description: Course Description: Seminar presentations dealing with principles of xenobiotic effects on immune system functions and specific examples of drugs and environmental chemicals exerting toxic effects on the immune system.
imm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Pharmacology/Toxicology, Immunology, Physiology, or Biochemistry.

imm.name: — Current Concepts in Immunology
imm.description: Course Description: Innate and acquired immunity as defense mechanisms against disease. Mechanisms regulating the distinct cell types driving these responses and current concepts in the literature.
imm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PMI 126; or consent of instructor.

imm.name: — Comparative Clinical Immunology
imm.description: Course Description: Clinical immunology in animals and man. Pathogenesis of representative infectious diseases, hypersensitive reactions, and autoimmunity. Emphasis on specific and nonspecific immune effector mechanisms to combat infections or mediate pathology.
imm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PMI 126; or consent of instructor.

imm.name: — Cytokines
imm.description: Course Description: Cytokines and their involvement in human and animal physiology/disease, molecular mechanisms and receptor signaling. Immune and non-immune actions. Overlapping/redundant functions (referred to as the "cytokine network").
imm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): IMM 293; or consent of instructor.

imm.name: — Advanced Topics in Immunology
imm.description: Course Description: Presentation and discussion of faculty research topics in Immunology
imm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

imm.name: — Mucosal Immunology
imm.description: Course Description: Basic concepts and current research topics in the field of mucosal immunology, with an emphasis on human immunology. Major emphases include innate and adaptive mucosal immunity, the gastrointestinal tract, the lung, lymphocyte trafficking, and mucosal vaccination.

idi.name: — Infectious Diseases of Humans
idi.description: Course Description: Integrates information on biological and molecular nature of the causative organism, modern diagnostics, treatment and prevention strategies, and the role of infectious diseases in contemporary society and throughout human history.
idi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Introductory knowledge in biology and chemistry recommended.

idi.name: — Research Internship in Internal Medicine
idi.description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in the division of Infectious Diseases. Undergraduates will have an opportunity to acquire research experience in clinical settings.

idi.name: — Infectious Diseases Research
idi.description: Course Description: Discrete problem requiring reading and actual manual effort in solution will be assigned to each student. Progress and results will be reviewed at intervals with instructor and via seminar presentation.
idi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; chemistry through organic chemistry (in addition, physical and biochemistry preferred), biology through basic bacteriology (in addition, microbiology and immunology preferred).

idi.name: — Epidemiology & Prevention of Infectious Diseases
idi.description: Course Description: Infectious disease epidemiology and prevention, with equal emphasis on human and veterinary diseases. Major categories of infectious diseases by mode of transmission.

idi.name: — Research in Infectious Diseases
idi.description: Course Description: Laboratory investigation contributing to the dissertation for a graduate degree.

idi.name: — Introduction to AIDS & Related Disorders
idi.description: Course Description: Familiarizes students with the diagnosis and treatment of individuals infected with the human immunodeficiency virus. Interview patients, observe patient care and participate in ongoing clinic research as well as examine alternative lifestyles.
idi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): First- and second-year medical students in good academic standing; consent of instructor.

idi.name: — Clinical & Social Care of the Injection Drug User
idi.description: Course Description: Lecture and guided clinical practice in a supervised clinical setting, focusing on the social and medical aspects of health care for injection drug users.
idi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; first- and second-year medical students in good academic standing.

idi.name: — Infectious Diseases Clinical Clerkship
idi.description: Course Description: Patients ill with infectious diseases, including AIDS, will be evaluated and presented at rounds and case conferences. Patients are also seen in the Infectious Diseases Clinic. Instruction in clinical microbiology and the proper use of the laboratory will be provided.
idi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Successful completion of two years of study in an accredited medical school.

idi.name: —  Outbreak Investigation & Infection Prevention
idi.description: Course Description: Outbreak investigation is a central aspect of infectious disease epidemiology. Gathering of clinical data and its analysis for surveillance underpins outbreak identification, response and control. Focuses on understanding routine and unusual outbreak and the application of methods for detection, investigation and control in both inpatient and outpatient settings as well as local and global environments.

idi.name: — Correctional Medicine SSM; Evaluation of HIV & Hepatitis C Patients
idi.description: Course Description: Primary agenda focuses on the evaluation of treatment of HIV and Hepatitis C patients in the correctional environment.

idi.name: — Research Topics in Infectious Disease
idi.description: Course Description: Discrete problem requiring reading and actual manual effort in solution will be assigned to each student. Progress and results to be reviewed at intervals with instructor and via seminar presentation.
idi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Successful completion of the first-year of study in School of Medicine; graduate students (approved for graduate credit); and/or consent of instructor.

ist.name: — Colloquium
ist.description: Course Description: Lectures, films, and readings on the interrelation between the arts and sciences.

ist.name: — Special Topics in Natural Science & Mathematics
ist.description: Course Description: Group study of a special topic in natural sciences and mathematics. Varies with topic offered.

ist.name: — Special Topics in Humanities
ist.description: Course Description: Group study of a special topic in humanities. Varies with topic offered.

ist.name: — Special Topics in the Social Sciences
ist.description: Course Description: Group study of a special topic in the Social Sciences. Varies with topic offered.

ist.name: — Seminar
ist.description: Course Description: Preparation of a research report. Normally taken with IST 008.

ist.name: — Seminar
ist.description: Course Description: Interrelation between the arts and sciences, focusing on a special topic.
ist.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): IST 009; consent of instructor; completion of 45 units with a minimum GPA of 3.250.

ist.name: — Introduction to Undergraduate Research
ist.description: Course Description: The nature of research at the undergraduate level.
ist.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): IST 009; consent of instructor; completion of 45 units with a minimum GPA of 3.500.

ist.name: — Topics in Integrated Studies
ist.description: Course Description: Discussion of the integration of the arts and sciences, focusing on a special topic.

ist.name: — Special Study for Honors Students
ist.description: Course Description: A program of research culminating in the writing of a junior honors thesis under the direction of a faculty advisor.
ist.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): IST 009; consent of instructor; completion of 90 units with a minimum GPA of 3.500.

ist.name: — Special Study for Honors Students
ist.description: Course Description: A program of research culminating in the writing of a junior honors thesis under the direction of a faculty advisor.
ist.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): IST 009;  consent of instructor; completion of 90 units with a minimum GPA of 3.500.

ist.name: — Tutoring in Integrated Studies
ist.description: Course Description: Tutoring in Integrated Studies  courses, usually in small discussion groups. Weekly discussions with the instructor on the subject matter of the course being tutored and on the art and craft of teaching.
ist.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of Director of Integrated Studies.

imd.name: — Seminar in Medical Ethics
imd.description: Course Description: Seminar Series covering the current topics in Medical Ethics.

imd.name: — Internship
imd.description: Course Description: Supervised internship in internal medicine and related fields.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

imd.name: — Directed Group Study
imd.description: Course Description: Directed group study in medicine and related fields.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

imd.name: — Undergraduate Research in Medicine: Molecular & Cell Biology
imd.description: Course Description: Undergraduate research in medicine, focusing on molecular & cellular biology.
