imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

imd.name: — Practicum in Community Health Clinic: Bayanihan Clinic
imd.description: Course Description: Through active participation in the medical aspects of community health clinics, the undergraduate student gains knowledge of the organization, administration, and problem-solving capabilities.

imd.name: — Internship in Internal Medicine
imd.description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in internal medicine and related fields.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

imd.name: — Practicum in Community Health Clinics
imd.description: Course Description: The undergraduate student, through active participation in the medical aspects of community health clinics, gains knowledge of the organization, administration, and problem-solving capabilities of these primary care facilities.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

imd.name: — Directed Group Study
imd.description: Course Description: Directed group study in medicine and related fields.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

imd.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
imd.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

imd.name: — Topics in Medical Ethics
imd.description: Course Description: The complex moral, legal and ethical dilemmas that patients, families, and health care providers face in today's clinics.

imd.name: — Cardiovascular System
imd.description: Course Description: Principles of etiology, mechanisms, diagnosis and management of the major diseases of the cardiovascular system. Included are ischemic, valvular, hypertensive, cardiomyopathic, pericardial, and electrical disorders.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): HPH 200; consent of instructor; graduate student status.

imd.name: — Medicine & the Law
imd.description: Course Description: Legal and bioethical principles and concepts in medicine. Topics include standard of care, informed consent, reproductive medicine, and end-of-life issues.

imd.name: — One Health: A Course on Global Health
imd.description: Course Description: Global health problems are complex and require culturally-sensitive, socially-acceptable, and action-oriented approaches to create practical and cost-effective solutions. Will examine major health problems created by the convergence of human, animal, and environmental influences.

imd.name: — Summer Institute on Race & Health
imd.description: Course Description: Using field trips, media, readings, and clinical experiences, eight-ten first-year medical students explore issues of race, health disparities and related issues in a four-week institute during the summer break.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

imd.name: — Hematology
imd.description: Course Description: Malignant disorders of blood cells and transfusion therapy. Covers acute leukemia, myelodysplasia, myeloproliferative disorders, lymphoma, and myeloma.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

imd.name: — Gastrointestinal System
imd.description: Course Description: Basic pathophysiologic principles of digestive diseases on which clinical concepts and judgments can be developed. Emphasis on pathophysiologic basis of gastroenterological and hepatic disorders with discussion of major disorders and their diagnosis and management.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval of Committee on Student Progress.

imd.name: — Pulmonary & Critical Care Medicine
imd.description: Course Description: Clinical aspects of respiratory anatomy, physiology, and pathology. Diagnostic procedures and a description of the major pulmonary diseases & disorders, and critical care medicine.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval of SOM's Committee on Student Promotions.

imd.name: — Cardiovascular System
imd.description: Course Description: Principles of etiology, mechanisms, diagnosis and management of the major diseases of the cardiovascular system. Included are ischemic, valvular, hypertensive, cardiomyopathic, pericardial, and electrical disorders.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval of the School of Medicine Committee on Student Promotions.

imd.name: — Nephrology
imd.description: Course Description: Fundamental aspects of disorders of body water, electrolytes and acid/base balance; major categories and mechanisms of parenchymal renal diseases; urinary tract infections.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval of Student Progress Committee.

imd.name: — Medicine Clerkship
imd.description: Course Description: Clerkship is divided into two, four-week blocks, one each at UCDMC and at Kaiser Hospitals. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty. On-going patient write-ups, rounds, conferences are required.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

imd.name: — SJVP Longitudinal Medicine Clerkship
imd.description: Course Description: Longitudinal Clerkship runs concurrently with Family Medicine, Pediatrics and Psychiatry for 32 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty. On-going patient write-ups, rounds, conferences are required.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

imd.name: — SJVP Longitudinal Medicine Clerkship
imd.description: Course Description: Longitudinal Clerkship runs concurrently with Family Medicine, Pediatrics and Psychiatry for 32 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty. On-going patient write-ups, rounds, conferences are required.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

imd.name: — SJVP Longitudinal Medicine Clerkship
imd.description: Course Description: Longitudinal Clerkship runs concurrently with Family Medicine, Pediatrics and Psychiatry for 32 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty. On-going patient write-ups, rounds, conferences are required.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

imd.name: — SJVP Longitudinal Medicine Clerkship
imd.description: Course Description: Longitudinal Clerkship runs concurrently with Family Medicine, Pediatrics and Psychiatry for 32 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty. On-going patient write-ups, rounds, conferences are required.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

imd.name: — Rural PRIME Internal Medicine Longitudinal Clerkship
imd.description: Course Description: Internal Medicine Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

imd.name: — Rural PRIME Internal Medicine Longitudinal Clerkship
imd.description: Course Description: Internal Medicine Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

imd.name: — Rural PRIME Internal Medicine Longitudinal Clerkship
imd.description: Course Description: Internal Medicine Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

imd.name: — Rural PRIME Internal Medicine Longitudinal Clerkship
imd.description: Course Description: Internal Medicine Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

imd.name: — Rural PRIME Internal Medicine Longitudinal Clerkship
imd.description: Course Description: Internal Medicine Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

imd.name: — TeachMS Longitudinal Medicine Clerkship (A)
imd.description: Course Description: Longitudinal Clerkship runs concurrently with Primary Care and Psychiatry for 24 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty. On-going patient write-ups, rounds, conferences are required.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

imd.name: — TeachMS Longitudinal Medicine Clerkship (B)
imd.description: Course Description: Longitudinal Clerkship runs concurrently with Primary Care and Psychiatry for 24 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty. On-going patient write-ups, rounds, conferences are required.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

imd.name: — TeachMS Longitudinal Medicine Clerkship (C)
imd.description: Course Description: Longitudinal Clerkship runs concurrently with Primary Care and Psychiatry for 24 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty. On-going patient write-ups, rounds, conferences are required.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

imd.name: — Directed Clinical Studies in Internal Medicine
imd.description: Course Description: Individual directed studies in extended preparation for modified curriculum or to complete a clinical rotation following a leave of absence.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

imd.name: — Directed Studies in Internal Medicine
imd.description: Course Description: Individual directed studies in extended preparation for remediation of all or part of clinical rotation. Clinical studies to accommodate and satisfy remedial work as directed by the Committee on Student Progress and approved by the course IOR.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

imd.name: — TEACH-MS Outpatient Internal Medicine
imd.description: Course Description: Two-week rotation. Participate in the clinical care of patients from underserved communities, working with outpatient Internal Medicine preceptors who are primarily based at the Sacramento County Health Center. Rotate through a variety of different outpatient clinics including: Primary Care, Same Day Access Clinic, Homeless Outreach Clinic, and Chronic Disease Management.

imd.name: — Medicine & the Law
imd.description: Course Description: Legal and bioethical principles and concepts in medicine. Topics include standard of care, informed consent, reproductive medicine, and end-of-life issues.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

imd.name: — Medicine & the Law
imd.description: Course Description: Legal and bioethical principles and concepts in medicine. Topics include standard of care, informed consent, reproductive medicine, and end-of-life issues.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

imd.name: — Climate Change: Implications for Clinical Practice & Population Health
imd.description: Course Description: Climate change and its associated environmental and social disruptions are and will increasingly lead to clinical and population health consequences for which clinicians, and health systems, will need to be prepared to best care for their patients and the populations they serve. Draws from the Global Consortium on Climate and Health Education’s set of Core Climate and Health Competencies for Health Professionals and places an emphasis on climate change and clinical practice.

imd.name: — Oncology: Research & Treatment of Cancer
imd.description: Course Description: Comprehensive review of current treatment practices of cancer and state-of-the-art research impacting treatment and prevention of cancer. Emphasis on epidemiology, molecular biology, and pharmacology.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Second-, third-, or fourth-year medical student and/or consent of instructor.

imd.name: — Correctional Health Care Clerkship
imd.description: Course Description: Covers Correctional Health delivery and the effects of detention and incarceration on health status. Special emphasis on problems unique to health care delivery in a prison setting. Student will spend time in clinical settings at three prison facilities.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student in good academic standing.

imd.name: — Mather VA Internal Medicine AI
imd.description: Course Description: Acting Internship in Internal Medicine for qualified 4th year Medical Students from the UC Davis School of Medicine at the Sacramento VA Hospital. Experiences will somewhat mirror those of AIs at UCDMC.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

imd.name: — Medicine Wards AI
imd.description: Course Description: Assume role of acting intern and be primary physician on medical ward under direction of medical resident and staff. Teams I-V take call every fifth night. Emphasis on evidence-based inpatient care.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MDS 431; consent of instructor; demonstrated ability to accept responsibility.

imd.name: — Acting Internship in Medicine Intensive Care Unit (MICU)
imd.description: Course Description: At UCDMC, student functions as acting intern on MICU service under direction of medical resident and staff. Responsibility for patients admitted to MICU. On call in hospital every fourth night.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of third-year in medical school; consent of Director of MICU.

imd.name: — Bayanihan Primary Care Clinic
imd.description: Course Description: Under the guidance and supervision of a physician, learn patient history taking, medical documentation, counseling, diagnosis and treatment of patients with chronic and acute disease. Provides exposure to the special needs of various ethnic and socioeconomic groups.

imd.name: — Medicos-Global Health Sciences
imd.description: Course Description: Travel to foreign country for four weeks to collaborate with faculty from local universities and work in urban and rural environments, including hands-on experience with clinic patients. Cultural exchange and awareness of global health care.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; medical students only.

imd.name: — Medical Spanish for Providers
imd.description: Course Description: Provides ample experience in Spanish patient interviews, supervision of interview styles and Spanish-language skills, discussion of common diagnoses, procedural consent, management/treatment plans, and patient education in Spanish to empower medical students to practice medicine with the nationally growing monolingual Spanish-speaking patient population. Curriculum adapted with permission from the Medical Spanish Taskforce.

imd.name: — TEACH-MS Outpatient Internal Medicine Advanced Clinical Clerkship
imd.description: Course Description: Two-week rotation with participation in the clinical care of patients from underserved communities, working with outpatient Internal Medicine preceptors who are primarily based at the Sacramento County Health Center.

imd.name: — Ambulatory Internal Medicine Externship
imd.description: Course Description: Hands-on primary care clinical experience in the ambulatory setting supervised by a general internist. Emphasis on evidence-based outpatient care.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): IMD 430; consent of instructor; demonstrated ability to accept responsibility.

imd.name: —  Acting Internship in Medicine Intensive Care Unit (MICU)
imd.description: Course Description: At UCDMC, student functions as acting intern on MICU service under direction of medical resident and staff. Responsibility for patients admitted to MICU.

imd.name: — Critical Evaluation of Landmark Studies in Evidence-Based Medicine
imd.description: Course Description: Primary objective is to prepare future physicians to effectively integrate evidence-based medicine into their clinical practice. While this course has an Internal Medicine emphasis, the skills the course aims to impart―formulating focused clinical questions, searching the medical literature, evaluating the quality of research, and integrating evidence into clinical practice, giving effective article presentations)―apply to all future clinicians, regardless of their specialty.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Fourth-year medical student.

imd.name: — Person Centered Assessment
imd.description: Course Description: Person-centered assessment modalities and diagnostic approaches with regards to Internal Medicine and its different subspecialties.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open to all medical students.

imd.name: — Medical Care for Underserved & Marginalized Communities
imd.description: Course Description: Review the evidence about health outcomes for marginalized communities, to use the frameworks of ‘structural competency’ and ‘implicit bias’ to understand phenomena that drive disparities, to study the cases of several underserved communities in the Sacramento area, experience first-hand community organizations that are providing care to marginalized communities and practice how to identify in the clinical setting unmet social needs and their impact on health.

imd.name: — Palliative Care: Essentials in Communication, Pain & Symptom Management
imd.description: Course Description: Spend one week with the inpatient palliative care service, one week with the inpatient pain pharmacy service, and two weeks with Snowline Hospice.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

imd.name: — Practicum in Community Health Clinics
imd.description: Course Description: Assigned to clinical settings that demonstrate ethnic, urban/rural, or other related aspects of clinical community health. Through active participation in health care delivery, learn to relate conceptual with practical aspects of primary health care.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical student with consent of instructor.

imd.name: — Palliative Care: Essentials in Communication, Pain & Symptom Management
imd.description: Course Description: Mix of didactic sessions and clinical time. Exposure to management of nociceptive pain, neuropathic pain and mixed pain syndromes. Introduction to the pathophysiology of pain, pharmacology of opioids and non-opioids medications, and management of pain, titration and equilanelgesic conversion of pain medications.

imd.name: — Medicine, Bioethics & the Holocaust
imd.description: Course Description: Concept of "evil" and the role of collaborators, bystanders and participants exemplified by the holocaust and compared to problems physicians face in practice today. Demonstration that evil emerges incrementally until taken for granted.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; medical students only.

imd.name: — Group Study in Internal Medicine
imd.description: Course Description: Special study for medical students which may involve laboratory or library research, ambulatory or inpatient care responsibility on campus, at UCDMC or off campus by specific arrangement.
imd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

imd.name: — General Medicine Reseach
imd.description: Course Description: General medicine research.

iad.name: — Introduction to International Agricultural Development
iad.description: Course Description: Theories, practices and institutions relating to agricultural development; the interaction of changing social, cultural and economic organization through successive stages of economic development; impact of new agricultural technology on underdeveloped regions.

iad.name: — Internship
iad.description: Course Description: Supervised internship, off and on campus, in community and institutional settings.

iad.name: — Social Change & Agricultural Development
iad.description: Course Description: How social and cultural factors influence technological change in agriculture; theories of diffusion of innovations; social impact analysis and technology assessment.
iad.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Introductory social science course (Anthropology (ANT), Sociology (SOC), Economics (ECN), International Agricultural Development (IAD)).

iad.name: — Equipment & Technology for Small Farms
iad.description: Course Description: Types and characteristics of agricultural equipment and technologies appropriate for small commercial farming. Adjustment and calibration of equipment. Selection of and budgeting for equipment.

iad.name: — Agroforestry: Global & Local Perspectives
iad.description: Course Description: Traditional and evolving use of trees in agricultural ecosystems; their multiple roles in environmental stabilization and production of food, fuel, and fiber; and socioeconomic barriers to the adoption and implementation of agroforestry practices.
iad.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 002 or BIS 001C or BIS 002C; (PLS 142 or PLS 150 or BIS 002B); or general ecology course in lieu of PLS 142 or PLS 150 or BIS 002B.

iad.name: — Program Development for International Agriculture
iad.description: Course Description: Principles of leadership and management for international agricultural development. Organizations and organizational behavior, and the implications for planning and administering organizations involved in the global development effort.

iad.name: — Proseminar in International Agricultural Development
iad.description: Course Description: Presentation and discussion of current topics in international agricultural development by visiting lecturers, staff and students.

iad.name: — Internship
iad.description: Course Description: Supervised internship, off and on campus, in community and institutional settings.

iad.name: — Directed Group Study
iad.description: Course Description: Directed group study.

iad.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
iad.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

iad.name: — Philosophy & Practice of Agricultural Development
iad.description: Course Description: Introduces key elements of philosophy and practice of agricultural development in less developed countries; major paradigms of development; historical context within which these paradigms operate; various development techniques and initiatives emerging from agricultural production to institutional capacity building and management.

iad.name: — Economics of Small Farms & Farming Systems
iad.description: Course Description: Economic perspective on small farm development. Establishes a basis for predicting farmers' responses to changes in the economic environment, and for proposing government policies to increase small farm production and improve farmer and national welfare.
iad.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ARE 100A or ECN 100; or the equivalent.

iad.name: — Analysis & Determinants of Farming Systems
iad.description: Course Description: Unifying concepts of cropping systems in temperate and tropical climatic zones; agroecosystems stability, diversity and sustainability; management strategies, resource use efficiency and their interactions; role of animals, their impact on energy use efficiency, nutrient cycling, and providing food and power.
iad.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 110C or PLS 111; or the equivalent.

iad.name: — Project Planning & Evaluation
iad.description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary setting for application of student skills and specialization to a "real world" development project. Focus on team-building and effective interdisciplinary problem-solving methods, with the objective of producing a project document and presentation within a specified deadline.
iad.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): IAD 200N; or consent of instructor.

iad.name: — Seminar in International Agricultural Development
iad.description: Course Description: Discussion and critical evaluation of advanced topics and issues in international agricultural development.

iad.name: — Topics in International Agricultural Development
iad.description: Course Description: Selected topics dealing with current issues in agricultural development in lesser developed nations. Variable content.

iad.name: — Graduate Internship
iad.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Individually designed supervised internship, off or on campus, in community, business or institutional setting. Developed with advice of faculty mentor and Humphrey Coordinator.
iad.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Participation in H. Humphrey Fellow Program or consent of instructor.

iad.name: — Directed Group Study
iad.description: Course Description: Directed group study.

iad.name: — Research
iad.description: Course Description: Research.

iad.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
iad.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.

icl.name: — Orientation in United States Law
icl.description: Course Description: Investigation of the Common Law System of the United States. Includes structure of the U.S. government, Constitutional law, contracts, torts, real property, consumer law, securities law, intellectual property, antitrust, taxation, labor law, environmental law, ethics, remedies, legal research and trial practice.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — Fundamentals in United States Law
icl.description: Course Description: Investigation of the Common Law System of the U.S. Includes the American constitutional system, the American judiciary, the American civil trial, and foundational substantive and procedural law such as real property, torts, criminal law and procedure, civil procedure, and contracts.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — Advanced Topics in United States Law
icl.description: Course Description: Orientation to advanced topics in U.S. law: Intellectual Property (including copyright and trademarks), Commercial and Consumer Law, Advanced Contracts, Antitrust, Taxation, Remedies, Labor Law, Environmental Law, Dispute Resolution, Remedies and introduction to trial techniques and legal research/writing.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — Introduction to Contracts
icl.description: Course Description: Examines sorts of promises that are enforced and the nature of protection given promissory obligations in both commercial and noncommercial transactions. Inquiry is made into the means by which traditional doctrine adjusts to changing social demands.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — Introduction to Contracts Formation
icl.description: Course Description: Examines formation of the sorts of promises that are enforced and the nature of protection given promissory obligations in both commercial and noncommercial transactions. Inquiry is made into the means by which traditional doctrine adjusts to changing social demands.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — Introduction to Contracts Formation
icl.description: Course Description: Examines formation of the sorts of promises that are enforced and the nature of protection given promissory obligations in both commercial and noncommercial transactions. Inquiry is made into the means by which traditional doctrine adjusts to changing social demands.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — Contracts Performance
icl.description: Course Description: Examines issues of performing promises that are enforceable and possible breach of promissory obligations in both commercial and noncommercial transactions. Inquiry is made into the means by which traditional doctrine adjusts to changing social demands.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — Contract Performance
icl.description: Course Description: Examines issues of performing promises that are enforceable and possible breach of promissory obligations in both commercial and noncommercial transactions. Inquiry is made into the means by which traditional doctrine adjusts to changing social demands.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ICL 202A; or equivalent; Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — Civil Procedure
icl.description: Course Description: Study of the fundamental and recurrent problems in civil actions including the methods used by federal and state courts to resolve civil disputes.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — International Joint Ventures
icl.description: Course Description: International and U.S. business and legal transactions. Legal planning, problem solving, decision making and negotiations related to the break-up and dissolution of a major international joint venture. U.S. laws including finance, tax, bankruptcy, labor, antitrust, environmental, corporate structures and intellectual property. Offered every three years.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ICL 201; Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — Introduction to Constitutional Law
icl.description: Course Description: Principles, doctrines and controversies regarding the structure and division of powers in American government. Includes judicial review, jurisdiction, standing to sue, federalism, federal and state powers and immunities, and the separation of powers among branches of the federal government.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — Overview of US Constitutional Law
icl.description: Course Description: Principles, doctrines and controversies regarding the structure and division of powers in American government. Includes judicial review, jurisdiction, standing to sue, federalism, federal and state powers and immunities, and the separation of powers among branches of the federal government.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — Overview of US Constitutional Law
icl.description: Course Description: Principles, doctrines and controversies regarding the structure and division of powers in American government. Includes judicial review, jurisdiction, standing to sue, federalism, federal and state powers and immunities, and the separation of powers among branches of the federal government.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — Constitutional Law–Protection of Individual Rights
icl.description: Course Description: Principles, doctrines and controversies regarding the U.S. Constitution Bill of Rights, including due process of law, equal protection, freedom of expression, freedom of religion, state action, and congressional legislation in aid of civil rights and liberties.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — Negotiations & Alternative Dispute Resolution
icl.description: Course Description: Mechanisms for resolving disputes including the alternatives to litigation such as negotiation, mediation, and arbitration. Advantages and disadvantages of each approach. Offered every three years.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ICL 201; Law school education or the equivalent.

icl.name: — Introduction to Negotiation
icl.description: Course Description: Introduction to theoretical and empirical approaches to negotiation for the purposes of making deals and resolving legal disputes.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — Introduction to Negotiation
icl.description: Course Description: Introduction to theoretical and empirical approaches to negotiation for the purposes of making deals and resolving legal disputes.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — Advanced Negotiation
icl.description: Course Description: Principles and empirical approaches to advanced negotiations including negotiation framework, models, styles, multiple party/issue negotiations and settlements.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — Advanced Negotiation
icl.description: Course Description: Principles and empirical approaches to advanced negotiations including negotiation framework, models, styles, multiple party/issue negotiations and settlements.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — Business Associations
icl.description: Course Description: Legal rules and concepts applicable to business associations including general partnerships, joint ventures, limited partnerships, limited liability entities, and sole proprietorships.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ICL 201; Law school education or the equivalent.

icl.name: — Business Associations
icl.description: Course Description: Legal rules and concepts applicable to business associations including general partnerships, joint ventures, limited partnerships, limited liability entities, and sole proprietorships.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ICL 201; Law school education or the equivalent.

icl.name: — International Business Transactions
icl.description: Course Description: Legal problems arising from international business transactions. Focus on international sales contracts, choice of law, forum selection clauses, letters of credit, transfers of technology, regulation of bribery, development of joint ventures, repatriation of profits, foreign exchange problems, and national efforts to control imports.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ICL 201; Law school education or the equivalent.

icl.name: — Alternative Dispute Resolution
icl.description: Course Description: Introduces students to a wide variety of alternative dispute resolution procedures, with an in-depth emphasis on negotiation, mediation and arbitration.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — Advanced Writing Project
icl.description: Course Description: The completion of a written research project under the active supervision of a faculty member in satisfaction of the research-writing requirement.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ICL 201; Law school education or the equivalent.

icl.name: — United States Taxation of Multinational Investments
icl.description: Course Description: An analysis of the United States taxation of multinational investments including jurisdiction of tax, the U.S. tax system, foreign tax credits, treaties, and transfer pricing.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ICL 201; Law school education or the equivalent.

icl.name: — Criminal Procedure
icl.description: Course Description: Federal constitutional limits on government authority to gather evidence and investigate crime. Includes Fourth Amendment limits on search, seizure, and arrest; Fifth Amendment privilege against self-incrimination; Sixth Amendment right to counsel.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — Mergers & Acquisitions Law
icl.description: Course Description: Practical approach to mergers and acquisitions with an in-depth look at the planning, negotiation and completion of mergers and acquisitions.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — Mergers & Acquisitions Law
icl.description: Course Description: Practical approach to mergers and acquisitions with an in-depth look at the planning, negotiation and completion of mergers and acquisitions.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — United States Securities Law & Regulation
icl.description: Course Description: Structural and jurisdictional issues associated with securities practice. Topics include the regulation of public offerings, transactions by corporate insiders, regulation of corporate disclosure and conduct, and the liabilities of corporations and individuals under anti-fraud provisions.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ICL 201; Law school education or the equivalent.

icl.name: — Mediation
icl.description: Course Description: Introduction to the mediation process. Development of communication skills, the ability to analyze disputes, to understand why mediations succeed or fail, and understand the advantages and limitations of mediation as a method of resolving disputes.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — Private International Law
icl.description: Course Description: Operating law across national borders; emphasis on methods of resolving international disputes. International aspects of jurisdiction, choice of law, judgment enforcement, forum choice, process service, taking of evidence, foreign sovereign immunity, extraterritorial regulation of antitrust, securities; other national laws.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ICL 201; Law school education or the equivalent.

icl.name: — Private International Law
icl.description: Course Description: Operating law across national borders; emphasis on methods of resolving international disputes. International aspects of jurisdiction, choice of law, judgment enforcement, forum choice, process service, taking of evidence, foreign sovereign immunity, extraterritorial regulation of antitrust, securities; other national laws.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ICL 201; Law school education or the equivalent.

icl.name: — Banking Law
icl.description: Course Description: Institutional features of international banking transactions, the structure of a large financial deal, and the mechanics of overseeing large loans. Emphasis on negotiable instruments such as bills of lading, letters of credit, standby letters of credit, and interbank transactions. Offered every three years.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ICL 201; Law school education or the equivalent.

icl.name: — Comparative Law
icl.description: Course Description: A comparative study of the development of schools of legal thought, chiefly Common law systems and Civil law traditions. Attention to the historical reasons for their divergence, contemporary aproaches to universal problems such as succession, torts, and contracts, the cross-fertilization of laws and difficulties commonly associated with importing foreign law into new territory.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ICL 201; Law school education or the equivalent.

icl.name: — International Trade Law
icl.description: Course Description: An investigation of global trading systems including international trade in goods and services, e-commerce, international intellectual property, international tax planning and investment. Includes substantive and procedural provisions of the World Trade Organization (WTO) and the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA). Offered every three years.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ICL 201; Law school education or the equivalent.

icl.name: — United States Litigation Issues
icl.description: Course Description: Prevention and resolution of disputes in international commerce. Emphasis on preparing for a trial in the United States. Includes the study of pre-trial motions, jury selection, opening statements, rules of evidence, closing arguments, and the selection of appropriate strategies. Offered every three years.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ICL 201; Law school education or the equivalent.

icl.name: — Antitrust
icl.description: Course Description: Historical and institutional background of Antitrust law in the United States. The statutory framework including price fixing, limits on distribution, monopolization and mergers, and reporting requirements.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ICL 201; Law school education or the equivalent.

icl.name: — Financing International Transactions
icl.description: Course Description: How capital is raised in international markets. Investment strategies for U.S. markets. Taxation of financial investments, international currency regulation, and assessing rates of return on international investments. Offered every three years.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ICL 201; Law school education or the equivalent.

icl.name: — Intellectual Property
icl.description: Course Description: Intensive study of intellectual property law. Including copyright, trademark and patent law and unfair competition.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ICL 201; Law school education or the equivalent.

icl.name: — Intellectual Property
icl.description: Course Description: Intensive study of intellectual property law. Including copyright, trademark and patent law and unfair competition.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ICL 201; Law school education or the equivalent.

icl.name: — Contract Remedies
icl.description: Course Description: Covers a range of remedies for contract breach: remedies under common law and equity, liquidated damages clauses, remedies for mistake and unconscionability as well as breach of contract for the Sale of Goods under UCC Article II.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — Contract Remedies
icl.description: Course Description: Covers a range of remedies for contract breach: remedies under common law and equity, liquidated damages clauses, remedies for mistake and unconscionability as well as breach of contract for the Sale of Goods under UCC Article II.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ICL 202A; ICL 202B; or equivalent; Law School education or equivalent.

icl.name: — Environmental Law
icl.description: Course Description: Introduction to federal and state environmental law. Historical development of environmental law; the role of courts, the legislature and the executive branch in the development and implementation of environmental policy. Review of major statutes.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — Licensing Academy in Intellectual Property & Technology Commercialization
icl.description: Course Description: Intellectual property as it relates to current forms of legal protection and how new innovations fit into these models, including public-private technology transfer, patents, institutional objectives, technology transfer offices, startups, and licenses.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ICL 201; Law School education or equivalent.

icl.name: — American Legal System Research Seminar
icl.description: Course Description: American legal system and its structure. Legal research methodologies and presentation with attention to analysis, synthesis, organization, and editing techniques common to legal writing.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ICL 201; Law School education or equivalent.

icl.name: — International Commercial Law Seminar
icl.description: Course Description: Advanced seminar on a current topic in International Commercial Law. Offered at the University of Cologne in Cologne, Germany for two weeks each summer.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ICL 201; Law School education or equivalent.

icl.name: — International Commercial Law Seminar
icl.description: Course Description: Advanced seminar in a current topic in International Commercial Law. Topic changes each year course is offered.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — International Commercial Law Seminar
icl.description: Course Description: Advanced seminar in a current topic in International Commercial Law. Topic changes each year course is offered.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Law school education or equivalent.

icl.name: — Advanced Research in Legal Problems
icl.description: Course Description: Student individualized research projects under faculty supervision.
icl.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ICL 201; Law School education or equivalent.

ire.name: — Global Interdependence
ire.description: Course Description: Development of the concept of global interdependence along its political, economic, demographic, cultural, technological, and environmental dimensions. Focus on the ways societies and states interact. Provides the foundation for upper division multidisciplinary work in international relations.

ire.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
ire.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.

ire.name: — The Political Economy of International Migration
ire.description: Course Description: Analysis of worldwide migration patterns, and social scientific theories of international and transnational migration. Focus in economical, political, and social impact of immigration and potential for international and regional cooperation.
ire.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SOC 001, SOC 002, SOC 003, or SOC 004 recommended.

ire.name: — Topics in International Relations
ire.description: Course Description: Selected topics in international relations. Variable content.

ire.name: — International Relations Internship
ire.description: Course Description: Work experience in international relations, with term paper summarizing the practical experience of the student.
ire.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

ire.name: — Special Study for Honors Students
ire.description: Course Description: Directed reading, research, and writing on topics selected by students and instructor culminating in preparation of a senior honors thesis under direction of a faculty advisor.
ire.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open only to majors of senior standing who qualify for Honors Program.

ita.name: — Studies in Italian Cinema
ita.description: Course Description: Introduction to Italian cinema through its genres. Focus is on cinema as a reflection of and a comment on modern Italian history. Film will be studied as an artistic medium and as a form of mass communication.

ita.name: — Lower Division Seminar

ita.name: — Directed Group Study

ita.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Instruction and practice in expository writing in Italian, with emphasis on advanced grammar, organization, and vocabulary building. May be taught abroad.

ita.name: — Italian Translation & Style
ita.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Practice in translation from Italian to English and English to Italian, using literary and nonliterary texts of different styles. Analysis of linguistic problems and elements of style contained in the translation material.
ita.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ITA 009 or ITA 009S; consent of instructor.

ita.name: — Italian Translation & Style
ita.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Practice in translation from Italian to English and English to Italian, using literary and non-literary texts of different styles. Analysis of linguistic problems and elements of style contained in the translation material. May be taught abroad.
ita.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ITA 009 or ITA 009S.

ita.name: — Introduction to Italian Literature
ita.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduction to the study of the principal authors, works, and movements of the Medieval, Renaissance, and Early Modern periods in Italy.
ita.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ITA 009 or ITA 009S; consent of instructor.

ita.name: — Survey of Italian Culture & Institutions
ita.description: Course Description: Assessment of the impact of regional autonomy on Italian cultural life from the Middle Ages to the present. Special emphasis will be placed upon achievements in literature, the arts, philosophy, and socio-political institutions. Taught in English.

ita.name: — Survey of Italian Culture & Institutions
ita.description: Course Description: Assessment of the impact of regional autonomy on Italian cultural life from the Middle Ages to the present. Special emphasis will be placed upon achievements in literature, the arts, philosophy, and socio-political institutions. May be taught abroad.

ita.name: — Contemporary Issues in Italian Culture & Society
ita.description: Course Description: Analysis of cultural issues in contemporary Italy: Myth and reality of imagined Italies, Italian identities; immigration and race relations; the media and popular culture. Taught in Englsih.

ita.name: — Contemporary Issues in Italian Culture & Society
ita.description: Course Description: Analysis of cultural issues in contemporary Italy; myth and reality of imagined Italies; Italian identities; immigration and race relations; the media and popular culture. May be taught abroad & in English.

ita.name: — Medieval & Renaissance Poetry: St. Francis to Petrarch
ita.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Study of the origins of Italian religious and secular poetry of the 13th and 14th centuries. Diversified poetry is illustrated in works of St. Francis, Dante, Cavalcanti, Petrarch, the Sicilian School, the Sweet New Style Poets, and other authors.
ita.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ITA 009 or ITA 009S; consent of instructor, or the equivalent.

ita.name: — Dante Alighieri, Divina Commedia (Inferno, Purgatorio, Paradiso)
ita.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Study of Dante Alighieri's Divina Commedia, and its role in the development of Italian language and literature. Emphasis will be placed on reading the whole poem within the historical context of the Middle Ages.
ita.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ITA 009 or ITA 009S; consent of instructor, or equivalent.

ita.name: — Boccaccio, Decameron, & the Renaissance Novella
ita.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Study of the development of the short story in Italy, as exemplified in Giovanni Boccaccio's Decameron, in his predecessors and Renaissance followers.
ita.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ITA 009 or ITA 009S; consent of instructor, or the equivalent course.

ita.name: — Studies in the Cinquecento
ita.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Analysis of key texts from the high moment of the Italian Renaissance. The political and aesthetic legacy of humanism will be foregrounded in relation to authors such as Ficino, Ariosto, Machiavelli, Aretino, Castiglione, and Tasso.
ita.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ITA 009 or ITA 009S; or consent of instructor, or the equivalent.

ita.name: — Italian Literature of the Renaissance & the Baroque: From Cellini to Marino
ita.description: Course Description: Continued examination into the loss of an ideal. Emphasis on the conflicts in Michelangelo and Tasso leading to Marino, with an excursus on Galileos role in the formation of a modern literary standard.
ita.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ITA 115A.

ita.name: — Italian Drama from Machiavelli to the Enlightenment
ita.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Development of comic and tragic forms as critical representations of their societal and historical contexts, i.e. Machiavelli and the logic of power, Baroque dramatists in the service of counter-reformation Italy, Goldoni's comedies and bourgeois social consciousness.
ita.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ITA 009; or consent of instructor.

ita.name: — Early Modern Italian Lyric
ita.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Examination of the poetic tradition influenced by Petrarch. Consideration of the relation between gender and genre in such poets as Petrarch, Bembo, della Casa, Tasso, Marino, Gaspara Stampa, Veronica Franco, Isabella di Morra.
ita.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ITA 009 or ITA 009S; or consent of instructor.

ita.name: — Italian Literature of the 18th Century
ita.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Development of modern Italian literature. Emphasis on the work of Goldoni, Bettinelli, Baretti, Parini, Alfieri, and Vico.
ita.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ITA 009 or ITA 009S; or consent of instructor.

ita.name: — Italian Literature of the 19th Century
ita.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Romanticism in Italy, including Manzoni, Verga, and Verismo.
ita.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ITA 009 or ITA 009S; or consent of instructor.

ita.name: — Italian Literature of the 20th Century: The Novel
ita.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Development of the novel from Svevo to the present. Emphasis on the work of Svevo, Levi, Moravia, Pavese, and Vittorini.
ita.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ITA 009; consent of instructor.

ita.name: — Italian Literature of the 20th Century: Poetry & Drama
ita.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Italian poetry with emphasis on Hermeticism; the theater of Luigi Pirandello and its role in the development of contemporary Italian drama.
ita.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ITA 009; or consent of instructor.

ita.name: — New Italian Cinema
ita.description: Course Description: Italian cinema of the 21st century in the context of profound cultural and social changes in Italy since World War II. Productions by representative directors such as Amelio, Giordana, Moretti, Muccino are included. Knowledge of Italian not required.
ita.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FMS 001; or consent of instructor; and upper division standing.

ita.name: — New Italian Cinema

Productions by representative directors such as Amelio, Giordana, Moretti, Muccino are included. Knowledge of Italian not required. May be taught abroad.

ita.name: — Topics in Italian Culture
ita.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: In-depth study of a particular topic in Italian Culture. Topics include: Italian Cities; Church and State; the "Southern Question"; Fascism and Resistance; 1968: Counter Culture, Feminism and Terrorism; Multicultural Italy.
ita.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ITA 009 or ITA 009S; or consent of instructor.

ita.name: — Autobiography in Italy
ita.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Development of representations of selfhood with particular attention to generic conditions, the confessional tradition and the problem of women's self-representation. Authors studied may included Petrarch, Tasso, Casanova, Alfieri, Zvevok, Sibilla Aleramo and Primo Levi.
ita.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ITA 009 or ITA 009S; or consent of instructor.

ita.name: — Italian Literature in English: Boccaccio, Petrarch & the Renaissance
ita.description: Course Description: Petrarch and Boccaccio and their relations to the Middle Ages and the Renaissance; the Renaissance, with particular attention to the works of Lorenzo de' Medici, Leonardo da Vinci, Machiavelli, Ariosto, Michelangelo, and Tasso.

ita.name: — Italian Literature in English Translation: Dante, Divine Comedy
ita.description: Course Description: Reading of Dante Alighieri's Divine Comedy, through the otherworld realms of Inferno, Purgatory, and Paradise.
ita.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Any course from the GE Literature Preparation List.

ita.name: — Gender & Interpretation in the Renaissance
ita.description: Course Description: Critical analysis of Renaissance texts with primary focus on issues such as human dignity, education and gender politics; "high" and "low" culture and its relation to literary practices.
ita.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

ita.name: — Masterpieces of Modern Italian Narrative
ita.description: Course Description: Analysis of major works of Italian narrative fiction from unification of Italy to present. Students will learn to use representative methods and concepts which guide literary scholarship. Consideration of works within European social and cultural context.
ita.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 003 or COM 002 or HIS 004C.

jpn.description: Course Description: Intensive course taught combining the work of JPN 001, JPN 002 and JPN 003. Introduction to Japanese grammar and development of all language skills in a cultural context with emphasis on communication. Taught abroad in Japan.

jpn.name: — Elementary Japanese
jpn.description: Course Description: Continuation of training in basic Japanese spoken and written skills.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 001 C- or better; or the equivalent language proficiency.

jpn.name: — Elementary Japanese
jpn.description: Course Description: Continuation of training in basic spoken and written skills in Japanese language. May be taught abroad.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 002 C- or better; or the equivalent language proficiency.

jpn.name: — Intermediate Japanese
jpn.description: Course Description: Intermediate-level training in spoken and written Japanese in cultural context, based on language skills developed in JPN 003.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 003 C- or better; or the equivalent language proficiency.

jpn.name: — Intermediate Japanese
jpn.description: Course Description: Intermediate-level training in spoken and written Japanese in cultural context, based on language skills developed in JPN 004.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 004 C- or better; or the equivalent language proficiency.

jpn.name: — Intermediate Japanese
jpn.description: Course Description: Intermediate-level training in spoken and written Japanese in cultural context, based on language skills developed in JPN 005. May be taught abroad.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 005 C- or better; or the equivalent language proficiency.

jpn.name: — Intensive Intermediate Japanese
jpn.description: Course Description: Special intensive course that combines the work of JPN 003, JPN 004, JPN 005, and JPN 006. Introduction to Japanese grammar and development of all language skills in a cultural context with emphasis on communication. Taught abroad in Japan.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 002 C- or better; or the equivalent language proficiency. consent of instructor.

jpn.name: — Masterworks of Japanese Literature (in English)
jpn.description: Course Description: Introduction to Japanese literature: readings and discussion in English of important works from earliest times to the present.

jpn.name: — Introduction to Japanese Culture
jpn.description: Course Description: Aspects of Japanese culture: literature, history, religion, art, language, and society. Taught abroad in Japan; in English.

jpn.name: — Japanese Language & Culture (in English)
jpn.description: Course Description: Classification and communication of experience in Japanese culture; principles of language use in Japanese society. Speech levels and honorific language, language and gender, minority languages, literacy. Role of Japanese in artificial intelligence and computer science.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 001 or LIN 001 or ANT 004 recommended.

jpn.name: — Basic Kanji
jpn.description: Course Description: Introduction and mastery of 300 basic Kanji or Chinese characters to establish a solid foundation in the novel and complex Kanji encountered while learning Japanese.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 001 C- or better; or consent of instructor, or equivalent proficiency of basic writing system (Hiragana and Katakana).

jpn.name: — Introduction to the Literature of China & Japan
jpn.description: Course Description: Methods of literary analysis and their application to major works from the various genres of Chinese and Japanese literature (in translation), including film. East Asian cultural traditions will also be introduced.

jpn.name: — Directed Group Study
jpn.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

jpn.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
jpn.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

jpn.name: — Japanese Literature in Translation: The Early Period
jpn.description: Course Description: Study of early Japanese literature from the Nara to the end of the Heian period through a broad survey of the major literary genres such as lyric poetry, court diaries, prose narratives, poem-tales, and classical Chinese writings.

jpn.name: — Japanese Literature in Translation: The Middle Period
jpn.description: Course Description: Study of the major literary genres from the 12th century to the second half of the 19th century including poetry, linked-verse, military chronicles, no drama, Buddhist literature, haiku, haibun, kabuki, bunraku, plays and Edo prose narratives.

jpn.name: — Japanese Literature in Translation: The Modern Period
jpn.description: Course Description: Modern Japanese literature from the late 19th century to the present with focus on the concept of modernity; in addition to the study of authors and genres, examines historical and cultural contexts. Lectures, readings and discussions in English.

jpn.name: — Modern Japanese Literature: War & Revolution
jpn.description: Course Description: Perspectives and sensibilities with which major modern Japanese writers have interpreted the traumatic and often poignant experiences of war and socio-political upheavals from the late 19th century to the 1970s. Lectures, discussions, and readings in English.

jpn.name: — Modern Japanese Literature: Hero & Anti-Hero
jpn.description: Course Description: Ways in which representative hero and anti-hero protagonists in modern Japanese literature perceive, confront, challenge, and resolve a wide array of social, political, and moral problems of their times. Taught in English.

jpn.name: — Japanese Culture Through Film
jpn.description: Course Description: Aspects of Japanese culture such as love, sexuality, war, the military, the family, the position of women, growing up and death as portrayed in Japanese cinema. Lectures, discussion, and readings in English. Films with English subtitles.

jpn.name: — Modern Japanese Autobiographies (in English)
jpn.description: Course Description: Exploring the modern and contemporary Japanese social and cultural landscape through critical analysis of modern Japanese autobiographies by prominent and other authors in the 19th and 20th centuries.

jpn.name: — Poetry of China & Japan (in English)
jpn.description: Course Description: A comparative approach to Chinese and Japanese poetry, examining poetic practice in the two cultures; includes a general outline of the two traditions, plus study of poetic forms, techniques, and distinct treatments of universal themes: love, nature, war, etc.

jpn.name: — Japanese Popular Culture
jpn.description: Course Description: Japanese popular culture, from its development during the early modern period to contemporary incarnations. Emphasis on major forms of popular culture that emerged in the 20th century, including manga, anime, and genre film.

jpn.name: — Modern Japanese: Reading & Discussion
jpn.description: Course Description: Readings in modern Japanese short stories, newspaper articles, and essays; conversation practice based on these readings.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 006 C- or better; or the equivalent language proficiency.

jpn.name: — Modern Japanese: Reading & Discussion
jpn.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Continuation of JPN 111.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 111 C- or better; or the equivalent language proficiency.

jpn.name: — Modern Japanese: Reading & Discussion
jpn.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Continuation of JPN 112. May be taught abroad.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 112 C- or better; or the equivalent language proficiency.

jpn.name: — Spoken Japanese
jpn.description: Course Description: Training in spoken Japanese for students with a basic working knowledge of the language. May be taught abroad.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

jpn.name: — Spoken Japanese
jpn.description: Course Description: Continuation of JPN 114A. Training in spoken Japanese for students with a basic working knowledge of the language. May be taught abroad.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 114A C- or better; or consent of instructor, or equivalent language proficiency.

jpn.name: — Spoken Japanese
jpn.description: Course Description: Continuation of JPN 114B. Training in spoken Japanese for students with a basic working knowledge of the language. May be taught abroad.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 114B C- or better; or consent of instructor, or equivalent language proficiency.

jpn.name: — Japanese Composition
jpn.description: Course Description: Development of skills in the techniques of writing Japanese. Practice in short essay writing with an aim toward mastery of the vocabulary and syntax of written style Japanese.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 006 C- or better; or consent of instructor.

jpn.name: — Culture & History in Kyoto
jpn.description: Course Description: Intensive course exploring the historical and cultural riches in Kyoto and its environs. May be taught abroad on-site in and around Kyoto, Japan.

jpn.name: — Intensive Modern Japanese: Reading & Discussion
jpn.description: Course Description: Introduction to basic Japanese grammar and development of more advanced reading, writing, and conversation skills in a cultural context. Combination of JPN 006, JPN 111, JPN 112, JPN 113; intensively taught abroad in Japan.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 005 C- or better; or consent of instructor, or the equivalent language proficiency.

jpn.name: — Advanced Japanese I
jpn.description: Course Description: First of three courses in a series of fourth-year Advanced Japanese which focuses on the levels of formality or politeness in conversation as well as socio-cultural aspects and topics in Japanese society.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 113 C- or better; or consent of instructor.

jpn.name: — Advanced Japanese II
jpn.description: Course Description: Second of three courses in a series of fourth-year Advanced Japanese which focuses on the levels of formality or politeness in conversation as well as socio-cultural aspects and topics in Japanese society.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 121 C- or better; or consent of instructor.

jpn.name: — Advanced Japanese III
jpn.description: Course Description: Third of three courses in a series of fourth-year Advanced Japanese which focuses on the levels of formality or politeness in conversation as well as socio-cultural aspects and topics in Japanese society.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 122 C- or better; or consent of instructor.

jpn.name: — Readings in Modern Japanese Literature to 1926
jpn.description: Course Description: Short stories and essays by Japanese writers of the Meiji and Taishô eras, from 1868 to 1926. Authors include Natsume Sôseki, Izumi Kyôka, Tanizaki Jun'ichirô and Akutagawa Ryûnosuke. Readings and discussion in Japanese with some emphasis on translation into English.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 113; or equivalent language proficiency, or consent of instructor.

jpn.name: — Readings in Modern Japanese Literature: 1920-1945
jpn.description: Course Description: Fourth-year level reading of representative works of modern Japanese literature including short stories, novellas, diaries, memoirs, poetry and excerpts from novels and plays from 1920 through the militaristic era, to the end of the war years in 1945.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 113; or equivalent language proficiency, or consent of instructor.

jpn.name: — Readings in Modern Japanese Literature: 1945-1970
jpn.description: Course Description: Continuation of JPN 131, but may be taken independently. Covers selected texts from the immediate post-war years beginning in 1945 down to 1970 and the post-war recovery.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 113; or equivalent language proficiency, or consent of instructor.

jpn.name: — Readings in Modern Japanese Literature: 1970-Present
jpn.description: Course Description: Fourth-year level reading in Japanese of fiction, essays and works drawn from other literary genres published since 1970.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 113; or equivalent language proficiency, or consent of instructor.

jpn.name: — Readings in the Humanities: Traditional Culture
jpn.description: Course Description: Fourth-year level reading of modern works by major specialists on traditional Japanese culture: history, religion, thought, art, international relations, and literary history and criticism. Focus is equally on developing reading skills and learning about Japanese culture.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 113 C- or better; or equivalent language proficiency, or consent of instructor.

jpn.name: — Readings in the Humanities: The Modern Period
jpn.description: Course Description: Fourth-year level reading of authentic modern writings on Japanese culture, history, philosophy, society, religion, law, politics, international relations, aesthetics, and comparative culture by prominent critics, commentators, and scholars.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 113; or equivalent language proficiency, or consent of instructor.

jpn.name: — Readings in Japanese Newspapers
jpn.description: Course Description: Fourth-year level reading of newspaper articles and other journalism in Japanese on a wide variety of subjects.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 113; or equivalent language proficiency, or consent of instructor.

jpn.name: — Readings in Contemporary Japanese Literature
jpn.description: Course Description: Readings of short stories and essays by contemporary writers. Representative writers include Yoshimoto Banana, Otsuichi, Suzuki Koji, Kyogoku Natsuhiko, Ogawa Yoko, and Murakami Haruki. Readings and discussion in Japanese with some emphasis on translation into English.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 113; or equivalent language proficiency, or consent of instructor.

jpn.name: — Readings in the Humanities:  Japan Today
jpn.description: Course Description: Topical essays focused on contemporary Japan. Themes center on defining Japan today in terms of its future and past such as through its urban society, trends in architecture, "soft power" industries, and "traditional" elements as mainstays of Japan's cultural currency.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 113; or equivalent language proficiency, or consent of instructor.

jpn.name: — Introduction to Classical Japanese
jpn.description: Course Description: Basic features of classical Japanese grammar through careful reading of selected literary texts such as Hojoki or Tsurezuregusa.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 113; or the equivalent language proficiency.

jpn.name: — Japanese Linguistics
jpn.description: Course Description: Introduction to Japanese linguistics, featuring key aspects of the Japanese language. Analysis of Japanese from the perspectives of phonology, syntax, discourse analysis, sociolinguistics and psycholinguistics.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 003; or equivalent language proficiency.

jpn.name: — Traditional Japanese Drama
jpn.description: Course Description: Survey in English of Japanese drama, focusing on traditional forms: noh, kyôgen, bunraku puppet theater, and kabuki, with some attention to modern theater. Texts of plays and secondary works on performance techniques and the composition of plays.

jpn.name: — Love, Sexuality & the Family in Modern Japanese Literature
jpn.description: Course Description: Modern Japanese literature from the late-19th century to the present with a focus on love and sexuality in various forms, particularly as understood through the evolving institution of the Japanese family. Lectures, readings and discussions in English.

jpn.name: — Tourism & Heritage in Japan
jpn.description: Course Description: Focus on related concepts of tourism and cultural heritage within Japan, with attention to questions of tradition, authenticity and nostalgia. Examination of cultural heritage sites on various scales, including built environment, national cultural forms, and local performances such as festivals.

jpn.name: — Introduction to Japanese Folklore
jpn.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Focus on narrative genres of myth, legend, and folktale, with additional attention paid to festivals, folk art, belief systems, and the development of folklore studies (minzokugaku) as an academic discipline. Examination of the relationship of folklore to ethnic and national identity.

jpn.name: — Japanese Literature on Film
jpn.description: Course Description: Survey of films based on works of Japanese literature, emphasis on pre-modern and early modern texts. Introduction to major directors of Japan, with a focus on cinematic adaptation. Lectures and readings in English. Films in Japanese with English subtitles.

jpn.name: — Japanese Women Writers
jpn.description: Course Description: Survey of women writers from earliest times to the present. Genres include poetry, narrative fiction, diaries, short stories, novels, and film. Representative authors include Murasaki Shikibu, Sei Shônagon, Higuchi Ichiyo, Enchi Fumiko and Ogawa Yôko. Readings and discussion in English.

jpn.name: — The Supernatural in Japan
jpn.description: Course Description: Depictions of the supernatural in Japanese history through the contemporary era. Overview of Japanese literary and visual arts and the socio-historical contexts of the supernatural. Lectures and readings in English. Films in Japanese with English subtitles.

jpn.name: — The “Other” in Modern Japanese Literature & Culture
jpn.description: Course Description: Modern Japanese literature and culture from the late 19th century to the present with focus on the concept of the “Other;” those seen as minorities (race, ethnicity, sexuality) or somehow different from mainstream society. Lectures, readings and discussions in English.

jpn.name: — The Culture of Japanese Food
jpn.description: Course Description: Study of Japanese food and the culture of eating and drinking in Japan. Attention to symbolism, historical development, aesthetics, identity and global contexts. Materials examined include critical sources as well as literary texts, art, and films.

jpn.name: — Japan Travelogue: Ethnographic Writing on Japanese Culture & People
jpn.description: Course Description: Focuses on ethnographic writing about Japan. Includes modern scholarly ethnographies, travel writing, blog posts, etc. Critical analysis of how the Japanese “other” is represented across time.

jpn.name: — Sexuality & Love in Premodern Japanese Literature
jpn.description: Course Description: Love and eros in opposite-sex, same-sex, marital, premarital, extramarital, commercial and “amateur” modes and in aristocratic, samurai and commoner milieus as reflected in works of literature produced in Japan between the 700s and 1867. Readings, lectures and discussions in English.

jpn.name: — Japanese Internship
jpn.description: Course Description: Work experience in Japanese language, with analytical term paper on a topic approved by instructor.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

jpn.name: — Special Thesis Honors Project
jpn.description: Course Description: Guided research, under the direction of a senate faculty member, leading to a senior thesis project on a topic in Japanese literature, culture, linguistics, or language studies.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; senior standing and qualification for the Japanese Senior Thesis Project.

jpn.name: — Tutoring in Japanese
jpn.description: Course Description: Leading of small voluntary discussion groups affiliated with one of the Program's regular courses.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of Department Chairperson.

jpn.name: — Directed Group Study
jpn.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

jpn.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
jpn.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

jpn.name: — Seminar in Modern Japanese Literature: Major Writers
jpn.description: Course Description: In-depth reading and critical analyses of major works by and critical literature on one or two prominent modern or contemporary writers such as Natsume Soseki, Mori Ogai, Shimazaki Toson, Akutagawa Ryunosuke, Tanizaki Junichiro, Abe Kobo and Oe Kenzaburo.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JPN 130 or JPN 131 or JPN 132 or JPN 133 or JPN 134 or JPN 135 or JPN 136 or JPN 137 or JPN 138; or the equivalent language proficiency.

jpn.name: — Directed Independent Study
jpn.description: Course Description: Directed independent study on a topic culminating in a term paper. Independent Studies may only be arranged with consent of the instructor and when graduate seminars are unavailable.
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

jpn.name: — Research
jpn.description: Course Description: Description:
jpn.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

jst.name: — Introduction to Jewish Cultures
jst.description: Course Description: Diverse Jewish cultures created over the past 2,000 years using examples from less-familiar communities such as India, China, and Ethiopia. Topics include the tensions between homeland/diaspora and questions of identity (race, nationality, culture, or religion).

jst.name: — Topics in Jewish Thought
jst.description: Course Description: Selected themes in Jewish thought in historical and social perspective. Traces the historical development of topics in Jewish thought such as Messianism, or focuses on one specific historical period, such as modern Jewish thought.
jst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): JST 010 or RST 023; or consent of instructor.

jst.name: — Selected Topics in Jewish Literature
jst.description: Course Description: Literature written about the Jewish experience, treated in its historical and social context. Examines literature written in one language, such as English, Hebrew, or Yiddish, or a theme, such as gender or modern identities, as expressed in different literary traditions.
jst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One lower division literature or Jewish Studies (JST) course or consent of instructor.

jst.name: — Israeli Writing Since 1960
jst.description: Course Description: Contemporary Hebrew literature, in translation, in relation to post-independence debates about religious, social, and political identity of the Jewish state; literary reflections of Israeli ethnic diversity and changing gender relations; modern Hebrew poetry and postmodern experiments in fiction.
jst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in American or European literature.

jst.name: — Readings in Jewish Writing & Thought in German Culture
jst.description: Course Description: Historical tradition of Jewish thought in the German cultural context; unique contributions of Jewish writers to culture of the German speaking world; what it means to be "other" in the mainstream culture.
jst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): RST 023; or consent of instructor.

jst.name: — Readings in Jewish Writing & Thought in German Culture
jst.description: Course Description: Historical tradition of Jewish thought in the German cultural context; unique contributions of Jewish writers to culture of the German speaking world; what it means to be "other" in the mainstream culture.
