law.name: — Advanced Writing Workshop
law.description: Course Description: Second- and third-year students produce a piece of academic writing that satisfies the King Hall writing requirement and is of publishable quality. Receive feedback both from the instructor and from one another in a workshop setting.

law.name: — Asian American Jurisprudence
law.description: Course Description: Legal, social, and political discourse on race relations has traditionally been framed in Black-White terms. Disrupts the traditional view by taking Asian Americans seriously.

law.name: — Labor Law
law.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Survey of the legislative, administrative, and judicial regulation of labor relations under federal law. Historical development of labor law, the scope of national legislation, unions, strikes, picketing, and collective bargaining agreements.

law.name: — Labor Law I
law.description: Course Description: Survey of the legislative, administrative, and judicial regulation of labor relations under federal law.

law.name: — Labor Law II
law.description: Course Description: Survey of the legislative, administrative, and judicial regulation of labor relations under federal law.

law.name: — International Litigation & Arbitration
law.description: Course Description: Current developments in international law, conflict of laws, civil procedure, arbitration, and comparative law in the context of transactions and disputes that cut across national boundaries.

law.name: — Introduction to Criminal Litigation; Pre-Trial
law.description: Course Description: Utilizes experiential learning techniques to teach advocacy skills during the life of a criminal case and simulates critical stages of the proceedings by conducting mock hearings throughout the semester.

law.name: — Policy Advocacy
law.description: Course Description: In-depth examination of the legislative process both within the California Legislature and from the advocates’ perspective. Train in key policy advocacy skills by legislative leaders and social justice advocates.

law.name: — Community Lawyering
law.description: Course Description: Study the need for community lawyering including the structural inequalities and privileges embedded in the legal system and society. Skills necessary for community lawyering as well as sites and models for practice will be examined.

law.name: — International Public Interest Law and Advocacy
law.description: Course Description: Simulation course introduction to the applied legal and policy skills necessary to become effective lawyers and advocates in the international public interest/nongovernmental organization community.

law.name: — Housing Law
law.description: Course Description: Survey course covers legal and policy issues related to developing, protecting and preserving affordable, safe and accessible housing and sustaining viable, diverse communities.

law.name: — Law & Rural Livelihoods
law.description: Course Description: Seminar considers rural manifestations of various legal, social and economic issues. Survey various subfields of legal study; e.g., criminal justice, poverty, environment and land use, local government, family, constitutional, agricultural, access to justice, as they relate to the rural-urban continuum. Debate rurality as an aspect of identity and consider its intersections with race, gender, sexuality, (dis)ability and other identity variables.

law.name: — Access to Justice
law.description: Course Description: Study of a variety of barriers that impede the access of unrepresented litigants to the courts–including poverty, racial bias, limited English proficiency and the digital divide–and critically examine existing solutions. Opportunity to develop and propose student's own solution to an access barrier.

law.name: — White Working Class & the Law
law.description: Course Description: Considers the social, cultural, economic, and legal situation of low-income and/or low-education whites in contemporary U.S. society.

law.name: — Practicum in Rural Community Advocacy
law.description: Course Description: Provides an opportunity to learn about Participatory Action Research (PAR) methods and community-­based lawyering in the context of rural community development and advocacy. Using these skills and knowledge to serve rural California communities.

law.name: — Pension & Employee Benefits Law
law.description: Course Description: Federal regulation and taxation of private pensions and employee benefits. Covers the Employee Retirement Income Security Act (ERISA) and Internal Revenue Code issues.

law.name: — Land Use
law.description: Course Description: Local agencies, developers, environmental interest groups, and others who regularly deal with the administrative and legislative applications of land use planning and development laws. Topics include zoning, general plans, local government land use regulation, and related areas of litigation. Expanding role of the California Environmental Quality Act.

law.name: — Legislative Process
law.description: Course Description: Fundamental elements of the legislative process, including legislative procedure; the legislature as an institution; lobbying; statutory interpretation, legislative-executive relations; and the legislature's constitutional powers and limitations.

law.name: — Legislative Intent Seminar
law.description: Course Description: Theories and principles of statutory and constitutional interpretation. Original intent vs. living constitution; permissible kinds of evidence for determining legislative intent; canons of construction; extent to which initiatives should be interpreted similarly to legislative enactments.

law.name: — Statutory Interpretation
law.description: Course Description: Elective course for Environmental Law Certificate Program. Provides an introduction to the theory and practice of statutory interpretation.

law.name: — Applied Statutory Interpretation: California’s Housing-Framework Legislation
law.description: Course Description: Theory and practice of statutory interpretation, taught using California statutes that address local barriers to housing supply. Writing intensive.

law.name: — Legislative Drafting
law.description: Course Description: Legislative Drafting at UC Davis School of Law provides practical experience in researching, analyzing, and drafting legislative measures in the State of California, including bills, resolutions, and constitutional amendments. Skills-based course to obtain training in drafting and amending legislative measures.

law.name: — Professional Responsibility
law.description: Course Description: The ABA's Model Rules of Professional Conduct and the Code of Judicial Conduct, which are tested on the MPRE, and the California Rules of Professional Conduct, which are tested on the California Bar Examination.

law.name: — Legal Ethics & Corporate Practice
law.description: Course Description: Focus on corporate practice to explore the ethical responsibilities of lawyers.

law.name: — Mindfulness & the Law
law.description: Course Description: Reviews the American Bar Association's Model Rules of Professional Conduct and the Code of Judicial Conduct, as tested on the Multistate Professional Responsibility Examination, and  covers California Rules of Professional Conduct, which are tested on the California Bar Examination.

law.name: — The Business of Lawyering
law.description: Course Description: Desired outcome is a thorough understanding of the business side of law practice and to promote an understanding of the relationship and balance between legal skills, business requirements of a practice, client needs and a work-life balance.

law.name: — Starting & Managing a Small Law Practice
law.description: Course Description: Using real practice examples, in this discussion/simulation-based course learn how to open and successfully run a small law practice. Included topics: structure and organization, office set-up, billing, fees, time management, client handling, overseeing office staff, trust accounting, and ethical rules.

law.name: — Setting Up & Maintaining Solo Law Practice
law.description: Course Description: Introduction/overview of how to start a successful solo practice.

law.name: — Utility of Law School & Careers in the Law
law.description: Course Description: Despite improvements in the economy, some observers continue to question whether law school is a viable option for college graduates. Considers the controversy and expose students to the variety of careers in the legal profession.

law.name: — Practice Ready Seminar
law.description: Course Description: Includes a discussion and review of the role of the junior attorney within a law firm/legal department, professional goal-setting, strategies for effective communication and work within teams, delegation and resource management, organization and time management, an introduction to common junior-level assignments and how to complete them efficiently and effectively, building a professional network, and an introduction to business development, among other topics.

law.name: — Business Fundamentals for Lawyers
law.description: Course Description: Surveys accounting and financial statements, basic financial concepts (e.g., time value of money), business valuation, capital markets, and major transaction types. Should help with other business law courses and be useful for communicating with business clients.

law.name: — Feminist Legal Theory
law.description: Course Description: Provides an overview of feminist legal theory and considers how its various strands inform legislative and judicial law making. Satisfies Advanced Writing Requirement.

law.name: — Women, Islam & the Law
law.description: Course Description: Study legal and religious reform movements for women's rights within Muslim communities in the context of current scholarly and political debates about fundamentalism, democracy, equality, secularism, universalism, and multiculturalism.

law.name: — Women's Human Rights
law.description: Course Description: Overview of international legal and institutional system for the protection of women’s human rights from an academic perspective and the view of the practitioner. Includes the (CEDAW), violence against women, sexual and reproductive rights, economic rights, and more.

law.name: — Women & the Law Practicum
law.description: Course Description: Complements the content of the feminist legal theory course by providing the opportunity to consider how feminist theory may be used to inform law-making.

law.name: — Employment Discrimination
law.description: Course Description: Examine federal laws prohibiting employment discrimination, including Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964, the Equal Pay Act, the Age Discrimination in Employment Act, the Americans with Disabilities Act, the Rehabilitation Act of 1973, and § 1981.

law.name: — Employment Law
law.description: Course Description: Provides an overview of employment law, labor law and employment discrimination law and aims to serve as a foundation for understanding the law and policy (statutory and common law) that surround the employer-employee relationship.

law.name: — Judicial Process
law.description: Course Description: Examines a variety of issues concerning the judicial process. Focus is on judge's role in the legal process, the administration of justice, ethical issues, decision making, bias, and critical examination of the strengths and weaknesses in our current judicial system.

law.name: — Antitrust
law.description: Course Description: Focus on the federal antitrust laws, concentrating on basic substantive areas of the Sherman and Clayton Acts.

law.name: — US Antitrust Law & Indian Competition Law: A Comparative Perspective
law.description: Course Description: Fundamental principles of Indian Competition Law and US Antitrust Law in a comparative perspective. Helps American students, interested in future corporate law careers, to develop effective strategies for better managing cross border deals in India.

law.name: — Regulated Industries
law.description: Course Description: Examines regulation of business in sectors, traditionally described as “common carrier” and “utility” industries, where because of market failures normal competitive mechanism will not protect consumers from exercises of market power.

law.name: — Antitrust & Intellectual Property
law.description: Course Description: Explores the challenges antitrust law faces in protecting the innovation incentives of dynamic technology-led market competition, motivating and incentivizing companies to innovate and allowing them to retain the profits of such market growth.

law.name: — Special Session Antitrust
law.description: Course Description: A study of the federal antitrust laws including price fixing, limits on distribution, tying arrangements, monopolization and mergers.

law.name: — Criminal Trials: Theory & Practice
law.description: Course Description: Trial advocacy centered on client relationship building, preparation for trial, and courtroom practice.

law.name: — Trial Practice
law.description: Course Description: Introduction to the preparation and trial of cases, featuring lectures, videotapes, demonstrations, assigned readings and forensic drills. Laboratory held on Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday evening.

law.name: — Advanced Trial Practice
law.description: Course Description: Train on the organization and presentation of a complex trial, including pretrial preparation, jury selection, strategy considerations, evidentiary issues, and effective handling of plaintiff and defense cases through verdict.

law.name: — Voir Dire: Theory & Practice
law.description: Course Description: Teaches (1) the law that restricts and supports jury selection in criminal law trials, (2) the most effective methods of engaging in jury selection, (3) how to think critically and strategically about voir dire questioning and juror challenges.

law.name: — Water Law
law.description: Course Description: Property rights in surface waters, including riparian rights, prior appropriation, and public rights use of water bodies; environmental constraints on exercise of water rights; groundwater rights and management; federal allocation and control of water resources; legal aspects of interstate allocation.

law.name: — Ocean & Coastal Law
law.description: Course Description: Introduction to the goals and challenges of coastal and ocean policy; the complicated web of public and private interests in coastal lands and ocean waters; regulation of coastal development; domestic and international fisheries management; and preservation of ocean resources.

law.name: — Natural Resources Law Seminar
law.description: Course Description: In-depth coverage of two foundational principles of natural resources law: public trust doctrine and private property rights protected under the Takings Clause of the U.S. and many state constitutions.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): LAW 285 or LAW 256 recommended, but not required.

law.name: — Commercial Law
law.description: Course Description: Survey of commercial transactions law under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC). Covers a number of topics under Articles 2, 3, & 9 of the UCC. Topics include attachment and perfection of security interests in personal property and general principles of negotiability. Primary goals are to provide a foundational knowledge and understanding of several articles of the UCC and improve problem-solving skills in this area.

law.name: — Cyberlaw
law.description: Course Description: Emerging legal issues crucial to the conduct of business in cyberspace. Discussion of the evolution and current administration of the Internet and the World Wide Web.

law.name: — Civil Rights Law
law.description: Course Description: Civil remedies for civil rights violations under the primary United States civil rights statute. Specifically, covers actions for constitutional and statutory violations under 42 USC §1983, affirmative defenses, and abstention doctrines.

law.name: — Civil Rights Seminar
law.description: Course Description: Social, political, legal and historical factors which led to the creation of the United States Commission on Civil Rights (USCCR) in 1957. The United States Commission on Civil Rights is a bipartisan, independent agency established by the Civil Rights Act. It is directed to investigate complaints alleging deprivations of the right to vote, and voter fraud; to study and collect information relating to discrimination and the denial of equal protection of the laws under the Constitution on the basis of race, color, religion, sex, age, disability, or national origin; and submit reports, findings and recommendations to the President and to Congress. The role that the USCCR has played and continues to play in American politics, legislative enactments and the national dialogue on equality, fairness and justice in the context of civil and human rights. Satisfies Advanced Legal Writing Requirement.

law.name: — DFEH Civil Rights Practicum
law.description: Course Description: Yearlong practicum (4-7 units/semester) has (1) weekly two-hour in-class lectures and case review, and (2) student participation in DFEH investigations (fall) and mediations (spring). Gain experience analyzing and applying the Fair Employment and Housing Act (FEHA).

law.name: — Blockchain & the Law: Introduction for Lawyers
law.description: Course Description: Student-led review of blockchain/distributed ledger technology (dlt) and its impact on law and transactions, from the basic functioning of a blockchain to the implication of smart contracts in areas such as cryptocurrencies, decentralized autonomous organizations, and self-sovereign identity.

law.name: — Suing the Government: Civil Rights, Torts, Takings, & More
law.description: Course Description: Explores the basic requirements of suing government, including sovereign immunity, particular schemes for litigating against government (Federal Tort Claims Act, APA, False Claims Act, etc.), direct constitutional claims and the procedural pitfalls and remedies available against government.

law.name: — Basic Finance for Lawyers
law.description: Course Description: Basic techniques of analysis that are part of the core curriculum in a good business school. Gives background necessary for understanding and advising your clients and for understanding other business-related law school courses.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Students with a non-law basic finance course will not be admitted, except with consent of instructor.

law.name: — The Financial Crisis: Law & Policy & Inequality
law.description: Course Description: Examines the regulation of financial intermediaries. Stated goal of regulation is to ensure systemic stability and to pursue consumer protection. Question asked whether there is an imbalance between systematic stability and consumer protection before the crisis of 2008.

law.name: — Consumer Protection & Financial Regulation
law.description: Course Description: Examines efforts to ensure a “fair” financial marketplace, focusing on the 2010 Dodd-Frank Act and its creation of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau and regimes enacted to protect consumers.

law.name: — Corporate Finance
law.description: Course Description: Focus on how corporations raise money, stocks and bonds, etc.; how deals are structured and why corporations use one strategy instead of another.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): LAW 215 or concurrent enrollment recommended.

law.name: — Seminar on Financial Regulation
law.description: Course Description: Introduction to the legal and regulatory issues presented by contemporary capital markets.

law.name: — Public Finance
law.description: Course Description: Introduction to the basic concepts of public finance, the underlying law governing public finance: in particular state law, federal tax law and federal securities law.

law.name: — Fintech Innovation & Financial Inclusion
law.description: Course Description: Focuses on fintech innovation and financial inclusion. Explores how fintech is transforming traditional financial services and providing new opportunities and challenges for financial inclusion.

law.name: — International Business Transactions
law.description: Course Description: Select legal problems arising from international business transactions.

law.name: — Life-Cycle Transactions & Drafting
law.description: Course Description: Focuses on analysis of contract drafting design for various types of transactions and actual transactional documents typically encountered.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Business Associations and/or Trusts, Wills  Estates are recommended for enhanced comprehension.

law.name: — Technology Transactions
law.description: Course Description: Practical overview of technology transactions, including licensing. In addition to substantive lectures, instruction via hypotheticals and scenarios to illustrate key issues in these transactions, drafting exercises, negotiation exercises, and group presentation exercises.

law.name: — Contract Drafting & Development
law.description: Course Description: Complete complex contracts. Learn various approaches to completing contracts (from term sheet to final document) and complete exercises and assignments to hone contract skills. Build a “contract skills toolbox” with the tools needed for completing and drafting contracts.

law.name: — Transactional Lawyering Skills: Contract Drafting for Tech
law.description: Course Description: Skills-based course applies legal concepts to client counselling and drafting of effective business documents with emphasis on the tech industry. Solve problems, analyze risk, and draft contracts in a real-world context.

law.name: — Special Session International Business Transactions
law.description: Course Description: A consideration of select legal problems arising from international business transactions. Topics include the international sales contract, letters of credit, transfers of technology, regulation of bribery, repatriation of profits, and national efforts to control imports.

law.name: — Nonprofit Organizations & Drafting
law.description: Course Description: Learn special legal rules and concepts applicable to non-profit organizations; particularly IRC 501(c)(3) nonprofits. Combination skills class and lecture class.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): LAW 215; or consent of instructor.

law.name: — NonProfit Organizations: State & Local Governance Issues
law.description: Course Description: Focuses on the state and local laws applicable to nonprofit organizations; i.e., public interest, cultural, religious, educational and other not-for-profit entities.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): LAW 215 (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

law.name: — Nonprofit Organizations: Tax Exemptions & Taxation Focus
law.description: Course Description: Focuses on the conceptual basis and substantive law criteria for the federal and state income tax exemption of nonprofit organizations.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): LAW 215; or consent of instructor; LAW 220 recommended.

law.name: — Nonprofit Organizations-Key Legal Topics
law.description: Course Description: Legal issues raised in operating and governing a nonprofit organization, primarily a public charity.

law.name: — Family Law
law.description: Course Description: An introduction to the legal regulation of the family.

law.name: — Education Policy & the Law
law.description: Course Description: Topics include civil rights, inequality and the "right" to an education, bilingual education, school finance litigation, educational access, No Child Left Behind Act, Common Core Standards and charter schools. For students interested in educational policy and social regulatory policy.

law.name: — Special Education Law & Policy
law.description: Course Description: Introduction to the law of special education including the Individuals with Disabilities in Education Act (IDEA), Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act, and federal regulations governing special education law.

law.name: — Intellectual Property
law.description: Course Description: Provides a broad survey of intellectual property law.

law.name: — International Intellectual Property & Development
law.description: Course Description: Examines international trade law, national customs law, intermediary liability rules, claims for rights in traditional knowledge and genetic resources, protections for geographical indications, technology transfer, and intellectual property piracy.

law.name: — Special Session Intellectual Property
law.description: Course Description: Provides a broad survey of the field of intellectual property. Areas covered will include trademarks, patents, trade secrets, idea protection, unfair competition, and copyright.

law.name: — Trade Secrets
law.description: Course Description: Examines effects of a burgeoning intellectual property regime on cultural conflict and formation.

law.name: — Knowledge Commons, Collaborative Authorship, Open Access
law.description: Course Description: Focuses on the increasingly global diffusion and success of collaborative forms of cultural and technoscientific production rooted in copyright-based licenses.

law.name: — Intellectual Property in Historical Context Seminar
law.description: Course Description: How the legal system has adapted to earlier periods of rapid change by creating, delimiting, and expanding intellectual property rights (IPRs). Required paper satisfies advanced writing requirement.

law.name: — Intellectual Property, Human Rights & Social Justice
law.description: Course Description: Examine the implications of copyright and patents for a broad set of social justice values, with particular emphasis on the interaction between intellectual property law and human rights law on the global stage.

law.name: — Censorship in the Global Age
law.description: Course Description: Examines from a globalized perspective a broad range of censorship issues, drawing from established cases and practices. This seminar attempts to identify a globally consistent set of theories that have gained traction in relevant regional or international debates.

law.name: — Race, National Identity & Intellectual Properties
law.description: Course Description: Drawing upon methods taken from critical race theory, critical/cultural studies, and rhetoric this course addresses the relationships between intellectual properties and processes racial/national identity formation in the US, particularly as exemplified in legal, popular cultural, and political texts.

law.name: — Theory & History of Intellectual Property
law.description: Course Description: Seminar traces development of intellectual property law in the U.S. and Europe because it is not possible to understand the logic and shape of current Intellectual Property concepts outside of their messy history.

law.name: — Current Controversies in Intellectual Property Law
law.description: Course Description: Examine controversial topics in intellectual property law and policy across a wide range of issues, from technology to the arts, to social justice, in their national and international dimensions.

law.name: — International & Comparative Intellectual Property
law.description: Course Description: Examines the international regulation of intellectual property rights and explores the place of the United States in the international IP community. Discusses international treaties and legal harmonization efforts, legislation and case law from different jurisdictions, and the role of technology.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion or simultaneous enrollment in Copyright and/or Intellectual Property.

law.name: — Complex Litigation in a Civil Rights Context
law.description: Course Description: Study of the issues that frequently arise in large complex litigation involving multiple parties and multiple claims.

law.name: — Federal Courts for Civil Rights Litigators
law.description: Course Description: Tackles the complex strategic questions facing civil rights litigators. Evaluated cases include Floyd v. City of New York, Dukes v. Wal-Mart, and others. includes guest speakers involved in these cases.

law.name: — Intellectual Property Agreement Drafting for Biotech & Pharma
law.description: Course Description: Covers the negotiation and drafting of intellectual property agreements common in the biotechnology and pharmaceutical arena.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division Business Law course or Intellectual Property course; priority given to students that have completed LAW 274.

law.name: — Juvenile Justice Process
law.description: Course Description: Legal and philosophical bases of a separate juvenile justice process for crimes committed by minors. The role of counsel at each phase of the process is examined.

law.name: — Child Welfare & the Law
law.description: Course Description: Focuses on the welfare and legal rights of children, especially the most at risk in society, including those in foster care and victims of crime and civil torts. Learn the substantive law of juvenile dependency and the special duties of lawyers representing children in dependency and civil cases, as well as child witnesses in criminal cases.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Constitutional Law I (required); Family Law (recommended); Juvenile Justice (recommended).

law.name: — Federal Indian Law
law.description: Course Description: Focuses on legal relations between Native American tribes and the federal and state governments.

law.name: — Tribal Justice
law.description: Course Description: Examines the administration of justice within tribal governments and courts and the efforts of advocates to achieve justice for tribes through litigation, policy advocacy, public education, organizing, and inter-governmental collaboration.

law.name: — Indian Gaming Law Seminar
law.description: Course Description: Examines unique historical, political and legal context in which Indian tribes operate casinos, including impacts on tribal sovereignty, relations between tribes, states and local governments and changing relationships among the tribes themselves members, with particular reference to experience of California.

law.name: — Pretrial Skills
law.description: Course Description: Uses role-playing exercises, videotaped simulations, and related projects to introduce students to lawyering skills basic to the practice of law, including client interviewing, witness interviewing and discovery, including depositions.

law.name: — Legal Analysis
law.description: Course Description: Focuses on skills critical to law school success, and ultimately, bar exam success.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of Instructor; restricted to second year law students only.

law.name: — Advanced Legal Writing: Analytical & Persuasive Writing
law.description: Course Description: Develop essay writing skills and performance test drafting typically employed on the bar examination.

law.name: — Problem Solving & Analysis
law.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Skills focused on the development of legal analytical and organizational methods essential to successful completion of the Performance Test component of the California Bar Exam (and other states), and, by extension, to success in the practice of law.

law.name: — State & Local Government Law
law.description: Course Description: Topics include: federalism, relations between states & localities, governmental liability, zoning, educational equity, and public finance. Readings drawn not only from case law and statues, but from history, theory and public policy.

law.name: — Energy Law Seminar
law.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: The history, law, and public policy of energy regulation in the United States with an emphasis on economic and environmental regulation. Competitive restructuring of the natural gas and electric utility industries emphasized. The basic regulatory schemes for other energy sources such as hydroelectric power, coal, oil, and nuclear power explored. Recommended to anyone who has an interest in the energy sector, various models of economic regulation, or regulated industries.

law.name: — Renewable Energy Seminar
law.description: Course Description: Provides a broad overview of renewable energy law and policy with a particular focus on the California policy context. Topics include renewable electricity, California’s renewable portfolio standard, and project development.

law.name: — Remedies
law.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Survey of modern American civil remedies law in both private and public law contexts. Topics include equitable remedies, equitable defenses, contempt power, injunctive relief, restitution, and money damages in torts and contracts.

law.name: — Law & Economics
law.description: Course Description: Introduction to the economic analysis of law. Prior study of economics is not required.

law.name: — Environmental Law
law.description: Course Description: Introduction to environmental law, focusing primarily on federal law.

law.name: — California Environmental Issues
law.description: Course Description: The "Nation-state" of California has for many years been a national and global leader in environmental law and policy. Survey of key California environmental law and policy issues.

law.name: — Environmental Practice
law.description: Course Description: Examines underlying theory and practice in securing compliance with our major environmental laws.

law.name: — Food Justice
law.description: Course Description: Focus on the law and policy of the emerging "food justice movement," which combines the goals and principles of the environmental justice movement with some of the policy initiatives involved in "ethical consumption" and "sustainable agriculture" movements.

law.name: — Food Systems Law & the Environment
law.description: Course Description: Explores the various legal structures surrounding the governance of our food system; we will cover environmental regulation (or lack thereof), food safety laws, trade laws, and labor laws.

law.name: — Farmworkers & the Law
law.description: Course Description: Provides an overview of California and federal laws impacting farmworkers and how such laws have been applied to regulate working conditions in agriculture.

law.name: — Climate Change Law & Policy
law.description: Course Description: Addresses the legal and public policy dimensions of climate change, perhaps the most important environmental issue of our time.

law.name: — Environmental Justice
law.description: Course Description: Introduction to the field of environmental justice.

law.name: — Environmental Law Seminar: Emerging Technologies & the Environment
law.description: Course Description: Examines legal regimes that might apply to various emerging technologies and consider governance mechanisms and reforms that might enable more foresighted and participatory development and management of technology.

law.name: — Comparative Environmental Law
law.description: Course Description: Focus on Pacific Rim, examining factors, similarities/differences in countries environmental regulation and success of environmental law. Including information and market-based regulatory approaches; compliance and enforcement gaps; citizen and community mobilization; the role of legal institutions; variations in regulatory style.

law.name: — Biodiversity Law
law.description: Course Description: Covers the law of biodiversity, with a focus on the laws of the United States, including both science and federal, state, and local policies. Graded based on short response papers and participation in class discussions.

law.name: — Environmental Law Seminar: Emerging Technologies & the Environment
law.description: Course Description: Examines legal regimes that might apply to various emerging technologies and consider governance mechanisms and reforms that might enable more foresighted and participatory development and management of technology.

law.name: — Health Care Law
law.description: Course Description: Addresses legal issues raised in general areas: access to health care and health care financing. Course materials and discussion focus on both public and private aspects of these issue areas.

law.name: — Topical Issues in Health Law
law.description: Course Description: Focuses on four-six issues at the interface of law, medicine, bioethics, and health policy that are currently the subject of major litigation, legislation, and/or contentious debate in the domains of bioethics and public policy.

law.name: — Public Health Law
law.description: Course Description: Public health law, seen broadly, is the government's power and responsibility to ensure the conditions for the population's health.

law.name: — Bioethics
law.description: Course Description: Examines the ethical and legal issues that arise from biomedical research and use of medical technologies.

law.name: — Legal Psychology Seminar
law.description: Course Description: Examines how psychological theory and research can be used to shape laws and policies to make them better reflect what we know empirically about how individuals process information, make decisions and behave.

law.name: — Reproductive Rights, Law, & Policy
law.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Addresses a variety of laws and practices that affect reproductive health and procreative decision making.

law.name: — Neuroscience & the Law
law.description: Course Description: Explore current topics at the crossroads of neuroscience and the law. Cover topics including neuroscience evidence at sentencing, brain-based lie detection, tort liability for brain injuries, brain based enhancement and the boundaries between life and death.

law.name: — Representing Life Science Companies
law.description: Course Description: Biotechnology and Pharmaceuticals are two of the fastest-growing industries in the U.S., and the legal issues that arise in connection with representing them are complex and evolving. Seminar focuses on the transactional, intellectual property, and regulatory legal issues that challenge lawyers working with clients in these industries.

law.name: — Public Land Law
law.description: Course Description: Legal aspects of federal land management, including the history of public land law, the scope of federal and state authority over the federal lands, and the allocation of public land resources among competing uses.

law.name: — Poverty Law
law.description: Course Description: Explore the theory and practice of law pertaining to the enactment and enforcement of laws regulating or aiding the poor and other disadvantaged persons.

law.name: — Law & Society Seminar
law.description: Course Description: Study of law and society challenges traditional legal scholarship by exploring multiple ways in which law both shapes and is shaped by societies and social interactions. Seminar introduction to important literature and debates in the field.

law.name: — Advanced Constitutional Law Seminar
law.description: Course Description: Seminar explores in-depth selected topics or problems in constitutional law and theory. The current focus will include diverse topics including abortion rights, the development of Second Amendment jurisprudence, and other subject areas.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): LAW 218 (can be concurrent) or LAW 218A (can be concurrent).

law.name: — Presidential Powers Seminar
law.description: Course Description: Explores the Constitutional powers of the President in Article II and how they intersect with Congressional power. Emphasis on executive and legislative power, executive orders, appointment and removal powers, executive privilege and immunity, pardons, impeachment, Congressional investigations, independent and special counsels, and the 25th Amendment.

law.name: — Supreme Court Simulation Seminar
law.description: Course Description: Take on the role of Justices of, and advocates before, the Supreme Court of the United States.

law.name: — National Security Law
law.description: Course Description: Examines the allocation of national security powers among the three branches of government, and the laws & policies that govern military operations, the collection & use of intelligence, homeland security, and other current national security issues.

law.name: — National Security Law: Crisis Simulation Seminar
law.description: Course Description: Explore Constitutional allocation of national security powers among three branches of government, and the vital role lawyers play in national security decision-making. Conduct deep dives on national security law case studies.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Constitutional Law I; Public International Law (recommended).

law.name: — Biotechnology Law & Policy
law.description: Course Description: Coverage includes the regulation of biotechnology research, including restrictions on cloning and fetal stem cell research; regulation of the products of biotechnology to protect human health or the environment, including restrictions on use or distribution of geneti- cally modified organisms; the availability and scope of intellectual property protection for biotechnology products, including genes and engineered organisms; and the international law governing access to the natural resources that provide the starting materi- als for biotechnology and trade in bioengineered organisms or their products.

law.name: — International Trade Law
law.description: Course Description: China has become factory to the world, India its back office, and the US its information intermediary. Trade law affects goods, safety of foods, and conditions under which clothes are produced. Reviews trade regulation from the World Trade Organization to regional organizations such as NAFTA. Considers the implications for developing economies and analyze strengths and weaknesses of the current international trade order.

law.name: — Privacy, Surveillance, & “Sousveillance”
law.description: Course Description: Issues of privacy and surveillance are important to businesses, governments and citizens. Surveillance raises issues of autonomy and the abuse of power. “Sousveillance,” (citizen holds the camera), is a mechanism for rooting out corruption and exposing individuals to societal scrutiny.

law.name: — Surveillance & States
law.description: Course Description: Examines the tensions between democracy and the rise of government power entailed by the growth of state surveillance, United States surveillance law and practice, and surveillance law and practice across the world. Considers international legal constraints on government surveillance.

law.name: — Information Privacy Law
law.description: Course Description: Examine several topics that arise in field of information privacy law, with a special emphasis on law enforcement access to this information.

law.name: — Comparative Privacy Law
law.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Compares regulatory privacy framework. Core lecturing focuses on the EU General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) and how it compares with U.S. law. Core concepts include controler/processor, personal data/personal information, data subject/consumer, etc.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Recommended passing one of the IAPP certifications or Privacy Law Seminar.

law.name: — International Finance
law.description: Course Description: Money makes the world go round. We will try to follow that money, learning how a framework of national and international laws and institutions regulates (or perhaps fails to regulate) its flow.

law.name: — International Investment Dispute Seminar
law.description: Course Description: This seminar will examine the law of investor-State dispute resolution.

law.name: — International Arbitration & Investment Law
law.description: Course Description: Covers international arbitration involving States, individuals, and corporations; including: the parties; the agreement to arbitrate; the arbitrators; the arbitral proceeding; and, the arbitral award.

law.name: — Immigration Law & Procedure
law.description: Course Description: Surveys the history of U.S. immigration law and policy.

law.name: — Advanced Topics in Immigration & Citizenship Law Seminar
law.description: Course Description: Conducts a closer examination of various topics and subject matters that relate to immigration and citizenship law.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): LAW 292; may be waived by the professor.

law.name: — Immigration Crimes
law.description: Course Description: Every year, tens of thousands of people are charged with immigration-related crimes in the federal court system; almost all of the people prosecuted in these cases come from Spanish-speaking countries to the south of the United States. Examine the history of such immigration-related prosecutions, explores how they are currently conducted, and looks in particular at the streamlined proceedings that happen in districts along the southern border.

law.name: — Humanizing Deportation
law.description: Course Description: Focus on student's investigation, research, interviewing and client counseling skills. Review the stories in the UC Humanizing Deportation archive, research possible forms of immigration relief for deported individuals, and identify possible candidates for legal screening. After in-depth training, students travel to Tijuana, Mexico to provide know-your-rights and educational workshops with deported individuals.

law.name: — Public Interest Law
law.description: Course Description: This class will examine the issues and problems associated with providing civil legal services to persons and interests in American society that typically have been unable to afford or otherwise obtain representation from the private bar.

law.name: — Contemporary Issues in Economic Justice
law.description: Course Description: Provides an introduction to the social justice critique of free markets.

law.name: — Representing Spanish-Speaking Clients: Language, Culture, & Emotional Intelligence
law.description: Course Description: Goal is to prepare future attorneys to effectively represent Spanish-speaking clients through various key tools, including litigation tools, language, culture, and emotional intelligence.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Spanish proficiency or consent of instructor.

law.name: — Public Interest Lawyering, Civil Rights & Employment Law
law.description: Course Description: Advanced course covers employment law issues through the lens of public interest lawyers and their constituencies.

law.name: — Law & Popular Culture
law.description: Course Description: Examines works of popular culture, films, and legal texts. Each session focuses on a particular film and its cultural implications, particular problem or problems of law, law practice, legal ethics, traditional ethics, or public policy.

law.name: — Video Game Law
law.description: Course Description: Focuses primarily on intellectual property law through the lens of video game-related litigation, and addresses the ways in which video games and the video game industry shape law and society. Addresses the video game business, the structure and form of video-game-related legal transactions, and other current legal issues surrounding video games.

law.name: — Business of Professional Sports
law.description: Course Description: Provides a basic understanding of how sports teams are legally structured; diversification of business lines, e.g., real estate, hospitality, non-profits, venture capital, marketing; role, structure, and importance of arena/facility as the modern community campfire; legal areas of focus, e.g., contracts, IP, finance, legislation, administrative law, risk management, construction; cutting edge legal issues, e.g., music license rights on social media, gambling, equal pay, eSports.

law.name: — Trademark & Unfair Competition Law
law.description: Course Description: Intensive look at selected issues in Trademark Law, including the concepts of trademarks & unfair competition, acquisition & loss of trademark rights, infringement, trademarks as speech, and international aspects of trademark protection.

law.name: — University Brands
law.description: Course Description: Universities gain from developing brands, to draw donors and students and lend prestige to a range of activities–merchandise, publishing, technology transfer, continuing education, hospitals, distance learning, etc. Whether private, public, elitist, or inclusive, the university can no longer avoid to brand itself. Discusses the role of trademarks in the university and changes affecting it.

law.name: — Brands
law.description: Course Description: Takes a close, interdisciplinary look at branding. Preparation to understand modern branding strategies and the challenges such strategies may pose to traditional trademark law and policy. Topics include merchandising rights, unfair competition, and counterfeits.

law.name: — Copyright
law.description: Course Description: Thorough examination of the law of copyright, including its application to literature, music, films, television, art, computer programs, and the Internet.

law.name: — Entertainment Law
law.description: Course Description: Provides a working knowledge of legal issues in the entertainment industry with general and more specialized knowledge in established media, including film, literature, music and television, as well as emerging online media and video games.

law.name: — Fictional Characters & Real People
law.description: Course Description: Celebrities and fictional characters both have a powerful hold on the human imagination and are important parts of our modern myths. Examines legal protection available for each.

law.name: — Art Law
law.description: Course Description: Selected issues in Art Law, including meaning of art, how to represent artists, copyright, publicity, first amendment rights, censorship, street art, government regulation, art markets, international protection of art and cultural property; and more.

law.name: — Art & Cultural Heritage Law
law.description: Course Description: Exploration of the law relevant to art and cultural heritage, including copyright, cultural property, and cultural heritage laws in international and comparative perspective. Studied issues include creativity, artists' moral rights, forgery, and repatriation.

law.name: — Alternative Dispute Resolution
law.description: Course Description: Introduction to a wide variety of alternative dispute resolution procedures, with an emphasis on negotiation, mediation and arbitration.

law.name: — Federal Arbitration Act Seminar
law.description: Course Description: Trace the development of commercial arbitration law, with a special emphasis on hot-button contemporary issues like consumer and employment arbitration, the separability doctrine, preemption of state law, and the arbitrability of statutory claims.

law.name: — International Commercial Arbitration
law.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Hybrid doctrinal/skills seminar on the theory and practice of international commercial arbitration including: relevant laws & treaties; drafting of arbitration agreements; advocacy in arbitral proceedings; and enforcement or challenge of arbitral awards.

law.name: — Sociology of the Legal Profession Seminar
law.description: Course Description: Comprehensive look at the organization, operation, and ideology of the legal profession.

law.name: — Leadership & the Law
law.description: Course Description: Preparation for responsible leadership and service in the many roles that lawyers perform in and out of legal practice. Introduction to the basic principles of leadership, conflict resolution and ethical decision-making in the legal profession.

law.name: — Trauma-Informed Lawyering
law.description: Course Description: Equip students with knowledge and skills to navigate the landscape of trauma. Explore the science of trauma, and develop strategies for working with trauma in clients, ourselves, and others.

law.name: — Study Abroad: University College Dublin, Ireland
law.description: Course Description: Semester away study abroad at the University College Dublin, Ireland. Enhance knowledge of international legal regimes and obtain a global legal educational experience. Taught abroad.

law.name: — Study Abroad: University of Cophengen, Denmark
law.description: Course Description: Semester study abroad at the University of Copenhagen, Denmark. Enhance knowledge of international legal regimes and obtain a global legal educational experience. Taught abroad.

law.name: — Study Abroad: China University of Political Science & Law
law.description: Course Description: Semester-away study abroad at the China University of Political Science and Law. Enhance knowledge of international legal regimes and obtain a global legal educational experience. Taught abroad.

law.name: — Study Abroad: University of Lausanne, Switzerland
law.description: Course Description: Semester-away study abroad at the University of Lausanne, Switzerland. Enhance knowledge of international legal regimes and obtain a global legal educational experience. Taught abroad.

law.name: — Study Abroad: Comillas Pontifical University Madrid, Spain
law.description: Course Description: Semester-away study abroad at the Comillas Pontifical University in Madrid, Spain. Enhance knowledge of international legal regimes and obtain a global legal educational experience. Taught abroad.

law.name: — Study Abroad: Université Paris Nanterre, Paris
law.description: Course Description: Semester-away study abroad at the  Universite Paris Nanterre, Paris. Enhance knowledge of international legal regimes and obtain a global legal educational experience. Taught abroad.

law.name: — Critical Topics in Environmental Law in a Comparative Perspective
law.description: Course Description: Intensive,  two-week  program  provides an opportunity for U.S. and  international law students to study environmental law by examining and comparing European Union and U.S. environmental law policies and regulatory regimes.

law.name: — Community Education Seminar
law.description: Course Description: Trains students to educate the community about basic legal rights and responsibilities. Students attend an initial four-hour orientation, followed by weekly seminars that will prepare students to teach in a local high school at least two times per week.

law.name: — Environmental Law Moot Court
law.description: Course Description: During the first eight weeks of fall semester, students research and submit briefs as appellants, respondents, or third parties on a problem of environmental law that is prepared by the National Environmental Law Moot Court Board.

law.name: — Appellate Advocacy I
law.description: Course Description: Basic appellate practice and procedure. Beginning instruction in oral advocacy skills and an opportunity to practice these skills in front of a moot court.

law.name: — Appellate Advocacy II  (Moot Court)
law.description: Course Description: Continuation of LAW 410A. Focuses on the development of effective appellate brief writing skills and the refinement of oral advocacy skills.

law.name: — Journal of International Law & Policy
law.description: Course Description: The UC Davis Journal of International Law & Policy publishes semi-annually and strives to contribute pertinent and interesting scholarly works to the field of international law.

law.name: — Social Justice Law Review
law.description: Course Description: The Social Justice Law Review is a publication of the UC Davis School of Law that addresses the unique concerns of social justice in the American legal system.

law.name: — UC Davis Business Law Journal
law.description: Course Description: The UC Davis Business Law Journal is run by dedicated law students who are committed to providing current and valuable legal and business analysis.

law.name: — Immigration & Nationality Law Review
law.description: Course Description: The Immigration & Nationality Law Review (INLR) is in part a reprint journal and serves as an anthology of seminal articles in immigration, nationality, and citizenship law. INLR has republished a number of articles authored by King Hall faculty. INLR also creates space for student Notes. The INLR also hosts a symposium or other immigration-related project each year and publishes materials from that enterprise in the year’s volume.

law.name: — Carr Intraschool Trial Advocacy Competition
law.description: Course Description: Named after the late Justice Frances Carr, this competition is open to secondand third-year students. A preliminary round is followed by quarter-finals,semi-finals,and a final round. Students participate in mock trials presided over by judges and critiqued by experienced litigators.

law.name: — Interschool Competition
law.description: Course Description: Participation in interschool moot court and lawyering skills competitions. Competition must be authorized by the appropriate faculty advisor. Faculty advisor may condition the award of academic credit for any particular competition on the performance of such additional work as may be reasonable to justify the credit. May satisfy advanced legal writing requirement.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of appropriate faculty advisor.

law.name: — Moot Court Board
law.description: Course Description: Members of Moot Court Board may receive 1 unit for each semester of service on the board; maximum of 2 units. Credit awarded only after certification by Moot Court Board and approval of the faculty advisors to Moot Court Board.

law.name: — Negotiations Board
law.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Members of the King Hall Negotiations Board assist in the administration of the King Hall Negotiation Team by performing a variety of tasks under the supervision of the course instructor.

law.name: — Trial Practice Honors Board
law.description: Course Description: Members of the Trial Practice Honors Board administer the Frances Carr competition. Members are nominated by their individual Trial Practice I adjuncts.

law.name: — Law Review Writer
law.description: Course Description: Writing of a law review article under the editorial supervision of editors of the UC Davis Law Review. Office hours (including but not limited to Bluebooking and cite-checking) are required. 1 or 2 units.

law.name: — Law Review Editor
law.description: Course Description: Editors must have completed an editorship article and must perform editorial duties (a substantial time commitment). Credit is awarded only after completion of both semesters.

law.name: — Law Review Editor
law.description: Course Description: Editors must have completed an editorship article and must perform editorial duties (a substantial time commitment). Credit is awarded only after completion of both semesters.

law.name: — Environmental Law & Policy Journal
law.description: Course Description: Environs is a biannual environmental law and policy journal that provides an open forum for the discussion of current environmental issues, particularly those pertaining to the state of California.

law.name: — Advanced Writing Project
law.description: Course Description: Completion of a writing requirement project under the active and regular supervision of a faculty member in satisfaction of the legal writing requirement. Writing project must be an individually authored work of rigorous intellectual effort of at least 20 typewritten double-spaced pages, excluding footnotes. Project may take any of several forms, for example, a paper, a brief, a memorandum of law, a proposed statute, a statutory scheme or set of administrative regulations (with explanatory comments), or a will or agreement (with explanatory comments). Advanced writing project may also be undertaken in connection with another course or seminar to satisfy the legal writing requirements. Number of units shall be approved by the faculty supervisor and will depend upon the scope of the writing effort.

law.name: — Advanced Writing Project
law.description: Course Description: Completion of a writing requirement project under the active and regular supervision of a faculty member in satisfaction of the legal writing requirement. Writing project must be an individually authored work of rigorous intellectual effort of at least 20 typewritten double-spaced pages, excluding footnotes. Project may take any of several forms, for example, a paper, a brief, a memorandum of law, a proposed statute, a statutory scheme or set of administrative regulations (with explanatory comments), or a will or agreement (with explanatory comments). Advanced writing project may also be undertaken in connection with another course or seminar to satisfy the legal writing requirements. Number of units shall be approved by the faculty supervisor and will depend upon the scope of the writing effort.

law.name: — Special Session Advanced Writing Project
law.description: Course Description: Completion of a writing requirement project under the active and regular supervision of a faculty member in satisfaction of the legal writing requirement. Writing project must be an individually authored work of rigorous intellectual effort of at least 20 typewritten double-spaced pages, excluding footnotes. Project may take any of several forms, for example, a paper, a brief, a memorandum of law, a proposed statute, a statutory scheme or set of administrative regulations (with explanatory comments), or a will or agreement (with explanatory comments). Advanced writing project may also be undertaken in connection with another course or seminar to satisfy the legal writing requirements. Number of units shall be approved by the faculty supervisor and will depend upon the scope of the writing effort.

law.name: — Civil Rights Clinic
law.description: Course Description: Clinic provides practical experience in providing legal services to indigent clients who have filed civil rights actions in state and federal trial and appellate courts. Students work on clinic cases under the supervision of the clinic director.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): LAW 219 (can be concurrent); and consent of instructor. Priority given to students enrolled in or have taken LAW 267.

law.name: — Corporate Counsel Externship
law.description: Course Description: Earn academic credit for field placements in a corporate counsel office, working under attorney supervision.

law.name: — Professional Development Seminar
law.description: Course Description: Create strategic goals for their placement, focus on professionalism and professional identity issues in seminar meetings and with their small section coaches, and engage in reflection on what they are learning through discussion and written assignments.

law.name: — Judicial Clinical
law.description: Course Description: Students may arrange judicial clerkship clinical programs with an approved list of state and federal judges through the Clinical office and under the sponsorship of the faculty member in charge. All students must complete weekly time records and bi-weekly journals.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): LAW 261; Required for full-time clinical students and recommended for part-time clinical students.

law.name: — Taxation Externship
law.description: Course Description: Opportunity to work with the Internal Revenue Service or other governmental tax agency. Journals and attendance at group meetings required.

law.name: — Family Protection Clinic
law.description: Course Description: Represent low-income persons in family law and related matters arising out of situations involving family violence.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): LAW 219 (can be concurrent); Full–Year Clinic: prior or concurrent enrollment in LAW 219 to qualify for state court certification; prior or concurrent enrollment in LAW 272 and LAW 263A recommended, not required;

law.name: — Family Protection Clinic
law.description: Course Description: Represent low-income persons in family law and related matters arising out of situations involving family violence.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): LAW 219 (can be concurrent); consent of instructor. Full-Year Clinic: LAW 219 is required to qualify for state court certification; prior or concurrent enrollment in LAW 272 and LAW 263A recommended not required. One-Semester Clinic: prior or concurrent enrollment in LAW 272 and LAW 263A recommended not required.

law.name: — Family Protection Clinic
law.description: Course Description: Represent low-income persons in family law and related matters arising out of situations involving family violence.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): LAW 219 (can be concurrent); and consent of instructor. Full-Year Clinic: LAW 219  is required to qualify for state court certification; prior or concurrent enrollment in LAW 272 and LAW 263A recommended not required.

law.name: — Immigration Law Clinic
law.description: Course Description: Provides legal representation to indigent non-citizens in removal proceedings before U.S. Immigration Courts, the Board of Immigration Appeals, and federal courts, including the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals.

law.name: — Immigration Law Clinic
law.description: Course Description: Provides legal representation to indigent non-citizens in removal proceedings before U.S. Immigration Courts, the Board of Immigration Appeals, and federal courts, including the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals.

law.name: — Immigration Law Clinic
law.description: Course Description: Provides legal representation to indigent non-citizens in removal proceedings before U.S. Immigration Courts, the Board of Immigration Appeals, and federal courts, including the Ninth Circuit Court of Appeals.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): LAW 292 (can be concurrent); consent of instructor.

law.name: — Legislative Process Externship
law.description: Course Description: Practical experience in the operation of the office of a legislator or a legislative committee. The major thrust of the program is to enable students to become familiar with the give and take realities of making laws, as contracted with their interpretation and enforcement. Journals are required.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): LAW 240 (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

law.name: — Aoki Water Justice Clinic
law.description: Course Description: Aoki Water Justice Clinic trains students to use community lawyering and transactional legal tools to ensure that low-income, California communities receive safe, clean, and affordable drinking water.

law.name: — Advanced Aoki Water Justice Clinic
law.description: Course Description: The Advanced Aoki Water Justice Clinic allows students to leverage their legal research and practical lawyering skills to advance policies that ensure that low-income, California communities receive safe, clean, and affordable drinking water.

law.name: — UC Davis Capital Law Scholars Externship Program
law.description: Course Description: Program is designed to provide students with hands-on lawyering experience in a legislative office, with a legislative committee, or with a government/nonprofit office engaged in legislative and policy work. Grading is on a S/U basis.

law.name: — UC Davis Capital Law Scholars Seminar
law.description: Course Description: May be required for students enrolled in Capital Law Scholars Externship. Covers issues related to lawyering in California’s state capital, and help students maximize educational and professional experience in their externship placements.

law.name: — Environmental Law Externship
law.description: Course Description: Practical experience in environmental law. Students will work in an approved government, non-profit or private law office engaged in some form of environmental law work for a minimum of eight hours per week. Students must prepare a journal describing and reflecting upon their clinical experience, and meet periodically with the instructor.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): LAW 285; or consent of instructor.

law.name: — Employment Relations Externship
law.description: Course Description: Practical experience in employment relations, including employment discrimination and public sector labor law. Work under the direct supervision of a government lawyer. Opportunity to participate in a range of with emphasis on observation and participation in actual investigation, interviewing, drafting pleading, and attendance at hearings.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): LAW 251 or LAW 260 (can be concurrent).

law.name: — Public Interest Law Externship
law.description: Course Description: Opportunity to work with a public interest practitioner in a nonprofit organization. Journals and attendance at two group meetings required. Students must complete an evaluative final paper of approximately eight pages. Hours completed in public interest setting may be applied toward the practicum requirement for the Public interest Law Program.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Prior or concurrent enrollment in LAW 293 recommended.

law.name: — Intellectual Property Externship
law.description: Course Description: Opportunity to work for government, academic, and nonprofit entities.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): LAW 293 and Comparative Public Services recommended.

law.name: — Administration of Criminal Justice Externship
law.description: Course Description: Gain practical experience working full or part time in a District Attorney’s or Public Defender’s office in one of several surrounding counties or in a federal Public Defender or U.S. Attorney’s office. Participate in the many activities associated with the office for which they extern: observation, interviewing, research, counseling, motion practice, and trials under State Bar rules.
law.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): LAW 219 (can be concurrent); LAW 227 (can be concurrent); completion of or concurrent enrollment in LAW 219 and LAW 227; LAW 263A recommended.

law.name: — Washington UC-DC Law Program
law.description: Course Description: Uniquely collaborative externship program in Washington, D.C., combining weekly seminars with full-time field placement offering an unparalleled opportunity to learn how federal statutes, regulations, and policies are made, changed, and understood in the nation's capital. Taught in Washington, D.C.

law.name: — Law Making & Law Changing in the Nation's Capital
law.description: Course Description: Companion seminar to the Washington UC-DC Externship. Designed to enhance the externship experience in three principal ways. Taught in Washington, D.C.

law.name: — Law & Lawyering in the Nation's Capital
law.description: Course Description: Companion seminar to a remote/part-time externship where the organization or the supervisor is based in Washington DC. Designed to enhance a part-time/remote Washington D.C. experience.

law.name: — Clinical Program in Prison Law
law.description: Course Description: Provides practical experience in providing legal services to real clients who have various problems related to their incarceration in state prison. The services require analysis and application of Constitutional Law, state statutory law, agency regulations, and the rules of professional responsibility.

law.name: — California Supreme Court Clinic
law.description: Course Description: California Supreme Court Clinic provides students with an immersive experience in litigating cases before the state’s highest court.

law.name: — Aoki Federal Public Defender Clinic
law.description: Course Description: Outgrowth of the work of the Aoki Center on Race and Nation. As part of its work, the Aoki Center provides educational opportunities to students interested in critical race perspectives in practice.

law.name: — Legal Research & Writing Mentor
law.description: Course Description: Participants assist in instructing the Legal Research & Writing programs for first-year students under the direction of the Legal Research & Writing instructors.

law.name: — Lawyering Skills Mentor
law.description: Course Description: Assist the faculty in Lawyering Skills course for first-year students.

law.name: — Group Study
law.description: Course Description: Groups of students with common interest in studying a stated legal problem may plan and conduct their own research and seminar program under the direction of faculty.

law.name: — Group Study
law.description: Course Description: Groups of students with common interest in studying a stated legal problem may plan and conduct their own research and seminar program under the direction of faculty.

law.name: — Independent Research Project
law.description: Course Description: Students may receive credit for individual projects, subject to the following regulations: (1) the project may extend over no more than two semesters; (2) each project will be under the supervision of a faculty member; (3) an outline of the project must be approved by the supervising faculty member; (4) normally, no faculty member will be permitted to supervise more than 5 students working on individual programs during any semester; and (5) each student must submit an individual paper or approved alternative to the supervising faculty member.

law.name: — Independent Research Project
law.description: Course Description: Students may receive credit for individual projects, subject to the following regulations: (1) the project may extend over no more than two semesters; (2) each project will be under the supervision of a faculty member; (3) an outline of the project must be approved by the supervising faculty member; (4) normally, no faculty member will be permitted to supervise more than 5 students working on individual programs during any semester; and (5) each student must submit an individual paper or approved alternative to the supervising faculty member. Grading is on a Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory basis unless a request for letter grading has been made in advance.

law.name: — Law Students Study Away
law.description: Course Description: Students studying away from UC Davis, School of Law. Taught abroad or off campus.

law.name: — Joint Degree Student-GSM
law.description: Course Description: Joint degree course for graduate School of Management students.

law.name: — Special Independent Research Project
law.description: Course Description: Students may receive credit for individual projects, subject to the following regulations: (1) the project may extend over no more than two semesters; (2) each project will be under the supervision of a faculty member; (3) an outline of the project must be approved by the supervising faculty member; (4) normally, no faculty member will be permitted to supervise more than five students working on individual programs during any semester; and (5) each student must submit an individual paper or approved alternative to the supervising faculty member.

law.name: — Special Session Independent Research Project
law.description: Course Description: Students may receive credit for individual projects,subject to the following regulations: (1) the project may extend over no more than two semesters; (2) each project will be under the supervision of a faculty member; (3) an outline of the project must be approved by the supervising faculty member; (4) normally, no faculty member will be permitted to supervise more than five students working on individual programs during any semester; and (5) each student must submit an individual paper or approved alternative to the supervising faculty member. Grading is on a Satisfactory/Unsatisfactory basis unless a request for letter grading has been made in advance.

law.name: — Special Session Independent Research Project
law.description: Course Description: Students may receive credit for individual projects, subject to the following regulations: (1) the project may extend over no more than two semesters; (2) each project will be under the supervision of a faculty member; (3) an outline of the project must be approved by the supervising faculty member; (4) normally, no faculty member will be permitted to supervise more than 5 students working on individual programs during any semester; and (5) each student must submit an individual paper or approved alternative to the supervising faculty member.

lin.name: — Introduction to Linguistics
lin.description: Course Description: Introduction to the study of language; its nature, diversity, and structure.

lin.name: — Introduction to Linguistics
lin.description: Course Description: Introduction to the study of language; its nature, diversity, and structure.

lin.name: — Language & the Body
lin.description: Course Description: Perspectives on the role of language in issues about bodies. Language-related disabilities. Social implications of language use in discussing body-related conditions.

lin.name: — Global English & Communication
lin.description: Course Description: English as a global language and its uses in intercultural communication. Cultural, historical, and political dimensions of varieties of English spoken around the world. Experiential grounding in strategies for increasing interpretive and verbal communicative competence for a globalized world.

lin.name: — Language & Society
lin.description: Course Description: Language as a social phenomenon. Topics include linguistic diversity, language policy, language and identity, language and social structure, speech communities and social networks, the effect of social factors on language variation, linguistic consequences of language contact.

lin.name: — Academic Oral Communication
lin.description: Course Description: Structure of oral communication, critical thinking, and persuasion in classroom discourse in American English and in cross-cultural perspective.

lin.name: — Directed Group Study in English as a Second Language
lin.description: Course Description: Directed group study of topic in English as a Second Language (ESL).

lin.name: — Directed Group Study
lin.description: Course Description: Intended for lower division students.

lin.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
lin.description: Course Description: Intended for lower division students.

lin.name: — Linguistic Analysis I: Phonetics, Phonology, Morphology
lin.description: Course Description: Introduction to fundamental methods and concepts used in linguistic analysis, focusing on phonetic, phonological, and morphological phenomena. Emphasizes development of analytical skills and appreciation of structural regularities and differences among languages.

lin.name: — Linguistic Analysis II: Morphology, Syntax, Semantics
lin.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduction to fundamental methods and concepts used in linguistic analysis, focusing on morphological, syntactic, and semantic phenomena. Emphasizes development of analytical skills and appreciation of structural regularities and differences among languages.

lin.name: — Topics in Language & Linguistics
lin.description: Course Description: Detailed examination of a major contemporary linguistic theory, a major contemporary issue or related set of issues in linguistics, or the structure of a particular language or language family.
