Consumer and industrial markets, market segmentation, pricing strategies, distribution channels, promotion, and sales.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate student in the Graduate School of Management.

mgb.name: — Financial Theory & Policy
mgb.description: Course Description: Corporate financial policy and investment management. Covers capital budgeting, optimal financial structure, cost-of-capital determination, risk measurement. Develops basic valuation principles for investments with long-lived and risky cash-flows, and extends these to derivative securities, asset portfolios, investment management and hedging.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate student in the Graduate School of Management.

mgb.name: — Decision Making & Management Science
mgb.description: Course Description: Develops decision-making and problem-solving skills in conjunction with a quantitative model-building approach. Emphasizes how structured modeling techniques, probability forecasts, simulations, and computer optimization models are used in the overall process of making decisions in an uncertain environment.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate student in the Graduate School of Management MBA program or consent of instructor.

mgb.name: — Management Information Systems
mgb.description: Course Description: Introduction to computer programming and data handling skills. Use of computer in organizations, emphasis on managerial aspects of computing. Standard and nonstandard uses of data files, centralization versus decentralization of computing, office automation, computer security.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate Student or consent of instructor.

mgb.name: — Business Law
mgb.description: Course Description: Introduction to law and legal process in the United States. Sources of law. Structure and operation of courts, federal-state relationships, fundamentals of administrative law, fundamentals of business law.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of administration core requirements or petition with consent of instructor.

mgb.name: — Managing Professionals, Budgets, Controls & Ethics
mgb.description: Course Description: Performance measures, budgetary controls and ethical pressures which occur at middle management levels in service-type operations. Addresses such organizations as engineering, medical groups, law offices, management consultants.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

mgb.name: — Management of Social Networks
mgb.description: Course Description: Principles and applications of social network theory: coordinating divergent interests to create value for individuals and organizations. Emphasis on conceptual models, web-based diagnostic tools, and practical applications.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGB 201A.

mgb.name: — Power & Influence in Management
mgb.description: Course Description: Investigation of the bases of power in organizations and the tactics used to translate power into influence. Topics include the control of resources (including information), social psychological processes (including commitment), the construction of meaning, and ethics.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGT 201A or MGB 201A or MGP 201A; consent of instructor.

mgb.name: — Managing People in High-Performance Organizations
mgb.description: Course Description: Strategic approach to the management of people within organization. Analyze employment systems' fit with firms' environments and strategies. Explore consequences of choices firms make in managing people; decisions as to selection, performance evaluation, compensation, and other management policies and practices.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGT 201A or MGB 201A or MGP 201A.

mgb.name: — Pricing
mgb.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Combines lectures, cases and homework to teach students tools and skills necessary to analyze pricing situations, make pricing decisions, and implement them, in a systematic manner.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MGT 202A or MGV 202AV or MGP 202A); (MGP 203B or MGB 203B or MGT 203B); (MGT 204 or MGB 204 or MGP 204).

mgb.name: — Digital Marketing
mgb.description: Course Description: Equips students for a career in digital marketing and social media. Topics include online advertising, search engine optimization, interactive mktg, online privacy issues, e-commerce, social influence, social network theory, measurement of social influence, integrating social and traditional media.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGB 204 or MGT 204 or MGP 204.

mgb.name: — Management Policy & Strategy
mgb.description: Course Description: Examines the scope of missions, objectives strategies, policies, structures, measurements and incentives which bear on the management of an organization. Real client organizations, in the private and public sectors, are assigned to student teams as the subjects of study.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): First-year core courses of M.B.A. program.

mgb.name: — New Product Development
mgb.description: Course Description: State-of-the-art concepts and methods to enhance the effectiveness of new product development activities. Focuses on the understanding of managerial issues and acquiring the ability to solve problems.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGT 204 or MGB 204 or MGP 204.

mgb.name: — Marketing Communications
mgb.description: Course Description: Issues in designing a marketing communications strategy. Topics include mass and direct communications, institutional aspects of advertising, consumer behavior, evaluating ad effectiveness, determining ad budget, creative strategy, and use and abuse of promotions.

mgb.name: — Customer Relationship Management
mgb.description: Course Description: Customer Relationship Management (CRM) is a management approach under which marketing activities are organized and measured around customers (rather than around brands.) This approach is appealing because customers, not brands, are those who make buying decisions.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGT 204 or MGB 204 or MGP 204.

mgb.name: — New & Small Business Ventures
mgb.description: Course Description: Student teams develop complete business plans for their own start-up ventures. Process includes: elevator pitch, business strategy, comprehensive bottoms-up financial projections, capital requirements, product differentiation, competitive, alliance, and go-to-market strategy development, investor presentation, and comprehensive written business plan.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGT 204 or MGP 204 or MGB 204.

mgb.name: — Business Writing
mgb.description: Course Description: Techniques for sharpening writing skills are introduced, along with grammatical structure, word choice, and punctuation. Learn to develop styles that are pitch-perfect for given situations and to think strategically about each communication challenge in a management setting.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of first-year core courses at the Graduate School of Management or the equivalent.

mgb.name: — Negotiation & Team Building
mgb.description: Course Description: Basic theory of negotiation; applies theory to process of building teams to achieve business purposes. Covers integrative and distributive strategies of claiming value, how to recognize bargaining tricks, uncovering hidden agendas, brainstorming to extend Pareto frontier.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGB 205; MGB 202.

mgb.name: — Customer Service as a Marketing Tool
mgb.description: Course Description: Understanding the distinct features of services, how to create value through service, methods of building strong relationships with customers, methods of measuring and building customer satisfaction, and measuring the financial impact of service improvement.

mgb.name: — Marketing Strategies
mgb.description: Course Description: Examines process by which organizations develop strategic marketing plans. Includes definition of activities and products, marketing audits, appraising market opportunities, design of new activities and products, and organizing marketing planning function. Applications to problems in private and public sector marketing.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MGT 202A or MGV 202AV or MGP 202A); (MGP 204 or MGT 204 or MGB 204).

mgb.name: — Marketing Research
mgb.description: Course Description: Addresses the managerial issues and problems of systematically gathering and analyzing information for making private and public marketing decisions. Covers the cost and value of information, research design, information collection, measuring instruments, data analysis, and marketing research applications.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MGT 202A or MGV 202AV or MGP 202A); (MGP 203A or MGB 203A or MGT 203A); (MGT 204 or MGB 204 or MGP 204).

mgb.name: — Technology Competition & Strategy
mgb.description: Course Description: Why is software typically so defective? Why do many firms in the IT industry give away their best products free? Helps analyze questions like these by modeling competition and strategy in the network, technology and information industries.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MGT 202A or MGV 202AV or MGP 202A); (MGP 203A or MGB 203A or MGT 203A).

mgb.name: — Management of Innovation
mgb.description: Course Description: Managing innovative enterprise in changing and uncertain environments. Covers technology forecasting and assessment, program selection and control, financial management, regulation, and ethics.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGT 201A or MGB 201A or MGP 201A.

mgb.name: — Managing for Operational Excellence
mgb.description: Course Description: Explores the management of operations as applied to manufacturing as well as services provided both inside and outside the organization. Develop an understanding of how uncertainty affects planning and delivery by looking at fundamental models of operations.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGB 203A or MGP 203A or MGT 203A.

mgb.name: — Corporate Social Responsibility
mgb.description: Course Description: Develop a thought process and approach to corporate social responsibility that students will be able to build on during their post-school leadership roles, whether as corporate executives, entrepreneurs, or NGO leaders.

mgb.name: — Entrepreneurship & Venture Investment Clinic
mgb.description: Course Description: Provides the necessary analytical and design tools to create business ideas and refine business models based on emerging technologies. Students learn to work closely in small teams to synthesize technical, strategic, and marketing needs into designs for new ventures.

mgb.name: — Mergers & Acquisitions
mgb.description: Course Description: Focuses on the market for corporate acquisitions and restructuring activity. Topics include: sources of value creation; takeovers; anti-takeover provisions; bidding strategies; use of leverage in buyouts; regulatory risk and hurdles; and, valuation approaches for highly leveraged transactions.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGB 205.

mgb.name: — Banking & the Financial System
mgb.description: Course Description: Analyzes the role of financial markets and institutions in allocating capital. Focuses on: bank lending; debt securities; financial market innovations; regulation; functions of commercial banks and other financial intermediaries. Utilizes case studies.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGP 205 or MGT 205; consent of instructor.

mgb.name: — Corporate Finance
mgb.description: Course Description: Focuses on planning, acquiring, and managing a company's financial resources. Includes discussion of financial aspects of mergers and other forms of reorganization; analysis of investment, financial, and dividend policy; and theories of optimal capital structure.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MGT 200A or MGB 200A or MGP 200A); (MGP 202A or MGV 202AV or MGT 202A); (MGT 205 or MGB 205 or MGP 205).

mgb.name: — Investment Analysis
mgb.description: Course Description: Examines asset pricing theories and relevant evidence, including the investment performance of stocks and bonds. Topics include the efficiency of markets, domestic and international portfolio diversification, factors influencing the value of stocks and other investments, and portfolio management and performance.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MGT 203A or MGB 203A or MGP 203A); (MGP 205 or MGT 205 or MGB 205).

mgb.name: — Money & Security Markets
mgb.description: Course Description: Examines how money and securities markets are organized; how public agencies, businesses, others obtain and invest funds in those markets. Relationship between interest rates, monetary policy, government's role in improving capital markets, approaches to assessing changes in regulation of specific markets.

mgb.name: — Derivative Securities
mgb.description: Course Description: Behavior of options, futures, and other derivative securities markets and how public agencies, business and others use those markets. Trading strategies involving options, swaps, and financial futures contracts. Pricing of derivative securities, primarily by arbitrage methods.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MGT 203A or MGB 203A or MGP 203A); (MGP 205 or MGT 205 or MGB 205).

mgb.name: — Business Taxation
mgb.description: Course Description: Analysis of the impact of business taxation on investment, production, and finance decisions. Discussion of the relationship between business organization and tax liability. Not intended for tax specialists.

mgb.name: — Technology Finance & Valuation
mgb.description: Course Description: Venture capital finance and the related practice of research and development finance. Application of finance tools and framework to the world of venture capital and financing of projects in high-growth industries.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGT 205 or MGB 205 or MGP 205.

mgb.name: — International Finance
mgb.description: Course Description: Studies fixed and floating exchange-rate systems. Topics include determinants of a nation's balance of international payments; macroeconomic interdependence of nations under various exchange-rate regimes and its implications for domestic stabilization policies; and the international coordination of monetary and stabilization policies.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGT 205 or MGB 205 or MGP 205;  Or the equivalent.

mgb.name: — Teams & Technology
mgb.description: Course Description: Theory and practice of managing teams with primary goals of: providing conceptual guidelines for analyzing and diagnosing group dynamics and determining strategic options as a manager; imparting interpersonal skills for implementing effective strategies; understanding how technological change affects team processes.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mgb.name: — Articulation & Critical Thinking
mgb.description: Course Description: With commitment to this course, students will become competent public speakers, write well at a level expected in business, think efficiently and critically about business challenges and have a useful personal code of ethics to shape their actions and decisions. No student may repeat course for credit.

mgb.name: — Machine Learning with Python
mgb.description: Course Description: Introduction to machine learning methods covering association rules, clustering, classification, and numeric prediction. Hands-on machine learning skills with Python. Big data technologies. Business applications.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mgb.name: — Corporate Financial Reporting
mgb.description: Course Description: Analyzes and evaluates contemporary issues in financial reporting and develops implications of those issues for business decision makers, investment managers, and accounting policymakers.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGT 200A or MGP 200A or MGB 200A.

mgb.name: — Strategic Cost Management
mgb.description: Course Description: Theoretical frameworks and associated techniques for using organizational design and cost management to achieve a sustainable, profitable cost structure. Topics include: target costing, process design for low cost, total cost of ownership, cost of customers, implementing structural change, and incentives.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGT 202A or MGP 202A or MGV 202AV.

mgb.name: — Evaluation of Financial Information
mgb.description: Course Description: Studies how investors, creditors, others use accounting and other information in making rational investment, lending decisions. Emphasis is placed on the analysis of financial information in a variety of contexts. Where applicable, recent research in finance and economics is discussed.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGT 200A or MGP 200A or MGB 200A.

mgb.name: — Accounting & Reporting for Government Nonprofit Entities
mgb.description: Course Description: Concepts, methods, and uses of accounting and financial reporting by governmental and nonprofit entities. Introduction to budgeting and performance evaluation, and accounting for entities such as hospitals, universities, and welfare agencies.

mgb.name: — Corporate Governance
mgb.description: Course Description: Discusses how corporations can better operate in the interests of shareholders and public. Directly relevant to managers, consultants in compensation and incentives, staff working on mergers and acquisitions, corporate regulators, shareholder rights activists, and board members.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Full-time MBA students or consent of instructor.

mgb.name: — Real Estate, Finance & Development
mgb.description: Course Description: Focus on single family, attached, detached, multi-family, and light commercial development. Study factors that make up successful real estate developments. Consider financial aspects involved in land acquisition, land development, construction, and project lending.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MGT 205 or MGP 205 or MGB 205); (MGT 201A or MGB 201A or MGP 201A).

mgb.name: — Systems Analysis & Design
mgb.description: Course Description: Design and specification of computer-based information systems. Applications systems development life cycle, use requirements and feasibility assessment, logical and physical design, program development and testing, conversion and implementation.

mgb.name: — Supply Chain Management
mgb.description: Course Description: Matching supply with demand is a primary challenge for a firm: excess supply is too costly, inadequate supply irritates customers. Matching supply to demand is easiest when a firm has a flexible supply process, but flexibility is generally expensive.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGT 203A or MGB 203A or MGP 203A.

mgb.name: — Applied Linear Models for Management
mgb.description: Course Description: Covers regression, analysis of variance, and multivariate analysis. Topics will focus on applications to management and policy problems.

mgb.name: — Time Series Analysis & Forecasting
mgb.description: Course Description: Considers application of time series methods to evaluation and forecasting problems. Covers univariate and multivariate ARIMA models and transfer function models. Applications will be in such areas as economics, finance, budgeting, program evaluation, and industrial process control.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGB 203B or MGT 203B or MGP 203B.

mgb.name: — Telecommunications & Computer Networks
mgb.description: Course Description: Communication system components; common carrier services; design and control of communications networks; network management and distributed environment; local area networks; data security in computer networks.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGB 280.

mgb.name: — Business Database & Database Marketing
mgb.description: Course Description: Practical introduction to fundamental principles of database management systems and database marketing. Database design. SQL queries. Concepts of database marketing, data warehouse, data visualization and big data analytics.

mgb.name: — Topics in General Management
mgb.description: Course Description: Advanced topics in general management. Varied topics to cover more extensively issues discussed in MGB 201A and MGB 201B, or current business interest topics in fields of business writing, business communications, development, or workplace processes.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of all first-year graduate courses at the Graduate School of Management or the equivalent.

mgb.name: — Topics in Organizational Behavior
mgb.description: Course Description: Advanced topics in social psychology and sociology of organizations. Varied topics to cover more extensively issues discussed in MGB 201A and MGB 201B, or current business interest topics in fields of organization design, strategy, development, or workplace processes.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of all first-year graduate courses at the Graduate School of Management or the equivalent.

mgb.name: — Topics in Finance
mgb.description: Course Description: Contemporary and emerging issues in finance. Application of modern techniques of finance to business problems. Use of appropriate electronic database and research techniques.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of all first-year graduate courses at the Graduate School of Management or the equivalent.

mgb.name: — Topics in Marketing
mgb.description: Course Description: Advanced topics in marketing, which may include marketing research, new product development, brand management, pricing, distribution management, service marketing, hitech marketing, advertising, sales promotions, marketing through the Web.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of all first-year graduate courses at the Graduate School of Management or the equivalent.

mgb.name: — Topics in Accounting
mgb.description: Course Description: Contemporary and emerging issues in financial management accounting. Application of modern techniques of evaluation and analysis of financial information. Use of appropriate electronic database and research techniques.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of all first-year graduate courses at the Graduate School of Management or the equivalent.

mgb.name: — Topics in Information Technology
mgb.description: Course Description: Applications of information technology to management and management of information technology. Adaptation to the dynamic nature of the field.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of all first-year graduate courses at the Graduate School of Management or the equivalent.

mgb.name: — Topics in Technology Management
mgb.description: Course Description: Cyclical nature of innovation and technological change, features of innovative firms and industries, national innovation systems, and impact of information technologies on innovation processes.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of all first-year graduate courses at the Graduate School of Management or the equivalent.

mgb.name: — Topics in International Management
mgb.description: Course Description: Broader environment in which U.S. firms and their foreign competitors operate. Integration of material from other topics courses (marketing, strategy, finance, accounting, information technology, technology management) into the international setting.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of all first-year graduate courses at the Graduate School of Management or the equivalent.

mgb.name: — Directed Group Study
mgb.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mgb.name: — Individual Study
mgb.description: Course Description: Individual study.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mgb.name: — Financial Accounting
mgb.description: Course Description: Introduction to the concepts and objectives underlying the preparation of financial statements. Topics include understanding the accounting cycle, measurement and valuation problems associated with financial statement components, consideration of the usefulness of financial statements in the analysis of a corporation’s operations.

mgb.name: — Financial Accounting
mgb.description: Course Description: Introduction to the concepts and objectives underlying the preparation of financial statements. Topics include understanding the accounting cycle, measurement and valuation problems associated with financial statement components, consideration of the usefulness of financial statements in the analysis of a corporation’s operations.

mgb.name: — Crisis Management
mgb.description: Course Description: Establishes and explores the defining characteristics of crises. Will learn to anchor crisis management firmly within overall strategic management and also acquire a set of useful tools and techniques for planning for and handling actual crises.

mgb.name: — The Individual & Group Dynamics
mgb.description: Course Description: Examines basic psychological and social psychological processes shaping human behavior and applies knowledge of these processes to the following organizational problems: motivation, job design, commitment, socialization, culture, individual and group decision making, and team building.

mgb.name: — Individual & Group Dynamics
mgb.description: Course Description: Examines basic psychological and social psychological processes shaping human behavior and applies knowledge of these processes to the following organizational problems: motivation, job design, commitment, socialization, culture, individual and group decision making, and team building.

mgb.name: — Organizational Strategy & Structure
mgb.description: Course Description: Strategic management of organizations, including analysis of industries, firm resources and capabilities and corporate strategy. Strategy formulation, implementation and strategic decision-making. Firm and industry life cycles and change. Analysis of organizational design and structure including differentiation and integration.

mgb.name: — Organizational Strategy & Structure
mgb.description: Course Description: Strategic management of organizations, including analysis of industries, firm resources and capabilities and corporate strategy. Strategy formulation, implementation and strategic decision-making. Firm and industry life cycles and change. Analysis of organizational design and structure including differentiation and integration.

mgb.name: — Crisis Communications & Reputation Management
mgb.description: Course Description: Intended to provide you with an understanding of the framework and tools necessary to successfully address communications and reputation management tasks in a variety of crisis situations.

mgb.name: — Markets & the Firm
mgb.description: Course Description: Examines the interaction of consumers, firms and government, and the effect this interaction has on the use of resources and firm profitability. Fundamental economic concepts such as marginal analysis, opportunity cost, pricing, and externalities are introduced and applied.

mgb.name: — Markets & the Firm
mgb.description: Course Description: Examines the interaction of consumers, firms and government, and the effect this interaction has on the use of resources and firm profitability. Fundamental economic concepts such as marginal analysis, opportunity cost, pricing, and externalities are introduced and applied.

mgb.name: — Business Statistics Practicum
mgb.description: Course Description: Applies techniques and concepts in business statistics to real case studies.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MGT 203A or MGP 203A or MGB 203A); (MGT 203B (can be concurrent) or MGP 203B (can be concurrent) or MGB 203B (can be concurrent)); MGT 203B, MGP 203B, or MGB 203B completed or required concurrently.

mgb.name: — Data Analysis for Managers
mgb.description: Course Description: Introduction to statistics and data analysis for managerial decision making. Descriptive statistics, principles of data collection, sampling, quality control, statistical inference. Application of data analytic methods to problems in marketing, finance, accounting, production, operations, and public policy.

mgb.name: — Data Analysis for Managers
mgb.description: Course Description: Introduction to statistics and data analysis for managerial decision making. Descriptive statistics, principles of data collection, sampling, quality control, statistical inference. Application of data analytic methods to problems in marketing, finance, accounting, production, operations, and public policy.

mgb.name: — Marketing Management
mgb.description: Course Description: Analysis of market opportunities, elements of market research, development of marketing strategies, market planning and implementations, and control systems. Consumer and industrial markets, market segmentation, pricing strategies, distribution channels, promotion, and sales.

mgb.name: — Marketing Management
mgb.description: Course Description: Analysis of market opportunities, elements of market research, development of marketing strategies, market planning and implementations, and control systems. Consumer and industrial markets, market segmentation, pricing strategies, distribution channels, promotion, and sales.

mgb.name: — Financial Theory & Policy
mgb.description: Course Description: Corporate financial policy and investment management. Covers capital budgeting, optimal financial structure, cost-of-capital determination, risk measurement. Develops basic valuation principles for investments with long-lived and risky cash-flows, and extends these to derivative securities, asset portfolios, investment management and hedging.

mgb.name: — Financial Theory & Policy
mgb.description: Course Description: Corporate financial policy and investment management. Covers capital budgeting, optimal financial structure, cost-of-capital determination, risk measurement. Develops basic valuation principles for investments with long-lived and risky cash-flows, and extends these to derivative securities, asset portfolios, investment management and hedging.

mgb.name: — Ethical Issues in Management
mgb.description: Course Description: Explores the philosophical foundation of ethical theory and its recent applications to business situations. Professional codes of ethics, such as those promulgated by educational, managerial, engineering, scientific, medical and legal professional societies, are presented.

mgb.name: — Decision Analytics: Spreadsheet Based
mgb.description: Course Description: Develops decision-making and problem-solving skills in conjunction with a quantitative model-building approach.

mgb.name: — Decision Analytics: Scalable
mgb.description: Course Description: Builds on concepts learned in 406A to develop techniques for describing and implementing models that can scale in all dimensions.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGT 406A or MGP 406A or MGB 406A.

mgb.name: — Storytelling for Leadership
mgb.description: Course Description: Internalize the fundamental principles behind stories that educate, influence, motivate, inspire, persuade and connect.

mgb.name: — The Business of the Media
mgb.description: Course Description: Focuses on the media industries and how emerging digital technologies are disrupting the way media consumption, distribution and business models work. Will highlight the economics of several media, both news and entertainment.

mgb.name: — The Business of the Media
mgb.description: Course Description: Focuses on the media industries and how emerging digital technologies are disrupting the way media consumption, distribution and business models work. Will highlight the economics of several media, both news and entertainment.

mgb.name: — Managing Multi-Asset Class Investment Portfolios
mgb.description: Course Description: Examines top down management of multi-asset class portfolios. Topics include bonds, hedge funds, private equity, real estate, commodities, endowments, return generation, performance analysis, credit cycles, financial crises, manager selection, investment policy, and investment careers. Student teams present endowment portfolio recommendations.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGV 202AV; MGB 203A; MGB 205.

mgb.name: — Corporate Governance
mgb.description: Course Description: Covers recent and not-so-recent business and accounting scandals, discuss how corporations can better operate in the interests of shareholders and the public, and learn from people who rely on corporate governance in making investment decisions.

mgb.name: — Turnaround Management
mgb.description: Course Description: Evaluate the financial performance of a company, identify opportunities for improvement, propose real solutions to enhance performance, and most important inspire action in staff.

mgb.name: — International Marketing
mgb.description: Course Description: Basic concepts of international marketing. Understanding and managing heterogeneous, dynamic, and interdependent environments across countries. How to develop and implement an international marketing strategy: where and how to compete, how to adapt your marketing mix.

mgb.name: — Sustainable Business Ventures: Business & Energy
mgb.description: Course Description: Introduction to sustainability goals, indicators, values, measurement techniques, and practice how it applies to large and small enterprise.

mgb.name: — Multi-Channel Marketing
mgb.description: Course Description: Multi-channel marketing strategies empower managers to create value for different customer segments. Covers the necessary concepts to evaluate and select go-to market strategies in order to capitalize on the ubiquity of modern customers.

mgb.name: — Climate Risks & Opportunities
mgb.description: Course Description: Provide a working knowledge of the risks and opportunities arising from climate change and climate policy for businesses.

mgb.name: — Business Law
mgb.description: Course Description: Introduction to law and legal process in the United States. Sources of law. Structure and operation of courts, federal-state relationships, fundamentals of administrative law, fundamentals of business law.

mgb.name: — Topics in Private Equity
mgb.description: Course Description: Focuses on the finance principles related to the risk and return of the private equity (PE) industry, valuation of PE target companies, the structuring of leveraged buyouts (LBOs), and the management of portfolio companies.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGB 205 or MGP 205 or MGT 205.

mgb.name: — Incentives & Controls
mgb.description: Course Description: Understand how organizations use financial and nonfinancial performance management and incentive systems to motivate people and manage resources.

mgb.name: — Scientific Discovery & Business Innovation at Scale in the Food & Agriculture Sector
mgb.description: Course Description: Scientific discovery and business innovation within the food and agriculture sector profoundly influences the sustainability of society and enterprise competitiveness. Students will learn how business innovation models co-exist antagonistically or synergistically with scientific discovery and its influence on enterprise competitiveness.

mgb.name: — Business Strategy Consulting Skills
mgb.description: Course Description: Students will learn practical business consulting skills which will help apply strategy theories in the workplace. Students will learn and practice tools to frame and analyze problems, conduct research, communicate findings and navigate client relationships.

mgb.name: — Business Strategy Consulting Skills
mgb.description: Course Description: Students will learn practical business consulting skills which will help apply strategy theories in the workplace. Students will learn and practice tools to frame and analyze problems, conduct research, communicate findings and navigate client relationships.

mgb.name: — Advanced Optimization in a Python-based Modeling Language
mgb.description: Course Description: Covers advanced optimization modeling techniques and practical application of modern, scalable modeling language. Techniques will be developed using examples from production planning in a supply chain, but students may explore other areas of application of optimization for their final project.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MGB 252 or MGT 252 or MGP 252); (MGB 206 or MGT 206 or MGP 206).

mgb.name: — Monte Carlo Simulation for Managerial Analysis
mgb.description: Course Description: Create Excel-based simulation models across business domains, from finance to hypothesis testing and inventory management. By course-end, students are experts at recognizing this decision-making fallacy and fixing it.

mgb.name: — Behavioral Finance & Valuation
mgb.description: Course Description: Investor psychology and market frictions can cause asset prices to deviate from fundamental values, creating profit opportunities for sophisticated investors. Covers techniques of financial analysis with the goal of learning how to value assets and identify mispricing.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MGT 260 or MGP 260 or MGB 260); (MGT 261 or MGP 261 or MGB 261)

mgb.name: — Leader as Coach: An Introduction to Coaching Skills for Leaders
mgb.description: Course Description: Introduces the fundamental coaching skills and coaching models that leaders can apply in everyday interactions with their team and colleagues in order to build trust, overcome challenges and help others discover their own full potential.

mgb.name: — Power & Influence in Management
mgb.description: Course Description: Investigation of the bases of power in organizations and the tactics used to translate power into influence. Topics include the control of resources (including information), social psychological processes (including commitment), the construction of meaning, and ethics.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGT 201A or MGP 201A or MGB 201A.

mgb.name: — Practicum for Managing People in Modern Organizations
mgb.description: Course Description: Provides solid grounding in the management of work and the employment relationship. Examines firms’ interrelated policies and practices for managing people.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGB 224.

mgb.name: — Digital Marketing Techniques
mgb.description: Course Description: Provides students with an introduction to digital marketing. Introduces MBA students to the fundamental aspects and tools of online marketing communication, i.e., how organizations use digital channels to effectively communicate their value propositions to the target customers.

mgb.name: — The Business of Healthcare
mgb.description: Course Description: Intended to provide an overall understanding of the unique business aspects of the healthcare industry.

mgb.name: — Implementing International Strategy
mgb.description: Course Description: Looks at the pitfalls of implementing international strategies, and suggest several accessible, yet powerful frameworks to help international managers implement strategies successfully and completely.

mgb.name: — Renewable Energy Ventures
mgb.description: Course Description: Advanced innovation lab will introduce students to issues addressed by entrepreneurs and investors in renewable ventures. Lectures, simulations, case studies and practical experience of the presenters will be delivered.

mgb.name: — Detection & Prevention of Asset Misappropriation Fraud in the Workplace
mgb.description: Course Description: Discusses the fundamentals of fraud detection and prevention in the workplace. Learn the major schemes involving workplace fraud, how management can detect fraud and what policies and procedures can be implemented to prevent fraud.

mgb.name: — Learning From Catastrophes: Lessons for Managers
mgb.description: Course Description: Catastrophes unfold in surprisingly similar ways. Analyze catastrophes to understand these common patterns and investigate how they can be prevented and mitigated. Apply these lessons to management to gain unconventional insights.

mgb.name: — Project Management
mgb.description: Course Description: Students learn project management; including project scope, project planning, milestones and project closing. Important themes include leadership, team dynamics, storytelling/creating a narrative, communication, and conflict management.

mgb.name: — Project Management with Applications in Healthcare
mgb.description: Course Description: Focuses on the heart of healthcare administration and how project management can be applied as a key lever to increase efficiency, decrease costs and improve the patient experience.

mgb.name: — Project Management with Applications in Healthcare
mgb.description: Course Description: Focuses on the heart of healthcare administration and how project management can be applied as a key lever to increase efficiency, decrease costs and improve the patient experience.

mgb.name: — Corporate Social Responsibility
mgb.description: Course Description: Learn practical information that will help students understand the basics of designing, managing and evaluating an effective CSR program. Expose students to a basic set of CSR issues in the context of cross-purpose business challenges and then focus on the analysis and critical decisions that managers must make to move their business and their social agenda forward.

mgb.name: — Data Wrangling
mgb.description: Course Description: Develop practical skills to pre-process data. Tidied raw data can then be used for downstream data analysis, modeling, and visualization.

mgb.name: — Introduction to Derivative Securities
mgb.description: Course Description: Introduction to derivative securities and other forms of financial innovations.

mgb.name: — Healthcare Analytics
mgb.description: Course Description: Introduction to advanced analytics framework, key Artificial Intelligence & Machine Learning concepts, and modeling techniques towards solving high-value and high-impact healthcare business problems.

mgb.name: — Healthcare Analytics
mgb.description: Course Description: Introduction to advanced analytics framework, key Artificial Intelligence & Machine Learning concepts, and modeling techniques towards solving high-value and high-impact healthcare business problems.

mgb.name: — Integrated Management Project
mgb.description: Course Description: Applies classroom learning to solve complex business challenges for real-world clients. Students learn practical consulting skills while their clients benefit from the student’s experience, insights, and work product.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): First-year core courses of MBA program.

mgb.name: — Integrated Management Project
mgb.description: Course Description: Applies classroom learning to solve complex business challenges for real world clients. Student teams learn practical consulting skills while their clients benefit from the student’s experience, insights, and work product.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): First-year core courses of MBA program.

mgb.name: — Integrated Management Project
mgb.description: Course Description: Applies classroom learning to solve complex business challenges for real world clients. Student teams learn practical consulting skills while their clients benefit from the student’s experience, insights, and work product.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): First-year core courses of MBA program.

mgb.name: — Integrated Management Project Lead
mgb.description: Course Description: Integrated Management Project Team leader.

mgb.name: — Integrated Management Simulation
mgb.description: Course Description: Apply theory and concepts from marketing, finance, organizational behavior, accounting, and strategy in order to manage a simulated corporation.

mgb.name: — New Product Development
mgb.description: Course Description: State-of-the-art concepts and methods to enhance the effectiveness of new product development activities. Focuses on the understanding of managerial issues and acquiring the ability to solve problems.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGT 204 or MGP 204 or MGB 204.

mgb.name: — Practicum for Marketing Communication
mgb.description: Course Description: Provides experience applying concepts learned in Marketing Communications to a realistic advertising or communication problem faced by firms.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGB 242.

mgb.name: — Customer Analytics
mgb.description: Course Description: Teaches how to use customer analytics to learn about and market to individual customers. Examines the different types of data analytics and how they fit into the customer relationship management world.

mgb.name: — Customer Analytics
mgb.description: Course Description: Teaches students how to use customer analytics to learn about and market to individual customers. Examines the different types of data analytics and how they fit into the customer relationship management world.

mgb.name: — Product Management
mgb.description: Course Description: Overview of the requirements, issues, and tools involved in marketing of products and services via lectures, case studies, and a hands-on, quarter-long competitive simulation.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGT 404 or MGP 404 or MGB 404.

mgb.name: — Practicum for Marketing Strategies
mgb.description: Course Description: Provides opportunities to apply the concepts covered in the Marketing Strategies class through a group project involving the analysis of strategic marketing decisions based on business-related issues, simulation and modeling.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGB 248.

mgb.name: — Marketing Strategies
mgb.description: Course Description: Examines process by which organizations develop strategic marketing plans. Includes definition of activities and products, marketing audits, appraising market opportunities, design of new activities and products, and organizing marketing planning function. Applications to problems in private and public sector marketing.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MGT 202A or MGP 202A or MGB 202A); (MGT 204 or MGP 204 or MGB 204).

mgb.name: — Marketing Research Practicum
mgb.description: Course Description: Provides opportunities to apply the concepts and methods covered in the Marketing Research class. Hands-on and project-based, work could be either individual or in groups depending on enrollments and/or interests of students.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGB 249.

mgb.name: — Practicum for Technology Strategy & Competition
mgb.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: In-depth practicum project course. Apply theories, concepts, and models, learned in MGB 250 to a real-world business problem, through data collection, data analysis, simulation, modeling and post-model interpretation.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGB 250.

mgb.name: — Managing for Operational Excellence
mgb.description: Course Description: Explore the management of operations as applied to manufacturing, as well as services provided both inside & outside the organization. Develop an understanding of how uncertainty affects planning & delivery by looking at fundamental models of operations.

mgb.name: — Managing for Operational Excellence
mgb.description: Course Description: Explore the management of operations as applied to manufacturing, as well as services provided both inside & outside the organization. Develop an understanding of how uncertainty affects planning & delivery by looking at fundamental models of operations.

mgb.name: — Causal Inference and Statistical Experiments
mgb.description: Course Description: Surveys causal inference methods with applications in business settings, especially marketing. Covers both primary data approaches such as A/B testing and secondary data approaches such as difference-in-differences.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGT 403A or MGP 403A or MGB 403A.

mgb.name: — Marketing Analytics
mgb.description: Course Description: Surveys a variety of marketing analytics applications, training students to identify (i) what questions data can answer, and, conversely, (ii) what data is needed to answer a question.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGT 454A or MGP 454A or MGB 454A.

mgb.name: — Practicum for Corporate Finance & Real Estate
mgb.description: Course Description: Work in groups to select and value a financial entity. It could be a firm, a sports player, a building, a project, or a patent. Grade based on an in-class presentation and a write-up.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGB 260.

mgb.name: — Corporate Finance: Fundamentals
mgb.description: Course Description: Course will study valuation techniques in applied settings, study a variety of investment decisions, and analyze how capital structure considerations play a role in firm’s investment policies.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGT 205 or MGP 205 or MGB 205.

mgb.name: — Corporate Finance: Advanced Topics
mgb.description: Course Description: Advanced course in corporate finance that builds on 460A, with an aim to extend knowledge of the theory and practice of corporate finance.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGT 460A or MGP 460A or MGB 460A.

mgb.name: — Practicum for Investment Analysis
mgb.description: Course Description: Provides practical experience applying concepts learned in Investment Analysis to a realistic portfolio management setting via a hypothetical exercise. Produce a realistic executive summary and presentation of an investment proposal for a hypothetical client.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGB 261.

mgb.name: — Practicum & Taxes & Business Strategy
mgb.description: Course Description: Practical application project drawing from the tax planning theory contained in MGB 264. Project consists of a business formation and operation, change in organization (incorporation), and movement into multi-national and multi-jurisdictional tax.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGB 264.

mgb.name: — Practicum for Venture Capital
mgb.description: Course Description: Provides an opportunity to apply concepts learned in Venture Capital in a realistic setting. Complete project analyzing a potential investment in a hypothetical venture and prepare an deal term sheet/investment agreement.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGB 265.

mgb.name: — Practicum for Teams & Technology
mgb.description: Course Description: Groups investigate the performance, creativity, conflict, information sharing, and leadership behaviors of a real world team. Provide consulting advice to the team, which not only gives analytic skills, but also builds presentation skills.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGB 267.

mgb.name: — Teams & Technology
mgb.description: Course Description: Theory and practice of managing teams with primary goals of: providing conceptual guidelines for analyzing and diagnosing group dynamics and determining strategic options as a manager; imparting interpersonal skills for implementing effective strategies; understanding how technological change affects team processes.

mgb.name: — Articulation & Critical Thinking
mgb.description: Course Description: Public speaking, business writing, efficient and critical thinking about business challenges, and defining a personal code of ethics to shape actions and decisions.

mgb.name: — Articulation & Critical Thinking
mgb.description: Course Description: Public speaking, business writing, efficient and critical thinking about business challenges, and defining a personal code of ethics to shape actions and decisions.

mgb.name: — Practicum for Business Intelligence Technologies
mgb.description: Course Description: Projects applying concepts learned in Business Intelligence Technologies to real business problems.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGB 269.

mgb.name: — Real Estate, Finance & Development
mgb.description: Course Description: Focus on single family, attached, detached, multi-family, and light commercial development. Study factors which make up successful real estate developments. Consider financial aspects involved in land acquisition, land development, construction, and project lending.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MGT 401A or MGP 401A or MGB 401A); (MGT 405 or MGP 405 or MGB 405).

mgb.name: — Practicum for Supply Chain Management
mgb.description: Course Description: Provides experience applying concepts learned in Supply Chain Management to a realistic management setting via a project.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MGT 282 (can be concurrent) or MGP 282 (can be concurrent) or MGB 282 (can be concurrent); course is a pre-requisite or co-requisite.

mgb.name: — Topics in Business
mgb.description: Course Description: Provides opportunity for students to gain experience in applying business methodologies previously acquired in other GSM courses.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Sponsorship of a GSM Academic Senate faculty member; approval of graduate advisor.

mgb.name: — Topics in Management
mgb.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Advanced topics in general management. Varied topics to cover more extensively issues discussed in the MBA core such as business writing, management, organizational behavior, business communications, development, and workplace processes.

mgb.name: — Topics in General Management-Extended
mgb.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Advanced topics in general management. Varied topics to cover more extensively issues discussed in the MBA core such business writing, management, organizational behavior, business communications, development, finance and workplace processes.

mgb.name: — Topics in Management
mgb.description: Course Description: Advanced topics in general management. Varied topics to cover more extensively issues discussed in the MBA core such business writing, management, organizational behavior, business communications, development, and workplace processes.

mgb.name: — Topics in General Management
mgb.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Advanced topics in general management. Varied topics to cover more extensively issues discussed in MGT 201A and MGT 201B, or current business interest topics in fields of business writing, business communications, development, or workplace processes.

mgb.name: — Topics in Finance
mgb.description: Course Description: Contemporary and emerging issues in finance. Application of modern techniques of finance to business problems. Use of appropriate electronic database and research techniques.

mgb.name: — Topics in Marketing
mgb.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Advanced topics in marketing, which may include marketing research, new product development, brand management, pricing, distribution management, service marketing, hi-tech marketing, advertising, sales promotions, marketing through the Web.

mgb.name: — Directed Group Study Management Practicum
mgb.description: Course Description: Provides the opportunity for students to gain experience in applying business methodologies previously acquired in other GSM courses.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Sponsorship of a GSM Academic Senate faculty member, and approval of graduate advisor.

mgb.name: — Directed Individual Study Management Practicum
mgb.description: Course Description: Provides the opportunity for students to gain experience in applying business methodologies previously acquired in other Graduate School of Management courses.
mgb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Sponsorship of a Graduate School of Management Academic Senate faculty member and approval of graduate advisor.

mpm.name: — Introduction to Information Management for Epidemiologists
mpm.description: Course Description: Introduction to practical application of epidemiological methods to solve problems involving population health data. Emphasis on using worksheet/database software tools for organizing, analyzing, reporting, and interpreting data. Ten, three-hour sessions.

mpm.name: — Emerging Issues at the Interface of Animal, Human, & Ecosystem Health
mpm.description: Course Description: Introduce one health topics emphasizing relationships between environmental, animal and human health. Topics include ecosystem change and impacts on animals and humans, cross-species disease transmission and approaches for addressing critical data gaps to inform ecosystem health and disease prevention.

mpm.name: — Medical Statistics I
mpm.description: Course Description: Basic statistics in clinical, laboratory and population medicine: descriptive statistics; probability; binomial, Poisson, normal, t-, F-, and Chi-square distributions; sampling distributions; parameter estimation; hypothesis testing; elementary nonparametric methods, simple linear regression and correlation; life table construction and analysis.
mpm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MPVM or MPH standing or consent of instructor.

mpm.name: — Medical Statistics II
mpm.description: Course Description: Continuation of MPM 202. Analysis of variance in biomedical sciences; nonparametric methods; multiple regression; unconditional logistic regression; biomedical applications of statistical methods. Microcomputer applications in population medicine to reinforce principles that are taught in lecture. Required for students in the Preventive Veterinary Program Graduate Group (PVM) and the Masters of Public Health Program (MPH).
mpm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MPM 202; or consent of instructor, or equivalent.

mpm.name: — Medical Statistics III
mpm.description: Course Description: Continuation of MPM 203. Selecting the best regression equation, conditional logistic regression, Poisson regression, survival analysis, analysis of time dependent variation and trends. Microcomputer applications in population medicine to reinforce principles that are taught in lecture.

mpm.name: — Principles of Epidemiology
mpm.description: Course Description: Basic epidemiologic concepts and approaches to epidemiologic research, with examples from veterinary and human medicine, including outbreak investigation, infectious disease epidemiology, properties of tests, and an introduction to epidemiologic study design and surveillance.
mpm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MPM 202; or consent of instructor; an introductory statistics course.

mpm.name: — Epidemiologic Study Design
mpm.description: Course Description: Builds on concepts presented in MPM 205. Concepts of epidemiologic study design (clinical trials, observational cohort studies, case control studies) introduced in MPM 205A are covered in more depth, using a problem-based format. Discussion of published epidemiologic studies.
mpm.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MPM 205; or consent of instructor.

mpm.name: — Applied Epidemiologic Problem Solving
mpm.description: Course Description: Integration of epidemiologic and statistical methodology in a problem-solving approach to contemporary animal population health issues. Data validation and manipulation.

mpm.name: — Research Planning & Reporting I
mpm.description: Course Description: Identify and implement research questions through hypothesis construction, articulation of aims, acquiring permits, working as a team, and all other techniques needed to develop a successful research program.

mpm.name: — Research Planning & Reporting II
mpm.description: Course Description: Concepts and skills in effective scientific writing for publication in a peer-reviewed journal in animal health or biomedicine. Includes developing an argument, organizing and writing a manuscript, improving readability, and responding to peer review.

mpm.name: — Advanced Health Leadership
mpm.description: Course Description: Develop skills for effective scientific leadership, including: project management and collaboration, conflict resolution, communication with the public, dynamic distribution of health information, and evidence-based policy influence.

mpm.name: — Concepts & Methods in Infectious Disease Surveillance & Control
mpm.description: Course Description: Basic and advanced level of conceptual and methodological foundations in infectious disease epidemiology necessary for veterinarians to develop and evaluate programs for detection, prevention, and control of infectious diseases in animal populations.

ems.name: — Materials Marvels: The Science of Superheroes
ems.description: Course Description: Introduction to science and technology of materials as key engineering ingredients. Explores the relationship between art and materials, and how superheroes are both products and resources of ideas for new materials' technologies.

ems.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
ems.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates with lower division standing.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ems.name: — Principles of Polymer Materials Science
ems.description: Course Description: Basic principles of polymer science presented including polymer structure and synthesis; polymerization mechanisms, polymer classes, properties, and reactions; polymer morphology, rheology, and characterization; polymer processing.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 002A; CHE 002B; ((CHE 008A,  CHE 008B) or (ENG 045 or ENG 045Y)); introductory physics.

ems.name: — Thermodynamics of Materials
ems.description: Course Description: Review of thermodynamic principles of interest to materials scientists and engineers. Application of thermodynamics to material processing, phase stability, corrosion.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ENG 045 C- or better or ENG 045Y C- or better); PHY 009B C- or better; MAT 022B C- or better; CHE 002C recommended.

ems.name: — Structure & Characterization of Engineering Materials
ems.description: Course Description: Description of the structure of engineering materials on the atomic scale by exploring the fundamentals of crystallography. Importance of this structure to materials’ properties. Description of experimental determination using x-ray diffraction techniques.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ENG 045 C- or better or ENG 045Y C- or better); MAT 022A C- or better; PHY 009B C- or better.

ems.name: — Structure & Characterization of Materials Laboratory
ems.description: Course Description: Experimental investigations of structure of solid materials are combined with techniques for characterization of materials. Laboratory exercises emphasize methods used to study structure of solids at the atomic and microstructural levels. Methods focus on optical, x-ray and electron techniques.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EMS 162 (can be concurrent); concurrent enrollment in EMS 162 recommended.

ems.name: — Kinetics of Materials
ems.description: Course Description: Basic kinetic laws and the principles governing phase transformations. Applications in diffusion, oxidation, nucleation, growth and spinodal transformations.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ENG 045 C- or better or ENG 045Y C- or better); EMS 160; (ECH 060 or ENG 006).

ems.name: — Sustainable Energy Technologies: Batteries, Fuel Cells, & Photovoltaic Cells
ems.description: Course Description: Basic principles of future energy devices such as lithium batteries, fuel cells, and photovoltaic cells. Examines the current status of these energy technologies and analyze challenges that still must be overcome.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 045 or ENG 045Y.

ems.name: — Sustainable Energy Technologies Laboratory
ems.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Fundaments of manufacturing and characterization of energy devices, such as lithium batteries, fuel cells and photovoltaic cells. Discussion on limiting factors in the performance of the devices.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 045; EMS 170 (can be concurrent); EMS 172 (recommended).

ems.name: — Smart Materials
ems.description: Course Description: Electronic, optical, and magnetic properties of materials as related to structure and processing of solid state materials. Physical principles for understanding the properties of metals, semiconductors, ceramics, and amorphous solids and the applications of these materials in engineering.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 110A or PHY 009D; ENG 006 or ECH 060 or equivalent recommended.

ems.name: — Smart Materials Laboratory
ems.description: Course Description: Experimental investigation of electronic, optical and magnetic properties of engineering materials, emphasizing the fundamental relationship between microstructure and properties as well as the influence of rate processes on the evolution of the microstructure and properties.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EMS 172 (can be concurrent); concurrent enrollment in EMS 172 recommended.

ems.name: — Mechanical Behavior of Materials
ems.description: Course Description: Microscopic and macroscopic aspects of the mechanical behavior of engineering materials, with emphasis on recent development in materials characterization by nondestructive testing. Fundamental aspects of plasticity in engineering materials, strengthening mechanisms and mechanical failure modes of materials systems.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ENG 045 C- or better or ENG 045Y C- or better); EMS 162 recommended.

ems.name: — Mechanical Behavior Laboratory
ems.description: Course Description: Experimental investigation of mechanical behavior of engineering materials. Laboratory exercises emphasize the fundamental relationship between microstructure and mechanical properties, and the evolution of the microstructure as a consequence of rate process.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EMS 174 (can be concurrent); concurrent enrollment recommended.

ems.name: — Materials in Engineering Design
ems.description: Course Description: Quantitative treatment of materials selection for engineering applications. Discussion of design & material selection strategy; process & process selection strategy; process economics; life-cycle thinking & eco-design. Use of materials selection software.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 045 C- or better or ENG 045Y C- or better.

ems.name: — Manufacturing of 3D & Composite Materials
ems.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Fundamental physical and chemical principles underlying various processing techniques, used in manufacturing processes for bulk (3D) and composite structural and functional materials. Effects of processing variables on structure-property relationships.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ENG 045 C- or better or ENG 045Y C- or better); (ENG 105 or ECH 152B or EEC 140A or EMS 164).

ems.name: — Failure Analysis
ems.description: Course Description: Analysis of the way materials fail. Effects of temperature, mechanical deformation and corrosion on the properties of materials. forensics and methodologies for investigating failures of materials including optical microscopy, x-ray analysis and scanning electron microscopy. Investigation of practical problems.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ENG 045 C- or better or ENG 045Y C- or better; EMS 174 recommended.

ems.name: — Processing of 2D & Nanomaterials
ems.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Fundamentals of processing methods for two-dimensional materials, including thin films and graphene-like materials; as well as nanomaterials, including nanoparticles, nanowires, and quantum dots.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ENG 045 C- or better or ENG 045Y C- or better); (ENG 105 or ECH 152B or EEC 140A or EMS 164).

ems.name: — Materials Design Project
ems.description: Course Description: Major materials design experience involving analysis of real materials synthesis/processing/fabrication and technological applications including critical assessments of economic, manufacturing, and ethical constraints. Various principles of materials science are integrated into a culminating team design project.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EMS 160; EMS 162; EMS 164; EMS 172; EMS 174.

ems.name: — Honors Materials Design
ems.description: Course Description: Examination of special topics covered in the materials design course through additional readings, discussions, collaborative work, or special activities which may include projects, laboratory experience or computer simulations.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Enrollment in the Materials Science  Engineering Honors Program.

ems.name: — Materials Design Project
ems.description: Course Description: Major materials design experience involving analysis of real materials synthesis/processing/fabrication and technological applications including critical assessments of economic, manufacturing, and ethical constraints. Various principles of materials science are integrated into a culminating team design project.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EMS 188A.

ems.name: — Honors Materials Design
ems.description: Course Description: Examination of special topics covered in the materials design course through additional readings, discussions, collaborative work, or special activities which may include projects, laboratory experience or computer simulations.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Enrollment in the Materials Science  Engineering Honors Program.

ems.name: — Research Group Conference
ems.description: Course Description: Individual and/or group conference on problems, progress and techniques in materials research.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Upper division standing.

ems.name: — Internship in Materials Science & Engineering
ems.description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in the Materials Science & Engineering field.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ems.name: — Tutoring in Materials Science & Engineering
ems.description: Course Description: Tutoring of students in courses taught by instructors in the Department of Materials Science & Engineering. Tutor responsibilities may include attending class, assisting an instructor or TA in laboratory sections or group discussions, or providing non-graded feedback on assignments. Weekly meeting with the instructor.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ems.name: — Directed Group Study
ems.description: Course Description: Group study of selected topics.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ems.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
ems.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ems.name: — Preparing for Graduate Student Success
ems.description: Course Description: Introduction to the soft-skills and campus resources needed to succeed in graduate school. Emphasis on the student-mentor relationship and the process of selecting a research mentor.

ems.name: — Fundamentals of Electron Microscopy
ems.description: Course Description: Principles and techniques of scanning and transmission of electron microscopy used in the study of materials will be described. Emphasis upon practical applications.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EMS 162.

ems.name: — Laboratory for Electron Microscopy
ems.description: Course Description: Practical application of techniques of electron scanning and transmission microscopy including x-ray microanalysis.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EMS 230 (can be concurrent); EMS 230 required concurrently.

ems.name: — Interaction of Materials & their Environment
ems.description: Course Description: Thermodynamic and kinetic foundations of the corrosion and oxidation processes. Practical aspects of corrosion control and prevention. Stress-corrosion and gas-embrittlement phenomena. Special topics in corrosion; microbiological and atmospheric corrosion.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ENG 045 or ENG 045Y); ENG 105A recommended; or consent of instructor.

ems.name: — Micro- & Nano-Technology in Life Sciences
ems.description: Course Description: Survey of biodevice design from engineering and biological perspectives; micro-/nano-fabrication techniques; surface science and mass transport; essential biological processes and models; proposal development skills on merging aforementioned themes.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

ems.name: — Photovoltaics & Solar Cells
ems.description: Course Description: Physics and application of photovoltaics and solar cells, including design, fabrication technology, and grid incorporation. Mono and microcrystalline silicon devices; thin-film technologies, heterojunction and organic-semiconductor technologies. Collectors, electrical inverters and infrastructure issues. Challenges and concerns.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EEC 140B; or consent of instructor, or equivalent.

ems.name: — Fracture of Engineering Materials
ems.description: Course Description: Description of the failure of materials by crack propagation. Topics include the stress fields about elastic cracks, the Griffith-Irwin analysis, descriptions of plastic zones, fracture toughness testing, microstructural aspects of fracture and failure at elevated temperatures.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EMS 174.

ems.name: — Mechanisms of Fatigue
ems.description: Course Description: Microstructural description of the mechanisms of fatigue in metals. Topics include a phenomenological treatment of cyclic deformation, dislocation processes in cyclic deformation, fatigue crack nucleation, Stage I growth, threshold effects and high temperature cyclic deformation.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EMS 174; or consent of instructor. EMS 248 recommended.

ems.name: — Special Topics in Polymer & Fiber Science
ems.description: Course Description: Selected topics of current interest in polymer and fiber sciences. Topics vary each time course is offered.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EMS 147; or consent of instructor.

ems.name: — Special Topics in Polymer & Fiber Science
ems.description: Course Description: Selected topics of current interest in polymer and fiber sciences. Topics vary each time course is offered.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EMS 147; or consent of instructor.

ems.name: — Special Topics in Polymer & Fiber Science
ems.description: Course Description: Selected topics of current interest in polymer and fiber sciences. Topics vary each time course is offered.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EMS 147; or consent of instructor.

ems.name: — Advanced Thermodynamics of Solids
ems.description: Course Description: Thermodynamic principles, formalism and their application to solid materials. Statistical mechanics and the relations between microscopic and macroscopic properties. Prediction of phase diagrams and phase stability, particularly for solids.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EMS 160.

ems.name: — Advanced Topics in Structure of Materials
ems.description: Course Description: Electronic structure and crystal structure of engineering materials on the atomic scale with a detailed discussion of crystallography. Types of bonding, distinction between band structures of metals, semiconductors, and insulators. Symmetry elements, point and space groups, and common crystal structures.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EMS 162; EMS 174 recommended; graduate standing in Engineering or consent of instructor.

ems.name: — Transport Phenomena in Materials Processes
ems.description: Course Description: Thermodynamic driving forces and atomic-scale mechanisms underlying diffusive mass transport and interface motion in materials. Nucleation, growth and coarsening dynamics of phase transformations.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Engineering.

ems.name: — Advanced Materials Characterization
ems.description: Course Description: Fundamental working principles for characterization methods used in structural and compositional analysis of engineering materials. Topics include x-ray, electron, ion, and neutron interactions with materials and techniques include diffraction, spectroscopy, and imaging methods.

ems.name: — Advanced Functional Properties of Materials
ems.description: Course Description: Fundamental physical properties of solid materials important to solid state devices, specifically electronic, magnetic, and optical properties. Topics include band structures, metals, superconductors, semiconductors, dielectrics, optical properties, and magnetic properties and implementation of these properties into devices.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Physics, Chemistry, and Engineering.

ems.name: — Advanced Mechanical Properties of Materials
ems.description: Course Description: Comprehensive study of mechanical properties of materials, with special attention to dislocations and deformation and fracture control mechanisms. Mechanical properties of conventional engineering materials as well as advanced materials such as nanocrystalline solids and thin films are considered.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EMS 174.

ems.name: — Graduate Capstone Project
ems.description: Course Description: Advanced materials design experience involving analysis of engineering applications of materials, including synthesis, processing, and fabrication. Additional consideration of critical assessments of economics, manufacturing, and ethical constraints. Fundamental principles of materials science are integrated into a culminating capstone project.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in an engineering discipline.

ems.name: — Graduate Capstone Project
ems.description: Course Description: Advanced materials design experience involving analysis of engineering applications of materials, including synthesis, processing and fabrication. Additional consideration of critical assessments of economics, manufacturing, and ethical constraints. Fundamental principles of materials science are integrated into a culminating capstone project.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EMS 280A.

ems.name: — Glass: Science & Technology
ems.description: Course Description: Modern paradigms in glass science and their applications to technologies. Relation of macroscopic properties of glasses and glass-forming liquids to atomic-level structures, including principles of formation, relaxation, transport phenomena, nucleation, crystallization and phase separation in glasses.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Chemistry, Physics or Engineering, or consent of instructor.

ems.name: — Advanced Computational Materials Science
ems.description: Course Description: Capabilities and limitations of modern approaches in computational materials science. Implementation and use of these approaches. Molecular dynamics, cellular automata, and phase field techniques.
ems.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Prior numerical programming experience and familiarity with control flow statements is recommended.

ems.name: — Living Matter: Physical Biology of the Cell
ems.description: Course Description: Introduction to the origin, maintenance, and regulation of the dynamic architecture of the cell, including cellular modes of organization, dynamics and energy dissipation, molecular transport, motility, regulation, and adaptability.

ems.name: — Special Topics in Materials Science
