msa.description: Course Description: In-depth analysis of the Persian Book of Kings (Shahnameh) by Abu al-Qasim Ferdowsi (d. 1020 CE) in its historical context with a comparative perspective on the role of this work in Persian and world literature.

msa.name: — A Story for a Life: The Arabian Nights
msa.description: Course Description: In-depth exploration of The Arabian Nights, the best-known work of pre-modern Arabic literature and a major work of world literature. Analysis of the work in its historical context and in comparison to other frame tales in world literature.

msa.name: — Themes in the Arabic Novel
msa.description: Course Description: Select modern Arabic fiction (novels and short stories) in translation. Thematically connected readings supplemented by non-fictional writings when appropriate.

msa.name: — Modern Iranian Cinema
msa.description: Course Description: Iranian cinema of the 20th century in the context of profound cultural and social changes in Iran especially since the Iranian Revolution. Productions by representative directors such as Kiarostami, Makhmalbaf, Bahram Beizaie are included. Knowledge of Persian not required.
msa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing, or consent of instructor.

msa.name: — Modern South Asia Cinema
msa.description: Course Description: South Asian cinema of last 100 years in the context of cultural, social, and political changes. South Asian history, Independence, Partition, urban life, class, migration, postcolonial identity, diaspora, gender, sexuality, religion, sport, performance, etc.
msa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

msa.name: — Religion & Media in Arab World
msa.description: Course Description: Exploration of the role and experience of media technologies in the Arab world. Study of digital and electronic media as well as alternative media practices. Investigation of new trends in political activism and identity formation.

msa.name: — Women & Islamic Discourses
msa.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduction to the debates/discourses about women and Islam. Transformations in debates/discourses in colonial and postcolonial periods in the Middle East & South Asia. Comparative study of debates/discourses on family, work, law, sexuality, religion, comportment, human rights, feminist and religious movements.

msa.name: — Iranian Society & Culture
msa.description: Course Description: In-depth investigation of modern Iranian society and culture. Exploration of structures of Iranian society: family, gender, religion, minorities, economy, politics, and state. Iran’s role in the globalizing world, and the role of Iranian diasporas.

msa.name: — Topics in Middle East & South Asian Studies
msa.description: Course Description: Comparative perspective on the Middle East and South Asia. Topics may include: modernity, religious traditions, colonialism, subalternity and social movements, gender and sexuality, history and memory, science and development, ritual and performance, public culture, diasporas.

msa.name: — Topics in Regional ME/SA Studies
msa.description: Course Description: Iran & Persian topics for students specializing in region-specific Middle East & South Asia Studies.

msa.name: — Topics in Regional ME/SA Studies
msa.description: Course Description: Indian/South Asia topics for students specializing in region-specific Middle East & South Asia Studies.

msa.name: — Topics in Regional ME/SA Studies: Arab Studies
msa.description: Course Description: Arab Studies topics.

msa.name: — Undergraduate Proseminar in Middle East/South Asia
msa.description: Course Description: Seminar in Iran & Persian topics specializing in region-specific Middle East & South Asia studies.

msa.name: — Undergraduate Proseminar in Middle East/South Asia
msa.description: Course Description: Seminar in India/South Asia topics specializing in region-specific Middle East & South Asia studies.

msa.name: — Undergraduate Proseminar in Middle East/South Asia: Arab Studies Seminar
msa.description: Course Description: Seminar in Arab Studies topics.

msa.name: — Internship
msa.description: Course Description: Supervised internship on and off campus in the area of Middle East & South Asia Studies.

msa.name: — Special Study for Honors Students
msa.description: Course Description: Independent study of a problem in Middle East/South Asian studies involving the writing of an honors thesis.
msa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; open only to majors of senior standing who qualify for honors program.

msa.name: — Directed Group Study
msa.description: Course Description: Directed group study.

msa.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
msa.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

msc.name: — U.S. Army Leadership & Personal Development
msc.description: Course Description: United States Army, its organization, customs, courtesies, and rank structure. Surveys personal development skills needed for effective leadership such as critical thinking, time management, and health and fitness. Familiarization with the Army ROTC program.
msc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Lower division standing.

msc.name: — Introduction to Tactical Military Leadership
msc.description: Course Description: Military leadership fundamentals to include setting direction, problem-solving, presenting briefs, and using effective writing skills. Basic military tactics, orienteering and land navigation. Dimensions of leadership values, attributes, skills, and actions.
msc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Lower division standing.

msc.name: — Introduction to Basic Military Operations
msc.description: Course Description: Basic military tactical theories and their application at the individual and squad level. Military tactical operations and basic military first aid.
msc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Lower division standing.

msc.name: — Introduction to Military Leadership Skills
msc.description: Course Description: Personal and organizational leadership skills introduced in leadership laboratory. Extensive supervised leadership experiences conducted in a military environment. Basic military skills necessary to function in a leadership role.
msc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

msc.name: — Introduction to Military Leadership Skills
msc.description: Course Description: Continuation of development of leadership and military skills introduced in MSC 014A. Emphasis on the role of the individual, the basic organizational element of the Army, the squad. Supervisory controls reduced as students gain capabilities.
msc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

msc.name: — Introduction to Military Leadership Skills
msc.description: Course Description: Development of skills required for promotion to junior non-commissioned officer level. Chain of command from company through individual levels. Interrelationship of squad and platoon organizations.
msc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

msc.name: — Military History, Study of Battles
msc.description: Course Description: Application of the nine Principles of War to key battles in American and World history. Tactics on a strategic and operational level. Evaluation of leadership and decision-making processes of key leaders.
msc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MSC 022B; or consent of instructor.

msc.name: — Innovative Team Leadership
msc.description: Course Description: Leadership values, attributes and theories. Use of basic military skills such as land navigation and squad operations to enhance understanding of the Army. Types of military briefings. Practice in interpersonal skills. Presentation of a briefing.
msc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Lower division standing or consent of instructor.

msc.name: — Foundations of Tactical Leadership
msc.description: Course Description: Leadership of tactical teams in complex operating environment. Self-assessment of leadership style. Basic military skills: terrain analysis, patrolling and operations orders. Dynamics of adaptive leadership in the context of military operations.
msc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MSC 022A; or consent of instructor.

msc.name: — Individual Military Leadership Skills
msc.description: Course Description: Develop and practice personal military leadership skills in extensive supervised leadership labs. Cadets perform basic military skills, improve on troop leading procedures and lead subordinates in tactical situations. Begin with drill and ceremony, land navigation and individual movement techniques.
msc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MSC 014A; MSC 014B; MSC 014C; MSC 022A (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor. MSC 022A required concurrently.

msc.name: — Individual Military Leadership Skills
msc.description: Course Description: Development and practice of personal military leadership skills in extensive supervised leadership labs. Performance of basic military skills, improvement on troop-leading procedures, leadership of subordinates in tactical situations.
msc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MSC 014A; MSC 014B; MSC 014C; MSC 022B (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor. MSC 022B required concurrently.

msc.name: — Individual Military Leadership Skills
msc.description: Course Description: Develop and practice personal military leadership skills in extensive supervised leadership labs. Begin with drill and ceremony, land navigation and individual movement techniques. Cadets perform basic military skills, improve on troop leading procedures and lead subordinates in tactical situations.
msc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MSC 014A; MSC 014B; MSC 014C; MSC 021 (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor; MSC 021 required concurrently.

msc.name: — Military Leadership & Management
msc.description: Course Description: Leadership and management in organizational context. Team dynamics, leadership styles, professional ethics, development of a leadership framework. Management skills for planning, decision making, and organizing developed through definition of problems, development of courses of action, implementation of solutions.
msc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

msc.name: — Advanced Military Operations
msc.description: Course Description: Military small unit tactical theory as the basis for leadership development. Principles of war, contemporary operating environment, Geneva Law of Land Warfare, military offensive and defensive operations. Emphasis on development of critical thinking, problem solving, and communication skills.
msc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MSC 131; or consent of instructor; upper division standing.

msc.name: — Applied Leadership
msc.description: Course Description: Military small unit tactical theory and application as basis for leadership development. Application of leadership styles and skills to complete problem-solving exercises and the development of an adaptable framework applicable to a variety of shifting environments and situations.
msc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MSC 132A; or consent of instructor; upper division standing.

msc.name: — Adaptive Tactical Leadership
msc.description: Course Description: Small unit tactical operations serve as the basis for enhancement of leadership performance through tactical application. Assessment of leadership attributes, skills, and actions through participation in a variety of leadership roles in problem-solving exercises.
msc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MSC 131; or consent of instructor; upper division standing.

msc.name: — Adaptive Tactical Leadership
msc.description: Course Description: Small unit tactical operations as the basis for enhancement of leadership performance through tactical application. Assessment of leadership attributes, skills, and actions through participation in a variety of leadership roles in problem-solving exercises.
msc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MSC 132A; or consent of instructor; upper division standing.

msc.name: — Adaptive Tactical Leadership
msc.description: Course Description: Small unit tactical operations are taught, serve as basis for students exploration, development. Serve in variety of leadership roles in which leadership attributes, skills, actions are closely assessed and developed while they are faced with series of problem solving exercises.
msc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MSC 132B; or consent of instructor; upper division standing.

msc.name: — Ethical Leadership
msc.description: Course Description: Direct influence of leaders on individual motivation and group processes. The complexities of balancing moral, legal, and ethical obligations while applying fundamental business principles in determining the best possible outcome from competing solutions.
msc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

msc.name: — Military Law
msc.description: Course Description: The United States Constitution and the Military Justice System. Basic law of war, with an emphasis on issues that might arise on the battlefield or during a national emergency.
msc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MSC 141; or consent of instructor; upper division standing.

msc.name: — U.S. Army Management Systems
msc.description: Course Description: Leadership and management, focusing on four management systems: planning, organizing, leading and controlling. Practical methodologies for assessing management decisions while balancing competing ethical, economic, infrastructure and future growth trade-offs.
msc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MSC 142; or consent of instructor; upper division standing.

msc.name: — Military Training Leadership Skills
msc.description: Course Description: Enhancement of student leadership performance through practical application. Small unit military tactical operations as the basis for the student exploration and development.
msc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MSC 141; or consent of instructor; upper division standing.

msc.name: — Military Training Leadership Skills
msc.description: Course Description: Enhancement of student leadership performance through practical application. Small unit military tactical operations serve as the basis for student exploration and development.
msc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MSC 142; or consent of instructor; upper division standing.

msc.name: — Military Training Leadership Skills
msc.description: Course Description: Enhancement of student leadership performance through practical application. Small unit military tactical operations as the basis for student exploration and development.
msc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MSC 143; or consent of instructor; upper division standing.

msc.name: — Special Studies in Military Science
msc.description: Course Description: Intensive examination of one or more special problems in military science. Possible areas of study include leadership dimensions, principles of war, air-land battle imperatives, military strategy, the operational art and professional ethics.
msc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MSC 131; MSC 132A; MSC 132B; MSC 141; MSC 142; MSC 143; consent of department chair.

mcb.name: — Introduction to Human Heredity
mcb.description: Course Description: Topics in human heredity and human gene structure and function, including the genetic basis of human development, causes of birth defects, mental retardation, genetic diseases, sexual determination, development, and behavior.

mcb.name: — Biography of Cancer: Past, Present & Future
mcb.description: Course Description: Historical account of the progression of cancer treatment, prevention, and human understanding of the biological basis of cancer. Past, present and future social implications of cancer treatment and prevention. May be taught abroad.

mcb.name: — Special Study
mcb.description: Course Description: Special study.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mcb.name: — iBioseminars in Cell & Molecular Biology
mcb.description: Course Description: Hybrid course in Cellular & Molecular Biology for senior level (1) Biochemistry/Molecular Biology; (2) Genetics; or (3) Cell Biology majors. Face-to-face instruction combined with online lectures available at iBioseminars website delivered by leading researchers in Cellular & Molecular Biology.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; BIS 102; (BIS 103 or BIS 105); BIS 104.

mcb.name: — Communicating Research in the Biological Sciences
mcb.description: Course Description: Writing and communicating research concepts in the biological sciences for scientific audiences. Refining brief, informal, oral descriptions of research, writing documents required for graduate school applications, preparing conference posters, and drafting proposals for scientific fellowships.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; open to students with senior status and currently involved in laboratory research.

mcb.name: — Molecular Biology & Biochemistry Laboratory Associated Lecture
mcb.description: Course Description: Introduction to laboratory methods and procedures employed in studying molecular biology and biochemical processes. Lecture component for MCB 120L.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 102; or consent of instructor.

mcb.name: — Molecular Biology & Biochemistry Laboratory
mcb.description: Course Description: Introduction to laboratory methods and procedures employed in studying molecular biology and biochemical processes. Designed for students who need experience in use of molecular biology and biochemical techniques as research and analytical tools.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 102; or consent of instructor; must be taken concurrently with MCB 120.

mcb.name: — Advanced Molecular Biology
mcb.description: Course Description: Structure, expression, and regulation of eukaryotic genes. Chromosome structure and replication; gene structure, transcription, and RNA processing; protein synthesis and translation control; development, immune system, and oncogenes.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; (BIS 102 (can be concurrent) or BIS 105 (can be concurrent) or ABI 102 (can be concurrent)); BIS 102 or BIS 105 or ABI 102 can be concurrent although prior completion is recommended.

mcb.name: — Behavior & Analysis of Enzyme & Receptor Systems
mcb.description: Course Description: Introduction to the principles of enzyme kinetics and receptor-ligand interactions with emphasis on metabolic regulation and data analysis. Topics include simultaneous equilibria, chemical and steady-state kinetics, allosteric enzymes, mulitreactant systems, enzyme assays, membrane transport and computer-assisted simulations and analyses.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 103.

mcb.name: — Macromolecular Structure & Function
mcb.description: Course Description: In-depth investigation into protein and nucleic acid structure and thermodynamics and how these properties influence their biological functions. Key examples of important functional classes of these molecules are examined.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 102 C- or better; BIS 101.

mcb.name: — Plant Biochemistry
mcb.description: Course Description: The biochemistry of important plant processes and metabolic pathways. Discussion of methods used to understand plant processes, including use of transgenic plants.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 103 or BIS 105.

mcb.name: — Undergraduate Seminar in Biochemistry
mcb.description: Course Description: Discussion of the historical developments of modern biochemistry or current major research problems.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 103.

mcb.name: — Undergraduate Seminar in Biochemistry
mcb.description: Course Description: Discussion of the historical developments of modern biochemistry or current major research problems.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 103.

mcb.name: — Cell Biology Laboratory Associated Lecture
mcb.description: Course Description: Lectures illustrating the principles of cell biology with emphasis on light microscopy. Accompanies MCB 140L.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 104; or consent of instructor.

mcb.name: — Cell Biology Laboratory
mcb.description: Course Description: Exercises illustrating the principles of cell biology with emphasis on light microscopy.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 104 (can be concurrent).

mcb.name: — Advanced Cell Biology: Contractile & Motile Systems
mcb.description: Course Description: Advanced cell biology with emphasis on molecular, biophysical and cellular properties of contractile and motile systems.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 102; BIS 104 (can be concurrent); MAT 016B.

mcb.name: — Cell & Molecular Biophysics
mcb.description: Course Description: Physical chemical principles by which molecules form living, moving, reproducing cells. Physical nature of cytoplasm; molecular structure/bonding in macromolecules, macromolecular assemblies and protein machines. Physical techniques and modeling of cytoskeletal polymer-motor dynamics and function during intracellular transport, mitosis and motility.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; BIS 102; BIS 103; BIS 104.

mcb.name: — Mechanisms of Cell Division
mcb.description: Course Description: The molecules and mechanisms that allow eukaryotic cells to coordinate cell growth, DNA replication, segregation of chromosomes and cell division.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; BIS 102; BIS 104.

mcb.name: — Assembly & Function of Cell Signaling Machinery
mcb.description: Course Description: Molecular basis of cell signaling, including positioning of cellular machinery, components of various signaling pathways, and downstream effects of signaling on cell adhesion, cell differentiation, and programmed cell death.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; BIS 102; BIS 104.

mcb.name: — Undergraduate Seminar in Cell Biology
mcb.description: Course Description: Student reports on current topics in cell biology with emphasis on integration of concepts, synthesis, and state-of-the-art research approaches. Reviews of literature and reports of undergraduate research may be included.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing in the biological sciences or a related discipline.

mcb.name: — Developmental Biology
mcb.description: Course Description: Analysis of the mechanistic basis for animal development with a focus on experimental evidence and the relevant fundamental experimental strategies. Fertilization and early development, morphogenesis and patterning, cell differentiation, regulation of cell proliferation and tissue growth.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101.

mcb.name: — Undergraduate Seminar in Developmental Biology
mcb.description: Course Description: Student reports on current topics in cell biology with emphasis on integration of concepts, synthesis, and state-of-the-art research approaches. Reviews of literature and reports of undergraduate research may be included.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing in the biological sciences or a related discipline.

mcb.name: — Genetics Laboratory Associated Lecture
mcb.description: Course Description: Lecture instruction in the theoretical basis of laboratory techniques in transmission and molecular genetics, discussion of lab results and experiment interpretation.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; or consent of instructor.

mcb.name: — Principles of Genetics Laboratory
mcb.description: Course Description: Laboratory work in basic and molecular genetics including gene mapping, isolation and characterization of mutants in eukaryotic model systems, reverse genetics, gel electrophoresis, recombinant DNA techniques, and PCR.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101.

mcb.name: — Human Genetics & Genomics
mcb.description: Course Description: Human genome and genetic variation in human populations, molecular and genomic approaches in the practice of human genetics, epigenetic gene regulation, personal genetics and genomic medicine.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101.

mcb.name: — Developmental Genetics
mcb.description: Course Description: Current aspects of developmental genetics. Historical background and current genetic approaches to the study of development of higher animals.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MCB 121 (can be concurrent).

mcb.name: — Advanced Eukaryotic Genetics
mcb.description: Course Description: Principles and logic of modern genetic analysis to understand mechanisms governing Mendelian and epigenetic inheritance, with a focus on model organisms. Molecular basis of human genetic diseases and cancers explored through reading primary literature.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MCB 121.

mcb.name: — Undergraduate Seminar in Molecular Genetics
mcb.description: Course Description: Discussion of current topics in molecular genetics to show advanced applications of basic principles and to highlight professional career opportunities.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; MCB 121 (can be concurrent); upper division standing, and completion or concurrent enrollment in MCB 121.

mcb.name: — Principles of Genomics
mcb.description: Course Description: Fundamentals of genomics, including structural genomics, functional genomics, proteomics, and bioinformatics,  focusing on the impact of these disciplines on research in the biological sciences. Social impacts of genomic research.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101.

mcb.name: — Computer Programming for Biologists
mcb.description: Course Description: Introduction to computer programming specifically for biology majors. Programming projects have molecular biology and bioinformatic themes.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101 C- or better.

mcb.name: — Undergraduate Research Conference
mcb.description: Course Description: Presentation and discussion of current research by faculty and students.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MCB 193 (can be concurrent) or MCB 199 (can be concurrent); and consent of instructor; upper division standing; MCB 193 or MCB 199 required concurrently.

mcb.name: — Introduction to Research
mcb.description: Course Description: Various topics in molecular and cellular biology including biochemistry, genetics, and cell biology will be discussed, along with ways undergraduates can participate in research projects of faculty members.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 102 (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

mcb.name: — Internship
mcb.description: Course Description: Technical and/or practical experience on and off campus, supervised by a member of the Section of Molecular and Cellular Biology faculty.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of 84 units.

mcb.name: — Advanced Research
mcb.description: Course Description: Research project carried out under the supervision of a faculty sponsor. Discussion and analysis of results and proposed experiments on a weekly basis with faculty sponsor. May include presentation of a seminar to a research group.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing; completion of an upper division Molecular  Cellular Biology (MCB) laboratory course.

mcb.name: — Thesis Research
mcb.description: Course Description: Continuation of an intensive, individual laboratory research project in biochemistry, genetics, or cell biology culminating with the presentation of the work in a written thesis and in a seminar.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; 6 units of MCB 193 and/or MCB 199 with faculty director; senior standing.

mcb.name: — Research Honors
mcb.description: Course Description: Honors project. Continuation of an intensive, individual laboratory research project in biochemistry, genetics, or cell biology culminating with the presentation of the work in a written thesis and in a seminar.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; 6 units of MCB 193 and/or MCB 199 with faculty director; senior standing; GPA of at least 3.250.

mcb.name: — Tutoring in Molecular & Cellular Biology
mcb.description: Course Description: Assisting the instructor in one of the section's regular courses by tutoring individual or small groups of students in a laboratory, in voluntary discussion groups, or other voluntary course activities.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing, completion of course to be tutored.

mcb.name: — Directed Group Study
mcb.description: Course Description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mcb.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
mcb.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mcb.name: — Seminar in Cell Biology
mcb.description: Course Description: Discussion of recent literature on the physical and chemical aspects of organization and function of living systems, topics of current interest in ultrastructure and function of cells. Organizational and functional properties of the molecular and cellular levels of biological systems.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mcb.name: — Seminar in Development
mcb.description: Course Description: Reports and discussion on embryology, morphogenesis, and developmental mechanisms.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mcb.name: — Literature in Developmental Biology
mcb.description: Course Description: Critical presentation and analysis of recent journal articles in developmental biology.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mcb.name: — Biotechnology Internship
mcb.description: Course Description: Research at a biotechnology company or interdisciplinary cross-college lab for a minimum of 3 months as part of the Designated Emphasis in Biotechnology Program.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

mcb.name: — Research Conference
mcb.description: Course Description: Presentations and critical discussions of faculty and graduate student research in molecular and cellular biology including biochemistry, genetics, and cell biology.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

mcb.name: — Current Progress in Molecular & Cellular Biology
mcb.description: Course Description: Seminars presented by guest lecturers on subject of their own research activities.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

mcb.name: — Literature in Molecular & Cellular Biology
mcb.description: Course Description: Critical reading and evaluation of current literature in molecular and cellular biology disciplines. Papers presented and discussed in detail.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

mcb.name: — Group Study
mcb.description: Course Description: Group study.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mcb.name: — Research
mcb.description: Course Description: Research.

mcb.name: — Methods of Teaching
mcb.description: Course Description: Practical experience in the methods and problems of teaching biochemistry/genetics/cell biology. Includes analysis of texts and supporting material, discussion of teaching techniques, preparing for and conducting discussion and laboratory sections, formulating examinations under supervision of instructor. Participating in the teaching program required for Ph.D.
mcb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

vmb.name: — Internship
vmb.description: Course Description: Work experience off and on campus in all subject areas offered in the Department of Molecular Biosciences. Internships supervised by a member of the faculty.
vmb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

vmb.name: — Principles of Pharmacology & Toxicology
vmb.description: Course Description: Online course provides training in core concepts of pharmacological and toxicological sciences and prepares to develop higher-order problem solving and critical thinking skills. Designed for advanced undergraduate students with interests in pursuing graduate degrees in pharmacology, toxicology, physiological sciences, and for students with an interest in pursuing D.V.M., M.D., Pharmacy, Dentistry and Nursing professional degrees. Students who pursue careers in environmental sciences, public health management, and epidemiology may also benefit from the subject matter presented in this course.
vmb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor;  upper division standing in a science major; chemistry through organic chemistry, general biology, or consent of instructor; good standing with the university; computing capability (use MS Word®, Excel®, PowerPoint®, menu driven software programs, Course LMS); own a computer or have ready access to a computer with broadband Internet access; NPB 101 and BIS 104 recommended.

vmb.name: — Principles of Pharmacology & Toxicology
vmb.description: Course Description: Hybrid course provides training in core concepts of pharmacological and toxicological sciences. Develop higher-order problem solving and critical thinking skills.
vmb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing in a science major; chemistry through organic chemistry and general biology, or consent from instructor; good standing with university; computing capability using MS Word®, Excel®, PowerPoint®, menu driven software programs, SmartSite; computer, or ready access to a computer, with broadband Internet access.

vmb.name: — Internship
vmb.description: Course Description: Work experience off and on campus in all subject areas offered by the Department of Molecular Biosciences. Internships supervised by a member of the faculty.
vmb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of 84 units.

vmb.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
vmb.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

vmb.name: — Oxidative Stress & Free Radical Signaling
vmb.description: Course Description: Nature of nitrogen and oxygen radicals, their role in health, disease, medicine, toxicology, pharmacology, and related disciplines. Free radicals, antioxidants, and biological pathways. Clinical cases of increased oxidative stress.
vmb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Advanced undergraduates, graduates, and professional students with a solid background in biochemistry and physiology.

vmb.name: — Current Topics in Neurotoxicology
vmb.description: Course Description: General principles of neurotoxicology, the cell and molecular mechanisms and health impacts of specific neurotoxicants and the contribution of neurotoxic compounds to complex neurodevelopmental disorders and neurodegenerative diseases.
vmb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Core courses in one of the following graduate programs: Pharmacology  Toxicology (PTX), Agricultural  Environmental Chemistry (AGC), Biochemistry  Molecular Biology (BMB), Cell  Developmental Biology (CDB), Immunology (IMM), Molecular Cellular  Integrative Physiology (MCP) or Neuroscience (NSC).

vmb.name: — Metabolism of Toxicants & Drugs
vmb.description: Course Description: Significance/chemical pathways of toxicants and drug metabolism, enzymology and molecular aspects of P450 and flavin monooxygenases, hydrolases and phase 2 transferases and experimental approaches for metabolism studies.
vmb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PTX 201; PTX 202; PTX 203; general biochemistry or consent of instructor.

vmb.name: — Toxicology of the Respiratory System
vmb.description: Course Description: Survey of structure and function of the respiratory system, the pathophysiology of major lung diseases, the interactions of toxicants with the lung and response of this organ to injury.
vmb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PTX 201; PTX 202; PTX 203; or consent of instructor.

vmb.name: — Pharmacokinetics & Biopharmaceuticals
vmb.description: Course Description: In-depth study of pharmacokinetics, including the fundamentals of pharmacokinetics, how to design a pharmacokinetic study and how to use both compartmental and non-compartmental analysis to interpret the data.

vmb.name: — Seminar
vmb.description: Course Description: Topics in nutrition, pharmacology/toxicology, and biochemistry.
vmb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

vmb.name: — Tutoring in Graduate Molecular Biosciences
vmb.description: Course Description: Assist in preparation and teaching of courses in Nutrition, Pharmacology and Toxicology, or other courses offered by the department under direct supervision of the instructor. Designed for graduate or professional students who desire teaching experience in graduate courses.
vmb.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate or professional student standing.

mcp.name: — Animal Cell Culture Laboratory
mcp.description: Course Description: Techniques of cell culture, with emphases on cell physiology and the actions of drugs and toxicants on cultured somatic cells. Design, performance and interpretation of experiments with animal cells in vitro.
mcp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Courses in undergraduate Biochemistry, Cell Biology, or General Physiology, or consent of instructor.

mcp.name: — Advanced Physiology
mcp.description: Course Description: Advanced course on fundamental principles of cell physiology, transport physiology, signal transduction, physiology of excitable cells, and muscle physiology.
mcp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Physiology Ph.D. program or consent of instructor.

mcp.name: — Advanced Physiology
mcp.description: Course Description: Advanced course in general principles of physiology, surveying homeostasis, cellular and selected topis, and neurophysiology.
mcp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Physiology Ph.D. program, or consent of instructor.

mcp.name: — Advanced Physiology
mcp.description: Course Description: Graduate level instruction in the general principles of physiology and the neural and humoral control of the cardiovascular, renal, respiratory, gastrointestinal, sensory, musculoskeletal, and reproductive systems.
mcp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Doctoral student in the Molecular, Cellular,  Integrative Physiology graduate group, or consent of instructor.

mcp.name: — Physiology Laboratory Rotations
mcp.description: Course Description: One mandatory rotation and up-to two voluntary rotations. Students learn techniques and perform experiments related to particular research problems. At the end of the rotations students give a short talk and hand in a research paper.

mcp.name: — Electrophysiology Techniques & Applications
mcp.description: Course Description: Broad scope of topics in electrophysiology techniques and applications.

mcp.name: — Neurophysiology Literature
mcp.description: Course Description: Lectures covering experimental and theoretical methods in studying cell membrane ion channels and the resulting characterization of the physiological functions and structure/function relationships of some of the most important channel types. Discussion of classical and current original papers.

mcp.name: — Muscle Growth & Development
mcp.description: Course Description: Integration of growth and development of skeletal muscle; morphology, biochemistry, neural control mechanisms, circulatory and nutritional factors. Prenatal and neonatal differentiation of fiber types. Experimental and hereditary myopathies.
mcp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 103; (BIS 104 or MCB 150); or consent of instructor.

mcp.name: — General & Comparative Physiology of Reproduction
mcp.description: Course Description: Basic phenomena of sexual and asexual reproduction and comparisons of processes in a wide variety of animals; gamete formation, structure, and metabolism; fertilization; neuroendocrine mechanisms in maturation and reproductive cycles; behavioral aspects.
mcp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; BIS 103; NPB 110; NPB 110L.

mcp.name: — Mammalian Gametogenesis & Fertilization
mcp.description: Course Description: Emphasizes our current understanding of events in mammalian gametogenesis and the fertilization process. Published results, conclusions drawn from these results, and their contribution to our understanding are discussed.
mcp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 121; or the equivalent.

mcp.name: — Advanced Endocrinology
mcp.description: Course Description: Focus on timely topic of endrocrine research. Critical review of current literature and discussion of future research strategies in the area.
mcp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 130; or the equivalent, and graduate standing.

mcp.name: — Neuroendocrinology
mcp.description: Course Description: Neural-endocrine interactions; neural regulation of the endocrine system, especially in relation to reproduction; the role of hormones and growth factors in sexual differentiation of the brain.
mcp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 130; or the equivalent course in endocrinology; NPB 110 or the equivalent course in systemic physiology.

mcp.name: — Current Topics in Neurotoxicology
mcp.description: Course Description: General principles of neurotoxicology, the cell and molecular mechanisms and health impacts of specific neurotoxicants and the contribution of neurotoxic compounds to complex neurodevelopmental disorders and neurodegenerative diseases.
mcp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Core courses in one of the following graduate programs: Pharmacology  Toxicology (PTX), Agricultural  Environmental Chemistry (AGC), Biochemistry  Molecular Biology (BMB), Cell  Developmental Biology (CDB), Immunology (IMM), Molecular Cellular  Integrative Physiology (MCP) or Neuroscience (NSC).

mcp.name: — Biological Rhythms
mcp.description: Course Description: General aspects and basic mechanisms of biological rhythms; the importance of rhythm desynchronization in areas of pharmacology and space medicine; telemetry; mathematical methods; chronometry; daily, reproductive, and annual periods; shift-work, jet lag and sleep disorders.
mcp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 110 or the equivalent.

mcp.name: — Physiology of the Stress Response
mcp.description: Course Description: Definition of Stress; Physiological mechanisms of adaptation to stress; Hormonal control of the systemic stress response; Mechanisms of the cellular stress response; Discussion of current trends in stress physiology and current methods for studying the stress response.
mcp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate Student Status.

mcp.name: — Topics in Vision: Eyes & Retinal Mechanisms
mcp.description: Course Description: Structure and function of the visual system, with emphasis on the eye and retina, including optics, anatomy, transduction, retinal synapses, adaptation, and parallel processing.
mcp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 100 or NPB 112; or the equivalent; graduate standing.

mcp.name: — Topics in Vision: Systems, Psychophysics, Computational Models
mcp.description: Course Description: Functions of the central visual pathways and their underlying mechanisms. Recent research on aspects of anatomy, biochemistry, electrophysiology, psychophysics, development, and genetics of the visual system.
mcp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; MCP 261A recommended.

mcp.name: — Topics in Vision: Clinical Vision Science
mcp.description: Course Description: Causes and mechanistic bases of major blinding diseases. Recent research on aspects of anatomy, biochemistry, electrophysiology, psychophysics, development, and genetics of the visual system related to disease.
mcp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MCP 261A; MCP 261B; or consent of instructor.

mcp.name: — Neurohumoral Regulatory Mechanisms of Thermogenesis
mcp.description: Course Description: Designed for graduate and advanced undergraduate students, examines thermogenic systems in homeotherms (primarily mammals) with respect to regulation (hormonal and central nervous control) and effector mechanisms (basis of heat generation at the target cell).
mcp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 104; BIS 102; or equivalent courses, and consent of instructor.

mcp.name: — Seminar
mcp.description: Course Description: Discussion and critical evaluation of advanced topics and current trends in research.

mcp.name: — Research Conference in Physiology
mcp.description: Course Description: Presentation and discussion of faculty and graduate student research in physiology.
mcp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Graduate standing.

mcp.name: — Seminar in Cellular Mechanisms of Adaptation
mcp.description: Course Description: Review and evaluation of current literature and research in cellular adaptations to the environment.
mcp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 103; NPB 100B; consent of instructor.

mcp.name: — Research Approaches in Physiology
mcp.description: Course Description: Current research in physiology. Overall design of experiments and particular research areas.

mcp.name: — Current Progress in Physiology
mcp.description: Course Description: Seminars presented by guest lecturers describing their current research activities.
mcp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

mcp.name: — Group Study
mcp.description: Course Description: Group study.

mcp.name: — Research
mcp.description: Course Description: Research.

mcp.name: — Pedagogical Aspects of Physiology in Higher Education
mcp.description: Course Description: Participation as a teaching assistant for one quarter in a designated physiology course. Instruction in methods of leading discussion groups, leading laboratory sections, writing and grading quizzes, operation and use of laboratory equipment, and reading and grading laboratory reports. Meets teaching requirements for Ph.D. program in Physiology.
mcp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Meet qualifications for teaching assistant in physiology.

mcp.name: — Pedagogical Aspects of Physiology in Higher Education
mcp.description: Course Description: Participation as a teaching assistant for one quarter in a designated physiology course. Instruction in methods of leading discussion groups, leading laboratory sections, writing and grading quizzes, operation and use of laboratory equipment, and reading and grading laboratory reports. Meets teaching requirements for Ph.D. program in Physiology.
mcp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Meet qualifications for teaching assistant in physiology.

mcp.name: — The Teaching of Physiology
mcp.description: Course Description: Practical experience in methods and problems of teaching physiology lecture courses. May include analyses of texts and supporting material, discussion of teaching techniques, preparing for and conducting discussion sessions, and formulation of topics and questions for examinations under supervision of instructor.
mcp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; Teaching Assistant assignment to a physiology lecture course.

mus.name: — Keyboard Competence, Part 1
mus.description: Course Description: Training to meet the minimum piano requirements for the major in music. Scales and simple harmonic progressions in twelve keys, both major and minor.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 006A (can be concurrent); MUS 016A (can be concurrent); consent of instructor. MUS 006A and MUS 016A required concurrently.

mus.name: — Keyboard Competence, Part 2
mus.description: Course Description: Training to meet the minimum piano requirements for the major in music. Harmonic progressions, modulations and score reading at the piano.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 002A; (MUS 006B (can be concurrent),  MUS 016B (can be concurrent)); consent of instructor. MUS 006B and MUS 016B required concurrently. Completion of MUS 002A or demonstration of required keyboard proficiency level on diagnostic exam.

mus.name: — Keyboard Competence, Part 3
mus.description: Course Description: Training to meet the minimum piano requirements for the major in music. Harmonic progressions, figured bass realization, sight reading and keyboard repertory.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 002B; (MUS 006C (can be concurrent),  MUS 016C (can be concurrent)); consent of instructor. MUS 006C and MUS 016C required concurrently; completion of MUS 002B or demonstration of required keyboard proficiency level on diagnostic exam.

mus.name: — Introduction to Music Theory, Part 1
mus.description: Course Description: Fundamentals of music theory, ear-training, harmony, counterpoint, and analysis directed toward the development of listening and writing techniques. Intended for the general student.

mus.name: — Introduction to Music Theory, Part 2
mus.description: Course Description: Continuation of MUS 003A. Development of melodic and harmonic writing skills. Basic analysis training. Intended for the general student.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 003A; or consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Elementary Theory, Part 1
mus.description: Course Description: Development of music writing and listening skills through the study of music fundamentals, species counterpoint, harmony, analysis of repertory. Intended primarily for music majors.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 002A (can be concurrent); MUS 016A (can be concurrent); required concurrently.

mus.name: — Elementary Theory, Part 2
mus.description: Course Description: Continuation of MUS 006A.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 002B (can be concurrent); MUS 016B (can be concurrent); required concurrently; completion of MUS 006A or demonstration of required proficiency level on diagnostic exam.

mus.name: — Elementary Theory, Part 3
mus.description: Course Description: Continuation of MUS 006A & MUS 006B.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 002C (can be concurrent); MUS 016C (can be concurrent); MUS 002C MUS 016C required concurrently; completion of MUS 006B or demonstration of required proficiency level on diagnostic exam.

mus.name: — Intermediate Theory, Part 1
mus.description: Course Description: Homophonic music of the Classical era with a focus on analysis of music by Haydn, Mozart, and Beethoven. Composition of pieces in the homophonic forms such as minuet and trio, theme and variations, rondo and sonata. Intended for music majors.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 006C; MUS 017A (can be concurrent).

mus.name: — Intermediate Theory, Part 2
mus.description: Course Description: Harmony and voice of the 19th century leading through the music of the Romantic era. Focus on analysis of music by Chopin, Schumann, Brahms, Wagner, and Wolf. Composition of character pieces and songs. Intended for Music majors.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 007A; MUS 017B (can be concurrent).

mus.name: — Intermediate Theory, Part 3
mus.description: Course Description: Music of the first thirty years of the 20th century and various analytical tools pertaining to it. Works of Debussy, Stravinsky, Schoenberg, Berg, and others. Composition of small pieces for solo instruments, voice and piano. Intended for music majors.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 007B; MUS 017C (can be concurrent).

mus.name: — Introduction to Musical Literature
mus.description: Course Description: Introduction to composers and major styles of Western music. Lectures, listening sections, and selected readings. For non-majors.

mus.name: — Musics of the World
mus.description: Course Description: Survey of selected art, folk, and popular music cultures from different parts of the world. Emphasis on understanding relationship of musical style, aesthetic principles, and performance practice to wider cultural contexts.

mus.name: — Elementary Musicianship, Part 1
mus.description: Course Description: Melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic materials of Western music. Includes sight singing, explanations, drills, melodic/rhythmic/harmonic dictations, and listening analysis.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 002A (can be concurrent); MUS 006A (can be concurrent); MUS 002A and MUS 006A required concurrently.

mus.name: — Elementary Musicianship, Part 2
mus.description: Course Description: Melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic materials of Western music. Includes sight singing, explanations, drills, melodic/rhythmic/harmonic dictations, and listening analysis.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 016A; (MUS 002B (can be concurrent), MUS 006B (can be concurrent)); MUS 002B and MUS 006B required concurrently; completion of MUS 016A or demonstration of required proficiency level on diagnostic exam.

mus.name: — Elementary Musicianship, Part 3
mus.description: Course Description: Melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic materials of Western music. Includes sight singing, explanations, drills, melodic/rhythmic/harmonic dictations, and listening analysis.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 016B; (MUS 002C (can be concurrent), MUS 006C (can be concurrent)); MUS 002C and MUS 006C required concurrently; completion of MUS 016B or demonstration of required proficiency level on diagnostic exam.

mus.name: — Intermediate Musicianship, Part 1
mus.description: Course Description: Melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic materials of Western music. Includes sight singing, explanations, drills, melodic/rhythmic/harmonic dictations, and listening analysis.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 016C; MUS 007A (can be concurrent); or demonstrate required proficiency level on diagnostic exam.

mus.name: — Intermediate Musicianship, Part 2
mus.description: Course Description: Melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic materials of Western music. Includes sight singing, explanations, drills, melodic/rhythmic/harmonic dictations, and listening analysis.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 017A; (MUS 007B (can be concurrent); MUS 007B required concurrently. Completion of MUS 017A or demonstration of required proficiency level on diagnostic exam.

mus.name: — Intermediate Musicianship, Part 3
mus.description: Course Description: The melodic, rhythmic, and harmonic materials of Western music. Includes sight singing, explanations, drills, melodic/rhythmic/harmonic dictations, and listening analysis.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 017B; completion of MUS 017B or demonstration of required proficiency level on diagnostic exam; MUS 007C required concurrently.

mus.name: — History of Western Music: Baroque & Classic Eras
mus.description: Course Description: History of western music in the baroque and classic eras, roughly 1600-1800. Intended primarily for majors in music.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 006A; or consent of instructor.

mus.name: — History of Western Music: Romantic Era
mus.description: Course Description: History of music from the romantic period, roughly 1800-1900. Intended primarily for music majors.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 024A; or consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Introduction to African American Music
mus.description: Course Description: Survey of African American music, such as spirituals, blues, ragtime, jazz, theater, gospel, R&B, rap, and art music. Emphasis on historical and sociocultural contexts, as well as African roots.

mus.name: — Directed Group Study
mus.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
mus.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Advanced Theory, Part 1
mus.description: Course Description: Music of the 20th century from 1930 through 1950 and the various analytical tools pertaining to it. Works of Copland, Sessions, Schoenberg, Bartók, and Stravinsky. Composition of small pieces for piano and voice.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 007C.

mus.name: — Advanced Theory, Part 2
mus.description: Course Description: Music from 1950 to the present and the analytical tools pertaining to it. Works of Babbit, Carter, Dallapiccola, Ligeti, Messiaen, Reich and others. Composition of small pieces for ensemble.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 101A.

mus.name: — Tonal Counterpoint
mus.description: Course Description: Imitative tonal counterpoint with an analytical focus on the Two-Part Inventions and fugues from the The Well-Tempered Klavier by J. S. Bach. Composition of exercises and short pieces using contrapuntal techniques. Intended for music majors.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 006C; or consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Workshop in Composition
mus.description: Course Description: Workshop in musical composition for undergraduates who are interested in pursuing serious compositional studies and intending to follow the composition track of the major. Explores the techniques and materials of musical composition.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 006C; or consent of instructor.

mus.name: — History & Analysis of Jazz
mus.description: Course Description: Jazz and the evolution of jazz styles in historical and cultural context. For non-majors.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 003A or MUS 006A or MUS 010 or MUS 011 or MUS 028; or consent of instructor.

mus.name: — History of Rock Music
mus.description: Course Description: Rock and the evolution of rock styles in historical and cultural context. For non-majors.

mus.name: — Introduction to Electronic Music
mus.description: Course Description: Basics of electronic music history, techniques, and composition. Fixed media creation using field recordings. Focus on history, theory and techniques of musique concrète, elektronische musik, and related repertoire.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Handmade Electronic Music
mus.description: Course Description: Hacking, bending, and creating electronic circuits to make sound. Learning to read circuit diagrams, to build prototypes, and to solder components together. Repertoire study.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 107A; consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Computer Music
mus.description: Course Description: Making electronic music in an open source programming environment. Intermediate synthesis, physical controllers, and algorithmic music. Overview of history, aesthetics, and techniques of digital sonic art. Three composition projects.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 107A.

mus.name: — Orchestration
mus.description: Course Description: Techniques of orchestration from study of basic instrumental techniques to analysis of orchestral scores and scoring for various instrumental combinations.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 006C; or consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Orchestration
mus.description: Course Description: Techniques of orchestration from study of basic instrumental techniques to analysis of orchestral scores and scoring for various instrumental combinations.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 108A; or consent of instructor.

mus.name: — The Musical World of Beethoven
mus.description: Course Description: Work of Beethoven will be studied in the context of his time and his contemporaries. Lectures, discussion/guided listening sections, and selected readings. For non-majors.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 003A or MUS 006A or MUS 010; or consent of instructor.

mus.name: — The Musical World of a 20th-Century Composer
mus.description: Course Description: Overview of concert music by a significant twentieth-century composer outside the United States (for example: Igor Stravinsky, Claude Debussy, Gustav Mahler, Arnold Schoenberg, Bela Bartok, Dmitri Shostakovich, Benjamin Britten, Olivier Messiaen, Osvaldo Golijov, Tan Dun, Kaija Saariaho).  Lectures, discussion/guided listening sections, and selected readings. For non-majors.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 003A or MUS 006A or MUS 010; or consent of instructor.

mus.name: — The Musical World of J. S. Bach
mus.description: Course Description: Work of J. S. Bach will be studied in the context of his time and his contemporaries. Lectures, discussion/guided listening sections, and selected readings. For non-majors.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 003A or MUS 006A or MUS 010; or consent of instructor.

mus.name: — The Musical World of Mozart
mus.description: Course Description: Work of Mozart will be studied in the context of his time and his contemporaries. Lectures, discussion/guided listening sections, and selected readings. For non-majors.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 003A or MUS 006A or MUS 010; or consent of instructor.

mus.name: — The Musical World of an 18th-Century Composer
mus.description: Course Description: Overview of concert music by a significant European eighteenth-century composer other than Mozart, Beethoven, or J. S. Bach (for example: Franz Joseph Haydn, George Frideric Handel, Antonio Vivaldi). Lectures, discussion/guided listening sections, and selected readings. For non-majors.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 003A or MUS 006A or MUS 010; or consent of instructor.

mus.name: — The Musical World of an American Composer
mus.description: Course Description: Overview of American concert music by a significant American composer (for example: Aaron Copland, George Gershwin, Ruth Crawford, Charles Ives, Duke Ellington, Leonard Bernstein, John Cage, John Adams). Lectures, discussion/guided listening sections, and selected readings. For non-majors.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 003A or MUS 006A or MUS 010 or MUS 011 or MUS 028; or consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Jazz Fundamentals
mus.description: Course Description: Fundamentals of Jazz music theory, ear training, harmony and composition techniques. Designed to complement participation in Jazz Combo or Jazz Band. First of a three-course sequence.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 003A C- or better; or consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Jazz Theory
mus.description: Course Description: Intermediate level Jazz music theory, ear training, harmony, and composition techniques including improvisation. Designed to complement participation in Jazz Combo or Jazz Band. Second of a three-course sequence.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 112A C- or better; consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Jazz Composition
mus.description: Course Description: Jazz compositions and arranging in different styles using techniques of Jazz theory, harmony and improvisation. Third of a three-course sequence.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 112B C- or better; consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Introduction to Conducting
mus.description: Course Description: Principles and techniques of conducting as they apply to both choral and instrumental ensembles.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 006C; or consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Intermediate Conducting
mus.description: Course Description: Intermediate conducting with a continued focus on principles and techniques as they apply to both choral and instrumental ensembles.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 113; or consent of instructor.

mus.name: — History of Film Music
mus.description: Course Description: Film music from silent films to movies of the past decade. How music supports and shapes film narrative and structure. Use of jazz, rock and classical music in film.

mus.name: — Introduction to the Music of The Beatles
mus.description: Course Description: Survey of music of The Beatles, focusing on the songs of Lennon and McCartney. Emphasis on understanding their evolution as musicians, composers and cultural figures. Discussion of their musical influences in wider cultural contexts.

mus.name: — The Broadway Musical
mus.description: Course Description: Exploration of a variety of Broadway and film musicals from different time periods, and how musicals reflect and help create social reality, and the different aspects of the creative process as manifested through music, dance, scenery, and acting.

mus.name: — Topics in Music Scholarship
mus.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Sources and problems of a historical period or musical style selected by the instructor and announced in advance.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 006C; MUS 024C; or consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Topics in Analysis & Theory
mus.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Analysis of works of a composer or musical style selected by the instructor and announced in advance. Consideration of theoretical issues.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 006C; MUS 024C; or consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Music as Culture
mus.description: Course Description: Introduction to the study of music in cross-cultural perspective. Basic theories and frameworks of ethnomusicology; in-depth case studies of three musical traditions from around the world. Intended for music majors.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 024B; or consent of instructor.

mus.name: — History of Western Music: 20th Century to the Present
mus.description: Course Description: History of Western Music from 1900 to the present. Intended primarily for music majors.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 024B; or consent of instructor.

mus.name: — History of Western Music: Middle Ages & Renaissance
mus.description: Course Description: History of Western Music in the Middle Ages and Renaissance, roughly 800-1600. Intended primarily for music majors. Leaning Activities: Lecture 3 hour(s); Listening.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 024C or MUS 124C; or consent of instructor.

mus.name: — American Music
mus.description: Course Description: Introductory survey of American musics, including Native American music, Hispanic polyphony, New England psalmody, and selected 20th-century composers and styles.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 003A or MUS 006A or MUS 010 or MUS 011 or MUS 028; or consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Music from Latin America
mus.description: Course Description: Examination of music from Latin America. Characteristic music (i.e., tango, bossa nova, salsa, musica motena, musica andina) as well as its implications in other musical genres. Taught in English or Spanish depending on instructor.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Music from Latin America
mus.description: Course Description: Examination of music from Latin America. Characteristic music (i.e. tango, bossa nova, salsa, musica motena, musica andina) as well as its implications in other musical genres. Taught abroad in Spanish or English depending on instructor.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Musics of the Americas
mus.description: Course Description: Survey of music cultures from North, Central, and South America, including the Caribbean, with emphasis on the role of music in society and on the elements of music (instruments, theory, genres and form, etc.). Introduction to ethnomusicological theory, methods, approaches.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 003A or MUS 006A or MUS 010 or MUS 011 or MUS 028; or consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Musics of Africa, Middle East, Indian Subcontinent
mus.description: Course Description: Survey of music cultures with special emphasis on the role of music in society and on the elements of music (instruments, theory, genres and form, etc.). Introduction to ethnomusicological theory, methods, approaches.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 003A or MUS 006A or MUS 010 or MUS 011 or MUS 028; or consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Musics of East & Southeast Asia
mus.description: Course Description: Survey of music cultures from Japan, China, Korea, Vietnam, and Indonesia, with special emphasis on the role of music in society and on the elements of music (instruments, theory, genres and form, etc.). Introduction to ethnomusicological theory, methods, approaches.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 003A or MUS 006A or MUS 010 or MUS 011 or MUS 028; or consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Folk Musics of Europe
mus.description: Course Description: Survey of folk musics from all of Europe, with emphasis on the role of music in society and on the elements of music (instruments, genres, form, etc.). Introduction to ethnomusicological theory, methods, approaches.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 003A or MUS 006A or MUS 010 or MUS 011 or MUS 028; or consent of instructor.

mus.description: Course Description: Class instruction, arranged by section; Voice. Offered as demand indicates.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; admission by audition.

mus.name: — Singing for Actors
mus.description: Course Description: Elements of basic singing techniques, through selected exercises, vocalises, and songs.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mus.name: — University Jazz Band
mus.description: Course Description: Rehearsal, study, and performance of jazz band music and a full variety of jazz band styles, including swing, be-bob, and contemporary jazz styles.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; admission by audition.

mus.name: — University Symphony
mus.description: Course Description: Open to any student in the University whose proficiency meets the requirements of concert performance. Sight-reading, rehearsal and performance of music from the orchestral literature.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; admission by audition.

mus.name: — University Chamber Singers
mus.description: Course Description: Rehearsal and performance of works for small choral group.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; admission by audition.

mus.name: — University Concert Band
mus.description: Course Description: Rehearsal and performance of music for band.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; admission by audition.

mus.name: — University Chorus
mus.description: Course Description: Rehearsal and performance of choral music.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; admission by audition.

mus.name: — Early Music Ensemble
mus.description: Course Description: Rehearsal and performance of Medieval, Renaissance, and Baroque music for vocal ensemble and historical instruments.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; admission by audition.

mus.name: — Chamber Music Ensemble
mus.description: Course Description: Open to any student in the University whose proficiency meets the requirements of concert performance. Study, rehearsal, and performance of ensemble music for strings, winds, voice, piano, harpsichord, and organ.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; admission by audition.

mus.name: — University Wind Ensemble
mus.description: Course Description: Rehearsal, study, and performance of a full variety of wind ensemble music; and to have students share their work in public performances.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Hindustani Vocal Ensemble
mus.description: Course Description: Basics of Hindustani music through theory and practice. Fundamentals of raga (mode) and tala (rhythms) with special emphasis on improvisation, a central feature of khyal (singing style). Five ragas each quarter.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Indonesian Gamelan Ensemble
mus.description: Course Description: Indonesian music practice. Basic instrumental technique and repertory. Focus on two styles of Sundanese gamelan (tuned percussion orchestras):  salendro and degung.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Brazilian Samba School
mus.description: Course Description: Practice of Brazilian music. Basic instrumental technique and repertory. Focus on the percussion traditions of Rio de Janeiro and Bahia.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Korean Percussion Ensemble
mus.description: Course Description: Practice of Korean percussion styles. Basic instrumental technique and repertory. Focus on the percussion traditions of samulnori and basic concepts of p'ungmul.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Afro-Cuban Ensemble
mus.description: Course Description: Performance of African derived folkloric music of Cuba. Basic instrumental technique and repertory. Focus on percussion and song traditions from Havana, Matazas and Santiago, Cuba.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Brazilian Capoeira Ensemble
mus.description: Course Description: Basic instrumental techniques, songs, and dance movements of Capoeira Angola. Protocols of a Capoeira Angola performance and the meanings of Capoeira in Brazil with its connections to Afro-Brazilian culture.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Percussion Ensemble
mus.description: Course Description: Study and rehearsal of percussion chamber music from the 20th and 21st centuries. Study of standard and extended techniques for a broad range of percussion instruments. Public performance of significant works for percussion ensemble.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; admission by audition.

mus.name: — Mariachi Ensemble
mus.description: Course Description: Rehearsal and performance of traditional and contemporary mariachi repertoire.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Internship in Music
mus.description: Course Description: Internship outside the university related to music.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor or academic advisor.

mus.name: — Special Study for Honors Students
mus.description: Course Description: Preparation and presentation of a culminating project, under the supervision of an instructor, in one of the creative or scholarly areas of music.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 007C; MUS 123; consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Special Study for Honors Students
mus.description: Course Description: Preparation and presentation of a culminating project, under the supervision of an instructor, in one of the creative or scholarly areas of music.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 194HA; consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Senior Project
mus.description: Course Description: Preparation of a senior project in music composition (public presentation of a new work), in music performance (a public recital), or in music history and theory (public presentation of research results).
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 007C; MUS 123; consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Directed Group Study
mus.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
mus.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Notation
mus.description: Course Description: Study of musical notation; investigation of techniques for editing Medieval and Renaissance music.

mus.name: — Music Composition
mus.description: Course Description: Technical projects that explore compositional problems, the skill and techniques with which to solve them, and free composition.

mus.name: — Advanced Conducting
mus.description: Course Description: Technical aspects of conducting and the broader issues in music history and analysis that conductors must face before leading a rehearsal or performance.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Advanced Electronic & Computer Music
mus.description: Course Description: Advanced composition of computer and electronic music.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MUS 107A; MUS 107B; MUS 107C; consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Proseminar in Music: Theory & Analysis
mus.description: Course Description: Voice-leading analysis of tonal music derived from Schenker and pitchclass set theory. Recent work on compositional design, generalizations of the concept of interval, psychologically oriented music theory, and theories of durational structure and timbre.

mus.name: — Proseminar in Music: Musicology &Criticism
mus.description: Course Description: Issues and concepts of music history, including performance practice questions for specific repertoires and periods; principles, aims, and methods of archival study; historical theory; evolution of musical styles; philosophical debates about goals and aims of the discipline in general.

mus.name: — Proseminar in Music: Ethnomusicology
mus.description: Course Description: Introduction to ethnomusicology through its intellectual history, theoretical approaches, analytical techniques, and methodologies.

mus.name: — Ethics of Musical Ethnography
mus.description: Course Description: Role, methodology, perception, and assumptions of the ethnomusicologist in ethnographic scholarship. Examination of complex ethical and political questions in relation to practical fieldwork techniques.

mus.name: — Transcription & Notation
mus.description: Course Description: Practical instruction in the transcription and analysis of primarily non-Western musics. Analytical and theoretical issues, the politics of representation, and the cultural values and ideologies implicit in notation.

mus.name: — Recent Issues in Ethnomusicology
mus.description: Course Description: Issues, schools of thought, and basic literature in ethnomusicology from the 1980s to present. Emphasis on theory and methodology.

mus.name: — Topics in Music History
mus.description: Course Description: Studies in selected areas of music history and theory.

mus.name: — Techniques of Analysis
mus.description: Course Description: Analysis and analytical techniques as applied to music of all historical style periods.

mus.name: — Topics in Ethnomusicology
mus.description: Course Description: In-depth ethnomusicological studies of selected cultures and their musics; study of historical, theoretical, contextual, and cultural features.

mus.name: — Directed Group Study
mus.description: Course Description: Directed Group Study.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

mus.name: — Individual Study
mus.description: Course Description: Individual study.

mus.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
mus.description: Course Description: Teaching Assistant Training Practicum.
mus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

nas.name: — Introduction to Native American Studies
nas.description: Course Description: Introduction to Native American Studies with emphasis upon basic concepts relating to Native American historical and political development.

nas.name: — Introduction to Native American Literature
nas.description: Course Description: Intensive focus on analysis of Native American literary texts, with frequent writing assignments to develop critical thinking and composition skills.
nas.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Subject A requirement.

nas.name: — Writer's Workshop
nas.description: Course Description: Disciplinary writing support course focuses on the development of writing and revision strategies, exploring ways to understand a writing task, to develop appropriate content for a writing task, to revise content to reflect competence as a communicator.

nas.name: — Indigenous & Minority Languages
nas.description: Course Description: Survey of the status of indigenous, immigrant, and other minority languages in the Americas and around the world.
