Neuronal cell biology, the structure and function of ion channels, electrical excitability, signaling cascades, sensory transduction and, mechanisms of synaptic transmission, and the cellular basis of learning and memory.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

nsc.name: — Systems Neuroscience
nsc.description: Course Description: Integrative and information-processing aspects of nervous system organization. Topics include sensory systems, motor function, sensorimotor integration, the limbic system, and the neurobiology of learning and memory.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

nsc.name: — Cognitive Neuroscience
nsc.description: Course Description: Graduate core course for neuroscience. Neurobiological bases of higher mental function including attention, memory, language. One of three in three-quarter sequence.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate student standing in Psychology or Neuroscience or consent of instructor.

nsc.name: — Molecular & Developmental Neurobiology
nsc.description: Course Description: Key issues in developmental and molecular neurobiology. Discussion emphasis on critical evaluation of the experiments and methods described in research papers. Readings of seminal, primary research papers, reviews, and book chapters. Reading materials will be distributed one week in advance.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

nsc.name: — Molecular & Developmental Neurobiology
nsc.description: Course Description: Continuation of NSC 224A. Key issues in developmental and molecular neurobiology, focusing on developmental topics. Discussion emphasis on critical evaluation of experiments and methods described in associated literature.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NSC 224A; or consent of instructor.

nsc.name: — Translational Research in the Neurobiology of Disease
nsc.description: Course Description: Provides an overview of major neuropsychiatric and neurological disorders from both the clinical and fundamental science perspectives.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NSC 221 (can be concurrent); NSC 222 (can be concurrent); NSC 223 (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor; past or concurrent enrollment in NSC 221 NSC 222 NSC 223.

nsc.name: — Molecular & Developmental Neurobiology
nsc.description: Course Description: Key issues in developmental and molecular neurobiology. Topics include neural induction and patterning, neurogenesis, axon guidance, synapse development and remodeling. Discussion emphasis on critical evaluation of the experiments and methods described in primary seminal research papers and current literature.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

nsc.name: — Topics in Cellular & Behavioral Neurobiology
nsc.description: Course Description: An advanced examination of several currrent problems in neurobiology. Topics vary in different years.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

nsc.name: — Topics in Functional Neurogenomics
nsc.description: Course Description: The theory, methods and principles of functional neurogenomics with emphasis on the relationship to molecular mechanisms involved in development and disease of the nervous system.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

nsc.name: — Biology of Neuroglia
nsc.description: Course Description: The properties and functions of non-neuronal or neuroglial cells in the mammalian central nervous system with relevance to neuronal development, physiology and injury response.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

nsc.name: — Topics in Vision: Eyes & Retinal Mechanisms
nsc.description: Course Description: Structure and function of the visual system, with emphasis on the eye and retina, including optics, anatomy, transduction, retinal synapses, adaptation, and parallel processing.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 100 or NPB 112; or the equivalent; graduate standing.

nsc.name: — Topics in Vision: Systems, Psychophysics, Computational Models
nsc.description: Course Description: Functions of the central visual pathways and their underlying mechanisms. Recent research on aspects of anatomy, biochemistry, electrophysiology, psychophysics, development, and genetics of the visual system.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; NSC 261A recommended.

nsc.name: — Topics in Vision: Clinical Vision Science
nsc.description: Course Description: Causes and mechanistic bases of major blinding diseases. Recent research on aspects of anatomy, biochemistry, electrophysiology, psychophysics, development, and genetics of the visual system related to disease.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NSC 261A; NSC 261B; or consent of instructor.

nsc.name: — Computational Neuroscience
nsc.description: Course Description: Mathematical models and data analysis techniques used to describe computations performed by nervous systems. Lecture topics include single neuron biophysics, neural coding, network dynamics, memory, plasticity, and learning. Lab topics include programming mathematical models and data analysis techniques in MATLAB.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; one course in general Neuroscience at the level of NSC 100; or NPB 110B; one year college-level Calculus at level of MAT 016A, MAT 016B, MAT 016C or higher; one year Physics at the level of PHY 007A, PHY 007B, PHY 007C, recommended; or consent of instructor.

nsc.name: — How to Write a Fundable Grant Proposal in the Biomedical Sciences
nsc.description: Course Description: Teaches the do's and don'ts of writing grants in the biomedical sciences and the mechanisms of the review process.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

nsc.name: — Core Concepts & Methods in Learning, Memory, & Plasticity
nsc.description: Course Description: Core concepts and methods used in studies of learning, memory and plasticity. Behavioral paradigms and measurement approaches in human and animal studies of learning and plasticity, as well as a consideration of the functional, anatomical and neuronal mechanisms underlying brain plasticity.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate Standing or consent of instructor.

nsc.name: — Core Concepts & Methods in Learning, Memory, & Plasticity
nsc.description: Course Description: Core concepts and detailed survey methods used in studies of learning, memory and plasticity, from the cellular and molecular level to the level of neural circuits. Areas of learning, memory, and plasticity research where recent progress has been made in linking across these levels of analysis.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NSC 271A or NPB 271A or PSC 271A.

nsc.name: — Translational Approaches to Learning, Memory, & Plasticity Disorders
nsc.description: Course Description: Neurological disorders, the effect of these disorders on learning, memory and plasticity, approved therapeutic options and current research designed to improve understanding and treatment of these diseases: (i) the clinical presentation, diagnostic criteria, and existing therapies, (ii) mechanistic studies in humans and animal models, and (iii) molecular pathways involved in the disease and approaches for drug discovery.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NSC 271B or NPB 271B or PSC 271B.

nsc.name: — Neurobiological Literature
nsc.description: Course Description: Critical presentation and analysis of recent journal articles in neurobiology.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

nsc.name: — Development of Sensory Systems
nsc.description: Course Description: Presentation and discussion of recent literature on the development of sensory systems.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

nsc.name: — Literature in Visual Neuroscience
nsc.description: Course Description: Critical presentation and discussion of current literature in visual neuroscience.

nsc.name: — Frontiers in Biology of Glia
nsc.description: Course Description: Frontiers of glial biology. Research articles in current literature on experimental approaches, technical aspects of experimental techniques, data interpretation, and other topics.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor

nsc.name: — Topics in Theoretical Neuroscience
nsc.description: Course Description: In-depth exploration of topics in theoretical neuroscience. Topic varies each year. Fall quarter (287A): foundational material from books and review articles. Spring quarter (287B): continuation of year's topic through readings of seminal articles from the primary literature.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

nsc.name: — Topics in Theoretical Neuroscience
nsc.description: Course Description: In-depth exploration of topics in theoretical neuroscience. Topic varies each year. Fall quarter (287A): foundational material from books and review articles. Spring quarter (287B): continuation of year's topic through readings of seminal articles from the primary literature.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

nsc.name: — Topics in Molecular & Developmental Neurobiology
nsc.description: Course Description: Analysis and discussion of seminal and current research papers in molecular and developmental neurobiology. Different topics will be covered each quarter. In the past topics have included, "Synaptic vesicle dynamics," "Neuronal polarity," and "Glutamate receptors."

nsc.name: — Research Conference in Neurobiology
nsc.description: Course Description: Presentation and discussion of faculty and graduate student research in neurobiology.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NSC 299 required concurrently; graduate standing in Neuroscience or consent of instructor.

nsc.name: — Cortical Plasticity & Perception
nsc.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Examination of research articles on cortical plasticity and changes in perception. Examples drawn from studies of the somatosensory, visual, auditory, and motor cortex.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 100 or NPB 112; or equivalent or consent of instructor.

nsc.name: — Literature in Neuroengineering
nsc.description: Course Description: Critical presentation and discussion of current literature in neuroengineering.

nsc.name: — Group Study
nsc.description: Course Description: Group study.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

nsc.name: — Research
nsc.description: Course Description: Research.
nsc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

nsu.name: — Special Study in Neurosurgery for Advanced Undergraduates
nsu.description: Course Description: Students may participate in ongoing neurosurgical projects or may pursue and design independent projects.
nsu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Advanced undergraduate standing with consent of instructor.

nsu.name: — Neurosurgery Research
nsu.description: Course Description: Student may participate in ongoing neurosurgical projects or may pursue and design independent projects.
nsu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate student with consent of instructor.

nsu.name: — Neurosurgical Critical Care Clerkship
nsu.description: Course Description: Students participate in the care of neurosurgical patients in the NSICU and in the admission and surgical management of patients admitted through the Emergency Room.
nsu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Third- or fourth-year medical student having completed a neurosurgical clerkship or consent of instructor.

nsu.name: — Clinical Pediatric Neurosurgery
nsu.description: Course Description: Admission and follow-up of pediatric patients. Neurological history, examination, and diagnostic procedures are emphasized. Students will participate in surgical procedures and are required to attend all pediatric neurosurgery conferences.
nsu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NSU 460; consent of instructor; third- or fourth-year medical students.

nsu.name: — Clinical Neurosurgery
nsu.description: Course Description: Approved for graduate degree credit. Admission and follow-up of patients. Neurological history, examination, and further diagnostic procedures emphasized. Participate in meaningful aspects of surgical procedures and attend listed conferences, rounds, and seminars.
nsu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; third- and fourth-year medical students.

nsu.name: — Externship
nsu.description: Course Description: Clerkship in neurosurgery to be arranged at another institution with accredited residency program in neurosurgery under proper supervision.
nsu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Fourth-year medical student having completed a neurosurgical clerkship or consent of instructor.

nsu.name: — Neurocritical Care
nsu.description: Course Description: In this Acting Internship, learn and practice how to safely assess and manage acutely ill patients with life-threatening neurologic and neurosurgical disease or life-threatening neurologic manifestations of systemic disease as part of our multidisciplinary neurocritical care team.

nsu.name: — Neurocritical Care (NSICU)
nsu.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Participate in the care of neurosurgical patients in the NSICU and in the admission and surgical management of patients admitted through the Emergency Room.

nsu.name: — Advanced Clinical Neurosurgery
nsu.description: Course Description: Student will function as acting intern on neurosurgery service. Admission and management of patients. Neurological history, examination, diagnostic procedures, and surgical management are emphasized. Students participate in meaningful aspects of surgical procedures and attend required conferences and rounds.
nsu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student in good academic standing.

nsu.name: — Away Acting Internship in Neurosurgery
nsu.description: Course Description: Away acting internship in Neurosurgery.

nsu.name: — Insights in Neurosurgery
nsu.description: Course Description: Observation of neurosurgical care in emergency room, operating room and hospital floors, including manner of treatment of a variety of chronic and acute neurological diseases.
nsu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; first- and second-year medical students in good academic standing.

nsu.name: — Neurosurgery Research
nsu.description: Course Description: Student may participate in ongoing neurosurgical projects or may pursue and design independent projects.
nsu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical student with consent of instructor.

nrs.name: — Quantitative Design & Data Collection in Nursing & Healthcare
nrs.description: Course Description: Introduction to quantitative study designs, common methods for sampling, data collection, and instrument selection. Implications of various design and methods choices on causal inference, internal and external validity, and ethical considerations.

nrs.name: — Quantitative Research Methods in Nursing & Healthcare
nrs.description: Course Description: Foundational approaches to describing and analyzing quantitative data. Assumptions and appropriate selection of basic descriptive and inferential statistics, and interpreting and communicating the results.
nrs.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NRS 200AY B- or better; or consent of instructor.

nrs.name: — Applied Quantitative Analysis in Nursing & Healthcare
nrs.description: Course Description: Practice of quantitative data analysis. Develop research questions using quantitative methods, identify appropriate datasets, prepare data, conduct secondary analysis, and report results.
nrs.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NRS 200BY B- or better; or consent of Instructor.

nrs.name: — Health Status & Care Systems
nrs.description: Course Description: Comparative health status data, major current health issues globally, nationally, regionally. Theoretical perspectives on social, political, economic determinants of health. Health-care systems examined, linked to data, and evaluated in regards to outcomes. Aging, rural, ethnic minority populations highlighted.

nrs.name: — Implementation Science

nrs.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Learn concepts central to the effective management of a variety of common chronic illness and disabling conditions across the lifespan in a variety of different settings. Practice conducting in-depth health assessments of individuals with chronic conditions.
nrs.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NRS 221; NRS 272; NRS 420; NRS 421; consent of instructor.

nrs.name: — Psychosocial Wellness & Illness
nrs.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Explore the biological, psychological, cultural, societal, and environmental factors that affect psychological wellness and illness. Practice providing care to individuals and families experiencing disruptions in mental health secondary to physical or psychiatric illness, trauma or loss.
nrs.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NRS 221; NRS 272; NRS 420; NRS 421; consent of instructor.

nrs.name: — Nursing Care of Older Adults
nrs.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Build skills for situations involving older adults, such as in the management of complex clinical and administering and interpreting standardized assessment tools. Develop plans of care for older adults experiencing a variety of geriatric syndromes.
nrs.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NRS 221; NRS 223; NRS 272; NRS 273; NRS 420; NRS 421; NRS 422; NRS 423; NRS 425; NRS 426; consent of instructor.

nrs.name: — Family Focused Nursing
nrs.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Focuses on family as the unit of nursing and interprofessional care. Includes influences of family on health and illness, reproductive and gender/sexuality issues, pregnancy, birth and child-rearing, and the health and illness in children and youth.
nrs.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NRS 221; NRS 272; NRS 273; NRS 420; NRS 421; NRS 422; NRS 423; consent of instructor.

nrs.name: — Nursing Care of Adults with Complex Illness or Injury
nrs.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Prepares students to provide comprehensive, patient-centered nursing care for patients with acute or complex illness and injury. Theory portion focuses on concepts associated with complex physiological alterations.
nrs.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NRS 221; NRS 272; NRS 273; NRS 420; NRS 421; NRS 422; NRS 423; NRS 425; consent of instructor.

nrs.name: — Fostering Healthy Communities
nrs.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Focuses on populations & communities, and emphasizes working with diverse communities in providing health promotion, chronic disease management, transitional support and crisis intervention. Develop skills to critically analyze and shape health policy and develop accessible community resources.

nrs.name: — Capstone Clinical Nursing Practicum
nrs.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Practicum experience is designed to facilitate transition to professional practice. Opportunity to choose a clinical practice area of interest and to work with a preceptor with expertise in that area.
nrs.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NRS 202; NRS 203; NRS 212; NRS 220; NRS 221; NRS 222A; NRS 222B; NRS 223; NRS 224; NRS 272; NRS 273; NRS 420; NRS 421; NRS 422; NRS 423; NRS 424; NRS 425; NRS 426; NRS 427; NRS 429A; NRS 429B; NRS 429C; NRS 429D; NRS 429E; consent of instructor.

nrs.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Students are placed in clinical settings and/or clinical simulation laboratories to observe and practice the integration of clinical skills with direct supervision by faculty.

nrs.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Each of the required primary care rotations is a four-week supervised clinical practice experience in primary care, under the supervision of an appropriate community-based primary care provider per accreditation requirements.

nrs.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Each of the required primary care rotations is a four-week supervised clinical practice experience in primary care, under the supervision of an appropriate community-based primary care provider per accreditation requirements.

nrs.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Each of the required primary care rotations is a four-week supervised clinical practice experience in primary care, under the supervision of an appropriate community-based primary care provider per accreditation requirements.

nrs.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Each of the required primary care rotations is a four-week supervised clinical practice experience in primary care, under the supervision of an appropriate community-based primary care provider per accreditation requirements.

nrs.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Each of the required primary care rotations is a four-week supervised clinical practice experience in primary care, under the supervision of an appropriate community-based primary care provider per accreditation requirements.

nrs.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Four-week clinical rotation under the supervision of an appropriate community-based Pediatric Medicine provider per accreditation requirements.

nrs.name: — Supervised Clinical Practice-Other Specialties
nrs.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Two four-week selective rotations are available to accommodate student interest and/or accommodate a student’s clinical deficits identified by the program.

nrs.name: — Health Care Ethics
nrs.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Guided independent study of issues in biomedical ethics, with discussion of readings that are based on student interests and needs. Participation in ethics rounds.

nrs.name: — Supervised Clinical Practice-Geriatrics
nrs.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Four-week clinical rotation under the supervision of an appropriate community-based Geriatric Medicine provider per accreditation requirements.

nrs.name: — Supervised Clinical Practice-Acute Care

nrs.name: — Supervised Clinical Practice-Rural Health
nrs.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Rural health rotations focus on providing care in medically underserved rural sites. Students will experience care across the continuum in ambulatory, inpatient, and community based settings.

nrs.name: — Supervised Clinical Practice: Quality & Safety
nrs.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Clinical rotation that allow students to work directly with patient safety and quality improvement committees in various organizations.

nrs.name: — Improving Quality in Health Care
nrs.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Working in interdisciplinary teams, will explore the theory and practical methods being employed to make improvement in health care systems while providing an opportunity for interprofessional educational experience.

nrs.name: — Improving Quality in Health Care
nrs.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Working in interdisciplinary teams, will explore advanced theory and practical methods being employed to make improvement in health care systems while providing an opportunity for interprofessional educational experience.

nrs.name: — Enhancing Patient Safety in Health Care
nrs.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Inter-professional module is designed to explore the theory and practical methods being employed to improve patient safety in health care while providing an opportunity for inter-professional educational experience.

nut.name: — Discoveries & Concepts in Nutrition
nut.description: Course Description: Nutrition as a science; historical development of nutrition concepts; properties of nutrients and foods.

nut.name: — Discoveries & Concepts in Nutrition
nut.description: Course Description: Nutrition as a science; historical development of nutrition concepts; properties of nutrients and foods.

nut.name: — Discoveries & Concepts in Nutrition
nut.description: Course Description: Nutrition as a science; historical development of nutrition concepts; properties of nutrients and foods.

nut.name: — Current Topics & Controversies in Nutrition
nut.description: Course Description: Exploration of current applications and controversies in nutrition. Rread scientific journal articles and write summaries, as well as give brief oral presentations. Topics change to reflect current interests and issues.

nut.name: — Individual Study for Undergraduates
nut.description: Course Description: Individual study for undergraduates.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

nut.name: — Environmental & Nutritional Factors in Cellular Regulation & Nutritional Toxicants
nut.description: Course Description: Cellular regulation from nutritional/toxicological perspective. Emphasis: role of biofactors on modulation of signal transduction pathways, role of specific organelles in organization/regulation of metabolic transformations, major cofactor functions, principles of pharmacology/toxicology important to understanding nutrient/toxicant metabolism.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 101; (BIS 103 or ABI 103).

nut.name: — Nutrition through the Life Cycle
nut.description: Course Description: Unique nutrient needs of people in different stages of the life cycle, including pregnant and lactating women, infants, children, adolescents, adults and the elderly. Physiological changes and conditions that influence nutrient needs, factors that influence food choices and appropriate dietary recommendations, and recent research are discussed.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 103 or ABI 103); NUT 111AY; or consent of instructor.

nut.name: — Food Chemistry for Clinical Nutrition
nut.description: Course Description: Chemical and physical principles that influence functional properties, nutrient content, safety, and sensory aspects of food. Emphasis on the application of these concepts in clinical nutrition.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 008B C- or better or CHE 118B C- or better or CHE 128B C- or better; concurrent with FST 100A recommended.

nut.name: — Introduction to Nutrition & Metabolism
nut.description: Course Description: Introduction to metabolism of protein, fat and carbohydrate: the biological role of vitamins and minerals; nutrient requirements during the life cycle; assessment of dietary intake and nutritional status.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 008B; NPB 101; or the equivalent of NPB 101.

nut.name: — Recommendations & Standards for Human Nutrition
nut.description: Course Description: Critical analysis of the development of nutritional recommendations for humans. Topics include: history of modern recommendations, development of the Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) and other food guides; the Dietary Reference Intakes (DRI); administrative structure of regulatory agencies pertinent to nutrition recommendations; introduction to scientific methods used to determine the recommendations; food labeling laws; nutrition recommendations in other countries and cultures.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (CHE 008B or CHE 118B or CHE 128B); NUT 111AY; NPB 101 recommended.

nut.name: — Nutritional Assessment
nut.description: Course Description: Methods of human nutritional assessment, including dietary, anthropometric, biochemical methods. Principles of precision, accuracy, and interpretation of results for individuals and populations.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ((ABI 102,  ABI 103) or (BIS 102,  BIS 103)); NUT 111AY; (STA 013 or STA 013Y or PLS 120).

nut.name: — Principles of Epidemiology in Nutrition
nut.description: Course Description: Introduction to epidemiology as it relates to the field of nutrition, including study design, principles of epidemiologic inference, criteria for causality, and interpreting measures of disease risk.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 013 or STA 013Y or PLS 120 or STA 100.

nut.name: — Developmental Nutrition
nut.description: Course Description: Role of nutritional factors in embryonic and postnatal development.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ABI 102 or BIS 102); (ABI 103 or BIS 103); NUT 111AY; NUT 111B.

nut.name: — Animal Nutrition
nut.description: Course Description: Comparative differences among animals in digestion and metabolism of nutrients. Nutrient composition of feeds, digestive systems, digestion, absorption, feeding strategies.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 008B or CHE 118B; or consent of instructor.

nut.name: — Clinical Nutrition
nut.description: Course Description: Biochemical and physiological bases for therapeutic diets. Problems in planning diets for normal and pathological conditions.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (NUT 111AV or NUT 111AY); NUT 111B; NUT 112; NPB 101; or the equivalent to NPB 101.

nut.name: — Clinical Nutrition Practicum
nut.description: Course Description: Fundamental principles of planning and evaluating therapeutic diets and patient education for pathological conditions covered in 116A.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 116A (can be concurrent).

nut.name: — Clinical Nutrition
nut.description: Course Description: Biochemical and physiological bases for therapeutic diets. Problems in planning diets for normal and pathological conditions.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (NUT 111AV or NUT 111AY); NUT 111B; NUT 112; NPB 101; or the equivalent to NPB 101.

nut.name: — Clinical Nutrition Practicum
nut.description: Course Description: Fundamental principles of planning and evaluating therapeutic diets and patient education for pathological conditions covered in NUT 116B. Continuation of NUT 116AL.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 116AL; NUT 116B (can be concurrent).

nut.name: — Experimental Nutrition
nut.description: Course Description: Methods of assessing nutritional status. Application of chemical, microbiological, chromatographic and enzymatic techniques to current problems in nutrition.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (NUT 111AV or NUT 111AY); NUT 111B; NUT 112; BIS 102; BIS 103; MCB 120L or other laboratory course in biochemistry is recommended.

nut.name: — Community Nutrition
nut.description: Course Description: Nutrition problems in contemporary communities and of selected target groups in the United States and in developing countries. Nutrition programs and policy, principles of nutrition education.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 116A; (NUT 111AV or NUT 111AY); NUT 111B.

nut.name: — Global Nutrition
nut.description: Course Description: Global prevalence, etiology, and consequences of nutrition problems, ranging from under nutrition and food insecurity to overweight and associated chronic diseases; underlying social, environmental, and behavioral factors that contribute to malnutrition; strategies to improve nutritional status, with emphasis on low- and middle-income countries.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 111AY; NUT 111B; or consent of instructor.

nut.name: — International, Community-Based Nutritional Assessment
nut.description: Course Description: A six-week summer course in Peru. Implementation of a community-based nutritional assessment survey, including development of the survey instrument, selection. Taught abroad.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 119A; and consent of instructor.

nut.name: — Nutritional Anthropology
nut.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Nutritional anthropology from historical and contemporary perspectives; the anthropological approach to food and diet; field work methods; case histories that explore food patterns and their nutritional implications.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (NUT 010 or NUT 010V); (ANT 002 or SOC 001 or SOC 003); upper-division standing.

nut.name: — Nutritional Geography
nut.description: Course Description: Nutritional geography from historical and contemporary perspectives; the geographical approach to food and diet; cultural and environmental factors that influence dietary practices; food-related landscapes and patterns.

nut.name: — Ruminant Nutrition & Digestive Physiology
nut.description: Course Description: Study of nutrient utilization as influenced by the unique aspects of digestion and fermentation in ruminants, both domestic and wild. Laboratories include comparative anatomy, feed evaluation, digestion kinetics using fistulated cows, computer modeling, and microbial exercises.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (ABI 103 or BIS 103); BIS 002A; BIS 002B; BIS 002C; (ANS 100 or NPB 101); or consent of instructor. MAT 016B recommended.

nut.name: — Comparative Animal Nutrition
nut.description: Course Description: Comparative nutrition of animals; including laboratory, companion, zoo, and wild, animals. Digestion and metabolic adaptations required for animal species to consume diverse diets. Relation of nutrition to metabolic adaptations and physiological states, including growth, reproduction, and diseases.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ABI 103 or BIS 103.

nut.name: — Comparative Animal Nutrition Laboratory
nut.description: Course Description: Laboratory exercises leading to written reports on establishment of nutritional requirements and formulation of complete diets for laboratory, companion, zoo and wild animals.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ABI 103 or BIS 103.

nut.name: — Nutrition & Feeding of Finfishes
nut.description: Course Description: Principles of nutrition and feeding of fishes under commercial situations; implication of fish nutrition to the environment and conservation of endangered species.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 103 or ABI 103.

nut.name: — Environmental Stress & Development in Marine Organisms
nut.description: Course Description: Taught at Bodega Marine Laboratory. Effects of environmental and nutritional stress, including pollutants, on development and function in embryos and larvae of marine organisms. Emphasis on advanced experimental methods.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ETX 101 or BIS 102 or BIS 104; or equivalent course; ETX 114A or NUT 114 recommended.

nut.name: — Journalistic Practicum in Nutrition
nut.description: Course Description: Critical analysis and discussion of current, controversial issues in nutrition; use of journalistic techniques to interpret scientific findings for the lay public. Students required to write several articles for campus media.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (NUT 111AV or NUT 111AY); NUT 111B; or consent of instructor; a course in written or oral expression.

nut.name: — Experiments in Nutrition: Design & Execution
nut.description: Course Description: Experiments in current nutritional problems. Experimental design:students choose project and, independently or in groups of two-three, design a protocol, complete the project, and report findings.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; NUT 111AV, NUT 111AY, NUT 111B or NUT 114 recommended.

nut.name: — Comparative Animal Nutrition & Metabolism
nut.description: Course Description: Foundational principles of nutrition, nutrient composition of feed ingredients, digestive systems of domestic and exotic animals, nutrient digestibility and absorption, nutrient metabolism.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ABI 103; (NUT 115 or NUT 116A or NUT 116B); or consent of instructor.

nut.name: — Companion Animal Nutrition
nut.description: Course Description: Applied companion animal nutrition, focused primarily on dogs and cats. Nutritional considerations specifically related to health and longevity of companion animals. Evaluation of commercial and prescription-type diets with an emphasis on functional ingredients. Impact of physiological status and disease on nutrient requirements of the animal and nutrient utilization in the body.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ABI 102; NUT 115; recommend ANS 042.

nut.name: — Proseminar in Nutrition
nut.description: Course Description: Discussion of human nutrition problems. Each term will involve a different emphasis among experimental, clinical, and dietetic problems of community, national and international scope.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (NUT 111AV or NUT 111AY); NUT 111B.

nut.name: — Nutrition Research Conference
nut.description: Course Description: Introduction to research findings and methods in nutrition. Presentation and discussion of research by faculty and students.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing in Nutrition or related biological science.

nut.name: — Internship
nut.description: Course Description: Work experience on or off campus in practical application of nutrition, supervised by a faculty member.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; one upper division course in nutrition.

nut.name: — Tutoring in Nutrition
nut.description: Course Description: Tutoring of students in nutrition courses, assistance with discussion groups or laboratory sections, weekly conference with instructor in charge of course: written evaluations.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; Nutrition Science, Clinical Nutrition or related major.

nut.name: — Directed Group Study
nut.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

nut.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
nut.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

nut.name: — International Nutrition
nut.description: Course Description: Epidemiology, etiology, and consequences of undernutrition, with particular focus on the nutritional problems of children and women in low income populations.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 111AV; NUT 111AY; graduate standing; undergraduates only admitted with consent of instructor.

nut.name: — International Nutrition
nut.description: Course Description: Intervention programs to prevent or ameliorate nutritional problems in low-income populations. Planning, implementing, and evaluating nutrition intervention programs.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 219A.

nut.name: — Experiments in Nutrition: Design & Execution
nut.description: Course Description: Student-selected projects to enhance laboratory skills. Independently, or in groups of two-three students, design a protocol, carry out the project, analyze the results and report the findings.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; NUT 201, NUT 202, NUT 203, NUT 204, or the equivalent recommended.

nut.name: — Metabolic Homeostasis
nut.description: Course Description: Regulatory mechanisms of carbohydrate, lipid, and protein homeostasis; mechanisms of metabolic enzyme regulation and of the metabolic hormones; homeostatic mechanisms and interactions; fuel-fuel interactions; nutrition-energy balance.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Passing the Nutrition Graduate Group Preliminary Examination or consent of instructor.

nut.name: — Nutrition & Immunity
nut.description: Course Description: Cellular and molecular mechanisms underlying interactions of nutrition and immune function, including modulation of immunocompetence by diet and effects of immune responses on nutritional needs. Lectures and discussion explore implications for resistance to infection, autoimmunity and cancer.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PMI 126; ABI 102; MMI 107; or the equivalent to MMI 107.

nut.name: — Nutrition & Development
nut.description: Course Description: Relationship of nutrition to prenatal and early postnatal development.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUB 210A, NUB 210B, and NUB 210C recommended.

nut.name: — Control of Energy Balance & Body Weight
nut.description: Course Description: Comprehensive study of the biochemical, nutritional and physiological mechanisms controlling food intake, body composition and energy expenditure. Subject matter will be approached through lectures and discussions where students and staff will critically evaluate the literature.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

nut.name: — Applications of Systems Analysis in Nutrition
nut.description: Course Description: Quantitative aspects of digestion and metabolism; principles of systems analysis. Evolution of models of energy metabolism as applied in current feeding systems. Critical evaluations of mechanistic models used analytically in support of nutritional research.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 202; or the equivalent.

nut.name: — Field Research Methods in International Nutrition
nut.description: Course Description: Issues and problems related to implementation of nutrition field research in less-developed countries, including ethics; relationships with local governments, communities, and scientists; data collection techniques and quality assurance; field logistics; research budgets; and other administrative and personal issues.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

nut.name: — Nutrition & Aging
nut.description: Course Description: Interaction between nutrition and aging. Topics include physiological/biochemical basis of aging, age-related changes affecting nutritional requirements, nutrition and mortality rate, assessment of nutritional status in the elderly, and relationship between developmental nutrition and the rate of aging.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 201; NUT 202; NUT 203; NUT 204; three of the four courses.

nut.name: — Scientific Ethics in Biomedical Studies:   Emphasis on Nutrition
nut.description: Course Description: Scientific ethics in biomedical studies, especially nutrition. Discussion and case study presentations on scientific integrity, fraud, misconduct, conflict of interest, human and animal research protections.

nut.name: — Beginning Nutrition Seminar
nut.description: Course Description: Discussion and critical evaluation of topics in nutrition with emphasis on literature review and evaluation in this field. Students give oral presentations on relevant topics.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): First-year graduate standing.

nut.name: — Research Conference
nut.description: Course Description: Major professors lead research discussions with their graduate students. Research papers are reviewed and project proposals presented and evaluated. Format will combine seminar and discussion style.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

nut.name: — Advanced Nutrition Seminar
nut.description: Course Description: Advanced topics in nutrition research. Multiple sections may be taken concurrently for credit.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Second-year graduate standing.

nut.name: — Current Topics in Obesity, Food Intake & Energy Balance
nut.description: Course Description: Current research and its evaluation. Principles of experimental design and scientific background for given article. Articles summarized for posting on Internet for use by healthcare professionals.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 129; or graduate standing; undergraduates with upper division standing with at least one writing course may enroll with consent of instructor.

nut.name: — Current Topics in Obesity, Food Intake, & Energy Balance with Special Topics
nut.description: Course Description: Undergraduates with upper division standing with at least one writing course may enroll with consent of instructor. A continuation of NUT 293A, with additional special topics.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 129; Graduate standing.

nut.name: — Current Topics in Developmental Nutrition
nut.description: Course Description: Effects of nutrition on embryology, morphogenesis, and developmental mechanisms.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 114 or NUT 252; or consent of instructor.

nut.name: — Supervised Teaching in Nutrition
nut.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Practical experience in teaching nutrition at the university level; curriculum design and evaluation; preparation and presentation of material. Assistance in laboratories, discussion sections, and evaluation of student work.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in nutrition or consent of instructor.

nut.name: — Group Study
nut.description: Course Description: Group study.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

nut.name: — Research
nut.description: Course Description: Research.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

nut.name: — Professionalism: An Academic Perspective
nut.description: Course Description: For graduate students in their initial quarter of residence. Professionalism topics are presented and examples drawn from both the biological and social sciences.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

nut.name: — Grant Writing
nut.description: Course Description: Preparation of grants for governmental agencies (particularly NIH and USDA) and private foundations. Students will write a research grant or fellowship application.
nut.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Nutrition or consent of instructor.

nub.name: — Advanced Nutrition I: Nutrition & Metabolism, Macronutrients
nub.description: Course Description: Advanced general nutritional concepts. Integrating nutrition with biological systems, population nutrition issues, and research approaches. Advanced concepts on lipid and protein metabolism.
nub.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Nutritional Biology Graduate Group or consent of instructor.

nub.name: — Advanced Nutrition II: Nutrition & Cell Biology, Micronutrients
nub.description: Course Description: Effects of nutrients at the cellular level. Principles of cell signaling and signaling modulation by nutrients. Advanced concepts of mineral and vitamin metabolism. Mineral and vitamin deviencies and associated pathologies.
nub.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Admission to the Nutritional Biology Graduate Group or consent of instructor.

nub.name: — Advanced Nutrition III: Nutrition in Health & Disease
nub.description: Course Description: Integration of biochemical, physiological, and genetic aspects of nutrition in the context of clinical and epidemiological observations related to health and disease, including obesity and diabetes, cancer, vascular and neurodegenerative diseases, osteoporosis, and birth defects. Review and consideration of governmental.

nub.name: — Research Group Conference
nub.description: Course Description: Weekly conference on research problems, progress and techniques in animal sciences.

nub.name: — Directed Group Study
nub.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Nutritional Biology Graduate Group or consent of instructor.

obg.name: — Shifa Clinic Student Volunteer
obg.description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in Obstetrics & Gynecology.

obg.name: — Shifa Clinic Student Volunteer
obg.description: Course Description: Attend clinic every third Sunday performing duties of receptionist, intake, translation, monitor. Students attend a meeting immediately after end of clinic. There is a mandatory Monday meeting with Clinic co-directors. Students are expected to participate on various committees.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; applications will be available for students; selection of students will be made by selection committee of medical students coordinators and the instructor of record.

obg.name: — Directed Group Study
obg.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

obg.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
obg.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

obg.name: — Genetics of Reproduction
obg.description: Course Description: Introduction to genetics of mammalian reproduction for domestic species, species used in research, and the human. Mendelian and non-Mendelian modes of inheritance. Research paper.

obg.name: — Current Topics in Research
obg.description: Course Description: Selected topics in reproductive biology.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

obg.name: — Group Study
obg.description: Course Description: Group study.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

obg.name: — Research
obg.description: Course Description: Research.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

obg.name: — Obstetrics & Gynecology Clerkship
obg.description: Course Description: Obstetrics, gynecologic and gynecological oncology experience in the delivery room, operating room, clinics and wards at UCDMC and affiliated sites. Rounds, conferences, interactive student presentations and seminars ongoing.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

obg.name: — SJVP OBGYN Clerkship at UCSF
obg.description: Course Description: Obstetrics, gynecologic and gynecological oncology experience in the delivery room, operating room, clinics and wards at UCSF Fresno. Rounds, conferences, interactive student presentations and seminars ongoing.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

obg.name: — Rural PRIME OBGYN Longitudinal Clerkship
obg.description: Course Description: Obstetrics and Gynecology Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

obg.name: — Rural PRIME OBGYN Longitudinal Clerkship
obg.description: Course Description: Obstetrics and Gynecology Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

obg.name: — Rural PRIME OBGYN Longitudinal Clerkship
obg.description: Course Description: Obstetrics and Gynecology Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

obg.name: — Rural PRIME OBGYN Longitudinal Clerkship
obg.description: Course Description: Obstetrics and Gynecology Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

obg.name: — Rural PRIME OBGYN Longitudinal Clerkship
obg.description: Course Description: Obstetrics and Gynecology Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

obg.name: — Directed Clinical Studies in OBGYN
obg.description: Course Description: Individual directed studies in extended preparation for modified curriculum or to complete a clinical rotation following a leave of absence.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

obg.name: — Directed Studies in OBGYN
obg.description: Course Description: Individual directed studies in extended preparation for remediation of all or part of clinical rotation. Clinical studies to accommodate and satisfy remedial work as directed by the Committee on Student Progress and approved by the course IOR.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

obg.name: — Away Clinical Elective in OBGYN
obg.description: Course Description: Active participation in inpatient and outpatient care. Attendance at specified conferences; student-faculty member informal conferences.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): OBG 430; or the equivalent, and consent of instructor; third- or fourth-year medical student.

obg.name: — Away Acting Internship in OBGYN
obg.description: Course Description: Work at the level of a sub intern in Inpatient and/or Outpatient settings. Students are expected to provide direct patient management.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): OBG 430; and consent of instructor; other third-year core clerkships.

obg.name: — Gynecologic Oncology Acting Internship
obg.description: Course Description: Four week elective primarily involves direct inpatient management of women on the UCDMC Gyn/Onc service. Students will be acting at the level of a sub-intern and will work under the supervision of house staff, fellows, and attendings.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): OBG 430; consent of instructor; the third-year core clerkships.

obg.name: — Ambulatory Gynecology & Obstetrics Elective
obg.description: Course Description: Conduct examinations, present patients and discuss treatment regimens at the following ambulatory clinics: General Obstetrics & Gynecology, New and Return Obstetrics (including Post-Partum), High-Risk Obstetrics, Pre-Operative Clinic, and other sub-specialty clinics as assigned.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): OBG 430; and consent of instructor. Third- or fourth-year Medical Student.

obg.name: — Family Planning & Reproductive Health
obg.description: Course Description: Elective focuses on the Gynecologic Subspecialty of Family Planning. Counseling and provision of contraceptive methods, experience with pelvic ultrasounds, management of spontaneous, inevitable and induced abortion and post-abortion care by both surgical and medical techniques are included.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): OBG 430; consent of instructor.

obg.name: — Labor & Delivery Acting Internship
obg.description: Course Description: Four week elective primarily involves direct inpatient management of women on the UCDMC L&D unit. Students will be acting at the level of a sub-intern and will work under the supervision of house staff, fellows, and attendings.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): OBG 430; consent of instructor; the third-year core clerkships.

obg.name: — The Birthing Process
obg.description: Course Description: Open only to UC Davis medical students. Training to assist in the birthing process as a Doula. Topics not covered in the summer course.

obg.name: — Gender Specific Medicine SSM
obg.description: Course Description: Special Studies Module, a four-week course on the topic: Basic Science Principles Relating to Gender Specific Medicine.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

obg.name: — Shifa Clinic
obg.description: Course Description: Interaction with patients from multiple ethnic and cultural backgrounds under the direct supervision of a physician/preceptor. Women's health issues and primary care issues in a diversely mixed population.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical student in good standing.

obg.name: — Shifa Clinic
obg.description: Course Description: Interaction with patients from multiple ethnic and cultural backgrounds under the direct supervision of a physician/preceptor. Women's health issues and primary care issues in a diversely mixed population.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; medical student in good standing.

obg.name: — Shifa Clinic
obg.description: Course Description: Interaction with patients from multiple ethnic and cultural backgrounds under the direct supervision of a physician/preceptor. Women's health issues and primary care issues in a diversely mixed population.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; medical student in good standing.

obg.name: — Shifa Clinic
obg.description: Course Description: Interaction with patients from multiple ethnic and cultural backgrounds under the direct supervision of a physician/preceptor. Women's health issues and primary care issues in a diversely mixed population.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; medical student in good standing.

obg.name: — Group Study
obg.description: Course Description: Explore particular topics in-depth in Obstetrics and Gynecology. Extensive contact with and oversight by instructor.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

obg.name: — Research in Obstetrics & Gynecology
obg.description: Course Description: Research in Obstetrics and Gynecology arranged with instructor.
obg.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student.

opt.name: — Research Internship
opt.description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in ophthalmology research. Research staff in Ophthalmology have programs in cell biology, electron microscopy, biochemistry, immunology and visual psychophysics.
opt.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; approval of project prior to period of internship by preceptor.

opt.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
opt.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

opt.name: — Basic Research in Visual Science
opt.description: Course Description: Basic research in visual science.

opt.name: — Introduction to Ophthalmology
opt.description: Course Description: Ocular disease diagnosis and management relevant to the clinical practice of future primary care physicians and others.
opt.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Third- or fourth-year Medical Student with consent of instructor; consent of advisor; completion of third-year clerkships in Medicine and Surgery; consult Course Coordinator.

opt.name: — Advanced Subspecialty Ophthalmology
opt.description: Course Description: Participation in disciplines of neuro-ophthalmology/pediatric ophthalmology, diseases of the cornea and external eye, glaucoma and retina.
opt.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): IMD 430; consent of instructor; medical students in third or fourth year.

opt.name: — Group Study
opt.description: Course Description: Directed reading and discussion.
opt.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical students with consent of instructor.

opt.name: — Research in Ophthalmology
opt.description: Course Description: Individual research on selected topics in optics and visual physiology, cornea and external disease.
opt.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical students with consent of instructor.

osu.name: — Special Studies for Undergraduates
osu.description: Course Description: Special studies for undergraduates.
osu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

osu.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
osu.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
osu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

osu.name: — The Musculoskeletal System
osu.description: Course Description: Basic and clinical science of orthopaedic surgery and rheumatology.
osu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of committee on student progress.

osu.name: — Ambulatory & Emergency Room Orthopaedics
osu.description: Course Description: Introduction to general orthopaedic problems and trauma and their management in an outpatient environment, including the emergency room. Conduct orthopaedic examinations, present patients to staff rotating through trauma, hand, pediatrics, adult and foot clinics.
osu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student in good academic standing.

osu.name: — Community Preceptorship
osu.description: Course Description: Acquaints student with private practice of orthopaedics in the community setting. Opportunity to observe and assist private practitioners in office, emergency room, operating room and inpatient environment. Student must provide own transportation.
osu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student in good academic standing; consent of instructor.

osu.name: — Acting Internship
osu.description: Course Description: Rotation designed to increase basic knowledge of musculoskeletal abnormalities at clinical level. Attention focused on selective case material. For those students who demonstrate proficiency, responsibility will be similar to that of intern.
osu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student in good academic standing.

osu.name: — Externship in Advanced Orthopaedics
osu.description: Course Description: Advanced Orthopaedic rotation done at an approved institution. Topics may include Trauma, Sports, Spine, Pediatrics, Joint and/or Foot/Ankle. Students are expected to perform at the level of an Intern.
osu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student in good academic standing.

osu.name: — Away Clerkship in Orthopaedics
osu.description: Course Description: Orthopaedic advanced clerkship at an approved institution.

osu.name: — Insights in Orthopardic Surgery
osu.description: Course Description: Exposure to aims, methods and procedures in orthopaedic surgery via attendance at grand rounds, patient care conferences, and group discussions.
osu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; first- and second-year medical students in good academic standing.

osu.name: — History of Medicine for Medical Students
osu.description: Course Description: Overview of the history of medicine throughout the world to introduce medical students to landmark accomplishments and key figures in the development of health care and to provide an expanded philosophical perspective on the everchanging field of modern medicine.
osu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Third- or fourth-year students in the School of Medicine or second-year students with consent of instructor.

osu.name: — Orthopardics Research
osu.description: Course Description: Laboratory or clinical investigation on selected topics.
osu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; third- or fourth-year medical student in good academic standing.

oto.name: — Internship in Otolaryngology
oto.description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in otolaryngology and related fields. Final project report.
oto.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; approval of project prior to period of internship by preceptor.

oto.name: — Special Study in Otolaryngology for Advanced Undergraduates
oto.description: Course Description: Special study in Otolaryngology for advanced undergraduates.
oto.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Advanced undergraduate with consent of instructor.

oto.name: — Research Conference in Otolaryngology
oto.description: Course Description: Presentation and discussion of faculty and student research in otolaryngology.
oto.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate students; medical students; advanced undergraduates with consent of instructor.

oto.name: — Principles of Speech, Hearing & Equilibrium
oto.description: Course Description: Presentations by faculty and guest lecturers on anatomy, physiology, and behaviors involved in speech production, hearing, and equilibrium. Each student expected to make one class presentation.
oto.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate students; medical students; advanced undergraduates with consent of instructor.

oto.name: — Individual Study in Otolaryngology for Advanced Graduate Students
oto.description: Course Description: Individual study in Otolaryngology for advanced graduate students.
oto.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Advanced graduate student with consent of instructor.

oto.name: — Basic Principles of Reconstructive Surgery
oto.description: Course Description: Formal presentations covering basic principles of reconstructive surgery, including wound healing, treatment of lacerations, skin and bone grafts, flaps, Z-plasties and revision of scars. Laboratory session utilizing animal tissues.
oto.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Third- or fourth-year medical student with consent of instructor.

oto.name: — Otolaryngology Required Clerkship
oto.description: Course Description: Provide fundamental knowledge of otorhinolaryngologic diagnosis and principles, develop facility with basic ENT instruments, provide an understanding of treatment for ear, nose and throat problems and provide knowledge of what patients should be referred for otorhinolaryngologic care.
oto.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent by Committee on Student Evaluation and Promotion.

oto.name: — Fourth Year Otolaryngology Elective
oto.description: Course Description: Participation in Otolaryngology Clinic and operating room. Evaluation and management of common Otolaryngologic diseases.
oto.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; third- or fourth-year Medical Students.

oto.name: — Clinical Otolaryngology Elective
oto.description: Course Description: Approved for graduate degree credit. Total involvement in clinical activities of the department.
oto.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Third- and fourth-year medical students with consent of instructor; open to graduate students.

oto.name: — Away Acting Internship in Otolaryngology
oto.description: Course Description: Externship rotation for Acting Internships in Otolaryngology.

oto.name: — Journal Seminar
oto.description: Course Description: Approved for graduate degree credit. Monthly review of current otolaryngologic and related literature and recent advances.
oto.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Fourth-year medical students with consent of instructor; open to graduate students.

oto.name: — Individual or Group Study
oto.description: Course Description: Introduction to basic research in Otolaryngology. Lectures, discussion and laboratory study of sensory and motor systems.

oto.name: — Research
oto.description: Course Description: Approved for graduate degree credit. Participation in ongoing projects.
oto.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical students with consent of instructor; open to graduate students.

pmd.name: — Internship in Human Pathology
pmd.description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in pathology and related fields.
pmd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; approval of project prior to period of internship by preceptor.

pmd.name: — Special Study in Pathology for Advanced Undergraduates
pmd.description: Course Description: Special study in Pathology for advanced undergraduates.
pmd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; advanced undergraduates.

pmd.name: — Research Group Conferences
pmd.description: Course Description: Focused around the mechanisms of function of the central nervous system under normal and pathogenic conditions. Seminars lead by various speakers from UC Davis and other Institutions, both domestic and international.
pmd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate level standing.

pmd.name: — Neurodevelopment Group Study
pmd.description: Course Description: Explore mechanisms that impact perinatal development of the cerebral cortex, and other cortical structures, under normal and pathological conditions.

pmd.name: — Advanced Group Study
pmd.description: Course Description: Group Study provides the opportunity for a faculty member to work with students in a focused manner.
pmd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

pmd.name: — Research
pmd.description: Course Description: Research.
pmd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

pmd.name: — Brain Cutting Conference
pmd.description: Course Description: Current specimens are sectioned, discussed, and clinical correlations proposed.
pmd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Third- and fourth-year medical students or consent of instructor.

pmd.name: — Advanced Neuropathology
pmd.description: Course Description: Presents an integrated introduction to mechanisms of the central and peripheral nervous system injury. Gain an understanding of pathological mechanisms underlying disease, the anatomic and molecular manifestations of pathologic processes of the CNS and PNS.
pmd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; third- or fourth-year medical student.

pmd.name: — General & Endocrine Pathology
pmd.description: Course Description: Pathologic mechanisms of human disease. Concepts of general pathologic processes, i.e., cell death, inflammation and neoplasia. Endocrine pathology in the context of clinical human disease. Emphasis on integration of clinical practice with gross and histologic images emphasizing team-based learning.

pmd.name: — Systemic Pathology
pmd.description: Course Description: Anatomic and clinical pathology of organ system human disease with an emphasis on integration with clinical medicine. Topics include hematopathology and neuropathology.
pmd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by SOM Committee on Student progress.

pmd.name: — Systemic Pathology
pmd.description: Course Description: Anatomic and clinical pathology of organ system human disease with an emphasis on integration with clinical medicine. Topics include pulmonary pathology, cardiovascular pathology, hematopatology, oncologic pathology, and nephropathology.
pmd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by SOM Committee on Student progress.

pmd.name: — Systemic Pathology
pmd.description: Course Description: Anatomic and clinical pathology of organ system human disease with emphasis on integration with clinical medicine. Content parallels concurrent clinical courses with integration of lectures and discussions. Topics include gastrointestinal and gynecologic pathology, hepatopathology, oncologic pathology and musculoskeletal pathology.
pmd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by SOM Committee on Student progress.

pmd.name: — Clinical Patient Care in Pathology
pmd.description: Course Description: Four-week course is designed to give the third-year medical student an exposure to the diverse roles that pathologists have in clinical patient care.
pmd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completed one of the following 3rd year clerkships: Family Medicine, Internal Medicine, Surgery, OBGYN or Pediatrics.

pmd.name: — Surgery-Pathology-Radiology (SPR) Research Laboratory
pmd.description: Course Description: Provide future clinicians and scientists with basic clinical and bioengineering laboratory skills to prepare for careers in translational research.
pmd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

pmd.name: — Diagnostic Medicine: Pathology in Practice
pmd.description: Course Description: Asynchronous learning course bridges the gap between foundational pathophysiology learned in pre-clerkship curriculum and the utilization of pathology and laboratory medicine studies in clinical practice.

pmd.name: — Anatomic Pathology
pmd.description: Course Description: Anatomic pathology with an emphasis on autopsy and surgical pathology with application to clinical practice. Specimen grossing, frozen sections, microscopic sign-out and conferences. Exposure to cytopathology, hematopathology, and clinical pathology is available.
pmd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical students.

pmd.name: — Applied Clinical Laboratory Medicine
pmd.description: Course Description: Emphasis upon laboratory techniques, procedures, and interpretation of laboratory results. Students will be expected to participate fully and in all laboratory operations including bench techniques, laboratory management, and quality control.
pmd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

pmd.name: — Sub-Specialty in Didactic Pathology
pmd.description: Course Description: Externship provides in-depth exposure to one of a variety of sub-specialties in Pathology.
pmd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

pmd.name: — Anatomic Pathology Acting Internship
pmd.description: Course Description: Anatomic Pathology AI will permit students to gain skills needed for first year Pathology Residency. Students will perform autopsies and take full responsibility for a variety of surgical pathology cases. A mix of outpatient and inpatient cases is expected.
pmd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Fourth-year medical student or consent of instructor.

pmd.name: — Anatomic Pathology Acting Internship
pmd.description: Course Description: Year four level course designed to provide a concentrated experience in Surgical Pathology and Cytolopathology. Rotate on the surgical and cytopathology sub-specialty teams and assume responsibility for patient cases.
pmd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PMD 410A; PMD 410B; PMD 410C; PMD 410D; or equivalent, and consent of instructor. Successful completion of third-year clinical rotations.

pmd.name: — Interdisciplinary Study of Gastrointestinal Cancer
pmd.description: Course Description: In-depth study of gastrointestinal, hepatic and pancreatic cancer. Emphasis on an integration of basic science and clinical medicine. Participating departments include pathology, surgical oncology, medical oncology, gastroenterology, radiology and radiotherapy.
pmd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

pmd.name: — Tutoring in Pathology
pmd.description: Course Description: Assist instructor by tutoring medical students in preparation for one of the departmental courses that is a component of the required curriculum of the School of Medicine.
pmd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Advanced standing or consent of instructor.

pmd.name: — Advanced Group Study
pmd.description: Course Description: Group study in variety of advanced topics in general, special, experimental, or comparative pathology.
pmd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; medical student.

pmd.name: — Research
pmd.description: Course Description: Research in experimental, molecular, comparative, and applied pathology.
pmd.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical student with consent of instructor.

pmi.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
pmi.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.

pmi.name: — Fundamentals of Immunology
pmi.description: Course Description: Overview of immunology including components of the immune system, initiation and regulation of the immune response, infection and immunity, hypersensitivity and immune dysfunction. Clinical immunologic techniques, immunodeficiency, and vaccinology.
pmi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 102; or equivalent, or consent of instructor.

pmi.name: — Immunology Laboratory
pmi.description: Course Description: Laboratory procedures in clinical immunology. Cells of the innate and adaptive systems. Quantitative and qualitative characterization of the immune response.
pmi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PMI 126 (can be concurrent); or equivalent.

pmi.name: — Medical Bacteria & Fungi
pmi.description: Course Description: Introduction to the bacterial and mycotic pathogens of man and animals, with emphasis on pathogenic mechanisms and ecologic aspects of infectious disease.
pmi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Any Microbiology course with lab; Immunology strongly recommended.

pmi.name: — Biology of Animal Viruses
pmi.description: Course Description: Fundamental physical and chemical properties of animal viruses; methods of propagation, purification and assay. Mechanisms of viral replication and pathogenesis of viral infections in man and animals. Immunity to virus diseases and oncogenic properties of animal viruses.

pmi.name: — One Health: Human, Animal & Environment Interfaces
pmi.description: Course Description: Introduction to fundamentals, challenges, and opportunities in One Health  using local and global health case studies. Animal, human, and environmental health problems, along with tools and transdisciplinary approaches, will be introduced to foster innovative thinking that addresses complex issues.

pmi.name: — Directed Group Study
pmi.description: Course Description: Directed group study.

pmi.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
pmi.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

pmi.name: — Research Foundations
pmi.description: Course Description: Introduction to key components of graduate school success including mentor/mentee relationship issues, avoiding plagiarism, hypothesis development and experimental design, demystifying the grant writing process, understanding the NIH administrative structure, preparing for a non-academic career, and strategies to maintain a work-life balance.

pmi.name: — Integrative Pathobiology Core I
pmi.description: Course Description: Overview of molecular biology techniques, tissue structure and function, cell membrane pathology and cellular mechanisms of disease including cellular responses and adaptations to stress, cell cycle, cell death, cell biomechanics, vascular disturbances, and mechanisms of neoplasia and tumorigenesis.

pmi.name: — Integrative Pathobiology Core II
pmi.description: Course Description: The second required core course in the graduate group with topics in inflammation, host-pathogen interaction, regenerative medicine, integrative pathology and population and ecosystem health.

pmi.name: — Experimental Design & Data Analysis in Pathobiology
pmi.description: Course Description: Follows two required core courses, PMI 201 & PMI 202, for Ph.D. and M.S. students. Goal is to bridge gap between statistics and real-world pathobiology to increase students' skills and independence in experiment design and data analysis.

pmi.name: — Mentored Scientific Writing
pmi.description: Course Description: Drafting a scientific manuscript for publication based on research results. Students engage in collaborative peer review and learn effective writing, including how to convey a persuasive message and write clearly and succinctly.

pmi.name: — Vector-borne Infectious Diseases: Changing Patterns
pmi.description: Course Description: Vector-borne infectious diseases especially as they relate to changing patterns associated with climatic changes, trade and population movement.
pmi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open to graduate students, MPVM and MPH students, DVM and medical students with second- or third-year standing; open to upper division undergraduate students with consent of instructor(s).

pmi.name: — Topics in Virus  Research
pmi.description: Course Description: Discussion-based seminar covering graduate student virology research. Informal presentations and discussion of technical problems in research design and experimentation are encouraged. Current stage of the research project is not important.
pmi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate student standing (Ph.D. or M.S.).

pmi.name: — Advanced Immunology
pmi.description: Course Description: Current concepts of immunology with an emphasis on interactions between the host, the environment and the pathogen. These interactions will include those that are protective and successful for the host as well as those that are deleterious.

pmi.name: — Seminar
pmi.description: Course Description: Topics in pathology, microbiology or immunology.

pmi.name: — Seminar in Infectious Diseases
pmi.description: Course Description: Discussion of current topics and cases of infectious diseases.
pmi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Current enrollment in health science professional school or graduate standing in biological sciences.

pmi.name: — Group Study
pmi.description: Course Description: Group study.

pmi.name: — Research
pmi.description: Course Description: Research.
pmi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.
