ped.name: — Special Study in Pediatric Research
ped.description: Course Description: Special study for Pediatric research.
ped.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Undergraduate student with consent of instructor based upon adequate preparation as determined by instructor.

ped.name: — Pediatric Research
ped.description: Course Description: Pediatric research.
ped.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Graduate students who are candidates for a degree in some area of biology or behavioral sciences.

ped.name: — Preceptorship in Pediatrics
ped.description: Course Description: Opportunity to observe and participate in primary medical care in a practicing pediatricians office. Participation in history-taking and physical examination will be at discretion of preceptor and dependent on students experience. Evaluation by student.
ped.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Second-year medical student or first-year medical student with consent of instructor.

ped.name: — Clinical Experience in Private Practice
ped.description: Course Description: Opportunity to participate in practice of preceptor, performing such tasks as history taking, physical examination, and patient management.
ped.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PED 430; third-or fourth-year medical student; consent of preceptor and Chairperson.

ped.name: — Pediatrics Lecture Series
ped.description: Course Description: Lecture series covers major topics in pediatrics with case presentations and panels from pediatric subspecialists. Topics include, but are not limited to: cardiology, pulmonology, nephrology, gastroenterology, critical care, and primary care pediatrics.

ped.name: — Fetal & Neonatal Physiology
ped.description: Course Description: Elective is designed to combine for study a variety of aspects of the physiology, anatomy and biochemistry of the fetus and newborn with relevant clinical examples of disorders in each of the 10 topics that will be discussed.

ped.name: — Pediatric Clerkship
ped.description: Course Description: Eight week clinical clerkship providing students with the opportunity to learn fundamentals of caring for the pediatric patient by participating in nursery, ambulatory and inpatient services at UCDMC and affiliated clinical sites. Rounds, conferences, student presentations ongoing.
ped.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

ped.name: — SJVP Pediatric Clerkship at UCSF
ped.description: Course Description: Eight-week clinical clerkship providing students with the opportunity to learn fundamentals of caring for the pediatric patient by participating in nursery, ambulatory and inpatient services at UCSF Fresno. Rounds, conferences, student presentations ongoing.
ped.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

ped.name: — SJVP Longitudinal Pediatrics Clerkship
ped.description: Course Description: Longitudinal Pediatrics Clerkship runs concurrently with Internal Medicine, Family Medicine and Psychiatry for 32 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty.

ped.name: — SJVP Longitudinal Pediatrics Clerkship
ped.description: Course Description: Longitudinal Pediatrics Clerkship runs concurrently with Internal Medicine, Family Medicine and Psychiatry for 32 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty.

ped.name: — SJVP Longitudinal Pediatrics Clerkship
ped.description: Course Description: Longitudinal Pediatrics Clerkship runs concurrently with Internal Medicine, Family Medicine and Psychiatry for 32 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty.

ped.name: — SJVP Longitudinal Pediatrics Clerkship
ped.description: Course Description: Longitudinal Pediatrics Clerkship runs concurrently with Internal Medicine, Family Medicine and Psychiatry for 32 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty.

ped.name: — Rural PRIME Pediatrics Longitudinal Clerkship
ped.description: Course Description: Pediatrics Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.

ped.name: — Rural PRIME Pediatrics Longitudinal Clerkship
ped.description: Course Description: Pediatrics Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.

ped.name: — Rural PRIME Pediatrics Longitudinal Clerkship
ped.description: Course Description: Pediatrics Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.

ped.name: — Rural PRIME Pediatrics Longitudinal Clerkship
ped.description: Course Description: Pediatrics Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.

ped.name: — Rural PRIME Pediatrics Longitudinal Clerkship
ped.description: Course Description: Pediatrics Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.

ped.name: — TeachMS Longitudinal Pediatrics Clerkship (A)
ped.description: Course Description: Longitudinal Clerkship runs concurrently with Primary Care and Psychiatry for 24 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty. On-going patient write-ups, rounds, conferences are required.

ped.name: — TeachMS Longitudinal Pediatrics Clerkship (B)
ped.description: Course Description: Longitudinal clerkship runs concurrently with Primary Care and Psychiatry for 24 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty. On-going patient write-ups, rounds, conferences are required.

ped.name: — TeachMS Longitudinal Pediatrics Clerkship (C)
ped.description: Course Description: Longitudinal clerkship runs concurrently with Primary Care and Psychiatry for 24 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty. On-going patient write-ups, rounds, conferences are required.

ped.name: — Directed Clinical Studies in Pediatrics
ped.description: Course Description: Individual directed studies in extended preparation for modified curriculum or to complete a clinical rotation following a leave of absence.

ped.name: — Directed Studies in Pediatrics
ped.description: Course Description: Individual directed studies in extended preparation for remediation of all or part of clinical rotation. Clinical studies to accommodate and satisfy remedial work as directed by the Committee on Student Progress and approved by the course IOR.

ped.name: — Pediatrics for the Differentiated Student
ped.description: Course Description: One goal is to facilitate the development and reinforcement of the knowledge, skills and attitudes needed as an intern caring for children. Provides a bridge between student experiences in the pre-clerkship phase, the Pediatric clerkship, their Pediatric acting internships and varied Pediatric electives and the Transition to Residency course.

ped.name: — General Inpatient Pediatric Acting Internship
ped.description: Course Description: The Ward Acting Intern functions in a manner similar to that of a pediatric intern. The Acting Intern takes admissions in the regular sequence and is expected to take night call.
ped.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PED 430 B or better; and consent of instructor; letter of recommendation from Pediatrics faculty member.

ped.name: — Acting Internship: Outpatient Pediatrics
ped.description: Course Description: Supervised experience in pediatric care on outpatient service at UCDMC. Student functions as Acting Intern with appropriate supervision by residents and attending faculty.
ped.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PED 430 B or better; and consent of instructor; letter of recommendation from Pediatrics faculty member.

ped.name: — Pediatric Inpatient AI in Hematology/Oncology
ped.description: Course Description: Inpatient and outpatient experience in diagnosis and management of oncologic and hematologic disorders in children. Laboratory experience and participation in clinical investigation may be arranged.
ped.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PED 430; consent of instructor; satisfactory completed.

ped.name: — Elective in Pediatric Endocrinology
ped.description: Course Description: Inpatient and outpatient experience in diagnosis and management of endocrine endocrine disorders in children. Laboratory experience and participation in clinical investigation may be arranged.
ped.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of second-year study or the equivalent.

ped.name: — Medical & Mental Health Evaluation of Children at Risk for Maltreatment
ped.description: Course Description: Elective for fourth-year medical students covers basic areas of knowledge needed for child abuse prevention and consultation. Rotation includes legals cases, abuse exams, child and parent interactive therapy and visits to community organizations.

ped.name: — Acting Internship in Neonatology
ped.description: Course Description: Diagnostic and therapeutic aspect of the medical and surgical high-risk neonate. Student expected to take night call.
ped.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PED 430 B or better; consent of instructor; letter of recommendation from Pediatrics faculty member.

ped.name: — Pediatrics Specialty Elective
ped.description: Course Description: Supervised experience in a variety of pediatric subspecialties at a local or away site.

ped.name: — Elective in Pediatric Cardiology
ped.description: Course Description: Inpatient and outpatient experience in diagnosis and management of cardiologic disorders in children. Laboratory experience and participation in clinical investigation may be arranged.

ped.name: — Elective in Pulmonary Medicine
ped.description: Course Description: Inpatient and outpatient management of pediatric patients with pulmonary diseases. These will include but will not be limited to cystic fibrosis, asthma, and other forms of chronic pulmonary diseases as well as congenital abnormalities.

ped.name: — Elective in Pediatrics Nephrology
ped.description: Course Description: Inpatient and outpatient experience in diagnosis and management of renal disorders in children. Laboratory experience and participation in clinical investigation may be arranged.
ped.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PED 430; consent of instructor; satisfactory completed.

ped.name: — Elective in Pediatric Infectious Disease
ped.description: Course Description: Inpatient and outpatient experience in diagnosis and treatment of infectious disease of infants and children. Laboratory and clinical investigation may be arranged.
ped.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PED 430; consent of instructor; satisfactory completed.

ped.name: — Elective in Pediatric Neurology
ped.description: Course Description: Inpatient and outpatient experience in diagnosis and management of neurological disorders in children. Students will also participate in other pediatric subspecialty clinics which serve children with neurological disorders. Does not satisfy the fourth-year neurology requirement.
ped.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PED 430; IMD 430; OBG 430; consent of instructor; all courses satisfactory completed.

ped.name: — Elective in Pediatric Gastroenterology
ped.description: Course Description: Inpatient and outpatient experience in diagnosis and management of gastroenterology disorders in children. Laboratory experience and participation in clinical investigation may be arranged.
ped.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PED 430; consent of instructor; satisfactory completed.

ped.name: — Clinical Rotation in Adolescent Medicine
ped.description: Course Description: Under supervision, students will see patients in the UC Davis clinic and at a number of community-based sites. Emphasis on the socially-mediated problems that face adolescents, including substance abuse, STD's, pregnancy, depression and suicide. One hour of lecture each week.
ped.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year Medical Student.

ped.name: — Away Acting Internship in Pediatrics
ped.description: Course Description: Work at the level of a sub intern in Inpatient and/or Outpatient settings. Expectation is to provide direct patient management.
ped.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; satisfactory completion of Pediatrics Clerkship.

ped.name: — Neonatal (ICU)
ped.description: Course Description: The Pediatric ICU at UC Davis Children's Hospital is a 24 bed ICU on Davis 10 that provides care for critically ill pediatric patients. These patients are usually younger than 18 years of age and can have either primary medical or surgical issues.

ped.name: — Acting Internship in Pediatric Intensive Care
ped.description: Course Description: Evaluation and support of critically ill infants and children. In general, student expected to take night call every third night during rotation.
ped.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PED 430 A is required; or consent of instructor; letter of recommendation from Pediatrics faculty member.

ped.name: — Pediatric Intensive Care Unit
ped.description: Course Description: Evaluation and support of critically ill infants and children. In general, student expected to take night call every third night during rotation.

ped.name: — Ethical, Legal & Social Issues in Clinical Genetics
ped.description: Course Description: Develop advanced knowledge, communication skills and attitudes necessary to provide compassionate, knowledgeable, and expert care to patients who may be at increased genetic risk for disease. Seminars cover ethical and legal principles, epidemiology, and genetics.

ped.name: — Living with Intellectual & Developmental Disability in the Community
ped.description: Course Description: In-depth experience with Intellectual & Developmental Disability across the lifespan.

ped.name: — Fetal & Neonatal Physiology SSM
ped.description: Course Description: Elective is available for students interested in exploring the fascinating world of the fetus and neonate. Designed to combine the basic sciences with relevant clinical examples of disorders.

ped.name: — Intellectual & Developmental Disability in the Community
ped.description: Course Description: In-depth experience with Intellectual & Developmental Disability across the lifespan.

ped.name: — Fetal & Neonatal Physiology
ped.description: Course Description: Didactic is available for students interested in exploring the fascinating world of the fetus and neonate. Designed to combine the basic sciences with relevant clinical examples of disorders.

ped.name: — Directed Group Study
ped.description: Course Description: Explore in-depth various topics in Pediatrics. Extensive contact with and oversight by instructor.

ped.name: — Research Topics in Pediatrics
ped.description: Course Description: Individual research project in pediatric subspecialty areas (cardiology, endocrinology, hematology, metabolism, newborn physiology and others) may be arranged with faculty member. Independent research by student will be emphasized and long-term projects are possible.
ped.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Student in Medical School with consent of instructor.

pfs.name: — Methods & Materials in Theatre Research
pfs.description: Course Description: Essential research tools in theatre and related fields; bibliographies, primary sources; methods of evaluating and presenting evidence; delineating research areas in the field.

pfs.name: — Topics in Contemporary Theatre & Performance
pfs.description: Course Description: Special topics designed to study in depth aspects of contemporary performance including performance analysis, cultural and historical context, modes of production, theoretical and political entailments, and issues of spectatorship; e.g., "Brecht and After," "British Theater," "Race and Gender in Performance."

pfs.name: — Performance Studies: Modes of Production
pfs.description: Course Description: Introduction to the literature of performance production in a variety of media: theatre, dance, film, video, computer-based, looking at cultural, aesthetic, rhetorical and political theory.

pfs.name: — Performance Studies: Signification & the Body
pfs.description: Course Description: Introduction to analysis of the body in performance, drawing on theoretical models from several fields.

pfs.name: — Performance Studies: Performance & Society
pfs.description: Course Description: Introduction to the role of performance (broadly defined), in everyday life, sociopolitical negotiation, identity, social movements, the media, and the state.

pfs.name: —  Performance Studies: Theory, History, Criticism
pfs.description: Course Description: Introduction to the theory, history and criticism, informing performance studies.

pfs.name: — Individually Guided Research in Performance Studies
pfs.description: Course Description: Individually guided research, under the supervision of a faculty member, on a Performance Studies topic related to the student's proposed dissertation project to produce a dissertation prospectus.
pfs.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PFS 200; (PFS 265A or PFS 265B or PFS 265C or PFS 265D); and consent of instructor.

pfs.name: — Individually Guided Research in Performance Studies
pfs.description: Course Description: Individually guided research, under the supervision of a faculty member, on a Performance Studies topic related to the student's proposed dissertation project, to produce a dissertation prospectus.
pfs.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PFS 200; (PFS 265A or PFS 265B or PFS 265C or PFS 265D); and consent of instructor.

pfs.name: — Individually Guided Research in Performance Studies
pfs.description: Course Description: Individually guided research, under the supervision of a faculty member, on a Performance Studies topic related to the student's proposed dissertation project to produce a dissertation prospectus.
pfs.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PFS 200; (PFS 265A or PFS 265B or PFS 265C or PFS 265D); and consent of instructor.

pfs.name: — Colloquia in Performance Studies
pfs.description: Course Description: Designed to provide cohort identity and faculty exchange. Opportunity to present papers, hear guest   lecturers, and see faculty presentations, gather for organizational and administrative new, exchange of information and make announcements. Must be taken every year that a Performance Studies graduate is registered, prior to taking the Qualifying Examination.
pfs.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Registration in Performance Studies Graduate Group and prior to Qualifying Examination.

pfs.name: — Dissertation Research
pfs.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; advancement to Candidacy.

pfs.name: — Approaches to Theatre & Dance
pfs.description: Course Description: Work on approaches to theatre, dance, film/video, design and performance, with a focus on methodology and professional development.
pfs.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; advanced graduate students.

per.name: — Elementary Persian
per.description: Course Description: Introduction to listening, speaking, reading and writing skills in Persian and to Persian culture.

per.name: — Elementary Persian
per.description: Course Description: Continuation of PER 001. Introduction to listening, speaking, reading and writing skills in Persian and to Persian culture.
per.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PER 001; or consent of instructor.

per.name: — Elementary Persian
per.description: Course Description: Continuation of PER 002. Introduction to listening, speaking, reading and writing skills in Persian and to Persian culture.
per.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PER 002; or consent of instructor.

per.name: — Intermediate Persian
per.description: Course Description: Integrated presentation of listening, speaking, reading and writing skills as well as cultural topics in intermediate Persian.

per.name: — Intermediate Persian
per.description: Course Description: Integrated presentation of listening, speaking, reading and writing as well as cultural topics in Intermediate Persian.

per.name: — Intermediate Persian
per.description: Course Description: Integrated presentation of listening, speaking, reading and writing skills as well as cultural topics in Intermediate Persian.
per.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PER 022; or equivalent knowledge of Persian.

per.name: — Advanced Persian: Topics in Modern Persian Culture 1900-Present
per.description: Course Description: Integrated work on reading, listening, discussion and writing about modern Persian cultural production using fiction and poetry as well as cinema and theory.
per.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PER 023; or consent of instructor.

per.name: — Advanced Persian: Topics in Medieval Persian Culture 900-1500
per.description: Course Description: Integrated work on reading, listening, discussion, writing about medieval Persian culture with a focus on lyric and narrative poetry and representative selections of literary prose, rhetoric, biography, history, religious and philosophical discourse.
per.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PER 023; or consent of instructor.

per.name: — Advanced Persian
per.description: Course Description: Review, refinement, and development of skills learned in intermediate Persian through work with texts, video, and audio on cultural and social issues. Integrated approach to reading, writing, listening, speaking Persian.
per.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PER 023; or consent of instructor.

per.name: — Advanced Persian
per.description: Course Description: Continuation of PER 121. Further development of advanced skills in reading, listening, writing, and speaking modern Persian through work with texts, video, and audio on cultural and social issues.
per.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PER 121; or consent of instructor.

per.name: — Advanced Persian
per.description: Course Description: Continuation of PER 122. Further development of advanced skills in reading, listening, writing, and speaking modern Persian through work with texts, video, and audio on cultural and social issues.
per.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PER 122; or consent of instructor.

ptx.name: — Principles of Pharmacology & Toxicology I
ptx.description: Course Description: First of three courses presenting fundamental principles of pharmacology and toxicology. Introductory overview of basic concepts in pharmacology/toxicology, followed by in-depth blocks on fate processes of chemicals in the body, fate processes in tissue selective responses, selective toxicity employed therapeutically.

ptx.name: — Principles of Pharmacology & Toxicology II
ptx.description: Course Description: Second of three courses presenting fundamental principles of pharmacology and toxicology. Principles of pharmacodynamics and mechanisms of drug/toxicant actions.

ptx.name: — Principles of Pharmacology & Toxicology III
ptx.description: Course Description: Integrated physiological systems, cardiovascular and nervous systems and how drugs and toxicants act to perturb function.

ptx.name: — Electrophysiology Techniques & Applications
ptx.description: Course Description: Broad scope of topics in electrophysiology techniques and applications.

ptx.name: — Advanced Topics in Pharmacology & Toxicology
ptx.description: Course Description: In-depth coverage of selected topics for graduate students in Pharmacology-Toxicology and related disciplines. Topics determined by instructor in charge for each quarter.
ptx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PTX 201; and consent of instructor.

ptx.name: — Molecular Mechanisms in Cancer & other Diseases
ptx.description: Course Description: Exploration of cutting edge investigations on the underlying mechanisms of cancer biology, cancer therapy and other diseases. Current medical research in cancer and other diseases, as it spans the bench to bedside.
ptx.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MCB 121 or MCB 122; undergraduate or graduate introductory course in cell biology (such as BIS 104), and general biochemistry (MCB 121 or MCB 122) required; PTX 202 recommended.

ptx.name: — Seminar
ptx.description: Course Description: Current topics in pharmacology and toxicology.

ptx.name: — Advanced Research Conference
ptx.description: Course Description: Provide credit for participation in and attendance at research conferences.

ptx.name: — Research
ptx.description: Course Description: Research with a faculty member in the Pharmacology & Toxicology Graduate Group.

phi.name: — Introduction to Philosophy
phi.description: Course Description: Problems of philosophy through major writings from various periods. Problems are drawn from political, aesthetic, religious, metaphysical, and epistemological concerns of philosophy.

phi.name: — Critical Reasoning
phi.description: Course Description: Criteria of good reasoning in everyday life and in science. Topics to be covered may include basic principles of deduction and induction; fallacies in reasoning; techniques and aids to reasoning; principles of scientific investigation; aids to clarity.

phi.name: — Philosophical Perspectives on Sexuality
phi.description: Course Description: Philosophical issues related to sexuality, including, but not limited to, ethical and social issues regarding sexual practice, orientation, classification and identity.

phi.name: — Philosophical Perspectives on Sexuality
phi.description: Course Description: Philosophical issues related to sexuality, including, but not limited to, ethical and social issues regarding sexual practice, orientation, classification and identity.

phi.name: — Introduction to Cognitive Science
phi.description: Course Description: Introduction to the interdisciplinary cognitive scientific approach to the study of mind, drawing concepts and methods from psychology, philosophy, linguistics, artificial intelligence, and other disciplines.

phi.name: — Asian Philosophy
phi.description: Course Description: Survey of the main philosophical systems of south and east Asia: Hinduism, Buddhism, Confucianism, and Taoism. Topics include the nature of reality, including God, the universe and the human self, human knowledge, and the proper conduct of human life.

phi.name: — Introduction to Symbolic Logic
phi.description: Course Description: Syntax and semantics of the symbolic language sentence logic. Symbols of sentence logic. Translation between sentence logic and English. Truth table interpretation of sentence logic. Proof techniques. Application of truth tables and proof techniques to arguments in English.

phi.name: — Minds, Brains, & Computers
phi.description: Course Description: Computational theories of the nature of the mind. Mind as a computer process. Possibility of machine intelligence, consciousness, and mentality.

phi.name: — Minds, Brains, & Computers with Discussion
phi.description: Course Description: Computational theories of the nature of the mind. Mind as a computer process. Possibility of machine intelligence, consciousness, and mentality.

phi.name: — Ethical & Social Problems in Contemporary Society
phi.description: Course Description: Philosophical issues and positions involved in contemporary moral and social problems. Possible topics include civil disobedience and revolution, racial and sex discrimination, environment, population control, technology and human values, sexual morality, freedom in society.

phi.name: — Introduction to Bioethics
phi.description: Course Description: Critical analysis of normative issues raised by contemporary medicine and biology. Possible topics include euthanasia, reproductive technologies, genetic engineering, informed consent and patient autonomy, experimentation on human subjects and non-human animals.

phi.name: — Philosophical Foundations of American Democracy
phi.description: Course Description: The philosophical underpinnings of democratic government and the tension between the goals of providing security and of preserving democracy and civil liberties. Illustration of the tension through focus on issues related to war and terrorism.

phi.name: — Language, Thought, & World
phi.description: Course Description: Puzzles in the philosophy of language, such as what language is, how language conveys thoughts, whether we each speak our own private language, and what we can learn about the world by studying language.

phi.name: — Philosophical Classics of the Ancient Era
phi.description: Course Description: Survey of ancient Western philosophy with special attention to the Pre-Socratics, Plato, Aristotle, and the Sceptics.

phi.name: — Philosophical Classics of the Modern Era
phi.description: Course Description: Survey of modern Western philosophy, including Descartes, Locke, Hume, and Kant.

phi.name: — Introduction to Ethics
phi.description: Course Description: Reading of historical and contemporary philosophical works in ethics. Topics include the nature of morality, the justification of moral claims, and major ethical theories, such as consequentialist, deontological, and virtue theories.

phi.name: — Introduction to Philosophy of Science
phi.description: Course Description: Basic problems in the philosophy of science, common to the physical, biological, and social sciences. Analysis of explanation, confirmation theory, observational and theoretical terms, the nature of theories, operationalism and behaviorism, realism, reduction.

phi.name: — Appraising Scientific Reasoning
phi.description: Course Description: Introduction to scientific hypotheses and the kinds of reasoning used to justify such hypotheses. Emphasis on adequate justification, criteria, and strategies for distinguishing scientific from pseudoscientific theories. Concrete historical and contemporary cases.

phi.name: — Understanding Scientific Change
phi.description: Course Description: Concepts of scientific change in historical and philosophical perspective. Survey of models of growth of knowledge, 17th century to present. Relationship between logic of theories and theory choice. Kuhns revolution model. Examples from various sciences.

phi.name: — Introduction to Philosophy of Biology
phi.description: Course Description: Non-technical introduction to philosophical, social, and scientific ideas, methods and technologies in contemporary biological fields such as evolution, genetics, molecular biology, ecology, behavior. Philosophical consideration of determinism, reductionism, explanation, theory, modeling, observation, experimentation. Evaluation of scientific explanations of human nature.

phi.name: — Directed Group Study
phi.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

phi.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
phi.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

phi.name: — Metaphysics
phi.description: Course Description: Theories of being. Such topics as reality, substance, universals, space, time, causality, becoming, body, experience, persons, freedom, and determinism. Views of the nature and method of metaphysics. Anti-metaphysical arguments.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy recommended.

phi.name: — Theory of Knowledge
phi.description: Course Description: Analysis of the concept of knowledge. The relation between knowledge, belief and truth. Development of foundationalist, coherentist and externalist theories of justified belief. Examination of skepticism.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy recommended.

phi.name: — Philosophy on Mind
phi.description: Course Description: The relation between mind and body, our knowledge of other minds, and the explanation of mental acts. Discussion of such concepts as action, intention, and causation.

phi.name: — The Evolution of Mind
phi.description: Course Description: Interpretation of human thought and behavior through the lens of evolutionary theory. Topics include the nature/nurture debate concerning cognitive and other mental capacities and traits, and the interaction between evolution, learning and development.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One previous course in Philosophy recommended.

phi.name: — Philosophy of Religion
phi.description: Course Description: Logical, metaphysical, epistemological, and existential aspects of selected religious concepts and problems.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy recommended.

phi.name: — Philosophy of the Physical Sciences
phi.description: Course Description: Nature of testability and confirmation of scientific hypotheses; nature of scientific laws, theories, explanations, and models. Problems of causality, determininism, induction, and probability; the structure of scientific revolutions.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One Philosophy course or a science background recommended.

phi.name: — Philosophy of the Biological Sciences
phi.description: Course Description: Scientific method in biology. Nature of biological theories, explanations, and models. Problems of evolutionary theory, ecology, genetics, and sociobiology. Science and human values.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Biology or one course in Philosophy recommended.

phi.name: — Philosophy of the Social Sciences
phi.description: Course Description: The nature of the social sciences, their subject matter and methods. Similarities to and differences from natural and life sciences. Predicting and explaining human behavior. Behaviorism. Reduction, holism, and individualism. Related moral issues. The social sciences and philosophy.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy or a social science recommended.

phi.name: — Philosophy of Space & Time
phi.description: Course Description: Philosophical problems of space and time. Philosophical implications of space-time theories, such as those of Newton and Einstein. Topics may include the nature of geometry, conventionalism, absolutist versus relationist views of space and time, philosophical impact of relativity theory.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One upper division Philosophy course recommended.

phi.name: — Intermediate Symbolic Logic
phi.description: Course Description: Predicate logic syntax and semantics. Transcription between predicate logic and English. Models, truth-trees, and derivations. Identity, functions, and definite descriptions. Introduction to concepts of metatheory.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 012 C- or better; or consent of instructor.

phi.name: — Metalogic
phi.description: Course Description: The metalogic of classical propositional and first-order predicate logic. Consistency, soundness and completeness of both propositional and predicate logic. The Löwenheim-Skolem theorem for predicate logic. Undecidablity of predicate logic.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 112; MAT 108; or the equivalent.

phi.name: — History of Ethics
phi.description: Course Description: Study of some classic texts from the history of philosophical writing on central problems of ethics, taking the form either of a survey or concentrated examination of selected historical figures. Readings from such philosophers as Aristotle, Butler, Hume, Kant, Mill.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One previous Philosophy course recommended.

phi.name: — Problems in Normative Ethics
phi.description: Course Description: Moral philosophy studied through examination of moral problems and the moral principles and common sense intuitions that bear on them. Problems discussed may include: animal rights, fetal rights, euthanasia, justice and health care, war, nuclear deterrence, world hunger, environmental protection.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One previous course in Philosophy recommended.

phi.name: — Ethical Theories
phi.description: Course Description: Study of fundamental concepts and problems in ethical theory through an examination of classical and contemporary philosophical theories of ethics. Among the theories that may be discussed are utilitarianism, virtue theory, theories of natural rights, Kantian ethical theory, and contractarianism.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in ethics recommended.

phi.name: — Foundations of Ethics
phi.description: Course Description: Advanced investigation of questions about the nature and foundations of morality. Among the topics that may be discussed are moral realism and anti-realism, cognitivism and non-cognitivism, types of relativism, moral skepticism, normative language and normative belief.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 114, 115, 116, 101, or 137 recommended.

phi.name: — Political Philosophy
phi.description: Course Description: Intensive examination of some central concepts of political thought such as the state, sovereignty, rights, obligation, freedom, law, authority, and responsibility.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy recommended.

phi.name: — Philosophy of Law
phi.description: Course Description: Philosophical theories of the nature of law, legal obligation, the relation of law and morals. Problems for law involving liberty and justice: freedom of expression, privacy, rights, discrimination and fairness, responsibility, and punishment.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; one course in Philosophy recommended.

phi.name: — Environmental Ethics
phi.description: Course Description: Conceptual and ethical issues concerning the environment. Extension of ethical theory to animals, all life, and ecosystem wholes. Topics may include contemporary environmental issues such as global warming, sustainability and biodiversity.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy recommended.

phi.name: — Bioethics
phi.description: Course Description: In-depth coverage of topics in bioethics including resource allocation, measures of health and disease/disability, public health, and ethical issues related to research on human subjects and emerging technologies.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 015 recommended.

phi.name: — Philosophy of Race
phi.description: Course Description: Core issues in the philosophy of race, including investigation of the nature and reality of race, use of race in science and medicine, nature of racial identity, and ethical responses to racial injustice.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One previous course in Philosophy recommended.

phi.name: — Aesthetics
phi.description: Course Description: Nature of art, of artistic creation, of the work of art, and of aesthetic experience; nature and validity of criticism; relations of art to its environment.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy recommended.

phi.name: — Theory of Action
phi.description: Course Description: Survey of prominent contemporary approaches to leading problems in action theory. Problems include issues about the nature of intentional action and the conceptual character of explanations of actions in terms of the agent's reasons.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy recommended.

phi.name: — Rationality
phi.description: Course Description: Philosophical issues concerning rationality in its various forms. Focus is on theoretical and practical reasoning and conditions for rational belief, choice, and action. Possible additional topics include rationality and human limitations; paradoxes of rationality; varieties of irrationality; rationality and objectivity.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy recommended.

phi.name: — Knowledge & the A Priori
phi.description: Course Description: Self-evidence, intuition, the (in)fallibility and (in)defeasibility of a priori methods. Analytic, formalist and Kantian accounts of how knowledge can be acquired through reasoning and intuition alone, without recourse to empirical methods.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy recommended.

phi.name: — Philosophy of Logic & Mathematics
phi.description: Course Description: Nature of formal systems and mathematical theories. Selected topics include logical and semantical paradoxes; foundations of mathematics; set theory, type theory, and intuitionistic theory; philosophy of geometry; philosophical implications of Gödels incompleteness results.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 012 or one course for credit in mathematics.

phi.name: — Logic, Probability, & Artificial Intelligence
phi.description: Course Description: Introduction to theoretical artificial intelligence with a focus on nonmonotonic logic, Bayesian networks, and learning theory.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 012; (PHI 112 or STA 013).

phi.name: — Modal Logic
phi.description: Course Description: Survey of the main systems of modal logic, including Lewis systems S4 and S5. Possible worlds semantics and formal proofs. Applications to epistemology, ethics, or temporality.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 112 or MAT 108; or the equivalent.

phi.name: — Alternative Logics
phi.description: Course Description: Alternatives to standard truth-functional logic, including many-valued logics, intuitionist logics, relevance logics, and non-monotonic logics.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 012 or MAT 108; or the equivalent.

phi.name: — Formal Epistemology
phi.description: Course Description: Formal (mathematical) approaches to belief revision, knowledge and deduction, meta-knowledge, (multi-agent) epistemic logic, Bayesian confirmation, Bayes nets, epistemic and probabilistic paradoxes.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 012.

phi.name: — Philosophy of Language: Theory of Reference
phi.description: Course Description: Survey of issues and views concerning reference, or how words refer to things. Topics include names and descriptions, the distinction between sense and reference, the puzzle of non-referring terms, causal theories of reference, and possibility and necessity.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy or Linguistics recommended.

phi.name: — Philosophy of Language: Truth & Meaning
phi.description: Course Description: Comparative treatment of theories about the relationship between truth and meaning. Topics include: the identification of meaning with truth conditions, the nature of propositions, theories of linguistic understanding, the roles of mind and world in determining meaning.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy or Linguistics recommended.

phi.name: — Philosophy of Language: Semantics & Pragmatics
phi.description: Course Description: Philosophical issues and positions concerning the meaning and use of language. Topics include the distinction between meaning and implication, the roles of context and convention in language use, speaker meaning versus linguistic meaning and speech act theory.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy or Linguistics recommended.

phi.name: — Socrates & the Socratic Dialogue
phi.description: Course Description: Philosophy of Socrates as found in the Socratic dialogues of Plato. Topics include the Socratic practice of refutation, its method, epistemological foundation, and moral purpose; Socratic eudaimonism and Socratic virtue theory; the paradoxes of Socratic intellectualism.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 021 recommended.

phi.name: — Hellenistic Philosophy
phi.description: Course Description: Positions and arguments of the major philosophical schools of the Hellenistic period: Stoicism, Epicureanism, and Scepticism. Focus is on ethical, epistemological and metaphysical questions and their interconnectedness.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 021 recommended.

phi.name: — Christian, Islamic, & Jewish Philosophers of the Middle Ages
phi.description: Course Description: Major Christian, Islamic, and Jewish philosophers of the Middle Ages.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 021 recommended.

phi.name: — 19th-Century European Philosophy
phi.description: Course Description: Survey of the main movements in 19th-century philosophy on the European continent. Idealism in Schopenhauer and Hegel, dialectical materialism in Marx, irrationalism in Kierkegaard, Nietzsche and Dostoevsky.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 022 recommended.

phi.name: — Contemporary Analytic Philosophy
phi.description: Course Description: Consideration of central issues such as meaning/reference, analytic/synthetic, reductionism, formal and ordinary language, essential properties, ontological commitment, possible world semantics; influential works by philosophers such as Russell, Moore, Wittgenstein, Austin, Carnap, Quine, Putnam, Kripke, van Fraassen.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy recommended.

phi.name: — 20th-Century European Philosophy
phi.description: Course Description: Survey of the main movements in 20th-century philosophy on the European continent, including phenomenology, existentialism, post-structuralism and post-modernism. Philosophers covered are Husserl, Heidegger, Sartre, Foucault, Derrida.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in Philosophy recommended.

phi.name: — Pre-Socratics
phi.description: Course Description: Study of the metaphysical views of such pre-Socratic figures as the Milesians, the Pythagoreans, Heracleitus, Parmenides, Empedocles, Anaxagoras, and the atomists.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 021 recommended.

phi.name: — Plato
phi.description: Course Description: Examines Platos most important contributions in metaphysics, epistemology, psychology, cosmology, ethics and political philosophy. Dialogues will be selected from Platos middle and later writings.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 021 recommended.

phi.name: — Aristotle
phi.description: Course Description: Overview of Aristotles most central and influential writings. Topics selected from fields such as metaphysics, physics, ethics, logic, and psychology.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 021 recommended.

phi.name: — Descartes
phi.description: Course Description: Philosophical writings of René Descartes. Topics include the refutation of skepticism, the nature and existence of mind and body, the existence of God, and the foundations of science.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 022 recommended.

phi.name: — Spinoza & Leibniz
phi.description: Course Description: Philosophical writings of Spinoza and Leibniz in the 17th century. Topics drawn from both philosophers include: the nature and existence of God, the nature of mind, the relation between mind and body, human freedom, metaphysical monism vs. pluralism.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 022 recommended.

phi.name: — Locke & Berkeley
phi.description: Course Description: Principal metaphysical works of John Locke and George Berkeley. Topics include abstract ideas, existence of matter, primary and secondary qualities, essence, substance, the existence of God, and the nature of scientific knowledge.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 022 recommended.

phi.name: — Hume
phi.description: Course Description: David Hume's Treatise of Human Nature and related writings. Topics include empiricism, space, causality, belief, skepticism, the passions, and morality.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 022 recommended.

phi.name: — Kant
phi.description: Course Description: Immanuel Kant's Critique of Pure Reason and related writings. Topics include the nature of human cognition, space and time, a priori concepts, substance, causality, human freedom, and the existence of God.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 022 recommended.

phi.name: — Frege
phi.description: Course Description: Development of Gottlob Frege's views about language and logic. Formulation of his grand mathematical idea known as logicism and how it led to the philosophy of language.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; one upper division course in Philosophy recommended.

phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One course in the area of the special topic recommended.

phi.name: — Honors Research Project
phi.description: Course Description: Completion of honors research project under direction of an instructor. Consult departmental major advisor for list of instructors available in a given quarter.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; open to students who are members of the honors program in Philosophy.

phi.name: — Research Project
phi.description: Course Description: Completion of honors research project under direction of an instructor. Consult departmental major advisor for list of instructors available in a given quarter.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; open to students who are members of the honors program in Philosophy.

phi.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

phi.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
phi.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

phi.name: — Proseminar I
phi.description: Course Description: Intensive study of core works in a selected area of philosophy. Intensive experience in philosophical writing, discussion, and presentation of written work.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

phi.name: — Proseminar II
phi.description: Course Description: Intensive study of core works in a selected area of philosophy. Intensive experience in philosophical writing, discussion, and presentation of written work.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

phi.name: — Metaphysics
phi.description: Course Description: Topics vary from quarter to quarter and may include the following: What are things? Do names refer to things? If so, how? Do things have essential properties? What is the nature of necessity?
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

phi.name: — Theory of Knowledge
phi.description: Course Description: Topics vary from quarter to quarter. Sample topics include belief, skepticism, justification, externalism, naturalized epistemology.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Philosophy or consent of instructor.

phi.name: — Philosophy of Mind
phi.description: Course Description: Topics in the philosophy of mind, such as the mind-body problem, mental representation, consciousness, intentionality.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

phi.name: — Philosophy of Mind Practicum
phi.description: Course Description: Specific research conducted and prepared for publication by advanced students in a team setting. Topics include knowledge representation and learning in neural networks, the nature and formal properties of mental representation.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

phi.name: — Philosophy of Physics
phi.description: Course Description: Intensive treatment of one (or more) topic(s) in the philosophy of physics, such as foundations of spacetime theories, the interpretation of quantum mechanics, or foundations of statistical mechanics.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Philosophy or consent of instructor.

phi.name: — Philosophy of Biology
phi.description: Course Description: Intensive treatment of one (or more) topic(s) in the philosophy of biology, such as foundations of evolutionary theories, reductionism in biology, sociobiology and cultural evolution.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

phi.name: — Philosophy of Science
phi.description: Course Description: Treatment of one or more general topics of current interest in philosophy of science. Topics may include scientific explanation, theories of confirmation, scientific realism, reduction in physics and biology.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

phi.name: — Philosophy of Logic & Mathematics
phi.description: Course Description: Philosophical issues in logic and math. Topics may include nature of logical and mathematical truth or knowledge, correctness of logical systems, foundations of mathematics, metaphysical and epistemological presuppositions, applications to philosophical problems and formalization of philosophical theories.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHI 112 or PHI 113 or MAT 108; or MAT 125 or the equivalent.

phi.name: — Advanced Logic for Graduate Students
phi.description: Course Description: Intensive study of advanced logic, including set theory, metatheory of predicate logic, and modal logic.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Philosophy.

phi.name: — Ethics
phi.description: Course Description: Topics may include morality and motivation, objectivity in ethics, the relationship between the factual and the moral. Topics vary from quarter to quarter.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Philosophy or consent of instructor.

phi.name: — Political Philosophy
phi.description: Course Description: Advanced studies in political philosophy. Topics vary but may include distributive justice, enforcement of morality by the state, equality, obligation to obey the law, social contract theory.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

phi.name: — Environmental Ethics
phi.description: Course Description: Intensive treatment of one or more topic(s) in environmental ethics, such as biodiversity, sustainability, composition of the moral community, invasive species, endangered species, applications of ethical theories to contemporary environmental issues.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

phi.name: — Philosophy of Language
phi.description: Course Description: Study of philosophical issues raised by language, such as the nature of semantic content, proper semantics for verbs of propositional attitude, feasibility and limitations of formal semantics and pragmatics for natural languages.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

phi.name: — Philosophy of Language Workshop
phi.description: Course Description: Discussion of recently published, unpublished and in-progress research in philosophy of language, including work on the relation of language and mind, of language and logic, and linguistic theory.

phi.name: — Plato
phi.description: Course Description: Advanced seminar designed for analysis of arguments, doctrines, and texts from Plato's works. Methods of argumentation and interpretation are especially stressed. Topics vary according to instructor.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

phi.name: — Aristotle
phi.description: Course Description: Advanced seminar designed for analysis of arguments, doctrines, and texts from Aristotle's works. Methods of argumentation and interpretation are especially stressed. Topics vary according to instructor.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

phi.name: — Kant
phi.description: Course Description: Intensive study of a topic in the philosophy of Kant, in such areas as metaphyics, theory of knowledge, ethics.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Philosophy or consent of instructor.

phi.name: — History of Philosophy
phi.description: Course Description: Topics in the history of philosophy. Topics vary according to instructor from quarter to quarter.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

phi.name: — Group Study
phi.description: Course Description: Group study.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

phi.name: — Research
phi.description: Course Description: Research.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

phi.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
phi.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training.
phi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

pmr.name: — Research Approaches to Disability & Rehabilitation
pmr.description: Course Description: Discussion and evaluation of research approaches to medical rehabilitation, community integration, and quality of life of disabled persons, with a focus on the progressive disabilities associated with neuromuscular diseases. Intent is to encourage interest in professions that serve the disabled community and increase awareness of rehabilitation goals.

pmr.name: — Directed Group Study
pmr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; advanced standing.

pmr.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
pmr.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
pmr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; advanced standing.

pmr.name: — Healthy Living: Leading by Example
pmr.description: Course Description: Improve the physical and mental health of participating students while supplementing their medical education with specific concepts.

pmr.name: — Healthy Living: Leading by Example
pmr.description: Course Description: Improve the physical and mental health of participating students while supplementing their medical education with specific concepts.

pmr.name: — Healthy Living: Leading by Example
pmr.description: Course Description: Improve the physical and mental health of participating students while supplementing their medical education with specific concepts.

pmr.name: — Introduction to Sports Medicine
pmr.description: Course Description: Introduction to basic concepts of Sports Medicine in Physical Medicine & Rehabilitation. Students attend afternoon clinic with Sports Medicine attending; attend lectures focusing on Sports Medicine topics. Students also eligible to cover sporting events with attending physicians where available.

pmr.name: — Introduction to Rehabilitation Medicine
pmr.description: Course Description: Rehabilitation and comprehensive care of physically disabled and physical medicine management of neurologic, neuromuscular and musculoskeletal disorders. Emphasis on evaluation and conservative treatment of spinal disorders, sports injuries and neuromuscular disease. Additional emphasis on inpatient rehabilitation, pediatrics, spine or sports possible.
pmr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): IMD 430; SUR 430; consent of instructor.

pmr.name: — Comprehensive Rehabilitation Medicine
pmr.description: Course Description: Four-week rotation designed as broad overview of Physical Medicine & Rehabilitation practice for students interested in residency training in the specialty. Emphasis on evaluation and conservative treatment of spinal disorders, sports injuries, neuromuscular disease, neurological and non-operative orthopedic problems requiring rehabilitative management.
pmr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): IMD 430; SUR 430; consent of instructor.

pmr.name: — Rehabilitation Medicine Clinical Elective
pmr.description: Course Description: Emphasis on evaluation of patients with neurological or orthopaedic problems requiring rehabilitative techniques for their management. Introduction to management of such patients. Physical Medicine & Rehabilitation at off-campus facility must be approved by Chairperson.
pmr.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): IMD 430; SUR 430; and consent of instructor; completion of third-year in Medical School.

pmr.name: — Pediatric Rehabilitation Medicine: Caring for Developmental Disabilities
pmr.description: Course Description: Clerkship. Participate in the outpatient clinical care of children with a wide variety of medical conditions at Shriner's Hospitals for Children. Rotate through a variety of different outpatient clinics including cerebral palsy, neuromuscular disease, limb difference, spinal cord injury, spina bifida, brachial plexus, and sports medicine.

pmr.name: — Away Acting Internship in Physical Medicine & Rehabilitation
pmr.description: Course Description: AI Externship option for PM&R rotations at other institutions.

pmr.name: — Applied Musculoskeletal Anatomy: Sports & Spine SSM
pmr.description: Course Description: This four-week module will review the anatomy and biomechanics of the musculoskeletal system as well as its associated pathology. The students will be instructed on appropriate musculoskeletal exam techniques and logical approach to the patient in the clinical setting.

pmr.name: — Applied Musculoskeletal Anatomy: Sports & Spine
pmr.description: Course Description: Review of the anatomy and biomechanics of the musculoskeletal system as well as its associated pathology. Instruction on appropriate musculoskeletal exam techniques and logical approach to the patient in the clinical setting.

pmr.name: — Advanced Group Study
pmr.description: Course Description: Study and experience for medical students in any of a number of areas in physical medicine and rehabilitation.

pmr.name: — Research for Medical Students
pmr.description: Course Description: Research on any of a variety of topics in physical medicine and rehabilitation.

pas.name: — Professional Practice in Healthcare 1
pas.description: Course Description: Role of the Physician Assistant in the context of healthcare system. Physician Assistant topics in practice of healthcare delivery within interprofessional team.

pas.name: — Primary Health Care

pas.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PAS 251B C or better; PAS 271B C or better; PAS 410B C or better; consent of instructor.

pas.name: — Gender and Transgender Health
pas.description: Course Description: Health care concepts specific and essential to the care of men, women, and transgender populations. Unique aspects of preventive care and treatment of conditions specific to these populations.
pas.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PAS 251B C or better; PAS 271B C or better; PAS 410B C or better; consent of instructor.

pas.name: — Surgery & Emergency Medicine
pas.description: Course Description: Concepts essential to the care of common urgent and emergent medical conditions, as well as chronic, urgent, and emergent surgical conditions. Epidemiology, presentation, evaluation and management of these conditions.
pas.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PAS 251D C or better; PAS 251C C or better; PAS 271C C or better; PAS 410C C or better; consent of instructor.

pas.name: — Pediatrics & Gerontology (Special Populations)
pas.description: Course Description: Health care concepts essential to care of special populations at earliest and latest stages of life. Unique aspects of both pediatric and geriatric patients.
pas.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PAS 410C C or better; PAS 251C C or better; PAS 271C C or better; PAS 251D C or better; consent of instructor.

pas.name: — Foundations of Behavioral Health
pas.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Spectrum of normal psychological development over the lifespan for children, adults and elders. Theories of stress and coping mechanism as a framework for the assessment of individuals.

pas.name: — Foundations of Pharmacology
pas.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduction to major concepts in foundational pharmacology including pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, pharmacogenetics, and other molecular mechanisms of health and disease.

pas.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PAS 251E C+ or better; PAS 251F C+ or better; PAS 410D C+ or better; or consent of instructor.

phy.name: — Principles of Physics
phy.description: Course Description: Mechanics. Introduction to general principles and analytical methods used in physics with emphasis on applications in applied agricultural and biological sciences and in physical education.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Trigonometry or consent of instructor.

phy.name: — Principles of Physics
phy.description: Course Description: Continuation of PHY 001A. Heat, optics, electricity, modern physics.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 001A or PHY 009A.

phy.name: — General Physics
phy.description: Course Description: Introduction to general principles and analytical methods used in physics for students majoring in a biological science.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 016B (can be concurrent) or MAT 017B (can be concurrent) or MAT 021B (can be concurrent); completion or concurrent enrollment in MAT 016B or MAT 017B or MAT 021B.

phy.name: — General Physics
phy.description: Course Description: Continuation of PHY 007A.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 007A.

phy.name: — General Physics
phy.description: Course Description: Continuation of PHY 007B.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 007B.

phy.name: — Classical Physics
phy.description: Course Description: Introduction to general principles and analytical methods used in physics for physical science and engineering majors. Classical mechanics.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 021B or MAT 021M; or consent of instructor.

phy.name: — Classical Physics
phy.description: Course Description: Continuation of PHY 009A. Fluid mechanics, thermodynamics, wave phenomena, optics.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 009A; MAT 021C; MAT 021D (can be concurrent).

phy.name: — Classical Physics
phy.description: Course Description: Electricity and magnetism including circuits and Maxwell's equations.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 009B; MAT 021D; (MAT 022A or MAT 027A (can be concurrent)).

phy.name: — Modern Physics
phy.description: Course Description: Introduction to physics concepts developed since 1900. Special relativity, quantum mechanics, atoms, molecules, condensed matter, nuclear and particle physics.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 009C; (MAT 022A or MAT 027A); MAT 022B or MAT 27B recommended (may be taken concurrently).

phy.name: — Honors Physics
phy.description: Course Description: Classical mechanics. Same material as PHY 009A in greater depth. For students in physical sciences, mathematics, and engineering.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 021B (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

phy.name: — Honors Physics
phy.description: Course Description: Special relativity, thermal physics. Continuation of PHY 009HA.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PHY 009HA or PHY 009A); MAT 021C (can be concurrent).

phy.name: — Honors Physics
phy.description: Course Description: Waves, sound, optics, quantum physics. Continuation of Physics 9HB.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 009HB; MAT 021D (can be concurrent).

phy.name: — Honors Physics
phy.description: Course Description: Electricity and magnetism. Continuation of Physics 9HC.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 009HC; MAT 021D.

phy.name: — Honors Physics
phy.description: Course Description: Application of quantum mechanics.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 009HD; (MAT 022B or MAT 027B (can be concurrent)).

phy.name: — Topics in Physics for Nonscientists
phy.description: Course Description: Emphasis varies: survey of basic principles or a deeper exploration of some particular branch. Past topics included black holes, space time, and relativity; physics of music; history and philosophy; energy and the environment; and natural phenomena.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): High school algebra.

phy.name: — Physics of California
phy.description: Course Description: Atmospheric phenomena common in CA, local weather patterns and microclimes. Applications to CA energy, water, and resource management policies. Physics underlying regional sports in CA.

phy.name: — Physics of California
phy.description: Course Description: Conceptual understanding of the physics underlying regional sports in CA. Focus on skiing, surfing, and scuba diving. Atmospheric phenomena common in CA, local weather patterns and microclimes, applications to CA energy, and water are also discussed.

phy.name: — Visualization in Science
phy.description: Course Description: Production, interpretation, and use of images in physics, astronomy, biology, and chemistry as scientific evidence and for communication of research results.

phy.name: — Fractals, Chaos & Complexity
phy.description: Course Description: Modern ideas about the unifying ideas of fractal geometry, chaos and complexity. Basic theory and applications with examples from physics, earth sciences, mathematics, population dynamics, ecology, history, economics, biology, computer science, art and architecture.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 016A or MAT 017A or MAT 021A.

phy.name: — Introduction to Physics Computation
phy.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduction to programming using C++ with examples from computational physics. Introduction to modern tools used for scientific analysis, including Scientific computing with Python.

phy.name: — Computational Physics
phy.description: Course Description: Algorithms and programming techniques of computational physics with applications from introductory physics.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 040; PHY 009C or PHY 009HD.

phy.name: — Supplementary Work in Lower Division Physics
phy.description: Course Description: With consent of instructor, students with partial credit in lower division physics courses may complete the credit under this heading.

phy.name: — Experimental Techniques
phy.description: Course Description: Experimental techniques. Design of circuits. Data analysis, sources of noise,  statistical and systematic uncertainties. Light sources, detection, and measurement in basic optical systems.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 009D or PHY 009HD.

phy.name: — Lower Division Seminar
phy.description: Course Description: Examination of a special topic in Physics through shared readings, discussions, written assignments, or special activities such as laboratory work.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

phy.name: — Directed Group Study
phy.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Primary for lower division students.

phy.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
phy.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

phy.name: — Computational Laboratory in Physics
phy.description: Course Description: Introduction to computational physics and to the computational resources in the physics department. Preparation for brief programming assignments required in other upper division physics classes.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MAT 021D,  (MAT 022A or MAT 027A),  (MAT 022B or MAT 027B)),  (PHY 009D or PHY 009HD),  PHY 040,  PHY 104A (can be concurrent).

phy.name: —  Introductory Methods of Mathematical Physics
phy.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduction to the mathematics used in upper division physics courses, including applications of vector spaces, Fourier analysis, partial differential equations.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ((PHY 009B C- or better,  PHY 009C C- or better,  PHY 009D C- or better) or (PHY 009HB C- or better,  PHY 009HC C- or better,  PHY 009HD C- or better,  PHY 009HE C- or better)); (MAT 021D C- or better,  (MAT 022A C- or better or MAT 027A C- or better),  (MAT 022B C- or better or MAT 027B C- or better)); or consent of instructor.

phy.name: — Computational Methods of Mathematical Physics
phy.description: Course Description: Introduction to the use of computational techniques to solve the mathematical problems that arise in advanced physics courses, complementing the analytical approaches emphasized in PHY 104A.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 104A C- or better; PHY 105AL; or consent of instructor.

phy.name: — Intermediate Methods of Mathematical Physics
phy.description: Course Description: Applications of complex analysis, conditional probability, integral transformations and other advanced topics.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 104A C- or better; or consent of instructor.

phy.name: — Analytical Mechanics
phy.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Principles and applications of Newtonian mechanics; introduction to Lagrange’s and Hamilton’s equations.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PHY 009B C or better,  PHY 009C C or better,  PHY 009D C or better) or (PHY 009HB C or better,  PHY 009HC C or better,  PHY 009HD C or better,  PHY 009HE C or better); (MAT 021D C or better,  (MAT 022A C or better or MAT 027A C or better),  (MAT 022B C or better or MAT 027B C or better)); or consent of instructor.

phy.name: — Analytical Mechanics
phy.description: Course Description: Principles and applications of Newtonian mechanics; introduction to Lagrange’s and Hamilton’s equations.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 104A C or better; PHY 105A C or better; or consent of department for any of the courses.

phy.name: — Continuum Mechanics
phy.description: Course Description: The continuum hypothesis and limitations, tensors, isotropic constitutive equations, and wave propagation. Applications such as elastic solids,heat flow, aerodynamics, and ocean waves.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 104A C- or better; PHY 105A C- or better; or consent of instructor.

phy.name: — Optics
phy.description: Course Description: The phenomena of diffraction, interference, and polarization of light, with applications to current problems in astrophysics, material science, and atmospheric science. Study of modern optical instrumentation. Open to non-majors.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ((PHY 009A,  PHY 009B,  PHY 009C,  PHY 009D) or (PHY 007A,  PHY 007B,  PHY 007C) or (PHY 009HA,  PHY 009HB,  PHY 009HC,  PHY 009HD,  PHY 009HE)); (MAT 021A,  MAT 021B,  MAT 021C,  MAT 021D); or consent of instructor.

phy.name: — Optics Laboratory
phy.description: Course Description: The laboratory will consist of one major project pursued throughout the quarter, based on modern applications of optical techniques.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 108 (can be concurrent); PHY 108 required concurrently.

phy.name: — Electricity & Magnetism
phy.description: Course Description: Theory of electrostatics, electromagnetism, Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic waves.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PHY 009B C- or better,  PHY 009C C- or better,  PHY 009D C- or better) or (PHY 009HB C- or better,  PHY 009HC C- or better,  PHY 009HD C- or better,  PHY 009HE C- or better); MAT 021D C- or better; (MAT 022A C- or better or MAT 027A C- or better); (MAT 022B C- or better or MAT 027B C- or better); PHY 104A; PHY 105A; or consent of department.

phy.name: — Electricity & Magnetism
phy.description: Course Description: Theory of electrostatics, electromagnetism, Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic waves.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 110A C- or better; PHY 104A C- or better; or consent of department.

phy.name: — Electricity & Magnetism
phy.description: Course Description: Theory of electrostatics, electromagnetism, Maxwell's equations, electromagnetic waves.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 110B C- or better; or consent of department.

phy.name: — Computational Physics Lab for Electricity & Magnetism
phy.description: Course Description: Applications of computational physics to problems from electricity and magnetism.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 045 or ECS 036B; PHY 110B (can be concurrent).

phy.name: — Thermodynamics & Statistical Mechanics
phy.description: Course Description: Introduction to classical and quantum statistical mechanics and their connections with thermodynamics. Theory is developed for the ideal gas model and simple magnetic models and then extended to studies of solids, quantum fluids, and chemical equilibria.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 115A; or the equivalent.

phy.name: — Computational Physics Lab for Statistical Mechanics
phy.description: Course Description: Applications of computational physics to problems from statistical mechanics.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 045 or ECS 036B; PHY 112 (can be concurrent).

phy.name: — Foundation of Quantum Mechanics
phy.description: Course Description: Introduction to the methods of quantum mechanics with applications to atomic, molecular, solid state, nuclear and elementary particle physics. Extensive problem solving.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 104A C- or better; PHY 105A C- or better; or consent of department.

phy.name: — Applications of Quantum Mechanics
phy.description: Course Description: Angular momentum and spin; hydrogen atom and atomic spectra; perturbation theory; scattering theory.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 115A C- or better; or consent of department.

phy.name: — Computational Physics Lab for Quantum Mechanics
phy.description: Course Description: Applications of computational physics to problems from Classical and Quantum Mechanics.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 045 or ECS 036B; PHY 115A.

phy.name: — Electronic Instrumentation
phy.description: Course Description: Experimental and theoretical study of important analog electronic circuits. Linear circuits, transmission lines, input impedance, feedback, amplifiers, oscillators, noise.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PHY 009C or PHY 009HD); (MAT 022B or MAT 027B); or consent of instructor.

phy.name: — Electronic Instrumentation
phy.description: Course Description: Continuation of PHY 116A. Introduction to the use of digital electronics and microcomputers in experimental physics. Nonlinear electronics, integrated circuits, analog-to-digital and digital-to-analog converters, transducers, actuators.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 009C or PHY 009HD; or consent of instructor.

phy.name: — Introduction to Computer-Based Experiments in Physics
phy.description: Course Description: Introduction to techniques for making physical measurements using computer-based instrumentation.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PHY 009D or PHY 009HD); PHY 116B; MAT 022B; or consent of instructor.

phy.name: — Physics Instrumentation with Analog & Digital Electronics
phy.description: Course Description: Experimental and theoretical study of important electronic circuits involving analog and digital components. Feedback, amplifiers, oscillators, noise, integrated circuits, digital logic, timers, analog-to-digital and digital-to-analog converters.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 080.

phy.name: — Physics Instrumentation for Data Acquisition
phy.description: Course Description: Experimental application of modern high-density integrated circuits. Automated data acquisition, microprocessors, field programmable gate arrays.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 080; PHY 045 or ECS 036B.

phy.name: — Advanced Laboratory in Condensed Matter Physics
phy.description: Course Description: Experimental techniques and measurements in solid-state physics. Three-six experiments performed depending on difficulty. Individual work is stressed. Thorough write-ups of the experiments are required.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 104A; PHY 105A; PHY 110B; PHY 115A; PHY 112 (can be concurrent); PHY 080; or consent of the department.

phy.name: — Advanced Laboratory in Particle Physics
phy.description: Course Description: Experimental techniques and measurements in nuclear and particle physics. Students perform three to six experiments depending on difficulty. Individual work is stressed. Thorough write-ups of the experiments are required.
phy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PHY 104A; PHY 105A; PHY 110B; PHY 115A; PHY 112 (can be concurrent); PHY 080; or consent of the department.

phy.name: — Signals & Noise in Physics
phy.description: Course Description: Techniques of measurement and analysis designed to avoid systematic error and maximize signal/noise ratio. Illustrative examples of optimal filters ranging from condensed matter to cosmology.
