Development on the following writing skills: analytical, argumentative, and creative.

por.name: — Directed Group Study
por.description: Course Description: Directed group study primarily for lower division students.
por.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor and department chairperson.

por.name: — Principles of Luso-Brazilian Literature & Criticism
por.description: Course Description: Principles of literary criticism applied to the study of fiction, poetry, and essays of major literary writers of the Luso-Brazilian world.
por.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POR 022 or POR 023; or consent of instructor.

por.name: — Structure of Portuguese: Sounds & Words
por.description: Course Description: Linguistic description of sound patterns of Portuguese and how those sounds can be used to form larger units, such as morphemes and words. Theoretical and practical comparisons with English and with other Romance languages.

por.name: — Survey of Luso-Brazilian Literature: 1500-1800
por.description: Course Description: Overview of Luso-Brazilian literature, covering three major literary periods: Renaissance, Baroque, and Enlightenment. Attention to the concept of imitation and nativism.

por.name: — Portuguese Literature: Medieval & Renaissance
por.description: Course Description: Overview of the origins of the Portuguese literature, spanning from the 13th century to the 16th century. Studies of lyrical and epic poetry, drama, and travel narratives.
por.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POR 100; or consent of instructor.

por.name: — Luis de Camões
por.description: Course Description: Overview of the greatest Renaissance Portuguese poet, Luis de Camões. Study his famous epic poem, Os Lusiadas, and a series of sonnets written by him.

por.name: — Introduction to Luso-Brazilian Culture
por.description: Course Description: Introduction to history, geography, and culture of Portugal and Brazil. Art, history of ideas, and everyday cultural manifestations. Introduction to critical reading and textual analysis. Taught in Portuguese.

por.name: — Special Topics in Luso-Brazilian Literature & Culture
por.description: Course Description: Special topics in the study of Luso-Brazilian literature and culture.
por.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POR 100; or consent of instructor.

por.name: — Luso-Brazilian Literature & Culture
por.description: Course Description: Colonial Brazilian literature survey. Readings include 16th-18th centuries manuscripts and books of cultural importance in a society dominated by censorship and with no printing presses. Study of the role literary Academies played in the so called "culture of manuscripts."
por.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POR 100; or consent of instructor.

por.name: — Introduction  to Brazilian Literature
por.description: Course Description: Narrative and poetic texts of the 19th and 20th centuries in Brazil. In-depth and comparative study of Romantic and (Neo)Naturalist movements as a forum for discussion about literary tradition and modernity in Latin America.

por.name: — 20th C Masters in Brazilian Literature
por.description: Course Description: Overview of modern Brazilian literature from early 20th C to the poetry by João Cabral de Melo Neto and the Concretists (1960s), including European avant-garde movements and literary and cultural manifestos leading to a revolutionary body of literature.
por.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): POR 100; or consent of instructor.

por.name: — Tutoring in Portuguese
por.description: Course Description: Tutoring in undergraduate courses, including leadership in small voluntary discussion groups affiliated with departmental courses.

por.name: — Directed Group Study
por.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
por.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor and Department Chairperson.

por.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
por.description: Course Description: Independent study with professor for advanced undergraduate students, or honor thesis students.

acc.name: — Financial Reporting
acc.description: Course Description: Coverage includes the fundamentals of accounting and reporting economic events and transactions. Emphasizes the preparation of balance sheets, income statements, statements of cash flow, and statements of stockholders’ equity.

acc.name: — Intermediate Financial Reporting
acc.description: Course Description: Focuses on the preparation of complex financial statements. Topics include accounting recognition, measurement, and disclosure, as well as the theoretical foundations of and motivations for financial reporting choices.
acc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ACC 201 or (MGB 200A or MGP 200A or MGT 200A).

acc.name: — Advanced Financial Reporting
acc.description: Course Description: Advanced treatment of recognition, measurement, and disclosure including pensions, accounting for income taxes, mergers and acquisitions, consolidations, special-purpose entities, and foreign subsidiaries. Includes accounting for governmental and nonprofit entities, as well as advanced treatment of international accounting standards.

acc.name: — Tax Reporting & Analysis
acc.description: Course Description: Introduction to the taxation of business entities and their related transactions, with an emphasis on the details of tax law and tax reporting requirements. Topics include individual, partnership, and corporate taxation, as well as tax theory.

acc.name: — Intermediate Tax Reporting & Analysis
acc.description: Course Description: Detailed analysis of federal taxation of individuals. Topics include the timing of income recognition, deductions and credits for tax purposes, as well as the basics of property transactions.
acc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ACC 211; (MGB 264 or MGP 264 or MGT 264).

acc.name: — Advanced Tax Reporting & Analysis
acc.description: Course Description: Advanced treatment of complex tax transactions and entities. Topics include aspects of federal taxation of entities and the applicable impact upon individual taxpayers. Coverage includes basis analysis as applicable to pass through entities and an introduction to professional responsibilities.

acc.name: — Taxation of Individuals, Property, & Estates
acc.description: Course Description: In-depth analysis of individual income tax issues and property transactions including non-taxable exchanges, compensation, gifts, and transfer taxes. Expanded analysis of multistate tax issues. Emphasis is on the interrelationships of complex individual transactions as well as planning techniques.

acc.name: — Taxation of Business Entities
acc.description: Course Description: Analysis of detailed business entity tax issues including basis calculations, alternative minimum taxation, multistate and multinational taxation, stock transactions, and mergers and acquisitions. Tax planning for entities and relationships between business entities and their owners.

acc.name: — Analysis & Use of Accounting Reports
acc.description: Course Description: Evaluation of complex financial accounting reports by managers and persons outside the firm, such as investors, creditors, and financial analysts. Topics include cash flow vs. income measurement, ratio and valuation analysis, and the effects of international accounting standards.

acc.name: — Auditing & the Accounting Profession
acc.description: Course Description: Introduction to the audit environment, professional standards, the accounting profession, and the professional responsibilities of accountants. Integrate audit topics across the areas of financial, cost, tax and systems accounting.
acc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ACC 201; (MGB 200A or MGP 200A or MGT 200A).

acc.name: — Auditing & Attestation Services
acc.description: Course Description: Advanced treatment of the audit process and environment. Topics include audit planning and performance, evidence, internal controls, professional standards, and audit reports. Reviews, compilations and attestation services are examined, as are governmental agency audits.

acc.name: — Managerial Accounting & Controls
acc.description: Course Description: Analysis of management accounting systems including cost accounting, performance measurement, and compensation and reward systems. Focuses on the production of information useful for managerial decision-making, as well as the design of these systems.
acc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ACC 201; (MGT 200A or MGP 200A or MGB 200A).

acc.name: — Accounting Information & Control Systems
acc.description: Course Description: Analysis of information systems used for accounting, recordkeeping, and control. Topics include the regulatory requirements of accounting control systems as well as their implementation and auditing considerations.
acc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ACC 201; (MGT 200A or MGP 200A or MGB 200A).

acc.name: — Communications for Professional Accountants
acc.description: Course Description: Overview of written and oral professional communications with an emphasis on structuring and documenting audits and reports, understanding audiences (investors, creditors, regulators, and other stakeholders), and consideration of ethical and regulatory responsibilities.
acc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ACC 201; (MGT 200A or MGB 200A or MGP 200A).

acc.name: — Accounting Ethics
acc.description: Course Description: Analysis of accountants' professional responsibilities and ethics. Topics include the behavioral foundations of ethics in a business environment, how those elements affect accountants' integrity, objectivity, and independence. Professional standards related to accountants' conduct are also covered.
acc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ACC 201; (MGT 200A or MGP 200A or MGB 200A).

acc.name: — Audit Data Analytics
acc.description: Course Description: Analytical techniques and methods as related to the practice of financial statement auditing. Combines theory and the application of auditing professional standards including diagnosing problems and issues, analyzing relevant information, and reporting decision results and recommendations.

acc.name: — Topics in Accounting
acc.description: Course Description: Contemporary and emerging issues in financial management accounting. Application of modern techniques of evaluation and analysis of financial information. Use of appropriate electronic database and research techniques.

psy.name: — Willow Clinic
psy.description: Course Description: Student run clinic for undergraduate students interested in learning about and meeting the unique health care needs for the homeless population.

psy.name: — Willow Clinic
psy.description: Course Description: Student run clinic for upper division students interested in learning about and meeting the unique health care needs for the homeless population.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. UC Davis enrollment; upper division standing.

psy.name: — Directed Group Study
psy.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; advanced standing.

psy.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
psy.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; advanced standing.

psy.name: — Directed Group Study for Graduate Students
psy.description: Course Description: Directed group study for graduate students.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

psy.name: — Special Study for Graduate Students
psy.description: Course Description: Special study for graduate students.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

psy.name: — Fundamentals of Clinical Psychiatry
psy.description: Course Description: Psychiatric interviewing, Mental Status Exam and diagnosis. Major child and adult disorders, including substance abuse and dependence. Weekly student interviews of psychiatric patients in small group format.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval of SOM Committee on Student Progress.

psy.name: — Klingenstein Summer Elective
psy.description: Course Description: During this "mini-clerkship," fellows will attend clinics, in-patient settings, and clinicians' offices. They will meet weekly to present cases and review current literature, and will complete a summary narrative at the end of their experience.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

psy.name: — Klingenstein Longitudinal Elective
psy.description: Course Description: Year-long mentoring program provides clinical exposure to child and adolescent psychiatric healthcare during a medical student's pre-clinical years.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

psy.name: — Psychiatry Grand Rounds
psy.description: Course Description: Weekly conference at UCDMC for presentation of selected clinical cases, presentation of lecture and research reports.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical students or staff or other qualified mental health professionals with consent of instructor.

psy.name: — Outpatient Psychiatry Clerkship
psy.description: Course Description: Experience in clinical management/treatment of adult outpatients with psychiatric and substance abuse disorders; crisis management/intervention, evaluation/development of diagnosis and treatment plan; emphasis on outpatient psychopharmacology/brief psychotherapy; observation of group therapy. Individual supervision by faculty/residents.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSY 430; and/or consent of coordinator.

psy.name: — Psychosomatic Medicine Clerkship
psy.description: Course Description: A large university hospital service in which the student functions as a member of the team in evaluation, management and psychiatric liaison with other medical specialties. Intensive supervision from senior staff and psychiatric residents.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Psychiatry Clerkship or consent of instructor; medical students only.

psy.name: — Telemedicine Clinical Elective
psy.description: Course Description: Fourth-year medical student elective in Telemedicine focusing on psychiatric issues. Align with University, School and Center for Health and Technology mission of rural outreach and public health, particularly in primary care.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Fourth-year medical student with consent of instructor.

psy.name: — Child Psychiatry Clerkship
psy.description: Course Description: Didactic and clinical inpatient, outpatient, and consultation-liaison experiences with children, adolescents and families. Clinical observations, diagnostic assessment, and treatment will be undertaken with close supervision. Literature review and case conferences presented on a regular basis.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSY 430; and/or consent of coordinator.

psy.name: — Jail Psychiatric Clerkship
psy.description: Course Description: Gain experience, under close faculty supervision, assessing acute and chronic mentally ill inmates in both inpatient and clinic settings.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSY 430; and/or consent of course coordinator.

psy.name: — Off-Campus Clinical Experience
psy.description: Course Description: Clinical or research elective in off-campus medical school or mental health setting. To be arranged with advance approval of instructor and individual in charge of off-campus setting.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical students.

psy.name: — Combined Family Medicine-Psychiatry Clerkship
psy.description: Course Description: Students rotate through the county Primary Care Clinic under the supervision of dual-boarded Psychiatry and Family Practice Faculty to provide medical care of indigent and uninsured patients as well as primary care for psychiatry patients.

psy.name: — Acting Internship in Psychiatry
psy.description: Course Description: Acting intern position with close faculty supervision with emphasis on biological psychiatry, psychopharmacology and psychodynamic aspects appropriate to diagnostic and long-term patient management.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSY 430; and/or consent of course coordinator.

psy.name: — Combined Internal Medicine-Psychiatry Clerkship
psy.description: Course Description: Students rotate through the county Primary Care Clinic under the supervision of dual-boarded Psychiatry and Internal Medicine Faculty to provide medical care of indigent and uninsured patients as well as primary care for psychiatry patients.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Psychiatry Clerkship or consent of instructor; medical students only.

psy.name: — Readings in Psychiatry
psy.description: Course Description: Independent reading of a selected topic in psychiatry. Supervision and discussion with a psychiatry faculty member.

psy.name: — Willow Clinic
psy.description: Course Description: Student-run clinic for medical students interested in learning about and meeting the unique healthcare needs of the homeless population.

psy.name: — Functional Genomics
psy.description: Course Description: The theory, methods and principles of functional neurogenomics with emphasis on the relationship to molecular mechanisms involved in development and disease of the nervous system.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

psy.name: — Psychiatry Clinical Clerkship
psy.description: Course Description: Assigned to clinical settings, students build upon the skills gained in preclinical years; emphasis on diagnostic, therapeutic and interpersonal skills. Areas of focus; patient management, interviewing skills, mental status exam, differential diagnosis, basic psychopharmacology, crisis assessment, intervention and case.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

psy.name: — SJVP Longitudinal Psychiatry Clerkship
psy.description: Course Description: Longitudinal Clerkship runs concurrently with Family Medicine, Pediatrics and Internal Medicine for 32 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

psy.name: — SJVP Longitudinal Psychiatry Clerkship
psy.description: Course Description: Longitudinal Clerkship runs concurrently with Family Medicine, Pediatrics and Internal Medicine for 32 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

psy.name: — SJVP Longitudinal Psychiatry Clerkship
psy.description: Course Description: Longitudinal Clerkship runs concurrently with Family Medicine, Pediatrics and Internal Medicine for 32 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

psy.name: — SJVP Longitudinal Psychiatry Clerkship
psy.description: Course Description: Longitudinal Clerkship runs concurrently with Family Medicine, Pediatrics and Internal Medicine for 32 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

psy.name: — Rural PRIME Psychiatry Longitudinal Clerkship
psy.description: Course Description: Psychiatry Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.

psy.name: — Rural PRIME Psychiatry Longitudinal Clerkship
psy.description: Course Description: Psychiatry Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

psy.name: — Rural PRIME Psychiatry Longitudinal Clerkship
psy.description: Course Description: Psychiatry Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

psy.name: — Rural PRIME Psychiatry Longitudinal Clerkship
psy.description: Course Description: Psychiatry Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

psy.name: — Rural PRIME Psychiatry Longitudinal Clerkship
psy.description: Course Description: Psychiatry Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

psy.name: — TeachMS Longitudinal Psychiatry Clerkship (A)
psy.description: Course Description: Longitudinal Clerkship runs concurrently with Primary Care and Medicine for 24 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty. On-going patient write-ups, rounds, conferences are required.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Promotions.

psy.name: — TeachMS Longitudinal Psychiatry Clerkship (B)
psy.description: Course Description: Longitudinal Clerkship runs concurrently with Primary Care and Medicine for 24 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty. On-going patient write-ups, rounds, conferences are required.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Promotions.

psy.name: — TeachMS Longitudinal Psychiatry Clerkship (C)
psy.description: Course Description: Longitudinal Clerkship runs concurrently with Primary Care and Medicine for 24 weeks. Time is spent in direct patient care situations under the guidance of faculty. On-going patient write-ups, rounds, conferences are required.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Promotions.

psy.name: — Directed Clinical Studies in Psychiatry
psy.description: Course Description: Individual directed studies in extended preparation for modified curriculum or to complete a clinical rotation following a leave of absence.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

psy.name: — Directed Studies in Psychiatry
psy.description: Course Description: Individual directed studies in extended preparation for remediation of all or part of clinical rotation. Clinical studies to accommodate and satisfy remedial work as directed by the Committee on Student Progress and approved by the course IOR.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

psy.name: — Insights in Psychiatry
psy.description: Course Description: On individual basis, student provided with an opportunity for gaining insight into various clinical activities in the practice of psychiatry.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; first- or second-year medical student in good academic standing.

psy.name: — Acting Internship in Inpatient Psychiatry, Away Rotation
psy.description: Course Description: Inpatient acting internship at approved non-UCDHS affiliated training program that provides experience and preparation for ambulatory medical care. Students perform as an intern, with a smaller number of patients, greater supervision, and responsibility for the ongoing care of assigned patients.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Psychiatry Clerkship and/or consent of course coordinator.

psy.name: — Acting Internship in Ambulatory Psychiatry, Away Rotation
psy.description: Course Description: Outpatient acting internship at an approved non-UCDHS affiliated training program that provides experience and preparation for ambulatory medical care. Students perform as an intern, with smaller number of patients, greater supervision, and responsibility for the ongoing care of assigned patients.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Psychiatry Clerkship and/or consent of course coordinator.

psy.name: — Social Justice & Medicine
psy.description: Course Description: Employ readings, videos and guest presentations to explore how historical injustices have resulted in structural inequities and barriers to wellbeing for marginalized communities. Looks at how socio-political, economic and historical forces create illness in specific groups, and how models of structural competency and cultural humility can be used to explore a path towards equity.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

psy.name: — Directed Group Study
psy.description: Course Description: Approved for graduate degree credit. Medical students desiring to explore particular topics in depth.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

psy.name: — Research
psy.description: Course Description: Approved for graduate degree credit. Individual research on selected topics or research projects.
psy.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

psc.name: — General Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Principles and basic concepts of psychology. The empirical study of individual behavior including perception, cognition, development, personality, social interactions and the biological underpinnings of behavior.

psc.name: — General Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Introduction to empirical approaches. Focus on perception, cognition, personality and social psychology, and biological aspects of behavior.

psc.name: — Data Visualization in the Social Sciences
psc.description: Course Description: Introduction to quantitative data across the social sciences (Communications, Political Science, Psychology, Sociology, and other disciplines). Transforming data, describing data, producing graphs, visual reasoning, and interpretations.

psc.name: — Freshman Psychology Seminar
psc.description: Course Description: Instructor will acquaint students with his or her program of research, the development of scientific questions from the literature, and the application of research methods to examine these questions. Critical thinking will be encouraged via expository writing and brief presentations.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Freshman standing.

psc.name: — Research Methods in Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Introduction to experimental design, interviews, questionnaires, field and observational methods, reliability, and statistical inference.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 012Y, STA 013, or STA 100 strongly recommended.

psc.name: — Mindreading: Understanding Other Minds
psc.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Psychological perspectives on the process of understanding other people’s minds. Integration of social-cognitive theories with empirical evidence to explore the human ability to make sense of others' thoughts, feelings, and behaviors.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 001; (SOC 001 or PHI 010).

psc.name: — Lower Division Seminar
psc.description: Course Description: Examination of a special topic in Psychology through shared readings, discussions, written assignments, or special activities such as fieldwork or laboratory work.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

psc.name: — Directed Group Study
psc.description: Course Description: Primarily for lower division students.

psc.name: — Special Study for Lower Division Students
psc.description: Course Description: Special study for lower division students.

psc.name: — Introduction to Cognitive Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Introduction to human information processing, mental representation and transformation, imagery, attention, memory, language processing, concept formation, problem solving, and computer simulation.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041.

psc.name: — Introduction to Cognitive Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Introduction to human information processing, mental representation and transformation, imagery, attention, memory, language processing, concept formation, problem solving, and computer simulation.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041.

psc.name: — Introduction to Biological Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Survey and integration of the relationships between behavior and biological processes, including physiology, genes, development, ecology, and evolution. May be taught abroad.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041.

psc.name: — Statistical Analysis of Psychological Data
psc.description: Course Description: Design and statistical analysis of psychological investigations and the interpretation of quantitative data in psychology.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041; (STA 013 or STA 013Y or STA 102).

psc.name: — Statistical Analysis of Psychological Data
psc.description: Course Description: Probability theory, sampling distributions, statistical inference, and hypothesis testing using standard parametric and correlational approaches. Simple regression analysis, multiple regression analysis, non-parametric statistics, introduction to multivariate statistics, with applications in psychology.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 103A; (STA 013 or STA 013Y or STA 102).

psc.name: — Applied Psychometrics: An Introduction to Measurement Theory
psc.description: Course Description: Examination of the basic principles and applications of classical and modern test theory. Topics include test construction, reliability theory, validity theory, factor analysis and latent trait theory.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 041; PSC 103A; (STA 013 or STA 013Y); upper division standing in Psychology.

psc.name: — Questionnaire & Survey Research Methods
psc.description: Course Description: Introduction to survey and questionnaire research methods with emphasis on how to ask questions. Social and psychological factors that influence survey response. Practical aspects of fielding survey and questionnaire research.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 001 or PSC 001Y; and consent of instructor; PSC 041 or an equivalent course on social or behavioral research methods or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Developmental Psychobiology
psc.description: Course Description: The biology of behavioral development; survey and integration of the organismic and environmental processes that regulate the development of behavior.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 101.

psc.name: — Agent-Based Modeling
psc.description: Course Description: Introduction to agent-based computer simulation and analysis with emphasis on learning how to model animals, including humans, to achieve insight into social and group behavior.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 100 and/or PSC 101 recommended.

psc.name: — Physiological Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Relationship of brain structure and function to behavior, motivation, emotion, language, and learning in humans and other animals. An introduction to the methodology of physiological psychology and neuroscience.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041; PSC 101.

psc.name: — Advanced Animal Behavior
psc.description: Course Description: Advanced integrative survey of biological principles of behavioral organization, emphasizing historical roots, current research directions, conceptual issues and controversies. Laboratory exercises on the description and analysis of the behavior of captive and free-living animals
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 101 or NPB 102.

psc.name: — Hormones & Behavior
psc.description: Course Description: Endocrine physiology with an emphasis on the principles of behavior. Fundamental relationships between hormones and various behaviors engaged in by the organism during its lifetime. Role of hormones in behavioral homeostasis, social behavior, reproductive behavior, parental behavior, adaptation to stress.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 101; (PSC 101 or NPB 102).

psc.name: — Comparative Neuroanatomy
psc.description: Course Description: Overview of the neuroanatomy in mammalian vertebrates, focusing on the cerebral cortex and experimental techniques. Examine changes or modifications to neural structures as a result of morphological or behavioral specializations.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NPB 100 or NPB 101 or NPB 110B or PSC 121.

psc.name: — Comparative Neuroanatomy Laboratory
psc.description: Course Description: Comparative neuroanatomy laboratory illustrating modern neuroanatomical techniques in determining neural connections within the mammalian brain. Includes experimentation and presentation of results.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 124 (can be concurrent).

psc.name: — Behavioral Epigenetics
psc.description: Course Description: Review of basic principles in genetics and epigenetics with emphasis on behavior. Introduction to the use of modern molecular methods in understanding the complex relationships between genes, environment, and behavior.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 101.

psc.name: — Health Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Psychological factors influencing health and illness. Topics include stress and coping, personality and health, symptom perception and reporting, heart disease, cancer, compliance, and health maintenance and promotion.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041; PSC 101 recommended.

psc.name: — Human Learning & Memory
psc.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Consideration of major theories of human learning and memory with critical examination of relevant experimental data.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041; (PSC 012Y or STA 013 or STA 100); or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Perception
psc.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Cognitive organizations related to measurable physical energy changes mediated through sensory channels. Perception of objects, space, motion, events.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041; (PSC 100 or PSC 135).

psc.name: — Language & Cognition
psc.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduction to the cognitive processes involved in language comprehension and production. Topics include the biological foundations of language, speech perception, word recognition, syntax, reading ability, and pragmatics.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041; (PSC 100 or PSC 135); or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Neuroeconomics/Reinforcement Learning & Decision Making
psc.description: Course Description: Theoretical and empirical approaches to neuroeconomics (neuroscience of decision making) from psychology, neuroscience, economics, and computer science. Neuroscience of judgment and decision making, behavioral economics, and reinforcement learning.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 100 or PSC 100Y or PSC 135 or ARE 100A or ECN 100A or NPB 162 or NPB 163); (STA 013 or STA 013Y or STA 100 or PSC 103A); or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Cognitive Neuroscience: The Biological Foundations of the Mind
psc.description: Course Description: Neuroscientific foundations of higher mental processes including attention, memory, language, higher-level perceptual and motor processes, and consciousness. Emphasis on the neural mechanisms which form the substrates of human cognition and the relationship of mind to brain. May be taught abroad.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041; or consent of instructor; PSC 101 or PSC 121 recommended.

psc.name: — Psychology of Music
psc.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Introduction to the mental and neural representations of musical structures and processes involved in perceiving, remembering, and performing music. Music and emotion.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041; (PSC 100 or PSC 135 or MUS 006C); or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Neurobiology of Learning & Memory
psc.description: Course Description: Overview of the neural basis of learning and memory focusing on modern behavioral  neuroscience research with animals. Topics include consolidation, neural plasticity, cellular competition for memory storage, and the role of neurogenesis in learning.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041; PSC 101.

psc.name: — Consciousness & Cognition
psc.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Current theoretical and empirical evidence in the study of cognition and consciousness. Theories of consciousness, psychological and neural basis of conscious and unconscious processes such as attention, intentionality, and dreams.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041; (PSC 100 or PSC 135).

psc.name: — Advanced Cognitive Neuroscience
psc.description: Course Description: Advanced integrative survey of cognitive neuroscience, including perception, attention, memory, and navigation. Emphasis on reviewing literature in psychology, neuroscience, and statistics; understanding methods in cognition; and presentation skills.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041; PSC 135; or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Developmental Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: An ontogenetic account of human behavior through adolescence with emphasis on motor skills, mental abilities, motivation, and social interaction.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041.

psc.name: — Developmental Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Ontogenetic account of human behavior through adolescence with emphasis on motor skills, mental abilities, motivation, and social interaction.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041.

psc.name: — Cognitive Development
psc.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Theories, methods, evidence, and debates in the field of cognitive development, such as nature/nurture, constraints on learning, and the role of plasticity. Topics include attention, memory, concepts about the physical and social world, and language.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 140 or HDE 100B or HDE 100A.

psc.name: — Social & Personality Development
psc.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Social and personality development of children, infancy through adolescence. Topics include the development of personality, achievement motivation, self-understanding, sex-role identity, and antisocial behavior. Emphasis on the interface between biological and social factors.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 140 or HDE 100A or HDE 100B.

psc.name: — Infant Development
psc.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Psychological development in infancy. Topics include physical and motor development, sensory and nervous system development, and memory and cognitive development. Emphasis will be  on evaluating theories, empirical research, and experimental methods for understanding infant development.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041; (PSC 140 or HDE 100A).

psc.name: — Developmental Cognitive Neuroscience
psc.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Neuroscientific theories and methods (EEG, ERP, fNIRS, fMRI) that inform an understanding of behavioral and cognitive development over infancy and childhood. Neurodevelopmental correlates of perception, action, language, and social cognition; value of the neuroscientific perspective; limitations and challenges of neuroscientific research in the developmental context.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 135 or ((PSC 140 or HDE 100A or HDE 100B); (PSC 101 or PSC 121 or NPB 161 or HDE 163)); PSC 141 recommended.

psc.name: — The Development of Memory
psc.description: Course Description: Theory and research on memory development with focus on infancy and childhood.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041; and any Psychology upper division course from Core Group A or D.

psc.name: — Developmental Disorders
psc.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Current scientific knowledge of the influences of biological, cognitive, and environmental factors on the emergence of disorders with onset in childhood. Examples include autism spectrum, ADD/ADHD, dyslexia and dyscalculia. Emphasis placed on understanding these disorders, their causes and their treatments.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041; (PSC 140 or PSC 141 or HDE 100A or HDE 100B).

psc.name: — Relationship Science: Lust, Love, & Evolution
psc.description: Course Description: Evolutionary perspectives on attraction and close relationships. Integrating social psychological and evolutionary theories with empirical evidence pertaining to human mating.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 001 or PSC 001Y; PSC 041 recommended.

psc.name: — Social Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Behavior of the individual in the group. Examination of basic psychological processes in social situations, surveying various problems of social interaction: group tensions, norm-development, attitudes, values, public opinion, status.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 001 or PSC 001Y, PSC 041 recommended.

psc.name: — Social Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Behavior of the individual in the group. Examination of basic psychological processes in social situations, surveying various problems of social interaction: group tensions, norm-development, attitudes, values, public opinion, status.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 001 or PSC 001Y and PSC 041 recommended.

psc.name: — Social Cognition
psc.description: Course Description: Examines how social factors influence how we attend to, encode, and process information and how these mental processes affect subsequent judgments and behavior.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041.

psc.name: — Psychology & Law
psc.description: Course Description: Current theoretical and empirical issues in the study of psychology and law. Topics include eyewitness testimony, child abuse, jury decision making, juvenile delinquency and criminology, prediction of violence, insanity defense, and memory for traumatic events.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041.

psc.name: — Psychology of Emotion
psc.description: Course Description: Introduction to current theories and research on emotion and bodily feelings with special reference to self-knowledge.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041.

psc.name: — Stereotyping, Prejudice, & Stigma
psc.description: Course Description: Social psychological underpinnings of stereotyping, prejudice, and stigma from sociocultural, motivational, and cognitive perspectives. Topics include: origins, maintenance, change, effects on person perception and memory, and the automaticity/controllability of stereotyping and prejudice.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041.

psc.name: — Sexual Orientation & Prejudice
psc.description: Course Description: Current scientific knowledge about sexual orientation and prejudice based on sexual orientation. Emphasis is placed on learning the skills necessary for a critical understanding of science and public policy issues relevant to sexuality.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041.

psc.name: — Gender & Human Reproduction
psc.description: Course Description: Psychology of reproduction. Reproductive events over the course of an individual’s life, including sexual development, mate choice, relationships, and reproduction. Biological and social psychological explanations at the levels of mechanism and evolutionary function.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041.

psc.name: — Psychology of the Self
psc.description: Course Description: Psychological theory and research on the self. Topics include: self-knowledge, self-esteem, self-regulation, self-presentation, cognitive and emotional aspects of the self, and the role of the self in shaping social interaction.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041.

psc.name: — Introduction to Personality Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Scientific study of personality. Methods of personality research. Overview of current research and theory in the field of personality psychology. May be taught abroad.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041.

psc.name: — Introduction to Clinical Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Major theoretical formulations in the history of clinical psychology, from classical psychoanalysis to contemporary existentialism and behavior modification. Survey based on lectures, films, and tapes, of what clinical psychologists do, including methods of appraisal, professional roles, and approaches to treatment.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041.

psc.name: — Abnormal Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Descriptive and functional account of behavioral disorders, with primary consideration given to neurotic and psychotic behavior.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041.

psc.name: — The Science of Multi-Cultural Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Effects of culture and ethnicity on psychological processes, such as social cognition, emotion, motivation, personality, self-concept, and interpersonal behavior (i.e., how culture makes who you are). Individuals' construction of multicultural identity and experiences.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041.

psc.name: — Psychology of Religion
psc.description: Course Description: Major theories, issues, data, and research methodologies of the psychology of religion. Religious experience and expression; religious development in childhood, adolescence, and adulthood; conversion; religious influences on physical and mental health; cross-cultural perspectives.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041.

psc.name: — Genius, Creativity, & Leadership
psc.description: Course Description: Phenomenon of genius is examined from a diversity of theoretical, methodological, and disciplinary perspectives, with an emphasis on outstanding creativity and leadership in art, music, literature, philosophy, science, war, and politics.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041; or equivalents, or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Research in Cognitive & Perceptual Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Empirical research on selected topics in general experimental psychology (general research design and analysis, perception, cognition, cognitive development, etc.). Specific content will vary from quarter to quarter.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 041; four upper division Psychology courses and consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Research in Psychobiology
psc.description: Course Description: Empirical research on selected topics in psychobiology (animal learning, animal behavior, physiological and sensory psychology, developmental psychobiology, computer modeling of neural systems). Content varies.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 101; three additional upper division Psychology courses and consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Research in Personality & Social Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Empirical research on selected topics in personality and social psychology (personality, social psychology, organizational psychology, etc.). Content will vary from quarter to quarter.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 041; four upper division Psychology courses and consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Research in Developmental Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Empirical research on selected topics in developmental psychology (research design and analysis, development, cognitive development, social and personality development etc.).
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 041; consent of instructor; Four upper division Psychology courses.

psc.name: — Methods in Laboratory Research
psc.description: Course Description: Training in specific lab-based research methods coupled with hands-on experience in a research lab. Students assessed on their ability report and interpret research findings. Content varies from quarter to quarter.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

psc.name: — History of Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Development of psychological thought and research in context of history of philosophy and science.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (PSC 001 or PSC 001Y); PSC 041; upper division standing or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Seminar in Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Intensive treatment of a special topic or problem of psychological interest.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Junior or senior standing; major in Psychology or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Upper Division Seminar
psc.description: Course Description: In-depth examination at an upper division level of a special topic in Psychology. Emphasis on student participation in learning. May not be repeated for credit.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

psc.name: — Fieldwork in Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Supervised internship off and on campus, in community and institutional settings. Maximum of 6 units may be used towards satisfaction of upper division major requirement.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing in Psychology.

psc.name: — Special Study for Honors Students
psc.description: Course Description: Directed research. Supervised reading, research and writing leading to submission of a Senior Honors thesis under the direction of faculty sponsor.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; senior standing in Psychology and qualifications for admission into college honors program; at least one course from PSC 180A, PSC 180B, PSC 180C or PSC 199 strongly recommended.

psc.name: — Special Study for Honors Students
psc.description: Course Description: Directed research. Supervised reading, research and writing leading to submission of a Senior Honors thesis under the direction of faculty sponsor.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 194HA; consent of instructor; senior standing in Psychology and qualifications for admission into college honors program; completion of PSC 194HA required.

psc.name: — Tutoring in Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Intended for advanced undergraduate students who will lead discussion sections in Psychology courses.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

psc.name: — Directed Group Study
psc.description: Course Description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
psc.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

psc.name: — Proseminar in Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Introduces matriculating graduate students to research activities of departmental faculty.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Research Preceptorship
psc.description: Course Description: Research preceptorship.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Research Seminar
psc.description: Course Description: Presentation of graduate research to program faculty and graduate students.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Psychology.

psc.name: — Statistical Analysis of Psychological Experiments
psc.description: Course Description: Probability theory, sampling distributions, statistical inference, and hypothesis testing using standard parametric and correlational approaches. Analysis of variance, factorial and repeated measures, and tests of trends.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 102; or equivalent; graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Causal Modeling of Correlational Data
psc.description: Course Description: Examination of how to make causal inferences from correlational data in the behavioral sciences. Emphasis is on testing rival causal models using correlations among observed variables. Beginning with multiple regression analysis, discussion advances to path analysis and related techniques.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 204A; or the equivalent course and graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Advanced Statistical Inference from Psychological Experiments
psc.description: Course Description: Advanced topics in statistical inference, which may include probability theory, sampling distributions, statistical inference and hypothesis testing, nonparametric statistics, Bayesian approaches, and advanced issues in analysis of variance.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 204A; or the equivalent; graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Applied Multivariate Analysis of Psychological Data
psc.description: Course Description: Review of the major methods of multivariate data analysis for psychological data. Students will program statistical routines using a linear algebra-based computing language. Topics will include multivariate analysis of variance. discriminant analysis, canonical analysis factor analysis, and component analysis.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 204A; PSC 204B; PSC 204D; or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Factor Analysis
psc.description: Course Description: Theory and methods of factor analysis, including exploratory factor analysis, confirmatory factor analysis, and principal component analysis.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 204A; PSC 204B; or equivalent courses, or consent of instructor; graduate standing.

psc.name: — Structural Equation Modeling
psc.description: Course Description: Theory and methods of structural equation modeling, including path analysis, confirmatory factor analysis, multiple-group modeling and latent growth curve modeling.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 204A; PSC 204B; or equivalent courses, or consent of instructor; graduate standing.

psc.name: — Multilevel Models
psc.description: Course Description: Introduction to statistical techniques for the analysis of normal, hierarchically structured data, such as cross-sectional clustered data or repeated-measures data. Topics include hierarchical linear models, latent growth curve models, and how these methods handle unbalanced and/or missing data.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 204A; graduate standing or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Applied Psychometrics & Measurement Theory
psc.description: Course Description: Examination of the basic principles and applications of classical and modern test theory. Topics include test construction, reliability theory, validity theory, factor analysis, and latent trait theory.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 204A; graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Item Response Theory
psc.description: Course Description: Item response theory allows for the creation of precise measurement instruments in psychological testing. Review Classical Test Theory, and then cover basic IRT models through advanced applications.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 204A; or the equivalent; graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Applied Longitudinal Data Analysis
psc.description: Course Description: Modeling and understanding of intraindividual change and interindividual differences in change. Reviews conventional methods and introduces contemporary techniques for modeling intraindividual change.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 204A; graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Applied Bayesian Statistics for Social Scientists
psc.description: Course Description: Bayesian methodology and inference for social scientists. Basics of probability theory, Bayes' theorem, inference and model checking, discussion of common distributions, sampling approaches, Bayes factors for hypothesis testing and introduction to dedicated software.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 204B; or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Theoretical Foundations: Research Methods in Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Examines the philosophy and research practices underlying experimental psychology. Topics to be covered include philosophy of science/epistemology, research design, inference and bias in research, theory development, validity, the social context of research, and critical thinking about research.

psc.name: — Research Methods in Psychology: Applications in Social-Personality Research
psc.description: Course Description: Overview of the research designs, assessment methods, and statistical procedure used by social-personality psychologists. Focus on the practical issues that arise when using each method in specific research contexts.

psc.name: — Survey & Questionnaire Research Methods
psc.description: Course Description: Survey and questionnaire research methods with emphasis on how to ask questions. Cognitive, motivational, and social processes that influence how respondents answer questions; sampling techniques; Internet resources; practical aspects of fielding survey and questionnaire research.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of a course on social or behavioral research methods; graduate standing.

psc.name: — Physiological Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: A conceptual analysis of the contributions of neuroanatomy, neurophysiology and neurochemistry to an understanding of animal and human behavior.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Fundamentals of Human Electrophysiology
psc.description: Course Description: In-depth introduction and hands-on experience with the event-related potential (ERP) method in the study of attention, executive control, memory, language and social cognitive neuroscience.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Introduction to Programming: Matlab
psc.description: Course Description: The Matlab programming environment as a means of organizing, analyzing, and visualizing scientific data. Basic programming concepts such as variables, loops, conditional branching, and efficient programming techniques will be emphasized.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Fundamentals of Cognitive Neuroimaging
psc.description: Course Description: Introduction to empirical foundations and methodology of neuroimaging, emphasizing pragmatics of functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) to study cognition. Topics include MR physics, the relationship between neural activity and the BOLD response, experimental design, and analysis of fMRI data.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Basic knowledge of inferential statistics and experimental Psychology.

psc.name: — Advanced Topics in Neuroimaging
psc.description: Course Description: Critical presentation and discussion of the most influential advanced issues in neuroimaging, emphasizing fMRI design/analysis and the integration of fMRI with EEG/MEG.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 210; or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Developmental Psychology: Cognitive & Perceptual Development
psc.description: Course Description: Theories and empirical findings concerning human cognitive and perceptual development. Development of perception, memory, concepts (e.g., theory of mind, concepts about number), problem solving, and language from infancy to adolescence.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor; completion of an undergraduate or graduate course on developmental psychology or human development.

psc.name: — Developmental Psychology: Social, Emotional, & Personality Development
psc.description: Course Description: Theories and empirical findings concerning human social, emotional, and personality development. Development of emotions, moral reasoning and behavior, personality, self-concept, and social cognition from infancy to adolescence (may include adulthood).
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor; completion of an undergraduate or graduate course on developmental psychology or human development.

psc.name: — Behavioral Genetics
psc.description: Course Description: Review basic principles in genetics and select topics in molecular genetics with emphasis on behavior. Use of modern molecular methods to outline complex relationships between genes, environment, and behavior.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

psc.name: — Fundamentals of Animal Behavior
psc.description: Course Description: Survey of the phenomena and theory of animal behavior from the perspectives of multiple biological disciplines, including evolution, ecology, psychology, genetics, neurobiology, endocrinology, and animal science.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division undergraduate introduction to the biology of behavior, such as PSC 101, PSC 122, PSC 123, NPB 102, NPB 150, NPB 152, WFC 141, ENT 104, or ANS 105.

psc.name: — Fundamentals of Animal Behavior
psc.description: Course Description: Survey of the phenomena and theory of animal behavior from the  perspectives of multiple biological disciplines, including evolution, ecology, psychology, genetics, neurobiology, endocrinology, and animal science.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 209A; or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — History of Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: A lecture-seminar on the history of psychology and on the applicability of early psychological theory and research to contemporary investigations.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Academic Writing in Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Strategies for developing and honing academic writing skills and writing productivity, with a particular focus on how to write a clear and compelling empirical journal article in psychology.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Cognitive Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Analysis of the mental processes by which knowledge is acquired, manipulated, stored, retrieved and used.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Sensation & Perception
psc.description: Course Description: Analysis of the role of sensory processes and perception in experience and their effects on behavior.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Attitudes & Social Influence
psc.description: Course Description: Survey of theory and research in the field of attitudes and social influence. Topics include attitude definition and measurement, major theories of attitude formation and change, the relationship between attitudes and behavior, and recent directions and controversies.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Attraction & Close Relationships
psc.description: Course Description: Social psychological theory and research on attraction and close relationships, with a particular emphasis on romantic relationships. Covers attachment theory, interdependence theory, and evolutionary psychological perspectives.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Psychology, Sociology, Human Development, a related social science, or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Social Cognition
psc.description: Course Description: Processes underlying the perception, memory, and judgment of social stimuli, the effects of social and affective factors on cognition, and the interpersonal consequences of those processes. Topics include automaticity/control, motivated cognition, person perception, stereotyping, attitudes, and persuasion.

psc.name: — Stereotyping, Prejudice, & Stigma
psc.description: Course Description: Examines the social psychological underpinnings of stereotyping, prejudice, and stigma, including sociocultural, motivational, and cognitive factors.

psc.name: — Social Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Theory and research in social psychology.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Personality
psc.description: Course Description: Theory and research in human personality.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Topics in Genetic Correlates of Behavior
psc.description: Course Description: Theory and experiment in the genetic contributions to animal and human behavior.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Topics in Psychobiology
psc.description: Course Description: Critical study in a selected area of psychobiology.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Cognitive Neuroscience
psc.description: Course Description: Graduate core course for neuroscience. Neurobiological bases of higher mental function including attention, memory, language. One of three in three-quarter sequence.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate student standing in Psychology or Neuroscience or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Topics in Cognitive Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Selected topics in language processing, memory, perception, problem solving, and thinking, with an emphasis on the common underlying cognitive processes.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Topics in Psycholinguistics
psc.description: Course Description: Discussion of fundamental issues in the psychology of language.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Topics in Personality & Social Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Critical study of a selected area of personality or social psychology.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate student standing or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Core Concepts & Methods in Learning, Memory, & Plasticity
psc.description: Course Description: Core concepts and methods used in studies of learning, memory and plasticity. Behavioral paradigms and measurement approaches in human and animal studies of learning and plasticity, as well as a consideration of the functional, anatomical and neuronal mechanisms underlying brain plasticity.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate Standing or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Core Concepts & Methods in Learning, Memory, & Plasticity
psc.description: Course Description: Core concepts and detailed survey methods used in studies of learning, memory and plasticity, from the cellular and molecular level to the level of neural circuits. Areas of learning, memory, and plasticity research where recent progress has been made in linking across these levels of analysis.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 271A or NPB 271A or NSC 271A.

psc.name: — Translational Approaches to Learning, Memory, & Plasticity Disorders
psc.description: Course Description: Neurological disorders, the effect of these disorders on learning, memory and plasticity, approved therapeutic options and current research designed to improve understanding and treatment of these diseases: (i) the clinical presentation, diagnostic criteria, and existing therapies, (ii) mechanistic studies in humans and animal models, and (iii) molecular pathways involved in the disease and approaches for drug discovery.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 271B or NPB 271B or NSC 271B.

psc.name: — Topics in Developmental Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Selected topics in developmental psychology, including developmental  neuroscience, memory development, infancy, cognitive development, social development, child maltreatment, children and law, perceptual development, emotional development, children at risk, and adolescence, with emphasis on developmental processes and developmental theory.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Current Research in Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Contemporary theory and empirical research in specialized topics in psychology. Topics include developmental attachment, social neuroscience, mental health, emotion, sexual orientation and identity.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Current Research in Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Intensive examination of contemporary theory and empirical research on a specialized topic in psychology. Sample topics include developmental attachment, social neuroscience, culture and mental health, electrophysiology and cognitive neuroscience, emotion, implicit cognitive processes, sexual orientation and identity, and attention.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 289A; graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Seminar
psc.description: Course Description: Seminar devoted to a highly specific research topic in any area of basic psychology. Special topic selected for a quarter will vary depending on interests of instructor and students.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Psychology or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Group Study
psc.description: Course Description: Group study.

psc.name: — Research
psc.description: Course Description: Research.

psc.name: — Dissertation Research
psc.description: Course Description: Dissertation research.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

psc.name: — The Teaching of Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Methods and techniques of teaching undergraduate psychology. Integration of learning outcomes with effective evaluation. Practical experience in the application of pedagogical principles.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; advanced graduate standing in Psychology or a closely related discipline.

psc.name: — The Teaching of Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Methods and problems of teaching psychology at the undergraduate and graduate levels; curriculum design and evaluation. Practical experience in the preparation and presentation of material.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; advanced graduate standing in Psychology or a closely related discipline.

psc.name: — The Teaching of Psychology
psc.description: Course Description: Methods and problems of teaching psychology at the undergraduate and graduate levels; curriculum design and evaluation. Practical experience in the preparation and presentation of material.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; advanced graduate standing in Psychology or a closely related discipline.

psc.name: — Teaching of Psychology Practicum
psc.description: Course Description: Supervised teaching in undergraduate classrooms. Techniques for delivering content through lectures, discussions, or labs; course administration; communications; assessment of student learning; solving ethical problems; instructional technology.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PSC 390; or consent of instructor.

psc.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
psc.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.
psc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

sph.name: — Internship in Community Health
sph.description: Course Description: Students apply theory and concepts learned in the classroom through field work in a community health agency.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

sph.name: — Research in Community & International Health
sph.description: Course Description: Work with faculty member in areas of research interest, including but not limited to injury control, international health, health policy, occupational and environmental health, health promotion and wellness, women's health, and health demographics.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; undergraduate standing.

sph.name: — Introduction to Public Health
sph.description: Course Description: Provide basic concepts and controversies in public health, basic science of public health, social and behavioral factors in health and disease, environmental and occupational health issues, the relationship of public health to the medical care system and health care reform.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Undergraduate standing.

sph.name: — Introduction to Human Epidemiology
sph.description: Course Description: Practice of epidemiology as it relates to human populations. Content is fundamental to the Public Health minor and a required core course.

sph.name: — Introduction to Health Economics, Services, Policy, Administration & Management
sph.description: Course Description: American health care system and how public health leaders, administrators, and researchers can make effective contributions to the populations served.

sph.name: — Globalization & Health: Evidence & Policies
sph.description: Course Description: Provides an overview of the evidence on the multiple effects of globalization policies on health.

sph.name: — Intermediate Human Epidemiology
sph.description: Course Description: Principles of epidemiological methods including causal inference, sources of bias such as confounding, effect measure modification, screening, and interpreting statistical tests of significance. Ethics and history of epidemiology.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): NUT 113 C or better or GDB 101 C or better or SPH 102 C or better.

sph.name: — Foundations of Epidemiology
sph.description: Course Description: Foundations of epidemiology. Distribution and determinants of disease and injury in populations. Practice of epidemiology as it relates to human populations. Relationship of epidemiology to public health.

sph.name: — Introduction to Program Planning & Evaluation
sph.description: Course Description: Appropriate techniques of community assessment, planning strategies, data collection, data analysis & evidence-based decision-making.

sph.name: — History of Epidemiology in Public Health
sph.description: Course Description: Historic events in public health and the epidemiology that paved the way for disease control and prevention.

sph.name: — Evaluation & Research Methods in Public Health
sph.description: Course Description: Evaluation of programs for professionals in the healthcare, social science, economic and business fields. Evaluations to be conducted for both internal and external purposes.

sph.name: — Health Disparities in the U.S.
sph.description: Course Description: Introduction to the principles and practice of health disparities research.

sph.name: — Introduction to Health Informatics
sph.description: Course Description: Introduction to concepts of health informatics and the impacts of the field on healthcare, research and public health.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Health Informatics Systems
sph.description: Course Description: Health Informatics with a focus on Information Technology. Data gathering, manipulating, storing, retrieving, and classifying.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Data Organization & Visualization in Health Informatics
sph.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Approaches to organizing and representing health data with a focus on visualization. Components of health data, visualization tools, methods and users for decision-making and analysis.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Health Issues Confronting Asian Americans & Pacific Islanders
sph.description: Course Description: Health issues confronting Asian Americans & Pacific Islanders.

sph.name: — General Health Education & Prevention
sph.description: Course Description: Topics include addiction, substance abuse/prevention, nutrition, stress management, physical fitness, body image, reproductive anatomy & physiology, contraceptive options, safer sex, sexual health, healthy relationships, and other general wellness/health promotion topics. Practice in peer counseling and outreach presentations.

sph.name: — Campus Alcohol/Other Drug Abuse Prevention Program Peer Educator Training
sph.description: Course Description: Preparation for internship in campus and community substance abuse prevention and educational intervention. Addiction and other physiological responses to alcohol and other drugs. Harm-reduction strategies for individuals and target populations. Practice in peer counseling skills and outreach presentations to groups.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPH 160 (can be concurrent); and consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Health Advocates Peer Educator Training
sph.description: Course Description: Preparation for internship in campus and community health promotion and risk reduction. Nutrition, stress management, physical fitness, body image and disordered eating, skin cancer prevention, and other general wellness/health promotion topics.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPH 160 (can be concurrent); and consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Topics in Public Health
sph.description: Course Description: Seminar on key issues and current topics in public health.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Research Conference in Community & International Health
sph.description: Course Description: Weekly conference on research problems, progress, and techniques in Community and International Health. Critical discussion of recent journal articles.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Internship in Community Health Practice
sph.description: Course Description: The student, through fieldwork in a community health agency, learns to apply theory and concepts learned in the classroom.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Upper division and graduate students.

sph.name: — Study in Community & International Health
sph.description: Course Description: Study and experience for undergraduate students in any number of areas in community and international health.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; undergraduate standing.

sph.name: — Research in Community & International Health
sph.description: Course Description: Student will work with faculty member in areas of research interest, including but not limited to injury control, international health, health policy, occupational and environmental health, health promotion and wellness, women's health, and health demographics.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; undergraduate standing.
