sph.name: — Introduction to Public Health
sph.description: Course Description: Provides an overview of public health. Covers the history of public health in the U.S.; defines its major functions and constituencies; and, introduces fundamental principles of epidemiology, biostatistics, behavioral sciences, environmental health, infectious diseases, and reducing health disparities.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Public Health Issues in California's Central Valley
sph.description: Course Description: Public health issues in California’s Central Valley, including the influences of  migration, racial and ethnic diversity, the agricultural industry, environmental exposures, and rurality.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Learning & Teaching in Public Health Contexts
sph.description: Course Description: Aimed at current and future public health professionals interested in learning more about the educational potential for interactions with community members and other health professionals, all stakeholders in improving the health of communities.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

sph.name: — Globalization & Health: Evidence & Policies
sph.description: Course Description: Provides an overview of the evidence on the multiple effects of globalization policies on health.

sph.name: — Epidemiology for Health Professionals
sph.description: Course Description: Basic epidemiologic concepts and approaches to epidemiologic research, with examples from  human medicine, including outbreak investigation, infectious disease epidemiology, properties of tests.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Advanced Epidemiologic Methodology
sph.description: Course Description: In-depth integration of advanced epidemiological concepts. Theory, methods, and applications for observational studies including random and systematic error, confounding, counterfactuals, causal inference, effect modification, internal and external validity, estimability, and interpretation of effect measures, and advanced study designs.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EPI 206.

sph.name: — Principles & Applications of Cancer Prevention & Control
sph.description: Course Description: Principles and applications of cancer prevention and control from a public health perspective.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sph.name: — History of Epidemiology in Public Health
sph.description: Course Description: Introduction to the history of epidemiology in solving major public health problems. Original historical articles will be read/discussed. Topics may include: infectious disease, accidents/adverse events, nutritional deficiencies, community vaccination trials, occupational exposures, cancer, birth defects, cardiovascular disease, and smoking.

sph.name: — Public Health Informatics
sph.description: Course Description: Collection, verification, and utilization of data related to populations; infrastructure, functions, and tools used to generate public health knowledge supporting public health practices and policy development/dissemination.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

sph.name: — Migration & Health
sph.description: Course Description: Principles of migration and health. Topics will include demographics, public health invention programs, health care delivery, occupational health, and effects of international migration on the health in communities of origin, transit and destination. Guest presentations by outside experts.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

sph.name: — Health Disparities in the U.S.
sph.description: Course Description: Introduction to the principles and practice of health disparities research.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Scientific Proposal Writing
sph.description: Course Description: Components and writing of research proposals for agencies such as the NIH and NSF.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sph.name: — GIS for Public Health
sph.description: Course Description: Concepts and components of a geographic information system (GIS) and essential skills of operating a functional GIS through the use of ArcGIS software package. Operational processes of spatial data acquisition, editing and QA/QC, metadata development, geodatabase design, spatial query and display, spatial analysis and modeling, preliminary GIS application development, cartographic mapping and dynamic visualization, and GIS implementation basics.

sph.name: — Social & Behavioral Aspects of Public Health
sph.description: Course Description: Theories and strategies of health behavior change at the individual, group, community, and environmental levels. Examples include: transtheoretical model, social networks, and social marketing. Theories are applied to solve common public health problems (cancer, obesity, smoking, and HIV/AIDS).
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 102; STA 106; and consent of instructor; graduate standing.

sph.name: — Obesity Prevention in Community Settings
sph.description: Course Description: Look at causes of the obesity epidemic in the U.S.; identify and critically assess the research literature on various prevention strategies; understand, and apply evidence-based public health strategies to combat obesity; and translate the science to a general audience.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Health Communication
sph.description: Course Description: Health communication theories and research traditions. Topics include consumer health information seeking; physician-patient interaction; information, social marketing, “edutainment,” and media advocacy campaigns; social networks and coping; media influences on health; and new communication technologies in health promotion and healthcare delivery.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Persuasive Technologies for Health
sph.description: Course Description: Theorizing, designing and evaluating ethical technology-based health communication interventions. Uses of social media, mobile communication apps, wearable devices, computer-generated tailored messages, educational games, and computational approaches in health promotion and healthcare delivery.

sph.name: — Health Communication Campaigns
sph.description: Course Description: Principles of health communication campaign planning, implementation and evaluation. Strategies for changing health behaviors, shaping policy, and improving healthcare organizations’ relations with stakeholders.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Introduction to Medical Statistics
sph.description: Course Description: Introduction to statistical methods and software in clinical, laboratory and population medicine. Graphical and tabular presentation of data, probability, binomial, Poisson, normal, t-, F-, and Chi-square distributions, elementary nonparametric methods, simple linear regression and correlation, life tables.

sph.name: — Biostatistics for Biomedical Science
sph.description: Course Description: Analysis of data and design of experiments for laboratory data.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CLH 244 or SPH 244; or an equivalent course and consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Biostatistics for Clinical Research
sph.description: Course Description: Emphasizes critical biostatistics for clinical research and targets biomedical audience. Students will develop understanding for basic planning and analysis of clinical studies and learn to develop collaborations with biostatisticians.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPH 245 or CLH 245.

sph.name: — Statistical Analysis for Laboratory Data
sph.description: Course Description: Statistical methods for experimental design and analysis of laboratory data including gene expression arrays, RNA-Seq, and mass spec.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CLH 245 or SPH 245.

sph.name: — Social Epidemiology
sph.description: Course Description: Social determinants of health; psychosocial and physiological pathways; health and social inequality; gender and racial/ethnic disparities in health; social support, social cohesion and health; social gradient in behavioral risk factors; social ecological approaches to health intervention; interventions addressing social determinants.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EPI 205A; and consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Human Reproductive Epidemiology
sph.description: Course Description: Human reproductive effects and risk of reproductive disorders, examined from macro- and micro-environmental exposures in community and occupational settings, epidemiologic study designs and analyses.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MPM 405; MPM 406; PHY 220; PGG 222; or equivalents or consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Principles of Environmental Health Science
sph.description: Course Description: Principles, approaches and issues related to environmental health. Recognizing, assessing, understanding and controlling the impact of people on their environment and the impact of the environment on the public.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Public Health Econometrics
sph.description: Course Description: Principles of demand and supply; elasticity; benefits and costs; least squares regression; stepwise regression; economic and statistical significance; fixed and random effects; longitudinal data; non-linear relations; continuous and binary variables; instrumental variables; attrition bias; tobit regression; Two-part cost model.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Applied Analytic Epidemiology
sph.description: Course Description: Principles and applications in analysis of epidemiologic data. Methods of analyzing stratified and matched data, logistic regression for cohort and case-control studies, Poisson regression, survival-time methods.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MPM 404; or consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Health Services Administration
sph.description: Course Description: Structure and function of public and private medical care. Topics include categories and trends in national medical spending, predictors of patient use, causes of death, managed care, HMOs, Medicare, Medicaid, costs of technology, and medical care in other countries.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Economic Evaluation in Health Care
sph.description: Course Description: Cost-effectiveness/cost-benefit analysis (CE/CBA) methods among various economic evaluation methods. CE/CBA is increasingly used to evaluate alternative choices in public health and clinical practice and to enlighten and inform health policy determinations.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): At least one semester of graduate level Statistics or consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Critical Assessment in Health Policy & Economics
sph.description: Course Description: Aims to develop critical reading skills of the health policy and health economics literature, mainly following the microeconomic paradigm and analytical techniques. Some basic concepts of micro economic theory will be explained.

sph.name: — Net Benefit Regression
sph.description: Course Description: Uses regression methods for cost-effectiveness analysis. Focus on methods that create and explain economic information in person-level data.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 100 or SPH 244 or MPM 202; or consent of instructor. Graduate student standing.

sph.name: — Introduction to SAS Programming
sph.description: Course Description: Introduction to SAS, an integrated software system for data retrieval and management, data manipulation and programming.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Introductory statistics course; e.g., MPM 402, STA 102.

sph.name: — Data Management in SAS
sph.description: Course Description: SAS programming for graduate students in the public health sciences or other fields who plan to use SAS software for data analysis.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Program Planning & Evaluation
sph.description: Course Description: Assessment of population needs, assets and capacities that affect communities’ health. Design and selection of methods for evaluating a population-based program.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Topics in Public Health
sph.description: Course Description: Key issues and current topics in public health. Begins in August summer session II. Must enroll in August, then Fall and Winter. Course is a series but grades and units are given at end of each quarter.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Public Health Sciences Doctoral Seminar
sph.description: Course Description: Seminar to explore research on translational science and rural health; includes presentations of student research in progress.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Public Health Translational Science Rotation
sph.description: Course Description: Public Health Translational Science Rotation for Ph.D. students in Public Health Sciences.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Ph.D. student in Public Health Sciences or consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Public Health Translational Science Rotation
sph.description: Course Description: Public Health Translational Science Rotation for Ph.D. students in Public Health Sciences.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sph.name: — International Health
sph.description: Course Description: Forum for learning health issues and health care systems in other countries. Topics include health care for refugees, the impact of political strife on health, the health care professional in international settings.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Public Health Practicum
sph.description: Course Description: Practical fieldwork experience in public health. Placement site will vary based on the interest and experience of each student.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; open to Master of Public Health students.

sph.name: — Study in Community & International Health
sph.description: Course Description: Study and experience for graduate students in any number of areas in community and international health.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate student in good academic standing.

sph.name: — Research in Community & International Health
sph.description: Course Description: Work with faculty member in areas of research interest, including but not limited to injury control, international health, health policy, occupational and environmental health, health promotion and wellness, women's health, and health demographics.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

sph.name: — Introductory Medical Spanish
sph.description: Course Description: The vocabulary needed to conduct a basic history and physical examination in Spanish.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical student or consent of instructor.

sph.name: — Clerkship in Community Health Group Practice
sph.description: Course Description: Overview of local community health in group practice situations. Students participate in treatment at several clinic sites in Yolo County. Topics include primary care, environmental health, maternal and child health, jail health, and preventive health care for the aged.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Third-or fourth-year medical student.

sph.name: — Community Health Preceptorship
sph.description: Course Description: Participate at state or county health department or other public health organization in on-going investigations into current public health problems, e.g., birth defects, cancer control, diabetes, hypertension, injury control, infectious diseases, aging, Alzheimer's disease, and smoking and tobacco use control.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student in good academic standing.

sph.name: — Occupational & Environmental Medicine Elective
sph.description: Course Description: Participate in activities of Occupational and Environmental Health Unit. Major activity is involvement in an epidemiologic research project of the University. Participate in Occupational and Environmental Medicine Clinic at UC Davis Medical Center and other sites, as arranged.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student in good academic standing.

sph.name: — Clinical Selective in Occupational & Environmental Medicine
sph.description: Course Description: Outpatient clinical experience in Occupational and Environmental Medicine at UCDMC and other sites, as arranged. Gain experience in evaluating occ/env medical conditions, use of medical literature resources, the worker's compensation system, and toxicological principles.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student in good academic standing.

sph.name: — Insights in Occupational & Environmental Medicine
sph.description: Course Description: Observe and participate in research and clinical activities in occupational and environmental medicine which include conferences, occupational and environmental medicine clinical activities and field visits. Develop and present small individual research projects.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; first- or second-year medical student in good academic standing.

sph.name: — International Health
sph.description: Course Description: Forum for learning health issues and health care systems in other countries. Topics include health care for refugees, the impact of political strife on health, the health care professional in international settings.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; medical student in good academic standing.

sph.name: — Current Issues in Public Health
sph.description: Course Description: Topical issues in public health. Speakers from the local public health community address issues such as disease control programs, access to care.

sph.name: — Study in Public Health Sciences
sph.description: Course Description: Study and experience for medical students in areas in community and international health.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; medical student in good academic standing.

sph.name: — Research in Public Health Sciences
sph.description: Course Description: Work with faculty member in areas of research interest, including but not limited to public health, injury control, international health, health policy, occupational and environmental health, health promotion and wellness, women's health, and health demographics.
sph.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical students with consent of instructor.

pul.name: — Internship in Pulmonary Medicine
pul.description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in pulmonary medicine.
pul.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing; approval of project by preceptor prior to internship.

pul.name: — Pulmonary Disease Research
pul.description: Course Description: Pulmonary disease research activity with focus in inhalation toxicity, oxidants or lung biochemistry, and cell and molecular biology.
pul.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; by arrangement only.

pul.name: — Comprehensive Pulmonary Medicine Clerkship
pul.description: Course Description: Rotation intended to provide a comprehensive student education in Pulmonary Medicine. Students will participate in hands on clinical education, as well as completing an assigned curricula. Intended for students pursuing Internal Medicine & Primary Care careers.
pul.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of second year of medical school and/or consent of instructor; completion of Internal Medicine Clerkship.

pul.name: — Critical Care Clinical Clerkship
pul.description: Course Description: Rotation intended to provide student education in the Critical Care Management of sub-specialty patients.
pul.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of second year of medical school and/or consent of instructor; completion of Internal Medicine and Surgical Clerkships.

pul.name: — Pulmonary Consult Clerkship
pul.description: Course Description: Similar to PUL 460. Rotation designed for students interested in learning pulmonary medicine, but who desire more variety in their clerkships, and do not desire the comprehensive experience offered by a four-week pulmonary rotation.
pul.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of second year of medical school and/or consent of instructor; completion of Internal Medicine Clerkship.

pul.name: — Away Advanced Clerkship in Pulmonary Medicine
pul.description: Course Description: Away advanced clerkship in Pulmonary Medicine.

pul.name: — Practicum in Care of the Terminally Ill
pul.description: Course Description: Work with hospice interdisciplinary team. Direct experience in the care of patients with illnesses where no cure is possible. Emphasis on symptom relief, end of life issues, physician assisted suicide.

pul.name: — Encounters in Ethics in the ICU
pul.description: Course Description: Care for critically ill adults with complex medical disease carries with it unique ethical roles and duties for the physician.

pul.name: — Pulmonary-Critical Care Medicine Insights
pul.description: Course Description: Attend respiratory outpatient clinics and in-patient pulmonary consultation rounds and medical intensive care rounds. Introduction to diagnosis and treatment of common pulmonary problems.
pul.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; student in good academic standing.

pul.name: — Research
pul.description: Course Description: Research opportunity in Pulmonary Medicine.

pun.name: — Elementary Punjabi
pun.description: Course Description: Introduction to listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills in Punjabi and to Punjabi culture.

pun.name: — Elementary Punjabi
pun.description: Course Description: Continuation of PUN 001V. Introduction to listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills in Punjabi and to Punjabi culture.
pun.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PUN 001V; or consent of instructor.

pun.name: — Elementary Punjabi
pun.description: Course Description: Continuation of PUN 002V. Introduction to listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills in Punjabi and to Punjabi culture.
pun.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PUN 002V; or consent of instructor.

pun.name: — Intermediate Punjabi
pun.description: Course Description: Integrated listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills in formal and informal contexts in Intermediate Punjabi. Continuation of fluency acquisition through grammar, vocabulary, and meaningful verbal and written expressions in Punjabi. Short readings and essays in Punjabi literature and culture.
pun.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PUN 003V; or consent of instructor.

pun.name: — Intermediate Punjabi
pun.description: Course Description: Integrated listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills in formal and informal contexts in Intermediate Punjabi. Continuation of  fluency acquisition in grammar, vocabulary, and meaningful verbal and written expression in Punjabi. Short final essay about topics in Punjabi literature and culture.
pun.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PUN 021; or consent of instructor.

pun.name: — Intermediate Punjabi
pun.description: Course Description: Integrated listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills in formal and informal contexts in Intermediate Punjabi. Greater comprehension and production of meaningful verbal and written expression in Punjabi. Final research project related to topics in Punjabi literature and culture.
pun.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PUN 022; or consent of instructor.

ron.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates: Research in Radiation Biology
ron.description: Course Description: Radiation Oncology is a unique discipline combining elements of clinical practice linked to complex physics based dosimetry and treatment planning. Included within this clinical environment is a strong basis in biology that underpins the clinical effectiveness of radiation treatment.

ron.name: — Introduction to Radiation Oncology Physics
ron.description: Course Description: Introduction to radiation oncology physics. Overview of treatment methodologies. Medical physics equipment. Treatment machine dosimetry, including calibration. Machine quality assurance. Patient dosimetry. Treatment planning. Simulation and treatment. Treatment quality assurance, including calculation checks and chart checks. Brachytherapy.
ron.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; restricted to physics and engineering graduate students and senior undergraduate physics majors.

ron.name: — Independent Study & Research
ron.description: Course Description: Research under supervision of Radiation Oncology faculty. Work must be appropriate to fulfill the requirements for the Ph.D. degree.
ron.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Enrollment with a graduate group for Ph.D. candidacy and consent of group advisor and sponsor.

ron.name: — Radiobiology Lecture Course
ron.description: Course Description: Radiobiology lectures are designed to engage the physician residents, physics residents and medical students in learning Radiobiology principles and concepts during the year the Radiation Physics course is taught.

ron.name: — Radiation Oncology Clerkship
ron.description: Course Description: Introduction to radiation oncology. Students will participate in workup and treatment planning for radiation oncology patients and will be introduced to the concepts involved in clinical radiation oncology, radiation biology, and radiation physics.
ron.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MDS 430; MDS 431; third-year clinical clerkship; consent of instructor required.

ron.name: — Radiation Oncology Away Clerkship
ron.description: Course Description: Away Advanced Clerkship in Radiation Oncology.

ron.name: — Externship in Radiation Oncology
ron.description: Course Description: Externship provides in-depth exposure to the field of Radiation Oncology for students who rotation through an affiliated institution.

ron.name: — Independent Study & Research in Therapeutic Radiology
ron.description: Course Description: Advanced-level research seminar in clinical and/or translational radiation oncology. Work with the course instructor to generate a testable hypothesis.

rdi.name: — Radiological Diagnosis II (Physics of Diagnostic Radiology)
rdi.description: Course Description: Physics of diagnostic imaging; x-ray production and interaction; image formation; modulation transfer function; fluoroscopy; cine fluoroscopy; stereoscopy; xeroradiography; computerized and geometrical tomography; magnetic resonance and ultrasound. Principles of radiation protection in imaging will be covered.

rdi.name: — Medical Radiation Biology
rdi.description: Course Description: Medical radiation biology; molecular cellular and organ system response to acute and chronic irradiation; radiation carcinogenesis and genetic effects; radiation risk assessment; diagnostic ultrasound and magnetic resonance imaging health effects. Medical/legal considerations of radiation exposure.

rdi.name: — Introduction to Clinical Radiology
rdi.description: Course Description: Introduces students to common radiology tests, including limitations and risks by using ACR Appropriateness Criteria and incorporate patient specific clinical data into ordering and interpreting appropriate imaging tests.

rdi.name: — Advanced Clinical Clerkship in Diagnostic Radiology
rdi.description: Course Description: Work with clinical Radiologists in image interpretation fluoroscopy angiography image-guided intervention cardiac stress testing radionuclide therapy. Daily conferences in Radiology Diagnosis and Therapy Health Physics Radiation Safety. Prepare two clinical cases for in-class presentation. Assigned readings.
rdi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; satisfactory completion of second-year medical school curriculum and of third-year clerkships in Internal Medicine and General Surgery.

rdi.name: — Diagnostic Imaging of Acquired & Congenital Heart Disease
rdi.description: Course Description: Main emphasis on radiology of acquired and congenital heart disease, but also on magnetic resonance, nuclear medicine, and echocardiography of heart diseases.
rdi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): RDI 461 (can be concurrent); fourth-year medical student in good academic standing.

rdi.name: — Advanced Clinical Clerkship in Neuroradiology
rdi.description: Course Description: Work with Neuroradiologists in image interpretation of CT, MRI, and fluoroscopy. Opportunity to participate in assessment of Neurointerventional patients, and to observe Neurointerventional procedures. Daily conferences in Neuroimaging, General Radiology, Health Physics, and Radiology Safety. Assigned readings.
rdi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Fourth-year medical student with interest in Diagnostic Radiology, Neuroradiology, Neurology, Neurosurgery, Psychiatry, Psychology, or related field; satisfactory completion of RDI 461, or the equivalent, is strongly encouraged.

rdi.name: — Advanced Clinical Clerkship in Pediatric Radiology
rdi.description: Course Description: Participation in the radiological care of Pediatric patients; evaluate the patient receiving the radiographic study, including pertinent historical/physical findings. Student expected to write up case files on interesting cases encountered during their rotation.
rdi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Fourth-year medical students with interest in Radiology and/or Pediatrics; interested third-year medical students who have successfully completed Pediatrics clinical clerkships may enroll, given availability and consent of the instructor of record; prior completion of PDI 461, or the equivalent, encouraged.

rdi.name: — Advanced Clinical Clerkship in Musculoskeletal Radiology (MSK)
rdi.description: Course Description: Work with Musculoskeletal Radiologists in interpretation of CT, MRI, radiography, and fluoroscopy. Opportunity to assess patients for, and to observe image-guided procedures. Daily conferences in Musculoskeletal Imaging, General Radiology, Health Physics, and Radiology Safety. Assigned readings.
rdi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Fourth-year medical student with interest in Musculoskeletal Radiology, Orthopedic Surgery, Sports Medicine, PMNR, or related field; satisfactory completion of RDI 461, or the equivalent, is strongly encouraged.

rdi.name: — Advanced Clinical Clerkship Vascular/Interventional Radiology (IR)
rdi.description: Course Description: Medical student will work with Vascular/Interventional Radiologists in the evaluation of patients for interventional procedures. There will be opportunities to Daily conferences in Neuroimaging, General Radiology, Health Physics, and Radiology Safety. Assigned readings.
rdi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Fourth-year medical student with interest in Diagnostic Radiology, Vascular/Interventional Radiology, Cardiovascular Imaging, Cardiology, Cardiovascular Surgery, Surgical Oncology, General Surgery, or related field; satisfactory completion of RDI 461, or the equivalent, is strongly encouraged.

rdi.name: — Advanced Clinical Clerkship in Ultrasound Radiology
rdi.description: Course Description: Participation as an active team member on a busy clinical ultrasound service.
rdi.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Fourth-year medical student with interest in Radiology, OB/GYN, or in other medical or surgical subspecialties employing ultrasound in their clinical practice; prior completion of RDI 461, or the equivalent, is encouraged.

rdi.name: — Advanced Clinical Clerkship Abdominal Imaging
rdi.description: Course Description: Work with clinical Radiologists on abdominal and pelvic CT, MR, ultrasound, digital radiography, gastrointestinal and genitourinary procedures, image-guided intervention. Offered as a two-week rotation for third-year medical students and a two/four-week rotation for fourth-year medical students.

rdi.name: — Specialty Externship in Radiology
rdi.description: Course Description: Externship provides in-depth exposure to one of a variety of sub-specialties in Radiology.

rdi.name: — Away Acting Internship in Radiology
rdi.description: Course Description: Away Acting Internship rotation for Radiology and Nuclear Medicine.

rdi.name: — Group Study in Diagnostic Radiology
rdi.description: Course Description: Group study in diagnostic radiology.

rdi.name: — Research in Diagnostic Radiology
rdi.description: Course Description: Approved for graduate degree credit.

rnu.name: — Directed Group Study
rnu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

rnu.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
rnu.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
rnu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

rnu.name: — Research: Special Study for Graduate Students
rnu.description: Course Description: Special study for graduate students.
rnu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

rnu.name: — Biomedical Radiochemistry
rnu.description: Course Description: Approved for graduate degree credit. Designed to combine basic nuclear physics, chemistry, and biology into a comprehensive and vigorous lecture-laboratory experience in biomedical nuclear chemistry. Subjects include choice and purification of appropriate gamma & beta radioisotopes, compounding biological pharmacodynamics and radioimmunoassay.
rnu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; open to graduate and medical students.

rnu.name: — Radiological Physics I (Physics of Nuclear Medicine)
rnu.description: Course Description: Physics of diagnostic and therapeutic nuclear medicine, nuclear physics, radioactive decay; interaction of ionizing radiation; dosimeters; attenuation; internal and external dosimetry; health physics; radiation detection and imaging, scintillation cameras, computerized planar and tomographic imaging. Offered at UC Davis Medical Center.

rnu.name: — Clinical Clerkship in Nuclear Medicine
rnu.description: Course Description: Clerkship correlates radioisotopic methods with clinical, pathophysiological, and other diagnostic aspects of the patients care. Each patient reviewed with student by faculty member. Reading assignments, informal projects, and research techniques available.
rnu.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; satisfactory completion of second-year medical school; RDI 461 recommended.

rnu.name: — Group Study in Nuclear Medicine
rnu.description: Course Description: Approved for graduate degree credit.

rnu.name: — Research in Nuclear Medicine
rnu.description: Course Description: Research in Nuclear Medicine.

rst.name: — Survey of Religion
rst.description: Course Description: Basic concepts introduced through readings of the primary religious literature. Discussion of central ideas (creation, history, law, prophecy, suffering, mysticism, asceticism, karma, reincarnation, moksha, etc.); readings from the Bible, Bhagavad Gita, the Koran, selections from Plato and early Buddhist writings.

rst.name: — Pilgrimage
rst.description: Course Description: Introduction to comparative religion, focusing on the theme of pilgrimage in different religious traditions.

rst.name: — Death & Afterlife
rst.description: Course Description: Introduction to comparative religion, focusing on the theme of death and the afterlife in different religious traditions.

rst.name: — Sacrifice
rst.description: Course Description: Introduction to comparative religion, focusing on the theme of sacrifice in different religious traditions.

rst.name: — Conversion
rst.description: Course Description: Introduction to comparative religion, focusing on the theme of conversion in different religious traditions.

rst.name: — Fundamentalism
rst.description: Course Description: Introduction to comparative religion, focusing on the idea of fundamentalism in different religious traditions.

rst.name: — Religion Today
rst.description: Course Description: Introduction to comparative religion, focusing on different religious traditions in the contemporary world.

rst.name: — Myth, Ritual, & Symbolism
rst.description: Course Description: Myths, rituals and religious symbols found in a variety of religious traditions including examples from ancient and contemporary religious life. Variety of religious phenomena; validity of different approaches to the study of religion.

rst.name: — Sex, Marriage, & Divorce in Medieval & Modern Society
rst.description: Course Description: Methods used in the study of religion, focusing on a particular theme in a number of religious traditions.

rst.name: — Music, Voice, & the Word
rst.description: Course Description: Exploration of relation between religion and musical traditions in various cultures. Investigation of ways music, vocal performance and sound production reflect and shape modern religious sensibilities. Special attention to gender, ethnicity, race, class, nationalism, secularism and mass media.

rst.name: — Comparative Religion
rst.description: Course Description: Comparative Religion based on rotating topics such as Dreams and Revelations, Evil, Prophecy, Salvation, and Crime and Punishment.

rst.name: — Introduction to Health Sciences & the Humanities
rst.description: Course Description: Humanities in the health sciences focusing on illness, the practice of medicine, and the role of culture in biomedical research.

rst.name: — Healthcare & Religious Ethics
rst.description: Course Description: Ethical dilemmas in healthcare and religion. End of life, illness, responsibility for the common good, humanity’s relationship to the natural world, growing up, birth, pregnancy, conception.

rst.name: — Contemporary Ethical Issues
rst.description: Course Description: Presents challenging, contemporary ethical issues from a multi-cultural perspective. Rotating topics will include Ethical Eating, Capital Punishment, Euthanasia, Poverty, and Animal Rights.

rst.name: — Contemporary Ethical Issues
rst.description: Course Description: Discussion of the readings assigned for RST 010 and completion of a major research paper.
rst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): RST 010 (can be concurrent); RST 010 required concurrently; GE topical breadth and diversity credit only with concurrent enrollment in RST 010.

rst.name: — Ethical Eating
rst.description: Course Description: Introduction to the complex and varied ethical, religious, and cultural meanings that food has had across the centuries and globe.

rst.name: — Emergence of Judaism, Christianity & Islam
rst.description: Course Description: Historical origins, founding figures, and sacred texts of Judaism, Christianity, and Islam. Jewish, Christian, and Muslim beliefs about their own origins. Interpretations of scriptures. Development of traditions over time.

rst.name: — Reading War/Fighting War
rst.description: Course Description: Introduction to both classic religious texts about war and a set of actual scenarios drawn from the experience and training of soldiers in recent military conflicts.

rst.name: — The Bible & Its Interpreters
rst.description: Course Description: Introduction to the Hebrew Bible (Old Testament): key narratives and themes (creation, flood, prophecy, justice, sexuality, etc.); origins in Ancient Israel; diverse ways it has been interpreted in Jewish and Christian communities.

rst.name: — Introduction to Judaism
rst.description: Course Description: Introduction to the study of religion using examples from the rituals, art and holy texts of Judaism. No prior knowledge of either Judaism or the study of religion is necessary.

rst.name: — Religions of South Asia
rst.description: Course Description: Introduction to South Asian religions, including Hinduism, Buddhism, Islam, Jainism and Sikhism. Traces historical developments from Vedic texts and their ascetic reformulation by sages such as Yajnavalkya, Siddhartha Gautama, and Mahavira into our global present.

rst.name: — Introduction to Jainism
rst.description: Course Description: Introduction to topics central to Jain tradition through critical, historical and ethical perspectives.

rst.name: — History of Yoga
rst.description: Course Description: History of yoga from antiquity to its most recent formulation in American popular and consumer culture.

rst.name: — Magic & Demons in South Asia
rst.description: Course Description: Exploration of magic, demons, and other powers in South Asian religions from the ancient to the modern periods.

rst.name: — Introduction to Buddhism
rst.description: Course Description: Buddhism in its pan-Asian manifestations, from its beginning in India to its development in Sri Lanka and Southeast Asia, Central Asia, China and Japan; teachings and practices, socio-political and cultural impact.

rst.name: — New Testament
rst.description: Course Description: New Testament literature from critical, historical, and theological perspectives.

rst.name: — Religion & Science Fiction
rst.description: Course Description: Representations of actual and fictional religious movements in science fiction and fantasy writing and film. Examination of: the characteristics of religion and religiosity in fictional religious movements; the relationship between religion, science, and technology in modern speculative fiction.

rst.name: — Christianity
rst.description: Course Description: Major concepts and practices in the Christian tradition. Survey of the history of Christianity and Christian expansion from antiquity to modern times. Pays particular attention to Christianity in China, India, Africa, the Middle East, and Latin America.

rst.name: — Introduction to Islam
rst.description: Course Description: Introduction to topics central to the Islamic tradition. Muhammad, the Qur'an, Islamic law, theology, philosophy, cosmology, worship, and mysticism. Race and gender in Islam, Islamic revival, and varying experiences of Islam in different historical and cultural settings.

rst.name: — The Qur'an & Its Interpretation
rst.description: Course Description: The Qur'an, its history, its various functions in the lives of Muslims, and its different interpretations. Quranic themes such as God and humankind, nature and revelation, eschatology and Satan. Islam and other religions; women, gender, and sexuality.

rst.name: — The Song of God: The Bhagavad Gita
rst.description: Course Description: The Bhagavad Gita, its history and reception, and its significance in the lives of Hindus. Themes explored include Hindu theories of god, self, war, peace, duty, and action.

rst.name: — Modern Hinduism
rst.description: Course Description: Historical survey of modern Hinduism from the early-19th century to the present. Topics include Rammohun Roy, Sir William Jones, and Mahatma Gandhi, nationalism, post-colonialism and diasporic religion.

rst.name: — Introduction to Hinduism
rst.description: Course Description: Survey of the diversity of Hindu traditions from ancient to the colonial period, including the development of temple worship, pilgrimage, goddess worship and regional festivals.

rst.name: — Introduction to Hindu Mythology
rst.description: Course Description: Survey of the major narrative traditions within Hinduism, including epic literature and local stories in oral, textual, visual and performative forms.

rst.name: — Religion & Language
rst.description: Course Description: Basic toolkit for studying religious discourse in a variety of traditions. Concentration on the sacred and profane, the wondrous and ordinary, and the mystical and reasonable.

rst.name: — Introduction to Chinese Philosophy
rst.description: Course Description: Introduction to Chinese philosophy from classical pre-modern times; emphasis on basic concepts and their impact on social conduct; the Age of Philosophers, the Han synthesis, the medieval Buddhist contribution.

rst.name: — Religion, Gender, Sexuality
rst.description: Course Description: Constructions of gender and sexuality within one or more religious  traditions, pre-modern and modern. Emphasis on the interaction between religious, medical, and ethical definitions of the human body and sexual behavior.

rst.name: — Directed Group Study
rst.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
rst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; primarily for lower division students.

rst.name: — Special Study for Lower Division Undergraduates
rst.description: Course Description: Special study for lower division undergraduates.

rst.name: — Study of Religion: Issues & Methods
rst.description: Course Description: Principal issues and methods of Religious Studies and associated fields.

rst.name: — Christian Origins
rst.description: Course Description: Development of Christianity from the end of the 1st century through the major controversies of the 5th century. Emphasis on the relationship between the new religious movement and the Roman Empire, and issues of early Christian identity and diversity.

rst.name: — Medieval & Byzantine Christianity
rst.description: Course Description: Christianity in Europe and the Near East from the year 600 to 1450. Focus on the development of Catholic and Orthodox traditions in ritual, art, and thought, with attention to interactions between regional groups, and Christian interaction with Islam.

rst.name: — Christianity 1450-1700
rst.description: Course Description: History of  Reformation conflicts over the authority of scripture, the nature of man and the universe, and the basis of morality with the goal of understanding how these conflicts laid the foundation for the modern world.

rst.name: — Christianity & Modernity, 1700-1920
rst.description: Course Description: Reaction of Christian critics and apologists to the profound cultural and scientific transformations resulting from the Scientific Revolution, the Enlightenment, and the advent of the modern critical study of religion.

rst.name: — Christianity in the Contemporary World
rst.description: Course Description: Christianity in the 20th and 21st centuries. Relationship of Christianity to globalization, industrialization, mass media, and the contemporary secular state. Focus on Christianity in America and developing nations, and on the relationship of established Christian institutions to new Christian movements.

rst.name: — Life, Meaning & Identity
rst.description: Course Description: Study of religious lives, the quest for meaning and for personal identity; how religions frame the problems of life; how cultural and personal crises affect youthful identity; the nature and structure of dreams, myths, and ideals.

rst.name: — Persuasion & Conviction in Religious Tradition
rst.description: Course Description: Selected topics in religious argument. Familiarizes students with the discourse structures of religious persuasion and enables them to perform analysis of such texts. Covers argument styles and structures used in ethics, theology, and preaching.

rst.name: — Mysticism
rst.description: Course Description: Historical and descriptive analysis of selected key figures in mystical traditions and readings of representative mystical texts. Analytic term paper.
rst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): One lower division Religious Studies course.

rst.name: — Religion, Magic & Science
rst.description: Course Description: Religion, magic, and science from the middle ages to the present. Contrast between modern scientific methodology and religious and magical thinking.

rst.name: — Studies in Biblical Texts
rst.description: Course Description: Study of a book from the Prophets or writings from critical, historical, and religious perspectives.

rst.name: — Sex & Gender in the Bible
rst.description: Course Description: Gender and sexuality in the Bible and its interpretation in Judaism and Christianity. Femininity and masculinity; gender roles; homosexuality; sexual violence. Historical origins in the ancient world; influence on contemporary views.

rst.name: — Topics in Judaism
rst.description: Course Description: Examination of selected aspects of Jewish life, religion, or literature. Potential topics include: Jewish Perspectives on Jesus; The Golem: History and Legend; Sexuality and Gender in Late Antique Judaism and Early Christianity.

rst.name: — Dead Sea Scrolls, Apocrypha, & Pseudepigrapha
rst.description: Course Description: Survey of the Dead Sea Scrolls, apocryphal and pseudepigraphical writings of Judaism and Christianity and their historical, social, and religious importance.
rst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): RST 021; or consent of instructor.

rst.name: — The Formation of the Rabbinic Tradition
rst.description: Course Description: Survey of the classical rabbinic Jewish texts such as the Talmud and of the social and historical contexts of their production in Palestine and Babylonia.

rst.name: — Topics in Religious Studies
rst.description: Course Description: Thematic study of a phenomenon in more than one religious tradition or of the relationship between religion and another cultural phenomenon. Topics may include archeology and the Bible, women and religion, religion and violence.
rst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): RST 001 or RST 002 or RST 003A or RST 003B or RST 003C; or consent of instructor.

rst.name: — Topics in Mediterranean Ancient Religion
rst.description: Course Description: Thematic study of specific sociological, literary or theological theme across the religious traditions of the ancient Mediterranean/Near East: Greek and Roman religions, Judaism, Christianity, Zoroastrianism, Manichaeism, etc. Topics may include creation, sacrifice, priesthoods, prophecies, holy books, the afterlife.

rst.name: — The Bible & Film
rst.description: Course Description: Examination of the uses of the Judeo-Christian Scriptures in film. Topics include dramatic depictions of biblical stories, the tension between science and religion, allegorical treatments of biblical themes, and the problems of religious conviction.

rst.name: — Topics in Jainism
rst.description: Course Description: Thematic study of specific periods, literary movements, sects and important figures within Jainism from a ranges of disciplinary perspectives.

rst.name: — Topics in Buddhism
rst.description: Course Description: Thematic exploration of historic developments, periods, regions and sects in Buddhism from an interdisciplinary perspective.

rst.name: — Topics in Hinduism
rst.description: Course Description: Thematic study of specific periods, movements, leaders, regions, ethics or philosophies within Hinduism from an interdisciplinary perspective.

rst.name: — Christian Theology
rst.description: Course Description: Historical and systematic introduction to Christian doctrine, with attention to divergent traditions and the problem of orthodoxy and heresy.

rst.name: — New Testament Literature: Synoptic Gospels
rst.description: Course Description: Life and thought of the early Church as reflected by the Synoptic Tradition; Matthew, Mark, Luke and Acts. Offered every third year to alternate with RST 141B, RST 141C.

rst.name: — New Testament Literature: John
rst.description: Course Description: Life and thought of the early Church as reflected by the Johannine Tradition; the Gospel and letters of John. Offered every third year to alternate with RST 141A, RST 141C.

rst.name: — New Testament Literature: Paul
rst.description: Course Description: Life and thought of the early Church as reflected by the Pauline tradition. The letters of Paul. Offered every third year to alternate with RST 141A, RST 141B.

rst.name: — New Testament Apocrypha
rst.description: Course Description: Extra-canonical Christian writings and their reception, from antiquity to the present. Emphasis on the importance of New Testament figures both as literary characters and as authors within different Christian traditions.

rst.name: — History of the Bible
rst.description: Course Description: History of the formation of the Christian biblical canon, with emphasis on differences between Christian traditions; survey of translations and adaptations of biblical narrative in Christianity, Judaism, and Islam, as well as in contemporary culture.

rst.name: — Contemporary American Religion
rst.description: Course Description: Examination of several major movements and phenomena in 20th-century American religion.

rst.name: — Religious Ethics
rst.description: Course Description: Study of the religious bases of ethics through examination of ethical problems that arise in different religious cultures around the world and in nations where multiple religious cultures face similar issues.

rst.name: — Justice, Equity, & Privacy in Medical Humanities
rst.description: Course Description: Global issues of justice, equity, and fairness in healthcare and biomedical research. Emphasis on issues of race, gender, paternalism, and genetic privacy. Texts include scholarly articles, fiction, and film.

rst.name: — Religion & Medicine
rst.description: Course Description: Cross-cultural approach to the relationship between Religion and Medicine from earliest times to the present. How specific religious and philosophical worldviews have shaped and continue to shape attitudes toward physical and mental health.

rst.name: — The Hindu Temple
rst.description: Course Description: Comparative history of architecture and symbolism of the Hindu Temple in India, Southeast Asia and the United States. Attention to the temple as expression of religious knowledge, political authority, and cultural heritage through the lens of colonialism and postcolonialism.

rst.name: — Bhakti: Indian Devotional Traditions to 1200 CE
rst.description: Course Description: Exploration of Indian devotional traditions through literary, visual, and performance culture. Emphasis on period up to 1200 CE in southern India.

rst.name: — Bhakti: Indian Devotional Traditions, 1200 CE to Present
rst.description: Course Description: Indian devotional traditions through literary, visual, and performance culture. Emphasis on period 1200 CE to the present.

rst.name: — Religion & the Performing Arts in India
rst.description: Course Description: Survey of religion and performing arts in India. Emphasis on the influence of colonialism, nationalism, and regionalism on the history of Indian performing arts.
rst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): RST 030; RST 068; or consent of instructor.

rst.name: — Hindu Women & Goddesses
rst.description: Course Description: Hindu goddesses and the religious lives of Hindu women in India and the diaspora.

rst.name: — The Ramayana
rst.description: Course Description: Exploration of the Indian epic, Ramayana, through the lens of literature, performance, and visual art. Emphasis on the text's diversity and its contemporary global relevance. Topics include Ramayanas in Southeast Asia, and in various South Asian diaspora communities.

rst.name: — The Mahabharata
rst.description: Course Description: Survey of the Indian epic, the Mahabharata, through textual, oral, and visual culture.

rst.name: — Introduction to Islamic Thought
rst.description: Course Description: The development of Islamic thought from the first centuries of Islam to the 18th century. Theology, philosophy, ethics, Sufism, historiography, political theory, fundamentalism, al-Farabi, al-Ghazzali, Ibn Rushd, Tusi, Ibn al-Arabi, Rumi, Molla Sadra, Ibn Khaldun, Ibn Abd al-Wahhab.

rst.name: — Modern Islam
rst.description: Course Description: Response of Islam to modernity: secularism, reformism, fundamentalism. Islam and imperialism, women, media and immigration. Islamic modernism, political Islam, Islam in Europe and America.

rst.name: — Modern Islam: Authority & Tradition In Process
rst.description: Course Description: Survey of Islamic thought, social organization, politics from 18th century through present. Focus on changing notations of moral authority and tradition. Concentration on Middle East and South Asia with sustained treatment of North American engagements with the Islamic world.

rst.name: — Introduction to Islamic Law
rst.description: Course Description: The development of Islamic law in the formative centuries of Islam, ca. 600-1000, as well as its adaptation to changing economic, social, and political conditions in subsequent periods. Legal schools, legal theory, the Shari'a, reformist movements, human rights.

rst.name: — Social Life of Islam
rst.description: Course Description: Introduction to culture and social life in Muslim societies. Focus on the plurality of traditions in Muslim faith, reason, and everyday practice. Special attention to Muslim rituals, ethical values, verbal genres, family life, sexuality and veiling, and youth culture.

rst.name: — Islam in Asia
rst.description: Course Description: Islam as a lived religion in the Indian sub-continent, Central Asia, China, and Southeast Asia. Emphasis is on primary sources studied comparatively and historically.

rst.name: — Religion & Media in the Arab World
rst.description: Course Description: Exploration of the role and experience of media technologies in the Arab world. Study of digital and electronic media as well as alternative media practices. Investigation of new trends in political activism and identity formation.

rst.name: — Topics in Islam
rst.description: Course Description: Thematic study of specific periods, movements, leaders, regions, ethics or philosophies within Islam from an interdisciplinary perspective.

rst.name: — Buddhism
rst.description: Course Description: Buddhism in its pan-Asian manifestations, from its beginning in India to its development in Sri Lanka and Southeast Asia, Central Asia, China and Japan; teachings and practices, socio-political and cultural impact.

rst.name: — Buddhist Art
rst.description: Course Description: A historical survey of Buddhist art in relation to the development of Buddhist doctrine and philosophy.

rst.name: — Ch'an (Zen) Buddhism
rst.description: Course Description: Doctrines and methods of the Ch'an Buddhism, both ancient and modern. Review of ritual techniques, including meditation.

rst.name: — Daoist Traditions
rst.description: Course Description: English-language survey of key Daoist texts and scholarship. Topics include Daoist concepts of the cosmos, the natural world, scripture, the body, and immortality; Daoist divinities; Daoism and the state.
rst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): A course in Chinese history recommended.

rst.name: — Popular Religious Art in India
rst.description: Course Description: Survey of Indian popular religious art in prints, trade labels, comics and photographs.

rst.name: — Hindu Gods & Hindu Symbols
rst.description: Course Description: A historical survey of the development of the language of symbolism and iconography in Hinduism.
rst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): RST 068: Hinduism or RST 069: Hindu Mythology recommended, but not required.

rst.name: — Ramayana, Religion, & the Arts
rst.description: Course Description: Comparative exploration of the visual, theatrical, ritual, performative and religious lives of the Ramayana epic in South and Southeast Asia.
rst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Recommended but not required preparation: COM 156/RST 158 or RST 181 or RST 068 or RST 069.

rst.name: — Senior Colloquium
rst.description: Course Description: Primarily for seniors in Religious Studies. Discussion in depth of a problem in religion which requires the methods of several disciplines and is important in the encounter between religions.

rst.name: — Seminar
rst.description: Course Description: Allows majors to integrate their disciplined study of the field. Emphasis on current scholarly debate about the methods for analyzing and comparing diverse religious traditions.

rst.name: — Special Study for Honors Students
rst.description: Course Description: Guided research, under the direction of a faculty member approved by the Program Director, leading to a senior honors thesis on a religious studies topic.

rst.name: — Special Study for Honors Students
rst.description: Course Description: Guided research, under the direction of a faculty member approved by the Program Director, leading to a senior honors thesis on a religious studies topic.

rst.name: — Directed Group Study
rst.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
rst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

rst.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
rst.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

rst.name: — Methods & Issues in Religious Studies
rst.description: Course Description: Focuses on controversies in the study of comparative religion. How is religion best defined? Are there methods unique to the study of religion? What does the study of religion contribute to the study of society in general?

rst.name: — Religion & Media
rst.description: Course Description: Many communities are finding global media technologies useful for religious practice. Examines how religious revitalization is historically situated. Phenomenological approach will enable students to situate media and religion within the social and material world of practitioners.

rst.name: — Religion & Postcoloniality, or Savages, Civilization, & Spirituality
rst.description: Course Description: Examines relations between religion and colonialisms. Using specific historical situations it explores some of our thorniest theoretical problems. Acquire a solid understanding of postcolonial theory and the historical tools to critically engage religion in the present.

rst.name: — Religion & Violence
rst.description: Course Description: Comparative and critical study of the ideological, cultural, and theological relationship between forms of violence and religion and religious practice.

rst.name: — Topics in the History of Christianity
rst.description: Course Description: Selected topics in the history of Christianity. Intended for graduate students seeking to do advanced work in the study of Christianity. May cover issues in Christian thought from antiquity, the middle ages, the early modern or modern period.

rst.name: — Directed Research
rst.description: Course Description: Directed research.

rst.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
rst.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.
rst.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

ral.name: — Directed Research Immunology
ral.description: Course Description: Independent research will be encouraged in basic immunology, including the role of the cellular immune system in oncogenesis.

ral.name: — Internship in Rheumatology-Allergy
ral.description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in rheumatology-allergy.
ral.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing; approval of project by preceptor prior to internship.

ral.name: — Directed Research in Immunology
ral.description: Course Description: Independent research will be encouraged in basic immunology, including the role of the cellular immune system in oncogenesis.

ral.name: — Current Topics in Immunology: From Presentations to Grants
ral.description: Course Description: Current developments in various aspects of immunology and their interrelationships. Focus on areas of immunology not currently covered in the basic and advanced immunology courses. Oral presentation, written review and grant preparation.

ral.name: — Topics in Rheumatology & Clinical Immunology
ral.description: Course Description: Library and/or laboratory work as required.

ral.name: — Research in Autoimmune Disease
ral.description: Course Description: Independent research will be encouraged in both animal models of human disease (including congenitally athymic [nude], asplenic, and New Zealand mice) and the cellular immune system of patients with systemic lupus erythematosus, Sjögrens syndrome, polymyositis and drug hypersensitivity.

ral.name: — Rheumatology Clinical Clerkship
ral.description: Course Description: Participation with members of the subspecialty service in the diagnosis and therapeutic management of patients with rheumatologic diseases.
ral.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MDS 431 and consent of instructor.

ral.name: — Allergy Clinical Clerkship
ral.description: Course Description: Student will work with practicing allergist in daily work with patients and participate in weekly allergy clinic and teaching conferences. Study of the literature. Will see patients with problems in clinical immunology, immunodeficiency, asthma, allergic rhinitis.
ral.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of second year of medical school.

ral.name: — Insights in Rheumatology
ral.description: Course Description: Participation in rheumatology consultation rounds, rheumatic disease clinics and conferences with supervised readings in rheumatology.
ral.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; student in good academic standing.

ral.name: — Research
ral.description: Course Description: Part-time participation in active clinical and basic research projects which can involve both patient care and relevant laboratory procedures. Students can gain experience in clinical medicine and clinical investigation.
ral.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical student with consent of instructor.

rus.name: — Elementary Russian
rus.description: Course Description: Introduction to Russian grammar and development of all language skills in a cultural context with special emphasis on communication.

rus.name: — Accelerated Intensive Elementary Russian
rus.description: Course Description: Special 12-week accelerated, summer session intensive combining the work of RUS 001, RUS 002, and RUS 003. Introduction to Russian grammar and development of all language skills in a cultural context with emphasis on communication.

rus.name: — Elementary Russian
rus.description: Course Description: Continuation of grammar and language skills developed in RUS 001.

rus.name: — Elementary Russian
rus.description: Course Description: Continuation of grammar and language skills developed in RUS 002.

rus.name: — Intermediate Russian
rus.description: Course Description: Grammar review and conversational practice in Russian.

rus.name: — Intermediate Russian
rus.description: Course Description: Grammar review. Introduction to literature in its sociopolitical context. Conversational practice.

rus.name: — Intermediate Russian
rus.description: Course Description: Grammar review. Intermediate conversation and continued reading of literature. Social and cultural practices in contemporary Russia; introduction to Russian history.

rus.name: — Directed Group Study
rus.description: Course Description: Directed group study.

rus.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
rus.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.

rus.name: — Advanced Russian
rus.description: Course Description: Topics in Russian. Grammar for the advanced student. Reading and discussion of journalistic texts and classic and contemporary literature. Conversation exercises utilizing literary and colloquial variants of current Russian speech.
rus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): RUS 006; or consent of instructor.

rus.name: — Advanced Russian
rus.description: Course Description: Continuation of RUS 101A. Topics in Russian grammar for the advanced student. Reading and discussion of journalistic texts and classic and contemporary literature. Conversational exercises utilizing literary and colloquial variants of current Russian speech.
rus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): RUS 101A; or consent of instructor.

rus.name: — Advanced Russian
rus.description: Course Description: Continuation of RUS 101B. Topics in Russian grammar for the advanced student. Reading and discussion of journalistic texts and classic and contemporary literature. Conversational exercises utilizing literary and colloquial variants of current Russian speech.

rus.name: — Russian Composition
rus.description: Course Description: Practice in writing Russian. One composition on a different topic each week. Topics include: history, geography, politics, and literature of Russia; comparison of Russian and American lifestyles; current events. Conducted in Russian.
rus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): RUS 006; or consent of instructor.

rus.name: — Literary Translation
rus.description: Course Description: Translation of Russian literary texts into stylistically equivalent idiomatic English.

rus.name: — Advanced Russian Conversation
rus.description: Course Description: Intensive conversational practice and discussion based on current events and contemporary texts.

rus.name: — Topics in Russian Literature & Culture
rus.description: Course Description: Knowledge of Russian not required. Investigation of significant themes and issues of Russian literature and culture within their European context.
rus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

rus.name: — 19th-Century Russian Literature
rus.description: Course Description: Study of Russian literature (prose fiction, drama, poetry) from the period between 1800 and the end of the 19th century. May include authors like Pushkin, Lermontov, Gogol, Turgenev, Dostoevsky, Tolstoy, Chekhov. Offered alternately in English or Russian.
rus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): RUS 101C when offered in Russian; no prerequisite when offered in English.

rus.name: — 20th-Century Russian Literature
rus.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Study of Russian literature (prose, drama, poetry) from the period between 1900 and the end of the 20th century. Authors like Y. Olesha, M. Bulgakov, D. Kharms, and L. Petrushevskaia. Taught in Russian.
rus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): RUS 101C when offered in Russian; no prerequisite when offered in English.

rus.name: — The Russian Theater
rus.description: Course Description: The main works of Russian dramatists from Fonvizin to the present, including Gogol, Turgenev, Tolstoy, Ostrovsky, Chekhov, Blok, Mayakovsky, Kharms. Conducted in Russian.
rus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): RUS 101C; or consent of instructor.

rus.name: — Russian Film
rus.description: Course Description: History of Russian film; film & social revolution, the cult of Stalin, dissident visions; film & the collapse of the Soviet empire; gender and the nation in Russian film. Taught in English; Russian films with English subtitles.
rus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Subject A requirements.

rus.name: — Contemporary Russian Culture
rus.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Trends in Russian culture and the relationship between artists and the government. Topics: recent changes in the cultural scene, postmodernist trends in literature, visual art, film, and theater.

rus.name: — Post-Soviet Literature
rus.description: Course Description: Major authors and trends in Russian literature in post-1991 period. Discussion of impact of economic, social, and cultural turmoil of post-Soviet period on literary marketplace. Analysis of development of literary postmodernism in Russia.

rus.name: — Pushkin
rus.description: Course Description: Three major periods of Pushkin's poetical works: his early Lyceum verse; his poetry of the early 1820s; and the mature period. Further study of Pushkin's prose fiction, drama, and journalism.
rus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): RUS 101C; or consent of instructor.

rus.name: — Dostoevsky (in English)
rus.description: Course Description: Reading and analysis of Dostoevskys principal works such as Crime and Punishment, The Idiot, The Brothers Karamazov, and The Diary. Study of social and political views as reflected in Dostoevskys works.

rus.name: — Tolstoy (in English)
rus.description: Course Description: Study of Leo Tolstoy's literary evolution and moral quest. Readings include his Confession, a major novel such as War and Peace or Anna Karenina, and representative shorter fiction.

rus.name: — Women in Russian Culture
rus.description: Course Description: Study of the representation of women in contemporary Russian fiction and film. Exploration of issues such as family dynamics/motherhood, sexuality, work, and women's relationship to the state. Offered in English.

rus.name: — Chekhov (in English)
rus.description: Course Description: Examination of Chekhov's short stories and major plays, such as The Seagull, Uncle Vanya, The Three Sisters, The Cherry Orchard, and Ivanov, in the broader cultural context of European and Russian fin de siecle.

rus.name: — Russian Culture
rus.description: Course Description: Study of Russian culture in 19th and 20th centuries. Brief introduction of the beginnings up to 19th century. Russian art, music, philosophy, church, traditions, and daily life. Knowledge of Russian not required.

rus.name: — Research Essay
rus.description: Course Description: Research essay, based on primary and secondary sources, dealing in depth with a topic arising from or related to the prerequisite literature course.
rus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): A Russian literature course; may be taken concurrently.

rus.name: — Special Study for Honors Students
rus.description: Course Description: Guided research, under the direction of a faculty member, leading to a senior honors thesis on a topic in Russian studies.
rus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open only to majors of senior standing who qualify for honors program.

rus.name: — Honors Thesis
rus.description: Course Description: Writing an honors thesis, under the direction of a faculty member, on a topic in Russian studies.

rus.name: — Tutoring in Russian
rus.description: Course Description: Tutoring in undergraduate courses, including leadership in small voluntary discussion groups affiliated with departmental courses.
rus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

rus.name: — Directed Group Study
rus.description: Course Description: Directed group study.

rus.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
rus.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

rus.name: — Individual Study
rus.description: Course Description: Individual study.
rus.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

rus.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
rus.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.

vet.name: — Research
vet.description: Course Description: Research.
vet.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): First-, second- and third-year standing in the School of Veterinary Medicine.

vet.name: — Professional & Clinical Skills — Y1
vet.description: Course Description: Outline expectations and skill set required to participate successfully in the DVM curriculum as well as providing learning opportunity in communication, team-building, leadership, conflict management, stress management, critical thinking, professional behaviors, history taking, physical examination skills and medical record keeping.
vet.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): First-year standing in the School of Veterinary Medicine.

vet.name: — Basic Foundations
vet.description: Course Description: Essential basic information regarding histology, general pathology, biochemistry, pharmacology and population health that is foundational to all blocks.
vet.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): First-year standing in the School of Veterinary Medicine.

vet.name: — Heme/Lymph/Coag
vet.description: Course Description: The lexicon, morphology, production, structure and function of peripheral blood cells, their bone marrow precursors and the lymphoid system, the process and regulation of hemostasis, and the laboratory evaluation of all of these in health and disease.
vet.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): First-year standing in the School of Veterinary Medicine.

vet.name: — Musculoskeletal
vet.description: Course Description: Anatomy, histology, and physiology necessary for understanding form and function of the bones, joints, muscles, and tendons in producing locomotion; and the pathologic processes that produce typical responses to injury of musculoskeletal structures in domestic animals.
vet.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): First-year standing in the School of Veterinary Medicine.

vet.name: — Neuroscience/Senses/Behavior
vet.description: Course Description: Establish a basis for clinical neurology, ophthalmology, and behavior by providing an integrated study of normal neurobiology, neuroanatomy, neurophysiology, neuropathology, neurpharmacology, neurotoxicology, ophthalmology and behavior.
vet.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): First-year standing in the School of Veterinary Medicine.

vet.name: — Gastrointestinal/Metabolism
vet.description: Course Description: Examine interrelatedness and functions of the organs associated with the gastrointestinal tract. Applied problems in pharmacology, physical examination, diagnostic testing, and imaging are used to reinforce a basic understanding of organ anatomy, physiology, pathophysiology, and nutrition/metabolism.
vet.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): First-year standing in the School of Veterinary Medicine.

vet.name: — Pharmacology/Nutrition/Toxicology
vet.description: Course Description: Basic principles of nutrition and toxicology as well as pathophysiologic changes, diagnostic procedures and treatments of nutritional diseases and intoxications of domestic animals and wildlife. Incorporate case examples and directed self-learning to reinforce important concepts.
vet.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; first-year standing in the School of Veterinary Medicine.

vet.name: — Connections — Y1
vet.description: Course Description: Integrate basic and preclinical material working with senior student in a clinical environment.
vet.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): First-year standing in the School of Veterinary Medicine.

vet.name: — Cardiology/Respiratory
vet.description: Course Description: Normal cardiovascular and respiratory system biology and the integrated response of those systems to injury or disease.
vet.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Second-year standing in the School of Veterinary Medicine.

vet.name: — Renal/Urinary
vet.description: Course Description: Examine and explore the normal morphology (gross and microscopic), physiology, pathology and imaging of the upper and lower urinary tract in multiple species.
vet.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Second-year standing in the School of Veterinary Medicine.

vet.name: — Endocrinology/Reproduction
vet.description: Course Description: Anatomy and histology of endocrine glands and reproductive systems in males and females. Understand the physiology and pathology at the molecular, cellular and organismal level.
vet.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Second-year standing in the School of Veterinary Medicine.

vet.name: — Skin
vet.description: Course Description: Structure and function of the skin and specialized keratinized structures in veterinary species. Review mechanisms by which skin responds to perturbations and discuss wound healing and skin pathology.
vet.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Second-year standing in the School of Veterinary Medicine.

vet.name: — Oncology
