soc.description: Course Description: Introduction to comparative and case methodological approaches to sociohistorical inquiry, theoretical and practical issues, and substantive research agendas ranging from study of large-scale social transformations to close microhistories, including research agendas being developed by students in the course.
soc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor not required for graduate students in the Social Sciences Division or the Humanities, Arts, and Cultural Studies Division; required for undergraduates and students from other divisions or colleges.

soc.name: — Urban Society
soc.description: Course Description: Broad overview of the issues and concerns of the field of urban sociology. Special emphasis on the human experience of urban living in contemporary, cross-cultural or historical settings.

soc.name: — Developing Societies
soc.description: Course Description: Analysis of social and economic problems of developing societies from the standpoint of theory and research on modernization and underdevelopment. Nature of third world dependency and interdependence in the global political economy.
soc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate student status or familiarity with problems of developing societies.

soc.name: — Social Movements
soc.description: Course Description: Analysis of current issues in and contributions to the study of collective behavior and social movements; particular focus upon the strategies and tactics of social movements.

soc.name: — Sociology of Health & Illness
soc.description: Course Description: Sociological perspectives and methods on the study of health and illness. Select topics for supervised research. Research paper required.

soc.name: — Sociology of Law
soc.description: Course Description: Analysis of the nature of the legal process and its impact on social behavior. Will consider (1) nature and functions of law, (2) the organization and administration of law, and (3) the capacity of law to affect social behavior.
soc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

soc.name: — Classical Sociological Theory
soc.description: Course Description: Introduces graduate students to the work of the main classical thinkers in the tradition of social theory, such as Marx, Durkheim, Weber, Simmel, Freud, G.H. Mead, and Parsons, locating them within the historical,cultural,and philosophical milieu in which their ideas originated.

soc.name: — Theory in Contemporary Sociology
soc.description: Course Description: Explores the uses of theories in contemporary sociology by tracing their connections with classical sociological writings and their relations to broader theoretical concerns of contemporary social thought, with particular emphasis on relevance to the current historical, cultural and social milieu.
soc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SOC 265A.

soc.name: — Social Demography
soc.description: Course Description: How social institutions affect and are affected by the level and variation of mortality, migration, and fertility. Special emphases on the determinants of fertility-related attitudes and behavior, on less-developed countries, and on contemporary empirical studies.
soc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SOC 170; or consent of instructor.

soc.name: — Organizations & Institutions
soc.description: Course Description: Theory of formal organizations and bureaucracy. Methods of research in organizational and institutional studies. Historical and comparative analysis of political, religious, educational, military, and economic structure.

soc.name: — Integrative Research Practicum
soc.description: Course Description: Continuing training in field, quantitative, and/or comparative-historical methods. Emphasis on students' research projects and applications of principles related to research design, concept and theory construction causality and interpretation, and data and measurement. Completion of research paper is required.
soc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SOC 207A; SOC 242A; SOC 292A; consent of instructor.

soc.name: — Seminar
soc.description: Course Description: Seminar.

soc.name: — Field Research
soc.description: Course Description: Introduction to the logic, methods, and practices of field research, with particular emphasis on the ethnographic tradition of participant observation. Interviewing and other qualitative techniques will also be covered. Students will develop original research projects based on their own fieldwork.
soc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Sociology or consent of instructor.

soc.name: — Proseminar in Sociology
soc.description: Course Description: Introduction to graduate training in sociology. A seminar designed to introduce students entering graduate work in the department to its ongoing research activities.
soc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): First-year Sociology graduate students only.

soc.name: — Special Topics Seminar
soc.description: Course Description: Research topics in Sociology. Specific topic will vary according to faculty interest and student demand.
soc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

soc.name: — Group Study
soc.description: Course Description: Group study.
soc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

soc.name: — Individual Study
soc.description: Course Description: Individual study.
soc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

soc.name: — The Teaching of Sociology
soc.description: Course Description: Practical instruction in teaching methods for qualitative and quantitative courses. Pedagogical issues involved in critical sociological analysis.
soc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing; required for first-time teaching assistants.

soc.name: — The Teaching of Sociology
soc.description: Course Description: Practical instruction in devising course syllabi, lectures and assignments for Associate-Instructors and others interested in college teaching. Discussion of pedagogical methods of teaching qualitative and quantitative courses.
soc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

soc.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
soc.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.
soc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

soc.name: — Research Paper Workshop
soc.description: Course Description: A workshop to assist advanced graduate students in the preparation of an original research paper. Students present their research papers and discuss issues in theory, research design, data, empirical inference, and verbal and written presentation of a professional research paper.
soc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Master of Arts standing.

ssc.name: — Soils in Our Environment
ssc.description: Course Description: Soils in our global ecosystem; soils as natural bodies formed by interactive environmental processes; soil response to use and management; sustainable use of soil resources; role of soils in  agricultural and environmental issues; role of soils in our daily lives.

ssc.name: — Soil Science Internship
ssc.description: Course Description: Work experience off and on campus in soil science. Internship supervised by a member of the faculty.
ssc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

ssc.name: — Principles of Soil Science
ssc.description: Course Description: Soil as part of natural and managed ecosystems and landscapes. Solid, liquid, and gas phases and their interactions in the soil. Water, gas and heat movement in soil. Soil biology. Plant nutrient acquisition and use.Soil development, management and use.
ssc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): College-level courses in each of chemistry, physics, biology, and geology recommended.

ssc.name: — Environmental Soil Chemistry
ssc.description: Course Description: Soil chemistry processes related to the fate and transport of contaminants in soil. Soil minerals, natural organic matter, surface charge, soil solution chemistry, redox reactions in soil, and sorption of inorganic and organic contaminants.
ssc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): General chemistry; SSC 100 or equivalent recommended.

ssc.name: — Field Studies of Soils in California Ecosystems
ssc.description: Course Description: Field-based studies of soils in California ecosystems, away from campus, throughout California. Emphasis on description and classification of soils; relationships among soils, vegetation, geology, and climate; physical, chemical, and biological processes in soils on the landscape; and the role of soils in land use.
ssc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SSC 100 and SSC 120 or equivalent recommended.

ssc.name: — Soil Physics
ssc.description: Course Description: Physical properties of soil. Principles of water, gas, heat, and solute movement in soil with selected examples related to soil and water management. Influence of soil properties on transfer processes.
ssc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SSC 100; ERS 100; MAT 016A; or the equivalent of MAT 016A.

ssc.name: — Sustainable Nutrient  Management
ssc.description: Course Description: Availability of nutrients in organic and conventional agricultural, vineyard, orchard and plantation forest soils; management of fertilizers, cover crops, compost, sewage sludge and manures for crop production and to prevent loss to the environment is emphasized.
ssc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SSC 100; or the equivalent.

ssc.name: — Soil Microbiology
ssc.description: Course Description: Major groups of microorganisms in soil, their interrelationships, and their responses to environmental variables. Role of microorganisms in cycling of nutrients. Plant-microbe relationships. Transformations of organic and inorganic pollutants.
ssc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002C recommended.

ssc.name: — Soil Ecology
ssc.description: Course Description: Overview of living constituents of soils, their interactions, importance to, and impact on biogeochemical cycles, decomposition, and soil properties. Practical applications of soil biological diversity are emphasized.
ssc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SSC 100 or equivalent recommended.

ssc.name: — Soils in Land Use & the Environment
ssc.description: Course Description: Soils are considered as elements in land use planning and environmental quality. Topics include: soil survey reports, remote sensing, land capability classification, soil erosion/conservation, waste disposal on soils and soil reclamation. One one-day field trip.
ssc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; SSC 100 or equivalent recommended.

ssc.name: — Soil Genesis, Morphology, & Classification
ssc.description: Course Description: Recognition and description of soils; chemical, biological and physical processes of soil formation. Factors of soil formation. Interactions of soils with diverse ecosystems. Introduction to soil classification. Practice using soil taxonomy. Practical experience describing soil properties in the field.
ssc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SSC 100; GEL 050 recommended.

ssc.name: — Soil Science Internship
ssc.description: Course Description: Work experience off and on campus in soil science. Internship supervised by a member of the faculty.
ssc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of 84 units.

ssc.name: — Directed Group Study
ssc.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
ssc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ssc.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
ssc.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
ssc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ssc.name: — Topics in Advanced Soil Chemistry
ssc.description: Course Description: Reviews of current research in soil chemistry. Topics include double layer theory; clay mineral and oxide surface chemistry; adsorption on soil surfaces; speciation and modeling of solution ions; solubility and mineral stability diagrams.
ssc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; general chemistry; SSC 100 or equivalent recommended.

ssc.name: — Field Studies of Soils in California Ecosystems
ssc.description: Course Description: Field-based soil studies in California ecosystems. Description and classification of soils; relationships among soils, vegetation, geology, and climate; physical, chemical, and biological processes; their role in land use. Similar to SSC 105; requires additional work for graduate credit.
ssc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SSC 100 and SSC 120 or equivalent recommended.

ssc.name: — Soil-Plant Interrelationships
ssc.description: Course Description: Plant needs, occurrence and reactions of water and mineral nutrients in soils; root systems and their growth in soils; mass flow and diffusion mechanisms in nutrient acquisition; models relating nutrient uptake to soil and plant characteristics;nutrient assimilation and crop quality.
ssc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SSC 100; PLB 111; or consent of instructor.

ssc.name: — Advanced Soil Microbiology
ssc.description: Course Description: Microbial metabolism of organic chemicals in soil, both natural and xenobiotic. Decomposition of organic matter. Kinetics of microbial processes in soil.
ssc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 008A; CHE 008B; SSC 111; BIS 102, BIS 103 or an equivalent course recommended.

ssc.name: — Ecosystem Biogeochemistry
ssc.description: Course Description: Multidisciplinary analysis of energy and nutrient transfers within terrestrial ecosystems. Examination of processes and inter- and intra-system interactions between the atmosphere, biosphere, lithosphere and hydrosphere. Laboratory section uses biogeochemical simulation models to examine case studies.
ssc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Introductory courses in ecology/biology and soils recommended; undergraduates accepted with consent of instructor.

ssc.name: — Pedology
ssc.description: Course Description: Topics selected from studies of soil-forming processes, soil-geomorphic relations, mineral weathering, new developments in soil classification, and development of pedologic theory. Topics vary from year to year.
ssc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; SSC 120 recommended.

ssc.name: — Global Carbon Cycle
ssc.description: Course Description: Global carbon cycle from Phanerozoic epoch to modern times. Examination of long and short-term carbon cycles. Transfer of carbon among ocean, land and life with emphasis on humic substance formation, methods of characterization, reactions with organics and soil carbon stabilization.
ssc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 008A; CHE 008B; MAT 016A; MAT 016B; SSC 100; or the equivalent of SSC 100.

ssc.name: — Special Topics in Soil Science
ssc.description: Course Description: Seminars and critical review of problems, issues, and research in soil science.
ssc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

ssc.name: — Group Study
ssc.description: Course Description: Group study.
ssc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ssc.name: — Research
ssc.description: Course Description: Research.
ssc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ssc.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
ssc.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.
ssc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

spa.name: — Elementary Spanish
spa.description: Course Description: Introduction to Spanish grammar and development of all language skills in a cultural context with special emphasis on communication.

spa.name: — Accelerated Intensive Elementary Spanish
spa.description: Course Description: Introduction to Spanish grammar and development of all language skills in a cultural context with emphasis on communication. Special 12-week accelerated, intensive summer session combining the work of SPA 001, SPA 002 and SPA 003.

spa.name: — Elementary Spanish
spa.description: Course Description: Introduction to Spanish grammar and development of all language skills in a cultural context with special emphasis on communication. May be taught abroad in a Spanish speaking country under the supervision of a UC Davis faculty/lecturer.

spa.name: — Elementary Spanish
spa.description: Course Description: Introduction to Spanish grammar and development of all language skills in a cultural context with special emphasis on communication.

spa.name: — Elementary Spanish
spa.description: Course Description: Continuation of SPA 001 and SPA 001S in the areas of grammar and basic language skills.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 001 or SPA 001S or SPA 001Y; or the equivalent.

spa.name: — Elementary Spanish
spa.description: Course Description: Continuation of SPA 001 and SPA 001S in the areas of grammar and basic language skills. May be taught abroad in a Spanish speaking country under the supervision of UC Davis faculty/lecturer.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 001 or SPA 001S or SPA 001Y.

spa.name: — Elementary Spanish
spa.description: Course Description: Continuation of SPA 001, SPA 001S, or previous high school experience in the areas of grammar and basic language skills. Online format combining synchronous chatting with technologically based materials.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 001 or SPA 001S or SPA 001Y; or the equivalent.

spa.name: — Elementary Spanish
spa.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Continuation of SPA 001 or SPA 001S in the areas of grammar and basic language skills. Hybrid format combining classroom instruction with technologically based materials.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 001 or SPA 001S.

spa.name: — Elementary Spanish
spa.description: Course Description: Completion of grammar sequence and continuing practice of all language skills using cultural texts.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 002 or SPA 002S or SPA 002V or SPA 002Y.

spa.name: — Elementary Spanish
spa.description: Course Description: Completion of grammar sequence and continuing practice of all language skills using cultural texts. May be taught abroad in a Spanish speaking country under the supervision of UC Davis faculty.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 002 or SPA 002S or SPA 002V or SPA 002Y.

spa.name: — Elementary Spanish
spa.description: Course Description: Continuation of SPA 002, SPA 002S, SPA 002V or SPA 002Y. Online format combining synchronous chatting with technologically based materials.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 002 or SPA 002S or SPA 002V or SPA 002Y.

spa.name: — Elementary Spanish
spa.description: Course Description: Completion of grammar sequence and continuing practice of all language skills using cultural texts. Hybrid format combining classroom instruction with technologically based materials.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 002 or SPA 002S or SPA 002V or SPA 002Y.

spa.name: — Intermediate Spanish
spa.description: Course Description: Review and development of grammar, vocabulary and composition acquired in the first year through exercises and reading of modern texts.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 003 or SPA 003S or SPA 003V or SPA 003Y.

spa.name: — Intermediate Spanish
spa.description: Course Description: Review and development of the grammar, vocabulary and composition acquired in the first year through exercises and reading of modern texts. May be taught abroad.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 003 or SPA 003S or SPA 003V or SPA 003Y.

spa.name: — Intermediate Spanish I
spa.description: Course Description: Continuation of SPA 003, SPA 003V, SPA 003Y, SPA 003S, or previous high school experience in the areas of grammar and intermediate language skills. Online format combining synchronous chatting with technologically based materials.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 003 or SPA 003Y or SPA 003V; or the equivalent from previous high school language experience.

spa.name: — Intermediate Spanish
spa.description: Course Description: Continuation of SPA 003, SPA 003S, SPA 003V and SPA 003Y in the areas of grammar and basic language skills. Hybrid format combining classroom instruction with technologically based materials where learning takes place both face-to-face and online.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 003 or SPA 003S or SPA 003V or SPA 003Y.

spa.name: — Intermediate Spanish
spa.description: Course Description: Development of all language skills through exercises and reading of modern texts. Development on more difficult grammar concepts and further practice on composition.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 021 or SPA 021S or SPA 021V or SPA 021Y.

spa.name: — Intermediate Spanish
spa.description: Course Description: Development of all language skills through exercises and reading of modern texts. Development of more difficult grammar concepts and further practice on composition. May be taught abroad.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 021 or SPA 021S or SPA 021V or SPA 021Y.

spa.name: — Intermediate Spanish II
spa.description: Course Description: Continuation of SPA 021, SPA 021V, SPA 021Y, SPA 022S, or previous high school experience in the areas of grammar and intermediate language skills. Online format combining synchronous chatting with technologically based materials.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 021 or SPA 021S or SPA 021V or SPA 021Y; or equivalent from previous high school language experience.

spa.name: — Intermediate Spanish
spa.description: Course Description: Continuation of SPA 021, SPA 021S, or SPA 021V in the areas of grammar and basic language skills. Online format combining synchronous chatting with technologically based materials.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 021 or SPA 021S or SPA 021V or SPA 021Y.

spa.name: — Spanish Composition I
spa.description: Course Description: Development of writing skills by way of reading, discussion, and analysis of authentic materials, literary texts, and videos. Selective review of grammar. Composition, journals, individual and group projects.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 022 or SPA 022S or SPA 022V or SPA 022Y.

spa.name: — Spanish Composition I
spa.description: Course Description: Development of writing skills by way of reading, discussion, and analysis of authentic materials, literary texts, and videos. Selective review of grammar. Composition, journals, individual and group projects. May be taught abroad in Spanish speaking country.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 022 or SPA 022S or SPA 022V or SPA 022Y.

spa.name: — Spanish Composition II
spa.description: Course Description: Development of advanced level writing skills, with emphasis on how to write argumentative prose, essays, and research papers. Introduction to the analysis of literary genres. Compositions, journals, individual and group projects.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 023 or SPA 023S.

spa.name: — Spanish Composition II
spa.description: Course Description: Development of advanced level writing skills, with emphasis on how to write argumentative prose, essays, and research papers. Introduction to the analysis of literary genres. Compositions, journals, individual and group projects. May be taught abroad.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 023 or SPA 023S.

spa.name: — Intermediate Spanish for Native Speakers I
spa.description: Course Description: First course of a three-quarter series designed to provide bilingual students whose native language is Spanish with the linguistic and learning skills required for successfully completing upper division courses in Spanish. Intensive review of grammar and composition.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 003 or SPA 003V or SPA 003Y; or equivalent course or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Intermediate Spanish for Native Speakers II
spa.description: Course Description: Continuation of SPA 031, intensive review of grammar and composition. Development of all language skills through reading of modern texts, presentation/discussion of major ideas, vocabulary expansion, and writing essays on topics discussed. Designed for students whose native language is Spanish.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 031; consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Intermediate Spanish for Native Speakers III
spa.description: Course Description: Development of writing skills, with emphasis on experimenting with various writing styles: analytical, argumentative, and creative. Analytical review of literary genres. Written essays will be assigned. Students will develop a research paper. Designed for students whose native language is Spanish.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 032; consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Directed Group Study
spa.description: Course Description: Primarily for lower division students. May be taught abroad.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor and department chairperson.

spa.name: — Student Facilitated Course
spa.description: Course Description: Student facilitated course intended primarily for lower division students.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
spa.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Principles of Hispanic Literature & Criticism
spa.description: Course Description: Principles of literary criticism applied to the study of fiction, drama, poetry, and essay of major literary writers of the Hispanic world.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 024S or SPA 033.

spa.name: — Principles of Hispanic Literature & Criticism
spa.description: Course Description: Principles of literary criticism applied to the study of fiction, drama, poetry and essay of major literary writers of the Hispanic world. May be taught abroad in a Spanish speaking country under the supervision of a UC Davis faculty/lecturer.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 033.

spa.name: — Advanced Spanish Composition
spa.description: Course Description: Practice in expository writing with emphasis on clarity and idiomatic expression. Practical application and review of selected grammar topics. (Part of former SPA 110A & SPA 110B.)
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 033.

spa.name: — The Structure of Spanish: Sounds & Words
spa.description: Course Description: Linguistic description of the sound patterns of Spanish and how those sounds can be used to form larger units, such as morphemes and words. Theoretical and practical comparisons with English and with other Romance languages. (Former SPA 132.)
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (SPA 024 or SPA 033); or consent of instructor. LIN 001 recommended.

spa.name: — The Structure of Spanish: Words & Phrases
spa.description: Course Description: Study of Spanish word and phrase structure, with special emphasis on the constituent structure of noun and verb phrases. Theoretical and practical comparisons with English and with other Romance languages. (Former SPA 131.)
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 111N; or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Spanish Pronunciation
spa.description: Course Description: Sound structure of modern Spanish; theoretical analysis of selected problems in pronunciation. Strongly recommended for prospective teachers of Spanish.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (SPA 024 or SPA 033); LIN 001 recommended.

spa.name: — Contrastive Analysis of English & Spanish
spa.description: Course Description: Contrastive analysis of English and Spanish, error analysis, introduction to structuralist and transformational linguistics. Individual and group conferences. (Former SPA 137.)
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 033; or consent of instructor. SPA 111N and SPA 112N recommended.

spa.name: — History of the Spanish Language
spa.description: Course Description: Spanish language from its roots in spoken Latin to modernity. Emphasis on the close relationship between historical events and language change, and the role that literature plays in language standardization.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 033; or consent of instructor. LIN 001 recommended.

spa.name: — History of the Spanish Language
spa.description: Course Description: Spanish language from its roots in spoken Latin to modernity. Emphasis on the close relationship between historical events and language change, and the role that literature plays in language standardization. Taught abroad in a Spanish speaking country under the supervision of a UC Davis faculty/lecturer.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 033; or consent of instructor. LIN 001 recommended.

spa.name: — Applied Spanish Linguistics
spa.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Exploration of the major theoretical and practical issues concerning learning Spanish as a second language. For students interested in teaching Spanish as a career.  May be taught abroad.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 033; or consent of instructor. LIN 001 recommended.

spa.name: — Applied Spanish Linguistics
spa.description: Course Description: Exploration of the major theoretical and practical issues concerning learning Spanish as a second language. For students interested in teaching Spanish as a career. May be taught abroad in a Spanish speaking country, in Spanish, under the supervision of UC Davis faculty.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 033; or consent of instructor. LIN 001 recommended.

spa.name: — Teaching Spanish as a Native Tongue in the U.S.: Praxis & Theory
spa.description: Course Description: Designed for students interested in teaching Spanish to native speakers. Focus on cultural diversity of the Spanish speaking population in the United States; applied language teaching methodologies in the context of teaching Spanish to native speakers at different levels.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 033; or consent of instructor. LIN 001 recommended.

spa.name: — Topics in Spanish Linguistics
spa.description: Course Description: Study of specialized topics in Spanish linguistics, for example: language and use; text and context; language and society; bilingualism; Spanish dialectology; syntax and semantics.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 111N; or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Creative Writing in Spanish
spa.description: Course Description: Intensive writing of poetry or fiction in Spanish or in a bilingual (Spanish/English) format. Students will write both in prescribed forms and in experimental forms of their own choosing.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 033; or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Survey of Spanish Literature to 1700
spa.description: Course Description: Survey of Spanish literature (narrative, poetry and drama) to 1700, Emphasis on the multicultural birth of the Spanish culture, the formation and growth of the Spanish language and letters through its written records and the literature of the early period.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.

spa.name: — Survey of Spanish Literature: 1700 to Present
spa.description: Course Description: Survey of modern Spanish literature, providing an overview of main literary movements (romanticism, realism, naturalism, modernism, avantgarde). Emphasis on the philosophical and historical background and on the European context for modern Spanish literature. (Part of former SPA 104A & SPA 104B.)
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.

spa.name: — Golden Age Drama & Performance
spa.description: Course Description: Golden Age drama: text and performance. Study of Spanish Baroque drama as performance art. Close reading of plays and related aspects of 17th-century theater: theatrical spaces, staging, performance, actors, public, language, costumes. Final project is performance of a play.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.

spa.name: — Golden Age Literature of Spain
spa.description: Course Description: Introduction to the study of the principal authors and literary movements of 16th- and 17th-century Spain and Spanish American colonial literature.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.

spa.name: — Don Quijote I
spa.description: Course Description: Critical interpretation of Don Quijote Part One by Cervantes. Focused study of key elements within the socio-cultural context of Golden Age Spain. Don Quijote as prototype for the modern novel.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.

spa.name: — Don Quijote II
spa.description: Course Description: Critical interpretation of Don Quijote Part Two by Cervantes. Focused study of key elements within the socio-cultural context of Golden Age Spain. Don Quijote as prototype for the modern novel.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 134A.

spa.name: — Spanish Romanticism
spa.description: Course Description: Romanticism as a philosophical concept, and as a literary movement in Spain, with emphasis on its distinctive, specific "romantic" qualities and its literary expression in five leading authors of the early-19th century. (Former SPA 114.)
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.

spa.name: — The Spanish Novel of the 19th Century
spa.description: Course Description: Literary realism in Spain, focusing on Leopoldo Alas (Clarín), Emilia Pardo Bazán and Benito Pérez Galdós unique characteristics of Spanish realism and its historical roots in Cervantes and the picaresque.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.

spa.name: — 20th-Century Spanish Fiction
spa.description: Course Description: Study of the main literary trends and authors of the modern Spanish novel and short story. Selected works by Unamuno, Valle-Inclán, Sender, Cela, Matute, Ayala and others.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.

spa.name: — Modern & Contemporary Spanish Poetry
spa.description: Course Description: Study of the main literary trends and authors of modern and contemporary Spanish poetry. Selected works by Machado, Juan Ramón Jiménez, García Lorca, Guillén, Aleixandre, Hernández Hierro and others. Offered in alternate years. (Former SPA 120C.)
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.

spa.name: — Modern Spanish Theater
spa.description: Course Description: Study of the main dramatic trends and playwrights of modern Spanish theater. Selected works by Valle Inclán, García-Lorca, Mihura, Buero-Vallejo, Arrabal and others. Offered in alternate years.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.

spa.name: — Modern Spanish Essay
spa.description: Course Description: Ortega, Unamuno and the modern Spanish essay. Their concept of Spain and their relations with other movements and thinkers.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.

spa.name: — Introduction to Spanish Culture
spa.description: Course Description: Introduction to history, geography and culture of Spain. Art, history of ideas, and everyday cultural manifestations. Introduction to critical reading and textual analysis.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 024S or SPA 033.

spa.name: — Introduction to Spanish Culture
spa.description: Course Description: Introduction to history, geography and culture of Spain. Art, history of ideas, and everyday cultural manifestations. Introduction to critical reading and textual analysis. May be taught abroad in a Spanish speaking country under the supervision of UC Davis faculty.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 024S or SPA 033.

spa.name: — Special Topics in Spanish Cultural & Literary Studies
spa.description: Course Description: Special topics in the study of Spanish literature and culture. May be taught abroad.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.

spa.name: — Spanish Art
spa.description: Course Description: Spanish art and the different historical, sociological and political manifestations that frame it. History of art, including Paleolithic, Roman, Visigothic, Romanesque, Goth, Renaissance, Baroque, Neoclassic and Contemporary art. May be taught abroad.

spa.name: — Topics in Spanish Cultural Studies
spa.description: Course Description: Study of specific historical tendencies in Spanish culture(s) from the Romans to the present. Sources studied may include literature, film, art, journalism, and performance. Approaches to material may address issues of aesthetics, politics, identity, and globalization.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 024S or SPA 033.

spa.name: — Anglos, Latinos, & Spanish Black Legend: Anti-Hispanic Prejudice Origins & Educational Implications
spa.description: Course Description: Examination of anti-Hispanic prejudice in the United States focusing on the "Black Legend," a 16th-century, anti-Spanish myth underpinning the doctrine of "Manifest Destiny." Exploration of the Legend's presence in contemporary American society through interviews and analysis of school textbooks.

spa.name: — Cinema in the Spanish-Speaking World in Translation
spa.description: Course Description: Analysis of the culture of the Spanish-speaking world through film in translation. Emphasis on the cultural information illustrated by the films; no prior knowledge of cinematography required. Films with subtitles.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 024S or SPA 033.

spa.name: — Cinema in the Spanish-Speaking World in Translation
spa.description: Course Description: Analysis of the culture of the Spanish-speaking world through film in translation. Emphasis on the cultural information illustrated by the films; no prior knowledge of cinematography required. Films with subtitles. May be taught abroad in a Spanish speaking country, in Spanish, under the supervision of UC Davis faculty.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 033.

spa.name: — Latin-American Literature in Translation
spa.description: Course Description: Reading, lectures and discussions in English of works by Borges, Cortázar, Fuentes, García Márquez, Paz and others.

spa.name: — Survey of Latin American Literature to 1900
spa.description: Course Description: Latin American literature from preconquest texts and the chronicles of the Conquest to romanticism and modernism. Reading selections include fiction, poetry, drama and essays.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.

spa.name: — Survey of Latin American Literature 1900 to Present
spa.description: Course Description: Latin American literature from 1900 to the present. Reading selections include fiction, poetry, drama, essays, testimonio, etc.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.

spa.name: — Latin American Short Story
spa.description: Course Description: Evolution of the Latin American short story from the 19th century to the present. Emphasis on the contemporary period.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.

spa.name: — Latin American Novel
spa.description: Course Description: Evolution of the Latin American novel from the 19th century to the present. Emphasis on significant contemporary works.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.

spa.name: — Mexican Novel
spa.description: Course Description: Evolution of the Mexican novel from the 19th century to the present. Emphasis on the narrative of the Revolution and significant contemporary works.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.

spa.name: — Latin American Literature of the Turn of the 20th Century
spa.description: Course Description: Modernism as an authentic expression of Latin American literature and its influence on 20th-century poetry and prose. In depth analysis of the works of Darío and other major writers of the era. Offered in alternate years.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.

spa.name: — Great Works of Latin American Literature/Culture
spa.description: Course Description: Study of major works of Latin American literature/culture and their cultural and literary milieus. May include novels, poetry, film, etc. Works may be analyzed in terms of style, influence, cultural significance, political importance, and/or commercial success.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.

spa.name: — Latin American Poetry: From Vanguardism to Surrealism & Beyond
spa.description: Course Description: Study of vanguardism, surrealism, and more recent movements of Latin American poetry. An in-depth analysis of the works of such major poets as Neruda, Vallejo, and Paz.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.

spa.name: — Special Topics in Latin American Literature & Culture
spa.description: Course Description: Special topics in the study of Latin American literature and culture.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.

spa.name: — Special Topics in Latin American Literature & Culture
spa.description: Course Description: Special topics in the study of Latin American literature and culture. May be taught abroad in a Spanish speaking country under the supervision of UC Davis faculty.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.

spa.name: — Special Topics in Latin American Literature & Culture
spa.description: Course Description: Special topics in the study of Latin American literature and culture. Hybrid format combining classroom instruction with technologically based materials.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 100 or SPA 100S or SPA 141 or SPA 141S or SPA 170 or SPA 170S.

spa.name: — Latin American Women Writers in Translation
spa.description: Course Description: Latin American women writers from the 19th and 20th centuries. Recent theoretical approaches to literature by women in Latin America. Discussions in English of works by Matto de Turner, Avellaneda, Storni, Ocampo, Agustini, Mistral, Castellanos, and others.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Borders of the Spanish Speaking World
spa.description: Course Description: Analysis of cultural dynamics of border contexts (contact zones) in which Spanish speaking populations are prominent. Contexts may include one or more of the following: US-Mexico, US-Caribbean, Mexico-Central America, Dominican Republic-Haiti, Spain-Portugal, Colombia-Venezuela, Argentina-Brazil, among others.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 024S or SPA 033; or consent of instructor.

spa.name: —  Introduction to Latinx Culture
spa.description: Course Description: Introduction to histories and cultures of Latinx (Mexican American, Puerto Rican, Salvadoran American, Ecuadorian American, etc.) populations of the US. Multiple genres of cultural production and representation, with a focus on cultural diversity and regional difference. Introduction to critical analysis across multiple genres of cultural production (literature, visual culture, media culture, etc.).
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 024S or SPA 033; or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Special Topics in Chicanx/Latinx Studies
spa.description: Course Description: Special topics in the study of Chicanx and/or Latinx literature and culture.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 024S or SPA 033; or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Introduction to Latin American Culture
spa.description: Course Description: Introduction to history, geography and culture of Latin America. Multiple genres of cultural production and representation, with a focus on cultural diversity and regional difference. Introduction to critical reading and textual analysis.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 024S or SPA 033.

spa.name: — Introduction to Latin American Culture
spa.description: Course Description: Introduction to history, geography and culture of Latin America. Multiple genres of cultural production and representation, with a focus on cultural diversity and regional difference. Introduction to critical reading and textual analysis. May be taught abroad in a Spanish-speaking country.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 024S or SPA 033.

spa.name: — Music from Latin America
spa.description: Course Description: Examination of music from Latin America. Characteristic music (i.e. tango, bossa nova, salsa, musica motena, musica andina) as well as its implications in other musical genres. Taught in English or Spanish depending on instructor.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Music from Latin America
spa.description: Course Description: Examination of music from Latin America. Characteristic music (i.e. tango, bossa nova, salsa, musica motena, musica andina) as well as its implications in other musical genres. May be taught abroad in English or Spanish depending on instructor.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Mexican Culture
spa.description: Course Description: Study of Mexican culture through a diversity of cultural expression, including elite, popular and mass media culture. Focus on national icons and archetypes, multiculturalism, transnationalism.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 024S or SPA 033.

spa.name: — Cinema & Latin American Culture
spa.description: Course Description: Understanding Latin American cultures through cinema. History and critical analysis of Latin American film. Focus on a national cinematic tradition. Comparative experiences in different parts of Latin America and/or a particular era. Conducted entirely in Spanish.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 024S or SPA 033.

spa.name: — Chicano Culture
spa.description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary survey of Chicano culture. Topics include literature, art, folklore, oral tradition, music, politics, as well as everyday cultural manifestations. Conducted in Spanish. (Former SPA 124.)
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 033.

spa.name: — Topics in Latin American Cultural Studies
spa.description: Course Description: Specific historical tendencies and issues in Latin American culture(s) from precolombian times to present. Studies of literature, film, art, journalism and performance. Focus on issues of aesthetics, politics, identity, and globalization. May be taught abroad.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 024S or SPA 033.

spa.name: — Literature in Spanish Written in the United States
spa.description: Course Description: Survey of the literary and cultural contributions of the main Spanish-speaking populations present in the U.S.: Chicanos, Puerto Ricans, Cuban-Americans, Central Americans, and other Latinos.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 033.

spa.name: — California & Latin America
spa.description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary survey on the relationship between California and Latin America (1500s-present). Latin American representations of California and Californian representations of Latin America, as well as borderlands texts, with a special focus on Mexican-American perspectives. Conducted in Spanish.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 024S or SPA 033.

spa.name: — Spanish for the Professions
spa.description: Course Description: For students with an advanced level of Spanish interested in the use of Spanish in the health care, legal and law enforcement and marketing and business professions. Field trips documenting the use of Spanish in the public context.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 024 or SPA 024S or SPA 033.

spa.name: — Science & Politics of the Human Body in the Spanish-Speaking World
spa.description: Course Description: Interaction between the interpretations of scientific ideas, philosophical issues, and politics concerning the human body in the Spanish- speaking world through different historical periods.

spa.name: — Science & Politics of the Human Body in the Spanish-Speaking World
spa.description: Course Description: Interaction between the interpretations of scientific ideas, philosophical issues, and politics concerning the human body in the Spanish-speaking world through different historical periods.

spa.name: — Senior Seminar in Spanish Linguistics
spa.description: Course Description: Group study of a special topic drawn from Spanish linguistics. Independent research project.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Senior standing; a major in Spanish or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Senior Seminar in Spanish Literature/Culture
spa.description: Course Description: Group study of a special topic drawn from Spanish literary or cultural studies. Independent research project.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Senior standing; a major in Spanish or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Senior Seminar in Latin American Literature/Culture
spa.description: Course Description: Group study of a special topic drawn from Latin American literary or cultural studies. Independent research project.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Senior standing; a major in Spanish or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Internship in Spanish
spa.description: Course Description: Internships in fields where Spanish language skills can be used and perfected (teaching, counseling, translating-interpreting). May be taught abroad.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 023; and consent of instructor; junior standing; major in Spanish, Chicano Studies, or a related field.

spa.name: — Special Study for Honors Students
spa.description: Course Description: Guided research, under the direction of a faculty member, leading to a senior honors thesis on a topic in Spanish literature, civilization, or language studies.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; senior standing and qualificaiton for the Spanish honors program.

spa.name: — Tutoring in Spanish
spa.description: Course Description: Tutoring in undergraduate courses including leadership in small voluntary discussion groups affiliated with departmental courses.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing and permission of the chairperson.

spa.name: — Tutoring in the Community
spa.description: Course Description: Tutoring in public schools under the guidance of a regular teacher and supervision by a departmental faculty member.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing and permission of the chairperson.

spa.name: — Directed Group Study
spa.description: Course Description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor and department chairperson.

spa.name: — Student Faciliated Course
spa.description: Course Description: Student facilitated course intended primarily for upper division students.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
spa.description: Course Description: Special study of a topic or an author to be determined in consultation with an individual faculty member. May be taught abroad.

spa.name: — Student Facilitated Course Development
spa.description: Course Description: Under the supervision of a faculty member, an undergraduate student plans and develops the course they will offer under 098F/198F.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Student Facilitated Teaching
spa.description: Course Description: Student-facilitated course under the supervision of a faculty member, an undergraduate student teaches a course under 098F/198F.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 199FA; consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Literary Theory I
spa.description: Course Description: Basic theories and practical approaches to modern and contemporary Hispanic literature. Emphasis on formalism, poststructuralism, socio-cultural discourses, and ideologies.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Literary Theory II
spa.description: Course Description: Major contemporary critical theories including recent, innovative approaches to Hispanic literature and culture. Readings from Semiotics and Deconstructionism to Psychological and Socio-ideological approaches. Emphasis on Postmodern and Neo-colonial discourse.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Research Methodologies
spa.description: Course Description: Introduction to the range of scholarly research methodologies currently being realized in Spanish linguistics, literary and cultural studies: archival research, textual analysis, discourse analysis, statistics for linguistics, etc.; introduction to scholarly writing (MLA style) and scholarly publishing.

spa.name: — Spanish Phonology
spa.description: Course Description: Analyzes the sound patterns of Spanish from both linear and non-linear perspectives. Students will develop a clear understanding of what phonology is and the nature of Spanish phonology, as defined by modern linguistic analysis.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Some knowledge of phonetics is required and consent of instructor; LIN 109 and LIN 139 highly recommended.

spa.name: — Spanish Syntax
spa.description: Course Description: An examination of Spanish word order within the framework of general linguistic theory. The student will investigate how to write a grammar of Spanish with particular attention to the structure of noun and verb clauses.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): LIN 165; LIN 140.

spa.name: — History of the Spanish Language
spa.description: Course Description: History of the Spanish language. (Former SPA 220A.)
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): LAT 001.

spa.name: — Old Spanish Texts
spa.description: Course Description: An in-depth linguistic examination of Old Spanish texts from the 12th to the 15th centuries, with particular attention to the significance of orthographic changes.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 207.

spa.name: — Hispanic Dialectology
spa.description: Course Description: Descriptive and historical study of the distinctive features of Peninsular and American Spanish dialects. (Former SPA 221.)
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SPA 220; or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Applied Linguistics
spa.description: Course Description: Focuses on the relevant linguistic aspects of teaching Spanish. Designed for graduate students who have an interest in second-language learning and teaching.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing and SPA 215 and SPA 216 recommended.

spa.name: — Special Topics in Hispanic Linguistics
spa.description: Course Description: Specialized topics in Hispanic linguistics (e.g., pragmatics, sociolinguistics, topics in syntax, semantics, or diachronic studies). May be repeated for credit when topic differs.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. SPA 205 and SPA 206 recommended.

spa.name: — Sociolinguistics: Spanish of the United States
spa.description: Course Description: Descriptive and critical overview of the linguistic practices of the different Spanish-speaking communities in the United States. Sociohistorical migration patterns and settlements; bilingualism; linguistic characteristics of Spanish in contact with English, code-switching, Spanish/English language use and attitude patterns.

spa.name: — Catalan Language & Culture
spa.description: Course Description: Foundation for the acquisition of Catalan oral, reading and elementary writing level skills for students of Spanish (Iberianists or Hispanists), with the capacity to interpret educated written language. Emphasis on weekly review of grammar and all language skills.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; good command of Spanish, Portuguese, French or Italian and graduate level of studies in any of these languages.

spa.name: — Critical Approaches to Spanish Literature I: Prose & Essay
spa.description: Course Description: Critical approaches to Spanish narrative and essay.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Critical Approaches to Spanish Literature II: Poetry & Drama
spa.description: Course Description: Critical approaches to Spanish poetry and drama.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Studies of a Major Writer, Period, or Genre in Spanish Literature
spa.description: Course Description: Artistic development of a major Spanish writer and his/her intellectual and literary milieu or study of a special topic, period, or genre. May be repeated for credit with consent of instructor.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Topics in Latin American Cultural Studies
spa.description: Course Description: Discussion of select contemporary theoretical debates in Latin American Cultural Studies. Application of critical questions to the analysis of cultural texts.

spa.name: — Interamerican Studies
spa.description: Course Description: Survey of methodologies of investigation for crosscultural or comparative projects in the geographical context of the Americas. Focus on particular problems of language, discipline, national definitions, and global hierarchies of knowledge that complicate such projects. Readings of interamerican cultural texts.

spa.name: — Topics in Latinx Cultural & Literary Studies
spa.description: Course Description: Discussion of select contemporary theoretical debates in Latinx Cultural and Literary Studies. Application of critical questions to the analysis of literary and cultural texts.

spa.name: — Medieval Spanish Literature: Prose
spa.description: Course Description: An exploration of the major genres of Medieval Spanish prose from its origins to 1450.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Medieval Spanish Literature: Epic
spa.description: Course Description: Medieval Spanish epic narratives. Major theoretical perspectives on the genesis, diffusion, and character of the Medieval epic. Relationship of epic to ballad literature.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Medieval Hispanic Lyric
spa.description: Course Description: Analysis of the most representative lyric poetry in the various Peninsular languages and in provencal, troubadour poetry, kharjas, villancicos, cantigas de amigo, and courtly lyric.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Spanish Literature of the Early Renaissance
spa.description: Course Description: Spanish Literature, 1450-1550, with emphasis on La Celestina. (Former SPA 229.)

spa.name: — Spanish Literature of the Renaissance & Golden Age: Poetry
spa.description: Course Description: Extensive critical study of the main currents of Renaissance and Baroque Spanish poetry through its language structures, styles (Culteranismo-Conceptismo), rhetorical devices, myths, and themes (love, death, time).
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Spanish Literature of the Renaissance & Golden Age: Drama
spa.description: Course Description: Exploration of major 16th and 17th century literary and cultural developments through the study of selected dramas.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Spanish Literature of the Renaissance & Golden Age: Prose
spa.description: Course Description: Origins and development of the Spanish novel during the Renaissance and the Spanish Golden Age.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Cervantes & the Novel
spa.description: Course Description: Narrative works of Miguel de Cervantes with special emphasis on Don Quijote.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Modern Spanish Literature
spa.description: Course Description: Topics of Spanish literature, from 1700-1920.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Contemporary Spanish Literature: Poetry
spa.description: Course Description: Critical analysis of modern Spanish poetry from a wide spectrum of poetic currents.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Contemporary Spanish Literature: Narrative
spa.description: Course Description: Study of the 20th-century novel and short story with emphasis on the avant-garde, existentialism, social realism, and postmodern trends.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Contemporary Spanish Literature: Drama
spa.description: Course Description: The Spanish theatrical production of the last 70 years.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Contemporary Spanish Literature: Essay
spa.description: Course Description: Major thinkers from Ganivet to Unamuno and Ortega y Gassett. Emphasis will be placed on the relationships between Spanish thought and European philosophical currents.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Women Writers of Spain
spa.description: Course Description: Introduction to the development of a feminine consciousness in the Spanish contemporary literary scene. Selected texts represent particularly innovative typologies of feminine discourse in the realm of the historical, psychoanalytical, and metafictional, erotic, and allegorical fiction.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Critical Approaches to Latin American Literature: Narrative
spa.description: Course Description: Development of Latin American literary periods and currents in narrative (novel, short story, and essay), from early colonial times to the present.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Critical Approaches to Latin American Literature: Poetry & Drama
spa.description: Course Description: Development of Latin American literary periods and currents in poetry and drama, from early Colonial times to the present.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Studies of a Major Writer, Period, or Genre in Latin American Literature
spa.description: Course Description: Artistic development of a major Latin American writer and his/her intellectual and literary milieu or study of a special topic, period, or genre.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Colonial Literature
spa.description: Course Description: An examination of pre-Hispanic and Colonial narrative, poetry and theatre. Emphasis on historical, anthropological, and ethnographic approaches to Colonial discourse.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Graduate standing.

spa.name: — 20th-Century Latin American Drama
spa.description: Course Description: Major Latin American dramatists from Florencio Sánchez to the present. (Former SPA 240.)
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Latin American Novel, 1900-1950
spa.description: Course Description: Study of main trends and key authors in Latin America in the first half of the 20th century. (Former SPA 241A.)
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — New Trends in Latin American Fiction
spa.description: Course Description: Recent developments in Latin American narrative. Emphasis on innovative language and structure. (Former SPA 241B.)
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Mexican Narrative
spa.description: Course Description: Study of the evolution of Mexican narrative. Emphasis on the narrative of the Revolution and significant contemporary works.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Latin American Short Story
spa.description: Course Description: Works by major writers with emphasis on 20th-century authors such as Quiroga, Borges, García Márquez, Cortázar, and Rulfo. (Former SPA 243).

spa.name: — Latin American Women Writers
spa.description: Course Description: Study of feminist critical theories, gender construction, and self-representation within the history of socio-cultural changes in Latin America.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Darío & Modernism
spa.description: Course Description: Study of poetry and prose of Spanish-American Modernism (1880-1916). (Former SPA 245.) Offered in alternate years.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — New Directions in Latin American Poetry
spa.description: Course Description: New trends in Latin American poetry.

spa.name: — The Latin American Essay
spa.description: Course Description: Major Latin American essayists from Sarmiento to contemporary essayists.

spa.name: — Multicultural Approaches to Cuban Literature & Culture
spa.description: Course Description: Study of main trends in Cuban literature. Emphasis on historical, geographic, social and cultural context (including music and film). Taught in English; some readings in Spanish.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

spa.name: — Foreign Language Learning in the Classroom
spa.description: Course Description: Overview of approaches to university-level foreign language instruction and the theoretical notions underlying current trends in classroom practices across commonly taught foreign languages.

spa.name: — Group Study
spa.description: Course Description: Group study.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

spa.name: — Research
spa.description: Course Description: Research.

spa.name: — The Teaching of Spanish
spa.description: Course Description: Teaching of Spanish.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Senior or graduate standing; a major or minor in Spanish.

spa.name: — The Teaching of Spanish in College
spa.description: Course Description: Theoretical instruction in modern teaching methods and demonstration of their practical application. Required of graduate teaching assistants.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

spa.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
spa.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.
spa.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

sta.name: — Statistical Thinking
sta.description: Course Description: Statistics and probability in daily life. Examines principles of collecting, presenting and interpreting data in order to critically assess results reported in the media; emphasis is on understanding polls, unemployment rates, health studies; understanding probability, risk and odds.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Two years of high school algebra.

sta.name: — Introduction to Discrete Probability
sta.description: Course Description: Random experiments; countable sample spaces; elementary probability axioms; counting formulas; conditional probability; independence; Bayes theorem; expectation; gambling problems; binomial, hypergeometric, Poisson, geometric, negative binomial and multinomial models; limiting distributions; Markov chains. Applications in the social, biological, and engineering sciences.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Two years of high school algebra.

sta.name: — Elementary Statistics
sta.description: Course Description: Descriptive statistics; basic probability concepts; binomial, normal, Student's t, and chi-square distributions. Hypothesis testing and confidence intervals for one and two means and proportions. Regression.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Two years of high school algebra or Mathematics D.

sta.name: — Elementary Statistics
sta.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Descriptive statistics; basic probability concepts; binomial, normal, Student's t, and chi-square distributions. Hypothesis testing and confidence intervals for one and two means and proportions. Regression.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Two years of high school algebra or Mathematics D.

sta.name: — Introduction to Statistical Data Science I
sta.description: Course Description: Principles of descriptive statistics. Concepts of randomness, probability models, sampling variability, hypothesis tests and confidence interval.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Two years of high school algebra or Mathematics D.

sta.name: — Introduction to Statistical Data Science II
sta.description: Course Description: Programming in R; Summarization and visualization of different data types; Concepts of correlation, regression, classification and clustering.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 015A C- or better or STA 013 C- or better or STA 032 C- or better or STA 100 C- or better.

sta.name: — Introduction to Statistical Data Science III
sta.description: Course Description: Classical and Bayesian inference procedures in parametric statistical models. Nonparametric methods; resampling techniques; missing data. Use of statistical software.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 015B C- or better.

sta.name: — Gateway to Statistical Data Science
sta.description: Course Description: Probability concepts; programming in R; exploratory data analysis; sampling distribution; estimation and inference; linear regression; simulations; resampling methods. Alternative to STA 013 for students with a background in calculus and programming.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 016B C- or better or MAT 021B C- or better or MAT 017B C- or better.

sta.name: — Statistical Data Science I
sta.description: Course Description: Principles of descriptive statistics; basic R programming; probability models; sampling variability; hypothesis tests; confidence intervals; statistical simulation.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 016A (can be concurrent) or MAT 017A (can be concurrent) or MAT 021A (can be concurrent).

sta.name: — Statistical Data Science II
sta.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Advanced programming and data manipulation in R. Principles of data visualization. Concepts of correlation, regression, analysis of variance, nonparametrics.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (STA 035A C- or better or STA 032 C- or better or STA 100 C- or better); (MAT 016A (can be concurrent) or MAT 017A (can be concurrent) or MAT 021A (can be concurrent)).

sta.name: — Statistical Data Science III
sta.description: Course Description: Introduction to statistical learning; Bayesian paradigm; model selection; simultaneous inference; bootstrap and cross validation; classification and clustering methods; PCA; nonparametric smoothing techniques.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 035B C- or better; (MAT 016B C- or better or MAT 017B C- or better or MAT 021B C- or better).

sta.name: — Seminar
sta.description: Course Description: Examination of a special topic in a small group setting.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; high school algebra.

sta.name: — Directed Group Study
sta.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sta.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
sta.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sta.name: — Applied Statistics for Biological Sciences
sta.description: Course Description: Descriptive statistics, probability, sampling distributions, estimation, hypothesis testing, contingency tables, ANOVA, regression; implementation of statistical methods using computer package.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 016B C- or better or MAT 017B C- or better or MAT 021B C- or better.

sta.name: — Advanced Applied Statistics for the Biological Sciences
sta.description: Course Description: Basic experimental designs, two-factor ANOVA without interactions, repeated measures ANOVA, ANCOVA, random effects vs. fixed effects, multiple regression, basic model building, resampling methods, multiple comparisons, multivariate methods, generalized linear models, Monte Carlo simulations.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 100 C- or better.

sta.name: — Applied Statistics for Business & Economics
sta.description: Course Description: Descriptive statistics; probability; random variables; expectation; binomial, normal, Poisson, other univariate distributions; joint distributions; sampling distributions, central limit theorem; properties of estimators; linear combinations of random variables; testing and estimation; Minitab computing package. May be taught abroad.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better or STA 032 C- or better or STA 100 C- or better); (MAT 016B C- or better or MAT 017B C- or better or MAT 021B C- or better).

sta.name: — Applied Statistical Methods: Nonparametric Statistics
sta.description: Course Description: Sign and Wilcoxon tests, Walsh averages. Two-sample procedures. Inferences concerning scale. Kruskal-Wallis test. Measures of association. Chi square and Kolmogorov-Smirnov tests.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better or STA 032 C- or better or STA 100 C- or better.

sta.name: — Applied Statistical Methods: Analysis of Variance
sta.description: Course Description: Basics of experimental design. One-way and two-way fixed effects analysis of variance models. Randomized complete and incomplete block design. Multiple comparisons procedures. One-way random effects model.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better or STA 032 C- or better or STA 100 C- or better.

sta.name: — Applied Statistical Methods: Regression Analysis
sta.description: Course Description: Simple linear regression, variable selection techniques, stepwise regression, analysis of covariance, influence measures, computing packages.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better or STA 032 C- or better or STA 100 C- or better.

sta.name: — Fundamentals of Statistical Learning
sta.description: Course Description: Principles of supervised and unsupervised statistical learning. Regularization and cross validation; classification, clustering and dimension reduction techniques; nonparametric smoothing methods.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 015C C- or better or STA 106 C- or better or STA 108 C- or better.

sta.name: — Mathematical Statistics: Brief Course
sta.description: Course Description: Basic probability, densities and distributions, mean, variance, covariance, Chebyshev's inequality, some special distributions, sampling distributions, central limit theorem and law of large numbers, point estimation, some methods of estimation, interval estimation, confidence intervals for certain quantities, computing sample sizes.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MAT 016C C- or better or MAT 017C C- or better or MAT 021C C- or better); (STA 013 C- or better or STA 013Y C- or better or STA 032 C- or better or STA 100 C- or better).

sta.name: — Mathematical Statistics: Brief Course
sta.description: Course Description: Transformed random variables, large sample properties of estimates. Basic ideas of hypotheses testing, likelihood ratio tests, goodness-of-fit tests. General linear model, least squares estimates, Gauss-Markov theorem. Analysis of variance, F-test. Regression and correlation, multiple regression. Selected topics.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 130A C- or better or STA 131A C- or better or MAT 135A C- or better.

sta.name: — Introduction to Probability Theory
sta.description: Course Description: Fundamental concepts of probability theory, discrete and continuous random variables, standard distributions, moments and moment-generating functions, laws of large numbers and the central limit theorem.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 021C C- or better; (MAT 022A C- or better or MAT 027A C- or better or MAT 067 C- or better); MAT 021D strongly recommended.

sta.name: — Introduction to Mathematical Statistics
sta.description: Course Description: Sampling, methods of estimation, bias-variance decomposition, sampling distributions, Fisher information, confidence intervals, and some elements of hypothesis testing.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 131A C- or better or MAT 135A C- or better; consent of instructor.

sta.name: — Introduction to Mathematical Statistics
sta.description: Course Description: Testing theory, tools and applications from probability theory, Linear model theory, ANOVA, goodness-of-fit.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 131B C- or better.

sta.name: — Multivariate Data Analysis
sta.description: Course Description: Multivariate normal distribution; Mahalanobis distance; sampling distributions of the mean vector and covariance matrix; Hotellings T2; simultaneous inference; one-way MANOVA; discriminant analysis; principal components; canonical correlation; factor analysis. Intensive use of computer analyses and real data sets.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (STA 130B C- or better or STA 131B C- or better); (MAT 022A C- or better or MAT 027A C- or better or MAT 067 C- or better).

sta.name: — Applied Time Series Analysis
sta.description: Course Description: Time series relationships; univariate time series models: trend, seasonality, correlated errors; regression with correlated errors; autoregressive models; autoregressive moving average models; spectral analysis: cyclical behavior and periodicity, measures of periodicity, periodogram; linear filtering; prediction of time series; transfer function models.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 108 C- or better.

sta.name: — Analysis of Categorical Data
sta.description: Course Description: Varieties of categorical data, cross-classifications, contingency tables, tests for independence. Multidimensional tables and log-linear models, maximum likelihood estimation; tests of goodness-of-fit. Logit models, linear logistic models. Analysis of incomplete tables. Packaged computer programs, analysis of real data.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (STA 130B or STA 131B) or (STA 106,  STA 108).

sta.name: — Fundamentals of Statistical Data Science
sta.description: Course Description: Introduction to computing for data analysis & visualization, and simulation, using a high-level language (e.g., R). Computational reasoning, computationally intensive statistical methods, reading tabular & non-standard data.
