sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 108 C- or better or STA 106 C- or better.

sta.name: — Data & Web Technologies for Data Analysis
sta.description: Course Description: Essentials of using relational databases and SQL. Processing data in blocks. Scraping Web pages and using Web services/APIs. Basics of text mining. Interactive data visualization with Web technologies. Computational data workflow and best practices. Statistical methods.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 141A C- or better.

sta.name: — Big Data & High Performance Statistical Computing
sta.description: Course Description: High-performance computing in high-level data analysis languages; different computational approaches and paradigms for efficient analysis of big data; interfaces to compiled languages; R and Python programming languages; high-level parallel computing; MapReduce; parallel algorithms and reasoning.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 141B C- or better or (STA 141A C- or better,  (ECS 010 C- or better or ECS 032A C- or better)).

sta.name: — Statistical Learning I
sta.description: Course Description: Fundamental concepts and methods in statistical learning with emphasis on supervised learning. Principles, methodologies and applications of parametric and nonparametric regression, classification, resampling and model selection techniques.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 141A C- or better; (STA 130A C- or better or STA 131A C- or better or MAT 135A C- or better); STA 131A or MAT 135A preferred.

sta.name: — Statistical Learning II
sta.description: Course Description: Fundamental concepts and methods in statistical learning with emphasis on unsupervised learning. Principles, methodologies and applications of clustering methods, dimension reduction and manifold learning techniques, graphical models and latent variables modeling.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 142A C- or better; (STA 130B C- or better or STA 131B C- or better); STA 131B preferred.

sta.name: — Sampling Theory of Surveys
sta.description: Course Description: Simple random, stratified random, cluster, and systematic sampling plans; mean, proportion, total, ratio, and regression estimators for these plans; sample survey design, absolute and relative error, sample size selection, strata construction; sampling and nonsampling sources of error.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (STA 130B or STA 131B) or (STA 106,  STA 108).

sta.name: — Bayesian Statistical Inference
sta.description: Course Description: Subjective probability, Bayes Theorem, conjugate priors, non-informative priors, estimation, testing, prediction, empirical Bayes methods, properties of Bayesian procedures, comparisons with classical procedures, approximation techniques, Gibbs sampling, hierarchical Bayesian analysis, applications, computer implemented data analysis.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 130B C- or better or STA 131B C- or better.

sta.name: — Practice in Statistical Data Science
sta.description: Course Description: Principles and practice of interdisciplinary, collaborative data analysis; complete case study review and team data analysis project.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 106 C- or better; STA 108 C- or better; (STA 130B C- or better or STA 131B C- or better); STA 141A C- or better.

sta.name: — Seminar
sta.description: Course Description: In-depth examination of a special topic in a small group setting.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 013 or STA 013Y or STA 032 or STA 100 or STA 103.

sta.name: — Internship in Statistics
sta.description: Course Description: Work experience in statistics.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

sta.name: — Special Studies for Honors Students
sta.description: Course Description: Directed reading, research and writing, culminating in the completion of a senior honors thesis or project under direction of a faculty advisor.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Senior qualifying for honors.

sta.name: — Special Studies for Honors Students
sta.description: Course Description: Directed reading, research and writing, culminating in the completion of a senior honors thesis or project under direction of a faculty advisor.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Senior qualifying for honors.

sta.name: — Directed Group Study
sta.description: Course Description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sta.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
sta.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sta.name: — Introduction to Probability Theory
sta.description: Course Description: Fundamental concepts of probability theory, discrete and continuous random variables, standard distributions, moments and moment-generating functions, laws of large numbers and the central limit theorem.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 021A; MAT 021B; MAT 021C; MAT 022A; consent of instructor.

sta.name: — Introduction to Mathematical Statistics I
sta.description: Course Description: Sampling, methods of estimation, bias-variance decomposition, sampling distributions, Fisher information, confidence intervals, and some elements of hypothesis testing.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 200A; or consent of instructor.

sta.name: — Introduction to Mathematical Statistics II
sta.description: Course Description: Testing theory, tools and applications from probability theory, Linear model theory, ANOVA, goodness-of-fit.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 200B; or consent of instructor.

sta.name: — SAS Programming for Statistical Analysis
sta.description: Course Description: Introductory SAS language, data management, statistical applications, methods. Includes basics, graphics, summary statistics, data sets, variables and functions, linear models, repetitive code, simple macros, GLIM and GAM, formatting output, correspondence analysis, bootstrap. Prepare SAS base programmer certification exam.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Introductory, upper division statistics course; some knowledge of vectors and matrices; STA 106 or STA 108 or the equivalent suggested.

sta.name: — Statistical Methods for Research with SAS
sta.description: Course Description: Focus on linear statistical models widely used in scientific research. Emphasis on concepts, methods and data analysis using SAS. Topics include simple and multiple linear regression, polynomial regression, diagnostics, model selection, variable transformation, factorial designs and ANCOVA.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): An introductory upper division statistics course and some knowledge of vectors and matrices; STA 100, or STA 102, or STA 103 suggested or the equivalent.

sta.name: — Statistical Methods for Research I
sta.description: Course Description: Focus on linear statistical models. Emphasis on concepts, method and data analysis. Topics include simple and multiple linear regression, polynomial regression, diagnostics, model selection, factorial designs and analysis of covariance. Use of professional level software.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Introductory statistics course; some knowledge of vectors and matrices.

sta.name: — Statistical Methods for Research II
sta.description: Course Description: Linear and nonlinear statistical models emphasis on concepts, methods/data analysis using professional level software. Topics include linear mixed models, repeated measures, generalized linear models, model selection, analysis of missing data, and multiple testing procedures.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 206; knowledge of vectors and matrices.

sta.name: — Statistical Methods in Machine Learning
sta.description: Course Description: Focus on linear and nonlinear statistical models. Emphasis on concepts, methods, and data analysis. Topics include resampling methods, regularization techniques in regression and modern classification, cluster analysis and dimension reduction techniques. Use professional level software.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 206; STA 207; STA 135; or their equivalents.

sta.name: — Optimization for Big Data Analytics
sta.description: Course Description: Optimization algorithms for solving problems in statistics, machine learning, data analytics. Review computational tools for implementing optimization algorithms (gradient descent, stochastic gradient descent, coordinate descent, Newton’s method.)
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 200A; STA 208.

sta.name: — Data & Web Technologies for Data Analysis
sta.description: Course Description: Essentials of using relational databases and SQL. Processing data in blocks. Scraping Web pages and using Web services/APIs. Basics of text mining. Interactive data visualization with Web technologies. Computational data workflow and best practices. Statistical Methods.

sta.name: — Big Data & High Performance Statistical Computing
sta.description: Course Description: High-performance computing in high-level data analysis languages; different computational approaches and paradigms for efficient analysis of big data; interfaces to compiled languages; R and Python programming languages; high-level parallel computing; MapReduce; parallel algorithms and reasoning.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 220.

sta.name: — Biostatistics: Survival Analysis
sta.description: Course Description: Incomplete data; life tables; nonparametric methods; parametric methods; accelerated failure time models; proportional hazards models; partial likelihood; advanced topics.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 131C.

sta.name: — Biostatistics: Generalized Linear Models
sta.description: Course Description: Likelihood and linear regression; generalized linear model; Binomial regression; case-control studies; dose-response and bioassay; Poisson regression; Gamma regression; quasi-likelihood models; estimating equations; multivariate GLMs.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 131C.

sta.name: — Analysis of Longitudinal Data
sta.description: Course Description: Standard and advanced methodology, theory, algorithms, and applications relevant for analysis of repeated measurements and longitudinal data in biostatistical and statistical settings.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ((STA 222,  STA 223) or (BST 222,  BST 223)); STA 232B; or consent of instructor.

sta.name: — Clinical Trials
sta.description: Course Description: Basic statistical principles of clinical designs, including bias, randomization, blocking, and masking. Practical applications of widely-used designs, including dose-finding, comparative and cluster randomization designs. Advanced statistical procedures for analysis of data collected in clinical trials.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 223 or BST 223; or consent of instructor.

sta.name: — Statistical Methods for Bioinformatics
sta.description: Course Description: Standard and advanced statistical methodology, theory, algorithms, and applications relevant to the analysis of -omics data.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 131C; or consent of instructor; data analysis experience recommended.

sta.name: — Mathematical Statistics I
sta.description: Course Description: First part of three-quarter sequence on mathematical statistics. Emphasizes foundations. Topics include basic concepts in asymptotic theory, decision theory, and an overview of methods of point estimation.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 131A; STA 131B; STA 131C; MAT 025; MAT 125A; or equivalent of MAT 025 and MAT 125A.

sta.name: — Mathematical Statistics II
sta.description: Course Description: Second part of a three-quarter sequence on mathematical statistics. Emphasizes: hyposthesis testing (including multiple testing) as well as theory for linear models.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 231A.

sta.name: — Mathematical Statistics III
sta.description: Course Description: Third part of three-quarter sequence on mathematical statistics. Emphasizes large sample theory and their applications. Topics include statistical functionals, smoothing methods and optimization techniques relevant for statistics.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 231A; STA 231B.

sta.name: — Applied Statistics I
sta.description: Course Description: Estimation and testing for the general linear model, regression, analysis of designed experiments, and missing data techniques.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 106; STA 108; STA 131A; STA 131B; STA 131C; MAT 167.

sta.name: — Applied Statistics II
sta.description: Course Description: Alternative approaches to regression, model selection, nonparametric methods amenable to linear model framework and their applications.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 106; STA 108; STA 131A; STA 131B; STA 131C; STA 232A; MAT 167.

sta.name: — Applied Statistics III
sta.description: Course Description: Multivariate analysis: multivariate distributions, multivariate linear models, data analytic methods including principal component, factor, discriminant, canonical correlation and cluster analysis.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 106; STA 108; STA 131C; STA 232B; MAT 167.

sta.name: — Design Experiments
sta.description: Course Description: Topics from balanced and partially balanced incomplete block designs, fractional factorials, and response surfaces.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 131C.

sta.name: — Probability Theory
sta.description: Course Description: Measure-theoretic foundations, abstract integration, independence, laws of large numbers, characteristic functions, central limit theorems. Weak convergence in metric spaces, Brownian motion, invariance principle. Conditional expectation. Topics selected from: martingales, Markov chains, ergodic theory.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MAT 125B,  MAT 135A) or STA 131A; or consent of instructor.

sta.name: — Probability Theory
sta.description: Course Description: Measure-theoretic foundations, abstract integration, independence, laws of large numbers, characteristic functions, central limit theorems. Weak convergence in metric spaces, Brownian motion, invariance principle. Conditional expectation. Topics selected from: martingales, Markov chains, ergodic theory.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 235A or MAT 235A; or consent of instructor.

sta.name: — Probability Theory
sta.description: Course Description: Measure-theoretic foundations, abstract integration, independence, laws of large numbers, characteristic functions, central limit theorems. Weak convergence in metric spaces, Brownian motion, invariance principle. Conditional expectation. Topics selected from: martingales, Markov chains, ergodic theory.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 235B or MAT 235B; or consent of instructor.

sta.name: — Time Series Analysis
sta.description: Course Description: Advanced topics in time series analysis and applications. Models for experimental data, measures of dependence, large-sample theory, statistical estimation and inference. Univariate and multivariate spectral analysis, regression, ARIMA models, state-space models, Kalman filtering.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 131B; or the equivalent of STA 131B.

sta.name: — Time Series Analysis
sta.description: Course Description: Advanced topics in time series analysis and applications. Models for experimental data, measures of dependence, large-sample theory, statistical estimation and inference. Univariate and multivariate spectral analysis, regression, ARIMA models, state-space models, Kalman filtering.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 131B; STA 237A; or the equivalent of STA 131B.

sta.name: — Theory of Multivariate Analysis
sta.description: Course Description: Multivariate normal and Wishart distributions, Hotellings T-Squared, simultaneous inference, likelihood ratio and union intersection tests, Bayesian methods, discriminant analysis, principal component and factor analysis, multivariate clustering, multivariate regression and analysis of variance, application to data.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 131B; STA 135.

sta.name: — Nonparametric Inference
sta.description: Course Description: Comprehensive treatment of nonparametric statistical inference, including the most basic materials from classical nonparametrics, robustness, nonparametric estimation of a distribution function from incomplete data, curve estimation, and theory of resampling methodology.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 231C; STA 235A, STA 235B, STA 235C recommended.

sta.name: — Nonparametric Inference
sta.description: Course Description: Comprehensive treatment of nonparametric statistical inference, including the most basic materials from classical nonparametrics, robustness, nonparametric estimation of a distribution function from incomplete data, curve estimation, and theory of re-sampling methodology.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 231C; STA 235A, STA 235B, STA 235C recommended.

sta.name: — Asymptotic Theory of Statistics
sta.description: Course Description: Topics in asymptotic theory of statistics chosen from weak convergence, contiguity, empirical processes, Edgeworth expansion, and semiparametric inference.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 231C; STA 235A, STA 235B, STA 235C desirable.

sta.name: — Introduction to Statistical Programming
sta.description: Course Description: Essentials of statistical computing using a general-purpose statistical language. Topics include algorithms; design; debugging and efficiency; object-oriented concepts; model specification and fitting; statistical visualization; data and text processing; databases; computer systems and platforms; comparison of scientific programming languages.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 130A; STA 130B; or equivalent of STA 130A and STA 130B.

sta.name: — Computational Statistics
sta.description: Course Description: Numerical analysis; random number generation; computer experiments and resampling techniques (bootstrap, cross validation); numerical optimization; matrix decompositions and linear algebra computations; algorithms (markov chain monte carlo, expectation-maximization); algorithm design and efficiency; parallel and distributed computing.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (STA 130A,  STA 130B); (MAT 067 or MAT 167); or equivalent of STA 130A and 130B, or equivalent of MAT 167 or MAT 067.

sta.name: — Topics in Applied & Computational Statistics
sta.description: Course Description: Resampling, nonparametric and semiparametric methods, incomplete data analysis, diagnostics, multivariate and time series analysis, applied Bayesian methods, sequential analysis and quality control, categorical data analysis, spatial and image analysis, computational biology, functional data analysis, models for correlated data, learning theory.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 131A; STA 232A recommended, not required.

sta.name: — Topics in Statistical Methods & Models
sta.description: Course Description: Topics may include Bayesian analysis, nonparametric and semiparametric regression, sequential analysis, bootstrap, statistical methods in high dimensions, reliability, spatial processes, inference for stochastic process, stochastic methods in finance, empirical processes, change-point problems, asymptotics for parametric, nonparametric and semiparametric models, nonlinear time series, robustness.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 231B; or the equivalent of STA 231B.

sta.name: — Advanced Topics in Biostatistics
sta.description: Course Description: Biostatistical methods and models selected from the following: genetics, bioinformatics and genomics; longitudinal or functional data; clinical trials and experimental design; analysis of environmental data; dose-response, nutrition and toxicology; survival analysis; observational studies and epidemiology; computer-intensive or Bayesian methods in biostatistics.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (STA 222 or BST 222); (STA 223 or BST 223).

sta.name: — Statistical Practice & Data Analysis
sta.description: Course Description: Principles and practice of interdisciplinary collaboration in statistics, statistical consulting, ethical aspects, and basics of data analysis and study design. Emphasis on practical consulting and collaboration of statisticians with clients and scientists under instructor supervision.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 207 or STA 232B; working knowledge of advanced statistical software and the equivalent of STA 207 or STA 232B.

sta.name: — Orientation to Statistical Research
sta.description: Course Description: Guided orientation to original statistical research papers, and oral presentations in class of such papers by students under the supervision of a faculty member.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sta.name: — Seminar in Statistics
sta.description: Course Description: Seminar on advanced topics in probability and statistics.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sta.name: — Graduate Group in Statistics Seminar
sta.description: Course Description: Advanced study in various fields of statistics with emphasis in applied topics, presented by members of the Graduate Group in Statistics and other guest speakers.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

sta.name: — Directed Group Study
sta.description: Course Description: Special topics in Statistics appropriate for study at the graduate level.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Graduate standing.

sta.name: — Individual Study
sta.description: Course Description: Individual study.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sta.name: — Dissertation Research
sta.description: Course Description: Research in Statistics under the supervision of major professor.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; advancement to candidacy for Ph.D.

sta.name: — Methods of Teaching Statistics
sta.description: Course Description: Practical experience in methods/problems of teaching statistics at university undergraduate level. Lecturing techniques, analysis of tests and supporting material, preparation and grading of examinations, and use of statistical software. Emphasis on practical training.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

sta.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
sta.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.
sta.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

sta.name: — Methods in Statistical Consulting
sta.description: Course Description: Introduction to consulting, in-class consulting as a group, statistical consulting with clients, and in-class discussion of consulting problems. Clients are drawn from a pool of University clients.

rel.name: — Historical Roots of the Study of Religion
rel.description: Course Description: Consideration of the historical and philosophical formation of religion as a concept. Treats the emergence of religion as a category of analysis and understanding from the Reformation through the Enlightenment.
rel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

rel.name: — Foundational Theories of Religion
rel.description: Course Description: Survey of classical 19th and 20th century approaches to the study of religion.
rel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

rel.name: — Contemporary Approaches to the Study of Religion
rel.description: Course Description: Consideration of major themes, issues and methods in the contemporary study of religion. Perspectives from diverse cultural settings employed to consider modern historical, philosophical, and social contexts that inform understandings of religion.
rel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

rel.name: — Field Profile Seminar I & II
rel.description: Course Description: Individually guided research to survey the field of study, under the supervision of a faculty member. Four units total over two or more quarters are required by the end of the second year.

rel.name: — Special Topics in American Religious Cultures
rel.description: Course Description: Comparative, interpretive study of the treatment of specific topics in American religious cultures.
rel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

rel.name: — Special Topics in Asian Religious Cultures
rel.description: Course Description: Comparative, interpretive study of the treatment of specific topics in Asian religious cultures.
rel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

rel.name: — Special Topics in Mediterranean Religious Cultures
rel.description: Course Description: Comparative, interpretive study of the treatment of specific topics in Mediterranean religious cultures.
rel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

rel.name: — Thematic Topics: Body & Praxis
rel.description: Course Description: Comparative, interpretive study of the treatment of religion through specific topics and themes relating to the body and praxis.
rel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

rel.name: — Thematic Topics: Language, Rhetoric, & Performance
rel.description: Course Description: Comparative, interpretive study of the treatment of religion through specific topics and themes relating to language, rhetoric, and performance.
rel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

rel.name: — Thematic Topics: Modernity, Science, & Secularism
rel.description: Course Description: Comparative, interpretive study of the treatment of religion through specific topics and themes relating to modernity, science, and secularism.
rel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

rel.name: — Thematic Topics: Theory & Method
rel.description: Course Description: Comparative, interpretive study of the treatment of religion through specific topics and themes relating to theory and method.
rel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

rel.name: — Thematic Topics: Values, Ethics, & Human Rights
rel.description: Course Description: Comparative, interpretive study of the treatment of religion through specific topics and themes relating to values, ethics, and human rights.
rel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

rel.name: — Thematic Topics: Visual Culture, Media, & Technology
rel.description: Course Description: Comparative, interpretive study of the treatment of religion through specific topics and themes relating to visual culture, media, and technology.
rel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

rel.name: — Theories of Language
rel.description: Course Description: Focuses on historical theories of language that precede and accompany post-structuralist theory. Intended to introduce graduate students to the context of modern theory formation. May cover structuralism, integrationalism, and grammaticalization.

rel.name: — History, Theory & Criticism of Human Rights
rel.description: Course Description: Introduces the advanced study of Human Rights and the theoretical and practical elaboration of the international Human Rights system. Seminar engages with criticism of Human Rights and develops research and teaching within disciplinary and interdisciplinary frameworks.
rel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

rel.name: — Group Study
rel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

rel.name: — Research
rel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

rel.name: — Dissertation Writing
rel.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; advanced to candidacy for the Ph.D. program.

sur.name: — Cardiovascular Tissue Engineering Research
sur.description: Course Description: Multidisciplinary research in cardiovascular tissue engineering and regeneration for acquired and congenital cardiovascular disease.

sur.name: — Internship in General Surgery
sur.description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in general surgery and related fields.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Upper division standing; approval of project prior to period of internship by preceptor.

sur.name: — Special Study in General Surgery for Advanced Undergraduates
sur.description: Course Description: Special study in general surgery for advanced undergraduates.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Advanced undergraduate student with consent of instructor.

sur.name: — Research
sur.description: Course Description: Research.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

sur.name: — Surgery Clerkship
sur.description: Course Description: Eight week general surgery clerkship includes GI, Burn, Oncology, Plastics, Vascular Cardiothoracic, consult, transplant and trauma. Clerkship assignments are at UCDMC. Daily core material presentations and reading assignments. Student involvement includes work-up and care of surgical patients.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

sur.name: — SJVP Surgery Clerkship at UCSF
sur.description: Course Description: General surgery clerkship includes GI, Burn, Oncology, Plastics, Vascular Cardiothoracic, consult, transplant and trauma. Clerkship assignments are at UCSF Fresno. Student involvement includes work-up and care of surgical patients.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Approval by School of Medicine Committee on Student Progress.

sur.name: — Rural PRIME Surgery Longitudinal Clerkship
sur.description: Course Description: Surgery Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sur.name: — Rural PRIME Surgery Longitudinal Clerkship
sur.description: Course Description: Surgery Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sur.name: — Rural PRIME Surgery Longitudinal Clerkship
sur.description: Course Description: Surgery Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sur.name: — Rural PRIME Surgery Longitudinal Clerkship
sur.description: Course Description: Surgery Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sur.name: — Rural PRIME Surgery Longitudinal Clerkship
sur.description: Course Description: Surgery Longitudinal Integrated Clerkship for the Rural PRIME Program.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sur.name: — Directed Clinical Studies in Surgery
sur.description: Course Description: Individual directed studies in extended preparation for modified curriculum or to complete a clinical rotation following a leave of absence.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; partial completion of a Clinical Rotation.

sur.name: — Directed Studies in Surgery
sur.description: Course Description: Individual directed studies in extended preparation for remediation of all or part of clinical rotation. Clinical studies to accommodate and satisfy remedial work as directed by the Committee on Student Progress and approved by the course IOR.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sur.name: — Surgical Skills Boot Camp
sur.description: Course Description: Goal of the surgical skills boot camp didactic is to enable students to demonstrate competence in basic surgical skills and theory, using analytical thinking and hands-on simulation.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sur.name: — Surgery Burn Unit Clerkship
sur.description: Course Description: Rotation through Surgery Specialty Clinics:Vascular, GI, GU, Thoracic, Plastic, Radiotherapy. Student works up one new and two return visit patients. Presents consult to on-site faculty. Weekly review with preceptor and course director. Reading assignments to add perspective for in-depth discussions.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SUR 430; and consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student or third-year medical student.

sur.name: — Surgery Trauma Service Clerkship
sur.description: Course Description: Student works as an extern on one of the two general surgery Trauma teams, participating in resuscitation and management of critically injured patients. Team hours consist of 24 hours on, and 24 hours off.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SUR 430; and consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student, or third-year medical student.

sur.name: — Surgery Intensive Care Unit
sur.description: Course Description: Student participates in direct supervision of critically ill surgical patients in a twelve-bed surgery ICU. Each student is closely supervised. Provides in-depth experience with management of critically ill patients.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SUR 430; and consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student, or third-year medical student.

sur.name: — Surgery Intensive Care Unit
sur.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Focuses on single family, attached, detached, multi-family, and light commercial development. Study factors which make up successful real estate developments. Consider financial aspects involved in land acquisition, land development, construction, and project lending.

sur.name: — Clinical Plastic Surgery Elective
sur.description: Course Description: Total involvement in patient care involving surgical preparation, treatment, operative care, and follow-up. Developing and understanding reconstruction and aesthetic plastic surgery. Microvascular surgery included. Student rotation.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SUR 430; and consent of instructor; third- or fourth-year medical students.

sur.name: — Surgical Oncology
sur.description: Course Description: Students actively participate in management of patients requiring surgery for cancer, endocrine disease and selected general surgical problems. Cases include malignant melanoma, sarcomas, gastrointestinal cancer, head and neck pathology, and metastatic malignancies. Attending rounds daily. Four teaching conferences weekly.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SUR 430; and consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student, or third-year medical student.

sur.name: — Cardiothoracic Surgery Clerkship
sur.description: Course Description: Student works as an extern on the Cardiothoracic Surgical Service, participating in perioperative management and operations on the heart, lungs, mediastinum, and other thoracic structures. Regularly scheduled teaching conferences are conducted.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SUR 430; and consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student, or third-year medical student.

sur.name: — Gastrointestinal Surgery
sur.description: Course Description: Student participates on the GI Surgery Service, working under the immediate supervision of the faculty and surgical housestaff, involving the full spectrum of gastrointestinal diseases performed by the medical student.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SUR 430; IMD 430; PED 430; and consent of instructor. Fourth-year medical student or third-year medical student.

sur.name: — Vascular Surgery
sur.description: Course Description: Student participates on the vascular surgery service and in the management and operations of arterial and venous system, exclusive of diseases that require cardiopulmonary bypass for treatment. Includes patient care responsibilities with appropriate supervision.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SUR 430; IMD 430; PED 430; and consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student or third-year medical student.

sur.name: — Colorectal Surgery
sur.description: Course Description: Students actively participate in clinic and the operating room on colon and rectal patients. This includes medical and surgical management. Assignments involve work up and care of the surgical patients.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student.

sur.name: — Pediatric Surgery
sur.description: Course Description: Care of patients with neonatal congenital surgical problems. Fluid and electrolyte management in infants. General experience with acquired surgical diseases in children.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SUR 430; and consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student or third-year medical student.

sur.name: — Surgical Consult Service
sur.description: Course Description: Students function as acting interns working in parallel with the interns on the service. They consult on all non-trauma patients in the emergency room and on the wards and also participate in the operating room.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SUR 430; and consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student or third-year medical student.

sur.name: — Clinically Oriented Anatomy
sur.description: Course Description: Anatomy of selected regions of the body using cadaver dissection, prosections and interactive CD ROMs. Anatomical relationships relevant to common surgical procedures. Surgical and interventional radiology procedures.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of three years of medical school.

sur.name: — Surgical Preceptorship: Off Campus
sur.description: Course Description: Student participates in the preoperative, operative and postoperative care of surgical patients under the supervision of attending staff.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical student.

sur.name: — Insights in Surgery
sur.description: Course Description: Individualized activities, including ward rounds, subspecialty clinics and conferences, grand rounds, and observation of a variety of surgical procedures.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; medical student in good academic standing.

sur.name: — Interactive Clinical Case Presentation (ICCP)
sur.description: Course Description: Case presentation of common clinical scenarios (i.e. chestpain/MI; fever/pneumonia; abdo pain/chlecy stites, etc.) from various discipline held in an auditorium with real patients exposure. Interactive session to review history, physical findings and case management. Students will be asked to perform H&P.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Fourth-year medical students; however, course is open for third- and fourth-year student observers.

sur.name: — Vascular Surgery Virtual External Rotation
sur.description: Course Description: Vascular surgery is the field of medical and surgical management of vascular pathology ranging from lower extremity claudication to aortic aneurysms. Rotation brings a level of understanding pursuant of an intern. Instruction through daily virtual rounding and self-directed learning through readings and operation videos; direct patient care is not included.

sur.name: — General Thoracic Surgery Acting Internship
sur.description: Course Description: This four- week Acting Internship (AI) with the Division of General Thoracic Surgery is designed to be an initial comprehensive exposure to adult general thoracic surgery, including preoperative assessment, perioperative management and postoperative care.

sur.name: — Multidisciplinary Experience in Endocrine Neoplasia
sur.description: Course Description: Consists predominately of multidisciplinary clinical experiences focusing on the diagnosis and management of patients with benign and malignant thyroid disease, parathyroid disorders, benign and malignant adrenal disease, pituitary neoplasia, and multiple endocrine neoplasia syndromes.

sur.name: — Critically Ill Surgical Patients SSM
sur.description: Course Description: Special Study Module, a four-week course on the topic: Application of Basic Cardiopulmonary Physiology to Problems Encountered in Critically Ill Surgical Patients.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sur.name: — Physiological Principles in SICU SSM
sur.description: Course Description: Special Study Module, a four-week course on the topic: Care of the Critically Ill Surgical Patient: Use of Physiological Principles to Guide Treatment of Patients with Common Surgical Problems.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sur.name: — Interdisciplinary Study of Gastrointestinal Cancer
sur.description: Course Description: In-depth study of gastrointestinal, hepatic and pancreatic cancer. Emphasis on an integration of basic science and clinical medicine. Participating departments include pathology, surgical oncology, medical oncology, gastroenterology, radiology and radiotherapy.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sur.name: — Fourth-Year Surgical Honors Program
sur.description: Course Description: To provide intensive and comprehensive training in surgery to students interested in a postgraduate surgical career, that would enable them to succeed during the internship and residency training.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): SUR 430; and consent of instructor; completion of third year of medical school with superior performance on SUR 430.

sur.name: — Intense Introduction to Cardiac Surgery
sur.description: Course Description: Close contact with vascular surgeon for two-week period. Includes Sunday mornings. Physiology of going on and off cardiopulmonary bypass. Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, structural and valvular heart disease and electrical and rhythmic heart disease.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

sur.name: — Group Study
sur.description: Course Description: Directed reading and discussion and/or laboratory investigation on selected topics.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; medical student.

sur.name: — Laboratory Research
sur.description: Course Description: Laboratory research on surgically related problems. Participation in projects to include the following: burn, nutrition, oncology, transplant and others.
sur.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of second year of medical school.

vsr.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
vsr.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.

vsr.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
vsr.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

saf.name: — SA & FS Seminar
saf.description: Course Description: Introductory or survey topics within Sustainable Agriculture & Food Systems.

saf.name: — SA & FS Portfolio
saf.description: Course Description: SA&FS Portfolios are designed to complement interdisciplinary, academic coursework by supporting student development of each of the SA&FS Student Learning Outcomes: Systems Thinking, Experimentation & Inquiry, Understanding Values, Interpersonal Communication, Strategic Management, Civic Engagement and Personal Development.

saf.name: — Internship
saf.description: Course Description: Lower-division internship for students enrolled in the Sustainable Agriculture & Food Systems program of study.

saf.name: — Directed Group Study
saf.description: Course Description: Group study on focused topics in Sustainable Agriculture & Food Systems. Varies according to instructor. Course plan is adapted to student need and interest in conjunction with the expertise of the instructor.

saf.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
saf.description: Course Description: Under faculty supervision, students pursue a special or individualized course of study related to Sustainable Agriculture & Food Systems.

saf.name: — Irrigation Practices for an Urban Environment
saf.description: Course Description: Basic design, installation, and operation principles of irrigation systems for turf and landscape: golf courses, parks, highways, public buildings, etc. Emphasis on hardware association with sprinkler and drip/trickle systems.

saf.name: — Internship
saf.description: Course Description: Upper-division internship for students enrolled in the Sustainable Agriculture & Food Systems program of study.
saf.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

saf.name: — Tutoring in Sustainable Agriculture & Food Systems
saf.description: Course Description: Undergraduates assist the instructor by tutoring students in regularly scheduled courses that fulfill SA&FS major requirements.
saf.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

saf.name: — SA&FS Tutoring in the Community
saf.description: Course Description: Undergraduates assist the instructor by tutoring in the community in settings related to Sustainable Agriculture & Food Systems.
saf.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

saf.name: — Directed Group Study
saf.description: Course Description: Group study on focused topics in Sustainable Agriculture & Food Systems. Varies according to instructor. Course plan is adapted to student need and interest in conjunction with the expertise of the instructor.
saf.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor;  upper division standing.

saf.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
saf.description: Course Description: Under faculty supervision, advanced students pursue a special or individualized course of study related to Sustainable Agriculture & Food Systems.
saf.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

tcs.name: — New Radio Features & Documentary
tcs.description: Course Description: New feature and documentary production for radio and other audiophonic media, including audio streaming websites and installation. Emphasis on new and experimental approaches to audio production for broadcast on community radio and in international arts programming.

tcs.name: — Introduction to Documentary Studies
tcs.description: Course Description: Recent evolution of the documentary. The personal essay film; found-footage/appropriation work; non-linear, multi-media forms; spoken word; storytelling; oral history recordings; and other examples of documentary expression.

tcs.name: — Media Subcultures
tcs.description: Course Description: Relationships between subcultural groups and media technologies. Media as the cohesive and persuasive force of subcultural activities. List-servs, websites, free radio, fan 'zines, and hip-hop culture.

tcs.name: — Ghosts of the Machine: How Technology Rewires our Senses
tcs.description: Course Description: Historical, aesthetic and critical approaches to how information technologies produced ghost effects or a sense of terror in response to new media like the photograph, gramophone, film, typewriter, computer, Turing Machine. Focus on technological media transforms sense perception.

tcs.name: — Small Scale Film Production
tcs.description: Course Description: Lecture and intensive workshop teaching small-scale film production. Appointments as a(n) director, director of photography, actor, writer, lighting designer, sound designer and other critical positions are used to produce and submit a short film to a film festival.

tcs.name: — Research Methods in Technocultural Studies
tcs.description: Course Description: Introduction to basic research methods for Technocultural Studies: electronic and archived images, sounds and data, satellite downlinking, radiowave scanning, and oral histories.

tcs.name: — Writing Across Media
tcs.description: Course Description: Introduction to experimental approaches to writing for different media and artistic practices. How written texts relate to the images, sounds, and performances in digital and media production.

txc.name: — Special Study for Lower Division Students
— Textile Processes
txc.description: Course Description: Physical processes involved in the production of textiles from the individual fiber to the finished fabric. Includes spinning, texturing, yarn formation, weaving preparation, weaving and knitting, tufting and fabric finishing.

txc.name: — Clothing Materials Science
txc.description: Course Description: The properties, characterization, and performance evaluation of clothing materials and structures for specific functional applications. Principles and methods related to wetting and transport properties, fabric hand and aesthetic properties, clothing comfort, and material and assembly technology.

txc.name: — Internship in Textiles & Clothing
txc.description: Course Description: Work-learn experience off campus in a textiles or clothing-related area. Supervision by a member of the Textiles & Clothing faculty.

txc.name: — Tutoring in Textiles & Clothing
txc.description: Course Description: Tutoring of students in Textiles & Clothing courses. Assistance with discussion groups and laboratory sections under supervision of instructor.
txc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division textiles-related major.

txc.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
txc.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

txc.name: — Behavorial Science Concepts in Textiles
txc.description: Course Description: Examination of theories and research concerning relationships between clothing and human behavior with emphasis on research techniques, including methods of measuring clothing variables.
txc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): TXC 107; upper division or graduate course in statistics (e.g., AMR 120) and one in a behavioral science (e.g., PSC 145).

txc.name: — Seminar
txc.description: Course Description: Critical review of selected topics of current interest in textiles.

txc.name: — Research Conference
txc.description: Course Description: Individual faculty members meet with their graduate students. Critical presentations of original research are made by graduate students. Research activities are planned. Discussions are led by major professors for their research groups.
txc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

txc.name: — Recent Advances in Textiles
txc.description: Course Description: Critical reading and evaluation on selected topics of current interest in textiles. Multidisciplinary aspects of the topics selected will be stressed.
txc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Two upper division courses in Textiles  Clothing (TXC) or consent of instructor.

txc.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
txc.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant, training practicum.

ttp.name: — Transportation Survey Methods
ttp.description: Course Description: Description of types of surveys commonly used in transportation demand modeling, including travel and activity diaries, attitudinal, panel, computer, and stated-response surveys. Discussion of sampling, experimental design, and survey design issues. Analysis methods, including factor, discriminant and cluster analysis.
ttp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 013 or STA 013Y; ECI 251 recommended.

ttp.name: — Applied Data Analysis
ttp.description: Course Description: Skills for examining, parsing, and analyzing datasets to answer research questions. Application of concepts from econometrics, statistics, and machine learning.
ttp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): STA 108, STA 141A, and STA 141B recommended.

ttp.name: — Fundamentals of Transportation Technology
ttp.description: Course Description: Designed to prepare in the basics of thermodynamics, fluid mechanics and heat transfer as they relate to transportation.
ttp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): MAT 021A; MAT 021B; MAT 022A; and consent of instructor; graduate or junior/senior undergraduate as a technical elective.

ttp.name: — Energy & Transportation Modeling for Policy Analysis
ttp.description: Course Description: Development of energy and transportation models for policy analysis. Methods for modeling transportation, electricity, fuels, resources, and infrastructure systems.

ttp.name: — Transportation Planning & Policy
ttp.description: Course Description: Transportation planning process at the regional level, including the role of federal policy in shaping regional transportation planning, tools and techniques used in regional transportation planning, issues facing regional transportation planning agencies, pros and cons of potential solutions and strategies.

ttp.name: — Pavement for Managers
ttp.description: Course Description: Concepts and knowledge needed by policy-makers, planners, and managers to understand pavements, including all urban hardscapes. Materials production, design, construction, maintenance and rehabilitation, use, and end-of-life. Implications for costs, environmental impacts, and societal impacts. Communicating pavement issues with decision-makers and the public.

ttp.name: — ITS Transportation Seminar Series
ttp.description: Course Description: Transportation seminars by guest speakers, on varied topics.

ttp.name: — Transportation Orientation Seminar
ttp.description: Course Description: Ten weeks of seminars, introducing various topics in transportation research and education, focusing on topics of particular interest at UC Davis.

ttp.name: — Professionalism, Leadership, & Ethics
ttp.description: Course Description: Speakers from industry, government, academia, and NGOs will lead discussions about succeeding and performing in the professional world. They will address leadership, ethics, and other workplace issues.

ttp.name: — Selected Topics in Transportation Technology & Policy
ttp.description: Course Description: Directed group study of special topics with instruction carried out through lecture or laboratory, or a combination of both.

ttp.name: — Selected Topics in Transportation Technology & Policy
ttp.description: Course Description: Directed group study of special topics with instruction carried out lecture or laboratory, or a combination of both.

ttp.name: — Graduate Research Group Conference
ttp.description: Course Description: Research problems, progress, and techniques in transportation.

ttp.name: — Internship in TTP
ttp.description: Course Description: Supervised work experience in transportation studies.
ttp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; second year standing; approval of project prior to period of internship.

ttp.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
ttp.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.

was.name: — Gun Violence
was.description: Course Description: Gun violence, viewed from the perspectives of criminology and public health. Topics include personal and societal contributing factors and critical assessment of potential solutions.

was.name: — Internship in the UC Davis Washington Program
was.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Internship in Washington, DC with associated, supervised research project.
was.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): WAS 193 (can be concurrent); junior or senior standing, admission in the UC Davis Washington Program. WAS 193 required concurrently.

was.name: — Washington Center Research Seminar
was.description: Course Description: Core academic component of Washington Program offered every quarter. Topics coordinated with internships. Research draws on resources uniquely available in Washington, DC. Supervised preparation of extensive paper.

uwp.name: — Introduction to Academic Literacies
uwp.description: Course Description: Introduction to reading and composing processes and key rhetorical concepts for academic literacies. Multiple drafts of composing projects in a variety of genres and modes with feedback from peers and the instructor.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

uwp.name: — Writers’ Workshop
uwp.description: Course Description: Writing course focuses on the development of writing and revision strategies, exploring ways to understand a writing task; to develop appropriate content for a writing task; to revise content to reflect competence as a communicator.

uwp.name: — Introduction to Academic Literacies: Online
uwp.description: Course Description: Introduction to reading and composing processes and key rhetorical concepts for academic literacies. Multiple drafts of composing projects in a variety of genres and modes with feedback from peers and the instructor.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

uwp.name: — Introduction to Academic Literacies
uwp.description: Course Description: Introduction to reading and composing processes and key rhetorical concepts for academic literacies. Multiple drafts of composing projects in a variety of genres and modes with feedback from peers and the instructor.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of Entry Level Writing Requirement (ELWR).

uwp.name: — Practices in College Reading & Writing
uwp.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Development of skills required for success in college-level writing across genres and disciplines. Integrates reading, critical thinking, and written communication, using texts from across the curriculum.

uwp.name: — Entry Level Writing: Practices in College Reading & Writing for Multilingual Writers
uwp.description: Course Description: Development of multilingual writers' composition and English language skills across genres and disciplines. Integrates college-level reading, critical thinking, and written communication, using texts from across the curriculum.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Enrollment via campus placement (using the English Language Placement Exam or Analytical Writing Placement Exam) or after successful completion of UWP 022.

uwp.name: — Practices in College Reading & Writing for Multilingual Writers
uwp.description: Course Description: Development of multilingual writers' composition and English language skills across genres and disciplines. Integrates college-level reading, critical thinking, and written communication, using texts from across the curriculum.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Enrollment via campus placement (using the English Language Placement Exam or Analytical Writing Placement Exam) or after successful completion of UWP 022.

uwp.name: — Practices in College Reading & Writing
uwp.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Development of skills required for success in college-level writing across genres and disciplines. Integrates reading, critical thinking, and written communication, using texts from across the curriculum.

uwp.name: — Practices in College Reading & Writing
uwp.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Development of skills required for success in college-level writing across genres and disciplines. Integrates reading, critical thinking, and written communication, using texts from across the curriculum.

uwp.name: — Introduction to Professional Writing Studies
uwp.description: Course Description: Introduction to writing as an object of study and to theories and research in the field. Survey of how writing is created, disseminated, and used in private, public, and academic contexts.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y; or the equivalent.

uwp.name: — Popular Science & Technology Writing
uwp.description: Course Description: Positioning of science and technology in society as reflected and constructed in popular texts. Topics include genre theory, demarcation, rhetorical figures, forms of qualitative and quantitative reasoning, and the epistemic role of popularization in science.

uwp.name: — Writing & Visual Rhetoric
uwp.description: Course Description: Introduction to writing needs, conventions, and genres in design contexts. Emphasis on applying critical reading, analysis, and writing skills to designed products, such as graphics, visual communications, and clothes, and designed spaces, such as exhibitions and interior architecture.

uwp.name: — Video Game Rhetorics
uwp.description: Course Description: Examination of video games as rhetorical texts whose meaning is produced through complex interplay of procedures, narratives, rules, and context. Writing about video games using critical perspectives and analytic methods.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better.

uwp.name: — Principles & Practices of Rhetoric
uwp.description: Course Description: Rhetorical principles for written communication—such as audience, purpose, and genre—as well as practical application of rhetoric in both analyzing persuasive discourse and composing across a variety of genres.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (UWP 001 C- or better; or UWP 001Y C- or better; or UWP 001V C- or better); ENL 003 C- or better; COM 001 C- or better; COM 002 C- or better; COM 003 C- or better; COM 004 C- or better; NAS 005 C- or better.

uwp.name: — Oral English for International Students
uwp.description: Course Description: Intensive work in oral English for international students, to increase fluency, accuracy, and use of appropriate discourse strategies in academic settings; e.g., seminar, discussion, laboratory. Training in segmental features of English sounds, intonation, stress, non-verbal cues, and register.

uwp.name: — Introduction to Academic Reading & Writing for Multilingual Students
uwp.description: Course Description: Reading and writing paragraphs and short multi-paragraph texts for academic purposes. Suitable for students whose primary home language was not English.

uwp.name: — Intermediate Academic Reading & Writing for Multilingual Students
uwp.description: Course Description: Reading and writing short multi-paragraph texts for academic purposes. Suitable for students whose primary home language was not English.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 021.

uwp.name: — English Structures & Strategies in Academic Writing
uwp.description: Course Description: Practice in academic writing designed to prepare undergraduate students from language backgrounds other than English for successful academic work. Development of academic writing, critical thinking, and reading skills. Development of clear, accurate language for presenting an effective argument.

uwp.name: — Academic Writing for ESL Students
uwp.description: Course Description: Writing skills necessary for upper division courses, including skills crucial to writing lab and project reports, summaries, critiques, abstracts, and responses to exam questions. Includes practice with the syntax, grammar, and vocabulary characteristics of academic writing.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

uwp.name: — Reading in Scientific & Technical Subjects for ESL Students
uwp.description: Course Description: Instruction and practice in reading scientific and technical texts. Techniques for comprehending and analyzing grammatical and organizational patterns. Notetaking skills, summarizing, vocabulary enrichment.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

uwp.name: — Persuasive Writing for Multilingual Students
uwp.description: Course Description: Instruction in analyzing style of persuasive texts, using appropriate vocabulary, and applying English grammatical structures in argumentation. Suitable for multilingual students desiring additional instruction in persuasive English writing.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better.

uwp.name: — Research Writing for Multilingual Students
uwp.description: Course Description: Reading and writing effectively in various research genres across the disciplines. Suitable for multilingual students desiring additional instruction in the linguistic and rhetorical features of research writing in English for academic purposes.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better.

uwp.name: — Style in the Essay
uwp.description: Course Description: Principles of style, language, and structure in the essay. Analysis and development of voice and genre, including sentence revision for force and clarity, and development of effective paragraphs and essays.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; or equivalent.

uwp.name: — Writing Research Papers
uwp.description: Course Description: Principles of research writing. Analysis and development of research topics and effective arguments, including critical reading, analysis, integration, and documentation of source material.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; or equivalent.

uwp.name: — Internship in Writing
uwp.description: Course Description: Internships in fields where students can practice their skills.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y or ENL 003.

uwp.name: — Directed Group Study
uwp.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y or ENL 003; or equivalent course; consent of instructor.

uwp.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
uwp.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y or ENL 003; or equivalent course; consent of instructor.

uwp.name: — Genre Theory & Professional Writing
uwp.description: Course Description: Introduction to discipline of professional writing. Examination of writing as a social practice, using genre theory as a conceptual framework. Analysis of how genres function rhetorically in specific contexts and how social systems both shape and are shaped by genres.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y); UWP 010; or the equivalent of UWP 001.

uwp.name: — Advanced Composition
uwp.description: Course Description: Instruction for students in all disciplines in advanced principles of academic and professional writing. Focus on writing tasks both within and beyond the academy. May be taught abroad.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Advanced Composition
uwp.description: Course Description: Instruction for students in all disciplines in advanced principles of academic and professional writing. Focus on writing tasks both within and beyond the academy.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Advanced Composition
uwp.description: Course Description: Instruction for students in all disciplines in advanced principles of academic and professional writing. Focus on writing tasks both within and beyond the academy.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Writing in the Disciplines: Special Topics
uwp.description: Course Description: Advanced instruction in writing in that discipline and practice in effective styles of communication.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Writing in the Disciplines: Biology
uwp.description: Course Description: Advanced instruction in writing in biology.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Writing in the Disciplines: History
uwp.description: Course Description: Advanced instruction in writing in history.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Writing in the Disciplines: International Relations
uwp.description: Course Description: Advanced instruction in writing in international relations.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Writing in the Disciplines: Engineering
uwp.description: Course Description: Advanced instruction in writing in engineering.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Writing in the Disciplines: Food Science & Technology
uwp.description: Course Description: Advanced instruction in writing in food science & technology.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Writing in the Disciplines: Environmental Writing
uwp.description: Course Description: Advanced instruction in writing and practice in effective styles of communication in the fields of environmental study, policy, or advocacy.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Writing in the Disciplines: Human Development & Psychology
uwp.description: Course Description: Advanced instruction in writing and practice in effective styles of communication in Human Development & Psychology.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Writing in the Disciplines: Ethnic Studies
uwp.description: Course Description: Advanced instruction in cross-disciplinary writing about race and ethnicity and practice in effective styles of communication.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Writing in the Disciplines: Fine Arts
uwp.description: Course Description: Advanced instruction in writing about the arts and practice in effective styles of communication.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Writing in the Disciplines: Sociology
uwp.description: Course Description: Advanced instruction in writing and practice in effective styles of communication in Sociology and related academic and professional fields.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Writing in the Disciplines: Film Studies
uwp.description: Course Description: Advanced instruction in writing about film and practice in effective styles of communication.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Writing in the Disciplines: Community & Regional Development
uwp.description: Course Description: Advanced instruction in writing in the Community & Regional Development discipline and practice in effective styles of communication.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Writing in the Disciplines: Anthropology
uwp.description: Course Description: Advanced instruction in writing and practice in effective styles of communication in Anthropology and related academic and professional fields.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; 4 or 5 on AP English Lit and Comp exam; or 6 or better on IB HL English Exam.

uwp.name: — Writing in Human Rights Studies
uwp.description: Course Description: Rhetorical concepts and processes applied to writing in Human Rights Studies through exploration of policy briefs, academic articles, journalism, and testimony. How authors use writing to inform readers, press the audience to empathize with others, reflect on the past, learn about injustices, and propose solutions.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better; or UWP 001V C- or better; or UWP 001Y C- or better; or ENL 003 C- or better; or NAS 005 C- or better; or COM 001 C- or better; or COM 002 C- or better; or COM 003 C- or better; or COM 004 C- or better; upper-division standing.

uwp.name: — Writing in the Professions: Business Writing
uwp.description: Course Description: Effective communication in and for organizations, including corporations, government agencies, and non-profit. Suitable for students entering careers such as management, public relations, and grant writing.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Writing in the Professions: Business Writing
uwp.description: Course Description: Effective communication in and for organizations, including corporations, government agencies, and nonprofit. Suitable for students entering careers such as management, public relations, and grant writing.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Writing in the Professions: Law
uwp.description: Course Description: Advanced principles of critical thinking, argumentation, and style, with special emphasis on their application in the legal profession. Suitable for students planning careers in law, business, administration, or management.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Writing in the Professions: Journalism
uwp.description: Course Description: Non-fiction for magazines and newspapers, with attention to style and language. Emphasis on research, interviewing, market analysis, and query letters.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Writing in the Professions: Elementary & Secondary Education
uwp.description: Course Description: Advanced expository writing in the contemporary American classroom. Strongly recommended for teaching credential candidates.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Writing in the Professions: Science
uwp.description: Course Description: Writing abstracts, research proposals, scientific papers, other forms of scientific communication. Presenting data graphically. Primarily for students engaged in or planning careers in basic or applied research.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division standing or enrollment in a graduate science curriculum.

uwp.name: — Writing in the Professions: Health
uwp.description: Course Description: Advanced expository writing common in the health professions, emphasizing effective communication between the writer and different audiences. Topics relate to health, disability, and disease. Suitable for students planning careers in professions such as medicine, dentistry, physical therapy, optometry.
