uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Writing in the Professions: Health
uwp.description: Course Description: Advanced expository writing common in the health professions, emphasizing effective communication between the writer and different audiences. Topics relate to health, disability, and disease. Suitable for students planning careers in professions such as medicine, dentistry, physical therapy, optometry.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better; UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Writing in the Professions: Internships
uwp.description: Course Description: Advanced instruction in writing in the workplace, including public and private sectors, government agencies, profit and non-profit organizations. Collaborative work and practice in effective styles of communication. May be taught abroad.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Writing in the Professions: Writing for Social Justice
uwp.description: Course Description: Advanced instruction in writing for Social Justice, using an interdisciplinary approach combining feminist, critical race, ethnic, cultural, and transnational studies; practice in techniques of research and styles of communication for diverse audiences. Suitable for activists in community organizing, non-profits, politics.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Writing in the Professions: Technical Writing
uwp.description: Course Description: Communicating effectively about technology and other technical subjects to varied audiences for varied purposes. Suitable for students entering professions that require communicating technical information to subject matter experts, managers, technicians, and non-specialists.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 C- or better or UWP 001V C- or better or UWP 001Y C- or better or ENL 003 C- or better or COM 001 C- or better or COM 002 C- or better or COM 003 C- or better or COM 004 C- or better or NAS 005 C- or better; and upper division standing.

uwp.name: — English Grammar
uwp.description: Course Description: Survey of present-day English grammar as informed by contemporary linguistic theories. The major syntactic structures of English; their variation across dialects, styles, and registers; their development; and their usefulness in describing the conventions of English.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y or ENL 003 or LIN 001 or LIN 001Y; or consent of instructor.

uwp.name: — Specialized Genres in Professional Writing
uwp.description: Course Description: Instruction in the elements and practices of professional writing in specialized genres. May be taught abroad.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Satisfaction of the upper division writing requirement.

uwp.name: — Specialized Topics in Journalism
uwp.description: Course Description: Instruction in the elements and practices of advanced journalism.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Satisfaction of the upper division writing requirement.

uwp.name: — Specialized Topics in Journalism: Investigative Journalism
uwp.description: Course Description: Instruction in the elements and practices of in-depth investigative journalism.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Satisfaction of the upper division writing requirement.

uwp.name: — Specialized Topics in Journalism: Science Journalism
uwp.description: Course Description: Instruction in the elements and practices of science journalism.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Satisfaction of the upper division writing requirement.

uwp.name: — Introduction to Professional Editing
uwp.description: Course Description: Introduction to general editing practices and principles, with an emphasis on professional editing in organizational contexts, including academia and the workplace. Extensive practice in copy, comprehensive, and collaborative editing.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): satisfaction of the upper division writing requirement.

uwp.name: — Writing Center Research, Theory, & Practice for Peer Writing Tutors
uwp.description: Course Description: Writing course explores writing center research with an emphasis on research-based theories and practices useful to student writing center peer tutors.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ELWR (Entry Level Writing Requirement) fulfillment required.

uwp.name: — Rhetorical Approaches to Scientific & Technological Issues
uwp.description: Course Description: Application of rhetorical theories to scientific issues. Topics include: Rhetorical dimensions of scientific knowledge-making; scientific voice; rhetorical figures in science; incommensurability and demarcation; epistemology, definition, and classification; science wars; models of scientific literacy and accommodation, and implications for risk communication.

uwp.name: — History of Scientific Writing
uwp.description: Course Description: History of scientific writing from the 17th century to the present; origins and evolution of scientific genres; role of scientific writing in producing scientific knowledge; discursive differences between disciplines; emergence of English as a global language of science.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Digital Rhetorics
uwp.description: Course Description: Rhetorical concepts and processes applied to digital environments with an emphasis on user experience, universal design, and writing for networked publics. Application of rhetorical theory as both an analytic method and as a heuristic for the production of digital texts and performances.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 010 C- or better; UWP 015 C- or better.

uwp.name: — Rhetorics & Culture
uwp.description: Course Description: Relationship between written communication and cultural practices, epistemologies, and genres. Producing texts for different professional and community writing scenarios that leverage cultural rhetoric strategies.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 010 C- or better; UWP 015 C- or better.

uwp.name: — Capstone Portfolio Seminar
uwp.description: Course Description: Capstone course for majors. Synthesis and application of  rhetorical concepts learned in the major. Development of professional digital and print portfolio for graduate school and career applications.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 100.

uwp.name: — Internship in Writing
uwp.description: Course Description: Internships in fields where students can practice their skills. May be taught abroad.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y or ENL 003; or equivalent course; consent of instructor.

uwp.name: — Tutoring in Writing
uwp.description: Course Description: Tutoring one-on-one or leading small voluntary discussion groups affiliated with a writing course.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Community Tutoring in Writing
uwp.description: Course Description: Field experience, with individuals or in K-12 classroom instruction, focusing on reading- and writing-to-learn strategies in any subject area.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; upper division standing.

uwp.name: — Directed Group Study
uwp.description: Course Description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 001 or UWP 001V or UWP 001Y or ENL 003; or equivalent course; consent of instructor.

uwp.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
uwp.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

uwp.name: — Rhetorical Approaches to Genre Study
uwp.description: Course Description: Using genre theory and methods of analysis to understand and prepare to do research on different types of writing in varying academic and professional contexts. Emphasis on problems in organizational, professional, and/or interdisciplinary communication.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

uwp.name: — English for International/ESL Graduate Students
uwp.description: Course Description: Multi-skills ESL course designed to help international/ESL students improve their English language skills for successful academic study. Emphasis on writing, speaking, listening, reading, and academic culture.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

uwp.name: — Writing for International Graduate Students
uwp.description: Course Description: Focuses on writing needed for academic work, including summaries, critiques, research & grant proposals, memos, resumes, and research papers. Includes a review of grammar needed for writing and some focus on reading skills and American vocabulary and idioms.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

uwp.name: — Writing Assessment
uwp.description: Course Description: Examines key testing and measurement concepts; the history of writing assessment; and relationships among writing tests and methods of teaching writing; the impacts of Information and Communication Technology (ICT), and how educational policies both drive and respond to writing assessments.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

uwp.name: — Writing Program Administration
uwp.description: Course Description: Theories, models, and procedures of writing programs, primarily in higher education. Developmental, first-year, and advanced writing programs, writing centers, writing-across-the-curriculum programs, writing minors and majors, and graduate programs in rhetoric and composition.

uwp.name: — Theory & Research in Response to Student Writing
uwp.description: Course Description: Intensive focus on the critical topic of response or feedback to student writers. Coverage of philosophy, theory, and empirical research on teacher written feedback, teacher-student writing conferences, peer response, and error correction.

uwp.name: — Literacy & Technology
uwp.description: Course Description: Examines how the physical qualities of texts offer different affordances during production and reception; grounds these discussions in the development of literacy practices and writing technologies from ancient to contemporary; creates frameworks for research into literacy, teaching, and textual technologies.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

uwp.name: — Second Language Writing
uwp.description: Course Description: Traces the history of second language writing theory and research on second language writers in a variety of academic and professional contexts. Emphasis on writer characteristics, texts, and contexts.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

uwp.name: — Journal Editing Workshop: Writing on the Edge
uwp.description: Course Description: Reading and critiquing manuscript submissions. Discussing relevant work in the field of writing studies. Applying principles of professional editing. Developmental editing, copy-editing, and typesetting of accepted manuscripts. Soliciting articles and communicating with contributors. Students encouraged to enroll both quarters.

uwp.name: — Directed Group Study
uwp.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

uwp.name: — Individual Study
uwp.description: Course Description: Individual study.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Graduate standing.

uwp.name: — Theory & Practice of Teaching University-Level Composition
uwp.description: Course Description: Examination of current theories and practices in teaching of writing. Practical application to undergraduate writing courses. Emphasis on designing assignments and class sequences, and responding to student writing. Examination of impact of cultural, technological and theoretical changes on composition pedagogy.

uwp.name: — Oral English for ESL Students
uwp.description: Course Description: Intensive work in oral English for non-native English-speaking students, particularly international student teaching assistants, to increase fluency, accuracy, and use of appropriate discourse strategies in academic settings; e.g., seminar, discussion, laboratory.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Open only to non-native speakers of English with priority enrollment to international student teaching assistants; completion of any required ESL courses or consent of instructor.

uwp.name: — Teaching Expository Writing
uwp.description: Course Description: Discussion of problems related to teaching expository writing at the university level, with special emphasis on teaching reading and writing skills and responding to student papers.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): UWP 390; graduate standing; appointment as Teaching Assistant in the Composition Program; or the equivalent of UWP 390.

uwp.name: — Theory & Practice of Teaching Writing Across the Curriculum
uwp.description: Course Description: Professional development in the teaching of writing for TAs across disciplines, including theories of writing, assignment design, responding and grading, and supporting multilingual writers. Supports TAs in their current contexts and prepares them to teach writing as future faculty.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate Standing.

uwp.name: — Teaching Multilingual Writers
uwp.description: Course Description: Preparing teachers of university-level second language writers, whether in composition courses or courses in other disciplines with a substantial writing component. Suitable for graduate students and advanced undergraduates.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or advanced undergraduate standing; recommended: UWP 390, LIN 1, ENL 106/LIN 106/UWP 106.

uwp.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
uwp.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.
uwp.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

uro.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
uro.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

uro.name: — Office Urology
uro.description: Course Description: Introduction to ambulatory care of urologic patients including basic therapeutic and diagnostic procedures from case material referred to private clinic. Management of urinary tract infection will be emphasized.
uro.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Fourth-year medical students with consent of instructor.

uro.name: — Urology Clinical Clerkship
uro.description: Course Description: Clinical experience in diagnosis and treatment of urologic disease. Student will work closely with house staff, participate in conferences and surgery, and perform initial patient evaluation on new patients.
uro.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; third-year medical student; physical diagnosis or the equivalent.

uro.name: — Externship in Urology
uro.description: Course Description: Under supervision, student acting as intern will assume full inpatient responsibility including admission history, physical examination, management of hospitalization, and participate in surgical procedures, outpatient clinic and learning diagnostic and therapeutic procedures.
uro.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; fourth-year medical students.

uro.name: — Research in Urology
uro.description: Course Description: Research in oncology, male infertility, urodynamics, neurogenic bladder. Unique opportunity to apply recent technologies (nuclear medicine resonance, flow cytometry, recombinant DNA) in investigation, diagnosis and treatment of GU cancer, infectious disease, male infertility and development of genitourinary bioprosthetics.
uro.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Medical or veterinary medical students with consent of instructor.

ven.name: — Introduction to Viticulture
ven.description: Course Description: Fundamental principles of biology and culture of the grapevine including taxonomy, morphology, physiology, distribution, domestication, utilization, propagation, production systems, harvesting, and storage and processing of grapes. Successful completion should prepare students for upper division courses in viticulture.

ven.name: — Introduction to Winemaking
ven.description: Course Description: Overview of the history of wine, viticulture, fermentation, winery operations, the physiology of wine consumption, wines produced in California and other major wine-producing regions and the sensory evaluation of wine. May be taught abroad.

ven.name: — Lower Division Seminar
ven.description: Course Description: Introduction to current issues surrounding wine and health as they relate to diet, nutrition, and toxicology.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

ven.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
ven.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.

ven.name: — Viticultural Practices
ven.description: Course Description: Identification, cultivation, and use of the major wine, table, raisin, and rootstock cultivars. Includes practices specific to the fall such as fruit contracts, maturity sampling, harvesting, cover crops, and soil-pests. One field trip required.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): VEN 002.

ven.name: — Viticultural Practices
ven.description: Course Description: Theory, principles, and practices of pruning and grapevine propagation. Plant materials and the certification process, weed control and weed identification, wood diseases, and frost protection. One field trip required.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): VEN 002.

ven.name: — Viticultural Practices
ven.description: Course Description: Field oriented experience in the principles and practices of grapevine production, including vineyard establishment, vine training, trellising, canopy management practices, irrigation and water management, and methods of crop adjustment for improvement of fruit quality. One field trip required.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): VEN 002.

ven.name: — Grapevine Growth & Physiology
ven.description: Course Description: Botanical aspects including morphology and domestication will precede lectures covering flower development and energy budget concepts. Impact of physiological variables such as photosynthesis translocation, mineral nutrition, and water relations on fruit ripening and composition will be covered.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): VEN 002.

ven.name: — World Viticulture
ven.description: Course Description: Study of the diversity of viticulture, both geographical and historical. History of grape growing and its spread throughout the world will be covered, along with discussions of current viticultural practices in different parts of the world, including California.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing.

ven.name: — Critical Evaluation of Wines of the World
ven.description: Course Description: Critical analysis of wines produced in different parts of the world with emphasis on the relationship between sensory properties of the wines and factors associated with their place of origin.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): VEN 111 required concurrently.

ven.name: — Soils in Viticulture
ven.description: Course Description: Landscape distribution, physical and chemical processes in viticultural soils. Site evaluation procedures, best soil management practices, vineyard fertilization, and soil health monitoring.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (CHE 002B or CHE 002BH); BIS 002A; (PHY 001A,  PHY 001B (can be concurrent)) or PHY 007A (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

ven.name: — Fermented Foods
ven.description: Course Description: Physiology, biochemistry, and genetics of microorganisms important in food fermentations. How microorganisms are used in fermentations and how raw materials are converted into finished fermented foods and beverages.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 103; MIC 102; or consent of instructor.

ven.name: — Raisin & Table Grape Production
ven.description: Course Description: Overview of the raisin and table grape industries in California and other production areas of the world. Cultural practices associated with raisin and table grape production will also be discussed.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): VEN 002.

ven.name: — Grapevine Pests, Diseases & Disorders
ven.description: Course Description: Various pests and diseases of vineyards throughout California. Pest/disease identification and control methods (to include sampling techniques) also will be discussed. Integrated management approach to pest control methods will be emphasized.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): VEN 002.

ven.name: — Analysis of Musts & Wines
ven.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Fundamental principles of analytical chemistry as they relate to specific methods used in winemaking.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 002C; PLS 021 or PLS 201V; (CHE 008B or CHE 118B or CHE 128B).

ven.name: — Analysis of Musts & Wines Laboratory
ven.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Fundamental principles of analytical chemistry as they relate to specific methods used in winemaking. Laboratory exercises demonstrating various chemical, physical and biochemical methods. Data will be analyzed and results interpreted in weekly lab reports; includes student-designed independent project and written report.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): VEN 123 (can be concurrent); CHE 002C; PLS 021; (CHE 008B or CHE 118B or CHE 128B).

ven.name: — Wine Production
ven.description: Course Description: Principles and practices of making standard types of wines, with special reference to grape varieties used and methods of vinification.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): VEN 003; VEN 123 (can be concurrent); (BIS 102 or BIS 105).

ven.name: — Wine Production Laboratory
ven.description: Course Description: Current technologies used in production of California table wines; analysis and monitoring of impact of fermentation variables on microbial performance and product quality; student-designed independent research project.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): VEN 124 (can be concurrent).

ven.name: — Wine Types & Sensory Evaluation
ven.description: Course Description: Principles of sensory evaluation and application to wines. Factors influencing wine flavor, data from sensory analysis of model solutions.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 120 or STA 106.

ven.name: — Sensory Evaluation of Wine Laboratory
ven.description: Course Description: Sensory evaluation of wines and model systems using discrimination tests, ranking, descriptive analysis and time-intensity analysis. Data will be analyzed by appropriate statistical tests and the results interpreted in extensive weekly lab reports.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): VEN 125 (can be concurrent).

ven.name: — Wine Stability
ven.description: Course Description: Principles of equilibria and rates of physical and chemical reactions in wines; treatment of unstable components in wines by adsorption, ion exchange, refrigeration, filtration, and membrane processes; and protein, polysaccharide, tartrate, oxidative and color stabilities.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): VEN 124.

ven.name: — Wine Stability Laboratory
ven.description: Course Description: Practical application of principles of equilibria and rates of physical and chemical reactions to wine stability.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): VEN 126 (can be concurrent); VEN 123L; and consent of instructor.

ven.name: — Post-Fermentation Wine Processing Lab
ven.description: Course Description: Sensory and chemical impact of processing on wines; bench-scale analytical results to make and implement processing decisions; principles and theories of equipment operation and scale-up.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): VEN 123; VEN 123L; VEN 126; VEN 126L; VEN 135 (can be concurrent); or consent of instructor.

ven.name: — Wine Microbiology
ven.description: Course Description: Nature, development, physiology, biochemistry and control of yeasts and bacteria involved in the making, aging and spoilage of wine.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (VEN 123,  VEN 124,  MIC 102,  MIC 103L); VEN 125, VEN 126 recommended.

ven.name: — Wine Microbiology Laboratory
ven.description: Course Description: Nature, development, physiology, biochemistry and control of yeasts and bacteria involved in the making, aging and spoilage of wine.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): VEN 123; VEN 124; VEN 128 (can be concurrent); MIC 103L.

ven.name: — Wine Technology & Winery Systems
ven.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Process technologies and process systems that are used in modern commercial wineries. Lectures, demonstrations, problem solving sessions, and possible field trips. Includes grape preparation and fermentation equipment; post-fermentation processing equipment; winery utilities, cleaning systems, and waste treatment.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 021; MAT 016A; MAT 016B; ((PHY 001A,  PHY 001B) or PHY 007A).

ven.name: — Distilled Beverage Technology
ven.description: Course Description: Distillation principles and practices; production technology of brandy, whiskey, rum, vodka, gin, and other distilled beverages; characteristics of raw materials, fermentation, distillation, and aging.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 008B; FST 110A.

ven.name: — Grape & Wine Industry Regulation
ven.description: Course Description: Regulatory and legal issues related to grape growing and winemaking. State and federal regulations for production and sale of alcoholic beverages. Land use, food and chemical safety regulations, crop insurance, wine distribution and importation, and direct-to-consumer sales.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ven.name: — Readings in Enology
ven.description: Course Description: Critical evaluation of selected monographs in enology. Discussion leadership rotates among the students.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): VEN 003.

ven.name: — Winemaking Seminar
ven.description: Course Description: Outside speakers on a specific winemaking topic chosen for the quarter. Discussion with the speaker hosted by the faculty member(s) in charge.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): VEN 003.

ven.name: — Internship
ven.description: Course Description: Work experience related to Fermentation Science (Enology) or Plant Science (Viticulture) majors. Internships must be approved and supervised by a member of the department or major faculty, but are arranged by the student.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; completion of 84 units.

ven.name: — Directed Group Study
ven.description: Course Description: Directed group study. May be taught abroad.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ven.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
ven.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ven.name: — Introduction to Scientific Methods
ven.description: Course Description: Processes involved in conducting scientific research. Topics covered will include conducting literature review, formulating hypotheses, and analyzing and reporting results. Students will complete an annotated bibliography and complete a written and oral research proposal.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

ven.name: — Grape Development & Composition
ven.description: Course Description: Anatomy, physiology and biochemistry of grape berry development, with emphasis on the development of grape composition relevant to winemaking.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 102,  BIS 103) or BIS 105.

ven.name: — Flavor Chemistry of Foods & Beverages
ven.description: Course Description: Become familiar with basic principles of flavor chemistry, analysis, and formation in fresh and processed foods. Required to read and critically evaluate flavor chemistry literature.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): CHE 008B; ((VEN 123,  VEN 123L) or FST 103); or consent of instructor.

ven.name: — Sensometrics
ven.description: Course Description: Experimental design and statistical analysis, including multivariate analysis, for both sensory and instrumental data in enology and food-related studies.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): FST 117; ((VEN 125,  VEN 125L) or (FST 107A or FST 107B)); or equivalent to FTS 117.

ven.name: — Sustainable Vineyard Development
ven.description: Course Description: Application of plant, meteorological, soil, water, GIS, and economic sciences to sustainable vineyard development. Preparation of a comprehensive study to determine the viticultural and economic feasibility of a given site for raisin, table, or wine grape production.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (VEN 101A,  VEN 101B,  VEN 101C); (VEN 115 or VEN 118); or consent of instructor.

ven.name: — Field & GIS Evaluation of Soils
ven.description: Course Description: Principles and practices used to evaluate agricultural soils in the field, including soil pits, soil cores, electrical conductivity meters, ground penetrating radar, geomorphology and surface terrain analysis. Use of geographic information sciences, soil databases, digital elevation models and geostatistics.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): PLS 120; (PLS 205 or PLS 206); (SSC 100 or SSC 105 or SSC 107); VEN 101C; consent of instructor; ABT 180 is recommended.

ven.name: — Natural Products of Wine
ven.description: Course Description: Structure, occurrence, and changes due to wine production to the natural products found in wine. Chemicals with a sensory impact will be emphasized, including flavonoids and other phenolics, terpenes and norisoprenoids, pyrazines, oak volatiles and other wine constituents.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): VEN 123; VEN 124; or natural products background, and consent of instructor.

ven.name: — Instrumental Analysis of Must & Wine
ven.description: Course Description: Theory and practice of instrumental analysis of wines and musts. mphasis on the principles of analytical techniques (e.g., CE, GC, HPLC, Mass Spectrometry) and factors determining correct choice of instrumental method.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): VEN 123 or FST 103; ((BIS 102 and BIS 103) or BIS 105), (CHE 107B or CHE 115) recommended.

ven.name: — Advances in the Science of Winemaking
ven.description: Course Description: Selected topics in the science and technology of winemaking. Topics will be drawn from current research of participating enology and viticulture faculty. Critical analysis of the technical content of published material will be emphasized.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): VEN 125; VEN 126; or consent of instructor; graduate standing.

ven.name: — Advanced Sensory Analysis of Wines
ven.description: Course Description: Sensory descriptive analysis experiments will be designed and conducted using standard sensory science methods.Data will be analyzed by analyses of variance, principal component analyses and generalized Procrustes analysis to evaluate the judges performance and interpret the significance of the results.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ((VEN 124,  VEN 125) or FST 107); AMR 120; or the equivalent.

ven.name: — Winery Design
ven.description: Course Description: Design of wineries. Includes process calculations, equipment selection, process layout and building choice and siting. Project scheduling, capital costs, and ten-year cash flow analysis for the winery. One field trip required.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): VEN 124; VEN 135; or consent of instructor.

ven.name: — Critical Evaluation of Scientific Literature
ven.description: Course Description: Contemporary research topics in biological sciences. Discussion of recent research articles in a special topic area chosen by instructor. Intended to develop skills in critical evaluation of scientific publications.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ven.name: — Seminar
ven.description: Course Description: Seminar.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ven.name: — Advanced Research Conference
ven.description: Course Description: Planning and results of research programs, proposals, and experiments. Discussion and critical evaluation of original research being conducted by the group. Discussion led by individual research instructors for research group.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

ven.name: — Advanced Viticulture
ven.description: Course Description: Critical evaluation of scientific and popular literature on selected topics of current interest that relate viticulture to fruit or wine sensory attributes or quality.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): VEN 110; VEN 116; VEN 124; VEN 125; VEN 210 recommended.

ven.name: — Advanced Internship
ven.description: Course Description: Work experience related to Fermentation Science (Enology) or Plant Science (Viticulture) majors. Internships must be approved and supervised by a graduate group faculty member or students major professor, but are arranged by the student.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): VEN 123; VEN 123L; VEN 124; VEN 124L; VEN 125; VEN 125L; VEN 126; VEN 126L; VEN 128; VEN 128L; and consent of instructor.

ven.name: — Tutoring in Viticulture & Enology
ven.description: Course Description: Designed for graduate students who desire teaching experience, but are not teaching assistants. Student contact primarily in laboratory or discussion sections, and under direction of a faculty member.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; graduate standing.

ven.name: — Group Study
ven.description: Course Description: Group study.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ven.name: — Research
ven.description: Course Description: Research.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

ven.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
ven.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.
ven.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

wfc.name: — Wildlife Ecology & Conservation
wfc.description: Course Description: Introduction to the ecology and conservation of vertebrates. Complexity and severity of world problems in conserving biological diversity.

wfc.name: — Natural History of California's Wild Vertebrates
wfc.description: Course Description: Examination of the natural history of California's wild vertebrates (fish, amphibians, reptiles, birds, and mammals), including their biogeography, systematics, ecology and conservation status.

wfc.name: — Introduction to Conservation Biology
wfc.description: Course Description: Introduction to conservation biology including both biological and social issues related to the loss of species and habitats. Intended for students with no background in biological sciences.

wfc.name: — Internship
wfc.description: Course Description: Work experience off and on campus in all subject areas offered in the department. Internships supervised by a member of the faculty.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor; lower division standing.

wfc.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
wfc.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

wfc.name: — Field Methods in Wildlife, Fish, & Conservation Biology
wfc.description: Course Description: Introduction to field methods for monitoring and studying wild vertebrates and their habitats, with an emphasis on ecology and conservation. Required weekend field trips.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EVE 101 (can be concurrent) or ESP 100 (can be concurrent); (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C); or equivalent course of EVE 101 or ESP 100 (can be taken concurrently), and consent of instructor.

wfc.name: — Field Research in Wildlife Ecology
wfc.description: Course Description: Field research in ecology of wild vertebrates in terrestrial environments; formulation of testable hypotheses, study design, introduction to research methodology, oral and written presentation of results. Limited enrollment.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. One upper division course in each of ecology, statistics, and either ornithology, mammalogy, or herpetology.

wfc.name: — Field Research in Wildlife Ecology: Laboratory
wfc.description: Course Description: Field research in ecology of wild vertebrates in terrestrial environments; testing ecological hypotheses through field research, application of research methodology, supervised independent research projects. Held between Labor Day and fall quarter.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): WFC 101 (can be concurrent); and consent of instructor.

wfc.name: — Field Studies in Fish Biology
wfc.description: Course Description: Emphasis on theory of quantitative fish capture methods and design of individual research projects on ecology, behavior, physiology or population biology of fishes.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Upper division course in each of ecology, aquatic biology, fish biology, and statistics.

wfc.name: — Field Studies in Fish Biology: Laboratory
wfc.description: Course Description: Field investigations of fish biology are emphasized including quantitative capture methods and individual research projects on ecology, behavior, physiology or population biology of fishes at the field site in relation to their habitats.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): WFC 102 (can be concurrent); and consent of instructor.

wfc.name: — Applied Statistics for Wildlife Research
wfc.description: Course Description: Introduction to basic statistical concepts and methods as tools for fish and wildlife research. Application of general guiding principles of developing research questions and projects, basic probability theory, statistical estimation (correlation, regression, ANOVA, Chi-square test) and hypothesis testing. Introduction of some specialized analytical techniques, such as population dynamics modeling and time series analysis.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MAT 016B or MAT 017B or MAT 021B); (WFC 010 or WFC 050); or consent of instructor.

wfc.name: — Biology & Conservation of Wild Mammals
wfc.description: Course Description: Origins, evolution, diversification, and geographical and ecological distributions of mammals. Morphological, physiological, reproductive, and behavioral adaptations of mammals to their environment.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C); (EVE 101 (can be concurrent) or ESP 100 (can be concurrent)); or equivalent course to ESP 100 or EVE 101.

wfc.name: — Laboratory in Biology & Conservation of Wild Mammals
wfc.description: Course Description: Laboratory exercises in the morphology, systematics, species identification, anatomy, and adaptations of wild mammals to different habitats.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): WFC 110 (can be concurrent); and consent of instructor.

wfc.name: — Biology & Conservation of Wild Birds
wfc.description: Course Description: Phylogeny, distribution, migration, reproduction, population dynamics, behavior and physiological ecology of wild birds. Emphasis on adaptations to environments, species interactions, management, and conservation.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; BIS 002B; BIS 002C; upper division ecology course recommended.

wfc.name: — Laboratory in Biology & Conservation of Wild Birds
wfc.description: Course Description: Laboratory exercises in bird species identification, anatomy, molts, age and sex, specialized adaptations, behavior, research, with emphasis on conservation of wild birds. Several weekend field trips, after class bird walks, and independent bird study are required.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): WFC 111 (can be concurrent); and consent of instructor.

wfc.name: — Biology & Conservation of Fishes
wfc.description: Course Description: Evolution, ecology, and conservation of marine and freshwater fishes.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; BIS 002B; BIS 002C; upper division ecology course recommended.

wfc.name: — Laboratory in Biology & Conservation of Fishes
wfc.description: Course Description: Morphology, taxonomy, conservation, and identification of marine and freshwater fishes with emphasis on California species.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): WFC 120 (can be concurrent); and consent of instructor.

wfc.name: — Physiology of Fishes
wfc.description: Course Description: Comparative physiology, growth, reproduction, behavior, and energy relations of fishes.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division courses in nutrition and physiology or consent of instructor.

wfc.name: — Population Dynamics & Estimation
wfc.description: Course Description: Description of bird, mammal and fish population dynamics, modeling philosophy, techniques for estimation of animal abundance (e.g., mark-recapture, change-inratio, etc.), mathematical models of populations (e.g., Leslie matrix, logistic, dynamic pool, stockrecruitment); case histories.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (MAT 016A,  MAT 016B); (STA 013 or STA 013Y); (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C); or the equivalent of STA 013; an upper division course in ecology.

wfc.name: — Sampling Animal Populations
wfc.description: Course Description: Introduction to major statistical modeling approaches for estimating animal population parameters, including: sample counts, distance sampling, repeated point counts (N-mixture modeling), capture-mark-recapture for closed and open populations, static and dynamic occupancy modeling, and richness estimation. Methods are embedded in the context of obtaining reliable estimates of abundance, survival, occurrence and other ecological parameters for management and conservation.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (STA 100 or WFC 103 or PLS 120); (EVE 101 or ESP 100); or equivalent; upper division standing.

wfc.name: — Tropical Ecology & Conservation
wfc.description: Course Description: Ecology and natural history of the tropics. Challenges and opportunities associated with tropical conservation. Design and communicate course-based research project.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EVE 101 or ESP 100.

wfc.name: — Conservation in Working Landscapes
wfc.description: Course Description: Ecology, natural history, and conservation of working landscapes. Critical evaluation of tradeoffs (and potential synergies) that arise when simultaneously pursuing conservation, food production, and human livelihood objectives in crop fields, pastures, settlements, forestry systems, and patches of semi-natural habitat.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002B; or consent of instructor; EVE 101 or ESP 100 recommended.

wfc.name: — Physiological Ecology of Wildlife
wfc.description: Course Description: Principles of physiological ecology, emphasizing vertebrates. Ecological, evolutionary, and behavioral perspectives on physiological mechanisms used by animals to adapt to their environment, including consideration of climate-change and other threats to biodiversity. Tropical, temperate, and polar ecosystems are highlighted.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EVE 101 or ESP 100; (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C); or equivalent course to ESP 100.

wfc.name: — Herpetology
wfc.description: Course Description: Evolution and ecology of the world’s diverse reptiles and amphibians. Emphasis on adaptations to environments, species interactions, management, and conservation.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; BIS 002B; BIS 002C; upper division ecology course recommended.

wfc.name: — Herpetology Laboratory
wfc.description: Course Description: Diagnostic characteristics and functional attributes of amphibians and reptiles, emphasizing ecological, bio-geographic and phylogenetic patterns. Field experience with common species of reptiles and amphibians in the Davis area.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): WFC 134 (can be concurrent); and consent of instructor.

wfc.name: — Ecology of Waterfowl & Game Birds
wfc.description: Course Description: Detailed examination of distribution, behavior, population dynamics, and management of waterfowl and upland game birds.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): WFC 111; or consent of instructor. WFC 111L strongly recommended.

wfc.name: — Behavioral Ecology
wfc.description: Course Description: Basic theories underlying the functional and evolutionary significance of behavior, and the role of ecological constraints. Supporting empirical evidence taken mainly from studies of wild vertebrates.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EVE 101 or ESP 100 (can be concurrent); (BIS 002A,  BIS 002B,  BIS 002C); or equivalent course.

wfc.name: — Marine Conservation Science
wfc.description: Course Description: Key differences between marine and terrestrial ecosystems, major stressors of marine ecosystems (e.g., fisheries, pollution, bioinvasions, climate change and habitat destruction) and their consequences. Laws and agencies responsible for addressing problems, and the policies used.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Course in introductory ecology.

wfc.name: — Urban Wildlife Ecology
wfc.description: Course Description: Introduction to the behavior, ecology, and evolution of wild animals in urban environments. Effects of urbanization on disease, fitness, and dynamics of animal populations. Conservation and conflict management efforts in urban settings.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; BIS 002B; BIS 002C; or the equivalent.

wfc.name: — Wildlife Ecology
wfc.description: Course Description: Ecology of wild vertebrates, including habitat selection, spatial organization, demography, population dynamics, competition, predation, herbivory, energetics, and community dynamics, set in the context of human-caused degradation of environments in North America.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002B; or equivalent.

wfc.name: — Ecology of Human-Wildlife Conflicts
wfc.description: Course Description: Ecological approaches to managing wild vertebrates that come into conflict with agriculture, public health, or the conservation of biodiversity.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002B; or equivalent.

wfc.name: — Wildlife Ecotoxicology
wfc.description: Course Description: Various forms of environmental pollution in relation to fish and wildlife, the effects and mechanisms of pollutants, effects on individuals and systems, laboratory and field ecotoxicology, examples/case histories, philosophical/management considerations.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Introductory courses in organic chemistry, ecology, and physiology, or consent of instructor; ETX 101 recommended.

wfc.name: — Conservation Biology
wfc.description: Course Description: Introduction to conservation biology and background to the biological issues and controversies surrounding loss of species and habitats.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002B; or the equivalent.

wfc.name: — Wildlife Habitat Ecology & Conservation
wfc.description: This version has ended; see updated course, below.Course Description: Relationships between habitat characteristics and wildlife behavior/ecology, principles of habitat conservation and management.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EVE 101 or ESP 100; or the equivalent of EVE 101 or ESP 100.

wfc.name: — Habitat Conservation & Restoration Laboratory
wfc.description: Course Description: Analysis of the characteristics of wildlife and fish habitats, application of restoration methods, and evaluation of conservation and restoration projects in the field. Participate during the term in a restoration project.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (EVE 101 or ESP 100); WFC 155 (can be concurrent); or the equivalent of ESP 100 or EVE 101.

wfc.name: — Plant Geography
wfc.description: Course Description: Survey of the geographical distribution of vegetation types and habitats, with consideration of the environmental and historical factors that determine these patterns. Conservation and management approaches. Analytical field and lab techniques introduced.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ESP 100 or EVE 101; PLB 102 or PLB 108 strongly recommended.

wfc.name: — Coastal Ecosystems
wfc.description: Course Description: Overview of coastal ecosystems, physical and biological elements and processes, and coastal zone dynamics, including sandy, rocky and muddy shorelines, estuaries, dunes and coastal watersheds. Discussion of the role of historical factors and conservation, restoration, and management approaches.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EVE 101; course work in organismal biology, physical geography, and geology recommended.

wfc.name: — Infectious Disease in Ecology & Conservation
wfc.description: Course Description: Introduction to the dynamics and control of infectious disease in wildlife, including zoonotic diseases and those threatening endangered species. Basic epidemiological models and their applications. Role of scientists in developing disease control policies.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): EVE 101 or ESP 100 or VET 409; or the equivalent.

wfc.name: — Animal Coloration
wfc.description: Course Description: Evolutionary and ecological significance of coloration in mammals, birds, reptiles, amphibians, fish, cephalopods, crustaceans, spiders, insects, humans as well as color in fashion, plants and the military. Topics include history, protective coloration, warning coloration, mimicry, sexual dichromatism and color change.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002A; BIS 002B; BIS 002C.

wfc.name: — Climate Change Ecology
wfc.description: Course Description: Ecological responses to current and expected future climate change, across levels of biological organization from individuals to ecosystems.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): BIS 002B; (EVE 101 or ESP 100); or consent of instructor.

wfc.name: — Departmental Research Seminar
wfc.description: Course Description: Reports and discussions of recent advances related to wildlife and fisheries biology.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing in the Biological Sciences.

wfc.name: — Museum Science
wfc.description: Course Description: Principles and methods required to preserve and present biological specimens for research, teaching collections, and museums.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Upper division standing.

wfc.name: — Internship
wfc.description: Course Description: Work experience off and on campus in all subject areas offered in the department. Internships supervised by a member of the faculty.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Completion of 84 units.

wfc.name: — Field & Laboratory Research
wfc.description: Course Description: Critique and practice of research methods applied to field and/or laboratory environments of wild vertebrates. Work independently or in small groups to design experimental protocol, analyze data, and report their findings.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (WFC 110L or WFC 111L or WFC 120L); (WFC 121 or WFC 130); EVE 101; or the equivalent of EVE 101, and consent of instructor.

wfc.name: — Tutoring in Wildlife & Fisheries
wfc.description: Course Description: Experience in teaching under guidance of faculty member.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Major in Wildlife, Fish, and Conservation Biology.

wfc.name: — Directed Group Study
wfc.description: Course Description: Directed group study.

wfc.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
wfc.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.

wfc.name: — Conservation Biology & Animal Behavior
wfc.description: Course Description: Influences of concepts of animal behavior (functional, evolutionary, developmental, mechanistic, and methodological issues) on conservation biology theory and practice.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): ECL 208 or ANB 221; and consent of instructor.

wfc.name: — Advanced Physiological Ecology of Wildlife
wfc.description: Course Description: Advanced principles of physiological ecology. Ecological, evolutionary and behavioral perspectives on physiological mechanisms used by animals to adapt to their environment in the context of climate change and other threats to biodiversity. Primary literature will form the basis of discussion.

wfc.name: — Advanced Population Dynamics
wfc.description: Course Description: Logical basis for population models, evaluation of simple ecological models, current population models with age, size, and stage structure, theoretical basis for management and exemplary case histories. Emphasis on development and use of realistic population models in ecological research.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing; advanced course in ecology (e.g., EVE 101), population dynamics (e.g., WFC 122), and one year of calculus; familiarity with matrix algebra and partial differential equations recommended.

wfc.name: — Seminar
wfc.description: Course Description: Seminar devoted to a highly specific research topic in any area of wildlife or fisheries biology. Special topic selected for a quarter will vary depending on interests of instructor and students.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

wfc.name: — Research Group Conference
wfc.description: Course Description: Weekly conference on research problems, progress and techniques in wildlife and fishery sciences.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

wfc.name: — Seminar in Aquatic Ecology
wfc.description: Course Description: Presentation and analysis of assigned topics in aquatic ecology emphasizing fish, fisheries and aquatic conservation.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Biology.

wfc.name: — Physiology of Fishes Seminar
wfc.description: Course Description: Seminar devoted to current topics concerning the physiological functioning of fishes.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Graduate standing and at least two courses in physiology.

wfc.name: — Seminar in Behavioral Ecology of Predators & Prey
wfc.description: Course Description: Presentation and analysis of research papers on social and foraging behavior of predatory animals, antipredator strategies of prey species, co-evolution of predators and prey, and ecology of predator prey interactions.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.

wfc.name: — Seminar in Wildlife Ecotoxicology
wfc.description: Course Description: Presentation and analysis of assigned and searched research papers on transport, exposure, and effects of environmental contaminants on wildlife-associated ecosystem components, especially at individual/population levels. Specific subjects vary each offering.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing in Biology.

wfc.name: — Supervised Teaching in Wildlife & Fisheries Biology
wfc.description: Course Description: Tutoring and teaching students in undergraduate courses in Wildlife, Fish, & Conservation Biology. Weekly conferences with instructor; evaluations of teaching; preparing for and conducting demonstrations, laboratories, and discussions; preparing and grading examinations.
wfc.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Meet qualifications for teaching assistant; graduate standing.

wfc.name: — Group Study
wfc.description: Course Description: Group study.

wfc.name: — Research
wfc.description: Course Description: Research.

wms.name: — Cultural Representations of Gender
wms.description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary investigation of how specific cultures represent gender difference. Examine a variety of cultural forms and phenomena including film, television, literature, music, popular movements, and institutions.

wms.name: — Gender & Global Cinema
wms.description: Course Description: Role gender plays in film history/culture in various geographical contexts and in aspects of contemporary globalization. Films from nations such as China, Colombia, Cuba, Ethiopia, India, Iran, Korea, New Zealand, and the U.S.

wms.name: — Feminist Critiques of Western Thought
wms.description: Course Description: Critical introduction to major traditions of social thinking in the West from a feminist perspective.

wms.name: — Theory & History of Sexualities
wms.description: Course Description: Key issues in the social construction, organization, and reproduction of sexualities such as the intersection of sexual identity with gender, race, ethnicity, and class, and the relation between movements for sexual liberation and the regulation of the body.

wms.name: — Lower Division Seminar
wms.description: Course Description: Examination of a special topic in Womens Studies through shared readings, discussions, and written assignments.

wms.name: — Research Seminar in the Transnational Production & Consumption of Fashion
wms.description: Course Description: Preparation for a research conference.

wms.name: — Directed Group Study
wms.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
wms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

wms.name: — Special Study for Undergraduates
wms.description: Course Description: Special study for undergraduates.
wms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

wms.name: — Gender & Post Colonialism
wms.description: Course Description: Explores changing configurations of race, gender, sexuality, class and implications for governmentality in one or more colonial or postcolonial regimes in one or more societies.

wms.name: — Feminist Research
wms.description: Course Description: Introduction to feminist applications and transformations of traditional disciplinary research practices; initial training in methodologies for feminist interdisciplinary work.
wms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Required for Women's Studies major.

wms.name: — Globalization & Politics of Family Change
wms.description: Course Description: Political/cultural changes, conflicts, and economic disparities that have led to greater mobility and dispersal of families. Transnationalism on gender relations, sexualities, and the meaning of family.

wms.name: — Critical Food Studies
wms.description: Course Description: Production and consumption of food at the intersections of gender, race, ethnicity, nation, and body. Individual and familial experiences as part of larger economic and political structures in the U.S. and globally.

wms.name: — Contemporary Debates in Western Feminist Theory
wms.description: Course Description: Interpretations of poststructuralist, postmodern, and postcolonial thought from a critical feminist perspective; includes methods of applying theory to concrete social/cultural problems of gender, race, sexuality, class.
wms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): WMS 060; or consent of instructor.

wms.name: — Critical Fashion Studies
wms.description: Course Description: Feminist cultural studies of style-fashion-dress through transnational circuits, personal subjectivities. Fashion as means of gender oppression and liberation. Histories and discourses of  masculinities and femininities. Clothing works on global assembly line. Use of dress in construction/regulation of identities.

wms.name: — Feminist Cultural Studies
wms.description: Course Description: Histories, theories, and practices of feminist traditions within Cultural Studies.

wms.name: — Gender & Law
wms.description: Course Description: Exploration of womens legal rights in historical and contemporary context, discussing a variety of legal issues and applicable feminist theories. Topics include constitutional equal protection, discrimination in employment and education, sexual orientation discrimination, and the regulation of abortion.

wms.name: — Women's Movements in Transnational Perspective
wms.description: Course Description: Transnational perspectives on 20th- and 21st-century women’s movements in Western, colonial and post-colonial contexts, examining movement’s forms and political orientations and relationships between women’s movements and other forces for change.
wms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): WMS 050 recommended.

wms.name: — Gender, War & Peace
wms.description: Course Description: Applies a critical gender perspective to militarism as manifest in contexts of military rule, war, conflict, peacebuilding and security post-conflict. Addresses the changing configurations of gender and sexuality in military institutions and militarized economies and cultures from an interdisciplinary perspective.
wms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

wms.name: — Science, Gender, & Social Justice
wms.description: Course Description: Critical reading and reflection on the history of Western science, scientific institutions and the changing role of science in relation to inequalities of class, race, gender and sexuality, and global struggles for equality and justice.

wms.name: — Masculinities
wms.description: Course Description: Cultural, economic, and political forces which shape historical and contemporary masculinities. Impact of race, class, ability, nation and sexuality on experiences and cultural representations of masculinity.

wms.name: — Women, "Race" & Sexuality in Postcolonial Cinema
wms.description: Course Description: Feminist analysis of race, sexuality and class in the representation of women in commercial and/or independent films.

wms.name: — Feminist Film Theory & Criticism
wms.description: Course Description: Historical overview of and contemporary issues in feminist film theory, including representation, spectatorship, and cultural production. Film stars, women filmmakers, and the intersections of gender, race, sexuality, and class in films and their audiences.

wms.name: — Topics in Gender & Cinematic Representation
wms.description: Course Description: Examination of a specific topic within the broad rubric of gender and cinema. Possible topics include Latinas in Hollywood; gender, nation, cinema; and gender and film genre. Topics vary.

wms.name: — Feminist Media Production
wms.description: Course Description: Media production as a mode of cultural criticism, furthering feminist/ social justice activist goals. Fundamentals of camera, editing and distribution via a social engagement model. Study and hands-on response to key historic and contemporary feminist and social justice media discourses.
wms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): (CTS 020 or CDM 020); or two WMS courses.

wms.name: — Queer Studies
wms.description: Course Description: Study of queer sexualities, identities, theories, practices. Alternative sexualities as historical, social, and cultural constructions in intersections with race, gender, class, nationality. Interdisciplinary exploration of sexual liberation and the regulation of sexuality through history, theory and expressive cultural forms.
wms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): WMS 070 recommended or consent of instructor.

wms.name: — Body Politics
wms.description: Course Description: The body as a site where status inequalities are formed and resisted. Self-making through bodywork, history of gendered and racial meanings of the body, and analysis of normalizing discourses and practices.

wms.name: — Gender & Experience of Race
wms.description: Course Description: Exploration of the co-construction of “race” and gender in comparative national historical contexts and contemporary lived experience. Study of intersections of race and gender in identities and how institutions, labor migration, social movements and consumption shape racialized gendered identities.

wms.name: — Autobiography, Narrative, Memoir
wms.description: Course Description: Life narrative writings by women. Transgressive voices exploring issues of race, class, and sexuality, women's silence and marginalization. Theories of autobiography, autoethnography and memoir included.
wms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

wms.name: — Women Writers & the Transnational Imaginary: The Arab World
wms.description: Course Description: Writings by women from diverse regions and cultures, understood in their cultural, socio-economic, and historical contexts, with each course offering a focus on women’s writing in specific geographic/national locations and their diasporas: The Arab World.
wms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor.

wms.name: — Women Writers & the Transnational Imaginary: Asia
wms.description: Course Description: Writings by women from diverse regions and cultures, understood in their cultural, socio-economic, and historical contexts, with each course offering a focus on women’s writing in specific geographic/national locations and their diasporas: Asia.

wms.name: — Women Writers & the Transnational Imaginary: The Caribbean
wms.description: Course Description: Writings by women from diverse regions and cultures, understood in their cultural, socio-economic, and historical contexts, with each course offering a focus on women’s writing in specific geographic/national locations and their diasporas: The Caribbean.

wms.name: — Women Writers & the Transnational Imaginary: Africa
wms.description: Course Description: Writings by women from diverse regions and cultures, understood in their cultural, socio-economic, and historical contexts, with each course offering a focus on women’s writing in specific geographic/national locations and their diasporas: Africa.

wms.name: — Women Writers & the Transnational Imaginary: Diasporic Women Writers in Europe
wms.description: Course Description: Writings by women from diverse regions and cultures, understood in their cultural, socio-economic, and historical contexts, with each course offering a focus on women’s writing in specific geographic/national locations and their diasporas: Diasporic Women Writers in Europe.

wms.name: — Transnationalism & Writing by Women of Color
wms.description: Course Description: Writings by women of color in a transnational framework, understood in their cultural, socio-economic, and historical contexts. The interrelation among gender, writing, nationalism, and transnationalism with focus on women's writing in specific geographic/national locations and their diasporas: Topics on Women Writers of Color.

wms.name: — Literature as Aesthetics of Resistance
wms.description: Course Description: Literature by women and other marginal groups which embody dissent and subversion as a means of challenging the status quo and to affect social transformation.

wms.name: — Women of Color Writing in the United States
wms.description: Course Description: Literature, especially novels, written by contemporary women of color in the United States, understood in their socio-economic, cultural and historical contexts.

wms.name: — Globalization, Gender & Culture
wms.description: Course Description: Critical gender analysis of globalization as a process of interconnected cultural, social and economic transformations inflected by gender, nation, class and race/ethnicity. Critical self-reflection and social observation skills.

wms.name: — Gender in the Arab World
wms.description: Course Description: Examination of the history, culture, and social/political/economic dynamics of gender relations and gendering in the Arab world.

wms.name: — Women & Islamic Discourses
wms.description: Course Description: Introduction to debate/discourses about women and Islam. Transformations in debate/discourses in colonial and postcolonial periods in the Middle East & South Asia. Comparative study of debate/discourses on family, work, law, sexuality, religion, comportment, human rights, feminist and religious movements.
wms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): WMS 050; or comparable course.

wms.name: — Gender & Public Policy
wms.description: Course Description: Role of gender in the creation of social policies, especially with respect to issues brought into the policy arena by contemporary feminism.

wms.name: — Special Topics in Critical Gender Studies
wms.description: Course Description: In-depth examination of a women's studies topic related to the research interests of the instructor.

wms.name: — Senior Seminar
wms.description: Course Description: Capstone course for senior Womens Studies majors, which focuses on current issues on feminism as they impact theory, public policy, and practice.

wms.name: — Capstone Seminar
wms.description: Course Description: Revision, completion, and presentation of senior research or creative project. Creating a multimedia website for publishing research and creative projects.

wms.name: — Internship in Women's Studies
wms.description: Course Description: Supervised internship and study in positions/institutional settings dealing with gender-related problems or issues, as for example, a women's center, affirmative action office, advertising agency, or social welfare agency. Final written report on internship experience.
wms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Completion of a minimum of 84 units and consent of instructor; enrollment dependent on availability of intern positions with priority to Women's Studies majors.

wms.name: — Feminist Leadership Seminar
wms.description: Course Description: Use feminist methods to critically reflect on the ethical, methodological and strategic aspects of an organization, project, campaign, movement or other social change initiative.

wms.name: — Senior Honors Project in Women's Studies
wms.description: Course Description: In consultation with an advisor, students complete a substantial research paper or significant creative project on a Womens Studies topic.
wms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Senior standing, Women's Studies major, and advisor's approval.

wms.name: — Senior Honors Project in Women's Studies
wms.description: Course Description: In consultation with an advisor, students complete a substantial research paper or significant creative project on a Women's Studies topic.
wms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Senior standing, Women's Studies major, and advisor's approval.

wms.name: — Thematic Seminar in Critical Gender & Women's Studies
wms.description: Course Description: Group study of a topic, issue or area in feminist theory and research involving intensive reading and writing.

wms.name: — Tutoring in Women's Studies
wms.description: Course Description: Leading small, voluntary discussion groups affiliated with a Womens Studies course.
wms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Upper division standing and consent of director.

wms.name: — Directed Group Study
wms.description: Course Description: Directed group study.
wms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Upper division standing.

wms.name: — Special Study for Advanced Undergraduates
wms.description: Course Description: Special study for advanced undergraduates.
wms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Consent of instructor. Upper division standing.

wms.name: — Current Issues in Feminist Theory
wms.description: Course Description: Current issues in feminist theory; techniques employed to build feminist theory in various fields.

wms.name: — Problems in Feminist Research
wms.description: Course Description: Application of feminist theoretical perspectives to the interdisciplinary investigation of a problem or question chosen by the instructor(s).
wms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): WMS 200A B+ or better.

wms.name: — Special Topics in Feminist Theory & Research
wms.description: Course Description: Explores in depth a topic in feminist theory and research related to the research interests of the instructor.

wms.name: — Cultural Study of Masculinities
wms.description: Course Description: Interdisciplinary approaches to understanding the social and cultural construction of masculinities; attention to the effects of biology, gender, race, class, sexual and national identities; criticism of oral, printed, visual, and mass mediated texts, and of social relations and structures.
wms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing or consent of instructor.

wms.name: — Special Study for Graduate Students
wms.description: Course Description: Special study for graduate students.

wms.name: — Dissertation Research & Writing
wms.description: Course Description: Dissertation research & writing.
wms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): WMS 200A; WMS 200B; fulfillment of course requirements for the DE in Feminist Theory and Research; advancement to candidacy.

wms.name: — Teaching Assistant Training Practicum
wms.description: Course Description: Teaching assistant training practicum.
wms.prerequisites: Prerequisite(s): Graduate standing.
